name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Julie Girling, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants (COM (2013) 0920 - C7-0004/2014 - 2013/0443 (COD)) (A8-0249/2015).

name: Julie GIRLING
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am pleased to take this opportunity to address you on the National Emission Ceilings (NEC) Directive ahead of our final plenary vote this afternoon here in Strasbourg. This proposal represents three years of work for me personally and even longer for many others in the Commission and beyond. I would like to thank the political Group shadow rapporteurs for their close cooperation throughout the work on the proposal, the Commission team for their technical knowledge and irrepressible optimism and the Dutch Presidency for the good spirit in which these difficult negotiations were conducted. On the last day of the Dutch Presidency, 30 June 2016, we reached an agreement on this challenging legislative proposal after five months of tough trilogues and many technical drafting meetings. The political backdrop has changed dramatically over the past three years, with the issue of air quality moving up the public agenda in an unprecedented way, culminating in the VW scandal and the focus on the issue of real-driving emissions. Perhaps there is also a recognition that we have spent the past decade or more concentrating so much on CO2 that we have neglected air quality. We have known for some time that Europe needs to take action to clean up its air, and I believe strongly that this vote is a step in the right direction. It is not a perfect solution but it will go a long way to making important health improvements for our citizens. Air pollution is the number one environmental cause of death in the EU. More than 400 000 of our citizens die prematurely each year and millions more suffer debilitating illness requiring medication and hospitalisation. This has an enormous human and economic cost, with tens of billions of euros in days lost at work and even more spent on healthcare bills, particularly in a country like my own where healthcare costs are met directly through our national system. Air pollution also hits the natural environment through eutrophication and acid deposition. So in December 2013 the Commission published its clean air package the central plank of which was the NEC Directive and the setting of emissions reduction targets in all the Member States for 2030. This proposal has had a difficult passage through the legislative process. We had the European elections shortly after it was published, a new Commission taking office and a real fight from this House to keep the directive on the table after a suggestion that it might be withdrawn from the work programme. More recently, we have had to contend with the UK referendum on EU membership and securing a deal in the difficult days – for me at least – after the vote to leave. I still feel strongly, as your rapporteur, that this is a key issue which is best tackled at EU level. Simply put, air pollution does not stop at Member State borders. I strongly believe that better regulation and good air quality are not mutually exclusive and that is why I fought so hard to keep this proposal alive and get it onto the books. There will be some people here who will say that the deal is not ambitious enough and that we should have fought longer and harder for even higher targets. The fact is, however, that this is a negotiation. Each side has its positions and, whilst there is always room for improvement, we have to be cognisant of the political reality and not allow perfection to become the enemy of good. Parliament’s starting position on Annex II was in line with the Commission’s impact—assessed proposal, which estimated the emission reduction commitments would result in a 52% health improvement, whereas the Council’s figures, set out as part of a general approach, would have resulted in a 48% reduction in premature mortality. In the final, hard-fought agreement the overall level of ambition on Annex II takes us to just under 50%. Concerning the targets for 2025, the final compromise specifies that Member States may follow a non-linear trajectory if that is economically or technically more efficient, provided that, as from 2025, it converges progressively with the linear trajectory and does not affect any reduction commitment for 2030. In addition, Member States would have to explain the reasons for any deviation from the linear trajectory, as well as the measures necessary to return to it. On flexibility provisions, Parliament accepted that Member States should be granted some flexibility in achieving the 2030 targets but tightened the wording proposed by the Council to ensure that the provisions were not open to abuse. Parliament accepted that methane be excluded from the scope of the legislation on condition that the Commission confirmed, in accordance with its right of initiative, that it would carry out a review with regard to methane even if it was not specifically in the directive. This issue should never be about playing to the gallery: it should be about real action for our citizens. As the rapporteur, I am fully supportive of this final text and consider it to be an ambitious, fair and workable agreement for reducing the number of premature deaths attributable to air pollution. It is not a perfect agreement but, as a Brit working in Brussels, I am not sure there is any such thing, ever. Compromise is key to any negotiation and any final agreement. Indeed, having a seat at the table and being able to influence the discussions is a precious thing. So I urge you all to vote in favour of this deal today. (Applause)

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Girling, and her team for their tireless efforts throughout the process, as well as the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation on this important issue. The result is a major achievement on the biggest environment and health problem facing Europe. It will reduce the health impacts of air pollution, respiratory diseases and premature death by close to 50% by 2030. Citizens across the whole European Union will benefit enormously and these are results that we collectively can be very proud of. It will also pave the way for ratification of the revised Gothenburg Protocol and for pollution reduction in the Eastern European Caucasus and Central Asian States. It is important not only for the population of all those countries but also in terms of reducing trans-boundary pollution in the European Union. In any negotiation there are compromises to be made, and discussions on the key points were long and hard, but the final position is an honourable outcome which is ambitious, fair and practical. The level of ambition is high, the flexibilities are limited and their use must be justified, and there must be steady progress towards the 2030 commitments, to ensure full and timely implementation, as well as providing legal certainty to investors in green technology.  All Member States and sectors will need to play their part in the implementation of the directive. It is understandable that where pollution, and therefore health impacts, are highest more effort is needed. We must maximise the use of European Union support as well as synergies with other policies such as those on agriculture, energy and climate. Cost-effective implementation will deliver not only better health but also the economic benefits of cleaner air, such as lower health costs and less absenteeism at work. The Commission regrets the deletion of methane from the scope of the directive, and we have made clear in our statement that we will continue to monitor these emissions and their effect on ambient air quality and we will take action as appropriate. On ammonia, we regret that the reduction is less than we had initially proposed on the basis of scientific analysis in our impact assessment. Lastly, we also regret that the co-legislator has departed from the letter and the spirit of the regulation governing the adoption of implementing acts. We have made our concerns clear in a further statement. However, this will not distract attention from the fact that the agreement before us is a major achievement by the three EU institutions working together for the benefit of the public, which I hope you will endorse today. This would enable us to turn our attention to implementation, with the health and wellbeing of our citizens always in mind. I trust that we can rely on your support.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — Clean, unpoisoned air, ecological innovation, natural capital protection and new ecological technologies are our objective, but extending restrictions on non-poisonous gases and limiting methane emissions, for example, can disrupt the functioning of the agricultural sector. Restrictions in this sector should apply only to highly poisonous hydrogen sulfide and ammonia, and in areas with compact development. Poisons emitted into the atmosphere work locally, and averaging them by incorporating overseas territories, so-called flexibility in accruing, is an evident scam. It becomes vital to update the limits of nitrogen oxides emitted by diesel engines. Unfortunately, this project does not take into account the emission of particles much less than two and a half micrometers in size, does not take into account dioxins and, unfortunately, completely omits the dangerous low level emission occurring during the heating season.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. — (NL) First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Julie Girling for her hard work and dedication to this difficult dossier. As rapporteur for the Committee on Agriculture, I am pleased that methane has been left out of the agreement. By doing so, we have prevented double laws and regulations. Methane is a greenhouse gas and is already regulated through climate targets. In addition, the agricultural sector maintains the flexibility to decide for itself how it will reduce the emissions of various greenhouse gases. I want to prevent farmers from having to keep the cows in their homes to catch methane that emits cows. That's exactly what society doesn't want. In addition, we must also take account of the organic sector. Organically kept animals emit more methane on average because they receive a different compound ration. On the other hand, it is precisely the organic sector and the common sector that can make a major contribution to reducing greenhouse gases in the air by binding CO2 in the soil through organic substances.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. Many thanks to the rapporteur, Julie Girling, and the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation. We welcome the agreement reached with the Council on 30 June 2016 under the Dutch Presidency. This will speed up the improvement of air quality in Europe, which will also provide the sectors concerned with the necessary planning and investment security. The five main points in detail: firstly, the health target: we are achieving a nearly 50% improvement in health by significantly reducing five air pollutants: sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia, volatile organic compounds and particulate matter. Secondly — and Mr Huitema has just rightly pointed this out: methane has been excluded from the scope of the directive. A legitimate concern of colleagues from the Committee on Agriculture has been taken into account. Thirdly, the national emission reduction targets for ammonia have been set at a realistic level, i.e. at an achievable level. That was definitely a good negotiation result. Fourthly, the reduction targets for mercury have not been included here. An equally legitimate concern of colleagues from the Committee on Industry has been taken into account here. We have remained true to the principle of 'no regulation without impact assessment'. We should remain true to this principle in the future. Then we really do better laws and not just say this. Fifthly and lastly, the targets for 2025. Member States will be able to follow a nonlinear path if this is more efficient for them. The key factor is not the achievement of intermediate targets, but the principle of cost-efficiency. Conclusion: Overall, we achieved a good negotiation result. We can get a better air for Europe faster. This is good for the people, this is good for the people Health of the people of Europe. In this respect, we, as the European People's Party, can approve this compromise with conviction.

name: Seb DANCE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I like to extend my thanks to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation on this very important file. It is important to recognise that, at the beginning of the mandate of this Parliament, the issue of air equality was not perhaps quite uppermost in people’s thoughts. It has taken a scandal or two to get us to this situation, most notably, of course, the ‘Dieselgate’ scandal involving VW. This is an issue that affects so many of our citizens: 400 000 across the EU are dying prematurely, and in my city – the EU’s biggest city, London – 10 000 people are dying every single year from the effects of poor air. 90% of our citizens who live in cities are exposed to dangerously high levels of air pollution. We could be proud of this place and the coordinated action that has taken place at a European level. Throughout the process, it was the European institutions that led the way in terms of ambition. The high initial ambition shown by the Environment Committee is testament to the individual ambitions of the Members who supported the highest targets, and this place can be proud of consistently holding a higher line than that shown by the Member States. Ultimately we had to compromise, but it was the national governments who had consistently shown the least resolve. At every stage this Parliament, representing 500 million citizens across the European Union, was backed not just by NGOs, scientists and public health campaigns, but also by cities from Berlin to Barcelona, London to Lisbon, Paris to Prague, to Dublin to Dubrovnik, Amsterdam to Aarhus. City mayors have shown us that they want this action to be taken at European level. We now have this deal on the table with Member States; it is not perfect, and it will not eliminate the problem, but it is significant progress and it does show what can be achieved by scaling up overriding competing regional and national interests and acting in the common good. Our task is now to hold governments to account on delivering these targets. We must challenge the old tired but re-emerging competition between industry and the idea that industry and clean air cannot go hand in hand. We must consistently put pressure to target resources into innovation and the development of new technology, and we must never surrender to the divisive rhetoric from those who want to see a race to the bottom between us on environmental standards. It has perhaps become fashionable in my country to pretend we can insulate ourselves from difficult decisions, to pretend that we can deal with these issues on our own. We cannot. We breathe the same air. I have no idea what Brexit will end up doing to my city and my country, but I do know that the best environmental protections we have have come from this place. If we are to continue to work and to trade with our nearest neighbours in the world’s biggest market, we have to abide by its rules. I do not expect them to, but if my government decides to use environmental standards as a bargaining chip, I expect and urge all of us here to stand firm. Let us continue in this place to show the highest resolve.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! Madam Rapporteur! Clean air is a goal that we should all be aiming for, but too ambitious targets will, among other things, increase low emissions and hit agriculture very hard. The agreement concluded between the institutions on the reduction of certain pollutants is critically evaluated for three reasons. First, Ladies, for methodological reasons. The whole negotiation was based on a questionable methodology that converted pollution reduction into a percentage of determined health improvements — as if health improvements depended only and solely on that sole source. Secondly, I also assess them critically for procedural reasons, because Parliament has made it a point of honour to achieve a specific level of health protection. In order to satisfy Parliament, the Dutch Presidency has imposed on three countries — Poland, Romania and Hungary — commitments that are not really able to meet. And the third reason — it's decency. The European Commission has made it clear that the cost of reductions in the Netherlands is several times lower than in Poland, for example. So how does this come to decency? If, therefore, the Dutch Presidency wants to satisfy Parliament, it could do so in its example. It would be cheaper and decent.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, air pollution is serious. Doctors and scientists are giving us the evidence and warning European governments of the disastrous effects on us all. It is high time that clean air is seen as an essential human right, as is clean drinking water and enough food for all. Air pollution causes 400 000 premature deaths every year in Europe. Dirty air is particularly damaging to unborn babies. While I am pleased that EU governments have agreed to halve the number of early deaths in Europe from air pollution by 2030, it is clear that we must all work to achieve this – industry, farming, governments and everyone else.  These negotiations were tough, and it has been good to work cross-party. I thank all of us who were working on that. Thankfully, we had Julie Girling, who was that tough negotiator that we really needed, but many Member States were reluctant to agree to the targets and may drag their feet. Just look at my own government in the UK. They know that London is failing on air quality, yet they plough on with expanding Heathrow Airport. Air pollution around the airport is already dangerously above legal levels of nitrogen dioxide, and this will make it worse. For the Conservative Government, air pollution is a trade-off. Chasing economic growth is more important than actually protecting the public’s health, or perhaps they think that outside the EU we will not be affected by air at all. That is not acceptable, and as a Liberal Democrat I will continue to fight against the Heathrow expansion and for good quality care for all European citizens.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Let me first of all thank the rapporteur Julia Girling and the other shadow rapporteurs. I think it was not always a simple job, and I think it was a rather time-consuming job, and yet I dare say that, above all, the rapporteur, as our head, managed and mastered it her well. However, remembering in retrospect how the whole negotiations for this directive took place, I am kind of sad, because I also consider them a missed chance. The final text is a mere shadow of the originally approved ambitious wording. The conclusion of the negotiation was negatively affected by two things. First and foremost with the panic fear of the forthcoming Presidency of the Council, and second, sorry Julie, a Brexit that at the time had just a few days since its shocking birth. We panicked unnecessarily in this atmosphere and what's about the final result is knowing that. The biggest problem I see is that the original text, as amended before the trialogues, contained a legally binding commitment to reduce the health burden caused by people by air pollution by 52% compared to a year ago 2005. However, at the same time, the text voted agrees with the Council's proposed value of 49,6%, while the red line was 50%. Behind these abstract numbers, however, lie concrete foiled extra human lives, which could have been prevented. And I am not even commenting on the other huge concessions we have served to the Council on a silver tray. That's why it's very hard for me to identify with this document in any way. However, I would like to end my speech at least a little positive. Any air improvement is the way forward and will help people's health, even in situations where it may have been greater. While I see the value as a great disappointment, ultimately that number may mean cleaner air than our citizens breathe now, and that is certainly, albeit small, positive.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Girling, for her very good work on striking this deal. Indeed, as a previous colleague said, it was a very interesting and tough negotiation path, but I do think that in the end Ms Girling was very helpful in trying to strike a deal. However, if you assess the deal we can only be disappointed. Just look at the demands that we had as a Parliament. We wanted higher ambition. We had to give in substantially. We did not want any flexibilities on top of that. The Council and the Member States were asking for more and more flexibilities. We do not have a 2025 target, so it is now only talking about 2030, which is very, very far down the road. Methane is out, so the agriculture sector is off the hook again for cleaning our air. All these things together can only lead to one conclusion and that is that this package is not good enough. And I think I have to turn now to the Council – to the Dutch Presidency maybe in particular – who did good work in striking this deal. But if you turn to all the Member States, I really have a question. We are discussing air pollution. If there is one thing that is clearly a European competence and that is really cross-border, it is air pollution. If we do something about it, it will lead to jobs, cleaner technologies, cleaner air, better improvements for our citizens, lower costs for health. All these things we can achieve. What we saw at the Member State level was just a purely nationalistic approach; what can I do? I shall pay no mind to my neighbouring countries and only do what I can deliver. That approach really caused the deterioration of this deal, and it is a shame. I ask the Member States to keep in mind that if you want to fight for Europe, you have to fight for European solidarity on these kind of issues. Otherwise, we are giving away this project, and that is the worst thing we could do.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that 92% of the world's population today live in places where air quality levels do not meet the limits set from the World Health Organization. Every year in Europe 490 000 people die due to smog or pollution in general in our cities. That equates to an eighth of the total deaths on our territory. Yet, incredibly, in the new text on national emissions limits, reduction targets have been weakened, thus giving up saving 10 000 people each year. You also have to explain why you excluded methane from the pollutant gas list, despite it being a greenhouse gas 21 times more environmentally damaging than CO2. This change of direction of large groups goes against the fundamental right to health of European citizens, while defending the usual oilmen, incinerator lobbies, as well as the agricultural sector. It is often heard by the large groups in this chamber that we are Eurosceptic and populist, but it is precisely these actions that are crumbling the European Union, which today more than ever is rejected by the citizens Europeans. It is precisely these actions that the people loathe.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of Directive 2001/81/EC addresses an environmental and public health priority. However, the environmental issue cannot become a lead screed for states and economic actors. In this regard, I regret the rapporteur's proposal to strengthen the Commission's control over national programmes and to remove the mechanism for deducting emissions from the international maritime sector. Furthermore, I strongly oppose the inclusion of ammonia and methane in the scope of a new directive. In particular, I do not accept methane being covered by the new directive, even though it would only be included from 2030 onwards. This would penalise the agricultural sector, even though other European texts already deal with this gas in a specific way. According to the rapporteur, this issue should also be dealt with under the common agricultural policy. The opening up of new administrative remedies to citizens seems to serve a commendable purpose of informing the public. This is actually another breach in the sovereignty of States, some of which, like France, already have an important arsenal of possibilities for administrative and judicial remedies open to citizens. For all these reasons, and in particular because I believe that air pollution abatement programmes should remain within the purview of the Member States, I cannot support Mrs Girling's report, whom I also thank for her quality work.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr. President! Air pollution is the main cause of the damage to our ecosystem and, as we have heard from the rapporteur, it is responsible for the premature deaths of four hundred thousand people in Europe. This is a cross-border issue, so regulation at EU level is understandable. The current amendment sets national emission limit values for each pollutant by 2020 and '30. This is correct, but one requirement cannot be fully met, so that these values are realistic and that no sector should be hit more strongly. It is not by chance that the situation of agriculture, livestock husbandry and the strict limits on ammonia emissions have been said several times. It should have been taken into account that this sector has already achieved a 30% reduction since '90. By the way, Hungary is facing the highest requirement. Agriculture must reduce ammonia emissions by 32% by 2030. We must also look at this in the light of where we are with one of the most dangerous emitters, the pollution caused by the car. It seems that the automotive industry is going to achieve that it will not have to meet the requirement that has been known eight years ago, and, of course, its partner, the European Commission, is cooperating with it. This is unacceptable!

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to thank Julie Girling as rapporteur and all the others who have helped, especially the shadow rapporteur for the European People's Party, Jens Gieseke. I believe that we have achieved a good result and we should vote for it by a large majority. As a result, we improve air quality. The pollutants involved are causing, among other things, lung cancer, heart disease, and in major European cities — including in Brussels, where we spend a large part of our lives — life expectancy is significantly reduced by the fact that we have such high air pollution. Therefore, these pollutants have to be down What is now on the table is also feasible for industry. As the EPP, we did not agree to the very strict values in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, but then the Commission proposal in plenary. Unfortunately, the Council softened him a little. But this is definitely doable now. I would like to say one more sentence on ammonia. This is a pollutant that does not come primarily from industry, but above all from agriculture, for example when spauting manure. If we manage to deliver manure more specifically — through new technology — if you do better than before, we can bring down ammonia emissions and thus protect health and the environment. But it also has another advantage: it just stinks less. I think that is good for the acceptance of agriculture. We have to help farmers, and there have been exaggerated proposals here too. But if it stinks less, then this is good for the acceptance of agriculture, and if the pollutants go down, it is good for the environment and human health. It has to be realistic, we managed to do that. That's why I think we have a good result. We should be by a large majority this afternoon agree.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: — Nixtieq nibda billi nirringrazzja wkoll lil Julie Girling, li naf li ma kellhiex biða xogħol fali, imma anke lix-shadow Rapporteur tan-naħa tagħna, tas-co-cialists in D-democratiði, lil Seb Dance, li naf li ħadem ħafadem ħafadem proprju fuq din il-leġiżlazzjoni. Imma tajjeb insostnu illi, wara D-direttiva Ewropea li qegħdin nitkellmu dwarha llum, hemm regolament li jikkonźerna dritt bażiku ta' kull źittadin Ewropew: id-dritt li tieħu nifs minn arja nadifa! Dritt, li sfortunatament ilna niħduh for granted għal żmien twil wisq issa. It-tniġġis tal-arja, kif diġà smajna, la jaf b'distanza in lanqas jaf bi fruntieri nazzjonali jew fruntieri Ewropej. Hawnhekk għandna issue b'konsegwenzi diretti ta' saħa in konsegwenzi ambjentali għaċ-ittadini kollha tal-unjoni Ewropea. Għaldaqstant iva, hemm bżonn ta' azzjoni immedjata. U filwaqt li huwa pożittiv li t-tniġġġis tal-arja qed jingħata aktar prominenza fuq l-aġenda politika, anke minħabba l-implikazzjonijiet serji fuq is-saħħa pubblika, sfortunatament għad għandna ħafna Stati Membri li xorta mhumika, sfortunatament għad għandna ħafna Stati Membri li xorta mhumimika ex qegħdin jilħqu l-istandards miftiehma. Neħtieġu aktar ambizzjoni biex nindirizzaw l-isfidi preżenti imma, minkejja dan, il-kunsill jidher li m'għandux l-ambizzjoni meħtieġa. Ngħid li neħtieġu gvernijiet Ewropej li jaġixxu u jintroduċu limiti fuq l-emissjonijiet biex ir-riżultati jkunu immedjati in reali. Qed nitkellmu fuq is-saħa tað-ðittadini tagħna. Għalhekk li l-gvernijiet għandhom jaħdmu aktar. Konformità sħiħa hija mistennija mill-istati Membri kollha. Inoltre, l-ibliet in anke l-lokalitajiet l-aktar esposti għal tniġġġis tal-arja għandhom iżidu l-isforzi tagħhom biex jikkontrollaw b'mod effettiv dawn il-problems in jibqgħu conforma mal-miri tal-emissjonijiet tal-ununjoni Ewropewrope-unjoni A. Li niftiehmu dwar l-objettivi sal-2030 huwa l-ewwel pass. Imma hemm bżonn inkomplu naħdmu biex nilħqu l-għanijiet fit-tul. In dan huwa importanti issa aktar minn qatt qabel. L-industry in s-setturi economikollha għandhom isegwu triq aktar sostenibbli. Wara kollox, huma biss l-ambizzjoni fit-tul in miri ta' tnaqqis fl-emissjonijiet għal tul ta' żmien li jistgħu jassiguraw li d-dritt tagħna għal arja nadifa jkun protett u salvagwardjat sew għalina in anke gall-ħenedien razzjonijiet tal-futur.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Poor air quality causes an estimated 400 000 people to die prematurely in the European Union. That is unacceptable. The new standards we are voting on today should lead to a halving of this number, and it is indeed our responsibility to protect EU citizens from health risks. They expect that from us. According to the Eurobarometer, there is a large majority of Europeans, 79%, who want the European Union to take action in this respect. Joint European agreements are needed to tackle the deadly problem of air pollution structurally. Indeed, air pollution knows no boundaries. This applies primarily to densely populated and industrialised regions such as my own country, such as Flanders with Dutch, German and French industrial centres nearby. About 45% of air pollution in my country comes from our neighbours. So it's taking responsibility together or choking together. And Mr Cañete, Commissioner, of course, you are right, everything can always be better and the level of ambition would have been a little higher for us, but I think Mr Girling has reached the best agreement possible and I will also fully support it. It is essential that the Member States now take effective action on these tightened standards. There is no time to waste, as any improvement in air quality has an immediate positive impact on public health. Again, that's exactly what people expect from us.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Mr President, we as people can do a great deal to improve our own health. We can move more, we can eat healthy, we can decide not to smoke. One thing we cannot do as an individual, and that is to determine which air we breathe. We breathe in the air that is around us, here, we in this plenary room, and when we are in Brussels on the Rue de la Loi or Rue Belliard. And that is why the responsibility of governments is so great. The government is the only one who can determine how clean that air is. Public health is one thing. Economic damage is a second. And I find it incomprehensible that the Member States themselves have taken part in the cost-effective scenario of the European Commission. Mr President, today the European Environment Agency will present the annual air quality report, which shows that one sector is doing far and far too little to improve air quality, and that is the agricultural sector. And let that be the sector that is being kept out of the wind again today. Ammonia targets quickly down and methane even completely deleted. Is dirty air, dirty emissions, is it less harmful when it comes from agriculture? Maybe someone here can explain to me why it should always be treated so special. Mr President, the Member States have really failed. Citizens have the right to clean air, and that is why I will unfortunately have to vote against this agreement.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the right to air quality is a fundamental right, like the right to health. And then I would like to tell you about a very special case that comes from my land, from Apulia, where ninety deaths per year are recorded only by emissions from the Ilva plant in Taranto. Here, I believe that this is one of the cases that shows how the subject we are talking about today is fundamental to the health of citizens and citizens and is the reason why we cannot accept no downward compromise on the air quality node. We would have liked binding interim targets for 2025; unfortunately, I believe that the Council is imposing downward mediation from this point of view. So, the point is that we really need this Parliament to deliver a very, very clear message on the issue of air quality. I believe that the credibility of this House is also playing on these issues.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President! As Greens, we are not entirely satisfied with the compromise, you know. Especially that the protection of health is not accepted by many as the highest good, this annoys us. The Council, in particular, has brought down some downward changes that we cannot accept. It has been said several times: the agricultural sector has basically been almost completely excluded from the reduction targets. I cannot say that the whole agricultural sector is now behind this, as he has always said today. There were also other opinions in the Committee on Agriculture. We have to rely on a different form of agriculture. Mr Huitema, organic is better than mass production, and then we could also achieve the Commission's objectives on this point. What is bad is that exemptions and some flexibility have been created again, which will make implementation more difficult. Implementation is most important now, and then I appeal to the car industry, which has been helping for years as the largest part of air pollution to ensure that we fail to meet the reduction targets that we already have. I find it scandalous that we do not take any tougher action against fraud by the car industry and consider this as a kind of cavalier offence. We must prevent diesel stinkers, for example, from coming to inner cities and endangering air quality there, and thus also the health of people.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, Mr Gerbrandy asked why agriculture gets a pass. Agriculture involves natural processes – urination and defecation. Mr Gerbrandy is guilty of the same processes. I challenge him to reduce them. When I was a boy in London we had a big problem called smog. We got rid of it without the help of the EU and without the help of the Green Party. I look at the problem of ammonia on farms and I am interested to see that small farms are going to get a pass, while larger farms are not. By a strange coincidence the larger farms are in the UK. I also wonder about the inspections and the enforcement of all of this. We will do it in the UK to the letter. I wonder if the same can be true of elsewhere in Europe.  I am also concerned about NMVO compounds. Are we going to export an industry here? Are we simply going to import materials that are being produced with these compounds elsewhere?  Finally, nitrous oxide is produced by leguminous plants, yet the European Commission wants farmers to produce more leguminous plants.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). — Mr President, Europe has taken very important steps in reducing emissions of air pollutants and, more generally, protecting the environment. This report is also in this direction, despite the individual disagreements that we may have. Unfortunately, however, environmental pollution is a global problem that cannot be solved by the European Union alone, while emissions and efforts to reduce them have complications that extend to issues beyond the ecological approach and have to do with the economy, competition of companies and the context in which companies operate. For example, with free trade agreements, companies that remain within the Union, where the many and correct emission restrictions apply, will find themselves facing companies based in China or South-East Asia or even the USA, where regulations are clearly more relaxed and, consequently, production costs are reduced. The result is essentially that companies are forced to migrate, causing social and economic problems in the Union, but also greater environmental pollution overall. We therefore conclude that restrictions on emissions must also be accompanied by a policy of economic protectionism, making imports from countries which do not meet exactly the same legal requirements regarding the emission of pollutants more expensive. Unfortunately, the free trade agreements are going in the exact opposite direction. Finally, the Union must review its relations with third countries and make environmental protection an important factor and a prerequisite for the continuation of these relations.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, let us not be afraid of words, air pollution is a silent mass killer that is very little talked about but is a real massacre. I have long chaired an air quality monitoring network and I am familiar with the subject. In France alone, this pollution is responsible for 48,000 premature deaths per year, or up to two years less life expectancy. In some urban areas, breathing the ambient air is as dangerous as smoking ten cigarettes a day. We are well placed to know that, Brussels is one of the most polluted metropolises in Europe. It is therefore urgent for the European Union to protect its citizens from this scourge of public health. I congratulate Mrs Girling on having achieved this agreement despite the reluctance of the Member States. The ambitious target of reducing mortality from air pollution by around 50% by 2030 should serve as a guide. However, the best is often the enemy of good, and all the goodwill of the world would not have been enough to implement this text if we had stayed on unattainable goals. That is why I am delighted that this agreement includes more realistic, graduated national emission ceilings which leave Member States some flexibility in how to achieve these objectives. The principle of subsidiarity must therefore apply. Finally, I am pleased that methane emissions do not fall within the scope of this directive because this legal framework would not have been the right for methane. It would only have created additional complications for our farmers who really do not need that at this time.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! We can't see nor taste them, but they're in the air. They are dangerous, and there are pollutants. They lead to more than 400,000 premature deaths a year and hundreds of thousands of serious illnesses for our citizens. And so these drugs also harm our environment. But now we're doing something about any of them. We are grabbing some of the most experienced drugs with this air package. And we are making demands on member countries that they should reduce the amount of pollution in the air. It is important for public health and it is important for the environment. The goal is that by 2030 we should have reduced the adverse health effects by 50%. In other words, it should not be 400 000 who die, but a maximum of 200 000 who die prematurely. Is that ambitious enough? No! I would have liked to see that it was even more ambitious. We must have done very much about air pollution. But I also think it's important that we say “yes” to this air package, because it is an important step in the right direction. This is serious about air pollution and we will have to make some demands for Member States to start acting. So I am happy to say “yes” to the air package, but I also hope that the Commission will take even more initiatives in other areas so that we can seriously bring all air pollution to life.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! Clean air is the right goal, we all agree with that. We should seek to reduce the emissions of poisonous gases into the atmosphere, but the level of standards and the length of the period of adaptation to the Directive cannot inhibit the development of agriculture and national economies of the Member States of the European Union. We all know that profitability in agriculture has been very low for many years and many branches are downright deficits. Standards must not jeopardize the profitability of production and force it to be significantly reduced. In my sense, it is important to establish the right norms. We know that each of the countries in the European Union are at different stages of development and are facing different problems in this regard. Therefore, the goal is right, while the execution itself is not necessarily accurate.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: — Mr President, air pollution means that thousands of tonnes of sulphur, methane, nitrogen and fine particulate matter are released into the atmosphere and kill 8 million people a year (400,000 in Europe alone). That is to say the magnitude of the challenge that is ours. The glass is not full, of course, but the directive we are finally voting at noon increases our ambitions in 2001, sets new ceilings and introduces a new pollutant. Only one, unfortunately. The Council has completely excluded methane, where Parliament had shown itself “sensitive” to our farmers' demands regarding ruminant emissions, which still account for a quarter of the total methane emissions. I would like to put two questions to the Commission in this regard. Do you confirm, Commissioner, that you will quickly take steps to reduce methane pollution in other tools, methane which is, moreover, a greenhouse gas 23 times more warming than CO2? What about checks and sanctions against Member States that did not respect and do not respect the new ceilings?

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, we in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality. Elevated levels of – and long-term exposure to – air pollution can lead to severe conditions affecting human health. The respiratory and inflammatory systems are very often affected, and serious illnesses such as asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and cancer are related. Air pollution also causes harm to flora and fauna.  However, UKIP is against further EU legislation, and in this instance we are concerned about the increased administrative burden for industry and governments. Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level. With Brexit, we will finally be free to reject EU environmental and climate policies that have been detrimental to our economies. We will be able to autonomously determine our own policy whilst mobilising our own resources in this area. Free from the EU Commission, the UK will provide a reliable and consistent regulatory environment in order to facilitate investment in all affordable energy technologies at the same time as putting the health and interests of our citizens first.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start my speech by thanking Mr Girling for his important work and for the result achieved. We have listened to different views in this chamber. One thing, however, is certain: 400 000 citizens die every year as a result of air pollution. And something had to be done with a policy, a decidedly community intervention. We did that and the deal is probably not the best deal. We have listened from some who would have liked other targets, well other pollutants included in the final agreement. But a deal is better than a non-agreement. And when with Mrs Girling, as part of the negotiation, we were faced with the choice of having to accept a downward deal to the positions of Parliament, but an agreement that went into the right direction, we have chosen the agreement; we have chosen to start a process, a process that will significantly reduce deaths in Europe from air quality, will lead us to have better quality for the citizens living in Europe and it is definitely a step in the right direction. For this announcement that I will vote for it and ask all other colleagues to do so. It's not fair to criticize if you don't move in the right direction. Criticism alone does not have any positive effects for European citizens.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: — Commissioner, Mr President. In a small Member State such as Austria, 42 000 children aged between 2 and 6 are currently suffering from asthma. How can we explain to them and their parents that around €2.2 billion per year could help ease their suffering? How can we explain to them that, on the other hand, this investment would free up some EUR 40 billion in Europe, which we need today in the health sector, in the environment, to counteract this damage caused by air pollution? How can we explain to these people that they are not alone, but that 400 000 Europeans die prematurely each year because we were not prepared to take appropriate precautions in the past and also to implement and monitor this provision thoroughly? I believe that what we have to decide today is an important step, even if it is not enough to really have a sustainable impact in all areas. I think here, for example, that we are not detecting methane yet. But I think I can safely go home today, tell these parents, these children: it is only a first step, but it is an essential step. We can help to ensure health, a better environment, not only here. We can also help create jobs and strengthen the competitiveness of the European Union. I think we're gonna have to take this out. Above all, I am sorry that there have been a number of Member States that have been gracing each other for so long and where I still suspect today that they will not push forward with full implementation and control. I may be wrong about this question.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, under the Geneva Convention we have the Gothenburg Protocol, which sets out specific targets for the reduction of emissions with transboundary polluting effects. The Directive we adopted today updates European legislation, the amendment made to this Protocol in 2012, and sets specific national targets for the reduction of five pollutants. These objectives have to be set by Member State, because the conditions of each State are different. It also provides for the control and monitoring of other pollutants and their revision in 2025, to make the necessary adjustments. The agreement reached by the Council is very positive and balanced for industry, transport and agriculture. The agreed targets for reducing ammonia emissions are realistic and the measures are very positive, and the combination of the two will reduce emissions in agriculture, which can sometimes have a strong impact on urban areas. It is also important that later, where comparable data are available, reduction targets for mercury and carbon monoxide be adopted. I would particularly like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Girling, on the result she has achieved and the effort she has made in the negotiations. This new directive will not be ideal for many, but it is an excellent tool for reducing pollution and its impacts, especially in the area of citizens' health.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all my support goes to this proposal: the aim is to clean up the air we breathe. The 400 000 premature deaths each year, already mentioned several times, are an unacceptable cost. The €300 billion in health care expenditures for chronic respiratory diseases alone is an unsustainable cost. Air pollution does not freeze at the borders of individual states with walls, which never go well. This directive significantly reduces pollution across the European Union, with realistic and achievable targets by 2030. We would have liked an even more ambitious text, but I consider this an important step forward in a broader strategy which must involve all sectors of production: industry 4.0, green agriculture and a more sustainable mobility. Smart environmental policy does not reduce jobs but creates new and more skilled ones. It is therefore not a point of arrival but a decisive contribution to a more sustainable development model.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: - Mr President! Thank you, colleague Julie Girling, for your input in the negotiations. We are many who would have wanted to go further, but now the EU is at least showing itself from its best side and on its strength. We can respond to many of the problems that we see — that people suffer from shortened life, caused deaths, asthma, allergies and other things leading not only to the great personal suffering of many European citizens, but also at very high cost in our societies, both when it applies to physical infrastructure and the clean health of people. I think that those who criticise the European Union for not delivering to citizens should take a hard look at the basis of this and what it can do. From my party, the Centre Party, we usually say that we want to see a Europe that is sharp in areas where Europe should have competence. This is an area where Europe should have more competence and more power to be able to lift the quality of the environment and also quality for our citizens. The EU has shown the front feet here, and we want to see more of that to come.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, clean air is important for the health of many people in Europe. We are talking here today about the proposal for national emission ceilings. What is important to us is that methane is no longer part of this proposal. Because then cows would be less frequent in the meadow in Europe, and I am thinking of Austria and the Netherlands, among other things. Cows belong in the meadow. That fits the landscape and animal welfare is also benefited from this. Mr President, now on ammonia. In Europe, ammonia emissions have been reduced by 30% since 1990 and ammonia emissions have been reduced by 70 percent in the Netherlands. The restriction has cost enormous efforts from our farm family farms, which have suffered heavily from these extra-heavy environmental measures, and it is therefore also good that both Parliament and the Council have adopted a review clause on this compromise. We also need to work on manure processing. This will result in clean air, cleaner water and better soil life, and let us work together to ensure that EFSI's money will be used for this. Finally, the average air quality in the European Union is among the cleanest in the world. This result has been achieved thanks to the efforts of many people in the Member States, businesses and entrepreneurs. And we must continue with that in the future. Let's give them a chance. Let's not only look at the sacred cow, the car, but also give the ordinary cow a chance. Our ambitions for cleaner air may cost efforts, but it is about feasibility, affordability and practicability. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue-card question. — Mr President! In any case, I would like to hear the opinion of a MEP, because I see that although I too agree very much with what has been said here, I would not be very, very satisfied. I'm asking them, I get it, this is how far it's been, but shouldn't we be working for more ambitious goals from tomorrow? Like banning fossil energies by 2050?

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: 'Blue Card' -answer. — (NL) I fully agree with you and we have been working on it all together. But you have to give everyone the chance to do that. I have just told you that if we want to continue as my two colleagues from the Netherlands have just mentioned, we will not have any farmers left in the Netherlands. They have made a lot of efforts. We have other options, too. We have to deal with that, too. If I look at this, I'm going to stick to agriculture and manure processing, then you have to make a lot of effort on that. But we also talked about the car industry. It must also work on the objectives. With each other, every sector to work and the business community wants to support us fully.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: — Mr President, poor air quality accounts for more than 400 000 premature deaths every year in Europe. About 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution considered harmful to human health. Many vulnerable sociodemographic groups are also particularly affected. And therefore we must act! Member States will have different paths to meet the new targets for reducing sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulates. The dynamization of electric mobility is an option that can make a very important contribution, especially in urban centres. As a member of the Committee of Inquiry into automobile emissions in this Parliament, I can say this with increased knowledge of the facts and, Commissioner, we appreciate this report following the Marrakech Summit and the risks posed to meeting the Paris agreement by the election of the new Northern President — American. The global appeal made in Marrakech to maintain the path of combating global warming and emissions increases is good news, but action is key, and this directive, now amended, makes an important contribution to the European Union's leadership on this agenda.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner. We all heard here this morning that the fundamental right of citizens is the right to air, the right to water, the right to health. And no one questions that. Thus, inhalation of fresh air is what is considered guaranteed. But at the same time, we have data on 400 thousand Europeans dying due to air quality effects. We have heard information that in urban areas there is a situation that even inhaling air is equal to ten smoked cigarettes. Anyway, it's a scary piece of information. I want to highlight here an example of a city in Croatia called Slavonski Brod, which is located on the border with another country, Bosnia and Herzegovina. We just said that pollution knows no bounds. Every year at the Progress Report for Bosnia and Herzegovina, we highlight the example of the oil refinery in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in Bosanski Brod, which causes pollution. We have an example that this country is the third in the world by the number of deaths due to air quality. Thus, 222 citizens die per 100 thousand inhabitants. So there are no borders, we in Croatia suffer from pollution in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Therefore, it is time to highlight this here in the European Parliament as well. This instrument that we brought here today is good, I understand that not all goals are achieved, but it is ambitious. This Parliament always has bigger targets than can be achieved, but in any case it is a good path to solve the problem by 2030.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, environmental care must be permanent, as it can help reduce health costs and save lives. I am a supporter of improving the quality of the environment. However, I believe that any measure we take in this respect must take into account the reality on the ground, the correlation of the proposed targets for emissions and GDP of the country, the possibilities of investment and refurbishment, the pace of research in the field. That is why I do not agree with what colleagues have said, that there is too much flexibility in this report. I claim that there is not enough flexibility, and I will also motivate why: for example, for sulphur dioxide, my country has a target of 77% reduction and 28% in the Netherlands. I know that the Netherlands “loves” Romania very much, it has also had problems with entering the Schengen area. It has been said here that 400 000 people die a year, but how many people die of poverty? How many people die because they cannot learn, follow an education, or because of living conditions? So we have to think economically, not shatter jobs. And I would vote on this report if the Commissioner promises to convince Mr Juncker that the strategic investment fund should also be given on a geographical basis, so that we can remove areas which now have poor living conditions from poverty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). — Mr President, the European Union's actions to reduce air pollution are important. However, Mr Cañete, I would like to mention again the problem that exists in Greece, namely the smog problem that has developed in recent years. And this problem has arisen because the poor Greek people, in order to warm up, use unsuitable materials for heating. And why is he doing that? Because the memorandum has increased the rate of excise duty on heating oil, as well as VAT on heating oil, electricity and gas. The result is an increase in particulate matter and a deterioration in public health. As Mr Moscovici accepted, in reply to my question, 11 000 premature deaths per year are due to this cause. I have therefore asked for a reduction in the excise duty on heating oil. Mr Moscovici's answer was: 'This cannot be done because Greece must fulfil its objectives from the memorandum. ' In the end, should the public health of Greek citizens be protected or should huge sums be collected from taxes in order to pay for primary surpluses and lenders? Answer us to that, Mr Cañete.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: — Mr. President, for years, I would say for decades, have fought a battle in Istria with regard to the air pollution that the Plomin thermal power plant did in the area of Labin and of course much wider. Clean air is a human right today. That battle that was won wasn't easy. I believe we also won a battle against what was going to be done, which is the next one, another coal-fired thermal power plant of course. And there's the main problem. However, today we have a problem in another part of Croatia. In the east of Croatia, Slavonski Brod is one of those cities that suffer huge air pollution across borders from Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is why I urge this Commission to think carefully about how to include cross-border air pollution from non-European Union countries but are candidates and want to enter the European Union. And we need to have a serious conversation with them about cross-border air pollution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this is an extremely important topic, because people dying from pollution – and particularly air pollution – is something that is seen across the world. Last week, I had the privilege of being in Marrakech with Commissioner Arias Cañete, among others, and the Chinese in particular were telling us about the efforts they are making to try and combat air pollution in their cities. Last year, I was honoured to represent Parliament in Vietnam. It was obvious there, again, that air pollution is a big problem. In our own countries, we have similar problems in many places, and, indeed, one of the things that our government did a number of years ago, under the then Minister for Health, Micheál Martin, was to ban smoking in public areas. It transformed the air quality in restaurants and bars, etc., so I think we have to do everything to ensure that the quality of air that people have is second—to—none, because otherwise people will continue to die.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement reached with the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants will allow premature deaths to be halved by 2030 toxic pollution. Currently there are more than 400 000 a year in Europe alone. But the limits identified by the directive are a far cry from the recommendations made by the World Health Organisation, which Parliament sought to defend in every way in the trilogue phase. The short-sighted attitude of some Member States will result in some 10 000 additional premature deaths each year. Also unsatisfactory are the flexibility criteria introduced, which will make the limits harder to enforce. The authorisation granted to Member States to regulate emissions according to seasonal temperatures or to compensate for the reduction of emissions from one sector with the largest emissions produced in another sector, arouse not a few perplexities. The hope is that Member States will change the short-sighted attitude they recorded during the negotiations. Breathing clean air is a citizens' right and the EU must raise the bar of ambition. We have to do it for ourselves and for the new generations.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President! We have now heard a lot that it is very important to increase air pollution because we have many health problems caused by air pollution — through various particles that can make people sick. That is certainly true, and that's why we have dealt with it. I must say that I would like to thank Julie Girling most sincerely for the compromise she has negotiated. It's not quite what Parliament wanted. However, I believe that it is precisely the right compromise that we need to move forward with air clearances in the interests of the citizens and, at the same time, to take a balanced approach. I want to say something about methane. It was regretted that methane is now taken out of here. But I think it's right. I'm also in favour of dealing with methane. We'll talk about Marrakech and COP 22 right away, that's where methane belongs. It is a greenhouse gas, and it is imperative that we see how we can contain this in the interests of the climate and the oceans and seas — which I always argue about. But it is not toxic to human health. That is why I think it's okay that we do not have this in this legislation now. But thank you again to everyone who worked on it.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you all for your pertinent and constructive comments. I am encouraged by the broad support for the agreement that has been reached. It is close to the original Commission proposal in terms of ambition and, given the difficulty of the negotiation, is in my view a good compromise between various positions. I know that concerns remain on flexibilities and on interim checks on the trajectory to 2030. However, the additional flexibilities are tightly constrained and we will monitor their application closely. Likewise, for the interim trajectory there is now a robust management framework in place to ensure that Member States are on track to meet their commitments. The Commission will evaluate the national programmes, including the credibility of the reduction pathways, and those evaluations will be made public. I have listened to and note the concerns of some about the level of effort required in particular Member States, but those are the very Member States whose citizens will benefit the most from implementation of the measures. They are the Member States that have the greatest problems in complying with ambient air quality standards and they are the Member States that will save most in terms of health and other economic benefits. We will work with non—Member States to maximise their support, including from European Union financing and from synergies with, for instance, EU climate and energy policies for the successful and cost—effective implementation of the directive. On the review of methane emissions, the Commission has made a declaration because it considers that there is a strong air-quality case for keeping the development of methane emissions in the Member States under review in order to reduce the ozone concentrations in the EU and to promote methane reductions internationally. The Commission confirms that, on the basis of the reported national emissions, it intends to assess further the impact of methane emissions on achieving the objectives set out in Article 1(2) of the NEC Directive; it will consider measures for reducing those emissions and, where appropriate, will submit a legislative proposal for that purpose. In its assessment the Commission will take into account a number of ongoing studies in this field, due to be finalised in 2017, as well as further international developments in this area. I would like to close by again thanking the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs for making possible this major step forward in air pollution control. Declaration by the Commission on the procedure for adoption of implementing acts The Commission underlines that it is contrary to the letter and to the spirit of regulation 182/2011 (OJ L 55 of 28.2.2011, p. 13) to invoke Article 5§4, subparagraph 2, point b) in a systematic manner. Recourse to this provision must respond to a specific need to depart from the rule of principle which is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered.  Given that it is an exception to the general rule established in Article 5§4 recourse to subparagraph 2, point b), cannot be simply seen as a "discretionary power" of the Legislator, but must be interpreted in a restrictive manner and thus must be justified.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you to all the colleagues who have spoken this morning. Their contributions reflect the divisions in this House over the ambition levels, and particularly the removal of methane and the effects on agriculture. In fact, agriculture has taken quite a prominent position in this debate, so I would particularly like to mention to Mr Häusling that, whilst he extols the virtue of organic farming, you will search in vain through his organic regulation proposals, currently in trilogue, for any reference to agricultural standards on air quality, whereas the NEC proposal contains an extensive annex referencing farming practices. This is a lost opportunity I think. Also, to those Polish members who criticise this directive: they have spoken about unfairness to agriculture, while rather ignoring the elephant in the room. In 2013, a survey by the Environmental Agency of air quality in 386 cities found that Krakow had the third most polluted air in Europe, predominantly as a result of 30 000 coal-fired boilers, with a further 150 000 in the wider Malopolska area. Dealing with this would improve their citizens’ health massively without affecting their agriculture at all. The solution, as ever, lies in their own hands. I would particularly like to acknowledge the support of those colleagues, led by the majority of the shadow rapporteurs, who see the agreement as a hard-fought compromise that is not perfect but are accepting it and encouraging a vote for it. I would like to urge those colleagues who will indulge themselves in a vote against – under the cover of the majority who, they know, propose to compromise – to think again and to give us, later today, as wide and as big a majority across the House as we can achieve.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: in writing. — (NL) Every year almost half a million people die from the effects of air pollution in Europe. The current European air quality standards are far too weak to protect people's health. Europe should adopt the World Health Organisation directives, which impose much higher demands on particulate matter, ozone, nitrogen dioxide and sulphur dioxide. Instead, it presents a strong weakening of current weak air quality standards. The Animals Party finds this proposal shameful and unacceptable. Compared to the current directives, this proposal will even suffer up to 10 000 additional deaths per year. Under pressure from the agricultural sector, greenhouse gas methane emissions have been removed from the proposal and ammonia standards are being reduced. While these substances have a huge share in the pollution of our air and also cause people to suffer serious health problems or die prematurely. Europe suffocates its inhabitants, and the Party for Animals does not participate in that.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: in writing. — Mr President, I am pleased that the directive was agreed upon. Air quality remains a very difficult problem in many Member States, which requires solutions. No need but to take a look at the Commission's listing for violations of environmental law, and you can see that Member States have difficulty even complying with existing legislation. This is not because our legislation is too strict, but because the lack of clean air is not taken seriously enough! Air pollutants cause more deaths in the EU than any other environmental problem. I hope that we will continue to regulate and pursue a more ambitious level in the future. Everyone has a right to clean air and we have a responsibility to ensure that this right is done.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. — I welcome the agreement on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants, even though the resulting compromise lags behind the European Parliament's ambitions. Overall, it is projected to see a 49.6% reduction in emissions after a conversion to health impacts by 2030, which is undoubtedly an improvement over the current state. The proposed reduction targets were informally agreed during the Dutch Presidency of the Council of the EU. They were also agreed to by the Czech Republic, which supports the proposal in the current version and which, under the National Emissions Reduction Programme, has already adopted more stringent reduction commitments by 2020 than what contains the text of the Directive It also complies with the approved framework position of the Czech Republic and will have positive impacts on air quality both as a result of the measures taken in the Czech Republic and the result of lower cross-border transmission pollution. I also want to stress that the reduction targets proposed are acceptable and fulfilled without imposing an unyielding burden on the economy. It should be remembered that air pollution does not negatively affect health and the environment, but that it also causes external costs in the range of EUR 330-400 billion, including direct economic damage amounting to EUR 15 billion (absence of employment due to health problems), EUR 4 billion (health care costs), EUR 3 billion (loss of agricultural crop yields) and 1 billion euro due to damage to buildings.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. — Honourable Members, three years have passed since the publication of the Clean Air Package, a time of long but important discussions and seeking acceptable solutions for cleaner and healthier air in our towns and villages. I support the compromise reached with the Council on the new directive, which sets ambitious targets for reducing air pollution in the period up to 2030. Recently, attention has been focused on greenhouse emissions, and this has led to a decline in the rates of limiting other pollutants, which have a serious impact on human health and the environment. For example, the expansion of diesel cars due to lower CO2-discharges has led to an increase in harmful nitrogen oxides from them. Almost 400,000 people in the EU die prematurely from polluted air and another 40 million people breathe particulate matter far above the norm. The new legislation must restore confidence in the reduction of harmful emissions with its ambition of targets and sound control mechanisms. I welcome the essential flexibility given to Member States to achieve their individual objectives set out in the directive, because this will find the most effective and expedient measures to tackle this problem. Particularly valuable in the directive is the concern for agriculture and taking into account its response specifics, although most of the ammonia and methane emissions come from the sector.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statement on the outcome of COP22 in Marrakech (2016/2995 (RSP)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, one year after the Paris Agreement, the conference in Marrakech last week clearly marked a new phase in global climate governance. At the outset, let me highlight that the European Union has shown its strong commitment to climate action by ratifying the Paris Agreement on 5 October 2016. Following the consent given by Parliament, the ratification of the Agreement by the EU, together with seven Member States, triggered its entry into force on 4 November 2016 and confirmed the key role of the European Union in the multilateral process. This was clearly recognised in Marrakech.  Overall, 112 parties ratified the Paris Agreement by 18 November. The European Union can be satisfied with the result of the Marrakech Conference. We witnessed the unprecedented quick entry into force of the Paris Agreement, the progress made on the development of its rules and the major demonstration of activities by non-state actors. This all confirmed the determination of the international community to continue moving forward, with a transition towards a low emission and climate-resilient future.  The European Union’s main objective at the Marrakech Conference was to put on track the swift preparation for the effective and comprehensive implementation of all the elements of the Paris Agreement.  Marrakech demonstrated progress and enabled action in the following areas: First, the subsidiary bodies outlined the work to establish the Paris rulebook, including the progress on the features of nationally determined contributions, the Transparency Framework, the Adaptation Mechanism and the Adaptation Registry.  Other elements to be mentioned are the global stock take, the Sustainable Development Mechanism concerning markets, non-market approaches and the compliance mechanism. The COP also mandated the current and incoming presidencies to start preparations for the 2018 facilitative dialogues. Secondly, progress was made on enhancing action and transparency before 2020, including on the predictability of climate finance flows to developing countries; on loss and damage, namely the review of the Warsaw International Mechanism; on technology development and transfer, capacity-building mechanisms, methodological issues, response measures, as well as on measures concerning gender and indigenous peoples.  Thirdly, the Global Climate Action Agenda was another key part of Marrakech. The Action Agenda builds on the growing momentum from stakeholders to mobilise global action in the water sector and in the areas of oceans, disaster risk reduction, agriculture, forestry, transport, energy and human settlements. All these initiatives by non-state actors support the Convention and the aims of the Paris Agreement.  Amongst many other issues, I would like to highlight the second round of the multilateral assessment process, which took place in Marrakech. Nineteen EU Member States and the European Union successfully completed the process of reviewing the progress made in the implementation of emission reductions and removals related to their quantified economy-wide emission reduction targets. The remaining Member States will follow next year.  And finally, the conference made a high-level political statement, the Marrakech Action Proclamation, which reflects the continuous political commitment towards the implementation of the Paris Agreement and reaffirms the willingness of all participants to fight against climate change and to support sustainable development.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Minister, it is a pleasure to be here today, having just returned from the COP22 in Marrakech, where almost 200 countries met against the background of the early ratification and entry into force of the Paris Agreement.  First, I want to thank the European Parliament’s delegation to COP for their very strong support throughout the conference. This enabled the European Union to stay unified as we forge ahead on global climate action. I also want to take this opportunity, in the presence of the Minister, to thank the Slovak Presidency for the close cooperation, both in the preparations and during the COP22. I will also stress again my appreciation for Parliament’s role in ensuring the early ratification of the Agreement, which enabled the Marrakech Conference to convene the first ever meeting of the parties to the Paris Agreement.  COP22 lived up to expectations as an action and implementation COP. It is true that, in the light of the United States election results, we face political challenges and uncertainties ahead, but the message from Marrakech was nevertheless clear: we will stand by Paris; we will defend Paris; and we will implement Paris.  The Marrakech Action Proclamation reflects the spirit of COP22. It is a statement of global unity, confirming that the parties remain committed to climate action post—Paris and the transition to a global low—carbon economy. Important progress was also achieved under the Paris Work Programme. The parties agreed a clear way forward to ensure that the rule book will be ready by 2018, and advanced on key elements to guide the implementation of the Agreement, including transparency and the five-year ambition cycle.  Solidarity with our international partners is critical if we wish to maintain global momentum on climate action, and the parties welcomed the adoption of the 2020 climate finance roadmap as progress towards the goal of mobilising USD 100 million by 2020. Member States have also shown their commitment to supporting the most vulnerable countries in dealing with the impacts of climate change.
