Several European Union Member States announced that new contributions to the adaptation fund, which now stands at USD 81 million, directly supporting developing countries in their efforts to cope with the effects of climate change. In addition, the parties also showed a continued commitment to capacity building and the Warsaw International Mechanism for Loss and Damage. A decision was adopted on the review of the Mechanism, which will result in increasing its potential and effectiveness and confirming the shared commitment of parties to address the concerns of the most vulnerable countries. On the Action Agenda, COP22 included an impressive range of high—level side—events. This enabled countries, states, regions, cities, the private sector and NGOs to come together under the Global Climate Action Agenda to showcase inspiring climate action initiatives to reduce emissions, transition to a low—carbon economy and support our partners in the mitigation and adaptation efforts. Besides several other major actions, COP22 saw the launch of the international NDC partnership. We will support developing countries in the implementation of the nationally determined contributions to the Paris Agreement.  The European Union played an instrumental role in achieving the Marrakech outcomes, and there was regular effective coordination with Member States, no red lines were crossed and all politically sensitive options were considered carefully and collectively. The European Union Member States negotiated with flexibility, and their commitment to delivering a positive outcome in Marrakech was very clear.  The European Union also demonstrated its determination to making significant efforts to scale up support to climate relevant action. In 2015, the European Union and its Member States provided EUR 17.6 billion to help developing countries tackle climate change. Moreover, the European External Investment Plan expected to trigger public and private investment of up to EUR 44 billion in Africa and the European Union’s neighbourhood area had a very positive reception by our international partners. The High Ambition Coalition – the alliance of developed and developing countries that made possible the Paris Agreement – also convened during COP22. The meeting helped to define our joint negotiation strategy during the COP, as well as to exchange views on the potential impact of the outcome of the United States elections on the United Nation negotiation process. What is clear is that, given the current uncertainties, the High Ambition Coalition has a renewed sense of purpose as we move ahead with the implementation of the Paris Agreement.  Now that we have returned from Marrakech, the hard work does not stop. In the current uncertain geopolitical setting the European Union must, more than ever, remain steady on its course to a low—carbon, energy-efficient future. Marrakech showed us we are not alone. The momentum keeps growing in many of our G20 partners, including China, that are more determined than ever. We have good scope for scaling up international collaboration in terms of bilateral policy dialogues and sharing experiences. I will do the necessary to deliver on this.  I will also work closely with the German G20 Presidency to make sure we exploit the positive opening under the G20 to follow up on the Paris implementation. In addition to strengthening our strategic partnerships, we must continue to demonstrate to the world our commitment to climate action by implementing our NDC. Our proposals on the 23rd legislative framework, including the European Union ETS and LLUCF, are now on the table, and I look forward to working with the Parliament in the months ahead to ensure strict progress on this package.  Implementing the Paris Agreement is an unprecedented opportunity to modernise our economy and create jobs and growth. It is a central element in achieving broad and sustainable development goals as well as the European Union priorities on investment, competitiveness, circular economy research, innovation and energy transition. Therefore, we will also shortly come forward with a package under the title Smart and Clean Energy for all Europeans – a package of proposals which will put energy efficiency first, will reinvigorate our global leadership in renewables and deliver a fair deal for European consumers and citizens, as well as business and industry. Together with existing proposals on the table, this package will ensure a comprehensive and coherent climate and energy policy framework up to 2030. It will deliver on our contribution to the Paris Agreement and will make bigger steps forward towards our overall vision for an energy union.  In conclusion, honourable Members, we have achieved marked progress this year on global climate action. Less than twelve months ago, we adopted the Paris Agreement, and through commitment and hard work ensured its entry into force earlier this month. We still have much work to do to implement our commitments on the ground and I count on your continued support to turn our commitments into reality.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the Marrakech conference ended with concrete results. COP22 — we told ourselves from the beginning — was the place to move from words to actions. And we did. I would like to thank Commissioner Arias Cañete for his strong action and for his continued and constant contact with the delegation of Parliament which I had the honour of chairing. Almost 200 countries met in Morocco and many were the commitments of our delegation, which had the opportunity to confront many other national delegations and prominent personalities. We can certainly say that the progress made in Marrakech is proof that the world will move forward with the fight against climate change. With the Marrakesh Declaration, in fact, states have shown an idea of solidarity and continuity with each other. The COP22 leaves no doubt: we must continue the path started last year. The Paris Agreement would not have been possible without the trust between the parties and we in Marrakech confirmed that confidence. As far as the EU is concerned, we will continue to implement our commitments and achieve the goals we set ourselves, no matter what happens. This is a bigger problem than a single country or a single election, although this is about the United States. We have a process ahead of us that will take us to the end of the century and which I consider irreversible. Beyond the uncertainties and doubts we will defend Paris and implement Paris. The transition to a clean economy has never begun and the European Union will continue to act as an opener and leader towards a sustainable and competitive economy.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. COP 22 was a success. On behalf of the S&D Group, I would like to thank the Commission and the Council for their good negotiation and also for the involvement of Parliament's delegation with the daily briefings. It is good to see in Marrakech that the international community stands together and that all 195 states have reaffirmed their commitment to enforce the Paris Agreement and not to be unsettled by the election of the new US President Donald Trump. However, with the election in the US, we need a revision of leadership in global climate protection. The EU must take on this leadership role and — Commissioner, you said — we should win China as a partner and keep it further so that this coalition can really push ahead with the Paris agenda. China will be useful for new technologies, as well as for a global carbon market. The next COP, which will be very important, will be COP 24 in two years' time — 2018, where we need to review the national commitments. Here would be my question to the Council and the Commission: what will the EU offer in 2018? Will we be discussing our 2030 targets there, too, whether we can stand up better? We also saw in Marrakech that 48 countries have chosen to switch 100% to renewable energy and to organise a long-term strategy. As the EU, are we also able to adopt a roadmap 2050, a 2050 strategy? I think we need to show our commitment now. Here are the big questions about the winter package. Are we able to further promote renewables, or are we curing them down, and are we ambitious in terms of energy efficiency? This will be the final test next week — Commissioner — of the winter package that we will then receive from you.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to Commissioner Arias Cañete for his continuing inclusive style of leadership through COP 22, continuing on from good experiences at COP 21. It is pretty impossible to ignore, though, the big orange cloud that was hanging over COP 22, and not from the Saharan dust. It is true that the US elections did have an effect, but there were positive outcomes. In a political statement of resolve following the US presidential elections, the Conference adopted a call for all nations to honour promises made in Paris and renew their attempts to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees. Negotiators focused on initiatives to reinforce existing carbon reduction plans, with some countries promising to review ambitions before 2020. Countries also fixed a 2018 deadline for preparing a rule book establishing the rules and processes needed to provide operational guidance for the Paris Agreement and 11 governments, including my own, actually ratified the climate agreement during the COP.  There were, of course, some negative outcomes. Despite strategic funding commitments from the US, Germany and the UK to improve carbon accounting in developing countries, the sums on offer fall well short of the EUR 100 billion a year developed countries have promised to mobilise by 2020 in order to help poorer countries develop their infrastructure on many fronts. I know that the work to increase these new financial pledges will be ongoing, and Mr Arias Cañete is in the forefront with his high ambition coalition.  The issue of loss and damage and how to approach recompense for damage caused by climate change has been put off again for discussions at further dates, but that does not mean that it has been forgotten. Over the past 12 months, we have made rapid and unprecedented progress in laying the foundations for a low-carbon, climate-resilient economy. This COP 22 showed us that progress is never linear, but it does not mean that it is not going on, and it does not mean that it will not be successful.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, let me also thank Commissioner Arias Cañete, not only for the way he works very inclusively with Parliament, but also for the way that he is dealing with the other important states in the world, and especially the way he has improved the relationship with China, in particular with President Xi Jinping is very encouraging to see.  At the start of the Marrakech COP I had one hope, and that was that the entire world would send a message to Washington that the Paris Agreement and the process after that would be irreversible, that the world would move towards this zero-carbon economy, and that in the end is exactly what happened. If President-elect Trump has achieved anything, it is that the world is much more united now behind this transition towards a zero-carbon economy, and even countries like India seem to be much more determined now than they were a few months ago – as does China. What happened in Marrakech shows very well how rapidly the geopolitical scene is changing at the moment. It is only two years since President Obama struck the deal with President Xi Jinping on climate with China. Before that, China was one of the biggest obstacles in international climate negotiations, and look at it now. China is now one of the leading countries in the post-Paris process and that is extremely encouraging.  And what about Europe? Of course Europe is still one of the leaders, and we are still leading by example, but we have to be careful. Look at the difficult internal negotiations within Council but also within Parliament on the ETS. Look at the first reactions by almost all Member States on the effort-sharing regulation proposal from the Commission. It is not that long ago that we all laughed about Russia counting every tree in the Kyoto Agreement to try to undermine that, but now all Member States are doing exactly the same. We think that our trees will save us in the fight against climate change and that is not going to happen.  Finally, it is also an economic issue. China is investing two-and-a-half times more on green technology than Europe. As a percentage of GDP, it is even four times as much, so we have to be extremely careful there. This is also a race .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, I am afraid that I will not be as optimistic as the rest of my colleagues. The Marrakesh Summit did not give us a good taste because we have not taken any steps forward in implementing the Paris Agreement; rather, we have left the fear that steps will be taken backwards. I'm sorry to say, Mr Cañete, that I am not going to thank you for your role as Commissioner. The European Union's little weight in the negotiations has become even more evident and, given the new world scenario, more worrying. We still wonder what does a politician with interests in the oil industry and ties with brick giants — also related to corruption scandals like Acuamed or Panama Papers — representing the European Union's position in the fight against climate change. You filled your mouth in Marrakech calling the energy transition unstoppable, yet the party to which you belong did not even ratify the Paris Agreement in time, withdrew the incentives for renewable energy, and, since the People's Party reached the government in Spain, emissions have not stopped growing. Spain is the only country in the European Union to have increased its greenhouse gas emissions since 2013. It seems to me that this is not a good method for making the energy transition. Mr Cañete, the European Union has been out, it has been absent in many important negotiations. This should make you think about your role as Commissioner, whether you are at the ethical level of the post. I really believe that, out of respect for citizens, out of respect for the rest of the countries, out of respect for the European Union, out of respect for Europe in short, you should resign.

name: Claude TURMES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, as a member of the delegation, I would also like to thank our Chairman, Mr La Via, for the excellent professional organisation. We had a great time and our Commissioner is certainly a good international negotiator. I think it is right that we should point this out. It was a good COP. We had the impression of a quick ratification, there was unity against Mr Trump and there were a lot of positive vibes, in part because of the positive agenda that the French have started in Paris: energy efficiency in buildings, energy efficiency in transport, renewable energy, interconnectivity, and getting financial markets to understand that it is not black energy but green energy which is the future. All that was around us and is really positive. I have two critical remarks to make. One, Commissioner, is that I think we in Europe could be better at selling our story. The success story of Europe is that 95% of our climate achievements are in eco-design, labelling, building legislation, energy efficiency legislation, renewables, CO2 and cars. Five percent may be due to the ETS, because the ETS is largely a failure. So why, at international COPs, do we speak only about carbon markets and why do we hide away our success stories on renewables? Why did nobody from the Commission speak about the Juncker external fund for Africa at a time when we could help Africa to improve and to move much more quickly into renewable energy? The second criticism concerns early ambition. You will have a difficult time in 2018 if we go with that the Council’s low level of ambition, which was set in the light of Mr Cameron’s veto threat. Forty percent by 2727 is not a story in a 1.5º world nor in a 2º world. Your energy package of next week will be the occasion to show that Europe is a leader and, in that regard, why are you now reducing the investment opportunities for renewables in Europe with low ambition, low governance and the destruction of priority access and despatch? On the rule book and the support scheme, you have some civil servants who prevent you from doing what you have politically agreed. Why is Mr Timmermans opposing a quota on renewable energy? I hope it is not because we have so many gas lobbyists hanging around. I tell you, and I tell Mr Juncker, if next week is not about Europe being positive, being number one, you will have another blow to European public opinion.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, COP22 should have been the action and was played in defence. The shadow of Trump's pre-election statements was all over the conference and in fact from Marrakech only one proclamation came out, but it reaffirms the desire to continue united and compact in the implementation of what was decided and established in the Paris Agreement, which was not for granted, so anyway it is good news. We want to be positive and say that “irreversibility” and “cooperation” are the two key words of COP22. Irreversibility, because the fight against climate change through the development of a sustainable economy is a mechanism that can no longer be stopped. Not even from Trump: Doubts about US engagement were swept up by the words of outgoing Secretary of State Kerry, who explained what the same US economy will look like, the same businesses , to get Trump back on his steps. Back there is no coming back. Cooperation, because it is only through support, investment and knowledge transfer between developed countries and developing economies, that the fight against global warming can be won. Now, with the United States likely to be less motivated and decided at the negotiating tables, it is up to the European Union to take the leadership in negotiations and policies against global warming. And the actions on which to be strong and decided now are, above all, those of individual countries. It is essential that the Union pushes for a first NDCs review, in the crucial year 2018, strong and ambitious and aimed at meeting the 1.5 degree limit set in Paris. And it cannot and should not let its Member States — as someone, including Italy, is already doing — start playing the downside. It is necessary to push hard on the newborn 2050 Pathway Platform, to which the European Union promptly has joined, to make it an opportunity to strengthen the climate policies of the Member States by integrating them into a broader and more effective plan. But how can we be credible on these commitments if Europe itself still earmarks more than 300 billion a year for fossil source subsidies?

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to reflect on a saying by my parties: 'If you kill the horse go home on foot. ' And we reflect on the very expensive decisions that affect families, farmers, artisans and businesses and impoverish, alas, our European countries. Years later what are the effects that have been created? On the one hand the impoverishment of labour, the impoverishment of the manufacturing production of our countries, relocated precisely in China, India, Brazil. But sadly, alas, world pollution has also not shrunk. Because it's obvious that if you move production from one side to another and don't act on the actual causes, you've shifted pollution but didn't reduce pollution. And therefore the pollution continues to be there and testify, alas, the actions that precisely want to put in the field of expenditure of more than 100 billion dollars to reduce the environmental impact. The invitation I make in the package you are studying is to use these resources to bring production back to Italy, to bring production back to Europe, to bring production back to where there is real culture respect for the environment, where citizens, businesses, our entrepreneurs have a culture of respect and attention to the environment. Last thought I make: you have been able to put around a table nearly 200 heads of state to decide the climate of the coming years: why do you fail to do so on immigration? (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Claude TURMES
text: blue-card question. – You are saying that we are deindustrialising Europe. Are you aware that electricity prices in Germany today, for example are as low as they are in the USA and that German industry has very good years behind it? Please show me the facts. Today, because we have renewables and energy efficiency, prices for big electricity consumers are relatively low. Be aware also that the Commission, through the Juncker investment fund, is now organising money for precisely what you want to have, which is combating energy poverty in Europe. So be more positive.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Answer to a question “blue card”. — I have no doubt that, perhaps, Germany was able to benefit from it. Unfortunately Italy has not benefited: you think that 50% of the electricity bill is burdened alas by these costs in Italy. So we have the cost of electricity which is 4-5 times higher than other European countries; it's a fact. I arrive from Lombardy and I have been the chairman of the Committee on Productive Activities, so I speak reasonably: we have unfortunately lost in these years a series of manufacturing realities and I think that a country without production is not a country that can look to the future. There can be no policy only of banks or speculative finance but that of production. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Question “blue card”. — I have just heard from you about the famous 100 billion that are getting together internationally, as the European resources to integrate and invest in the sector industrial. Look at that fund has a whole other purpose and then I invite you to study before you speak.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Answer to a question “blue card”. — Meanwhile I would have expected, perhaps, an explanation, since there was this occasion. After that, those resources, I hope — since they are still to spend — that all colleagues will think about using them to invest in generating production where there is a culture of respect for the environment and therefore in European companies and Italian companies.

name: Peter LIESE
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Marrakech has been a success and I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this. I would like to commend Mr Turmes for praising Mr Turmes for praising the Commissioner. We agree on the EPP: if the Greens praise Jean-Claude Juncker and Miguel Arias Cañete, then we must approve that. The election of Donald Trump was, of course, a shock to everyone in Marrakech. But there has been a clear response from all the rest of the world. If we used to have a situation where climate protection had to be done against the US and China, then we now have at least a clear commitment from China that it will continue to implement the Paris Agreement and the Convention. In the US, thank God, there are also discussions on whether Trump's announcements will be implemented in this way — we do not know yet. But we have to be armed. This is an important statement that I would like to make here on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party. Now, after the elections in the United States, we must all the more ensure that the industry is protected, if it is up to date. That is why we want to increase the free allocation for industry in emissions trading. We need to figure out what will happen if Trump really gets out. I have always been — like many in my group — against customs duties at borders, against carbon border tax adjustments. But if a country is opting out of the climate agreement — the Paris Convention and the Paris Convention — we must at least consider whether we will not use this instrument against that country. Jean-Claude Juncker said: We don't know Donald Trump yet. We'll get to know him. But he should get to know us too. We will not let a new American government please us, but will continue to protect our industry and climate protection. (The speaker agrees to answer a question about the “blue card” procedure according to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue-card question. — Madam President, Honourable Member, You're saying that you have to pay double attention to Donald Trump's activities. Well, I think we've been through that, and it's a lot of attention. I think that Europe should take action now, like this European Parliament, to send a very, very clear message to the new US administration that we do not tolerate trying to reverse world trends on their own. Do you agree with this?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — We should be clear about the objective of protecting the climate and implementing the treaties — the Paris Treaty. But we don't know yet what the American government is really doing. That is why this consideration of protective tariffs is something we need to approach very carefully now. Perhaps it will help Donald Trump to let go of his original plans. And I believe one more thing is very important: the next COP will take place in Bonn, but the Fiji Islands will have the presidency. This is the alliance we need: the European Union and the most vulnerable countries against backward trends. (The speaker agreed to answer a further question under the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), question 'Blue Card'. — I would like to ask for a simple clarification: you said that we need to increase the benefits to European industry. I don't disagree at all. But how does this combine with a reduction in emissions in Europe? Or did you mean something different?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — I think there is a very good compromise proposal for emissions trading by rapporteur, Ian Duncan. Unlike the Commission, we will give the risk industry such as the steel industry, but also other sectors, the assurance that if they are state-of-the-art, they will then receive the allowances free of charge. This is also good for climate protection. Because if industry, even though it does everything that is technically possible, is expelled from Europe, then this does not help the climate. But those who are not up to date will also have to invest. And Ian Duncan, for example, also suggested to sharpen the MSR, and that would give the right signal. So please: other groups, support this compromise, then both will be achieved!

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: — I did not come with you this time and I regret it. I thought it would be a regular COP to implement Paris. But I think that the election in the United States has made it a very political COP, and I have received very good signals about it. Many people have said that, and we absolutely want to support that: the dynamism that arose in Paris, which was not broken in COP 22, despite the elections in the United States. And on that momentum, work needs to be continued. And then it is extremely important that Europe not only maintains its historic leadership role, but further strengthens it and seeks new allies, for example by looking at China. And that means that we must also show that leadership in our own policies, and I support what Mr Turmes has said about this: when it comes to the winter package that is coming, please let that be the most ambitious thing that we can put forward when the is about energy efficiency, about our buildings and, of course, about renewable energy. But it is also a task for ourselves, as has been said a few times earlier: we are in the last straight line in Parliament to negotiate within ENVI on ETS. Here too, ladies and gentlemen, as ambitious as possible. We still have to negotiate with the Member States. We always know that this gives rise to some further dilution of the compromises. So set the bar high, show the rest of the world that we will not hang our heads. But, and I also agree with Peter Liese, I find that very encouraging, and I think that we really need to think, beyond the party political boundaries, in the coming weeks and months, how we are going to solve this. If, I say, the United States somehow withdraws from Paris, then we should not be naive. We must be ambitious and at the same time make sure that we protect. If we demand great efforts from our industry, what we need to do to ensure that we tackle CO2, we must also ensure that we look in a good way to protect ourselves from countries that leave the Paris Agreement. And I think that we should think about what is the best possible way, and that is, of course, also linked to a new vision of trade in the future.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: “He's got the whole world in his hands”, that song is about God holding the world in his hand. And he has given us the responsibility to take good care of his creation, and I hope and pray that future President Donald Trump will realise that and will emphatically do so. Fortunately, the climate summit in Morocco reaffirmed the Paris Climate Agreement and everyone called for concrete action. And I was also pleased that in Marrakesh, the business community also made a strong voice. And I find it hopeful that in the United States of all the more and more companies stand up for sustainable production, sustainable entrepreneurship, precisely at the time when Mr Trump is coming. As far as I am concerned, this concrete action must also take place in the sectors that have remained outside Paris. And then I think of shipping and aviation. It is true that aviation has taken a first step in Montreal, but that is far from sufficient. A lot more needs to be done. And shipping is indeed working on cleaner engines and perhaps retrofits of existing engines, but hard reduction targets remain out. Businesses and governments in these sectors must show that they take climate change seriously. Because if we really want to tackle climate change and its consequences, we need everyone's commitment: both companies and governments. Let's all join hands.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — COP 22's final statement characterizes the application of the current Paris undertaking as an urgent obligation. Today, more than ever before, it is necessary for developed countries to make clear again their commitment to bring the Treaty of Paris into action and ensure sufficient financing, mainly towards developing countries. Last year we were successful in historical success, we led to the climate negotiations all the essential players, even those who did not want to accept their share of responsibility for the fate of the world in the long term, among both them and the US. But their new president, in his words, is directly threatening that success, and I strongly hope that he really stays only at words on his part. President Trump should recognize that his stance will directly affect other big polluters as well. If he withdraws from the US contract, the rest of the big players, and with them the rest of the world, will withdraw from it too. We are in real danger of leaving Europe alone in its struggle. I would very much hate to live to see this end. We need to appeal to Mr. Trump to realize his huge share of responsibility for the fate of the planet and to stand up to him as the true guy he so likes to refer to himself.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, I would like first of all to thank the Council and the Commission for providing good information to the European Parliament’s delegation last week in Marrakech, which kept us informed and made sure that we could follow the negotiations very well. However, we all know also that the negotiations were tedious and very technical, and the big political point was, of course, what is going to happen with the United States. That was the political side of the story which was not in the negotiations room, but was very prominent and visible and you could feel it in the rooms in Marrakech. There, we really have a challenge. What we saw happening in Marrakech is that China is taking the lead. They say that they are going ahead no matter what. So we have left the idea that we are finger-pointing at each other and the idea of ‘we only move if you move’. That is very important, but we also know that it is a delicate balance. For example, a country like India is much more insecure. So this really boils down to ‘what is Europe going to do’? Is Europe going to step in in two ways – dealing with China and also increasing ambition? We need to show that we, as Europe, not only talk the talk but also walk the walk. That is crucial, and that is where Europe is not delivering yet, but it is also now very crucial in the negotiations on ETS, for example. Everyone who is talking about the importance of climate change – and I am looking at my EPP colleagues now – make sure you also deliver on ETS, because in the current negotiations we are only discussing ‘protecting, protecting, protecting’ and forgetting the ambition, and that is making us weak internationally.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Madam President, we have just seen the unedifying sight of 10 000 climate alarmists flying off to Marrakech and emitting thousands of tons of CO2 in the process. And what have they achieved? I will tell you: three parts of not very much. On the vexed question of finance, they agreed to keep talking; on the Adaptation Fund, they failed to reach agreement; on the Facilitative Dialogue, they postponed to 2018; on the rulebook, they reached no real conclusion; and on the vague concept of loss and damage from climate change, they agreed a five-year plan, effectively postponing the decision until 2022. That is failure writ large. A few weeks ago, I had the pleasure of hosting my friend Marc Morano of the American advocacy group Climate Depot in the Brussels Parliament for a showing of his movie ‘Climate Hustle’, a critical appraisal of climate alarmism. Marc Morano also went to Marrakech, where he symbolically shredded a copy of the Paris Climate Agreement. We were told that the Paris Agreement was legally binding. In fact, it had no binding targets and no sanctions for non-compliance. We now have a new American President who has repudiated that agreement. I think we can now say with some confidence that the Paris Agreement is well and truly dead.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: In recent months, the Members of this House and the Members of the Commission have ridiculed Mr Trump, mocked and taunted, and expressed his disregard for him. Mr Verhofstadt even called him a clown. But we now know, Mr President, that the majority of the people think exactly the opposite of the establishment and they chose Mr Trump as President. After that election, Mr Juncker said at a press meeting that Mr Trump understands nothing of the world, understands nothing of Europe and understands nothing of standards and values. And Mr. Juncker was going to explain it to him. Mr President, I do not think that that is as smart as you still have a lot of business to do with this gentleman, for example negotiating a climate agreement. So the biggest saboteurs of your climate treaty don't live in China, they won't live in the White House; the biggest saboteur of the climate treaty keeps his office a few hundred yards away, and that's the incompetent Mr. Juncker.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, like my colleagues I must say it was a pleasure to attend the Morocco COP22, having been in Paris last year for the historical global agreement. Thanks indeed to the Slovak Presidency, Commissioner Cañete and the Commission, and my colleagues under the chairmanship of the excellent Mr La Via. Also there is thanks due to Morocco itself, it was a good location because they gave an example of moving to low-carbon economy: they have the largest solar plant in the world and electric cars were used to ferry people around from place to place. Some people were worried about the impact of the presidential elections. I left much less worried then when I went there, for two reasons. Number one: the United States themselves have indicated that in many states there are movements to decarbonise the economy, both at official level and at business level. This is not going to change in states like California, Florida, Pennsylvania, and so on. Number two: China, in reply to a question I put to them directly as to whether they would use the election in the United States to renege, or to attain the opportunity for global leadership on this issue, they said they would continue with global leadership on the path they promised last year. So I think we can be encouraged. The word that we can use to describe this movement now is ‘unstoppable’. In answer to Mr Helmer, the climate change movement is alive and well, not dead; it is alive and well and living across the world. It will continue to grow. We have to do an awful lot, especially in relation to the developing countries. The EUR 100 billion fund will have to be attained. Energy use in Africa is going to treble over the next number of years, and double in Southeast Asia. So we have to help those countries, because they are also anxious to move, as they see the actual effects – on a daily basis – of global warming and climate change to their economies.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Madam President, climate change is the main challenge ahead of us. We are not only playing what kind of future humanity will have, but the very fact that humanity is going to have a future. And we don't have time to waste, so much time has been wasted. Paris was a big step forward, but in implementing the Paris Agreement is where we really play our response to climate change. Marrakech may be seen with optimism, but there are some reactions, fundamentally those of the United States, that lead us to concern. But I wanted to highlight the humanitarian aspects. Climate change intensifies natural disasters, accelerates the destruction of ecosystems, causes prolonged famines, devastating droughts, and it is the most vulnerable who suffer this reality. We need to accelerate financial support for those most vulnerable. As UNHCR had noted, around 27 million people become refugees each year for climatic reasons. In a few decades there may be hundreds of millions in the world. As the Red Cross has pointed out, climate political change is the main brake on the fight against hunger. Therefore, we have no time to waste; we cannot accept brakes when it comes to curbing global warming; we cannot accept, much less, steps backwards.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: (ECR). — (EL) Madam President, climate change is undoubtedly a threat to the environment and to humans. The World Health Organisation estimates that 12.5 million deaths per year are linked to environmental pollution, while 6.5 million of them are related to air pollution from domestic and external sources. Also about half of all child deaths from pneumonia are due to internal air pollution. More integrated policies are needed. Solutions and measures are needed to counteract the degradation of the environment and the health problems they cause. A further major issue to be raised in the Marrakesh Agreement is refugees due to increasing climate change. It is estimated that between 2008 and 2013 climate refugees amounted to 166 million, while this number is increasing. Finally, Mr Cañete, I await your answer to the question I put to you earlier about smog in Greece and the need to reduce the excise duty on heating oil.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). — Madam President, the Paris Agreement has achieved an important framework for tackling climate change. However, the purpose of the 22nd Climate Summit, which is to develop national action plans and promote more specific objectives, in order to strengthen actions by 2020 and thus support the implementation of the Paris Agreement, has failed. Unfortunately, the progress we expected for immediate action was not achieved in Marrakech, nor ambitious targets were set on the basis of the needs of the peoples and not on the basis of the interests of multinationals and monopolies. That is why we have left the announcements once again, and no binding decisions have been taken on meaningful action. Commissioner, the European Union and the rich States, regardless of what the US will do, must immediately proceed in cooperation with China and other States, support developing countries, develop a comprehensive action plan to combat energy poverty, end the misuse of natural resources and deforestation, to reduce greenhouse emissions and promote renewable energy sources.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: — Madam President, it is necessary to limit warming in the atmosphere in order to preserve the future of humanity. 197 states have become aware of this and signed the Paris Agreement in 2015, whereby they commit themselves to reducing their carbon emissions. The Marrakech conference, known as COP22, has just taken stock of the launch of the first concrete measures. The record is still modest, but already encouraging. First, the $100 billion Green Fund will be used to support Liberia and Nepal for approximately $2 million each. Second, a 2050 strategy platform brings together 22 states, 15 major cities, 17 regions and 196 companies to accelerate the reduction of carbon emissions. Thirdly, Germany is committed to achieving the zero emission target by 2050 and will host the next climate conference in a year. Nevertheless, it is to be feared that we will not avoid climatic upheavals that will lead to crises and migration. All States, including the United States of America, must continue to cooperate to mitigate its magnitude.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for once again leading the negotiations for the EU successfully. Marrakech was not about ground-breaking issues. It was about how to turn the Paris commitments into reality: that was the main topic. We have a clear message to our partners, especially the major economies: the Paris Agreement is our joint achievement and our joint responsibility. We have to deliver it together. My question, Commissioner, is this: how did they really answer, and what did you feel? Not only the regional proposals are important but also your general feeling. The second issue is that of our ‘homework’ – the internal responsibility of the European Union with regard to the ETS, proper reform of the ETS system to prevent carbon leakage and stimulate modernisation in a gradual and technological neutral way. We simply have to do this homework: otherwise, firstly, we neglect our share of global responsibility; secondly, we increase global emissions; and, thirdly, we endanger our competitiveness. All three of these are unacceptable. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Blue card question. — Mr Buzek, you are very sensitive to the problem of global warming — you want action — but I ask myself the question of the compatibility between strong and binding climate agreements at the level of individual states and free trade agreements. Don't you find that agreements such as TAFTA and CETA are incompatible with climate agreements? What is your position on this?

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — That is the question for the Commissioner and the Commission as well. From my point of view, we should first and foremost solicit that we are not the only big economy in the world that is really fighting climate change. For now, we're pretty embattled and won't help the climate fight if it continues to be the case. Our international situation and the impact on it is the most important moment, and if today we cause emissions to leak due to bad ETS-decisions — emissions leak, that is, the leakage of jobs from the European Union — then de facto global emissions will increase, not reduce, because emissions beyond the borders of the Union are greater. So carefully with ETS-reform, lest we destroy our own economy, because it is more dangerous to climate change than any harsh ETS-rules.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: — Fil-fatt, quddiem l-aħħar żviluppi FL-istati Uniti, COP22 uriet id-determinazzjoni ta' kważi mitejn mexxej minn madwar id-melon li jridu li l-ftehim ta' Pariġi jkun suċess. U dak li ġara f'marakex huwa xhieda oħra ta' kemm il-mudell ta' Pariġi fejn għandek it-tmexxija maqsuma bejn gvernijiet, bliet, reġjuni in kumpania privati qiegħed, fil-fatt, jaħdem u huwa b'saħtu. Iżda biex tassew jirnexxi, pajjiżi sinjuri u żviluppati jridu jonoraw il-wegħda li jipprovdu sostenn finanzjarju u jassist lil dawk il-pajjiżi li għadhom qegħdin jiżviluppaw, biex jindirizzaw bis-serjetà t-titià fil-air. Mexxejja minn madwar id-melon jridu jirrikonoxxu li l-ġlieda cons t-tibdil fil-klima hija dover urġenti in li d-melon kollha trid tiġbed ħabel wieħed. Il-messaġġ huwa wieħed ar. Jekk pajjiż jaħseb li għandu joħroż mill-ftehim ta' Pariġi u ma jonorax l-obbligi tiegħu, il-pajjiżi l-oħra se jżidu l-pressjoni. Nixtieq niffoka issa fuq il-effħa ta' implimentazzjoni, li s'issa kienet waħda inkonsistenti ħafna. It-tibdil fid-melon reali qiegħed jiġri b'aktar ħeffa minn dak li qegħdin jimxu bih il-gvernijiet fin-negozjati in t-taħdidiet f'marakex urew li ma nistgħux immorru lura mit-tranżizzjoni lejn enerġija aktar nadifa. Huwa evidenti li l-gvernijiet iridu jibdew jiððaqalqu, iridu jaġixxu aktar malajr biex ikun hemm tranżizzjoni sostenibbli u cost-effective għall-benefiðju tal-pajjiżi tagħna, tal-economics tagħna, in tað-itt tagtadini tagħna. B'dan il-mod biss nistgħu naćertaw li mill-kliem, bis-serjetà, ngħaddu għall-fatti.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: — Madam President, Mr Cañete, I want to express our concern at the use you intend to make of farming in the fight against climate change, to tell you that we will not accept it being made a accountable element for maintaining, or even increasing, emissions. We do not believe in false solutions like so-called climatically intelligent agriculture. Nor will we consent to pressure on agricultural land or the financialisation of natural resources. For us, it is essential to move forward in reducing emissions. That is why we advocate agriculture based on agroecology, prioritisation to local markets and short marketing routes as a key element for another CAP which will have to be described within the framework of food sovereignty. We deplore Morocco's instrumentalisation of COP22, condemn the expulsion of Sahrawi Mrs Selma Beiruk and support the decision of the Pan-African Parliament to withdraw from COP22.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Madam President, Commissioner. After the major headings that were adopted in Paris, the aim now is really to press ahead with the appropriate implementation in Marrakesh. Greenhouse gases cannot be stopped by borders, and when it comes to the climate, we are all really in the same boat worldwide. Unfortunately, we can't choose whether or not our seat neighbor on this boat believes in climate change. I believe it is now very important to note, apart from this speculation, that Europe alone will not be able to cope with the global challenges. A strong joint commitment to the Paris Agreement is all the more important. Climate finance and the division between North and South, between islands and mainland will really have a massive impact on our policy in the coming years. It is important and right that we have taken this path here. The EU is also well on its way to achieving its 2020 and 2030 targets, and with the climate package, the effort sharing decision proposals and many more, we also have the right basis for this. Agriculture, in particular, is severely affected by the effects of climate change and it is up to us, together with the economy and innovations in Europe, to prepare us for the climate future. Climate debt at the expense of our grandchildren really must end.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! COP 22 in Marrakesh clearly marks that the Paris climate agreement has come to stay. This is both good and necessary because climate change is negatively affecting millions of people and the environment. So thanks for a really good job in Marrakesh. But COP 22 must not become a sleeping pad, because promises are one thing, actions are quite another! And not least in light of the US presidential election, I think we in Europe need to play an even bigger and even stronger role, we need to take more responsibility on us. That means we will also have to increase our ambitions. That is why I am also addressing the Council directly today. It is particularly our Member States of the European Union that are foot-dragging. These are Member States which will not really lift ambitions. Good advice: Now take responsibility! Now do more! Raise ambitions! This is the only way we can get climate change resolved.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to welcome the host country of this 22nd United Nations Climate Action Conference, Morocco, which has worked to ensure that this COP is in line with the historic agreement adopted last year in Paris. COP21 marked a turning point in international cooperation to combat climate change. This agreement is sealed. Every State, every people must now honour its commitments. In Marrakech this year, and in Bonn, tomorrow, the effort must focus on implementing the Paris Agreement. As we see, COP22 has embarked on this momentum, but negotiations remain slow and difficult. Let me draw your attention to the topic of water. I note with regret that, too often, we make the supply of quality and sufficient water an achievement. However, climate change and population growth are unprecedented threats. 80% of the world's jobs depend on access to water supplies. Good water management is therefore a priority challenge. It is a cross-cutting topic that should be at the heart of climate action. COP22 devoted a day to water, which is a breakthrough. This event highlighted the hyperactivity of civil society that innovates daily, invents and develops to improve water management and rationalize uses. Water actors are ready to take up this challenge. What we need today is a political portage and a framework for action to unlock the potential of the blue economy. Several key principles seem to me to be a priority: to better take into account climate interaction and generalize the watershed system, which is the most relevant scale for good water management. The success of the COP depends on better water management. It is an essential resource to life which deserves our full attention in our climate action.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Madam President, I have a question for Commissioner Cañete. As Chair of the Development Committee, I want to ask what link you see, Commissioner, between what we are talking about today and the package adopted by the Commission yesterday? Because the Commission adopted two communications, one on the next steps for a sustainable European future and one on the consensus for development, and it seems to me that the link to be made with Paris is a golden opportunity to have real policy coherence for development. So I hope we will work together in this Parliament, and also that the various parts of the Commission will work together. The second opportunity concerns energy in Africa and developing countries, and I thank Claude Turmes for talking about the external investment plan because this is an extremely important opportunity, and we have not talked much today about Africa and developing countries. Seventy percent of African energy now comes from renewables, mainly biomass. In Marrakech, 47 developing countries, I think, pledged to invest in renewable energy, and we should be helping them to do that. I hope, Commissioner Cañete, that you will be working with Commissioners Mimica and Timmermans and the others in order to get a coherent EU policy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Marrakech summit was supposed to deal with the implementation of the Paris Agreement on climate change. That really wasn't the case: still many promises and few facts. It is a pity though that climate change does not proceed in small steps, as the World Meteorological Organisation has announced that 2016 is starting to become the hottest year since 1880 to the present. At this rate the Paris agreement, even if it were implemented, despite Donald Trump's statements, will not be enough to keep us within the two degrees of global warming. Climate finance with funds such as the Green Climate Fund is expected to mobilize funding of $100 billion per year from 2020, but has so far raised for climate adaptation only 81 million, and 91% from Europe. We need to rebalance the resources for climate change mitigation with those used for adaptation policies. If we do not solve this problem, the risk will be to divide the international community.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, I would like here to express my satisfaction at the pace and timelines agreed at the Marrakesh Summit to complete the rules of the Paris Agreement and because, both in the Moroccan city and at the Lyon, Paris or Quito summits, the regional and local role in the fight against climate change is being strengthened. It is cities and regions who know the environmental situation of their territory best, who are holders of competences such as urbanism or mobility, and who, thanks to their proximity, promote cultural and habits changes that are essential to decarbonize the planet. That is why I hope that, at European level, we will deepen the institutional consideration of key actors in order to make Europe a benchmark on the planet, with low emissions. To this end, they have been organised into entities such as The Climate Group, nations and regions for sustainable development, so I would like to know, Mr Cañete, how the Commission is adapting its methods to work with these types of organisations.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, one of the most alarming consequences of climate change, due to human action, is migrations caused by environmental disasters. According to the International Organisation for Migration, by 2050, at least 200-250 million people will be forced to move due to climate change; this means one person in every 45 in the world, an average of 6 million women and men forced each year to leave their territories. These are scary numbers that could even reach, if the most dramatic of the scenarios imagined by the UN agency were realised, the impressive figure of one billion refugees environmental. From this point of view, unfortunately, the commitments made by COP22 still appear weak. While waiting for the Member States to follow up on the solemnly commitments made in Marrakesh, I hope that the European Parliament will be able to take the opportunity offered by the reform of legislation on the asylum to provide adequate recognition and protection to environmental refugees.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). — Madam President, the Marrakech meeting at the 22nd Session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change marked the shift from the years of negotiation to the new phase which focuses on implementation, without, of course, marking Nothing tangible yet. Transition is a challenge, following the Paris Agreement because of the nature of differentiation between developed and developing countries. Further decisions are needed on a wide range of issues, including mitigation, adaptation, financing, transparency, procedures, market mechanisms, implementation and compliance. President-elect Trump has pledged a review, even a repeal of the Paris Agreement. Perhaps the new Agreement is a golden opportunity to review the policy areas of application in the areas of the Agreement.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Madam President, a year after Paris Marrakech happened. I consider it to be a new phase and it is good that Paris has come into force. The figure of 118 signatories is indicative — that's an unprecedented deadline. Results have been achieved, now we are ahead of implementation. Therefore, the most important is the implementation. But I think Marrakech was a strong political declaration to implement everyone from Paris. So implementing the Paris Agreement is very important, but one should take into account President Trump's latest statements and the results of the US elections. I don't believe what he was saying in the election campaign and what he's saying these days will carry out, but we remain determined anyway and thank you for that. Implement the agreement, take responsibility, protect the country and hand it over to future generations. I think this is a big milestone, because we need to reduce greenhouse emissions, use renewables more and consider energy efficiency.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, it is clear that the Paris Agreement at COP21 was a great moment to raise awareness of the world on the issue of global warming. Its effective implementation — and indeed fast, after the agreement of the European Union, but also of large states such as China, now the driving force in this field, and the United States — was another good news. COP22 in Marrakech confirmed and expanded this commitment, which is a third good news. But there is also bad news, that of Donald Trump's election in the United States, which expressed his willingness to exit the deal. The United States is, until further notice, an integral part of our planet. They would do well to also become aware of the consequences of global warming on their own territory, including the climatic disturbances that they are regularly subjected to. If all countries come together to push the United States to respect its signature, we have some chances of success, but all countries need to get together, including NGOs and all stakeholders.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner. It is not directly climate change and it is not directly energy production that I would like to deal with now, but its impact. We are discussing very fiercely at the moment that we want to obtain the Fauna Flora Habitats Directive as it is. This is because it will continue to be of important importance in the future how species protection, such as biodiversity in the European Union, function as a model for other countries of the world, but also as a refuge for plants and animals. This means that my request — also taking into account COP 22, the impact of climate change on the European Union and on our environment — is that we do not reopen this package here, but that we continue to monitor existing legislation, implementation and control. Let's not risk something that works with REFIT!

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. — Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to all the ladies and gentlemen who spoke in this debate and who demonstrate this House's interest in climate change policies. Clearly, the Commission has played a very intense role. We did so in Paris, launching the ambition of the grand coalition; in Marrakesh, in negotiations that are different, much more technical, but moving forward on the road map. And we will have to continue at future COP, future POPs that are going to be very different, they will not have that element of political negotiation so sharp that Paris had, but they are going to be POPs that are technically important in providing the Paris Agreement with the instruments necessary for its implementation and, on the other hand, they are going to be COP of implementation, to develop our policies. What we have seen at this COP is that non-governmental actors had a very important presence: municipalities, regions, autonomous communities, Oenegés, civil society, energy companies, renewable energy companies, energy efficiency companies, economic actors, social actors. It was a COP, as will be future POPs, to see best practices. I was asked what the Commission's attitude is to respect non-governmental actors: maximum cooperation and openness. We have worked very closely with the Covenant of Mayors, because we understood that cities were a very powerful melting pot of climate change experiences, and we will continue to work with other non-governmental actors, with the Committee of the Regions and with all these actors, because the fight against climate change is a bottom-up, up bottom, and therefore we have to do it enormously participatory. I want to say that 2016 has been a very positive year for climate change. 2015 had the emblematic Paris Agreement, but in 2016 we have ratified — the European Union and many of its Member States, at this time sixteen Member States, have already ratified it — it has entered into force thanks to European ratification, and we have developed COP 22 in accordance with expectations on the table and even with the Marrakesh Action Plan, which is a commitment to all parties to keep action at an important level and to implement our policies. Mr. Helmer said Paris was dead. For “the dead you kill are in good health”, because Paris is alive and kicking, which is said in Spanish, in Spanish, in Spanish, and, if anything I saw in Marrakech, it was everyone's desire to move forward. And the problem of China has arisen. Faced with a horizon of uncertainty, it is clear that China and the European Union have to approach in order to maintain that permanent leadership in the fight against climate change by developing our policies. And the European Union can be proud and come to these negotiations with very important assets that justify it being able to participate in global leadership. Because we have the most ambitious emission reduction target, at least 40% with domestic action, not international credits. Secondly, we are the only party that, at the moment, has launched (or is going to launch next week) all the legislation necessary to meet its climate goals, through legislation, not by presidential decisions. And that is a differential factor, because, apart from the various electoral results that may exist in the twenty-eight Member States, policies remain constant, and that is a value that Europeans can presume. And finally, we have international financial solidarity, respect for developing countries. We can orchestrate large coalitions with developing countries because we are financially supportive; because we are the ones that most climate finance we put on the table, and in addition, in coordination with our development policies. Commissioner Mimica and I worked together. We are the ones who contribute the most in climate finance; we are the ones who finance 50% of the Green Climate Fund; we finance 90% of the Adaptation Fund, and we are respected by developing countries. This is not the work of this Commissioner, it is the work of very consistent policies, which justify that the voice of the European Union can sound strong and seek alliances that will be complex in the future. And we will have to build alliances to India, said Mr Eickhout: it is essential to have India, a country that has impressive demography and equally impressive CO2 emissions, such as its demography. We will have to make approximations to the big emitters, to release the reduction of them. Therefore, the challenges ahead are important. Mr Turmes, you know that I fight to have the most ambitious package possible, and you know me well. Therefore, in this endeavour we will be together. I will launch an important package and then, as Mrs Van Brempt has said here, Parliament will also have its responsibilities, starting with the European emission allowance system, which is fundamental for the industrial sectors; following on the fuzzy sectors — agriculture, buildings, transport — and finally developing the technological innovation that allows us to lead energy efficiency and renewable processes in the world. For all this I know that I have this Parliament. It is very pleasant to work on a policy which, at a time of division in the European Union, is a policy that is a policy that attracts unity. There was unity in the Environment Council, under the Slovak Presidency, to launch the ratification process; there has been unity in this Parliament to give its consent to that ratification; there has been unity in parliaments since sixteen European Union parliaments have already ratified this process. And I wanted to say something to Mrs Estefanía Torres Martínez — which I don't think she is — when she criticized the lack of ratification in the country I know: man, I should tell the whole truth. The Government was in operation throughout the past year and an acting government, with the Spanish Constitution, cannot ratify an agreement. But the first act taken by the Government of the country I know best, after the investiture, was to launch the ratification process. This shows that throughout the European Union climate change policies are policies that bring about unity, ambition and hope.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you and I thank all those honourable Members who have spoken. I will not repeat what I stressed at the beginning of this debate, on behalf of the Council. Instead I would like to consider today’s debate because its title was to assess the outcome of Marrakech. That was extremely important, and many thanks to all those who agreed that Marrakech was a success for the European Union. But this debate was more than a stocktaking of what happened in Marrakech. For me the political message from here is to maintain the momentum for our common political commitment to continue the work because we know that what matters at the end of the day is implementation. Secondly, several of you referred to the Council. I dare say that, this year, the Council has delivered, and I thank Commissioner Cañete for reminding us that this was the case. We have been working hard and I am sure I can say that the upcoming Maltese and Estonian Presidencies will be equally committed. By the way, the Slovak Presidency is coming to an end, but we are still working hard and we hope that, at the meeting of the Environment Council in December, we will have an agreement on the ETS. Fourthly and lastly, I would like to thank Parliament for its cooperation throughout the year, including its committed cooperation on the spot in Marrakech, and in particular to thank Mr La Via, Chair of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, for his leadership.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — I welcome the outcome of the Conference of the Parties recently held in Morocco. I believe that adopting growth models compatible with environmental protection is today, as never before in the history of mankind, a top priority. The will of the international community to define, by 2018, a road map to give concrete implementation to the Paris Agreement, constitutes a very important signal of hope for the health and future of the our planet. While there are still several nodes to be resolved, such as the criticalities inherent in the establishment of the Green Climate Fund, I am convinced that the work schedule and the time deadlines set are the testament to a renewed sensitivity in environmental matters by the entire international community, which must make us optimistic.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. – At COP22, parties reaffirmed their collective commitment to implement the Paris Agreement – despite the outcome of the US elections. Unfortunately, the EU has also failed to put forward any new measures to help close the emission gap, to hold global warming to well below 2°C, and to pursue efforts to limit it to 1,5°C. Thus, COP24 in 2018 will be the next moment for countries to increase their ambition and scale up emission reduction pledges, and the EU’s leadership is crucial. We must start walking the talk and prioritise energy transition by ramping up our own policies and inadequate climate and energy targets. To this end, now we need an ambitious energy winter package for 2030 which promotes energy savings and efficiency measures, high renewables penetration as well as proper governance of the Energy Union. However, it seems that EC rather wants to subsidise new fossil fuel capacities and undermine market access for renewables. The credibility of the EU and our common future is at stake. We need to take commitments made in Paris seriously:  substantially reducing GHG emissions in the short term and bringing emissions to zero in the longer term –it is our only chance.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I do not share the optimistic assessment of the results of this COP 22. We criticize the Paris Agreement for limiting itself to voluntary commitments and for setting the temperature reduction to 1.5 °C instead of the 2 °C required by the scientific community. This summit does not go beyond these approaches and, in concrete agreements, the most industrialized countries have once again demonstrated their lack of commitment and vision. On the contrary, this has been the show of companies and finance, with their macroprojects and financial funds with which to parasitize the green economy for its own benefit. Nor has the host, the Kingdom of Morocco, used green propaganda to normalize its occupation of Western Sahara before the international community. I regret that I did not find in your words an explicit condemnation of the new green projects that will delve into the plundering of Saharawi remedies or against the expulsion of Sueilma Beiruk, a Saharawi parliamentary member, which triggered the absence of the entire African Union delegation. Europe lacks its climate commitments, but also, its commitments to peace.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — (PT) The twenty-second session of the Conference of the Parties - COP 22 in Marrakech has ended. The objective of moving forward in the definition of rules for the implementation of the Paris Agreement has not been achieved. An event that should have started with measures to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to climate change has turned into a huge disappointment. The announced Marrakech Charter cannot go beyond recognising that it is necessary to complete the work programme under the Paris Agreement “as soon as possible”, placing as a time limit the COP 24, which will meet at the end of 2018. It was once again clear that the Paris Agreement, which entered into force on 4 November, will only go away from paper with a strong mobilisation of peoples and workers in defence of the environment and the climate, and by transforming our society into another model of development, socialism.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: — Very short on the order of business, President. I do not know if you were told, but yesterday, during the debate in the House, some unjurious words were said: we were referring to the President-elect of the United States by the term clown. I point it out to him not already for the purpose of repression — because we are liberals and do not vote against those who express their views freely, nor do we call for their arrest or trial — but simply for a question of opportunity, knowing your sensitivity to the image of Parliament, so that you take the necessary steps.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We will check what was said at the sitting. If this is incompatible with Parliament's rules, I will logically take action against it.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President! As in previous years, my group has tabled an amendment to the proposed draft calendar for next year. Once again, Mr Schulz, you have declared our amendment inadmissible. The amendment only proposes a daily reduction for the partsession in Strasbourg. In our view, this does not undermine the Treaties or the judgment of the Court. Irrespective of this, the main objective of our amendment was to give Members of this House some control over their own Parliament. We regret, Mr Schulz, that you have decided to present the calendar without a vote.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Madam Honourable Member, I shall not present the calendar without a vote, but I shall present it to the vote. I have declared your amendment inadmissible. This is not the first time. This amendment is objectively inadmissible because you requested that Thursday be deleted. However, we have twice been obliged by the Court of Justice — by the European Court of Justice — to hold the partsession here in Strasbourg 12 times over four days, including Thursday, between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. Since you are a Member from the Federal Republic of Germany, you know that we are obliged to comply with the law, particularly with regard to judgments of the case law of the highest courts. I'll stick to these.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it seems that the majority of the political groups are coming to the conclusion that this Parliament should also postpone the vote on consent for the CETA agreement until December. I think that, if this is confirmed, it is very sensible because we need to deal with it responsibly. One reason why 89 Members have proposed this resolution calling for the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of this agreement – and especially of the investor protection rules – with EU law, is that we need to deal with this responsibly. Referring to Rule 190(4), I would like to suggest, in the name of my Group, that we postpone the vote on this resolution calling for the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with EU law until December.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President! So I think we can vote on this motion here now. I also find Mrs Hautala's view that Parliament would not deal responsibly with this agreement unjustified. The agreement has been negotiated for a year and a half. The committee responsible has been discussing it in a very responsible manner for a long time. I believe that the aim of this proposal by the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance here is to postpone the further steps of the procedure once again without achieving anything in substance. In this respect, I would speak against Mrs Hautala's request. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I shall now put the motion to the vote. It is about postponing the close vote on the motion for a resolution on this opinion. (Interjections) Mrs. Maybe you'll listen before you scream. We are on a voting procedure, we have a point of order here. The Rules of Procedure provide that the request shall be made. The president then asks one or another to talk for it or... (Heckling) No, she clearly did not report. All right, so that you do not say again that I am a terrorist: you have the floor, my colleague. (Interjections)

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: — If I have the opportunity to express my opinion... It is a good idea, and here we are, as the European Parliament, to talk about these important treaties, and you yourself have just said that we should listen to the rulings of the highest court. We must therefore give that body the opportunity to express its opinion on these important treaties which the European judges, the German Richterbund and 100 professors have said are very dubious. We must avoid adopting a treaty that goes against the European legal order.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: – Mr President, I would like it to read as follows: ‘Underlines the need for the European Union to develop a stronger export control regime for security and defence—related goods and services; calls on the Commission in consultation with the EEAS to develop a proposal on how to strengthen the implementation of the eight criteria of common position 994/2008/CFSP on arms exports, under which weapons, ammunition, defence equipment and technologies can be exported to third countries’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, because I was not offered the opportunity to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have contributed to this result and to this report yesterday, I am doing it now. Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: That closes the voting time.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President! I just wanted to get rid of two messages. Firstly, of course, I am pleased that we have already decided on the meetings for the calendar year 2018. Secondly, however, I do not lose hope that this time in 2018 we will be able to organise as many constituency weeks as possible, because the European Parliament must be present on the ground. Members also need time to work in the constituency. This is perhaps once again an appeal to ourselves, to our own administration, to organise the work so efficiently that we can also be present in the constituencies.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I wonder, as a thought experiment, what would happen if this Parliament were suddenly to disappear. Which of our constituents would notice? Which of us would be missed? That may sound like a rather ungenerous way of putting it, so let me phrase it the other way around: consider the immense talent gathered in this Chamber, the great skills and experience brought by people from 28 countries. Wouldn’t it be a wonderful thing if those skills could be released into the private sector to contribute to the economy by making and selling things instead of by regulating them? One great upside of the coming Brexit is that at least British Eurocrats and British MEPs, about whom I have occasionally been rude, will now be redeployed from the unproductive to the productive bit of the economy.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, Parliament’s calendar for 2018 was an issue which was approved without a vote. I would like to confirm, for the record, that if this had been voted on I would have abstained, because I am very hopeful that by 2018 this won’t affect me – I am hopeful that the UK will have left the European Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: In writing. ‒ I consider that the timetable proposed for parliamentary returns in the year 2018 is appropriate, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's timetable for 2018 in a formal procedure to support the proposal drawn up by the parliamentary services and agreed by the various political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. ‒ The draft calendar presented this week for 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg (12 are on the agenda) and limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned).
