We are very important to the seat of Strasbourg, which is officially the only seat of the European Parliament and the only institution of the European Union based in France. We can therefore be satisfied that this project does not disrupt the organisation of Parliament in order to further strengthen the Brussels site, as a number of MEPs do not fail to demand regularly, even launching petitions for the complete abandonment of Strasbourg. In these circumstances, as a Frenchman, supporting this draft calendar can be seen as a way of defending the interests of the city of Strasbourg and France and I therefore supported this proposal.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. — I voted for 2018. the calendar of Parliament's plenary sessions.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. ‒ The draft calendar presented this week for 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg (12 are on the agenda) and limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned). As a Frenchman, we have always defended the seat of Strasbourg, which is officially the only seat of the European Parliament and the only institution of the European Union based in France. We can therefore be satisfied that this project does not disrupt the organisation of Parliament in order to further strengthen the Brussels site, as a number of MEPs do not fail to demand regularly, even launching petitions for the complete abandonment of Strasbourg. In these circumstances, as a Frenchman, supporting this draft calendar can be seen as a way of defending the interests of the city of Strasbourg and France, so that's what I did.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I approved this item

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: In writing. ‒ Having no objection to the draft submitted, today I voted positive to the proposal for a timetable for the parliamentary part-sessions in 2018.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a timetable proposal which I consider appropriate.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: regularly, the presentation of the part-sessions of Parliament tries to strengthen the power of Brussels to the detriment of the seat of Strasbourg. As a French and elected member of the Grand Est region, and even though I am fighting this technocratic EU hard, I consider that the power of Strasbourg should not be diminished compared to Brussels. The usual calendar with the major sessions in Strasbourg and Brussels for mini-sessions still respects the balance. I would therefore be against any repatriation of Parliament's activities to Brussels which would be damaging to local commerce and hotels.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: In writing. ‒ I took note of the resolution on the calendar of part-sessions of the European Parliament for the year 2018.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposed timetable for the European Parliament's part-sessions in 2018.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this document because it was approved in 2018. Calendar of work of the European Parliament.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written. - I support the Report on the schedule of sessions of Parliament for 2018

name: Renata BRIANO
text: ‒ It is a good thing to have the timetable of parliamentary returns at our disposal well in advance, so as to allow each of us to organise in the best way to ensure the maximum presence and participation both in classroom work and on our territories of origin.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. — The draft calendar 2018 aims to maintain the traditional sessions in Strasbourg and to limit mini-sessions in Brussels. As a French Member of the European Parliament, I am, of course, pleased to see that this project does not call into question the existence of Parliament in Strasbourg for the benefit of the Brussels site, as some Members of Parliament do not fail to demand. By supporting this calendar, we are defending the interests of the city of Strasbourg and in a certain way those of France. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I agree with the calendar as proposed and voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We are voting in favour of the calendar of Parliament's 2018 part-sessions, as we agree with the proposed dates.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: In writing. ‒ I welcome the schedule established for parliamentary proceedings in 2018 and am honoured to be able to participate in it.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Parliament’s calendar of part—sessions – 2018.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the calendarization of the parliamentary part-sessions of 2018.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's timetable for 2018 in a formal procedure to support the proposal drawn up by the parliamentary services and agreed by the various political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. — I voted against the adoption of the calendar of the Parliament's monthly sessions for 2018 in view of the different position on the issue relating to the change in the duration of meetings. The calendar presented proposes to increase the time of the plenary meetings in Strasbourg. Having observed Parliament's work system so far and the organisation of working time, I do not see the need to return in this direction. I believe that these changes will not produce an increase in efficiency, but can only delay the decision-making process.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. — The purpose of this vote was to adopt the calendar of parliamentary sessions of Parliament in 2018. I am pleased to see that the number of mini-sessions in Brussels is significantly lower than in previous years; it should be recalled that the only seat of the European Parliament is in Strasbourg. I voted in favour of this timetable.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The draft calendar presented this week for 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg (twelve are on the programme) and limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned). The elected Front National have always supported the continuation of the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, contrary to the requests of other parliamentarians. For this principle alone, we support this calendar.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. — Vote in favour: we can therefore be satisfied that this project does not disrupt the organisation of Parliament and further strengthen the Brussels site.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I approve the Parliament calendar of part—sessions for 2018.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Parliament's calendar for 2018, but I must stress that I would have liked to extend the part-sessions in Strasbourg to Monday to Friday, as it used to be and much more efficient. At the same time, I call for the complete abolition of the completely unnecessary 'mini-plenary sittings' in Brussels. Strasbourg is the seat of the European Parliament — our aim should be to return to this one true 'single seat' and to sell the marodious buildings in Brussels instead of rehabilitating them with billions of dollars.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a timetable proposal which I consider appropriate.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I am pleased with the timetable of the European Parliament's activities for 2018. I believe that this time, the timetable respects the spirit of the Treaties, since twelve plenary sessions are held in Strasbourg and that the July session does not take place during the week of the French National Day as has been the case in the past. On the other hand, I am concerned about the deviations observed this year to increase the agenda of the special sessions in Brussels and to empty those in Strasbourg which, in the long term, would lead to delegitimitimization of the existence of the seat of Parliament in the Alsatian capital. It is a treacherous strategy against which we, the French and all those who respect the Treaties and legalism, should rise with the utmost vehemence.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted for the schedule of Parliament sessions for 2018 because I believe that the proposal is balanced and consistent with current predictions, and to establish a Labour plan for 2018 as soon as possible.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. ‒ The parliamentary calendar for 2018 was voted by a large majority of parliamentarians. I welcome the reduction in the number of “mini plenary sessions” in Brussels from 10 in 2015 to 3 in 2018. I maintain that the European Parliament in Strasbourg, which is its official seat, must be used effectively by concentrating all plenary sessions there and by rationalising expenditure on shuttles between Brussels and Strasbourg. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this timetable, which reduces the mini-sessions in Brussels and thus strengthens the seat in Strasbourg.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - I am voting in favor of the proposal to schedule plenary sessions in 2018. It comes early enough to plan for 2017 accordingly.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Parliament’s calendar of part—sessions for 2018.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the draft provisional timetable for our work for the year 2018. I am indeed delighted with the sharp reduction in the “mini-plenary sessions” scheduled in Brussels, which will only number 3 in number. 2018 (compared to 10 in 2015, 5 in 2016 and 5 also in 2017). It is important that most of our votes take place in plenary session in Strasbourg, the official and sole seat of the European Parliament.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. - The draft calendar presented this week for the year 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg (twelve are on the program) and, on the other hand, limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned). We care a lot about the Strasbourg headquarters, which is officially the only seat of the European Parliament, and the only European Union institution based in France. We can therefore be satisfied that this project does not upset the organization of Parliament to further strengthen the Brussels site, as a certain number of deputies do not fail to demand it regularly, even launching petitions for the complete abandonment of Strasbourg. Under these conditions, as a Frenchman, supporting this calendar project can be seen as a way of defending the interests of the city of Strasbourg and of France and, therefore, I was able to support this proposal.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of the adoption of the calendar of the European Parliament for the year 2018 in a formal procedure to support the proposal drawn up by the parliamentary services and agreed by the different political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the 2018 Parliamentary Session Schedule, because this Schedule, although it adequately and fully promotes the legislative and other parliamentary activities of the European Parliament, nevertheless operates exclusively on the basis of the religious holidays of the Catholic Church and does not take into account Orthodox religious churches, as defined in particular by the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, although a significant number of MEPs and EPs are Christian Orthodox and are therefore Easter holiday.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted for this text. This text maintains the sessions in Strasbourg, and limits the mini-sessions in Brussels, which we support given that Strasbourg is officially the only seat of the European Parliament. It is desirable for France to maintain the only EU institution based on its metropolitan territory and in this sense, this timetable respects our interests.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - The calendar of part-sessions includes the dates of EP meetings. I voted in favor.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - Determining the calendar of its sessions is one of the powers of Parliament. In the proposed calendar for 2018 important national commemorations are respected. It does not propose sessions, neither on May 8, the day of the surrender of the Nazi armies, nor on July 14, the revolutionary beginning of the modern era, nor on November 11, the day of the defeat of German imperialism. We will be able to participate in the ceremonies without being penalized by our absence from the session. I vote for and I strongly encourage this attitude of respect for the important history of Europe.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - The draft calendar presented for the year 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg but limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned). We care a lot about the Strasbourg headquarters, which is officially the only seat of the European Parliament and the only European Union institution based in France. We can therefore be satisfied that this project does not yet strengthen the Brussels site, as a certain number of deputies do not fail to demand it regularly, even launching petitions for the complete abandonment of Strasbourg. Under these conditions, as a Frenchwoman, supporting this calendar project is a way of defending the interests of the city of Strasbourg and of France. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Parliament’s calendar of part sessions for 2018.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of Parliament's 2018 Rules of Procedure.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The draft calendar presented this week for the year 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg (twelve are on the program) and, on the other hand, limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned). We care a lot about the Strasbourg headquarters, which is officially the only seat of the European Parliament and the only European Union institution based in France. We can therefore be satisfied that this project does not upset the organization of Parliament to further strengthen the Brussels site, as a certain number of deputies do not fail to demand it regularly, even launching petitions for the complete abandonment of Strasbourg. Under these conditions, as French people, supporting this calendar project can be seen as a way of defending the interests of the city of Strasbourg and of France and we can therefore support this proposal.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing. - This calendar essentially repeats the calendar of previous years. I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. - I support this new calendar of Parliament session periods, which aims to reduce plenary sessions in Brussels in order to refocus work in plenary in Strasbourg.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the Parliament’s calendar of 2018 part-sessions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - I agree with the 2018 calendar of sessions presented, as it coincides perfectly with the commitments

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The schedule of sessions of the European Parliament for 2018 provides an indicative calendar for planning the main activities of the Parliament and provides a framework for planning the activities of Members during 2018. A novelty compared to the calendars for 2016 and 2017 is the increase in the number of "green weeks" from the current 9 to 10 during which meetings of committees, political groups are not held at the headquarters of the European Parliament in Brussels and Strasbourg. This time is planned for other activities of MPs in their constituencies. The lack of communication with the electoral base and the possibility of presenting European policies that MEPs advocate to their constituents is considered to be the biggest problem in public perception due to the "distance" of MEPs in Brussels from their citizens. Increasing the time we can actively spend in the field with citizens and hear directly from them feedback and wishes regarding the policies we advocate at European level as well as specifically to hear their experiences on the implementation of these policies is a good proposal and I supported the Scheduling of Parliament sessions for 2018.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - The draft calendar presented this week for the year 2018 maintains the traditional sessions in Strasbourg (twelve are on the program) and, on the other hand, limits the mini-sessions in Brussels (only three are planned). I really care about the seat in Strasbourg, which is officially the only seat of the European Parliament. I am therefore satisfied with this draft calendar.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - We have adopted the calendar of plenary sessions of the European Parliament for 2018. It has 15 plenary sessions, including three additional mini-sessions, only in Brussels. In order to save money, we wanted to limit the addition of additional sessions in Brussels, while the agenda in Strasbourg is often insufficiently filled. Our ultimate goal would be to do away with plenary sessions in Brussels. On the other hand, I would like to reiterate the importance of recognizing Strasbourg as the official seat of the European Parliament.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I voted in favor of the proposed calendar for the part-sessions of the European Parliament in 2018.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the calendar of European Parliament part-sessions for 2018. This calendar allows Members in particular to have the time they need to meet citizens and thus voice their concerns in our hemicycle.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing. - I support the proposed document.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - In accordance with the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, it is necessary to approve the calendar of part-sessions for 2018, as provided for in Rule 145. Because it is a matter of formal legality, although related to the internal organization, I voted in favor of the proposed calendar for the period of parliamentary sessions in 2018.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I voted in favor of a calendar proposal that I consider appropriate.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of the adoption of the calendar of the European Parliament for the year 2018 in a formal procedure to support the proposal drawn up by the parliamentary services and agreed by the different political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ There was no vote on this proposal.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality actions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported Parliament's calendar of part-sessions for 2018, because, despite the reservations of many EU citizens, but also of us Members, we must abide by the existing treaties and meet 12 times in Strasbourg. The monthly removal from Brussels to Strasbourg of 751 deputies, assistants, officials, ... costs a considerable amount from the EU budget. But in order for this to change, all EU Member States must agree, including France, where plenary sessions take place. To save money, we tried to reduce the meetings in Strasbourg by setting one meeting for Monday and Tuesday, we did not negotiate on Wednesday and then a second meeting on Thursday and Friday. In doing so, we wanted to comply with the article of the treaty that sets out the Strasbourg meeting 12 times a year, but de facto we would only travel 6 times. This was ultimately challenged by the European Court of Justice, and although it met twice, only one meeting counted. The alternation of weeks when committees, political groups and plenary sessions are a good system, because it is sufficient time to prepare, discuss and discuss motions for resolutions before we vote in plenary.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposed calendar of part-sessions of the European Parliament for 2018 and thus also supported the proposal, as it seemed good and sensible to me.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The calendar of activities of the European Parliament shall be established annually on a proposal from the Conference of Presidents. It contains twelve four-day sessions in Strasbourg, 6 two-day sessions in Brussels, two weeks a month for parliamentary committees and interparliamentary delegations, one week a month for political groups and 4 weeks a year for MEPs to work and work in their constituencies.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - It is a common parliamentary practice.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposed timetable, which is broadly in line with our demands to carry out our work in an optimal and more efficient manner.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the "Proposed Schedule of Sessions for 2018". I believe that the timeframe of the envisaged schedule will adequately correspond to all the obligations and tasks set before the institution of the European Parliament according to the legal framework of the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I voted against because I strongly oppose unnecessary waste of taxpayers' money on travel between the two seats of the European Parliament because in the same way without any logical justification approximately 180 million euros are spent annually, which could certainly be spent on countless useful and necessary projects . I also oppose the persistent rejection of amendments by which my parliamentary group proposes at least shortening the plenary sessions in Strasbourg as a form of compromise solution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the calendar of Parliament's part-sessions for 2018.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of a calendar proposal that I consider appropriate.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. - Technical decision, which I supported.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I voted in favor of a calendar proposal that I consider appropriate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Parliament’s calendar of part-sessions for 2018 because I do not have any objections to the schedule of the Parliament’s part-sessions for 2018.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of the adoption of the calendar of the European Parliament for the year 2018 in a formal procedure to support the proposal drawn up by the parliamentary services and agreed by the different political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - To approve this calendar for 2018, when we face a huge social and political storm whose outcome is impossible to predict is always an uncomfortable gesture. The EU suffers from obvious contradictions. The blindness of the institutions and the refusal to state the obvious has only aggravated the crisis and allows foreseeing a black horizon and raises the eventual uselessness of this vote.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written. - There is no objection to the draft Parliament's calendar of meetings for 2018. That is why I approved this draft.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ While of course I support the Parliament continuing its important democratic work representing the citizens of the European Union, I would like to use this opportunity to register my opposition to the European Parliament’s Strasbourg seat. Together with an overwhelming majority of my MEP colleagues, I support a single seat for the European Parliament, doing its important work in Brussels.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the proposed schedule of sessions of the European Parliament in 2018. The new calendar shows a change compared to 2017 in the number of weeks that MPs spend in the field. In 2018, MPs will be able to spend an extra week in activities they organize outside of parliament and this is an advantage for getting to know and collaborating with the base, spotting existing problems and working on solving them.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Mr President, there are votes that are a matter of common sense and democratic decency. Today we are before a Treaty whose legality we question not only many MEPs and civil society, but also the judges themselves and even the German Constitutional Court. We voted today in favor of an issue that, as I was saying, is common sense. We want the European Court of Justice to rule, to decide, whether CETA is legal or not. It is unacceptable that some who call themselves Democrats, Social Democrats and Christian Democrats have voted no. You vote no because you fear that the Court will say what we all know: that CETA grants extraordinary and exclusive rights to companies and not to people, and that this threatens the equality of all before the law, which is a fundamental principle of the rule of law. And that's why it's illegal. His has been a vote of fear, fear of the truth, and of legality and democracy.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - If the proposed economic and trade agreement between Canada and the European Union (CETA) enters into force, we know that it would have catastrophic effects in many of the Member States. Furthermore, as it is structured, it acts outside the judicial system of the Member States and gives even more power to multinationals, which already have too much power. For these reasons I, my colleagues from the 5-star Movement and other Members have requested the opinion of the Court of Justice, which is the body responsible for assessing compliance with the European Union treaties. To show that agreements like CETA are illegal, I voted in favor.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted in favor of this motion because the Trade Agreement between Canada and the Union (CETA) raises serious legal problems that the CJEU should resolve before its implementation. As national authorities and courts have stated, CETA creates institutions such as arbitration tribunals (which allow foreign multinationals to obtain financial compensation for any regulatory change that affects them, putting their benefits before democratic rights) or the bodies of regulatory cooperation (in which multinationals intervene directly in the legislative process) that negatively affect state powers. It is therefore a legal requirement that the CJEU rule on the legislative scope of CETA and that it does not enter into force until it is voted favorably in each Member State. CETA is a treaty that will very negatively affect the rights of European workers, the financial and economic stability, environmental protection and democracy itself. I deeply regret that for a majority of Members of this House its approval, for the benefit of big capital, is so urgent as to want to avoid even the most elementary legal debates and protocols.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which called to refer the EU-Canada Comprehensive and Economic Trade Agreement (CETA) to the European Court of Justice. This comes following opinions by judges, legal practitioners and academics (including Irish) that Chapter 8 on Investment Protection, which establishes a Permanent Investment Court, is contrary to the EU judicial order as laid out in Article 19 of the TEU. The issue lies in the fact that this new court, established outside the existing judicial framework, which is not answerable to nor overseen by the CJEU or the national courts cannot be compatible with the EU Treaties. The European Parliament reserves the right to refer any International Agreement to the European Court of Justice for an opinion via Article 218(11) TFEU before it gives its consent.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing. - I voted for the referral to the Court of Justice of the European Union. This vote is a defeat for transparency and for democracy! The content of the CETA agreement is still surrounded by legal uncertainties that should be dispelled: what is the legal weight of the 38 additional declarations included at the end of the standoff led by Wallonia? Is the regulatory cooperation mechanism constitutional? Is the new Investment Dispute Settlement (ICS) system compatible with European law? I regret the choice made by a majority in the European Parliament to reject this referral. It is a political error! In doing so, Parliament leaves it to others to do what it should have done itself, on behalf of all European citizens.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution on the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the provisions of the Treaties of the forthcoming Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (IEPA) Agreement between Canada and the European Union. I very much regret that some Members of the European Parliament are trying to downplay the importance of the IEPS for the EU and Canada and to create as many obstacles as possible to the entry into force of this agreement. I firmly believe that the IEPS is one of the best and most useful international agreements concluded by the EU to date. IEPS will undoubtedly benefit EU citizens, contribute to the economic growth and business development of the EU Member States and, at the same time, Canada.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - This is a motion for a resolution by the European Parliament aimed at obtaining an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with the Treaties. Alongside my colleagues, I also believe that there is legal uncertainty as to whether the proposed agreement complies with the Treaties, and in particular with Article 19 of the Treaty on European Union and Articles 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and would very much like to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties. I regret that there was no majority in Parliament for this request. Regardless, I remain a staunch opponent of this agreement in its current form.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - This text determines whether CETA is compatible with European treaties, in particular as regards the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU). If we are not in favor of the CJEU, which reduces our sovereignty, I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution which would waste time in the application of the dangerous CETA treaty since it will be necessary to await the judgment of the CJEU.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ If CETA were a genuine move towards free trade, and one which was designed to benefit working people, then I would be fully supportive of it. Free trade is important for economic development, and indeed one of the arguments for Brexit is that it will enable us to negotiate free trade deals with countries around the world. However, CETA appears to be another deal which will support big business whilst hampering small business, and I have huge concerns about the proposed investor-state dispute resolution provisions. In the current case, I voted in favour of the resolution (and, in effect, against CETA) for three reasons: 1. The European Union must not break its own rules, and therefore legal questions should be resolved first. 2. If legal questions are not resolved before the adoption of CETA, it creates the potential for confusion and loss of business. 3. Regardless, this vote would in any case have served to cause a delay in the implementation of a bad deal.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because basically I want a break in the negotiation of free trade agreements. These only make sense in relation to a vision and a project for Europe. I do not intend to approve CETA then. On the other hand, I believe that Parliament should dispense with having recourse to the judge to decide its political options.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution requesting the Court of Justice to give an opinion on the compatibility with the provisions of the Treaties of the forthcoming Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (IEPA) between Canada and the European Union. This comprehensive economic and trade agreement between the EU and Canada is crucial for promoting trade and strengthening economic relations, which will contribute to the creation and growth of new jobs. I believe that this agreement must be implemented as soon as possible, which is why I voted against this proposed resolution, which would make it more difficult to implement the IEPS agreement.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - Eighty-nine Members have tabled a proposal for a decision instituting proceedings before the European Court of Justice concerning the compatibility of the EU-Canada Free Trade Agreement (CETA) with the EU Treaties. In particular, they sought the opinion of the court on the Investor-State Dispute Settlement Mechanism (ISDS). This procedure provides an opportunity for global companies to sue member states in an arbitrated private court if they consider that a state restriction on their activities has caused them a loss of profit. The restriction may be for environmental, public health or other socio-economic reasons, in the enforcement of which a sovereign government acts under the authority of the population. Nevertheless, its decision can be challenged, and in many cases the said court proceedings award significant sums to the investment firm. The European Parliament was shockingly rejected by 419 votes to 258, with 22 abstentions. motion. This has made it clear that non-voters represent the interests of global economic actors, even at the price that the international agreement they support may be contrary to the EU's founding treaties. Of course, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We supported this resolution because we see both CETA and TTIP as part of the globalisation of crony capitalism and primarily benefitting ‘big business’ rather than people.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. - I obviously voted for this motion for a resolution: it is indeed a question of ensuring that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of disputes between investors and States is compatible with articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services within the Union and to third States, Court of Justice of the European Union European). Basically, I remain opposed to CETA, better known by its English acronym “CETA”, little brother of the disastrous PTCI (in English TTIP or TAFTA).

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - Despite the clear improvements obtained by Wallonia and Belgium's commitment to seek an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the ICS with the European treaties, it seemed to me appropriate that the European Parliament itself, in as the representative of 500 million Europeans, asks the Court of Justice to verify the compatibility of this trade agreement between the Union and Canada and in particular of the settlement of trade disputes in matters of investment (ICS) with the European treaties . I therefore supported this resolution which carried this request. However, the Assembly rejected this request.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - The initiative to bring CETA before the Court of Justice of the European Union is an attempt at obstructionism. If we did it with all the laws, it would be impossible to advance, legislate and govern. In Europe, in Spain, in any town hall. The European Parliament has its legal services with good professionals. There has been a democratic process of debate and processing. Still, it is legitimate to go to court if it is believed that an approved law or agreement violates the law. Whoever believes so, report it. I am in favor of the excellent EU-Canada trade agreement. I think it is good for Europeans. I do not accept that it is a question of delegitimizing and insulting those of us who think this way. I believe that free trade is positive, because it brings prosperity and progress, and is compatible with social progress and respect for human rights. And I know, because history supports it, that protectionism and tariffs impoverish. However, of course, I respect those who they disagree, from Trump to Podemos.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution, rejected by Parliament, which called for an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of CETA with the Treaties. The global economic and trade agreement between Canada and the EU undoubtedly represents an important result obtained by the Commission: however, it also contains some provisions that could, in my opinion, generate situations of interference with the prerogative of the Community institutions, and governments, to legislate on central issues such as the protection of health or the environment. The greatest perplexities are related to sections D and F of Chapter 8 of the agreement, relating to the protection of investments and the resolution of investment disputes between investors and States. Above all, the establishment of supranational private courts for the arbitration of conflicts between states and multinationals, is in my opinion an argument particularly delicate, which would have deserved a legal study by the Court.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - The compatibility of the CETA ICS with the European legal system has been questioned by associations of lawyers from all over Europe. I have voted in favor of asking the European Court to give an opinion on the matter. It seems to us that it is a matter that goes beyond being in favor or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: granting the European Court of Justice the role that it deserves and, not running the risk that a treaty that contains an instrument that could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written. - I have voted against this request to consult the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the CETA Agreement. Consultations have already been made by the legal services, both of the European Parliament and the Commission, and also by some of the Supreme Courts of the Member States, such as Germany. Those who now make this proposal and the organizations that oppose this treaty or the TTIP have not sent to the Court episodes such as those that some member states have carried out using ISDS against others in the framework of bilateral treaties and now intend to send this Treaty that incorporates the deepest revision and improvement of this system ever made.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I voted for the motion for a resolution asking the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of CETA with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Indeed, this proposal calls for referral to the Court of Justice of the European Union to verify that CETA is compatible with the European treaties. Our group is fiercely opposed to CETA. Accordingly, we are in favor of anything that might delay its implementation.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution asking the Court of Justice to rule on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Agreement between Canada and the European Union on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). This Europe is finalizing an agreement with Canada, which will go against the economies of our territories, against our agriculture, against a Veneto and Italian market model based on the quality of our excellence that risks being swept away by the Canadian multinationals that they want to appropriate our "know-how". CETA must be stopped immediately, before it comes to eliminate our economy and our agri-food sector with the consequent loss of thousands of jobs in our regions.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it asks Parliament to give an opinion to the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the provisions of the Treaties of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (IEPA) between Canada and the European Union.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Today's vote was on a point of order on the free trade agreement between Canada and the European Union. The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance. In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution because, after a detailed examination of the legal arguments available, I found that these dilemmas cited by the proponents had already been clarified. The relevant committees, which have been working on the agreement for several years, have already legally verified the agreement's compliance with our acquis, and no deviations have been found by the European Parliament's Legal Service, which, as an independent body, provided a comprehensive explanation of this opinion. Obtaining the opinion of an EU court would be at least a two-year delay in the entry into force of the CETA agreement, and under EU law this court also has completely different jurisdictions. Therefore, I do not see any added value in this request other than delaying the matter indefinitely, and the EU would continue to gain a bad reputation as an incompetent and unreliable negotiator and partner in the world.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because there is no need to seek an opinion from the Court of Justice on the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between the EU and Canada if the one issued by the legal service of the Parliament already provide enough safety and the confirmation that the CETA is not against European Law.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report to seek the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the Canada-EU Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with the treaties. There are many concerns related to CETA: the negotiations have been carried out in complete secrecy and the conclusions could have very negative effects on our democratic processes and risk hitting public services and workers' rights hard. Unfortunately, the Parliament voted by a majority against the acceptance of the request. Had it been upheld, the Court could have ruled on issues related to the Investment Court System (ICS), which will guarantee foreign investors the ability to sue states if they issue regulations or legislation that jeopardize their business expectations. Indeed, the establishment of supranational private courts for the arbitration of conflicts between states and multinationals seem to be in conflict with the EU treaties because it essentially denies national sovereignty and bypasses ordinary justice. I consider it paradoxical that, in the face of all these doubts of legitimacy, we want to push for the immediate implementation of CETA.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We supported this resolution because we see both CETA and TTIP as part of the globalisation of crony capitalism and primarily benefitting ‘big business’ rather than people.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for a resolution as I believe that this resolution would unnecessarily disrupt and delay the process of implementation of CETA and would be harmful to CETA, as well as EU trade policy as a whole. Such a motion for a resolution would also signal to other countries with which the European Union intends to negotiate and sign trade agreements with, that the European Union is becoming a less open economy and is not a reliable partner to negotiate with.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - Asking the compatibility of a treaty concluded by the EU with a third country is one of the prerogatives of Parliament. In particular, the agreement between the EU and Canada raises multiple issues of primary importance for European citizens, which we have repeatedly denounced. I therefore voted in favor of asking the Court of Justice for an opinion without the slightest doubt.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing. - I abstained from voting on this opinion mainly because it was not an answer to questions that CETA may ask on the substance and far from me the desire to participate in an ideological vote. I do not have a firm position on CETA, because in my opinion there is too much evidence to say or not in all conscience in its favor. This treaty can bring beneficial things to the European Union. However, I regret that Parliament is not more clearly involved and I believe that it is necessary to wait until we have new concrete elements before taking a decision. This is not an opinion of the Court of Justice, however judicious it may be, which will answer all the economic and social questions that European citizens are entitled to ask themselves, just like me.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution which expresses the view that there is no legal certainty as to whether the CETA agreement is compatible with European law and considers the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties necessary. The consequences of the ratification of the forthcoming CETA agreement - a hasty and opaque vote in the European Parliament - will hit labor relations, the rural economy, the environment, the public health sector and public services as a whole in all Member States of the European Union and especially the financially weakest. Such free trade agreements and the resulting social dumping are a clear threat to subject to transatlantic negotiations with a view to reducing them to the benefit of multinational trade. The fight against CETA and TTIP, but also the forces that promote them, must continue by all possible means.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: in writing. - For the Social Democrats, it is the blood of the heart to be vigilant about workers' rights, the highest environmental, food and public health standards and the right to legislate freely. None of these we would ever buy - neither for a trade agreement nor for any other agreement. Therefore, we have also worked actively to ensure that effective protections and guarantees were put in place for these. And to ensure as democratic and transparent a process as possible. That work has borne fruit, and it is now stated - in black and white - in the consolidated text of the agreement on CETA between the EU and Canada that neither Canada, the EU nor Denmark in any way lose the right to legislate as they wish, and that no one existing courts in neither Denmark nor the EU will have their work or mandate curtailed. In addition to the guarantees in the agreement itself, there is already an assessment by the European Parliament's legal service confirming that the agreement contains safeguards against these matters. Against that background we have voted against the resolution to postpone the CETA agreement for up to two years while awaiting a ruling from the European Court of Justice. Such an opinion is already under way, as the Belgian region of Wallonia will demand one.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We are voting against the report, as we maintain significant disagreements with certain points in the report.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the resolution calling for the Court to rule on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union. As this is a very important issue that needs thorough research, I decided to vote in favor.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - Among the many discontents that an agreement of the proportions of CETA can arouse, certainly, the legal one cannot be counted. Confirmation of this assumption can not only be found starting from the already complete and exhaustive legal verification completed on 29 February, but also from the absence of incompatibility with the treaties of the proposed global economic and trade agreement between Canada and the European Union and especially with the aforementioned articles 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In fact, CETA cannot be considered adverse to the freedom of establishment postulated by article 49, which facilitates access to autonomous activities and their exercise. Just as it remains understood that the status of companies incorporated in accordance with the law of a Member State and having their registered office, central administration or principal place of business in the EU is comparable to that of natural persons having citizenship European. Likewise, there is nothing contrary to the principle established by Article 340, according to which the contractual liability of the Union is governed by the law applicable to the contract in question. Consistently with the foregoing, I reject the proposal and hope that where CETA may present gaps or well-founded doubts, there will be an effective intervention.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for resolution on an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). CETA should be implemented very soon so that EU citizens and business can reap the benefits of the agreement.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The free trade agreement between the European Union and Canada represents a milestone in the European Union's trade policy, eliminating more than 99% of the customs duties currently imposed on trade between the EU and Canada. I understand the concerns of citizens and businesses, but there are no perfect agreements, and I am sure that it will be easier for the Union as a whole to protect our interests than for each individual Member State. In a context in which some of the most influential countries in the world turn to nationalism and protectionist measures, there is a need to respond with more international trade, which translates into economic growth and job creation. The legal objections in which this resolution is based seem to me to be more based on the political will to hinder the agreement than on a concern to violate the Treaties. In addition, both the legal services of the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament were consulted in the matter and expressed their opinion on the compatibility of the provisions of the Agreement with the EU Treaties.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The CETA agreement between Canada and the European Union is illegal, as it fears the establishment of a supranational court to the detriment of the judicial system of the various Member States, benefiting multinationals. We, for our part, asked for an opinion from the European Court of Justice on this, so that the illegality of this agreement could be recognized, but our proposal was rejected in the parliamentary vote. In any case, I have expressed my vote on the CETA agreement, and it is clearly negative.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted in favor of this motion because the Trade Agreement between Canada and the Union (CETA) raises serious legal problems that the CJEU should resolve before its implementation. As national authorities and courts have stated, CETA creates institutions such as arbitration tribunals (which allow foreign multinationals to obtain financial compensation for any regulatory change that affects them, putting their benefits before democratic rights) or the bodies of regulatory cooperation (in which multinationals intervene directly in the legislative process) that negatively affect state powers. It is therefore a legal requirement that the CJEU rule on the legislative scope of CETA and that it does not enter into force until it is voted favorably in each Member State. CETA is a treaty that will very negatively affect the rights of European workers, the financial and economic stability, environmental protection and democracy itself. I deeply regret that for a majority of Members of this House its approval, for the benefit of big capital, is so urgent as to want to avoid even the most elementary legal debates and protocols.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution to ask the Court of Justice of the EU to review the compatibility of the CETA agreement with the European Union Treaties. The presented opinion is too liberal in the interpretation of the provisions and provisions contained in the contract. Legal experts who have worked on the interpretation of the rules believe that CETA does not affect the legal framework, EU competences or fundamental treaty rights. The legal teams of the European Parliament that investigated the compliance issue found no contradiction between the CETA investment chapter and the EU treaties. In view of the above, I do not consider it necessary to re-examine this case.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the request to ask for an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) as a European Parliament Legal Service opinion has already been made. My vote is conditional on the decision that Parliament  will provide more time for a proper analysis of the agreement to ensure that that the European Parliament’s various committees, including the Environment Committee, will be given the opportunity to analyse the agreement and submit their informed opinion.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution is an attempt to delay the implementation of the trade agreement with Canada by asking for an additional and unnecessary legal opinion, with the sole purpose of delaying the introduction of the trade deal. I cannot support an attempt to hold up the trade agreement, as doing so could cost UK exporters millions of pounds in lost exports and extra import duties and penalise UK consumers by forcing them to pay additional taxes and tariffs on goods imported from Canada.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. - CETA is an agreement that would have a very strong impact on the lives of European citizens. Public services would be permanently provided "at the highest level of liberalization", with the logic of competitiveness, the market and the pursuit of profit by companies. The interests of citizens, the quality of the services themselves and the benefits for society would be entirely marginal or non-existent. More than 3 million European citizens took action last year with a European Citizens' Initiative to stop TTIP and CETA and MEPs have a duty to give them a voice, taking due account of their concerns and their will. Transparency, democracy, public services and the environment are as important as trade. The perspective of the latter cannot prevail to the detriment of the protection of the rights and health of over half a billion Europeans. For this reason and in consideration of the opinion of the Court of justice on the compatibility of CETA with the European Treaties, my vote is positive.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - I voted firmly against the resolution on requesting an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the comprehensive economic and trade agreement between Canada and the European Union (CETA). I consider this resolution to be purely instrumental, presented with the sole objective of delaying the ratification by the European Parliament of the CETA agreement and, therefore, delaying its provisional application. The request in question refers in particular to the compatibility of the provisions relating to the settlement of investment disputes or the new ICS mechanism, compatibility that Belgium has already officially declared it wishes to verify before the final entry into force of the agreement. I would also like to remind you that the provisions in question have clearly been excluded from provisional application and that the Council and the Commission have reaffirmed their commitment to continue the work technical improvement of the ICS system in the direction that Parliament has requested. We need more clarity and transparency in commercial policy and the decision-making processes that accompany it, especially with regard to an increasingly interested and attentive public opinion. In this regard, it will be necessary to relaunch the role of the European Parliament as guarantor of democratic scrutiny and work to build an increasingly regulated, inclusive and fair globalization.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This resolution, tabled by 89 deputies, proposes to refer the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA, or CETA in English) to the Court of Justice of the European Union in order to verify its compatibility with European law. Union. Considering that the legal service of the European Parliament has found no contradiction between the content of CETA, in particular the chapter on investments, and the European treaties, and that this resolution has the sole aim of slowing down the process of ratification of CETA, j I voted with my colleagues from the French EPP delegation against this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing. - I voted against the motion for a resolution requesting the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of the agreement between Canada and the European Union known as the "comprehensive economic and trade agreement" (CETA) with treaties. Parliament's legal services have already been mobilized to respond to the same fears as those set out in this motion for a resolution and have already confirmed the compatibility of the provisions provided for by CETA with our treaties. The CETA agreement with Canada represents a great opportunity for citizens and businesses of the Union. We must speed up the process to submit the text to a vote in Parliament as quickly as possible and put an end to the political maneuvers by opponents of this agreement to delay its implementation.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution which asks for an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the trade agreement between the European Union and Canada with the European treaties. This request is an initiative of the firm opponents of CETA, who accuse the Commission of not having respected the treaties in the negotiations of this agreement, which is not the reality. CETA is a quality agreement, which will allow our companies to access Canadian public markets, while protecting our agricultural and food models, thanks to the recognition of European geographical indications, for example. The European Union is the world's leading trading power and it must not isolate itself. The opening of our markets represents important opportunities for a large number of sectors; it is also an opportunity to allow European standards to become international standards.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Today's vote was on a point of order on the free trade agreement between Canada and the European Union. The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance. In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution requesting the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on the CETA agreement in order to remove the legal uncertainties surrounding the new system of settlement of investment-related disputes, including the compatibility with treaties is raised. The majority of Parliament did not make this choice. Yet it would have reassured public opinion and European citizens, very divided on the issue of CETA. The CJEU's opinion would have provided the necessary clarity.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I voted against the dilatory request of 89 MEPs seeking the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on the conformity of the provisions of the free trade treaty between the European Union and the Canada (CETA) with the law of European treaties. I consider that it is unthinkable to block indefinitely an agreement negotiated for 7 years, which has been validated by the governments of the Member States representing more than 500 million Europeans and whose legal compatibility with European law has already been the subject three analyzes which confirmed that in this case, CETA has no consequences on our legal framework, on the competences of the Union or on our constitutional rights. I am, however, anxious to respect the intra-Belgian agreement recently obtained and in particular the possibility available to the Belgian government to question the CJEU on the precise point of the compatibility of the mode of conflict resolution (ICS) with the European treaties. I consider it to be in everyone's interest to definitively clarify this point.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - I voted for this text. This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure the compatibility of CETA, in particular as regards the protection of investments, with the freedoms defined under the terms of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. We are fiercely opposed to this free trade treaty, and hope that this procedure brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union will make it possible to slow down the implementation of this treaty.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of this resolution. I am definitely looking forward to the "Opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union (CETA)", which obliges Parliament to suspend its agreement procedure. Personally, I do not agree with the idea that the opinion of the European Parliament's legal services is sufficient. An agreement of this magnitude is not sufficient and legally adequate, assessed only through the EP Legal Service. This assessment cannot replace a court judgment or a national legal assessment. The European Court of Justice is the right binding instrument for issuing an opinion. National parliaments have not even started, nor have they had enough time Canada. In addition, according to the procedural rules for the negotiation and implementation of this type of international agreement, the necessary assessment of each Member State is pending, which will make its individual analysis at national level, after which the procedure for ratification and implementation of CETA could begin. , and without proper ex ante evaluation, only more political and procedural issues arise.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- The proposed EU-Canada Economic / Trade Agreement is not compatible with the Treaties, especially in the areas of investment protection and dispute resolution between investors and states.The agreement must be broken.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the free trade agreement between Canada and the European Union.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution to ask the European Court of Justice to rule whether CETA is compatible with the EU Treaties. I have been contacted by many hundreds of my constituents in Wales asking for the Parliament’s support for this move. With CETA, as with all trade deals, there has to be absolute certainty of compliance with EU law.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- The EU-Canada Trade Agreement has been negotiated for many years, and the Commission has been keen to keep the process as open and transparent as possible.The trade agreement provides great export opportunities for European companies, provides opportunities for better economic development in the EU and Canada and strengthens the important transatlantic link.The agreement contains more progressive dimensions than the already existing trade agreements.The report calls on the European Court of Justice to examine whether the trade agreement is compatible with the Treaties.I believe that the legal assessment of the trade agreement carried out by the Commission is fully sufficient and have therefore chosen to vote against the report.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- I voted for this text, which aims to determine whether CETA is compatible with the European treaties (Court of Justice of the European Union).

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This resolution is being presented at a time when the European Parliament and the other EU institutions intend to impose, at all costs, on the Member States, the Global Economic and Trade Agreement between the European Union and Canada - CETA. The EU is preparing to bring this Treaty into force, which has very serious impacts on many productive sectors, on employment, the environment and public health. It is preparing to do so following opaque negotiations and through a process that constitutes disrespect for democracy and the sovereignty of States. We recall here the web of pressures and blackmail on the people in Europe who have raised their voices against this agreement, which represents, moreover, an attempt to bring TTIP (negotiated in parallel with CETA) and US companies in Europe through the door. . Having no illusions about the nature of the EU Court of Justice, its role and, above all, the content of the Treaties that frame its action, we support this request as a way to prolong the period of clarification, mobilization and struggle of the populations against this Treaty which represents an intolerable social and economic setback.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe this proposed agreement must be tested under European law given it has far reaching consequences if ever enacted.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the resolution calling for the involvement of the Court of Justice to verify the compatibility with the treaties of the text resulting from the trade agreement (CETA) between the EU and Canada.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing.- I consider the Transatlantic Economic and Trade Agreement with Canada (CETA) to be an additional component of the security architecture and deepening of the transatlantic ties, as evidenced by the strategic partnership agreement signed in parallel.The arbitration mechanism, which is most often raised as an obstacle, will be subject to separate ratification in the Polish Sejm.The agreement respects the existing restrictions in Polish and EU law regarding agricultural trade, such as the non-release of GMOs.However, it eliminates customs duties and other non-tariff barriers, increasing the competitiveness of Polish goods.I share the view of fellow ECR colleagues who are against further attempts to delay the vote on CETA, especially after unanimous agreement has been reached by the 28 Member States.The position of the Polish government in this matter is also clear.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- The proposed EU-Canada Economic / Trade Agreement is not compatible with the Treaties, especially in the areas of investment protection and dispute resolution between investors and states.That is why I am voting against the Court's Opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: signed up.- The geostrategic component of CETA is important for Romania not only from an economic point of view, but also from a broader perspective of EU-Canada and Romania-Canada bilateral relations.I therefore rejected the motion for a resolution on the request for the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of CETA with European law to allow for the provisional application of an important part of the agreement as early as 2017. I consider that a request by the EPof the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) would have led to the prolongation of the uncertainty regarding the position of the European Parliament (and implicitly of the EU as a whole) regarding CETA.I therefore consider that this initiative is not appropriate, given the statement already annexed to CETA in which Belgium has clearly stated its intention to seek the opinion of the CJEU.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the Canada-EU Free Trade Agreement.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on this or any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted against the motion for a resolution considering that the Global Economic Agreement Treaty planned between the EU and Canada already has all possible democratic control mechanisms.In the same way, I consider that after the multiple filters that it has had to go through, there is no legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the Agreement envisaged with the Treaties, in particular Article 19 of the Treaty on European Union and with Articles 49,54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.We have to bear in mind that trade agreements, if they are fair and respect environmental and labor legislation, etc.of the Union, can bring benefits for society as a whole.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as citizens' representatives, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to the CETA investment court system will not be provisionally applied if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- The "Opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed Agreement between Canada and the European Union on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with the Treaties" requires a repeated, lengthy examination of the CETA agreement by the European Court of Justice.As a representative of the Family Party of Germany, I am against the CETA agreement in its current form - but I also think that further legal and political games are the wrong way to go.CETA deserves a clear decision.It takes political courage - but we should trust ourselves instead of employing lawyers again.That is why I abstained from this vote.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- We must not delay the CETA agreement any further, as CETA is estimated to create a surplus of around 12 billion euros annually and around 230,000 new jobs in the European Union.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I backed this motion. CETA and TTIP are being created to benefit big business and I have concerns about the investor dispute resolution provisions, to which I object strongly. The issue is the ECJ opinion is more complicated – I am often concerned about the motivation, impact and consequence of such ECJ rulings. However, I believed it was reasonable to ask for an early ruling and I am disappointed that it didn’t pass.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this initiative given that Parliament’s legal service has already given assurances concerning the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties in March 2016. The Council moreover decided to exclude parts of the investment protection provisions and of ICS from the provisional application of CETA.
