The Canadian Government, the Commission and the Council have taken explicit commitments to continue the technical work on the establishment of the ICS-system in the direction that we as social democrats put forward. We all share the objective of having a sound public system in place which corresponds to the criteria we have established in our position paper from February 2015. We have therefore an interest not to stop the process now with a referral to the European Court of Justice.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - I voted for the referral to the Court of Justice of the European Union to verify the compatibility of CETA with European treaties, even if this desperate attempt to buy time was doomed in advance to failure. This failure is in itself a scandal and proves that the “UMPS” majority - if I may say so - in this Parliament fears that major incompatibilities may indeed be revealed. This comprehensive trade agreement with Canada is the draft of the transatlantic treaty (TTIP) that the Commission continues to want to negotiate with the United States. It has all the vices, but is curiously considered by some, including François Hollande, as less dangerous because concluded with a partner deemed less predatory and more loyal. This is to quickly forget that Canada has been linked since 1994 to the United States, as well as to Mexico, by a free trade agreement, NAFTA. The election of Mr. Trump has raised tremendous hope for the death of TTIP, rejected by a large majority of European and American citizens. Ratifying CETA would be tantamount to betraying the populations once again by reintroducing, in a hypocritical and roundabout manner, the wolf into the fold. And that will be the exclusive responsibility of this Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- The compatibility of the CETA ICS with the European legal system has been questioned by associations of lawyers from all over Europe.I have voted in favor of asking the European Court to give an opinion on the matter.It seems to us that it is a matter that goes beyond being in favor or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: granting the European Court of Justice the role that it deserves and, not running the risk of a law entering into force.treaty that contains an instrument that could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - I abstained from voting on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the decision to seek the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on the conclusion of a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement. such a request would have both positive and negative aspects. First, it would prevent the provisional application of the agreement and would have the consequence of prolonging the uncertain situation regarding the European Parliament's position on CETA. Canada is an important economic partner for the European Union. Impeding the provisional application of the agreement could have negative effects from an economic and political point of view, including regarding the implementation of the provisions related to the elimination of visas for Romanian citizens. On the other hand, I did not wish to consider that I did not wish to allow the Court of Justice to examine the compatibility of the agreement with the Treaties. We considered it good to be sure that there are no incompatibilities in the agreement that could harm Member States and SMEs.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, because it is important to take responsibility for taking a decision on whether to support or not the ratification of CETA and not delay the decision for at least two years.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - Serious doubts weigh on the legal validity of CETA: it is to dispel these doubts that I voted in favor of the request for referral to the Court of Justice, before being able to pronounce on this agreement. This question is too important for us to let any uncertainty remain. I believe it is necessary to clarify that there can be no transfer from public deliberation to opaque negotiations, through the ICS - this new dispute settlement mechanism created to help settle disputes between investors. , almost exclusively multinational firms, and States. Very serious doubts remain as to the compatibility of CETA with European Union treaties. Only the Court of Justice can truly establish this. This is essential to regain the confidence of our citizens. This is about fighting so that the regulation of globalization no longer comes at the expense of democratic principles.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the free trade agreement between Canada and the European Union.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be voted on by the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision on the substance will be taken.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ As one of the authors of the resolution I strongly supported this motion. I believe it is essential to refer the Canadian trade deal to the European Court of Justice in order to establish if the Commission’s Investment Court System proposal is compatible with the EU treaties. This is the first EU trade deal which includes a form of ISDS and is with a country that has as robust and developed a judicial system as our own. These Investor Protection Courts appoint their own judges and are not answerable to national or EU courts. President Juncker in one of his first speeches in the Parliament said ‘my Commission will not accept that the jurisdiction of courts in the EU Member States be limited by special regimes for investor-state disputes’ yet this is precisely what is happening. Ireland is the only country in the EU which does not have these Investor Protection Courts in any bilateral trade agreements, yet we will leave ourselves open to multimillion euro claims in these special courts if the trade deal is ratified. This resolution is not anti—CETA and is merely asking for legal certainty on this important issue.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: written.- Free trade agreements such as CETA and TTIP are a disaster for animals, nature and the environment, but also threaten democracy.The Party for the Animals is of the opinion that the European Court should be given sufficient time to determine whether the trade agreement is in breach of the EU Treaties.There are still many uncertainties about CETA, so a judgment of the Court is certainly not superfluous.Such a procedure naturally takes time, but this postponement is a good thing.During this period, a full debate on CETA can finally be held in the European Parliament.No democracy without debate.That is why I voted in favor of an opinion of the Court of Justice.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- CETA is the best bilateral free trade agreement that the EU has negotiated so far.The Commission is following the negotiating mandate and has also addressed the investment protection concerns.In addition, we have already obtained an assessment from the Legal Service in the Committee on International Trade - the result: Investment protection is compatible with EU law.We are dealing with a dirty, tactical game here: What looks like a reasonable cause would delay CETA for at least 2 years.The EU would again show itself to Canada and the world as an unreliable negotiating partner on trade.After the agreement in principle with Canada, the EU renegotiated investment protection in an unusual way.In addition, the blockade of the Walloon Region at the end of October almost brought the agreement to a standstill.For these reasons, I reject the motion for a resolution.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the Canada-EU Free Trade Agreement.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on this or any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution calling for the CETA text to be referred to the ECJ, for consideration of whether the terms are entirely compatible with the EU treaties. A very large number of constituents have been in touch with me expressing concerns about the potential consequences of CETA, and also with concerns about the recent apparent moves to apply unseemly haste to the process of consideration by this Parliament. Surely we owe it to our constituents to allow time for full scrutiny in our Committees of this text, and to consider whether the concerns of critics can be openly and genuinely addressed. Although we have been told that the ICS system within CETA will be constrained to a limited extent by the inclusion of a clause which ‘guarantees’ the right of governments to regulate in the public interest, I think it reasonable to seek a judgement of the ECJ for clarity and I am disappointed that the resolution did not achieve a majority in the vote.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted against the European Parliament resolution seeking the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties because I followed the ALDE Group's position and because I do not support the proposal suspending provisional applicationAgreement.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- Being opposed by all possible means to CETA, this compatibility initiative is in my opinion a very good obstacle, although temporary, to the application of the treaty because it will be necessary to await the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union.I voted for.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I do not consider questioning of the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the EU relevant because both the EP’s and Commission’s legal services have no doubt that the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Investment Court System (ICS) are compatible with EU law. That is why I voted against this resolution. CETA is one of the most progressive treaties the EU has ever negotiated and I fully support its fulfilment without any further delay.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution asking for the opinion of the Court of Justice on the agreement with Canada.This pure parliamentary obstruction would have had the effect of delaying the ratification of this agreement by the European Parliament for two years.The legal services of the European Parliament had already considered that the agreement was fully compatible with the Treaties.There was therefore no point in delaying the process for two years to get the opinion of the Court of Justice.Moreover, as Belgium has already expressed its willingness to seek the opinion of the Court on the matter, without this hampering the process of ratification and provisional application of CETA, there was no point in making a similar request.The resolution was defeated by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Marek JUREK
text: in writing.- Justification of the vote on CETA: Following the US presidential election, the TTIP issue is no longer relevant.However, CETA is a breach through which weaker European economies will be pushed to unequal competition, which, for example, for agriculture - I note this as a Pole, representative of the most agricultural country in Europe - will be deadly.It is our duty to defend our agriculture, which is a great social capital for Poland and Europe.CETA also means limiting the sovereign rights of our states over our national markets, which are threatened with the consolidation and expansion of the international arbitration mechanism.This means privileging non-European companies and as such should have been examined by the Court of Justice of the European Union, which I supported with my vote.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it was about an alliance of circumstance between Greens, extreme left, extreme right and certain French socialists who, by requesting an opinion from the Court of justice, sought above all to makeparliamentary obstruction to delay ratification of the agreement with Canada.This agreement, which will further protect our protected geographical indications, has already waited too long.There is no question of blocking it for the wrong reasons.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. International trade has been shown to accelerate growth potential and the benefits of competition, and therefore an extroverted and open economic policy is part of any development policy for the Member States of the European Union. However, international trade without rules ceases to be trade. There must be safe regulations, which must be applied either legally or within commonly accepted institutional frameworks. CETA demonstrates that the process used by the European Union to conclude international trade agreements needs to be modified.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- This proposal must be approved.It provides that every opportunity can be used to critically review the agreement, which is of the utmost importance for the citizens.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: written. - I do not support the motion submitted by 89 Members of the European Parliament not to adopt the trade agreement with Canada (CETA) for the time being, but to refer it to the European Court of Justice for renewed examination. The EU Commission, the governments and the European Parliament have reviewed CETA for years. To ignore Parliament's independent legal service and now to ask for an examination at the end is pure delaying tactic. The request comes from those who do not want to agree to CETA anyway. This destroys trust in democratic institutions and stokes fears. We do not participate in the evil game of destroying trust! With our trade agreements, such as CETA, we are responding to people's worries without restricting our democratic scope for decision-making. We give rules to globalization without endangering communal services of general interest, art and culture. We protect our social, environmental and consumer protection standards and ensure a good future for our agriculture. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against the resolution before us.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the referral of CETA to the European Court of Justice because I believe that this agreement raises important legal questions that must receive proper answers before MEPs can vote on it. CETA would be the first ever EU trade deal to include an investment dispute arbitration mechanism. This mechanism, known as the Investment Court System (ICS), would become the template for investment protection in all future trade deals. Yet it has never been tested. A large number of respected legal experts, trade unions and consumer organisations have argued that ICS could seriously hamper the UK government’s ability to regulate in the public interest. It could also infringe on EU and national courts’ jurisdictions, and give foreign investors greater rights than European investors. These questions are too important to be overlooked, and it is therefore entirely appropriate for MEPs to seek the opinion of the European Court of Justice on these matters.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing. - For the Social Democrats, it is the blood of the heart to be vigilant about labor rights, the highest environmental, food and public health standards and the right to legislate freely. None of these we would ever buy - neither for a trade agreement nor for any other agreement. Therefore, we have also worked actively to ensure that effective protections and guarantees were put in place for these. And to ensure as democratic and transparent a process as possible. That work has borne fruit, and it is therefore now stated - in black and white - in the consolidated text of the agreement on CETA between the EU and Canada that neither Canada, the EU nor Denmark in any way lose the right to legislate as they wish, and that no one existing courts in neither Denmark nor the EU will have their work or mandate curtailed. In addition to the guarantees in the agreement itself, there is also already an assessment from the European Parliament's legal service confirming that the agreement contains safeguards against these matters. Against this background, we have voted against the resolution to postpone the CETA agreement for up to two years while awaiting a ruling from the European Court of Justice. Such an opinion is already under way, as the Belgian region of Wallonia will demand one.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- CETA is the best bilateral free trade agreement that the EU has negotiated so far.The Commission is following the negotiating mandate and has also addressed the investment protection concerns.In addition, we have already obtained an assessment from the Legal Service in the Committee on International Trade - the result: Investment protection is compatible with EU law.We are dealing with a dirty, tactical game here: What looks like a reasonable cause would delay CETA for at least 2 years.The EU would again show itself to Canada and the world as an unreliable negotiating partner on trade.After the agreement in principle with Canada, the EU renegotiated investment protection in an unusual way.In addition, the blockade of the Walloon Region at the end of October almost ruined the agreement.For these reasons, I reject the motion for a resolution.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I was very pleased to be able to table a motion for a resolution with my colleagues in the European Parliament, which considered that there was legal uncertainty as to whether the proposed CETA agreement was compatible with the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and wanted to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties. Miraculously, however, 419 Members of the European Parliament became renowned judges overnight and read the entire CETA contract (1,600 pages) and decided that they understood more, so that a court opinion was not needed. At the same time, there is something to research. CETA contains a mechanism of international arbitration, newly named ICS, which, however, retains the biggest problems of the previous ISDS, ie special courts for corporations, before which states are always only in the position of defendants. In addition, thanks to their Canadian headquarters, US multinational corporations can also take advantage of CETA lawsuits. About 80% of them have a Canadian seat. Canada itself has faced dozens of international arbitrations. An infamous example is Lone Pine, which is suing Canada for more than 175 million euros for banning the province of Quebec from hazardous shale gas extraction. I therefore voted in favor of this responsible proposal.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the free trade agreement between Canada and the European Union.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written.- The CETA agreement has been declared legal by Parliament's and the Commission's legal experts.Submitting it for reconsideration would delay decision-making in its worst years.I am not in favor of resubmitting the agreement for review.Parliament has listened to the public and switched from investor-to-state dispute settlement (ISDS) to the Investment Court System (ICS).I am in favor of the rule of law and I do not see a problem in resolving any disputes in an independent court.What do colleagues who oppose an independent court really fear?Why is an independent court such a big bastard for them?Personally, I see that in states governed by the rule of law, matters can and must be resolved in court if necessary.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: in writing. - The agreement with Canada raises many questions about both its economic and legal impact. In addition to trade openings which pose many risks to industrial jobs and the agricultural sector, a whole parallel legislative system is created by the agreement. In order to reduce the differences in standards between the European Union and Canada, it creates a regulatory cooperation mechanism that aims to write future laws with both hands multiplying the entry points for lobbies, accompanied by a court system private sector that could condemn a state if the laws go against the interests of investors. This resolution, which I co-signed and supported, asked that the Court of Justice of the European Union take up this issue and clearly tell us where the powers of the treaty with Canada end, in particular the privileges that it reserves for them. investors. By dropping this text, it is quite a questioning of the legal order of the agreement with Canada that is avoided after the refusal of the democratic debate. This is all the more worrying when you consider the impact this agreement will have on our jobs in the future, as well as on the way we make our laws.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted for the resolution on the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada and the European Union (CETA).This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of investment disputes between investors and States is compatible with Articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on discrimination, freedom of establishment and freedom to provide services within the Union and to third States.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of investment disputes between investors and States is compatible with Articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services within the Union and to third countries, Court of Justice of the European Union). We are, of course, not in favor of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), which overlooks states and undermines our sovereignty. However, the vote on this proposal would waste time in the application of the dangerous free trade treaty with Canada (CETA), since this will be dependent on the judgment of the CJEU. I therefore voted FOR this motion for a resolution, because all the reasons are good for - at least - delaying the implementation of this agreement.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written. - The N-VA delegation voted against the resolution requesting the Court of Justice for its opinion on the compatibility of the CETA agreement with the Treaties of the European Union. The text in this resolution is only aimed at delaying and postponing decision-making as much as possible. Our delegation does not wish to subscribe to this logic and prefers to follow the normal parliamentary path. Parliament was involved by the Council under the assent procedure on CETA. Before approving or rejecting the trade agreement and starting its possible provisional application, the members of parliament are given the opportunity within this procedure to enter into discussion and to inform themselves about the various parts of the agreement. We would also like to point out that, with regard to the main concerns regarding investment protection and dispute settlement (ICS), Belgium has indicated in its declaration accompanying the CETA agreement that it will take the Court of Justice to verify the compatibility of ICS with the European Have treaties checked. Moreover, any provisional application will not count for these provisions.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this motion because the Trade Agreement between Canada and the Union (CETA) raises serious legal problems that the CJEU should resolve before its implementation. As national authorities and courts have stated, CETA creates institutions such as arbitration tribunals (which allow foreign multinationals to obtain financial compensation for any regulatory change that affects them, putting their benefits before democratic rights) or the bodies of regulatory cooperation (in which multinationals intervene directly in the legislative process) that negatively affect state powers. It is therefore a legal requirement that the CJEU rule on the legislative scope of CETA and that it does not enter into force until it is voted favorably in each Member State. CETA is a treaty that will have a very negative impact on the rights of European workers, financial and economic stability, environmental protection and democracy itself. I deeply regret that for a majority of Members of this House its approval, for the benefit of big capital, is so urgent as to want to avoid even the most elementary legal debates and protocols.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This motion for a resolution seeks the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the Global Economic and Trade Agreement envisaged between Canada and the European Union.My vote is negative due to numerous reasons.To begin with, this spring the legal service of Parliament, which is politically neutral and based exclusively on legal conjecture, issued a conclusion in which it upheld the compatibility of CETA with the Treaties of the European Union.Likewise, the approval of the resolution would move CETA into legal limbo, since Parliament could not vote on it until the European Court had issued its opinion.I cannot support a resolution that seeks to block a treaty that will be extremely beneficial to the Union and its citizens and that is widely supported by Parliament.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- CETA is the best bilateral free trade agreement that the EU has negotiated so far.The Commission is following the negotiating mandate and has also addressed the investment protection concerns.In addition, we have already obtained an assessment from the Legal Service in the Committee on International Trade - the result: Investment protection is compatible with EU law.We are dealing with a dirty, tactical game here: What looks like a reasonable cause would delay CETA for at least 2 years.The EU would again show itself to Canada and the world as an unreliable negotiating partner on trade.After the agreement in principle with Canada, the EU renegotiated investment protection in an unusual way.In addition, the blockade of the Walloon Region at the end of October almost ruined the agreement.For these reasons, I reject the motion for a resolution.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: signed up. - Following the entry into force of the CETA, the EU and Canada will immediately and completely abandon part of the tariff lines for industrial and fishery products, and for the rest after transitional periods of up to seven years. The same goes for agricultural products. Second, in the area of ​​public procurement - an area that is sometimes underestimated but has a potential of hundreds of billions of dollars - CETA brings significant liberalization, which means that European companies will be able to bid for public contracts in Canada , at all levels of government (with some limitations in the provinces of Quebec and Ontario). All this will bring more business opportunities, a larger market, increased exports and more jobs. Experts estimate that the EU will have an annual profit of 12 billion euros. Romania will benefit from discounts in areas such as the production of leather and footwear products, agriculture, automotive components, ceramics, textiles. In addition, part of this agreement, Romanian citizens will no longer need a visa from December 1, 2017. The 28 Member States have given their unanimous consent, as such they support the application of CETA as soon as possible.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- On 27 April 2009, the Council authorized the Commission to negotiate an Economic Integration Agreement with Canada on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.Subsequently, on 12 September 2011, the Council adopted a Commission Recommendation amending the negotiating directives for an Economic Integration Agreement with Canada to empower the Commission to negotiate investment on behalf of the Union.Negotiators concluded negotiations on CETA in August 2014 and completed a legal review on 29 February 2016, but Parliament considers that there is legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties.That is why Parliament intends to seek the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties, and I therefore supported this resolution.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: In written form. - Today, I voted against the proposed resolution to seek the opinion of the Court of Justice on the Trade Agreement with Canada (SETA). The resolution states that there is legal uncertainty as to whether the Agreement (and in particular the new investor-state dispute settlement system) is compatible with the Treaties. I would like to remind you that the European Parliament's Legal Department was referred to this very issue back in the spring and came up with the opinion that no text in the chapter on investing in SETA is in conflict with the EU Treaties. I have no reason not to trust the lawyers working in the European Parliament's legal department, which is not linked to political groups. The purpose of the resolution was rather to delay ratification. The trial itself would take about a year and a half. To use legal procedures in this way, just to slow down the decision-making process, is at least wrong. Currently, there is the best possible prospect for Bulgaria: provisional implementation of the Agreement, procedure for its approval in each individual Member State and a clear commitment to abolish visas. Let us not limit the conversation about CETA to the European Parliament alone. It is high time that a broad, evidence-based public debate took place in the Member States.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the decision to ask the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the agreement between Canada and the European Union – CETA. We must be sure that this agreement corresponds to European law before we vote for it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - I did not support the motion for a resolution requesting the Court's previous opinion on the EU-Canada agreement.Further delays in ratifying the agreement are damaging the Union's economy and business environment.I am of the opinion that doubts can be contractually addressed by a legally appropriate provision.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- Today we voted for a resolution on the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the treaties of the proposed comprehensive economic and trade agreement between Canada and the European Union (CETA).The importance of the debate generated by CETA deserves that the Union acts with certainty and in full knowledge of the facts.Too many gray areas still persist on the legal value of the additional declarations included in CETA.That is why I supported this resolution calling for referral to the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of the investment dispute settlement mechanism with the treaties.I nevertheless regret the choice made by a majority of MEPs to reject this referral, while Parliament is only exercising its right on behalf of all European citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the motion for a resolution seeking the Court's opinion on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union, because it is complete and well-founded.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.This text aims to verify the compatibility between part of CETA and many articles of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), in particular on the subject of discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services.services within the Union and to third countries.Although we are not in favor of the Court of Justice of the European Union, voting for this text will allow, pending the judgment of the Court, to postpone the application of CETA, a catastrophic treaty for the interests of France.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - The recently concluded trade agreement between the European Union and Canada (CETA) is much more than a traditional free trade agreement. Since it is not just a question of dismantling tariffs but also harmonizing standards, the content of this "mega-deal" needs to be carefully analyzed before it can be put to a vote by parliamentarians. However, it is clear that the substance of the CETA agreement is still surrounded by a veil of uncertainties that no one is able to dispel. For example, in particular thanks to the fight led by Paul Magnette and the Walloon socialists, 38 additional declarations were added to CETA, but some of them are contradictory: the Commission was not able to specify, in these cases , which text should prevail. There are also significant uncertainties as to the compatibility - or incompatibility - of the Investment Protection Scheme (ICS) with Community law. So I not only supported but also co-signed the resolution proposing to the European Parliament to refer the case to the Court of Justice of the European Union to settle the outstanding issues. In my view, this is an absolutely essential precaution in the context of a democratic exercise in ratifying an international treaty.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I am convinced that the CETA free trade agreement will open many opportunities for Lithuanian business, and the opening of new markets is especially important after Russia's politically motivated decision to severely restrict food imports from Lithuania and other European countries.I believe that the proposal by a group of MEPs to go to the Court of Justice to assess whether CETA is compatible with the provisions of the EU Treaties is nothing more than an attempt to prevent the signing of this treaty.Going to the Court would delay the entry into force of the CETA agreement for at least 1.5 years, so I did not support such a proposal.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- The resolution asks that the Court of Justice of the European Union be seized to verify the compatibility of CETA, and more particularly aspects concerning arbitration tribunals, with European treaties.To tell the truth, even if it is considered compatible, I will maintain my opposition, en bloc and in detail, to CETA.Nevertheless, I take this opportunity to block the conclusion of the agreement.I vote FOR this resolution which I co-signed.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of disputes between investors and States is compatible with Articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty onfunctioning of the European Union (discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services within the Union and to third countries, Court of Justice of the European Union).This text aims to clarify the compatibility of CETA with European treaties.I therefore spoke in favor.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I presented my vote against the two motions for resolutions submitted by the GUE and the ALDE on the request for an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the agreement between the United States of America and the European Union on the protection of personal datain the field of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses.It is a delaying expedient that will delay the negotiation process.I am in favor of closing the agreement between the two blocs on this matter, compatible with European Union law.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion to request the opinion of the Court of Justice of the EU on the Canada-EU Agreement because it delays the adoption of the agreement unnecessarily. This agreement will boost trade, strengthen economic relations between Canada and the EU and spur job growth.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - I welcome the rejection of a motion for a resolution requesting the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the agreement between Canada and the European Union (CETA) with the European treaties. On November 23, the plenary session of the European Parliament rejected this request by a strong majority. In reality, it was a political maneuver by a few groups in Parliament (green, communist, far-right) whose objective was to block the procedure for the ratification of the agreement by the European Parliament first, by the parliaments of the Member States then. Another reason to vote against the request for referral to the Court: it is very far from the intra-Belgian agreement. Where the compromise reached between the federal government and the Walloon government limits the demand to the new arbitration procedure (known as ICS), the request of the 89 deputies targeted all the content of CETA. CETA has already been declared compatible with the European treaties on three occasions: by the Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe on October 13, and by the legal services of the Commission and Parliament. There is no question of blocking indefinitely an agreement negotiated for seven years, which has been validated by the governments of the Member States representing more than 500 million Europeans.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution Rule 108 on the opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the EU treaties of the proposed CETA agreement does not concern the text of the signed agreement between Canada and the EU, but the request to seek an opinion from the European Court of Justice on the compatibility with the EU law of the provisions of CETA related to investment dispute settlement. As a Social Democrat, I have always supported clarity about ICS, but this interest is already secured and reassured by the legal analysis made by the EP services.  Moreover, there is already a legal statement of Belgium attached to the CETA text that commits Belgium to ask the European Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of ICS with EU law and in the meantime ICS will not be applied. Therefore, I voted against this Resolution.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: signed up. - Such a request is not justified, given that the European Parliament's Legal Service has issued a written, unequivocal and public opinion on compatibility. The adoption would have had the effect of postponing for years the vote in the European Parliament and, more importantly, postponing the provisional application of parts of the agreement which bring immediate benefits to European citizens (including Romanians) and in connection with which no doubt about compatibility. Beyond the economic aspects, CETA and the Strategic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Canada have an important geostrategic component, helping to strengthen bilateral relations at a difficult time for Europe and the Western world in general, where both Europe and Canada need stability and political dialogue partners with common values. Romania's national interest demands the replacement as soon as possible of the old system of private arbitration between states and investors (ISDS) with the new system of investment courts (public system) contained in CETA. Any postponement of the procedures that allow the entry into force of CETA is therefore against the interest of Romania. CETA is currently being considered in committees, mainly in the Committee on International Trade, of which they are a part. The plenary of the European Parliament will vote on this important file in February 2017.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The European Parliament's legal experts have found the proposal for a CETA agreement to be compatible with the Treaties.At Belgium's request, the European Court of Justice is already examining the compatibility with the Treaties, and the section on the settlement of investment disputes between the investor and the State will not apply until the Court has ruled on the matter.If the draft submitted were adopted, CETA would not have been ratified until the Court had ruled on the matter, which would delay the entry into force of the agreement, which had been negotiated for seven years, for another two years.I therefore did not support the motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of investment disputes between investor and States is compatible with Articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services within the Union and to third countries, Court of Justice of the European Union).This text aims to clarify whether CETA is compatible with European treaties.Insofar as we are opposed to this type of treaty, because we can raise legal incompatibilities and, therefore, delay its possible implementation, we are in favor of this initiative.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text aims to clarify whether CETA is compatible with the European treaties, which will make it possible to slow down the adoption of this treaty.I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this text which requested the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on the compatibility of CETA with the treaties.This text constitutes an artifice implemented by the groups opposed to CETA to postpone its provisional execution.Indeed, seeking the CJEU will delay the application of the treaty by at least two years, which will penalize our producers and our industries, particularly in the access to public markets that this treaty allows.In addition, Belgium will already apply to the CJEU as a state, which will not alter the provisional application of CETA.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - The EU-Canada negotiations for CETA started in May 2009 and concluded in September 2014. The legal review of the treaty was completed in 2016, with the favorable verdict of the Parliament's legal services. We recall in particular how this Parliament, on the initiative of the Group of Socialists and Democrats in particular, requested - and obtained - the annulment of the controversial ISDS system, replaced with an international court model for resolving disputes between investors and States, providing in particular facilitation measures for SMEs, to make the system more accessible. Furthermore, in CETA there is the recognition of geographical indications, to protect consumers and typical foods of our country; as well as the standards agreements of the International Labor Organization. This agreement is - as has been said by many - a progressive trade agreement. Nonetheless, citizens have expressed their perplexity on some aspects, and I believe that the changes that have taken place have taken this into account. The request for this resolution, which I did not support, would have further slowed down a process which will guarantee Europe, SMEs and workers numerous opportunities for growth and employment.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I have rejected the motion for a resolution, partly because I am completely satisfied with the content of the agreement to be concluded with Canada, and partly because we are risking our credibility with tricks that delay the adoption of the agreement.Last spring, the Committee on International Trade addressed the same question to the European Parliament's independent legal services unit, from which a clear answer was received.We have been working on this convention for many years and it is time for it to take effect and begin to feel its positive effects.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution regarding the compatibility issue between CETA and the Treaties following the European Parliament’s Legal Service assessment that found no contradiction between CETA’s investment chapter and the EU Treaties.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I have decided to abstain from voting on this report, which proposes to request an opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the EU-Canada Economic Agreement, as I have not chosen to be part of a dispute between the EU and one of theMember States, namely Belgium, which, due to internal disputes, wants a postponement of the application of this Treaty.I believe that the discussions should be focused more on the background of the issue, on the analyzes of the benefits that this agreement will have for our countries and to decide accordingly.Last but not least, I cannot ignore the fact that a possible entry into force of CETA would mean the abolition of Romanians' access visas to Canada, and a postponement of a year and a half, necessary to obtain an opinion of the CJEU, would most likely have canceled.and this agreement between the Romanian and Canadian authorities.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I voted against the motion for a resolution asking the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the CETA agreement with the Treaties, and I am glad that the motion did not pass.I consider it an attempt by part of the political representation to prevent the entry into force of CETA at all costs, or at least to delay it.The CETA agreement is adopted by the standard procedure for the adoption of international agreements and there is no reason for the EU Court of Justice to enter into this process.I am convinced that CETA has been well negotiated and its early entry into force is in the interests of the Czech economy and the European economy as a whole.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this proposal because every opportunity to critically review the agreement should be used.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- Did not support.The Commission has negotiated the agreement on the basis of EU law and the Treaties, and the agreement has been approved by the European Parliament's Legal Service, so I do not consider it necessary to seek a separate opinion from the Court of Justice.Rather, it is another attempt to prolong or hinder the conclusion of a trade agreement, and this action is particularly detrimental to the EU's economic policy as a whole.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I support the resolution that has been tabled.I consider it appropriate to refer the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union to the Court of Justice for compliance with the provisions of the EU Treaties.It should be noted that this convergence means legitimizing the principles of globalization in European trade.Its provisions do not benefit the people of Europe.In particular, the agreement does not provide sufficient safeguards, not only for the creation of new jobs, but also for the preservation of existing ones in Europe.In addition, the cartel on security requirements for imported food and agricultural products is being significantly reduced.Trading partners are given much more rights and opportunities to resolve disputes in a more favorable legal environment.After all, the potential damage to European industry and the economy from such an agreement has not been fully assessed.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted against my colleagues' proposal because I believe that, since the agreement between the European Union and Canada is incompatible pursuant to Article 19 TEU and pursuant to art.49, 54, 56, 267, 340 TFEU, it seems useless to ask the Court of Justice for an opinion.Indeed, I believe that an agreement cannot be concluded which is contrary to two primary sources of Community law such as the TEU and the TFEU.I therefore voted negative

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I did not support the Motion for a European Parliament resolution seeking the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties. The Free Trade Agreement between Canada and the European Union was signed on October 30 this year, and negotiations ended in August 2014. By the treaty, the European Union and Canada have agreed on an ambitious agreement that will open up new opportunities for trade and investment for businesses on both sides of the Atlantic. Both sides of this Agreement emphasized the importance of conducting economic activity within the framework of clear and transparent regulations issued by public bodies and stressed that they consider the right to regulation in the public interest a fundamental principle of the Agreement. For example, in Article 1.9. The agreement states that water is not a commodity or a product and that both parties to the agreement protect and conserve natural water resources as nothing in the agreement obliges the signatories to the agreement to allow the commercial use of water for any purpose. In the last two years, there has been ample time to study and analyze this Agreement. Member States, if they consider it necessary, in accordance with the Basic Treaties of the EU, have the right to review certain parts of the agreement before the Court of Justice of the European Union, and I see no reason why I would support this initiative.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of investment disputes between investor and States is compatible with Articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services within the Union and to third countries, Court of Justice of the European Union).This text aims to clarify whether CETA is compatible with European treaties.I support this resolution, which could delay the implementation of this abominable treaty.I therefore vote in favor of this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- Parliament seeks the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with the Treaties of the European Union.On 27 April 2009, the Council authorized the Commission to negotiate an Economic Integration Agreement with Canada on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, and on 12 September 2011 adopted a Commission Recommendation authorizing the Commission to negotiate investment on behalf of the Union.The negotiators concluded the CETA negotiations in August 2014 and completed the legal revision on 29 February 2016. The text of the agreement submitted contains an investment chapter (Chapter 8) which includes, inter alia, an investment protection section (Section D).and a section on resolving investment disputes between investors and states (Section F).I believe that Parliament should take political responsibility for deciding on this Agreement and use its own legal resources for any possible ambiguities.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - We have witnessed yet another black page in the history of this Parliament. In view of the chorus of protest over CETA, the reservations raised by very diverse parties, institutions and associations spread across the European continent, this Parliament made it impossible to hold a debate that would have had the merit of clarifying its real objectives and confronting the different political groups and parties with their vision of the agreement. The vote on a draft resolution without the right to debate says a lot about the quality of democracy practiced in the European Parliament. CETA was secretly discussed over seven years, and was presented in the form of a 1600-page document without any possibility of alteration. CETA represents an instrument designed to liberalize commercial relations and open public markets to multinationals, leveling all social and environmental standards below. This is what the right and social democracy refuse to discuss, to the detriment and ignoring the struggle and just demands of the people.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's resolution and I am sorry that Parliament did not support it.I consider the trade agreement with Canada to be very beneficial for the development of the EU and Canadian economies; on the other hand, we must listen to and take into account the concerns of our citizens and be able to explain to them all the facts on which the question marks hang.I believe that the Court's findings will be an important element in the communication and transparency of the CETA process.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution requesting a legal opinion from the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) to verify the compatibility of CETA with the treaties. This is certainly yet another political maneuver from the far left, but it deserves a real explanation. The resolution's depositories have made it appear that they need all the elements in their hands to make a final decision on whether to vote on the deal. Someone should explain to me why 82 of the 89 signatories of the resolution have already said they would reject CETA! Above all, they accuse the Commission, guardian of the treaties, of having negotiated a trade agreement with the help of 28 Member States without this respecting the treaties. However, she always followed and defended them, to the point of being zealous! Seeking an opinion from the CJEU would take two years. Belgium is expected to do it anyway! By voting against this resolution, I voted against the politicking of the extremists, who wanted to do what they embody best: unnecessary duplication.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing.- On 27 April 2009, the Council authorized the Commission to negotiate an economic integration agreement with Canada, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.The CETA (Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement) negotiation and ratification procedure lasted for about six years.In addition, not only European and Canadian experts, several European Institutions and other supranational entities participated in this procedure.The agreement was approved by the European Council and signed at the Canada Summit on 30 October 2016. I understand that CETA is in accordance with all the rules of the European legal system.In view of the above, and recognizing that the agreement under consideration is of fundamental importance, I am voting against this report.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up.- The impact of the EU-Canada agreement will definitely change the lives of European citizens.I consider it imperative that, prior to the application, signing and provisional approval of this agreement, the European Parliament seek the opinion of the CJEU in order to clarify any trace of legal uncertainty as to the compatibility of the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on European Union.the functioning of the European Union with CETA.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We supported this resolution because we see both CETA and TTIP as part of the globalisation of crony capitalism and primarily benefitting ‘big business’ rather than people.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has voted on a resolution asking the Court of Justice of the European Union to rule on the legality of CETA, the draft free trade agreement with Canada. Trade in itself is not a bad thing; it would be unrealistic or in bad faith to say otherwise. The links between Europe and Canada are old, we need both sides of the Atlantic to be able to exchange goods and services. But trade cannot be done at the cost of our ability to legislate, and CETA must not lead to discrimination between European and Canadian companies. It is because the Court of Justice is the only body capable of deciding these thorny legal questions that I supported this resolution. Our chamber has unfortunately decided otherwise, which I deplore, but I will remain with the French Socialist delegation extremely vigilant on the evolutions of this text. The vote of the European Parliament remains an essential stage for the application of the treaty; legislative work is therefore far from over.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - Common sense won the day over the Canada-European Union Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). 419 MEPs, a large majority of the European Parliament, said NO to the motion for a resolution asking for the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of CETA with the European treaties. In reality, it was a political maneuver by a few political groups (mainly green, communists, sovereignists) whose objective was to block the procedure for the ratification of the agreement by the European Parliament first, by the Parliaments. Member States then. Another legitimate reason to reject this request for referral to the Court of Justice of the European Union: it is far removed from the intra-Belgian agreement. Where the compromise reached between the federal government and the Walloon government limits the demand to the new arbitration procedure (known as ICS), the request of the 89 deputies targeted all the content of CETA. However, on three occasions, the Constitutional Court of Karlsruhe (on October 13) and the legal services of the Commission and the Parliament have already declared the conformity of CETA with the European treaties. We must now hope that the European Parliament can quickly ratify this “win-win” agreement, negotiated for 7 years.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- The spirit of the CETA agreement provides for the removal of virtually all customs duties;new opportunities for access to the labor market;better access for European suppliers and greater competitiveness for EU companies on the market.The EU must give a sign of confidence to its partners in Canada.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The approval of this resolution implied that the vote on the CETA agreement in the European Parliament was suspended until the Court of Justice of the European Union issued an opinion on the compatibility of the investment chapter with the Treaties of the Union, which could last at least two years. This meant stealing the democratic political debate that the deputies of Parliament, as representatives of the citizens, must have on the content of CETA, constituting a legal tool to avoid a political decision. This would not have lived up to the responsibilities that the socialist group has in the European Parliament. We Socialists defend the need to have legal clarity on all aspects of the treaty and, in particular, the compatibility of the investment chapter of CETA with the Treaties of the Union, therefore we request the opinion on this point of the legal service of this Parliament, that endorsed said compatibility. Furthermore, we consider this resolution unnecessary, as the provisions relating to CETA's investment court system will not be provisionally applicable if the European Parliament consents to the agreement. For all these reasons, we have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution which aimed to bring CETA under the control of the Court of Justice of the European Union, because it seems essential to me that an agreement of such importance offers all the guarantees of compatibility with theEuropean law.Many judges have expressed reservations, in particular on the legal basis of the dispute settlement mechanism.This is why it is imperative to seek the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of this agreement with European law.Also, I regret that the deputies have not expressed a majority in favor of this legitimate position.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I am convinced that we are in too much of a hurry to sign agreements such as CETA and TTIP.While I welcome the development of transatlantic trade, the secrecy surrounding them is particularly worrying.What trade regulation secrets can the EU hide from its citizens?And why Canada, a democracy, should hide the relevant provisions from its citizens.After all, once the treaty enters into force, these provisions will become public.The court ruling, while bringing some clarity to this debate, is essentially a step to the side.First of all, we need to address the issues of publicity and transparency in the treaties themselves.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution - of which I am a signatory - which calls for referral by the European Parliament to the Court of Justice, so that the latter examines the compatibility of the CETA agreement with the European treaties.The scope of many provisions of this trade agreement remains uncertain: such is the case, for example, of the additional declarations, the regulatory cooperation mechanism, or the system for settling investment-related disputes.Without prejudging in any way the final position of the European Parliament on CETA, an opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union would have clarified the scope and the legal consequences of the agreement and allowed the European legislator to pronounce in fullknowingly.The majority of members of Parliament have chosen to vote against this resolution and I regret it.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - This proposal follows a request from 89 deputies belonging to 5 political groups: EFDD, Greens, GUE, S & amp; D (31 deputies) and ALDE (only 2 deputies) and represents no more than a dilatory expedient, with the purpose of clearly ideological and partisan, to delay the entry into force of this Treaty, which may delay the entry into force of the same 2 years. In fact, on 7 April, the Committee on International Trade already requested an opinion from the EP's legal services on the matter, and the answer was given on 1 June, formulating in its conclusions that "having regard to the the content of the chapter on investment in EFTA, the provisions for the resolution of investment disputes can be considered to be compatible with the EU Treaties ". Due to the central importance that the EU Court of Justice has in the architecture of the EU, it seems to me evident that we should not (let it) instrumentalize it, allowing its use as a weapon of political party throwing. In view of the reasons set out above, I voted against this motion for a resolution, as I believe that the European Parliament should give a strong signal of support and not of fragility to the conclusion of this Agreement.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution tabled individually by 89 MEPs asking for an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the CETA agreement between the European Union and Canada with the European treaties.Such a request would once again postpone the entry into force of the CETA agreement, which will allow our companies and citizens to benefit from many advantages such as access to public markets, the elimination of numerous customs duties and the protection of indications.geographic.After having cleared many obstacles, it is time for the CETA agreement to enter into force, on a provisional basis.In addition, the legal service of the European Parliament has already issued a legal opinion which has been published and which declares that the new ICS mechanism, for which a legal opinion is requested here under CETA, is compatible with the European treaties.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ The wide debate that went on internationally about comprehensive trade and investment treaties negotiated during past years has given rise to justified queries. Is the logic underpinning such treaties politically, economically and socially tenable under conditions of globalisation? No matter what one may think about Canada – and I have always been one of its admirers – the same doubts and questionings apply to the comprehensive agreement drafted with it. Its acceptance would serve as a precedent and model for the adoption of other comprehensive agreements with other trade blocs. In the circumstances it makes sense to take a step back and see whether the institutional and legal foundations for such a ground breaking exercise really exist.  On the other hand it is also true that the process of negotiation is now well advanced. One could reasonably claim that doubts and fears are being expressed at too late a stage. There must be a way, not necessarily the one indicated in this resolution, by which to review whether the agreement with Canada could simply serve as curtain raiser to a development by which we will be promoting the oligopolisation of global markets.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted against the decision on the Opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on a comprehensive economic and trade agreement (CETA) with the Treaties.Parliament's legal service, which is a neutral institution, issued a legal opinion on CETA in June, stating that CETA is compatible with European treaties.The decision was proposed by MPs who want to make CETA more difficult or even to prevent it.CETA plays an important role for Europe and offers many opportunities, which is why I supported this agreement.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: written. - In today's vote, we voted against this motion for a resolution because we believe that it is the European Parliament's own task to check the compatibility of international trade agreements with EU law. The European Parliament is sovereign in its deliberations, and we have always fought for sufficient space for consultation in the EP. Now that it is clear that a provisional timetable for the ratification of the CETA agreement is not tenable and that the change in the timetable and the participation of further specialist committees have been assured, we believe that Parliament has sufficient time to carry out this examination. Any other approach is not acceptable. In this way, in the course of further parliamentary deliberations, the arguments that justify the incompatibility with the EU treaties can be discussed in detail. The contents of the CETA treaty concerning the Investment Court will be excluded from the provisional application of the CETA treaty after a possible ratification by the European Parliament. If there are further well-founded doubts about a compatibility after the examination, it is still possible to submit the question to the European Court of Justice for examination.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this motion because the Trade Agreement between Canada and the Union (CETA) raises serious legal problems that the CJEU should resolve before its implementation. As national authorities and courts have stated, CETA creates institutions such as arbitration tribunals (which allow foreign multinationals to obtain financial compensation for any regulatory change that affects them, putting their benefits before democratic rights) or the bodies of regulatory cooperation (in which multinationals intervene directly in the legislative process) that negatively affect state powers. It is therefore a legal requirement that the CJEU rule on the legislative scope of CETA and that it does not enter into force until it is voted favorably in each Member State. CETA is a treaty that will have a very negative impact on the rights of European workers, financial and economic stability, environmental protection and democracy itself. I deeply regret that for a majority of Members of this House its approval, for the benefit of big capital, is so urgent as to want to avoid even the most elementary legal debates and protocols.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I wish to do everything to stop CETA.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. - I voted against the request for an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the new dispute settlement system (Investment Court System - ICS) included in the trade agreement with Canada (CETA) as it is a mere expedient to suspend the provisional application of the agreement, despite the achievements achieved in the negotiations, largely under pressure from the socialists. In addition, the Legal Service of the European Parliament (EP) has already issued an opinion which concludes that there is no incompatibility and that, in any case, it is ensured that Belgium will ask the Court of Justice for an identical opinion. It is one thing to ask for an opinion without blocking the provisional application, as Belgium proposes to do, another thing to ask it to halt that application for 2 years, threatening the agreement itself, as would happen with this proposal. Nothing justifies this attitude in the light of the outcome of the negotiations and the understanding reached with Wallonia, especially when it is known that the ICS system is excluded from provisional application. Finally, the immediate application of CETA, even if in portions, brings important benefits to the Portuguese economy through the elimination or reduction of heavy customs tariffs that seriously affect exports from our traditional sectors.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I voted against this resolution, not because I am against having clarity about the ICS provisions in CETA but against doing this to the detriment of the entire CETA Agreement, whose majority of the text does not pose any legal problem. It is important to take responsibility for taking a decision on whether to support or not the ratification of CETA and not delay the decision up until at least two years.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia.representative action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The above-mentioned resolution requires the Court of Justice to assess the compatibility of the CETA agreement with EU law. If this is really such a good agreement, as the European Commission convinces us, then what are certain people afraid of? In view of all the warnings and criticisms that most fly to international arbitral tribunals, I am of the opinion that the Court of Justice of the EU should rule on this before CETA enters into force. It is becoming increasingly clear that CETO wants to get under the roof with great haste, despite all the trampled democratic standards. Democracy seems to be a hindrance to the founders of CETE. It is outrageous that there is even a limited democratic debate in the European Parliament on such an important topic on which our future depends, as the motion for a resolution has not even been allowed to be debated. As well as parliamentary committees, which are responsible for some key areas that will be heavily affected by CETA, e.g. environment, health, food safety, employment, social affairs and consumer protection will not be allowed to participate in the decision-making process on the whole agreement. Such moves run counter to the fundamental notions of democracy and freedom of expression. That is why I voted in favor of the resolution, supporting the call for the EU Court of Justice to assess the compatibility of the CETA agreement with EU law.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - CETA is the best bilateral free trade agreement that the EU has negotiated so far. The Commission is following the negotiating mandate and has also addressed the investment protection concerns. In addition, we have already obtained an assessment from the Legal Service in the Committee on International Trade - Result: Investment protection is compatible with EU law: https://polcms.secure.europarl.europa.eu/cmsdata/upload/49daf369-5480-40d7 -aa8d-df745c4ff98c / SJ-0259-16_legal_opinion.pdf We are dealing with a dirty, tactical game: What looks like a reasonable concern would delay CETA by at least 2 years. The EU would again show itself to Canada and the world as an unreliable negotiating partner on trade. After the agreement in principle with Canada, the EU renegotiated investment protection in an unusual way. In addition, the blockade of the Walloon Region at the end of October almost ruined the agreement. For these reasons, I reject the motion for a resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Parliament rejected the order requesting the opinion of the Court of Justice.As Parliament considers that there is no legal uncertainty, it has decided not to seek an opinion.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I have agreed to the resolution of the EU Parliament to obtain an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on a comprehensive economic and trade agreement (CETA) with the treaties. The text of the agreement to be concluded, signed and provisionally applied to the Council includes a chapter on investments (Chapter 8), in which, inter alia, a section on the protection of investments (section D) and a section on the settlement of investment disputes between investors and States (Section F) are included. There is legal uncertainty as to whether the proposed agreement is compatible with the Treaties and in particular with Article 19 of the Treaty on European Union and Articles 49, 54, 56, 267 and 340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I was therefore in favor of asking the Court of Justice for an opinion on the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- I reject this motion for a resolution on the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties of the European Union because I do not consider legal uncertainty, but I support CETA in general.we will not free trade, which will negatively affect trade agreements with other countries.CETA is the EU's first comprehensive economic agreement with a highly industrialized country.Encouraging new economic activities and creating new markets by breaking down existing barriers shows that we are serious when it comes to free trade.This trade agreement would create many jobs and opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises that are the wheels of the economy.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted against the proposed resolution on obtaining an opinion from the Court on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties.Negotiations on an economic cooperation agreement between the European Union and Canada were concluded in August 2014, and a legal review was completed earlier this year.I cannot support the resolution because it is vague and not precise enough about the main thing: the lack of legal certainty as to the compatibility of the proposed agreement with the Treaties.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The proposed EU - Canada Economic / Trade Agreement is incompatible with the Treaties, in particular on investment protection and dispute resolution.The agreement must be broken.

name: József SZÁJER
