text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the Canada-EU Free Trade Agreement.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on this or any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing.- I supported the proposal for a decision, as I consider the entry into force of the Trade Agreement with Canada (CETA) to be useful and necessary.Nevertheless, I would have considered it desirable from a democratic perspective to proceed in all respects, based on the Court's examination.Although the majority did not take this position during the vote, I note that, in my view, a number of assurances were given during the preliminary parliamentary negotiation of the Convention, following compromises and mutual guarantees, that the Convention, including its settlement by international tribunal (ICJ), do not harm the interests of the EU and its Member States and European citizens, but also offer useful opportunities for developing our economic and trade relations with Canada.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - Left-wing, populist and greens parties have made another attempt to delay the entry into force of CETA, the most ambitious free trade agreement that the European Union has negotiated so far. The resolution proposed by some political groups present in the European Parliament with the request for an opinion by the Court of Justice of the EU on the compliance of the CETA agreement with the EU treaties is in fact another action against international trade, transnational cooperation and the globalization of welfare. CETA is the most comprehensive and advanced agreement of its kind that has been negotiated by the European Union to date. Thanks to the agreement, 98% of all tariff lines will be liquidated. It will also allow almost unlimited access to Canadian procurement at all levels. Most importantly, in response to the voices of Europeans, a new investment protection mechanism has been introduced ensuring that the government has the absolute right to legislate in the interests of the public interest. The motion for a resolution should therefore only be seen as a political manifesto and an attempt to engage in subversive action against international trade. It should be remembered that this summer, the legal service of the European Parliament issued an opinion on the compatibility of CETA with the Treaties, indicating that it is fully in line with EU legislation and does not affect our legal framework, EU competences or constitutional rights. Consequently, I voted against the resolution.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: written.- I voted against the draft report.The completion of this report would have delayed the ratification of the whole agreement at EU level by almost two years.In that case, the agreement could not have been applied, even in part.If the EU fails to implement a free trade agreement with Canada, the future of trade policy will look rather hopeless.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. - The majority of the European Parliament rejected the attempt to seek the opinion of the European Court of Justice on CETA, the treaty with Canada. There are serious doubts about its compatibility with European law, especially since it contains the ICS clause which allows investors to go to private courts to sue the state in the event of public measures contrary to their interests. For this reason 89 MEPs from various camps - including all of us from the M5S - asked to seek the opinion of the European Court of Justice: it was only a question of verifying the legality of the treaty outside the positions in favor or not. But the buildings of power are afraid that CETA will be analyzed: the more we talk about it, the more it comes to light that it contains a torpedo aimed at the precautionary principle, it weakens food security, sends our agriculture to the slaughterhouse, sets very wide margins for private intervention in services such as water, school and health, dictates the criteria for issuing permits and licenses relating to all economic activities.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up.- CETA provides several economic benefits for the European Union.In the case of Romania, we are talking about encouraging the development of important sectors due to the elimination of Canadian customs duties.This is an opportunity to further strengthen bilateral relations with the Canadian state, which over the years has emerged as a stable partner for the EU.Considering that CETA offers long-term positive effects to Romanian citizens, I vote against the motion for a resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- We are 89 MEPs calling for the Court of Justice of the European Union to rule on the conformity and legality of the CETA treaty.Our request was put to a vote on Wednesday.Of course, I voted for this request because I believe that it is normal and responsible to obtain all the guarantees for the respect of the rights of European citizens!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for a resolution seeking an opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on CETA. I believe that CETA is the most modern, progressive and extensive agreement that the EU has succeeded in closing. The agreement with Canada allows the EU to maintain its values and standards, while accessing new lucrative markets, providing consumer choices and new investment opportunities. I support CETA, and therefore voted against the motion for a resolution, which would once again delay the ratification process. I strongly support the final agreement as it significantly benefits European businesses and its citizens.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - The draft free trade treaty negotiated between Canada and the European Union is provoking a lively debate, justified by the often destructive consequences of free trade and reinforced by the opacity of the negotiations. The scope of a possible CETA deal on the way of life of European citizens is too large not to be scrutinized. It is a democratic imperative. Among the points of debate is the question of the conformity of such a trade agreement with European treaties, such as the dispute settlement system between multinationals and States (ICS). Many lawyers have expressed doubts, which justifies that the Court of Justice of the European Union is consulted. I consider that Parliament, an institution that guarantees the interests of citizens, is legitimate to seize it. This is the reason why I proposed, with 88 other MEPs from 5 political groups, a resolution to this effect, in order to have all the elements necessary for a decision-making when the draft final agreement will be available to us. submitted. So I helped promote, and voted for, this resolution.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing.- Today's vote was on a point of order on the Canada-EU Free Trade Agreement.The entry into force of the FTA on behalf of the Union is expected to be put to a vote in the European Parliament in December this year, so a decision will be taken on the substance.In addition to the European Parliament, Member States, inter alia, have the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, even after its entry into force, on this or any other matter relating to the agreement.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I do not support the motion for a resolution "Opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties".Taking into account that the Legal Service of the European Parliament found in June 2016 that the CETA agreement is not in breach of the Treaties of the European Union, I am of the opinion that seeking the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union will slow down the procedure.The position of the Court of Justice is binding and the implications of a negative response may prevent the entry into force of the CETA agreement.Believing in the expertise of the Legal Committee of the Parliament's Legal Service, I believe that possibly seeking answers would only slow down the process of adopting the CETA agreement and that as such it is not necessary.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- This resolution was added to the agenda of the plenary session at the last minute by the Greens, GUE, EFDD, ENF and several members of the S&D group.The resolution seeks the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of the CETA agreement with the Treaties of the European Union.If the resolution is adopted, it will mean that Parliament will automatically have to stop the assent procedure and await the Court's ruling.Without the consent of Parliament, the CETA agreement cannot be applied temporarily.I oppose this Resolution, because the aim is not to test the legal adequacy of the agreement, because the legal side of the agreement is not disputable in any segment - the European Parliament's legal service has already issued an opinion that the CETA agreement is compatible with the Treaties.The real goal is to postpone the agreement, which has already been unanimously approved in the 28 individual member states of the Union.I therefore vote against.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I did not support the motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 108 (6) of the Rules of Procedure on obtaining an opinion from the Court on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties.Some Member States question whether the EU-Canada FTA is in line with certain EU guidelines, such as health, safety and the environment.The European Parliament did not perceive any contradiction between the chapter of the CETA agreement on investments and some EU agreements.Some Members then asked for an additional opinion on the compatibility of the agreement, so they turned to the Court.CETA is an agreement that will create new jobs for the European economy.It will bring European companies more and better economic opportunities than Canada.The agreement will save exporters more than 500m euros a year and create the conditions for better economic co-operation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- The compatibility of the CETA ICS with the European legal system has been questioned by associations of lawyers from all over Europe.I have voted in favor of asking the European Court to give an opinion on the matter.It seems to us that it is a matter that goes beyond being in favor or against the Treaty, it is a matter of common sense: granting the European Court of Justice the role that it deserves and, not running the risk of a law entering into force.treaty that contains an instrument that could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- CETA is the best bilateral free trade agreement that the EU has negotiated so far.The Commission is following the negotiating mandate and has also addressed the investment protection concerns.In addition, we have already obtained an assessment from the Legal Service in the Committee on International Trade - the result: Investment protection is compatible with EU law.We are dealing with a dirty, tactical game here: What looks like a reasonable cause would delay CETA for at least 2 years.The EU would again show itself to be an unreliable negotiating partner on trade to Canada and the world.After the agreement in principle with Canada, the EU renegotiated investment protection in an unusual way.In addition, the blockade of the Walloon Region at the end of October almost brought the agreement to a standstill.For these reasons, I reject the motion for a resolution.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution signed by a number of MEPs (mostly from Groups on the left) to refer CETA and especially the Investment Court System (ICS) to the European Court of Justice, to check its compatibility with EU law. CETA is the most progressive treaty the EU has ever negotiated. CETA and ICS have been cleared by the German high court in Hannover. Both Parliament’s and the Commission’s legal services are in no doubt that CETA and ICS are compatible with EU law. Further, the ICS in CETA is a major overhaul and improvement on the outdated investor-state dispute system (ISDS), which neither MEPs nor NGOs ever tried to refer to the ECJ in the past. ICS is in fact the only way to improve the outdated ISDS, which our Member States continue to use, even against each other. There are more than 4 000 existing bilateral agreements between EU Member States with out-dated ISDS provisions. A referral to the ECJ of CETA would lead to a case taking up to one-and-a-half years. This resolution is a clear attempt by the anti-trade camp to further delay the approval of CETA in the hope of sabotaging the entire agreement, and in the process, EU trade policy as whole.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution is intended to ensure that the part of CETA on the protection of investments and the resolution of investment disputes between investor and States is compatible with Articles 19, 49, 54, 56, 267 and340 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (discrimination, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services within the Union and to third countries, Court of Justice of the European Union - CJEU).This text aims to verify the compatibility of CETA with the European treaties (CJEU).If we are not in favor of the CJEU, the vote on this motion for a resolution would waste time in the implementation of the dangerous CETA treaty since we will have to wait for the judgment of the CJEU.So I voted in favor.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The INTA Committee has already requested an opinion from the Legal Service of the European Parliament on this point.The opinion clearly states that the rules are in line with the EU Treaties as: "given the purpose and content of CETA's investment division, the envisaged rules on investment dispute settlement can be considered as compatible with the EU Treaties."It is worth adding that the opinion of the Legal Service was deemed sufficient and opposed any further attempts to delay the vote on CETA, especially after unanimous agreement was reached by the 28 Member States.That is why I voted against the opinion, which is meant to delay the decision-making process.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- The compatibility of the CETA ICS with the European legal system has been questioned by associations of lawyers from all over Europe.I voted in favor of asking the European Court to give an opinion on the matter.It seems to us that it is a question that goes beyond being in favor or against the Treaty, it is a question of common sense: to give the European Court of Justice the role that corresponds to it and, not to run the risk of entering into force atreaty that contains an instrument that could be incompatible with our legal system.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against of the opinion from the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between Canada and the European Union on a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). Negotiators finished the negotiations on CETA in August 2014, and completed the legal review on 29 February 2016. The text of the agreement submitted to the Council to be concluded, signed and provisionally applied contains a chapter on investment (Chapter eight), which includes a section on investment protection and a section on the resolution of investment disputes between investors and states. I voted against because I see no reason to delay further a final decision of the European Parliament.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I strongly supported the request to appeal to the Court of Justice for a ruling on the compatibility of CETA with EU law. We need to clarify this, because we believe that this agreement undermines the uniformity of European law and jeopardizes the protection of the fundamental rights of European citizens. With CETA, a supranational para-judicial court is created that would allow multinationals to sue states outside the normal judicial system to obtain compensation for any damage suffered due to laws and regulations to protect citizens, health and the environment. How can this legal monster be compatible with the rights and values ​​enshrined in the Treaties? We would have liked to hear the final opinion on the matter from the European judges. Unfortunately, with 419 votes to 258, Parliament wanted to reject this request and therefore deny the opening of the debate. They probably fear that the response of the European judges will prove us right and not the multinationals.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted against because I believe that there is no legal uncertainty as to whether the proposed agreement is compatible with the Treaties.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - It is superfluous to go back on CETA, the free trade agreement between the European Union and Canada, little brother or Trojan horse of TAFTA. Following Belgium's decision to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) to verify the compatibility of CETA - in particular its arbitration mechanism - with the European treaties, the GUE / NGL and the Greens have filed a motion to join these proceedings. It seemed to us indecent to vote this motion without any preliminary debate. At the start of the plenary session, we therefore called for a debate, but our proposal was rejected by 184 votes against, 170 for and 9 abstentions, and the resolution itself aiming to refer the matter to the CJEU was rejected by 419 votes against, 258 for and 22 abstentions. This rejection is an affront to democracy. CETA contains gray points, legal uncertainties that the European Parliament would have been honored to want to clarify. Why are the supporters of these agreements so afraid of the Court's decisions? The fight goes on; we look forward to the opinion of the Court of Justice.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- We have witnessed yet another black page in the history of this Parliament.In view of the chorus of protest about CETA, the reservations raised by parties and associations of all kinds, this Parliament made it impossible to hold a debate that would have had the merit of clarifying its real objectives and confronting each deputy with a free and democratic debate..In this way, we will have a vote on a draft resolution without the right to debate, which says a lot about the quality of democracy that we breathe in this Chamber.CETA was secretly discussed over seven years, and was presented in the form of a 1600-page document without any possibility of alteration.CETA represents an instrument aimed at opening public markets to multinationals and leveling down all social and environmental standards.This is what Parliament refuses to discuss.Democracy is lost and the peoples of Europe are lost.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- I accepted the proposal to request an expert opinion on the compatibility of the planned agreement with the Treaties, as I believe that every opportunity for a critical review of this agreement should be used.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As an advocate of the Alternative Trade Mandate, I support trade that puts people and planet ahead of profits. Citizens and civil society organisations from across Europe, as well as respected legal authorities have expressed doubts as to whether the Investment Court System (ICS) is compatible with the EU’s treaties, and with the ECJ as the sole interpreter of EU law. I am proud to have been one of the MEPs to co-sign the resolution. I voted in favour of the referral to the ECJ because it is important to have legal certainty that the rights of European citizens will not be violated, and that the democratic accountability of governments will be protected. I will continue to follow these issues actively as they develop.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for a resolution since I believe that CETA is an agreement that will strongly benefit Europe and its citizens. I don’t think there is any legal uncertainty as to whether the proposed agreement is compatible with the EU Treaties mentioned in the motion, since ICS will not be part of the provisional application of this Treaty. Thus there is no need to ask the intervention of the Court of Justice. We should now look forward on benefiting from this new international trade agreement and try to make it as more efficient and reliable as possible. Canada is a country with a strong economy and with a lot of values in common with European ones, so Europe will benefit a lot from the trade agreement.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up.- I voted against the motion for a resolution on the CJEU's opinion on the CETA Agreement.A request from the EP for the CJEU's opinion would have prevented the provisional application of the agreement and would have led to an extension of the uncertainty about the position of the European Parliament and, implicitly, of the EU as a whole with regard to CETA.I therefore considered that this initiative was not appropriate, given the statement already annexed to CETA in which Belgium clearly stated its intention to seek the opinion of the CJEU.At the same time, the postponement of the provisional application of CETA could have had negative effects from an economic and political point of view for Romania and the entire EU, including regarding the implementation of the provisions related to the elimination of visas for Romanian citizens.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. - The resolution on the referral of the anti-popular CETA to the WEU seeks to acquit the European Union. This is the well-known bankrupt propaganda that presents the European Union, the imperialist alliance of monopolies, as a pro-people union that allegedly "deviated" from its "values" due to the dominance in it of "neoliberal" perceptions. At the same time, it serves the manipulation of the people by political forces, such as SYRIZA, which as a government has widely extended its signature to CETA, while its MEPs pretend to be its opponents. Now they want to put people in the corner, to wait for the decision of the European Court, as CETA will be implemented unhindered. The European Court of Justice is an institution of the European Union and as such is ordained to serve the interests of capital. CETA is "compatible" with the European treaties and the "values" of the European Union, summarized in the four freedoms of capital, to maximize its profitability, which is the goal of the EU-Canada trade agreement. The fate of CETA, as well as TTIP, as a whole of the anti-popular policy of the European Union and governments, will be judged on the streets by popular mobilization. It will depend on the ability of the workers' and people's movement to direct their struggle to the real adversary, their monopolies, power and unions, paving the way for their own economy and power.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I did not support the resolution by which some political groups proposed submitting the CETA agreement to the European Court of Justice.On this basis, the groups wanted to suspend the procedure for this agreement in the European Parliament and then await the ruling of the Court of Justice.The Court was required to assess the question of the compatibility of certain elements of the agreement (in particular the investor protection system) with European Union law.I have chosen to vote against this resolution because the compatibility of the CETA agreement with European Union law has already been assessed by the European Parliament's Legal Service, and its conclusion was in favor of the agreement.Therefore, I see no reason to reassess the compatibility of something that has already been assessed once and with a positive result.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - The signing of a comprehensive free trade agreement by the European Union with Canada is a subject that gives rise to many controversies and fears. However, the initiators of actions aimed at referring the CETA agreement to the Court of Justice did not aim to explain the emerging reservations. The proposal that was voted on was an attempt to use public doubts to delay the ratification process of this agreement. These kinds of tricks should not be used in such a serious debate, which is why I voted against this proposal. Legal aspects of this agreement that may raise objections have been discussed many times at the forum of the European Parliament and in the Committee on International Trade, and in the opinion of many experts it complies with European law. This does not mean, however, that I remain uncritical about the agreement, and especially about the way it was negotiated. The lack of transparency in the negotiating process is a huge omission by the Commission, which has resulted in the emerging, sometimes very radical, voices of opposition to CETA. However, the process of ratifying this agreement has only just begun, and it will be the decision of the Member States. It is the citizens, thanks to the possibility of influencing the national authorities, that should make the final decision on this matter. Putting responsibility on lawyers is not the right answer to the EU's democratic deficit.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- I voted against sending the CETA Agreement (Global Economic and Trade Agreement between the EU and Canada) for an opinion by the Court of Justice, considering that the dynamization of international treaties is a necessary response to the isolationist and nationalist tendencies that are gaining strengthworld and because the entry into force of CETA before ratification by the 28 Member States is provisional in nature and does not include the ICS (arbitration mechanism) whose verification ofat this stage.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I do not support this motion for a resolution on the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties of the European Union. The European Union has its own values, norms and law arising from the founding acts and subsequent related legal documents. For this reason, it is important that all trade and economic agreements comply with these values, as there is no form of economic or other cooperation that could be more important than respecting the fundamental postulates of the Union. Encouraging new economic activities and creating new markets by breaking down existing barriers must not be accompanied by degradation of consumer protection, product quality and all other legal frameworks that regulate the market. Cooperation must be transparent, for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union and Canada. I believe that it is not necessary to carry out additional checks on the content of the contract because all legal uncertainties have been removed before signing and both signatories have signed the agreement reached in good faith.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - CETA, the free trade agreement between Europe and Canada, is illegal because it creates a supranational court for the use and consumption of multinationals, which will be able to sue states outside the normal judicial system. We of the 5 Star Movement have presented an appeal before the European judges of the Court of Justice to ask for a definitive opinion: we want to know if CETA is compatible with the European Treaties. The Court of Justice of the European Union is the only body that guarantees observance and respect for the founding treaties of the European Union. CETA undermines the uniformity of European law and with it the rights of citizens. The supranational court created by CETA could be called upon to interpret EU law. And how will a court set up to defend the rights of multinationals behave in the face of citizens' rights? All this without the European Court of Justice, that is the body responsible for interpreting EU law, having any say in the matter. We must have the courage to defend the rights of European citizens in a strong way, so I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I did not support the motion for a resolution to obtain the Court's opinion on the compatibility of the proposed Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union with the Treaties, as I consider that the trade agreement is in line with the Treaty on European Union.Union and will contribute to strengthening sustainable economic development.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, it seems that the UK Government is not only hell-bent on making Britain the dirty man of Europe again, but also lowering ambition for the rest of Europe. Our British Government has been taken to court several times now by ClientEarth for not meeting the current requirements on air pollution, specifically nitrogen dioxide, in the existing National Emission Ceilings Directive. In my constituency, the government has failed to create a clean air zone in Bristol, so air pollution will continue to cause at least 300 premature deaths every year within the city. It has been left to local campaigners to try to protect the people of Bristol from breathing dirty air. Parliament had a chance today to protect present and future generations, but the positive targets and measures in the Environment Committee report have been watered down to such a degree that supporting it would have meant condoning a policy of continued air pollution and the health damage it causes.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, medical care caused by pollution costs us between 330 and 940 billion euros a year. It's a huge amount. However, they have not led to the depletion and elimination of pollution, but, on the contrary, we continue to have cardiovascular diseases due to pollution and also to have respiratory diseases. It must be said very clearly that there are premature deaths caused by pollution. So, the money we spend, I don't know what we spend it on. Maybe they go to places where nothing happens, they just go to the sand and not to people and to eradicate pollution. Secondly, pollution is also a problem for the economy, not just an environmental problem. It is a generator of economic losses, increases costs and decreases productivity. In short: we need to monitor carefully, we need to spend money transparently and we need to check where it goes and what happens to it, and we also need to invest in innovation to really eradicate pollution and not just talk about it for years.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the Volkswagen scandal a couple of years ago was a terrible blow to the automotive industry, but few people stopped to ask how it was that we had got to the stage where the European Union was pushing for diesel fuel – which throughout our lives has been regarded as the filthier option – rather than doing what the rest of the world was doing, which was moving towards electric and hybrid cars. We now know the answer. It happened because of a brilliant lobbying operation by Volkswagen and other car manufacturers which had discovered a new form of turbo engine. The result was literally fatal. We do not know how many people died as the result of pushing diesel, because the death certificate will not show ‘diesel’. It will show ‘heart failure’ or ‘pollutants getting into the brain’. But the impact was that because of corporatism and because of crony lobbying, people who would otherwise be alive today are now not. The system, in other words, is not only corrupt and oligarchic, but is literally murderous.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this report because there is no doubt that we need to protect the atmosphere not only for ourselves but also for our children.We must protect health, the environment and lives.In my opinion, precisely because air knows no borders, it is clearly a cross-border problem and the EU's competence to work with the Member States to tackle air pollution is absolutely unquestionable.We in the Czech Republic, for example, have an area of Ostrava that is currently suffering from emissions and emissions into the air.This part of our country is affected in this way precisely because of this cross-border influence.I do not want to say which Member States in particular, but we should really address this issue in the cooperation of the Member States and in the competence of the EU institutions.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin. Ghlacas páirt sa díospóireacht faoin ábhar seo ar maidin agus bhí sé soiléir go raibh an chuid is mó de na feisirí i bhfabhar rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi thruailliú aeir atá timpeall an domhain; agus tá sé seo le feiceáil in a lán tíortha mar a dúradh, tíortha fiú amháin san Aontas Eorpach, ach go háirithe in áiteanna cosúil leis an tSín agus Vítneam. Bhí sé de phribhléid agamsa bheith i mBéising agus anuraidh i Vítneam agus bhí sé le feiceáil go soiléir go bhfuil truailliú aeir ann: daoine go raibh orthu a n-aghaidh a chosaint dá bharr. Ach anois tá siad ag iarraidh rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi agus is é an rud is tabhachtaí ná go gcuirfimid i bhfeidhm na geallúintí a tugadh in COP 21 i bPáras anuraidh agus tar éis COP 22 in Marrakech tá dóchas agam go dtarlóidh a leithéid. I mo thír féin freisin chuir siad chosc ar thabac a chaitheamh in áiteanna poiblí cosúil le bialann agus tithe tabhairne agus cabhróidh sé go mór. Go raibh míle maith agat.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Air pollution today represents a very serious and important problem and must be addressed as such.Thousands of people die or get sick every year from pollution, not to mention the cost it has on health, around € 1.4 trillion per year in Europe.The directive that is the subject of the report sets specific national reduction targets for all Member States, with the aim of reducing pollution through specific control programs.Since I believe that this report, while containing some important points, does not go far enough on the subject, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report, as the final result of the negotiations in the trilogues has reduced the demands of Parliament's initial position, making it easier for Member States to maintain the current situation.This directive has turned out to be a missed opportunity to force States to take immediate measures to improve air quality in their territory, especially in large cities.We are facing a critical situation, where thousands of deaths are taking place due to the poor quality of the air we breathe in the main urban areas of the Union, however, despite a good starting position of the European Parliament, in the negotiations withthe Council and the Commission have reduced the mandatory nature of the measures, leaving aside the real emergency that we must face.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted against this report. Air pollution in Europe causes 400 000 deaths per year and the National Emissions Ceilings Directive is a crucial piece of legislation which is meant to tackle this problem by placing appropriate limits on certain key pollutants which cause high levels of damage to public health. The agreement on updating this Directive which has come out of negotiations between the Parliament, Commission and Council is unacceptably weak. It has significantly lowered ambition on a range of pollutants to the extent that it is now estimated that this weakened agreement will lead to an extra 10 000 lives lost every year, compared to the original proposal. For these reasons I voted against endorsing this weak first reading agreement and would have preferred the three institutions to return to the negotiating table to considerably improve upon this legislation.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- After three years of negotiations, I welcome the fact that the Council and the European Parliament have finally reached an agreement.Air pollution causes more than 430,000 premature deaths in Europe per year, including more than 50,000 deaths in France.This is why it was imperative that the European Parliament adopted the "Air Quality" legislative package today.It is now done.The main objective is to respond to the health risks and the environmental effects of air pollution.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of certain atmospheric emissions in the Member States and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC. It should be noted that the European Union has made significant progress over the last 20 years in implementing specific policies on anthropogenic emissions and air quality, but that significant negative impacts and risks to the environment and human health remain unresolved. The established regime for the application of national emission ceilings should therefore be reviewed to ensure compliance with the international obligations of the Union and the Member States. I agree with the rapporteur that this directive should contribute to achieving air quality objectives set out in Union legislation in a cost-effective way, mitigating the effects of climate change by reducing short-term atmospheric emissions and improving air quality in general by strengthening synergies with Union climate and energy policies and avoiding duplication. existing legislation. In particular, this Directive should be aligned with emerging Union and international action on climate change. I agree that, in order to reduce emissions from the main sources, national air pollution control programs should include measures applicable to all relevant sectors, including agriculture, industry, road transport, non-road mobile machinery, inland waterways and national shipping. , domestic heating and solvents.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC, as this directive is an important step in tackling various problems.both health and the environment due to air pollution.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- With regard to the VW scandal and the question of emissions under real driving conditions, the issue of air quality is more topical than ever.Air pollution is highly damaging to the environment and health.Poor air quality causes around 400,000 premature deaths in the EU each year.The Parliament has therefore spoken out in favor of new regulations, the national emission reduction obligations for the pollutants sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds except methane (NMVOC), ammonia (NH3) and fine dust (particles less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter)establish.The proposed stricter limits are a step in the right direction.The goal is to reduce the public health impact of air pollution by around 50% by 2030, which is certainly a reasonable concern.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This report is unacceptable in many respects: It considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and implementation of national emission reduction programs.In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States.We cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector.I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am against further EU legislation and the consequent increased burden on Member States, I also recognise the dangers caused by the pollutants mentioned in this report. I could neither vote in favour nor vote against, and therefore I had to abstain.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this measured text because it is abnormal that air pollution in the Union still causes 400,000 premature deaths each year.I therefore welcome this project, but I stress, however, that despite this legislation, pollution levels will remain above WHO recommendations in much of the Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the reduction of certain atmospheric emissions in the Member States.The aim of this report is to reach the 2030 target.to further limit emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter and other air pollutants in EU countries.I welcome the updated rules, which set stricter emission limits for the new period (until 2030).I believe that an additional limitation on pollution will reduce the negative effects of air pollution on health.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP abstained on the legislative report on Emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We in UKIP firmly believe in the importance of improving air quality. Air pollution does not only have a negative effect on human beings, it also causes harm to plants and animals. This said, UKIP is firmly against the creation of further EU legislation. In this particular case, we are concerned of the considerable increase of administrative burden for industry and governments. Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level. We are also concerned at the possibility of fines being levied against the UK by the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The report consists of a series of amendments by the ENVI committee concerning the reduction of national emissions of Directive 2001/81 / EC setting national ceilings for certain air pollutants.The purpose of this text is to replace the aforementioned directive, in particular in line with the international commitments of the European Union (Gothenburg Protocol, 1999).The ceilings imposed on member states aim to achieve 70% of the technically achievable maximum reduction in health effects, according to the WHO definition.They are determined unilaterally by the Commission.I cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector, let alone the gas sector which includes an increasing share of biomethane.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this report which proposes to limit national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants.This must in particular aim at levels of air quality which do not entail major adverse effects or risks for human health and the environment.This objective requires Member States to commit to reducing their polluting emissions to more ambitious ceilings by 2030, to protect the health of vulnerable groups or even of course to support the transition towards investments in clean and efficient technologies.help from tax incentives.The Commission, for its part, should facilitate access to funding to ensure that measures can be adopted to meet the objectives set by the directive.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Air pollution is a major concern for public health. Poor air quality has resulted in 400,000 premature deaths, numerous sick leave from work and significant health care costs. It also generated a sharp decline in productivity, a decrease in yields and damage to buildings; considerable economic losses estimated at between 330 and 940 billion euros per year. I voted in favor of the Girling report because I agree with the need for stricter limits on pollutant emissions. Indeed, the approved text defines new national commitments for the reduction of emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles (less than a diameter of 2.5 micrometers). The European Union must continue its efforts to improve air quality and must do so by continuing to improve the control regulation which has proved ineffective in the VW case and in the discrepancy between the emissions values ​​in real driving conditions and the emissions of NOx in test tests of Euro 6 diesel cars.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I am voting against the report because, although the European Parliament and the Commission had proposed much stronger measures, these measures have not been successful during the negotiations with the Council. Weaknesses of the agreement reached: - The Council managed to eliminate methane and mercury from the final agreement. - Flexibility for Member States. The Council has succeeded in forcing Parliament to accept several of the directive's so-called 'flexibilities', which makes the limits far more difficult to enforce. - There are no binding intermediate targets for 2025. Parliament called for binding intermediate targets for all pollutants except methane, but in the end accepted the Council's position that these targets were only indicative. - The reduction of premature mortality in 2030. The original text amended by the European Parliament contained a legally binding commitment to reduce premature mortality in 2030 caused by air pollution by 52% compared to 2005. The proposal is finally accepted of the Board of 49.6%. While the agreed text seeks to further improve air quality conditions, the text was significantly watered down by the Council during the negotiations.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this report on the agreement obtained regarding emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants.There has been a lot of debate, but what has been achieved is a firm step in the right direction that has led me to support you in this vote.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I voted against the report of the ENVI committee on the reduction of national emissions of Directive 2001/81 / EC setting national ceilings for certain air pollutants.This report is unsatisfactory for two reasons.First, it considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and implementation of national emission reduction programs.Finally, we cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would place too heavy a burden on the agricultural sector.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- While presenting some passages that can be shared, I believe that during the negotiation phase our Government could have negotiated more favorable conditions for our companies.I am convinced that it would have been more appropriate to proceed with the "second reading" which would have made it possible to evaluate in a more in-depth and transparent manner the impact of the various proposals on the table in order to obtain a broader consensus among the member states.For these reasons I could not fully support this text and I expressed myself with an abstention.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. Air pollution in Europe causes 400 000 deaths per year and the National Emissions Ceilings Directive is a crucial piece of legislation which is meant to tackle this problem by placing appropriate limits on certain key pollutants which cause high levels of damage to public health. The agreement on updating this Directive which has come out of negotiations between the Parliament, Commission and Council is unacceptably weak. It has significantly lowered ambition on a range of pollutants to the extent that it is now estimated that this weakened agreement will lead to an extra 10 000 lives lost every year, compared to the original proposal. Intense lobbying from agri-business has led to a text which crucially no longer includes a cap for methane as well as a lowering of the limit for ammonia, two pollutants which contribute significantly towards premature mortality and adverse health outcomes in the EU. For these reasons I voted against endorsing this weak first reading agreement and would have preferred the three institutions to return to the negotiating table to considerably improve upon this legislation.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths a year, and its economic cost to health is estimated between 300 and 900 billion euros per year. Many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected, and around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution considered detrimental to human health. Within the Commission's Air Quality Package (12/18/2013), a proposal to amend Directive 2001/81 / EC on national emission ceilings (NEC / TNE Directive) is included, which replaces the current annual limitation regime of certain atmospheric pollutants. The goal is to reduce emissions in order to address the health risks and environmental effects they pose. The proposal sets limits for each State to five toxic pollutants: sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), fine particles (PM2.5), non-methane volatile organic compounds (MMVOC) and ammonia (NH3). Although I would have liked a more ambitious agreement, in view of the Council's opposition, I voted in favor of the agreement reached in order to implement the important steps it contains in the face of the high risks to health and the environmental impacts generated by pollution. atmospheric.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it expresses Parliament's position on the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of certain atmospheric emissions in the Member States.Poor air quality contributes to premature deaths, sick leave, high health care costs, lost productivity, lost crops and damage to buildings.In Europe, the total external health costs of air pollution to society range from around € 330 billion to € 940 billion per year.EUR.In addition, there is growing evidence that atmospheric nitrogen deposition is changing the natural environment, such as eutrophication and acidification, reducing the diversity of surface vegetation, slowing plant growth and creating an unbalanced diet.Efforts are being made to reduce air pollution throughout the Union, but most Member States are not meeting agreed standards.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new rules require Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the level of commitment to reduce emissions of ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to deal with it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch Presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agree with the proposed amendment to the directive, as I know how important it is to continue good practices in reducing emissions of major air pollutants.Cleaner air has an important aspect in public health.Low air quality contributes to premature mortality, absenteeism due to illness, high health care costs, lower productivity, crop loss and damage to buildings.At the same time, it is worrying that, despite the work done to reduce air pollution across the Union, many Member States still do not meet the agreed standards.In addition, the EU is still far from its long-term goal: to adhere to the recommended limit values as dictated by the World Health Organization guidelines.

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing.- The one approved today is a bearish agreement and that is why my vote was against.In the inter-institutional negotiation, the Council dictated the conditions and Parliament gave in on all the main points.In the new text on emission limits, the reduction targets for pollutants have been weakened, the 2025 targets are not binding and in certain circumstances various flexibilities are foreseen for compliance with the limits.Air pollution remains the main environmental risk factor for human health, lowers the quality of life and is the estimated cause of 467,000 premature deaths a year in Europe: more needed to be done!

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: in writing. ‒ I support this this deal because it will cut the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensuring, for the first time, that all polluting sectors, including agriculture, take responsibility for what they emit. The Member States now need to act to fully implement the Directive and furthermore step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants because I strongly believe the EU institutions should review and update their ceilings to emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds and ammonia in order to better address the air pollution in the Union.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Air pollution, neglected for years by politics, is now among the strategic priorities as a source of great concern for public health. Poor air quality leads to premature deaths, sick leave, substantial health care costs, lost productivity, reduced yields and damage to buildings. In Europe, the total external health costs borne by society and deriving from air pollution are estimated to be between 330 and 940 billion euros per year. In addition, there is a growing body of evidence showing that nitrogen deposition in the atmosphere leads to changes in the natural environment, including reduced diversity of soil vegetation, reduced plant growth and nutritional imbalances due to eutrophication. and acidification. Despite major improvements, many Member States are still far from agreed standards for reducing pollutant emissions. The new objectives for 2030 contained in the proposal under discussion aim to achieve about 70% of the reductions recommended by the WHO parameters: it is an important step forward, on which we cannot back down an inch and of which we must ask for the full and concrete application.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This report aims to amend Directive 2001/81 / EC which sets the national ceilings for the emission of certain atmospheric pollutants such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, ammonia and methane. This revision recommends tightening up the legislation in force in the Member States in order to achieve ambitious objectives for 2020 and 2030. On the one hand, this report considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission as well as the prerogatives of the European Union in terms of drawing up emission reduction programs to the detriment of our national sovereignty. On the other hand, the reduction of methane emissions, which the rapporteur calls for, will reinforce the constraints weighing on the agricultural sector, already in the grip of serious difficulties due to the fall in the price of raw materials, Russian embargo and the proliferation of free trade agreements. That’s why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - About 90% of Europe's city dwellers are exposed to pollutants in concentrations above air quality levels, which are considered harmful to health. At the same time, in Europe, the total external health costs associated with air pollution are estimated at EUR 330-940 billion per year. Although action has been taken to reduce air pollution in the Union, many Member States do not meet the agreed standards. Thus, the EU is still far from meeting its long-term goal of adopting and meeting the pollution limits recommended by the 2005 WHO Air Quality Guidelines. I am in favor of this report because I believe that, in order to pursue a sustainable path, Europe will have to show ambition and not confine itself to current legislation, and without the application of effective basic legislation, Member States will not will be able to meet their emission reduction targets.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up.- The proposal for a directive on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC gives a different position to certain Member States.In the case of Romania, at the end of the negotiations it was imposed targets to reduce emissions disproportionate to GDP, investment capacity and the stage of technological development, despite its constructive approach, demonstrated by the important voluntary contribution to increasing the level of ambition ofits targets in Annex II.I believe that the emission reduction targets in this directive need to be realistic and feasible in order to reduce the negative consequences of air pollution on human health, while at the same time considering that they do not affect economic development.I therefore abstained.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the reduction of national emissions of air pollutants, which is part of the committee’s legislative package on improving air quality.This is a first reading agreement on the downward revision of the national emission ceilings of five polluting substances for 2020. Ambitious emission reduction commitments are needed to resolve the problems of pollutant incidenceatmospheres on health and the environment.The trialogue agreement excludes enteric methane emissions produced by ruminants from the scope of the directive.This withdrawal makes it possible to protect European agriculture and to maintain consistency between the Union's policies, in particular the environmental policy and the common agricultural policy.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP abstained on the legislative report on Emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We in UKIP firmly believe in the importance of improving air quality. Air pollution does not only have a negative effect on human beings, it also causes harm to plants and animals. This said, UKIP is firmly against the creation of further EU legislation. In this particular case, we are concerned of the considerable increase of administrative burden for industry and governments. Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level. We are also concerned at the possibility of fines being levied against the UK by the EU.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of for new EU standards to be put in place for cleaner air as from 2020 and 2030. The plan provides for ambitious, but realistic standards. It will continue to drive emission limits further downwards between 2020 and 2030. This is an important step taken by EU legislators in order to continue our work on cleaner air for our citizens.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Air pollution causes the death of around 400 000 citizens every year within the European Union and consequent costs for the health system of the Member States estimated at between 300 and 900 billion euros, again on an annual basis. To reduce the impact of air pollution on public health, I decided to vote in favor of updating the directive concerning the reduction of national emissions of certain pollutants. In fact, I believe that each Member State, compatibly with its own possibilities, must compulsorily reduce its emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds in order to protect the environment and the well-being of its own citizens. To this end, Member States should send the Commission national pollution control programs every two years for all economic sectors, with particular reference to industrial activities and transport. I welcome the fact that the update of the directive commits the Member States to also assess the impacts of air pollution on aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. Finally, I am pleased that the directive has now included specific provisions for the protection of vulnerable groups and in particular of minors (for example the ban on the consumption of solid fuels in residential areas).

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We are voting in favor of the report and pointing out that air pollution has an important place on the political agenda as a major public health issue.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC.Although there are several positive elements in the report, I do not think that it manages to address important issues and, therefore, does not propose sufficient solutions.That is why I voted against.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - In the last 20 years, considerable progress has been recorded in the Union in terms of air quality and anthropogenic atmospheric emissions thanks, in particular, to the adoption of specific policies. Therefore, I welcome the setting of maximum limits for some of the most harmful gases in line with the long-term objectives of an atmosphere free of negative impacts on health and the environment. The approved provision intends to reduce the levels and deposits of acidifying and eutrophicating atmospheric pollutants and other pollutants, including ozone. In addition, the urgency of synergies between the future directive and the European climate and energy programs is confirmed. The request to Member States to minimize annual anthropogenic emissions in accordance with national commitments applicable from 2020 is followed by a request to monitor and update the Commission on its progress. However, flexibility mechanisms are envisaged, but these require clarification on the pollutants in question and on the sectors affected by this. Finally, Member States must ensure that the public concerned is consulted at an early stage in the development and adoption of national pollution control programs and at any stage of such activities prior to their actual completion.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report because the proposed measures will make it possible to significantly reduce air pollution by 2030.I think that with this text we are combining ambitious goals with a realistic approach: no general tightening of the directive, but stricter national limit values for emissions of certain pollutants such asB. for nitrogen oxides, which are indeed the main cause of air pollution in Europe.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the provision as I agree with the new limits envisaged by the text envisaged by 2020 and 2030. Air cleaning must become increasingly a priority within European policies with the aim of protecting in an increasingly incisive and the health of citizens is concrete: I am convinced that the measures envisaged by this directive can contribute to achieving this objective. The planned action will in fact continue towards the reduction of harmful emissions such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia, volatile organic compounds or fine dust (PM 2.5). It is necessary that the EU continue to pursue its strategy, guaranteeing in the medium term the pursuit of a better and healthier air quality in the EU territory and, in the short term, supporting the Member States in the process of achieving the EU standards required by directives on the matter. Air pollution, which for years has unfortunately been neglected by politics, must today more than ever become the subject of specific legislation also to eliminate the possible risks associated with the health of citizens.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The aims put forward in this report should be introduced in a cost-effective manner in line with air quality objectives set in Union legislation. I agree therefore with the rapporteur that Member States should ensure that impacts on small to medium-sized farms are fully taken into account and these impacts do not entail significant additional costs that cannot be borne by such farms. Such should also contribute to the reduction of the health-related costs of air pollution in the Union by improving EU citizens’ quality of life as well as to favour the transition to a green economy; given that in Europe the total external health-related costs to society from air pollution are estimated to be in the range of EUR 330 to 940 billion per year. It is of the essence that Member States establish a system of routine and non-routine environmental inspections and market surveillance and public reporting of mobile and stationary sources to ensure that policies and measures are effective in delivering emission reductions under real operating conditions.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing.- Although limiting air pollution is rightly a priority for Europe, this report has not succeeded in guaranteeing a marked reduction in the atmospheric pollutants in question, rather extensive concessions have been made such as the exclusion of methane from thelist of pollutants to limit.In addition, an excessively large degree of flexibility has been found which risks precluding the effectiveness of these emissions limitations.Therefore, my vote on this is negative.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report, as the final result of the negotiations in the trilogues has lowered the demands of Parliament's initial position, making it easier for Member States to maintain the current situation.This directive has turned out to be a missed opportunity to force States to take immediate measures to improve air quality in their territory, especially in large cities.We are facing a critical situation, where thousands of deaths are taking place due to the poor quality of the air we breathe in the main urban areas of the Union, however, despite a good starting position of the European Parliament, in the negotiations withthe Council and the Commission have reduced the mandatory nature of the measures, leaving aside the real emergency that we must face.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - Air pollution is a cross-border problem, important for both human health and the environment, which affects all citizens of the Union and requires immediate action. Today, poor air quality leads to premature deaths, sick leave, substantial health care costs, lost productivity, decreased yields and damage to buildings. I believe that the proposed revision of Directive 2001/81 / EC on national emission ceilings can be an effective tool to achieve 70% of the technically feasible maximum reductions in health effects, as established by the WHO. In the last decade, in fact, air quality has been neglected and this has favored the presence of divergent and incoherent policies, which must be overcome. To this end, I welcome the provision of measures for early identification of problems in cases where Member States risk failing to meet their obligations, in order to enable them to take corrective action.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - EU legislation is based on sound and comprehensive impact assessments. Air quality is an issue related to both the environment and human health, which knows no borders, directly affects every citizen of the European Union and requires immediate action. After many years in the background, air pollution has returned to the center of the political agenda as a major concern for public health. In Europe alone, the total health costs associated with air pollution are estimated at EUR 330-940 billion per year. Although action has been taken to reduce air pollution in the Union, many Member States do not meet the agreed standards. I voted in favor of more effective regulation and a reduction in administrative burdens for both businesses and Member States. The European Union is still far from meeting its target of adopting and meeting pollution limits.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on emissions of certain types of atmospheric pollution.Concerns arise from the fact that the wording of this initiative, assuming emission limitations, may have negative effects on the Polish agricultural, metallurgical, construction and especially heat sectors.The introduction of changes will result in a high financial outlay related to the reduction of emissions of sulfur dioxide and ammonia compounds, which are listed in the directives.In order to avoid negative consequences for the country and protect the Polish economy, I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year. This is unacceptable. We need to address the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. I am in favour of this report as it seeks to set limits on each Member State for five toxic pollutants and thus to reduce national emissions. It is high time that we implement measures that address dangerous pollutants. The European Union needs to prioritise our citizens’ health and force governments to act and take responsibility for what they emit.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I agree with the rapporteur's position on the Commission's commitment to introduce smarter and more efficient regulation at European level and to reduce administrative burdens for both businesses and Member States.The National Emission Ceilings Directive must also be in line with this.At the same time, I believe that for the long-term success of this Directive, we need: reliable data, improved information exchange, adequate monitoring and accurate reporting for both national emission ceilings and all basic legislative instruments.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - According to data recently published in a report by the European Environment Agency, in the period from 2000 to 2014, fine particles have caused the death of over 430,000 people in Europe every year, 66,000 in our country alone. A worrying and dramatic photograph, which confirms how smog and poor air quality remain the number one problem in Europe for public health and the environment around us. With the approval of the directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants, which updates and modifies the previous directive 2003/35 / EC, the European institutions are now taking a first step forward, towards reducing the limits of the major pollutants, through the definition of significant targets to be achieved by 2030. Premature deaths, to which must be added the total costs deriving from air pollution - estimated at over 940 billion euros per year across Europe - are an unacceptable burden that deserves a more responsibility and even more ambitious efforts by not only the European Union, but above all by the member states, which will be called upon to implement this directive.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This report proposes to adopt the result of the interinstitutional negotiations relating to the directive on national pollutant emission ceilings (NECD). This text aims to replace the current Union regime concerning the annual cap on national emissions of air pollutants and ensures that the national emission ceilings for the Member States apply until 2020. I fully share the objectives of this text which aims in particular to reduce the impact on human health of pollutant emissions, causing a significant number of victims each year. I was also particularly committed, within the AGRI and ENVI committees, to ensure that these limits are nevertheless reasonable and realistic with regard to methane (CH4) and more particularly enteric methane. Enteric methane, which is a release exclusively from ruminant farming, is very difficult to reduce unless the animals are locked up year round. I am delighted that enteric methane is no longer part of the ceilings in question and that at the same time the level of ambition of this legislation has remained very high. For all these reasons, I voted in favor of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported the directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants.As air quality is a problem common to all Member States, the fight against air pollution is one of the major missions of the European Union.This directive allows us to step up our efforts by limiting the emission of the largest European air pollutants with binding targets for 2020, 2025 and 2030. While air pollution is responsible for around 400,000 premature deaths in the European Union eachyear, I welcome the ambitious target we have set to reduce mortality from air pollution by almost 50% by 2030.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report concerning the revision of a directive which sets national emission ceilings for five polluting substances. It is important that regulations protect European citizens from environmental pollution, which is a public health problem to be taken very seriously. This directive sets ambitious objectives, such as precisely that of reducing mortality from atmospheric pollution by 50%. But at the same time it includes realistic national emission ceilings which respect the principle of subsidiarity of the Member States. Thus, each country can and must commit to reducing its emissions of air pollutants. I am also happy that enteric methane has been excluded from the substances mentioned in this directive. It seemed relatively difficult to integrate it coherently, the emissions of this methane being very difficult to measure. This exclusion was essential in the interests of European farmers.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new rules require Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the level of commitment to reduce emissions of ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to deal with it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch Presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- Air pollution is a source of public health concern.It is a commitment that the European Commission has been carrying out since 2013 with the "Clean Air" package aimed at improving air quality by 2030. I support the early detection of environmental problems and the adoption of corrective measures.Furthermore, I reiterate the need for the Commission to play a role of supervision and assistance to the Member States in the key aspects of their national programs.For these reasons, I thought it appropriate to vote for more stringent EU legislation on environmental issues.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which fixes national ceilings for the emissions of five pollutants (sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds, ammonia and fine particles) and excludes themethane (which comes 50% from agricultural activities) of the directive to address the concerns of the European agricultural sector.I had already been able to express myself on the issue of methane emanating from ruminants.It was absurd to want to limit these emissions except to put aside livestock farming and the active part that the agricultural world also takes in the fight against global warming through the maintenance of meadows and countryside, real carbon sinks.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.I spoke orally in plenary on this proposal by MP Julie Girling, amending the text of Directive 2001/81 / EC fixing national ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants.Julie Girling's proposals strengthen the powers of the European Union to the detriment of the Member States, and remove certain facilities granted to them (reductions in emissions of nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide and particles from maritime tradeinternational).

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I voted for this dossier. As part of the revised National Emission Ceilings Directive (NECD), part of the Commission's Clean Air package, it replaces the current Union regime of the annual national emission ceiling for air pollutants, as set out in Directive 2001/81 / EC on sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs) and ammonia (NH3) by 2020. The new directive will create new commitments to reduce national emissions applicable from 2020 and 2030 to these pollutants, as well as for fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and methane (CH4).
