I support the idea that Member States should have some flexibility in achieving the 2030 targets, as the situations and requirements for achieving these targets differ drastically, but that the wording itself should be clarified to ensure that the provisions are not open to abuse. As this is for the health of all citizens in all Member States of the European Union, this issue must be a priority. Methane is excluded from the scope as the Commission has confirmed that it will carry out a methane review even if it is not specified in the directive.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. Atmospheric air quality is an important cross-border issue of health and the environment, which has a huge impact on all EU citizens and requires immediate action. All Member States must fulfill their obligations, as well as provide for measures to identify the problem in a timely manner, so that remedial action can be taken. We therefore vote in favor of the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new regulation requires Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the extent of the commitment to reduce ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) emissions related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to address it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch Presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the emissions of atmospheric pollutants. This aim of the report was to establish new national emission reduction commitments from 2020 and 2030 but it was weakened to the extent that I couldn’t support it. Methane was completely removed from the text, and the 2025 target was made non-binding. I want better measures to protect my constituents and their environment in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- Air pollution in the Union is one of the biggest health problems we have in front of us.Every year, people's lives are lost due totoxic particles in the air.It is not only a health tragedy but also costs communities around the EU huge sums.Here it is important that we raise our ambition and access the dangerous substances in the air.I have long pushed for binding measures in this area - here we must continue to work for an ambitious climate policy that puts citizens' well-being at the center.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: this report does not satisfy us, in fact, in many respects: It considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the preparation and application ofnational emission reduction programs.In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States.We cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the Directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing.- Air pollution is the main environmental risk factor not only for human health but also for animal and plant biodiversity.Its negative repercussions on ecosystems, buildings, materials and the climate cause incalculable damage.It is responsible for an excessive number of premature deaths, illnesses and hospitalizations across the European continent.WHO and OECD believe that the economic cost of the impact of air pollution on health in Europe amounts to around 1.4 trillion euros.The worsening of air quality will not be stemmed with unrealistic objectives, therefore we can only unfavorably welcome a regulation that ends up protecting the affairs of a few at the expense of protecting the environment and health.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - In 2013, the European Commission adopted a package of proposals to improve air quality in Europe, called the "Air quality package". The main part of the package is a proposal to revise the National Emission Limits Directive (NEC). The current European Commission considered withdrawing the proposal in 2014, but due to strong resistance from the European Parliament and several NGOs, the proposal was maintained. The revised NEC Directive provides for controls on different types of pollutants in Member States. Its aim will be to halve the number of premature deaths - estimated at 400 000 per year in the EU - caused by air pollution by 2030. This revision proposal sets out new national emission reduction commitments, applicable from 2020 and 2030 , for sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and ammonia (NH3), and for fine particles (PM2.5) and methane (CH4) as well. As a result of the vote in the Environment Committee, among other things, mercury (Hg) was added to the pollutant list, average targets for 2025 were added to legislation, methane targets were postponed until 2030 (to give the agricultural sector time adaptation) and the European Commission's proposal for flexibility has been deleted.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- Air pollution, neglected for years by national and European politics, must be included among the strategic priorities of the EU agenda, as it represents a source of great concern for public health.I voted in favor of the proposed revision of national emission limits for certain air pollutants, as it concerns national commitments to reduce emissions, flexibility and the maintenance of methane.In particular, I believe it is important that the directive will allow Member States more flexibility to achieve the 2030 targets, while maintaining a program for transparency in each country's commitment.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The European Union is considered a leader in the fight against air pollution and climate change. Over the last decade, the European Union has made considerable efforts and introduced strict legislation. However, several Member States still have difficulty complying with established rules and agreed standards. Member States must have all the information on how they are meeting their emission reduction commitments. If Member States are at risk of failing to comply, measures should be put in place to identify the problem in a timely manner, allowing countries to take corrective action. It is very important for the European Commission to play a comprehensive surveillance and warning role in this regard, by helping Member States with key elements of their national program or, in the most serious cases, by enabling them to take the necessary measures. In future, the European Commission will have to focus more on regulating several sectors of the economy that have an impact on air pollution. A good example is the car industry, where the European Commission should present a regulation on Euro 6c emissions as soon as possible.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am refraining from the report as it would have been more appropriate to proceed with the second reading to assess in a more in-depth and transparent way the impact of the different proposals on the table in order to obtain a broader consensus among the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. Air quality is a major cross-border issue of health and the environment, which has a huge impact on all EU citizens and requires immediate action. All Member States must fulfill their obligations, as well as provide for measures to identify the problem in a timely manner, so that remedial action can be taken. I therefore vote in favor of the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ We must urgently tackle premature deaths as a result of toxic air pollution – which amount to over 400 000 in the EU. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed. I agree to support the full inclusion of ammonia but to exempt emissions of enteric methane produced by ruminant livestock from the Directive. I welcome the fact that we raised the overall level of ambition of the directive, by changing the ceilings for nitrogen oxides (NOx) and setting binding targets for 2025 to ensure linear reduction of emissions. It is important to establish requirements for drawing up and updating of national air pollution control programmes and ensuring emission reductions from road transport and other sources.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new rules require Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the level of commitment to reduce emissions of ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to deal with it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch Presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report considering that air quality is a matter of great importance with regard to human health and the environment. Poor air quality contributes to premature death, sick leave, high health care costs, lost productivity, crop failure and damage to buildings. In Europe, the external health-related costs to society from air pollution are estimated to range from 330 to 940 billion euros per year. Although work has been done to reduce air pollution across the Union, many Member States are falling short of agreed standards, thus the Union remains far from its long-term goal of meeting the pollutant limits recommended in the quality guidelines 2005 WHO air regulations. The Commission's proposal is based on achieving 70% of the maximum technically feasible reductions in health effects, as specified by the WHO. Now, from the institutions of the Union, we must carefully follow the development of regulations and their compliance by the Member States.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important report on ensuring our air quality and on action needed to be taken so that there are no significant negative impacts on and risks to human health and the environment. I support the report in establishing emission reduction commitments for the Member States in atmospheric emissions of sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC), ammonia (NH3) and fine particulate matter (PM 2.5 ). For this directive to be successful and to ensure air quality and emission levels in the EU, the Member States should set up and implement national control programmes. To achieve this it is important that the Member States can access EU funds for implementation of this directive and that there is an easy access for Member States to exchange best practises and experiences in reducing emissions and ensuring air-quality. Lastly I support the flexibility for Member States that is included in this directive, it is important that Member States are not forced to take a certain action to ensure air quality and emissions levels as the most efficient way for one Member State to deal with these issue might not hold true for another.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I expressed my support for the amendment of the directive on the emissions ceiling, I believe it is important to set new high standards to further limit certain harmful substances such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen, particles, ammonia.I want to underline the important improvement for public health: it is estimated that by 2030 the number of deaths due to toxic air can be halved;it will therefore be essential to verify that the governments' commitments to drastically reduce emissions according to the required standards are maintained.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC because it is an important vote that unlocks a dossier almost for 3 years and giving important answers to European citizens. The quality of the air we breathe is not just an environmental issue, but a serious health emergency, with nearly 90% of citizens in the EU living in polluted places and around 400,000 linked premature deaths annually. If we want to improve the quality of life of our citizens, especially in large urban areas, an ambitious reform is therefore necessary, with strong objectives. I personally applaud the effort made by Parliament, and by the S & amp; D Group in particular, in favor of binding targets by 2025. However, the agreement with the Council discounts the needs of governments, and gives us more flexible and open legislation, non-binding targets, the exclusion of certain sectors and a series of flexibility clauses. However, the agreement remains an important step forward, the implementation and implementation of which will now have to be carefully scrutinized by Parliament.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the “Report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC” by my esteemed colleague Julie Girling.The report is very balanced: it recognizes Europe's successful efforts to improve air quality, but at the same time it sets new, achievable goals to further improve the situation.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Commission wants to replace the existing NEC Directive with a new one. I am against the creation of further EU legislation and I am concerned about the considerable increase of administrative burden for industry and government. However, due to the sensitivity of the issue I abstained on this report (elevated levels and long-term exposure to air pollution can lead to severe conditions affecting human health).

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, which constitutes an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300bn and 900bn every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed. This deal will cut the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensuring, for the first time, that all polluting sectors, including agriculture, take responsibility for what they emit. The Member States now need to act to fully implement the directive and furthermore step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I am voting against the report because, although the European Parliament and the Commission had proposed much stronger measures, these measures have not been successful during the negotiations with the Council. Weaknesses of the agreement reached: - The Council managed to eliminate methane and mercury from the final agreement. - Flexibility for Member States. The Council has succeeded in forcing Parliament to accept several of the so-called 'flexibilities' in the Directive, which makes the limits much more difficult to enforce. - There are no binding intermediate targets for 2025. Parliament called for binding intermediate targets for all pollutants except methane, but in the end accepted the Council's position that these targets were only indicative. - The reduction of premature mortality in 2030. The original text amended by the European Parliament contained a legally binding commitment to reduce premature mortality in 2030 caused by air pollution by 52% compared to 2005. The proposal is finally accepted of the Board of 49.6%. While the agreed text seeks to further improve air quality conditions, the text was significantly watered down by the Council during the negotiations.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up.- I believe that measures taken at European level in the field of environmental protection must be real and the correlation of reduction targets with each country's GDP and with investment, refurbishment and research opportunities must be taken into account.For this reason, I voted against this report.I believe that care for the environment must be permanent because the impact of an unhealthy environment on the population can be devastating, but we must also consider other issues that affect the population.The fact that the Netherlands has set for Romania, for example, a target for sulfur dioxide of 77%, while the Netherlands has only 28%, is another reason why I cannot vote on this report.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, which constitutes an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because the European Union must protect its citizens against the public health scourge of air pollution.This is a real silent mass killer, responsible in France for 48,000 premature deaths per year.In some urban areas, breathing room air is as dangerous as smoking 10 cigarettes a day!This new directive therefore imposes the setting of national emission ceilings for five polluting substances in order to achieve the ambitious objective of reducing by almost 50% by 2030 the mortality due to air pollution.However, I am satisfied that methane emissions ultimately fall outside the scope of this directive.It was not the right legal framework and it would only create additional complications for our farmers.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new regulation requires Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the extent of the commitment to reduce ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) emissions related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas, so it would be more appropriate to continue to deal with it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. The purpose of the directive is to reduce national emissions of certain air pollutants, in order to address the extremely significant health and environmental risks, in particular air pollution in the Union. However, the report shows serious deficits, especially with regard to the removal of the ceiling for methane and mercury emissions, as well as the absence of binding intermediate targets (2025) for pollution reduction (there is only a reference to indicative targets). We therefore voted against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with the majority of MEPs, I supported this report on the emission of certain atmospheric pollutants which was agreed on with the Council. Air pollution a major health risk in the EU that causes more than 400 000 premature deaths each year. It is a cross-border threat that should be tackled at the European level. This Directive aims to achieve this by: - updating reduction targets for 2020 based on the current NEC Directive for certain pollutants; - new reduction targets for 2030 for the same pollutants. It is hoped that such measures will avoid tens of thousands of premature deaths annually and improve the quality of the environment. Meeting the new targets will cut the negative health effects of pollution by half by 2030. Tackling air pollution also brings economic benefits to society, since the economic cost of the health impacts of air pollution is estimated at 3-9% of GDP. I would like to point out that methane will not be part of this directive as was originally planned by the EP it will be dealt with under separate legislation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new rules require Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the level of commitment to reduce emissions of ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to address it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of this directive, which is an important step in addressing the high risks to human health and the environmental impact of air pollution. It has been found that there are 400 000 premature deaths each year due to air pollution, with an estimated economic cost to health of between EUR 300 and 900 billion each year. High levels of air pollution, which are harmful to human health, affect around 90% of Europeans. Urgent measures to reduce hazardous pollutants are needed to cover all sectors, thus reducing the number of deaths by almost half by 2030. Following the entry into force of these measures, European Union governments would be forced to ensure and assumes responsibility for polluting sectors. Member States must take measures to reduce air pollution and implement the Directive, as well as step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC as deterioration of human health and require urgent action. Air pollution directly and strongly affects premature death, rising health care costs, diversity of ground growth, plant growth, and a number of other problems. The targets for reducing air pollution have not yet been achieved, and concrete measures are needed to achieve the Union's long-term and consistent goals. I support the new emission limits for 2020 and 2030, and the development of national air pollution control programs. Furthermore, I believe that there is a need for smarter and more efficient legislation that will reduce the administrative burden for Member States and businesses, and better exchange of information at all levels. In this context, it is necessary for Member States to be clearly informed of the state of the impact of their actions, and to take concrete corrective action in the event of non-compliance.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- I am not satisfied with this agreement, which has the effect of increasing the regulatory power of the Commission and the hold of the European Union over its Member States, which are deprived of certain facilities which were previously granted to them.Finally, the inclusion of methane in the directive seriously undermines the agricultural sector.I voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this report because the European Union has made significant progress in the area of the protection of our environment and human health so far, but I believe that we have to continue in our efforts and keep leading by an example. The Commission’s proposal calls on Members States to contribute to air quality by reducing the pollution caused by anthropogenic air emissions. I am in favour of high standards of environmental legislation and that is why I supported this proposal ambitiously contributing to the EU’s global strategy to combat air pollution as well as the overall environmental legislative framework.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: written.- The SP voted in favor of this report as it represents progress on the current emission ceilings and should be seen as a step in the right direction.At the same time, we do not consider the set ceilings to be sufficient and we strive for stricter standards.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleague Julie Girling's report on air pollutant emissions.The text specifically targeted five pollutants including nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide and fine particles, with the aim of drastically reducing them by 2030. The Union has recorded nearly 400,000 deaths linked to pollution inEurope, which also has repercussions in terms of health expenditure or lost working days.Thus, this report is part of the concrete measures to combat urban pollution, in the interest of our fellow citizens.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ Air pollution in Europe causes 400 000 deaths per year and the National Emissions Ceilings Directive is a crucial piece of legislation which is meant to tackle this problem by placing appropriate limits on certain key pollutants which cause high levels of damage to public health.  The agreement on updating this Directive which has come out of negotiations between Parliament, the Commission and the Council is unacceptably weak. It has significantly lowered ambition on a range of pollutants to the extent that it is now estimated that this weakened agreement will lead to an extra 10 000 lives lost every year, compared to the original proposal.  Intense lobbying from agri-business has led to a text which crucially no longer includes a cap for methane as well as a lowering of the limit for ammonia, two pollutants which contribute significantly towards premature mortality and adverse health outcomes in the EU. For these reasons EH Bildu has voted against endorsing this weak first reading agreement and would have preferred the three institutions to return to the negotiating table to considerably improve upon this legislation.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which sets new ceilings for the emissions of several air pollutants.Air pollution has become a major concern of public opinion due to its negative effects on health and the environment.It was necessary to replace the existing directive on national emission ceilings and to set new ceilings for emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds for 2020 and 2030. J 'I also voted in favor of this report because it extends the scope of the directive to microparticles from 2020.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - While neglected by politicians for many years, air pollution has become a major issue on the political agenda as a major public health issue. Poor air quality causes premature deaths, absenteeism due to illness, significant health care costs, loss of productivity, crop yields and damage to buildings. In Europe, the total external health costs to society due to air pollution are estimated at between € 330-940 billion a year. Recognizing this, the rapporteur also believes that it is imperative that the competent authorities be empowered to ensure that they can take the necessary action to comply with all the legislation concerning the 2030 thresholds. A typical example of such action would be the introduction of low-emission zones, a system for charging road traffic pollution charges to reduce diesel vehicle emissions in urban areas most affected by nitrogen oxide and particulate emissions. I therefore voted in favor of the report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting in favor of this proposed law.While the Commission proposal is less far-reaching, the committee has done a good job and produced a report that is acceptable to all.In principle, a Europe-wide strategy to improve air quality is also desirable.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, which is an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Given that poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year, and the economic cost for ill health estimated at between EUR 300 and EUR 900 billion each year – measures to address dangerous pollutants are badly needed.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new rules require Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the level of commitment to reduce emissions of ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to deal with it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since in comparison to initial draft now we have much weaker text on the table than it was before unsuccessful negotiations with Council.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I supported the agreement reached on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants, as I believe that new specific targets are needed to reduce air pollution, which is a major problem for both the environment and human health. I support the new national targets for reducing emissions of the five major air pollutants by 2030 and the specific commitments provided in the report to adopt national control programs. The EU is a major player in the fight against climate change, some of which is due to air and environmental pollution. At the same time, the health of European citizens must be a key commitment for the EU. For this reason, I believe that it is necessary for the Member States to commit themselves to fulfilling their specific commitments to reduce emissions under the directive.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. Air pollution in Europe causes 400 000 deaths per year and the National Emissions Ceilings Directive is a crucial piece of legislation which is meant to tackle this problem by placing appropriate limits on certain key pollutants which cause high levels of damage to public health. The agreement on updating this directive which has come out of negotiations between the Parliament, Commission and Council is unacceptably weak. It has significantly lowered ambition on a range of pollutants to the extent that it is now estimated that this weakened agreement will lead to an extra 10 000 lives lost every year, compared to the original proposal. Intense lobbying has led to a text which crucially no longer includes a cap for methane as well as a lowering of the limit for ammonia, two pollutants which contribute significantly towards premature mortality and adverse health outcomes in the EU. For these reasons I voted against endorsing this weak first reading agreement and would have preferred the three institutions to return to the negotiating table to considerably improve upon this legislation.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ After years of political neglect, air pollution has become the single largest environmental cause of premature death in urban Europe, productivity loss, crop yield loss and damage to buildings. Over the last couple of decades, emission reductions have led to improvements in air quality in Europe, but not enough to avoid an unacceptable 400 000 premature deaths in Europe and growing damage to environment. I supported the resolution because the growing air pollution represents a real health threat to the EU, its Member States and citizens. I call particularly on Member States to adopt and implement national air pollution control programmes with a view to meeting their emission reduction requirements and to contributing effectively to the achievement of the Union air quality objectives. Most importantly, in order to reduce emissions from the main contributors, national air pollution control programmes should include measures applicable to all relevant sectors, including agriculture, industry, road transport, non-road mobile machinery, inland and domestic shipping, domestic heating and solvents.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the emissions of certain air pollutants.This text considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and application of national emission reduction programs.In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States.I cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the French agricultural sector.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- This report is unsatisfactory in several respects.First, it strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission as well as the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and application of national emission reduction programs.In addition, this text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States.Furthermore, I do not wish to support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, because such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector (compared to livestock).I voted strongly AGAINST this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor as it is an important step to address the high health risks and environmental impacts generated by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths each year, and its economic cost to health is estimated at between 300 and 900 billion euros per year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution considered detrimental to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. For this reason, action must be taken to address hazardous pollutants that span all sectors. The main objective of the Socialists is to urgently tackle premature deaths as a result of toxic air pollution, which amounts to more than 400 000 in the Union, which is why we consider it necessary to raise the overall level of ambition of the directive, such as the amendment NOx ceilings and binding targets for 2025 to ensure linear emission reductions.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report, as the final result of the negotiations in the trilogues has lowered the demands of Parliament's initial position, making it easier for Member States to maintain the current situation.This directive has turned out to be a missed opportunity to force States to take immediate measures to improve air quality in their territory, especially in large cities.We are facing a critical situation, where thousands of deaths are taking place due to the poor quality of the air we breathe in the main urban areas of the Union, however, despite a good starting position of the European Parliament, in the negotiations withthe Council and the Commission have reduced the mandatory nature of the measures, leaving aside the real emergency that we must face.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This text recalls the effects of poor quality air.An early death, sick leave or high healthcare costs are just some of their examples.Thus, this text establishes the new national emission limits for the most significant types of air pollutants.In this way, it modifies the commitment of emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds and ammonia, with fine particles with a diameter of not less than 2.5 microns and with methane emissions.It also establishes new norms on public participation in the preparation of plans related to the environment.I vote in favor of the clear benefits to human health and the environment of good air quality.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that seeks to place a limit on the overall amount of pollutants in the air and thereby improve our air quality and environment.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - This proposal for a Directive should effectively contribute to achieving the air quality objectives set out in Union legislation and mitigating the effects of climate change by improving synergies with short-lived climate pollutant emissions while improving global air quality. climate and energy policies of the Union and ensure that existing legislation does not overlap. However, the EU is still a long way from achieving its long-term goal of adhering to the recommended pollution limits according to the 2005 air quality guidelines. In 2013, the Commission published the long-awaited Clean Air Package, which sets out measures to ensure that existing targets are met. in the short term and sets new air quality targets for the period up to 2030. This report highlights the fact that better regulation and environmental protection are not mutually exclusive and that this Directive should therefore be aligned with other EU policy pillars. Better exchange of information, with particular emphasis on monitoring and reporting on national emission ceilings, is key to the long-term success of this Directive, so I supported this report,

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Over 400 000 Europeans die prematurely every year due to the bad quality of the air they breathe. This is why the European Parliament passed a new law to reduce the ceiling of dangerous pollutants allowed in EU Member States. I backed the new law because it will save lives and also public money: national governments pay between EUR 300 and EUR 900 billion every year in health-related costs.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The unsatisfactory state of the environment and the air has an impact on the quality of life, damages the natural environment and vegetation, which worsens the health of the population and at the same time increases public health expenditure.The cost of treating air pollution-related diseases in Europe is estimated at € 330-940 billion per year.Nevertheless, not all countries are meeting their emission reduction commitments.I support the new directive, which sets new national emission ceilings for the discharge of the five most common pollutants.However, sanctions also need to be reconsidered, otherwise the commitments are unenforceable.At the same time, research, science and the development of new measures that will lead to emission reductions need to be supported and funded.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing. - Atmospheric pollution is the leading health risk of environmental origin in Europe: it causes more than 430,000 premature deaths in Europe per year, including more than 50,000 deaths in France. Faced with this observation, the European Commission presented in December 2013 its legislative package "Air quality". The main objective of this legislative project is to respond to health risks and the effects of atmospheric pollution on the environment. Despite the good intentions of this report on the emissions of certain pollutants, this text is disappointing in several respects: on the one hand, it lacks ambition on the tolerated emission thresholds of pollutants. On the other hand, the overseas territories are excluded from the scope of the legislative project on which the report we are voting on today relates. This differentiated treatment between mainland France and overseas territories cannot be tolerated; all citizens, domiens or Europeans, should be able to benefit from equal protection of air quality. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and the amendment of Directive 2003/35 / EC, for the reasons set out in detail in my speech to the Plenary Session of the European Parliamentin Strasbourg on 23 November 2016, as well as because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.The objective of this report is to amend Directive 2001/81 / EC setting national ceilings for certain air pollutants.It aims to increase the limits imposed on Member States, and to make all reduction commitments binding by 2025. We cannot accept this text which considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission, as well as the prerogatives of the Commission.European Union on the Member States in the development and application of national emission reduction programs.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted positively for the report on reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. It is clear that air quality needs support and requires of immediate action because, just like the report points out, air is ‘a significant trans-boundary human health and environmental issue that profoundly affects all EU citizens.’ Air pollution has increased to worrying levels for the health and we can no longer let this keep on taking place. It is important to acknowledge the existing air-related health issues by introducing new legislation and policy that can lead to potential change even when the situation is challenging.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- This report concerns the emission of certain atmospheric pollutants, with a view to reducing and improving air quality conditions.Initially, the measures proposed by the European Parliament and the Commission were much stronger.However, such measures suffered several limitations and cuts during negotiations with the Council, supported by several EU countries.Based on a recent WHO report, air pollution is the greatest environmental hazard to health, with an estimated three million air pollution-related deaths per year.This report, among other weaknesses, does not include some air pollutants whose emissions seriously threaten the environment and health.I voted against.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- A Europe-wide strategy to improve air quality is desirable and I agree.It should be noted, however, that the Commission's proposal is less far-reaching than that of the committee.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.The Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council aims to set new national emission ceilings for the most important types of atmospheric pollutants.The purpose of the amendments is to reduce the potential threat to human health, the environment and the climate.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - In December 2013, the European Commission adopted a set of proposals to improve air quality in Europe, called the “air quality package”. The proposal presented to us revises this directive to put in place controls on the different types of air pollution in each Member State. Its goal is to halve, by 2030, the number of premature deaths - estimated at 400,000 per year in the EU - caused by air pollution. However, during negotiations with the Council, key elements of the proposal were deleted. Thus, methane and mercury are no longer affected by the emission limits. Member States will be allowed to average their emissions over three years for a "dry summer" or "cold winter". Finally, the binding intermediate targets (2015) proposed by Parliament have been deleted. In short, the proposal is emptied of its substance. Well done the lobbies! You deserve your pay. I vote against this text which ignores the objectives of public health.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The purpose of this text is to make it consistent with the international commitments of the European Union (Gothenburg Protocol, 1999).This revision aims to set targets for 2020 and 2030, in particular for the reduction of emissions of the main polluting gases: sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds and ammonia.This report is not, in my opinion, satisfactory because it considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission as well as the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and application of national emission reduction programs..Furthermore, we cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector.I therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Policy-making based on hard data should be the cornerstone of EU legislation.Laws should be based on sound and comprehensive impact assessments, which explain why the legislation addresses the fundamental questions about whether a proposal is necessary and proportionate and assesses what is the best action at EU level.In the case of air quality, the answer is clear: this is a significant cross-border issue in terms of human health and the environment, which deeply affects all EU citizens and requires immediate action.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because air pollution has detrimental effects on our health and hazardous emissions should be minimised wherever possible.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - Despite progress made in recent years in the fight against air pollution, air quality in Europe is still a cause for concern. Moreover, despite a number of good measures, road traffic, industry, electricity production, household emissions and the combustion of fossil fuels continue to cause significant damage to the environment and the health of citizens. According to the latest report by the European Environment Agency, particulate matter was responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths in the European Union in 2013. Nitric oxide caused a further 70,000 additional deaths. Because air pollution also leads to additional health care expenditure and poorer harvests for agriculture, the annual cost of this is estimated at at least € 330 billion. That is why I fully support the European Parliament's decision to significantly tighten standards by 2030 and introduce stricter and binding national emission ceilings for sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, particulate matter, volatile organic components and ammonia. The introduction of stricter emissions standards represents an important step forward that can save many lives and significantly improve the quality of life of people in cities and densely populated areas.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Efforts to reduce air emissions are an integral part of the European Union's environmental policy, in which the Union not only fulfills its international obligations but also seeks to maintain its position as a world leader in this field. The current report reflects the initiative of the Commission and the Council to revise legislation to combat air emissions at national level. Hazardous substances that Member States must unconditionally limit to the lowest possible level are, in particular, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds other than methane and ammonia, solid particles with a diameter of at least 2.5 micrometres and methane emissions. The elimination of these pollutants in the air is important in the context of meeting the 2030 targets. For this reason, all Member States are committed to lowering their national ceilings and regularly reviewing their targets (every two years). I believe that all Member States and sectors must contribute to the common goals, including coastal countries, air transport and shipping. The report has my support.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between €300 billion and 900 billion every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed and this report is an important step to address those issues.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Ranked as a top health hazard in Europe, air pollution is the cause of premature death of hundreds of thousands Europeans. A rational solution is to transform primarily our urban systems by adopting for example low-carbon mobility and energy efficiency strategies, hence applying stricter binding targets for EU Member States to reduce their atmospheric pollutants would be a driver for a sustainable and greener adjustment. I voted in favour of the report on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants because ambitious targets for the period after 2020 are essential in order to save lives. The industry should seize this opportunity to become fully compliant with EU legislation and, in the long run, this is consistent with cost-efficient results.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Commission has proposed to the Parliament and the Council the adoption of a Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC.In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety proposes that Parliament adopt the Commission proposal at first reading with 118 amendments.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The report consists of a series of amendments by the ENVI committee concerning the reduction of national emissions within the meaning of Directive 2001/81 / EC setting national ceilings for certain air pollutants. This review aims to set targets for 2020 and 2030 for reducing emissions of the main polluting gases. We are not satisfied with this report in many respects. It considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and implementation of national emission reduction programs. In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States. In particular, we cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector. Unfavorable vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the development and application of national emission reduction programs.In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States.Thus, the inclusion of methane in the scope of the Directive cannot be supported, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector.I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300bn to 900bn every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed. This deal will cut the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensuring, for the first time, that all polluting sectors, including agriculture, take responsibility for what they emit. The Member States now need to act to fully implement the directive and furthermore step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text relating to the emission of pollutants into the atmosphere.This was a first reading agreement to revise the directive which sets national emission ceilings for five polluting substances.The question that will arise will be the transposition of this text because France has unfortunately specialized in the "over-transposition" of European texts, which penalizes our farmers and for all producers.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.“An adult inhales tens of thousands of gallons of air a day, yet we tend to forget how important air quality is.Pollutants released into the air cause smog and acid rain, have a detrimental effect on the environment, and contribute to the development of various diseases.Clearly, joint EU action on air quality is the right solution.I am particularly pleased that the report covers the areas that have the greatest impact on air quality, such as the car industry or agriculture.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting this report on emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted against this report because I believe that the emission reduction values in this directive should have been realistic and feasible in order to have a safe objective, namely to reduce the negative consequences of air pollution on human health.Therefore, I do not believe that the efforts required of the Member States should dramatically affect their economic development.In the case of Romania, the emission reduction targets were disproportionate in relation to the GDP of our country, with the investment capacity and the stage of technological development and I consider this unprofessional and incorrect.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the EP-Council agreement at second reading, which sets stricter national ceilings for emissions of air pollutants such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds (thinners, solvents, cleaners), ammonia and fine particulate matter.The resulting agreement in the form of a European average of 50% national emission ceilings is a compromise between the EP's original stricter position, which proposed national ceilings at a European average of 52%, and the more lenient position of Member States in the Council, which proposed 48%.The approved directive will contribute to the improvement of air quality in the EU and in the Czech Republic its effects will be positively felt especially by the inhabitants of border regions who are exposed to pollution from some neighboring countries.Air pollution knows no borders, which is why air quality needs to be addressed in Europe.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out in favor of this report too, because I believe that a Europe-wide strategy to improve air quality is urgently needed.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- This directive aims to introduce new measures and regulations to limit air pollution in Europe, which is responsible for nearly 40,000 deaths each year.I voted against this text because of the lack of clear and coherent provisions such as the ceiling values for methane and mercury emissions, the absence of binding intermediate targets for 2025 or the absence of commitments aimed atreduce premature mortality from air pollution by 2030.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Given the extreme impact of air pollution on human health, it is necessary to address the reduction of air pollution.The EU is still a long way from the targets set so far, so further action is needed to reach them.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I support the report.Only through joint efforts can we effectively reduce air pollution and its negative effects on public health and the environment.It is therefore necessary to coordinate action to reduce emissions and air quality, as well as to protect against climate change and biodiversity.It should be noted that emission reduction commitments should take into account the impact of emissions in the Member States, not only at national level but also across borders.However, stricter emission reduction commitments should not lead to disproportionate costs for industry.Member States must be given some flexibility.In addition, maintaining the competitiveness of the European economy and protecting the interests of SMEs are essential for the transition to a low-carbon economy.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report which provides for the reduction of national emission limits for basic pollutants by 2030, including NOx nitrogen oxide, particulate matter and sulfur dioxide. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400,000 premature deaths each year and the financial cost to health is estimated at between € 300-900 billion each year. About 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution that are considered harmful to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. The new agreement to reduce permitted national limits will reduce the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensure, for the first time, that all polluting sectors including agriculture, will take responsibility for what they emit. Member States must now act to fully implement the directive and, in addition, put into practice their ambition to combat air pollution.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this trilogue agreement which makes it possible to set national ceilings for five pollutants responsible for serious diseases, respiratory disorders and cancer.Air pollution is in fact the number one health risk of environmental origin in Europe.Air pollution continues to cause more than 430,000 premature deaths in Europe per year, including more than 50,000 deaths in France.It was therefore imperative that we react to the health risks and the environmental effects of air pollution.With this directive, we are fully responding to it!

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposal because I believe it is important to commit ourselves, nationally, to a further reduction of air pollution emissions from 2020 to 2030. Furthermore, with this directive the objective is to improve, on the one hand, human health and,on the other hand, also to protect the environment.These national programs aimed at controlling air pollution would be applicable from the agricultural sector to the industrial sector, so anyone could benefit from them.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The programs required by the directive must take into account the cost-effectiveness of emission reduction measures, prioritize specific policy measures aimed at reducing the health risks of vulnerable groups of people, quantify additional reductions in emissions to meet the World Health Organization targets by 2030, support the shift of investment towards clean and efficient technologies and sustainable production through fiscal stimulus. The Commission will assess, by 2025 at the latest, progress in reducing atmospheric pollutants according to the World Health Organization's air purity scale. The Directive contributes to the Union's long-term goal of achieving air quality levels that do not lead to significant negative effects on human health and the environment, achieving the Union's biodiversity and ecosystem objectives by reducing the level and deposition of certain air pollutants, the impact of climate change by reducing emissions of short-term climate pollutants and improving synergies with the Union's climate and energy policies. I therefore supported the amendments adopted by the European Parliament on 28 October 2015 on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC after reconsideration in the parent Committee on Environment, Public Health and Safety food.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- I am not satisfied with this report in many respects.It considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and the prerogatives of the European Union over Member States in the design and implementation of national emission reduction programs.In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States.The inclusion of methane in the framework of the directive is likely to pose serious problems for the already very fragile agricultural sector.In these circumstances, I vote against this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The European Union has made significant progress in the last 20 years in the field of anthropogenic air emissions and air quality thanks to ambitious policies. However, risks to the environment and human health remain. This Directive is an important step in the fight against air pollution. The Directive should contribute to achieving the air quality objectives set out in Union legislation and mitigating the effects of climate change by improving global air quality by reducing emissions of short-lived climate pollutants and improving synergies with Union climate and energy policies. Poor air quality causes over 400,000 cases of premature death annually and its economic costs are estimated at 300-900 billion euros each year. This agreement aims to halve the number of premature deaths by 2030. 90% of Europeans live in cities and are exposed to levels of air pollution that are harmful to human health. Many vulnerable socio-economic groups are particularly exposed. Measures to combat hazardous pollutants are urgently needed in all sectors. EU governments must take action and ensure that sectors of the economy, including agriculture, act responsibly when it comes to substances that release into the atmosphere. I call on the Member States to act as soon as possible and fully implement the Directive and to take further steps in our joint fight against air pollution.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - In 2013, the European Commission adopted the "Air quality package" of proposals to improve air quality in Europe. The main part of the package is a proposal to revise the National Emission Limits Directive (NEC). The current European Commission considered withdrawing the proposal in 2014, but due to strong resistance from the European Parliament and several NGOs, the proposal was maintained. The revised NEC Directive provides for controls on different types of pollutants in Member States. Its aim will be to halve the number of premature deaths - estimated at 400 000 per year in the EU - caused by air pollution by 2030. This revision proposal sets out new national emission reduction commitments, applicable from 2020 and 2030 , for sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and ammonia (NH3), and for fine particles (PM2.5) and methane (CH4) as well. As a result of the vote in the Environment Committee, among other things, mercury (Hg) was added to the pollutant list, average targets for 2025 were added to legislation, methane targets were postponed until 2030 (to give the agricultural sector time adaptation) and the European Commission's proposal for flexibility has been deleted.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- The revision of the Directive, which sets limits on annual emissions of toxic air pollutants, aims in particular to ensure further reductions in these emissions and thus to prevent health risks associated with air quality.The report was the subject of very long and complex Council negotiations, especially due to pressure from countries such as the United Kingdom, France, Italy and Poland.Attitudes within parliamentary factions have also undergone many changes.I am glad that, in the end, our rapporteur, Julia Girling, has managed to find support across the spectrum, with the exception of the Greens, for whom, of course, this report is not ambitious enough.I, too, would like to be able to agree on higher goals, but I think that the compromise reached is the maximum possible in the given situation, and I believe that it will also be acceptable to the Council.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- Evidence-based policy making must be the cornerstone of EU legislation.In the case of air quality, this is an extremely important issue for both human health and the environment, which affects all citizens of the Union and requires immediate action at the supranational level.Air pollution, neglected for years by politics, is now among the priorities.It is essential that the Commission plays a supervisory and political impetus role in this respect.I believe it is of primary importance to ensure an adequate level of air quality as a public good.To this end, I believe it is necessary to find innovative ways to finance emission reductions.I believe that this directive is going in the right direction and that is why I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- The proposal to revise the National Emission Ceilings Directive (NECD) is part of the Commission's Clean Air Package and replaces the current rules set out in Directive 2001/81 / EC for sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), non-methane organic compounds (NMVOC)and ammonia (NH3), which are in force until 2020. The new directive was to set new emission reduction levels from 2020 to 2030 for these substances, as well as for dust (PM2.5) and methane (CH4).In view of the cost of reducing sulfur dioxide and ammonia emissions, which may have negative consequences for the agricultural and energy sectors, I voted against the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- Every year in Europe, 400,000 premature deaths are linked to air pollution.It is becoming urgent to act to significantly improve air quality by drastically limiting the emissions of certain air pollutants that come directly from industrial activities, means of transport or the heating systems that we use.I voted in favor of this report which plans to limit, by 2030, emissions of nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, ammonia, fine particles and non-methane volatile organic compounds through theestablishment of national programs.However, it was important for the protection of our farmers, and in particular our breeders, to exclude methane from the scope of this text.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The present proposal on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants is part of the Clean Air for Europe Program, announced by the Commission on 18 December 2013. After years of political neglect, air pollution has appeared on the international agenda as a major public health problem. There is no doubt that poor air quality contributes to premature death, illness-induced absenteeism, loss of productivity, loss of crop yields and damage to buildings. Significant health costs are another consequence of poor air quality, and in Europe, total external costs to society related to health and caused by air pollution are estimated at between 330 and 940 billion euros per year . The Commission proposal repeals and replaces the existing directive on national emission limit values ​​for certain air pollutants, establishing new emission limit values ​​for sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds for 2020 and 2030. Since, on the one hand, these values ​​reflect the limits that have been agreed at international level under the Gothenburg Protocol, and since, on the other hand, only compliance by these limits, on the part of Member States, will enable compliance of its emission reduction targets, I voted in favor.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up.- I voted against the report on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants because I considered, together with other Romanian MEPs, that the European Union's ambitions and objectives for reducing the effects of pollution at European level must take into account GDP, capacitymedium and long-term investment, technological and economic development of member countries.Regarding the effect of imposing this proposal in Romania, we considered it imperative that the percentage reduction of pollutant emissions, established by this proposal, be realistic and relevant and not negatively affect the economic and industrial process in Romania.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP abstained on the legislative report on Emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants. We in UKIP firmly believe in the importance of improving air quality. Air pollution does not only have a negative effect on human beings, it also causes harm to plants and animals. This said, UKIP is firmly against the creation of further EU legislation. In this particular case, we are concerned of the considerable increase of administrative burden for industry and governments. Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level. We are also concerned at the possibility of fines being levied against the UK by the EU.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - Poor atmospheric quality is responsible for around 400 thousand deaths annually. To this is added the enormous financial effort in medical care. The revision of the Directive establishing national emission limit values ​​for certain air pollutants (carbon dioxide, sulfur, oxides of nitrogen, etc.) was voted. It is a more ambitious proposal. Different limits are defined for each Member State and for each pollutant. The proposal is the result of a difficult negotiation with the Council. There were several controversial issues between the groups, mainly those related to the inclusion of methane and the requirement for less ambitious targets for ammonia. It was agreed to support the full inclusion of ammonia and to exempt emissions of enteric methane produced by ruminant cattle. The S & amp; D wanted more ambitious goals, but we support the agreement as it is the best that can be achieved without risking the Directive's indefinite retention in the Council.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Poor air quality is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths / year and its economic cost to health is estimated between 300 and 900 billion euros per year. Many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected and around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution considered detrimental to human health. Within the Commission's Air Quality Package (12/18/2013), a proposal is included to amend Directive 2001/81 / EC on national emission ceilings (NEC / TNE Directive) that replaces the current annual limitation regime for certain atmospheric pollutants. The goal is to reduce emissions in order to address the health risks and environmental effects they pose. The proposal sets limits for each State to five toxic pollutants: sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), fine particles (PM 2.5), non-methane volatile organic compounds (MMVOC) and ammonia (NH3). Although I would have liked a more ambitious agreement, in view of the Council's opposition, I voted in favor of the agreement reached in order to implement the important steps it contains in the face of the high risks to health and the environmental impacts generated by pollution. atmospheric.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- In 2015, I had already voted in favor of the European Parliament's position on this directive aimed at reducing atmospheric pollution and therefore improving air quality in the European Union by 2030. The text ofThe compromise negotiated between Parliament and Council is not perfect.It is in any case less ambitious than the initial position of the European Parliament.But despite this revised ambition, I have chosen to support this revision because I am convinced that it will allow significant advances in public health by considerably reducing the number of premature deaths linked toair pollution in the European Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- The draft resolution under discussion covers a very important area of the environment.The document itself is well drafted, with the exception of a few amendments drafted by colleagues on the right, which propose a freer regulatory regime for pollutants.I am glad that they were rejected and we received a good resolution.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - This report deals with the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants, amending Directive 2003/35 / EC. I recall that air pollution is responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths per year across the European Union. With the approval of this report, Parliament approved new national emission reduction targets, setting national emission limit values ​​for certain air pollutants, such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and fine particles. New targets for reducing air pollution impacts on health by about 50% by 2030 are also contemplated, stipulating different limits for each Member State and for each pollutant. As I consider these amendments in this proposal for a directive to be generally positive, as they contribute to improving air quality and combating environmental and public health problems, I voted in favor.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I supported this report, which fixes new national ceilings for certain pollutants and will allow ambitious control of the level of air pollution in the European Union. Indeed, we must provide solutions to the serious phenomenon of air pollution which causes more than 400,000 premature deaths each year in the European Union, including more than 48,000 in France!
