By voting on this report, we are pursuing the objective of improving air quality, and the European Union is fully committed to protecting European citizens against air pollution. This text sets realistic national emission ceilings for five polluting substances, notably asking for the exclusion of methane from the scope of the directive. Thus, Europe has set itself the ambitious goal of reducing the impact of air pollution on health by almost 50% by 2030, while not creating additional complications for farmers.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I am voting against the report because, although the European Parliament and the Commission had proposed much stronger measures, these measures have not been successful during the negotiations with the Council. Weaknesses of the agreement reached: - The Council managed to eliminate methane and mercury from the final agreement. - Flexibility for Member States. The Council has succeeded in forcing Parliament to accept several of the Directive's so-called 'flexibilities', which makes the limits much more difficult to enforce. - There are no binding intermediate targets for 2025. Parliament called for binding intermediate targets for all pollutants except methane, but in the end accepted the Council's position that these targets were only indicative. - The reduction of premature mortality in 2030. The original text amended by the European Parliament contained a legally binding commitment to reduce premature mortality in 2030 caused by air pollution by 52% compared to 2005. The proposal is finally accepted of the Board of 49.6%. While the agreed text seeks to further improve air quality conditions, the text was significantly watered down by the Council during the negotiations.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution in support of better air quality and improved public health. Air pollution leads to chronic, debilitating and fatal diseases which are, in many cases, avoidable. Complying with the new limits may be challenging, but there are a number of flexibilities in the directive which will help, including the non-binding nature of interim targets. Such big changes, bringing with them significant improvements to public health, cannot happen immediately. But setting ambitious targets for the long term health of people and society is critical. Preventing disease is not only the best option for the individual – it also delivers the biggest savings to society in the long run through lower health and social costs.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on national emissions of certain air pollutants because it specifies emission limits which have clear benefits for health and the environment.The report states that the new emission cap from the member states will run until at least 2020 and creates new emission reduction methods.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report, as the final result of the negotiations in the trilogues has reduced the demands of Parliament's initial position, making it easier for Member States to maintain the current situation.This directive has turned out to be a missed opportunity to force States to take immediate measures to improve air quality in their territory, especially in large cities.We are facing a critical situation, where thousands of deaths are taking place due to the poor quality of the air we breathe in the main urban areas of the Union, however, despite a good starting position of the European Parliament, in the negotiations withthe Council and the Commission have reduced the mandatory nature of the measures, leaving aside the real emergency that we must face.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- Every year, air pollution causes over 400,000 premature deaths in the European Union, constituting the main environmental risk factor for human health.Pollution attributable, for example, to transport, heating, industry and agriculture also implies high external costs due to lost working days, health costs, loss of crop yield and damage to buildings, for a total that varies from 330 to 940 billion euros per year.I therefore voted in favor of the proposal to update the directive setting national emission limits for atmospheric pollutants, hoping that the new legislation will help reduce premature deaths and improve air quality.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as I do not wish for the EU to get involved in emissions.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - The European Union attaches great importance to the issue of environmental protection and combating the effects of climate change. These actions, however, must take into account many factors and long-term effects on various sectors of the economy, of which agriculture has a special position. It is worth remembering that agriculture and forestry are the only sectors of the economy that, although they are significant emitters of greenhouse gases, are also sectors that at the same time counteract global warming by absorbing and binding significant amounts of carbon dioxide in soil and plants. In addition, agriculture and forestry are key to Europe's food security and the supply of raw materials to many industries. Due to this specific nature, the environmental functions performed by agriculture, and the already introduced restrictions, it would be problematic for the sector to include methane emission obligations in the Directive on national emission ceilings. It is therefore good that methane has been excluded in this report. The EU Member States are very diverse in terms of the structure of agricultural production, the size of farms or forms of production, therefore the modernization of this sector in terms of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and environmental impact should be carried out in a flexible way not to cause economic stagnation, but economic development in towards innovative and sustainable solutions. In any case, there is a need to ensure synergies between agricultural and energy policy and the environment.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of a first reading agreement on the revised National Emissions Ceiling Directive (NECD). This directive is an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300 billion and EUR 900 billion every year. This deal will cut the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensuring, for the first time, that all polluting sectors, including agriculture, take responsibility for what they emit. The Member States now need to act to fully implement the directive and furthermore step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - Air pollution is a problem at the local, pan-European and global level because air pollutants released in one country easily reach other countries, causing or contributing to poor air quality. Therefore, stronger efforts to address this problem are very much needed. The European Union works at a number of levels to reduce exposure to this problem: through legislation, cooperation with the sectors responsible for pollution, national and regional authorities, non-governmental organizations and research. The revised Thematic Strategy on Air Pollution sets new strategic targets for the period up to 2030 in order to achieve the Union's targets, and includes measures to reduce emissions of nitrogen dioxide, nitrous oxide, ammonia, particulate matter and the number of cases and deaths due to pollution. ray. However, aviation emissions during take-off and landing, as well as emissions from maritime transport, are still not taken into account. Directive 2003/35 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council needs to be amended to ensure the consistency of this Directive with the Aarhus Convention of 1998 on access to information, public participation in decision-making and access to justice in environmental matters. Increased efforts by all member states are a key factor in this process in reducing climate pollutant emissions and improving air quality worldwide.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - Although the EU and its Member States have made some progress in reducing air pollution, I must also say that many Member States are not complying with all the agreed standards. I therefore voted in favor of the draft legislative resolution because I think that if we want to meet the long-term air quality objectives, we must take measures to ensure that pollution from medium-sized combustion plants, such as large-scale power plants and small industrial plants, is reduced. Like the rapporteur, I support the Commission's new commitment to smarter and more effective regulation and to reduce the administrative burden on businesses and Member States. I believe that the ceilings for the target dates set out in the report will not only be sufficient to stimulate emission reductions, but will also be set at a level that is realistic, proportionate, feasible and will not have a disproportionate impact on any sector. I also consider it important for the Commission to play a comprehensive oversight and warning role in meeting its emission reduction commitments, thus helping the Member States to achieve the targets set.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC at third reading. The Directive sets targets for reducing emissions of the most serious air pollutants (sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds or ammonia) by setting reduction targets by 2030 for individual Member States and the EU as a whole compared to the 2005 benchmarks. total emissions by 49.6%. Although the European Parliament has gone even further in setting emission reduction targets than the Commission's proposal, these are achievable targets for the Czech Republic, which will not impose an unsolvable economic burden. In addition, it is important for our country that this will reduce cross-border pollution coming mainly from Poland. I am convinced that the targets for reducing emissions of the most serious pollutants that we have voted on today will help to reduce the negative impact of these emissions on the environment and the health of the population in the long term.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The proposal for a directive addressed in this report ensures that the existing emission ceilings for air pollutants set out in Directive 2001/81 / EC will apply until 2020, while setting new national emission reduction commitments by 2030. National emission ceilings are aimed at reducing air pollution and its adverse effects on public health and the environment throughout the European Union. As air pollution is transboundary in nature, this issue requires a multi-level approach, with some responsibility to be assumed at European, national, regional and local levels. Pollution reduction will only be possible with an integrated approach that takes into account the responsibility of polluters, legal competences and a fair distribution of costs. Unfortunately, the Commission's proposal is unfortunately not ambitious in several respects, as it does not impose binding intermediate targets (2025) on Member States, which would encourage them to reduce emissions steadily and steadily and meet the 2030 targets. does not take into account Parliament's requests to amend legislation to take greater account of the importance of clean air and other environmental objectives. Parliament's report also does not address these shortcomings, nor does it propose appropriate changes to the Commission's proposal, so I did not support it in the vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The fight against air pollution must take place at European Union level.However, it is also necessary to take into account the specifics of individual states and assess the structure of their economy.Emission ceilings for individual pollutants must be set so as not to impair the development of industrial production.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This directive is an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300billion and EUR 900 billion every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed. This deal will cut the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensuring, for the first time, that all polluting sectors, including agriculture, take responsibility for what they emit. The Member States now need to act to fully implement the directive and furthermore step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I abstained from the resolution of the EU Parliament on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and on the amendment to Directive 2003/35 / EC.This directive concerns pollutants and emissions.I think it would be better if pollutants were regulated by national democratic decisions.I reject the regulation of so-called greenhouse gases.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- I support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC because it correctly identifies shortcomings in existing regulations, especially as regards the cost-effectiveness of emission reduction measures.reducing the health risks of vulnerable groups.There is a need to move towards the use and design of new technologies that are clean and efficient.To this end, it is necessary to commit additional budgetary resources in order to achieve a satisfactory level of air quality and to avoid a negative impact on human health.Atmospheric pollutants affect not only humans, but also the environment and wildlife - action is needed to reverse the possible consequences for the ecosystem as a whole.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC.Air pollution, which in figures amounts to € 330-940 billion per year, which is the total cost of society due to air pollution, must remain an important issue that we need to address at European Union level.I support the Commission's proposal to set new emission ceilings for certain chemical compounds in the new directive.We are facing the problem that many Member States still do not meet the agreed standards.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. The case of ambient air quality is a cross-border issue of health and the environment. This report addresses the Commission proposal to revise the existing EAEC Directive by setting new ceilings for emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and volatile organic compounds other than methane for 2020 and 2030. Many, however, are the weak points of the report. The text is not ambitious with regard to the emission limits, and there is flexibility in the implementation of the Directive by the Member States, which makes the application of the limits very difficult. In addition, there are no binding intermediate targets for 2025. Taking into account the above weaknesses, we proceeded to vote against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.Atmospheric air quality is an important cross-border issue of health and the environment, which has a huge impact on all citizens of the European Union and requires immediate action.All Member States must fulfill their obligations and provide for measures to identify the problem in a timely manner, so that remedial action can be taken.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new regulation requires Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the extent of the commitment to reduce ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) emissions related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and it would therefore be more appropriate to continue to address it in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch Presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because I believe that it makes proposals that are as ambitious as possible for the European Commission's proposal. Important compromises have been reached in the EP's legislative process, and I trust that the Member States will also actively support it. Moreover, I believe that faster and more decisive action to reduce pollution would be possible, and the 2030 target date could be reached even sooner. As the report states, air pollution leads to the premature death of 400 000 Europeans a year, but that does not stop there: the whole ecosystem is threatened by anthropogenic emissions. All of this has serious costs, so the sooner we liquidate it, the sooner we can spend this huge amount on someone else, such as a regular health care system or real knowledge education. I believe that a complex action covering all sectors is needed.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - Given that, at the end of 2016, it cannot be said that we have clean air, the proposal for a directive on reducing national emissions of certain air pollutants is auspicious. It is clear that not only new Member States' commitments to reduce emissions at national level in the perspective of 2020, 2025 and 2030 for the six major air pollutants are needed, but also for the adoption, implementation and updating of national air pollution control programs. includes cost-effective measures specific to each polluting sector), conducting national emissions inventories and disseminating this information, streamlining controls, etc. Of course, the achievement of national emission limits by each Member State requires European financial support for each polluting sector, depending on the degree and intensity of the negative impact of those pollutants on human health and the environment, so that the desired is also achievable: the economy European green.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Air pollution has reached alarming levels in the Member States of the European Union. Every year, there are no less than 400,000 premature deaths caused by pollution, and the economic costs are estimated at around € 300 billion. It is also estimated that almost 90% of Europeans living in the city are exposed to this type of pollution that is harmful to human health. For these reasons, the European Union has decided to adopt regulations that significantly limit this negative phenomenon and limit the number of premature deaths by half by 2030. Toxic emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, suspended particles are targeted, non-methane volatile organic compounds and ammonia. Ceilings imposed at national level are insufficient to manage the situation and therefore regulation at European level is required. Following difficult negotiations, the Commission proposal was accepted, with a number of amendments by the Council in July this year. Although the resulting document could have been more ambitious in terms of targets to be achieved, it is a decisive step in the fight against pollution and must be adopted as soon as possible in order to generate concrete positive effects. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- 500,000 Europeans die prematurely each year from diseases linked to air pollution.We voted to challenge national ceilings that we considered too low for the biggest air pollutants.Even if it is not totally a breath of fresh air, we can still rejoice in this breath in the right direction.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Air pollution is a major health risk in the EU that causes more than 400 000 premature deaths each year. It is a cross-border threat that must be tackled at the European level. This directive will save lives: it will avoid tens of thousands of premature deaths annually and improve the quality of the environment. Meeting the new targets will cut the negative health effects of pollution by half by 2030. Tackling air pollution also brings economic benefits to society, since the economic cost of the health impacts of air pollution is estimated at 3-9% of GDP.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - Atmospheric pollution constitutes the first health risk of environmental origin in Europe. It shortens life expectancy and is the cause of serious illnesses, such as heart disease, breathing problems and cancer. According to the latest report by the European Environment Agency (EEA) published in 2015, air pollution continues to cause over 430,000 premature deaths in Europe per year. Thus, in December 2013, the European Commission presented a legislative package "Air quality", which revised the NEC / PEN directive, aligning itself with the commitments made at the international level following the revision of the protocol. Gothenburg in 2012. During the first reading in the European Parliament, in October 2015, my colleague Éric Andrieu suggested excluding enteric methane from the limitation of methane emissions. Unfortunately, following the trilogue discussions, the Council called for the exclusion of methane emissions from the directive, to meet the expectations of the European agricultural sector. However, I welcome the adoption of this report, which sets national limits for emissions of five polluting gases, including fine particles, responsible for thousands of deaths per year.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- The level of atmospheric pollutants in the air has not yet fallen below the levels necessary for the protection of human health and the environment.I believe that further efforts are needed to reduce the more than 460,000 premature deaths from fine dust each year, as well as the 80,000 from nitrogen dioxide emissions.I believe that the reduction of pollutants emitted every year, while recognizing the possible negative economic effects that would be recorded for some sectors, is an important stimulus for research in green technologies.The creation of countless jobs in the sector would send a positive signal from Brussels, concretely demonstrating the commitment that the European Union has made to protect its citizens, even in the face of new challenges in terms of economic growth.The costs of public health will also be significantly reduced, now substantial due to cardiovascular and respiratory diseases.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - Poor air quality is the leading environmental death in the European Union, leading to the premature death of 400,000 people a year. The Directive on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants aims to reduce air pollution and its adverse effects on human health and the environment throughout the Union. The new regulation requires Member States to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile (non-methane) organic compounds (NMVOCs), ammonia (NH3) and fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometres. dust). From the outset, the biggest problem for Hungary has been the extent of the commitment to reduce ammonia and small particulate matter (PM2.5) emissions related to residential heating by 2030. It was also debated whether there was a place in the proposal to regulate methane emissions, given that methane is not an air pollutant but a greenhouse gas and should therefore continue to be addressed in the field of climate protection. As a result of our position during the lengthy negotiations, the targets in the adopted version can be met from a professional point of view, and, under pressure from the Member States, methane has finally been removed from the scope of the regulation. Although the Dutch Presidency pursued the negotiations in a rather forced process and forced the final decision with an unusual procedural solution, in view of the above, I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I expressed my support for the "Motion for a European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC". The report offers a better solution for the use of modern technologies that will raise the efficiency of combating emissions of atmospheric pollutants. The report defined on the merits the shortcomings of the existing regulations, with an emphasis on the cost-effectiveness of measures to reduce pollutant emissions and on the establishment of adequate policy measures that will reduce health risks. Taking into account that pollutants affect the entire ecosystem, it is necessary to commit additional funding from the European Union budget in order to establish adequate air quality. The report insists that the regulation of the European Union's environmental policy be fully compliant with positive legal solutions. Also, I especially emphasize the legislative intention which takes into account the principle of proportionality and in the regulation of this matter takes into account the economically rational moves and more cost-effective measures.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of Mr Girling's report for a number of important reasons.Good air quality is very important to EU citizens, not only for health reasons, but also for a myriad of other reasons.I therefore believe that this issue must be addressed by the responsible authorities.Financial support for EU countries is essential to combat environmental and air pollution effectively.As the solution to this problem is relevant to all countries, the European Union has a great responsibility to put in place the right rules and restrictions.It is important to mention that compliance with the rules and restrictions imposed should be flexible and enforceable by all EU members.It is precisely these problems that Mr Girling summarized in his report.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- Although EU policies are largely focused on preserving and protecting the environment, it can be noted that most of the focus is on tackling climate change, while far less attention is paid to air quality.Given that poor air quality contributes to premature mortality, disease, loss of productivity, loss of crop yields and damage to buildings, it is clear that emissions of atmospheric pollutants are a health and environmental problem.I support the report's recognition of the need to reduce the negative impacts and risks that polluted air has on the environment and human health, but I believe that the establishment of new, increased restrictions will not achieve much as some Member States cannot achieve their targets.I believe that it is first and foremost necessary for each Member State to set targets that it will actually be able to meet, and I have voted accordingly.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for an EU directive of the Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC. EU legislation must be based on evidence-based policy-making. It is clear about air quality, as it is an important cross-border issue and concerns human health and the environment. Low air quality contributes to premature mortality, absenteeism due to illness, high health care costs, lower productivity, crop loss and damage to buildings. In Europe, society's total health-related external costs due to air pollution are estimated at around € 330-940 billion per year. In addition, there is growing evidence that the deposition of atmospheric nitrogen particles in the atmosphere causes changes in the natural environment, such as reduced diversity of ground vegetation, reduced plant growth, and an unbalanced nutritional status due to eutrophication and acidification. The Commission proposal repeals and replaces the current National Emission Ceilings Directive and sets new emission ceilings for sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and non-methane volatile organic compounds for the period 2020 and 2030.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - I am voting against the report because, although the European Parliament and the Commission had proposed much stronger measures, these measures have not been successful during the negotiations with the Council. Weaknesses of the agreement reached: - The Council managed to eliminate methane and mercury from the final agreement. - Flexibility for Member States. The Council has succeeded in forcing Parliament to accept several of the so-called 'flexibilities' in the Directive, which makes the limits much more difficult to enforce. - There are no binding intermediate targets for 2025. Parliament called for binding intermediate targets for all pollutants except methane, but in the end accepted the Council's position that these targets were only indicative. - The reduction of premature mortality in 2030. The original text amended by the European Parliament contained a legally binding commitment to reduce premature mortality in 2030 caused by air pollution by 52% compared to 2005. The proposal is finally accepted of the Board of 49.6%. While the agreed text seeks to further improve air quality conditions, the text was significantly watered down by the Council during the negotiations.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This report does not satisfy me, in fact, in many respects: - it considerably strengthens the regulatory power of the Commission and strengthens the prerogatives of the European Union over the Member States in the preparation and application of national programsreduction in emissions.In addition, the text removes certain facilities, hitherto granted to States;- we cannot support the inclusion of methane in the scope of the directive, as such inclusion would constitute an unacceptable constraint for the agricultural sector.I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The above report is convenient for many countries, but not for the Polish economy, which is 90% based on coal.It is carbon that causes the greatest increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.The deadlines proposed in the report do not allow the Polish economy to change its mind.I voted against the report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Evidence-based policy-making should be a cornerstone of EU legislation.Legislation should be based on detailed and comprehensive impact assessments that show why a piece of legislation addresses the central issue of the necessity and proportionality of the proposal and how it assesses whether action at EU level would be most effective.With regard to air quality, the answer is clear: this is a major cross-border problem for human health and the environment, which is having a serious impact on the lives of all EU citizens and requires immediate action.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I am voting against the report because, although the European Parliament and the Commission had proposed much stronger measures, these measures have not been successful during the negotiations with the Council. Weaknesses of the agreement reached: - The Council managed to eliminate methane and mercury from the final agreement. - Flexibility for Member States. The Council has succeeded in forcing Parliament to accept several of the Directive's so-called 'flexibilities', which makes the limits much more difficult to enforce. - There are no binding intermediate targets for 2025. Parliament called for binding intermediate targets for all pollutants except methane, but in the end accepted the Council's position that these targets were only indicative. - The reduction of premature mortality in 2030. The original text amended by the European Parliament contained a legally binding commitment to reduce premature mortality in 2030 caused by air pollution by 52% compared to 2005. The proposal is finally accepted of the Board of 49.6%. While the agreed text seeks to further improve air quality conditions, the text was significantly watered down by the Council during the negotiations.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- This Directive should contribute to the achievement of air quality objectives set out in Union legislation in a cost-effective manner, to mitigate the effects of climate change by reducing emissions of short-lived atmospheric pollutants and to improving air quality in general.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC. Close to half a million Europeans die every year from diseases linked to the millions of tons of gases and particulates human activity releases into the atmosphere. The aim of the new directive is to set tougher emission limits for key air pollutants. I voted in favour because I believe that the directive would set national targets to reduce emissions from five key air pollutants by 2030 compared to 2005.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - This proposal for a Directive to reduce emissions of air pollutants, known as National Emission Ceilings (NEC), is an essential instrument to improve air quality. In addition to establishing national ceilings for the years 2020 and 2030 (the agreement on the latter date is a novelty), it requires the Member States to draw up national air pollution control programs and the systematic monitoring of the impact of pollution. atmospheric in ecosystems. The consensual figures suppose drastic reductions in pollutant emissions, which seek to achieve a significant reduction in the impact on health measured in premature deaths caused by poor air quality (it is estimated that the 400,000 premature deaths annually in the Union). The application of this Directive will mean that all EU countries have to assume very demanding obligations, but also very necessary to alleviate a major environmental problem. Thus, and from the concern generated by the fact that the poor quality of the air that is breathed especially in cities has a serious impact on the health of citizens, I have supported this text with my vote.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted against this report, as the final result of the negotiations in the trilogues has lowered the demands of Parliament's initial position, making it easier for Member States to maintain the current situation.This directive has turned out to be a missed opportunity to force States to take immediate measures to improve air quality in their territory, especially in large cities.We are facing a critical situation, where thousands of deaths are taking place due to the poor quality of the air we breathe in the main urban areas of the Union, however, despite a good starting position of the European Parliament, in the negotiations withthe Council and the Commission have reduced the mandatory nature of the measures, leaving aside the real emergency that we must face.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, it is an important step in addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300 billion and EUR 900 billion every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor, because this directive should also contribute to reducing the health-related costs of air pollution in the Union by improving the quality of life of EU citizens and promoting the transition to a green economy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The report finds that, after years of political neglect, air pollution has appeared on the political agenda as a major public health problem. Poor air quality contributes to premature death, absenteeism due to illness, significant health costs, loss of productivity, loss of crop yields and damage to buildings. Thus, according to the report, in Europe, total external costs to society related to health and caused by air pollution are estimated between 330 and 940 billion euros per year. In addition, a growing body of evidence is available that demonstrates that atmospheric nitrogen deposition is leading to changes in the natural environment, with an impact on biodiversity. Unfortunately, and once again, the real causes that explain this inertia are not addressed, calling for greater and ever more complex and ineffective regulation. For our part, pollution and the inability to deal with this problem stem from the privatization policies of vast sectors of the economy, including transport and energy, condemning States to mere passive spectators of the progressive destruction of the planet.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written. - Measures should be taken at EU level to improve air quality. Air pollution causes external health costs (around EUR 330 to 940 billion) for society in Europe. The Commission's proposal repeals the existing directives on national emission ceilings and sets new emission ceilings for sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia and volatile organic non-methane hydrocarbons for 2020 and 2030. This proposal obliges the Member States to set up national air pollution control programs. The focus of the EU in the last ten years has been mainly on combating climate change, which has led to a neglect of the issue of air quality. This had divergent and conflicting poles. Approaches result. For example, the share of diesel vehicles that produce more nitrogen oxides and fine dust, but have 15% fewer CO2 emissions, increased. There are also major interactions between climate and air quality strategies, which is why methane should also fall within the scope of the directive. The CAP is to be included in order to achieve more environmentally friendly measures in European agriculture, in particular a reduction in ammonia and methane emissions. Since such a strategy to improve air quality is desirable, I approved the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a directive of Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants. Evidence-based policy making must be the cornerstone of EU legislation. In the case of air quality, the answer is clear: it is an important and cross-border issue for both human health and the environment that affects all citizens of the Union and requires immediate action. The Commission proposal sets new limits for emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia for 2020 and 2030: the new targets for 2030 aim at achieving 70% of the technically feasible maximum reductions in terms of health effects , as established by WHO. The Commission has set limits for individual Member States based on an assessment of the areas in which the most cost-effective measures can be implemented. The Commission text also requires Member States to adopt national air pollution control programs to be updated every two years.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This directive is an important step towards addressing the high health risks and environmental impacts posed by air pollution. Poor air quality is responsible for over 400 000 premature deaths each year and its economic cost for health is estimated at between EUR 300 billion and EUR 900 billion every year. Around 90% of Europeans living in cities are exposed to levels of air pollution deemed damaging to human health, and many vulnerable socio-demographic groups, such as the elderly, are particularly affected. Measures to address dangerous pollutants covering all sectors are urgently needed. This deal will cut the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030, forcing governments across Europe to act and ensuring, for the first time, that all polluting sectors, including agriculture, take responsibility for their emissions. Member States now need to act to fully implement the directive and furthermore step up their ambition in the fight against air pollution.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because a possibility is offered to each Member State to contribute to air quality with specific and defined measures. To protect the health of citizens and the environment, it is important to reduce emissions of mercury. I believe that in order to improve air quality, each relevant sector should be addressed such as agriculture, industry, road transport and shipping. It’s important that each Member State takes into account the impact that this kind of measures will have on small and medium enterprises. I believe that each Member State should update the Commission providing information on the progress towards achieving their national emission reduction commitments. Fiscal incentives can play a big role in shifting investments towards clean and efficient technologies for a more sustainable production. I think that the different needs and difficulties in tackling air pollution have to be analysed in advance for each national geographic region.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I supported the report on emissions of certain air pollutants.The report dealt with the revision of the National Emission Ceilings Directive, which is part of the so-calledclean air policy package.The new regulation thus sets binding national limits for the period up to 2030 for selected air pollutants.Indeed, despite the progress that has been made in this area, air pollution is still a major problem.Polluted air is responsible for a number of diseases, premature deaths, but also problems caused by subsequent climate change.That is why I appreciate that the revision has set ambitious goals in this, which include, in addition to reducing the adverse effects on public health and the environment, also the creation of new jobs and the development of innovative "green" technologies.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor of the Girling report for agreeing with the proposals presented to reinforce our strategy to reduce emissions of air pollutants in Europe. I emphasize that poor air quality is responsible for more than 400 000 premature deaths every year and with an estimated impact on health between 300 billion to 900 billion euros each year. Therefore, I welcome the proposals in this report to set more ambitious targets for air quality, allowing to reduce the number of premature deaths from toxic air by almost half by 2030. I also underline the role of clean electric mobility as an option that can very relevant contribution in the fight to reduce harmful emissions to health. Finally, I would also like to highlight the global call made in Marrakesh to make it possible to maintain the trajectory of combating global warming and this directive, now amended, will make an important contribution by the European Union in this regard.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - I support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC. Anthropogenic emissions of gases and particles are mostly caused by incomplete combustion of fuels used for heating, energy production, transportation or processes in industrial chemical plants and abrasion produced by motor vehicles. The aim of the proposed directive is to establish new national limits for the release of pollutants for the most significant air pollutants. Member States must ensure continuous monitoring of changes and reductions in the total amount of pollutants. For those countries that do not meet the criteria and set targets on time, it is necessary to establish mechanisms to ensure the implementation of this directive. Some of the objectives set by the regulation are a challenge for the Member States and in some circumstances the European Union must provide financial assistance in reform efforts, especially when it comes to transport. Clean air must remain a public good.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain air pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35 / EC.Efforts to achieve high air quality that do not have a major negative impact on human health and the environment and do not pose a serious threat to human health and the environment are one of the essential elements of sustainable development to which the EU aspires.As I believe that the measures proposed in the proposed directive will contribute to the gradual reduction of air pollution and to ensuring a high level of protection of human health and the environment, I have supported it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the financial crisis has shown us that we need criteria, sound standards and principles for the prudential regulation of banks. For this reason, I welcome the post-crisis work of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision. It aims to revise the standard approach for calculating potential risk assets. The banking sector must be negotiated and standardized in a very serious way and regulated very seriously for the people, in order to ensure fair market competition and financial stability. Fair competition both on the banking market and a competition - how to say - between banks, which offers all the guarantees for the population and for the people. Banks play a key role in financing the European economy and remain the main source of financing for the economy, including for small and medium-sized enterprises. I think that in a few years, the time will come when banks will look completely different and will have a much smaller role in the economy and in our daily lives. But, that's another discussion.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, we are often told that we need to be at the top table. It was a refrain throughout the recent UK referendum, but this report is a reminder that the top tables these days are global, rather than European. In this instance – the Basel III rules, the implementation of rules on financing and banking – the EU is, if you like, a regional subcontractor. It implements a decision that has been taken at a higher level, because of course finance is not continental but is worldwide in its scope and its movements. And the result of the European Union’s competence in this question is that all of our Member States are, in effect, represented around that table by one 28th of a European Commissioner or the relevant deputising official. How on earth can that be in the interests of an economy like my country’s, which depends heavily on financial services? One of the huge bonuses of taking back our place at the world table is that we will once again be able to speak in our own interests, rather than having to contract everything through a bureaucracy which may occasionally have an interest that coincides with ours but usually, as we have learned, does not.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, as noted in the resolution, attention must be paid to the specificities of European bank models, the markets they operate in and the varying size of the institutions. The Basel III reform measures should not be tossed into effect without clear appreciation of the fact that, whilst opportunity occupies one side of the coin, threats to that very sense of opportunity lie on the other side. Speaking from an Irish perspective, I can appreciate the ways in which Basel III has made the system more stable, but I am also worry that the increased instability may curtail opportunities for profit-making. These matters are worse for countries on the periphery, such as Ireland, where, between 2007 and 2015, investment as measured by gross fixed capital formation crashed from an average of 25.9% to 20.9% of gross domestic product. The discussion is a good one, and I hope to observe further improvement in ensuring competitive positioning for all banks.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The following motion for a resolution concerns the completion of Basel III, which is a set of reform proposals concerning banking regulation.European banks are experiencing a very critical period, caused above all by inadequate, and at times absent, financial regulation that began in the last decades of the previous century.I believe that Basel III is very far from being considered perfect or even just adequate for the conditions in which the current banking system is concerned.However, voting against would mean promoting the deregulation we talked about earlier.These are the main reasons why I decided to abstain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution requests that the financial position of entities be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.The report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- This resolution aims to dilute the work of Basel III and limit the capital requirements for European banks, one of the most speculative in the world.The financial system has amply demonstrated its inability to regulate itself and the serious risk it poses to the stability of the economic system as a whole: that is why our proposal is based on public banking and the prohibition of speculative activity.Meanwhile, it is necessary to ensure that private banks comply with such elementary precautions as providing themselves with sufficient capital so that their shareholders assume the financial risks they incur, instead of transferring their speculative losses to the States.That is why I cannot accept the content of this report and I have voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution and in favour of all amendments proposed by GUE/NGL. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS), the international standard-setting body for banking regulation, is in the process of finalising new prudential regulations (reducing the level of risks depositors are exposed to), which is supposed to be finished by the end of the year. It is considering several new requirements such as restrictions on how banks use internal models to estimate risks from real-estate loans as well as corporate and infrastructure lending. Banks like HSBC and Deutsche Bank, among others, have been lobbying fiercely against these new requirements saying they will amount to a massive increase in their capital requirements. This resolution is a statement of the European Parliament’s position on the issue, in response to Commission statement backing the banks. The resolution calls for the BCBS to revise its draft proposals to ensure the revision does not bring about a significant increase in overall capital requirements, and to ensure a ‘level playing field’ between EU and global banks. In other words, it calls on the Basel Committee to back away from imposing regulations that would protect the public and depositors.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this balanced report.It is essential that banks are an efficient part of our economy and not an element of risk.Banks must be well capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid a repeat of the huge bailouts seen during the crisis.The Basel Committee's on-going work is expected to promote a level playing field globally by reducing - rather than exacerbating - differences between jurisdictions and banking models and not unduly penalizing the EU banking model.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the final adoption of the Basel III agreement, in which the European Parliament notes the work of the Basel Committee to finalize the Basel III framework to increase simplicity, comparability and convergence of risk-weighted capital rules to address excessive asset the problem of differences in risk assessment and apply the same rules to the same risk. Importantly, greater transparency and accountability are needed to make the Basel Committee's deliberations more legitimate and accountable. I support the resolution's call for the Commission to carefully and comprehensively assess the qualitative and quantitative impact of recent and future reforms, including on the financing of the real economy in Europe and on forthcoming European legislative projects such as the Capital Markets Union. I believe that the Commission must ensure that the new Basel Committee proposals or their implementation do not run counter to these initiatives or undermine the legislative achievements to date, and that the committee's conclusions should not be seen as a call for deregulation.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the finalization of Basel III because it addresses issues that will affect the relevant legislation in the banking sector in the coming years.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- Priority must be given to the preservation of European banks in a context where prudential requirements will affect their American competitors less.The sovereignty of our economy is at stake.The report goes in this direction, so I voted in favor.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This motion was not subject to a roll-call vote, and therefore in the interests of transparency and democracy I would like to confirm that I voted against this resolution. This was due to the call for more Commission involvement in Member State affairs and a push for further globalisation of banking regulations.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the final adoption of Basel III.The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has made proposals to improve the prudential framework for banks in addressing credit and operational risk issues.I support this proposal that banks must have sufficient capital to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid a recurrence of the enormous public bailout measures taken during the crisis.In addition, the shadow banking sector needs to be properly regulated to ensure fair competition and financial stability.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The global financial crisis that erupted in 2007 highlighted the problems and shortcomings of banks' risk and crisis management practices. In 2011, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision published its Basel III framework, which sets out new global regulatory standards for banks' capital adequacy and liquidity and the accompanying implementation plan. Most importantly, banks need to increase their current share capital. They need to increase the current share capital ratio from 4 percent to 6 percent. The share capital must cover the bank's loss of income in a crisis situation. Another element of Basel III is the appropriate shaping of liquidity requirements. Financial institutions must have sufficient liquid assets to cover the so-called their net liquidity outflows. The motion for a resolution concerns the finalization of the Basel III agreement. The various provisions will be phased in by 2019. I supported the motion for a resolution because it reduces the likelihood of financial crises. At the same time, I would also like to emphasize that the problem can only be resolved once and for all if we return to the pre-1990s situation, ie the provisions of the Glass-Steagall Act, which prohibits commercial banks from investing in banking banking. ownership of securities trading companies.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to act, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This resolution could increase the competitiveness of European banks by limiting their constraints.At a time when the rest of the world, and in particular the United States with the announced intentions of the new Trump administration, leaves more room for maneuver to its banks, we cannot afford to be outdone while some European banks, and in particular France, have already had to divest part of their activities, particularly in Asia, due to Basel requirements.So I voted in favor.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.Parliament thereby reaffirms that banks must be properly capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid any repeat of the massive bailouts seen during the crisis.It stresses the need to develop appropriate regulation of the shadow banking sector in order to ensure fair competition as well as financial stability.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I agree to toughen certain banking rules in order to find a fairer system for citizens.But the sector is crucial for financing the economy, and the different models of European banking must be taken into account when changing certain criteria.We will closely monitor the involvement of the European Banking Authority, the ECB and the Commission in the Basel Committee.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The global financial crisis has led G20 leaders to agree on a comprehensive reform program aimed at strengthening the regulatory standards to which international banks are subject, a project that sees a central role of the Basel Committee which is developing minimum standards for prudential requirements applicable to large banks operating on an international scale. The motion for a resolution approved today by Parliament, and supported by me, develops a reflection on the central role played by banks within the EU and moves it to define some fundamental elements for a successful completion of the Basel III regulatory framework. The Basel Committee should undertake to promote standards of quality, transparency and consistency in terms of capitalization and risk coverage. The primary objective must be to guarantee real support to the real economy, reducing systemic risk and defining an approach that mitigates the differences between banking models and jurisdictions by establishing regulatory mechanisms that are based on risk.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against this resolution, in which Parliament blocks the revision of the Basel directive on the capital requirements of banks.Increasing capital requirements forces banks to save a larger sum of capital when making loans.This is a condition for reducing the instability and vulnerability of the financial system.However, the position of the banking lobbies and the Commission is that this would decrease the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis the US ones.I think that the high volatility of European banks and their disproportionate size is a very serious threat to European society and requires drastic intervention for financial institutions to fulfill their social function.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Gualtieri, for his work on the report which underlines the importance of sound global standards and principles for prudential regulation of banks and welcomes the post-crisis work of the CSBB on this.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This resolution on the finalization of the Basel III accord deserves to be supported because, in fact, I believe that priority must now be given to the preservation of European banks in a context where prudential requirements will affect less. their American competitors. The sovereignty of financing our economy is at stake. Since 2008, the trend has been one of tightening requirements, which has forced banks to increase their equity or reduce their commitments (lend less, more expensive, or to less risky projects or companies). There is a lot of complex work to refine the calculation formula to better contain the risks. We therefore support this option, which favors the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis their competitors, particularly American ones. She therefore takes a dim view of the introduction of the new requirements. The election of Donald Trump, who has announced that he wants to loosen the constraints on American banks (modification of the Dodd-Franck act), reinforces the topicality of the threat. In fact, some European banks, and in particular French banks, have already had to sell part of their activities, particularly in Asia, due to Basel requirements.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- "Basel 3" is a complex set of reform measures, prepared by the Basel Committee for Banking Supervision, in order to strengthen regulation, supervision and risk management in the banking sector.While the objectives set by this text are acceptable, I believe it is unacceptable that there is no critical passage in it regarding the behavior of some European banks that could have been avoided by an effective supervisory system.I am convinced that the right references to the role of the banking system in aid of families and SMEs are only a rhetorical exercise given the state of crisis at the financial level of many institutions, eventually also crushed by the private debt generated by the EU monetary policy.For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- I have supported this resolution of the Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.With this resolution, we request that the financial position of the entities be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.In addition, the report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it sets out Parliament's position on the Basel III agreement. Basel III aims to increase the simplicity, comparability and convergence of risk-weighted capital rules in order to address excessive differences in the risk-weighted exposure amounts and to apply the same rules to the same risk. The G20 leaders endorsed a comprehensive reform agenda in the wake of the financial crisis, strengthening regulatory standards for international banks, including tightening prudential requirements. The Basel Committee is developing internationally agreed minimum standards setting prudential requirements for large, internationally operating banks. The Basel Committee monitors and reviews the implementation of these global standards and reports to the G20, and its guidelines are an important tool for avoiding divergent regulation around the world.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I support the motions for resolutions, as a resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a fundamental condition for maintaining financial stability and providing adequate credit, and contributes to economic growth.The G-20 Heads of State also agreed on a comprehensive reform agenda to strengthen the regulatory standards of international banks, including the strengthening of prudential requirements to prevent further banking crises, as part of the financial crisis.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - Following the 2008 economic and financial crisis, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision was established with the aim of strengthening banks' ability to absorb shocks deriving from financial and economic tensions, in order to reduce the risk of contagion from the financial sector to the real economy. Indeed, in the EU, banks play a major role in financing the economy. With this resolution, which I support, the European Parliament emphasizes the need for internationally agreed minimum standards in order to avoid regulatory fragmentation in the area of ​​capital regulation. The need is precisely to ensure that the Basel III agreement respects standards of quality, transparency and consistency in terms of capitalization and risk coverage, paying attention to the fact that, with the new rules, the moderate growth that the EU is experiencing in the post-crisis period is favored and not slowed down. Parliament also recalls the importance of reforms based on the principle of a level playing field worldwide, so that differences between countries and banking models are reduced rather than increased.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this issue to the Commission.I think it is important for banks to be an effective component of our economy, not an element of risk.Banks must be able to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid the recurrence of the huge bailouts we witnessed during the crisis.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The Basel Accords are guidelines on the capital requirements of banks, drawn up by the Basel Committee, made up of the regulatory bodies of the main countries of the so-called "First World", in order to pursue international monetary and financial stability. The most recent of the three Basel Accords, which entered into force six years ago, established a body, the BCBS (Basel Committee on Banking Supervision), which presented to the international community a package of proposals aimed at perfecting the prudential framework for banks that are faced with credit and financial risks. These proposals must be collected by the European Union and reworked with the aim of improving risk sensitivity and the solidity of standardized approaches, better regulating financial flows and implementing - where necessary - the appropriate restrictions, completing the planning and the calibration of financial leverage with a long-term perspective and the political will to favor stability and the real economy over short-term financial speculations.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- The Basel Committee draws up prudential rules in the form of recommendations that can be transposed into national and European law by the competent authorities.Since the 2008 financial crisis, these rules have been aimed at forcing banking establishments to increase their capital in order to improve their solvency, the objective being to make them more resistant to scenarios of financial instability.This report considers that the new regulations, aimed at increasing the solvency ratios of European banks, should not harm the competitiveness of our banking sector.Combined with the Capital Markets Union, the application of Basel IV could further put our banks at a competitive disadvantage.I voted in favor of this text, which warns European and national authorities against the consequences of overly restrictive regulations.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution requests that the financial position of institutions be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.The report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- After careful reflection and discussion in the Chamber, I gave my positive vote to the resolution on the conclusion of the Basel III agreement, based on the following considerations: - a better management of the bank / company relationship is a priority on both thebank, to avoid operational risks and improve the prudential framework of banks;- correct access to the capital market and concrete assistance in identifying new forms of capitalization are essential elements to ensure stability to the production system;- the Commission must be the driving force in guaranteeing a level playing field and in calibrating the final rules.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to act, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as I believe that we need to take better account of the specificities of the European banking models, the different models, sizes of the institutions and risk profiles. The methods to measure risks proposed by the Basel Committee will put a disproportionate strain on European banks. We need to avoid penalising European banks over American banks when implementing the new plans of the Basel Committee.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and emphasize that a resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - We voted on the motion for a resolution to finalize the Basel III framework, which aims to strengthen and protect the financial system in Europe. Although the purpose of this framework could work to the benefit of the smaller European banks in particular, I believe that once again the rational regulation of the banks' operating framework is not being achieved, which in the recent past has been one of the reasons for the financial crisis the eurozone. I therefore decided to vote against the motion for a resolution.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - The third Basel Accord represents a vigorous network of reform measures for banking supervision in order to strengthen the regulation, supervision and risk management of the sector, specifically, minimum capital thresholds are imposed on banks to prevent shocks financials bring them to their knees with destructive consequences for the entire system. A prudential regulation, from my point of view, must be favored and implemented, therefore I externalize my favor to the provision. The reason that more than any other pushes me to do so has its origins in the support offered to the real economy. That is, the Basel rules are designed to stabilize the financial world and impose on its protagonists correct practices in terms of capitalization, risk management and liquidity, strongly conditioning their investments towards the real economy and therefore their convoy towards companies and citizens. Greater security of institutions, with anti-crisis capital buffers of a certain level can, in fact, result in a contraction of credit to businesses and therefore in a brake on the economy. Balance is everything and Basel 3 asks banks for guarantees on capital and liquidity so that financing for households and businesses is verifiable and secure.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions – Finalisation of Basel III.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the provision as I agree with the proposals put forward by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) aimed at perfecting the prudential framework for banks that face credit and operational risks (finalization of the Basel agreement III, the so-called "Basel IV"). The aim of the proposals is to improve the risk sensitivity and robustness of standardized approaches, analyze further restrictions on the role of internally modeled approaches in the capital framework, and complete the design and calibration of leverage and a any minimum level of capital, based on standardized approaches. In my opinion, it is necessary to continue to monitor the activity of banks - which today play a key role in financing the European economy and are likely to remain the main source of finance for households and businesses, especially SMEs - in order to reduce any systemic risk.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- This resolution aims to dilute the work of Basel III and limit the capital requirements for European banks, one of the most speculative in the world.The financial system has amply demonstrated its inability to regulate itself and the serious risk it poses to the stability of the economic system as a whole: that is why our proposal is based on public banking and the prohibition of speculative activity.Meanwhile, it is necessary to ensure that private banks comply with such elementary precautions as providing themselves with enough capital so that their shareholders assume the financial risks they incur, instead of transferring their speculative losses to the States.That is why I cannot accept the content of this report and I have voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - It is necessary to protect the peculiarity of the European banking system: where the large international banks are flanked by small regional and cooperative banks, European wealth. It is essential to protect diversity and heterogeneity in the European financial landscape, which also allows for risk diversification. In particular, it is important to protect those banks that are aware of the needs and problems of local artisans and small and medium-sized enterprises. Therefore the rules must be proportional to the size and risk of the bank. Regulation needs to be risk-based. In particular, the same risk must be matched by a common treatment at the global regulatory level. Thus, a reduction in regulatory arbitrage can be guaranteed. In this regard, it is important that Parliament reaffirm its legislative power with respect to a matter such as the implementation of the Basel standards, which very often is accused of being decided outside democratic schemes. Therefore, a direct transposition must be avoided, but a careful implementation that takes into account the proportionality and peculiarity of the European system. For these reasons, I consider the final text to be an excellent compromise in defense of the democratic role of Parliament towards policies in defense of a commitment of the financial system to the real economy.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted against the finalization of the Basel III package.I believe that this package will have negative consequences for bank customers, and I have doubts about the estimated economic benefits of the proposed changes.The use of regulation in the form of a specific framework, and not specific provisions, does not make it possible to clearly assess the effects of the package.On the other hand, the lack of a specific impact assessment gives rise to a number of conflicting opinions.According to experts, the introduction of higher capital requirements, as required by the proposed package, will mean higher costs for banks.These in turn will be passed on to customers.Too many doubts and the lack of a clear assessment of the benefits that this package could bring motivate us to continue working and, at present, to reject the package.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ In order to avoid the repeat of bailouts witnessed during the crisis our banks need to be well capitalised to reduce risks and provide a level playing field globally. A risk-based approach to regulation is also the key, with the same rules being applied to the same risk. The finalisation of Basel is a positive step forward in mitigating the differences between jurisdictions.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This resolution relates to the finalization of the Basel Accord, whose committee aims to establish financial recommendations on a global scale, and without binding value.In this context, the Basel III accord aims to increase banks' capitalization obligations, thus establishing additional rules (prudential rules).Considering that these agreements strengthen the regulation of the international financial system and its harmonization, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) played a key role in reforming the global banking system by establishing minimum regulatory standards.However, I consider that as it stands, the committee's latest proposals do not take into account the specificities of the European banking sector and are on the whole more favorable to American banks.I therefore voted in favor of the resolution on the finalization of Basel III, so that the representatives of the European institutions at the BCBS act to modify the next reform package of this committee and keep the European legislators informed of the progress of these discussions..

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.The Basel Committee agreements concern the solvency of banking establishments and establish the related prudential rules.Current work, known as Basel IV or III ½, studies the introduction of a new risk in the denominator of the solvency ratio, the interest rate risk (in addition to market risk, credit risk and operational risk).Prudential rules are certainly restrictive for European banking establishments, in competition with foreign establishments subject to more flexible rules.Nevertheless, the Front National favors the protection of depositors against systemic risks.We therefore have no reason to oppose this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
