text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the finalization of Basel III. Basel III is a comprehensive set of reform measures developed by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision aimed at strengthening the regulation, supervision and risk management of the banking sector. Their aim is to improve the ability of the banking sector to absorb shocks arising from financial and economic stress, regardless of its source, as well as to improve risk management and governance, enhance transparency and disclosure to banks. I believe that a sustainable and well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability and supporting economic growth.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - A well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability, while it must support economic growth. In the context of tackling credit risk and business risk, huge sums have been spent on rescuing banks, sums that citizens of EU Member States are required to pay. Especially in the case of Greece, rescuing banks, paying huge dividends to shareholders and the recapitalization of financial institutions translated into the signing of memoranda.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on the finalisation of Basel III, as I believe the European Parliament should take a stronger position on the financial system. Weaknesses in the system have caused damage to European citizens including my constituents in Wales.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - In the face of the neoliberal offensive of the 1980s and the deregulating and liberalizing fury that deregulated the financial sector, it soon became apparent that private banking needed some rules under penalty of jeopardizing the entire system. The rules created from Basel I to III aim to impose minimum levels of equity. However, the rules for their accounting have become increasingly complex and opaque, as befits interest groups that always take advantage of the lack of transparency. Today, asset risk assessment models are the responsibility of so-called systemic banks, unlike others that are subject to a standardized model. In other words, we have, in practice, assets with different weightings from bank to bank. In other words, we have a system in which the solvency ratios and stress tests are completely handled by the major banks, thus removing any credibility from the entire supervisory system. For our part, the solution is simple. Credit is too important to be left to the private sector's free enterprise. Public control over banking and the financial system is now more than ever necessary.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ While I agree that we all need a stable, safe, secure banking system, the system that currently exists isn’t it. Again, while I agree that banks should be regulated (and the more the better), introducing more legislation when that which already exists isn’t implemented is a bit of a joke – witness what happened to Jonathan Sugarman when he blew the whistle on major breaches of regulation in Ireland. We need an entirely new banking system, a system controlled by national governments, a system in which money creation is likewise controlled by national governments but to the benefit of the people (as in no/low interest rates) and not – as is currently the case – to the benefit of banks and financiers. That is why I voted against this piece of legislation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - This resolution will affect the forthcoming European Union legislation in the banking sector in the future.It is essential that banks play a positive role for society and that they once again become an effective element of the economy, not an element of risk.Banks must be well-capitalized and well-capitalized, and their main benefits must be to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and try to prevent a recurrence of the huge economic and financial crisis.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - A well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability, while it must support economic growth. In the context of tackling credit risk and business risk, huge sums have been spent on rescuing banks, sums that citizens of EU Member States are required to pay. Especially in the case of Greece, rescuing banks, paying huge dividends to shareholders and the recapitalization of financial institutions translated into the signing of memoranda. For the above reasons I am voting against the finalization of Basel III.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I consider that banks should be an efficient component of our economy and not an element of risk. Banks need to be well capitalised in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid the repeat of the enormous bailouts witnessed during the crisis. The ongoing work of the Basel Committee should promote the level playing field at the global level by mitigating – rather than exacerbating – the differences between jurisdictions and banking models and not unduly penalising the EU banking model. A risk-based approach to regulation is key, with the same rules being applied to the same risk.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution considering that it is vital to have a resilient banking system with a good capitalization, since they are indispensable conditions to preserve financial stability, providing an adequate granting of credits to the real economy and reinforcing theeconomic growth.It is therefore important to have solid global standards and principles for prudential regulation of banks, to continue working to finalize the Basel III framework, aimed at strengthening the simplicity, comparability and convergence of the risk-weighted capital framework, toto be able to respond to the excessive variability of risk-weighted assets and to apply the same rules to the same risks, as well as to achieve greater transparency and accountability.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution calls for the financial position of institutions to be improved without significantly increasing capital requirements and for the European banking model not to be harmed within the framework of international competition.In addition, the report supports the approach to calculating capital levels based on risk, but reducing variability.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution requests that the financial position of institutions be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.The report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this important report on the work of the BCBS to finalise the Basel III framework. This is a key part of legislation to develop internationally agreed minimum standards and requirements for large, international banks. This would serve to add simplicity and comparability of the existing framework on risk-weighted capital – this could serve to address excessive variability of these assets and it would importantly mean that the same rules are applied to the same risks. Extensive monitoring of the effects will be necessary in order to ensure no negative effects on the banking sector. Banks play a key role in financing the European economy and they are especially important for SMEs – who makes up the real backbone of the European economy. In regard to SMEs, flexibility plays a key role in their financing needs, and we as lawmakers must keep this a relevant theme in all financial regulation. It is of crucial importance that we promote the financing of, and investments in, European SMEs since they are already underfunded and financing possibilities are needed to reverse the sluggish growth of the EU economy.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the completion of Basel III on the capital requirements of financial institutions, on the transposition of which the EP worked extensively in the last parliamentary term. In fact, I believe that the EP, being a co-legislator, should be able to express its concerns regarding the revision by the Basel Committee, which will soon meet in Chile, of certain rules (revision of the standard approach to operational and credit risk, potential introduction of new minimum capital thresholds "output floors"). I resolutely share the concerns about a further tightening of capital requirements, due to the potential effects on the real economy, and at a very delicate stage for the entire European economy, whose signs of growth are still weak, as stated by President Draghi this one. week ahead of the EP. As well as the need for European banks to be well capitalized in order to support the real economy and SMEs and at the same time reduce risks. Therefore, I believe that the EP's request for a greater balance in the drafting of new rules is appropriate to reduce the possibilities of regulatory arbitrage and to counter the weakening of the European banking model, while guaranteeing economic growth and the stability of the financial system.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- Since 2013, Basel III has gradually replaced the "Basel II" forerunner rules for financial market and banking regulation.The reason for the reform were weaknesses in the previous banking regulation, which had been disclosed by the financial crisis since 2007 and corrected with Basel III.That is good for our citizens, good for Europe - that is why I voted for it.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given it is vital   to kick-start economic growth and create new jobs. Banks are key players in achieving this goal by bolstering the EU economy. However, we have to ensure that banks are stable and well capitalised because they are fundamental to sustainable economic growth. As co-legislator, Parliament needs to assess carefully the qualitative and the quantitative impact of these new reforms on the European economy, in particular the financing of infrastructure and real assets.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted against this resolution, in which Parliament blocks the revision of the Basel directive on the capital requirements of banks.Increasing capital requirements forces banks to save a larger sum of capital when making loans.This is a condition for reducing the instability and vulnerability of the financial system.However, the position of the banking lobbies and the Commission is that this would decrease the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis the US ones.I think that the high volatility of European banks and their disproportionate size is a very serious threat to European society and requires drastic intervention for financial institutions to fulfill their social role.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the finalisation of Basel III. It is fundamental for our citizens that banks are an efficient component of our economy and do not pose a risk. Banks must have sufficient capital to ensure that we avoid a repeat of the enormous bailouts witnessed during the crisis.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution requests that the financial position of institutions be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.The report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - We voted against the report, as our main concern was that European banks should not have a disadvantage compared to their counterparts in the US. The concern of the financial sector in the European Union is that the proposals could lead to significantly higher capital requirements especially for banks using internal models. The report focuses on the need to create a level playing field for competition and proportionality, especially for smaller and less complex banks. Although we agree with some of these concerns (as regards smaller and less risky banks), we disagree substantially with the fact that the banking sector should not be overburdened. We believe that the internal models of banks were a major cause of the financial crisis, as they were often used to hide significant risks in banks' balance sheets.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the finalisation of Basel III. Basel III is part of the continuous effort to enhance the banking regulatory framework. It builds on the Basel I and Basel II documents, and seeks to improve the banking sector’s ability to deal with financial stress, improve risk management, and strengthen the banks’ transparency. A focus of Basel III is to foster greater resilience at the individual bank level in order to reduce the risk of system-wide shocks.  However while this is being addressed on several levels  of the banking union, I  was happy to support an amendment to this resolution that highlights that regulation has not been sufficiently addressed around the ‘too big to fail’ banks, such as was seen in the Deutsche Bank case recently.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written. - The motion for a resolution by the grand coalition in the European Parliament clearly positions itself against an increase in capital requirements for European banks as a result of the upcoming Basel III reforms. I expressly believe that such an increase is indispensable for the stability of our financial system and as a lesson from the financial crisis, and I have therefore voted against the text. The current banking regulation is based on risk weighting of the capital requirements and thus stipulates that risks can be quantified in advance. It also completely ignores the enormous risks of the persistently low interest rate environment. As an argument against the Basel reforms, Parliament cites discrimination against European banks. In fact, American banks currently have to hold far more equity capital than their European competitors. I also do not share the argument that lending in the euro area will be jeopardized by an increase in equity. The greatest threat is a financial crisis and this can only be prevented if the necessary conclusions are finally drawn from the developments in the banking system of 2008 that were devastating for taxpayers.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The banking system should be an efficient component of our economy and not an element of risk. Banks have to be well capitalised in order to support the real economy and reduce systemic risk. Moreover, the initiatives of the Basel Committee should promote a level playing field at the global level, by working on mitigating the differences between jurisdictions and banking models, and not penalising the EU banking model.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the finalization of Basel III because in order to preserve financial stability, ensure lending to the real economy and support economic growth, a banking system that is well capitalized and resilient is needed.I believe that banks have an important role to play in financing the European economy, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and that differences between jurisdictions and banking models need to be reduced in order to promote a level playing field worldwide.In this context, it is important that the principle of proportionality and the risk-based approach be established at Union level, but also at international level, and that examples of good practice be exchanged between regulators.I also believe that European and national banking supervisors have a relevant role to play in ensuring the coherence of supervision in the European Union, and I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Roberto Gualtieri on the finalization of the Basel III accord.The Basel III accord is part of a reform of the 1988 Basel accords and aims to oblige banks to improve their internal risk management.Thus, after Basel II, the objective is to strengthen the capacity of banking institutions to adapt to the economic situation and therefore not to succumb in the event of a financial crisis.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which calls on the Commission to take into account several principles when translating the Basel III proposals into European law.First, the specificities of European banking models and markets, but also the preservation of the diversity of the banking sector and respect for the principle of proportionality.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - Significant legislative interventions have already been made to strengthen the institutional framework of the financial markets and the banking sector, and the European Union has always played a productive role in Basel. However, the success of the Basel regime goes through a balanced approach to the diversity of global banking systems, most notably the difference in approach to credit risk in Europe and the US, where in the US the normalization of the framework is excessive and leaves the risk open. unlike Europe, which is much more cautious about market risk and more resilient about credit risk. Banks' internal credit risk models are a tool that helps and does not hinder regulatory objectives, so we need to include it in our assessments of the framework that the Basel is coming to define.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting for the resolution before us.It urges the Commission to exercise more judgment in the implementation of the Basel III criteria and in the work of the BCBS and to address the specifics of the European banking system.The increase in the capital adequacy of banks when granting real estate and other loans, which is particularly aimed at by the US side, could pose a serious risk to Europe's economy.US banks are hardly affected by this, as US companies finance themselves more directly through the capital market and state development banks take most of the residential real estate loans from commercial banks.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given it is vital to kick-start economic growth and create new jobs. Banks are key players in achieving this goal by bolstering the EU economy yet we have to ensure they are stable and well capitalised because they are fundamental to sustainable economic growth.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - The motion for a resolution by the grand coalition in the European Parliament is clearly positioned against an increase in capital requirements for European banks as a result of the upcoming Basel III reforms. I expressly believe that such an increase is indispensable for the stability of our financial system and as a lesson from the financial crisis, and I have therefore voted against the text. The current banking regulation is based on risk weighting of the capital requirements and thus stipulates that risks can be quantified in advance. It also completely ignores the enormous risks of the persistently low interest rate environment. As an argument against the Basel reforms, Parliament cites a disadvantage for European banks. In fact, American banks currently have to hold far more equity capital than their European competitors. I also do not share the argument that lending in the euro area will be jeopardized by an increase in equity. The greatest threat is a financial crisis and this can only be prevented if the necessary conclusions are finally drawn from the developments in the banking system of 2008 that were devastating for taxpayers.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- The causes of the financial crisis that surfaced in 2007 are deeply rooted and clear to those familiar with the operational features of the banking system, the most superficial manifestations of which are the problems and shortcomings of banks' risk and crisis management practices.In order to avoid further similar crises, Basel III offers partial solutions.a framework containing new global regulatory standards for banks' capital adequacy and liquidity and an accompanying implementation plan.This motion for a resolution is a clear step forward for the financial security of European citizens and should therefore be supported, even if a comprehensive solution cannot be reached in this way.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted for the resolution on finalizing the Basel III accord. The Basel Committee is an international body that develops prudential rules applicable to banking institutions in order to improve their solvency. These are recommendations which must then be transposed by the competent institutions. The trend since the 2008 crisis has been one of tightening requirements, which has forced banks to increase their equity or reduce their commitments (lend less, more expensive, or to less risky projects or companies). I believe that the competitiveness of European banks must be strengthened against their competitors, especially the American ones. Combined with the Capital Markets Union (favoring market financing, where American institutions are the strongest, compared to traditional credit), the application of Basel IV could accentuate the competitive disadvantage of European institutions. Too much regulation would also end up crippling credit and the economy.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- This resolution could increase the competitiveness of European banks by limiting their constraints.At a time when the rest of the world, and in particular the United States with the announced intentions of the new Trump administration, leaves more room for maneuver to its banks, we cannot afford to be outdone while some European banks, and in particular France, have already had to divest part of their activities, particularly in Asia, due to Basel requirements.So I voted in favor.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution requests that the financial position of entities be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.The report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this resolution on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.The resolution requests that the financial position of entities be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.The report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- This resolution aims to dilute the work of Basel III and limit the capital requirements for European banks, one of the most speculative in the world.The financial system has amply demonstrated its inability to regulate itself and the serious risk it poses to the stability of the economic system as a whole: that is why our proposal is based on public banking and the prohibition of speculative activity.Meanwhile, it is necessary to ensure that private banks comply with such elementary precautions as providing themselves with sufficient capital so that their shareholders assume the financial risks they incur, instead of transferring their speculative losses to the States.That is why I cannot accept the content of this report and I have voted against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - The motion for a resolution by the grand coalition in the European Parliament clearly positions itself against an increase in capital requirements for European banks as a result of the upcoming Basel III reforms. I expressly believe that such an increase is indispensable for the stability of our financial system and as a lesson from the financial crisis, and I have therefore voted against the text. The current banking regulation is based on risk weighting of the capital requirements and thus stipulates that risks can be quantified in advance. It also completely ignores the enormous risks of the persistently low interest rate environment. As an argument against the Basel reforms, Parliament cites discrimination against European banks. In fact, American banks currently have to hold far more equity capital than their European competitors. I also do not share the argument that lending in the euro area will be jeopardized by an increase in equity. The greatest threat is a financial crisis and this can only be prevented if the necessary conclusions are finally drawn from the developments in the banking system of 2008 that were devastating for taxpayers.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that refines banking frameworks.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The motion for a resolution emphasizes that a resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a precondition for maintaining financial stability, ensuring adequate lending to the real economy and supporting economic growth. The European Union has implemented internationally agreed standards under the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD IV), although it has adapted them to the EU's real funding needs and allowed some degree of flexibility. It is essential that banks are well capitalized to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and not repeat the rescue of banks with huge financial resources, as they have a key role to play in financing the European economy and will remain the main source of financing for households and businesses. SMEs. European and national banking supervisors have a key role to play in ensuring the coherence of supervision in the EU, while respecting the principles of proportionality and the appropriateness of rules for different banking models. The resolution emphasizes the importance of reliable and comparable information on the state of the institutions being monitored so that this work can be done efficiently and reliably. I supported this resolution.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to establish global standards and principles for the prudential regulation of banks. Banks need to be well capitalised in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid any repeat of the enormous bailouts witnessed during the crisis.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Since 1988, the Basel Accords have been gradually adjusting the capital adequacy rules of banks. The Basel III rules are a response to the financial crisis of 2008-2009. They regulate in detail the global regulatory standards of banks' capital adequacy and liquidity, better risk coverage and introduce measures to support the construction of capital that can be drawn in times of crisis. However, they are not legally binding and need to be transposed into EU law in order to be effective. This was also the reason why some banks paid dividends to shareholders in the past period, despite being undercapitalized. The banking sector has a significant impact on the financing of the Union's economy, which is why I support the proposal that the Commission should work to transpose the rules without increasing the administrative burden. Strict banking supervision must prevent the savings of the population from being jeopardized and the irresponsible conduct of banks from being covered by common resources. Consistent personal responsibility must also take place in this area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the finalization of Basel III, for the reasons set out in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 21 November 2016, and because this motion for a resolution is incomplete and well-founded.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.The Basel III accord consists of prudential rules applicable to banking establishments in order, on the one hand, to improve their solvency and, on the other hand, to contain risks.Basel IV (also known as Basel III ½) aims to introduce a new risk in the denominator of several ratios (solvency, interest rate risk, etc.), and respects the trend that has existed since 2008: a strengthening of requirements.In this case, the proposal put to the vote tends to reduce these requirements and thus make European banks more competitive with their competitors, which we support.Indeed, some French banks have already had to divest part of their activities because of these requirements.The sovereignty of financing our economy is at stake.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the EP's position on Basel III.The purpose of this agreement is to ensure the stability of the banking system, adequate lending to the real economy and economic growth.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This resolution confirms the state of discussions on the new global banking standards known as Basel III. Defined in 2010, they were supposed to respond to the 2008 crisis but are still not in force due to lack of agreement on how to apply them. An oligarchic institution, the Basel committee is made up only of central bankers from countries with the largest banks. The ECB is represented there while the national regulators of the majority of EU countries are not part of it! The resolution does not say a word about the questionable legitimacy of such an institution. She is also destitute on the diagnosis of the financial system. It says nothing about speculation and marginally evokes the dangers of securitization. It prioritizes the assessment and compensation of financial risks but not their prevention at all. The resolution also does not say a word about the misappropriation of central liquidity granted to banks without the real economy ever seeing the color. On the contrary, it grants a satisfaction to the ECB. I vote against this resolution which makes no useful proposal in the face of the heightened dangers of financial capitalism.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - The Basel III accord has been transcribed into European regulations. The question is whether we should continue to regulate banks' exposure to market risks and therefore move towards a Basel III ½ and IV agreement in order to further limit the leverage effect. Our position is to favor the competitiveness of European banks against their competitors, particularly American ones. We are therefore reluctant to introduce new requirements, which is the direction the ECON resolution takes. The election of Donald Trump, who has announced that he wants to relax the constraints on American banks (modification of the Dodd-Franck Act), reinforces the topicality of the threat. In fact, some European banks, and in particular French banks, have already had to sell part of their activities, particularly in Asia, due to Basel requirements. Indeed, we must face the following paradox: regulations are more and more restrictive for our banks (while many other countries are not subject to the same) and this does not protect us from the risk of crises. . We therefore remain in our positions of defending the separation of investment and deposit banks. I therefore voted in favor of the motion for a resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Banks need to be well capitalized in order to be able to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid a repetition of the huge bailouts witnessed during the crisis.Adequate regulation for the shadow banking sector is necessary to ensure fair competition and financial stability.A resilient and well-capitalized banking system is an indispensable condition for preserving financial stability, ensuring adequate lending to the real economy throughout the cycle and reinforcing economic growth.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion because this comprehensive set of reforms on banking supervision are necessary to reinforce regulation, oversight and risk management in the banking sector.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - Much of the 2008 financial crisis was caused by unreasonable lending that got out of hand. The domination of the short term and yield at all costs has penetrated the financial market. Finance has thus been diverted from its primary purpose, namely to transform savers' deposits into long-term investments. When the financial bubble burst, some banks did not have the necessary liquidity to absorb their losses. Following this crisis, a broad reform program aimed at strengthening regulatory standards applicable to international banks, such as prudential requirements, was agreed by G20 leaders. The European Parliament reiterates today the importance of setting strong global standards and principles for the prudential regulation of banks in order to reduce the likelihood and severity of future crises. A strong and well-capitalized banking system is essential to preserve financial stability, ensure adequate lending to the real economy throughout the cycle, and support economic growth.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on finalization of Basel III, which has been adopted to state Parliament's position on some key issues under discussion by the Basel Committee (BCBS) that will influence the legislation for the banking sector in the coming years.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - Basel III, born in 2010. agreement is an international response to the financial crisis of 2008-2010 developed by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS). It is intended to gradually strengthen the security of commercial banks, in particular by raising the share capital ratio from the current 4 per cent to 6 per cent. With regard to the finalization of the agreement, the draft resolution of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs emphasizes two principles: on the one hand, that general capital requirements should not be significantly increased not deepening - the differences between jurisdictions and banking models. The report notes with concern that a preliminary analysis of recent drafts of the BCBS suggests that the reform package is not in line with these two principles at this stage, and calls on the relevant bodies to review the proposals in this regard. to ensure compliance. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The report presented essentially asks that the new standards of the Basel Committee do not lead to an increase in banks' capital requirements. The competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis their competitors, particularly American ones, is threatened by the introduction of the new requirements. The election of Donald Trump, who has announced that he wants to relax the constraints on American banks (modification of the Dodd-Franck act), reinforces the topicality of the threat. Combined with the capital markets union (which will favor market financing, where American institutions are the strongest, compared to traditional credit), the application of Basel III-IV could accentuate the competitive disadvantage of European institutions, d 'as far as the rules of CRR and CRD IV have not yet fully produced their effects. Too much regulation would also end up crippling credit, the economy. The vote is therefore favorable, while reaffirming that we must support efforts to force banks to cease their speculative activities or, failing that, impose a real banking separation, the only one capable of protecting depositors.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- The application of Basel IV could accentuate the competitive disadvantage of European institutions, especially as the rules of CRR and CRD IV have not yet fully produced their effects.Too much regulation would also end up crippling credit and therefore the economy.I therefore vote for this resolution.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on the Third Basel Accord.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the finalization of Basel III, because I believe that it is our duty to ensure a sustainable and well-capitalized banking system. Bulgaria is one of the countries that has experienced a collapse in the banking system. In Bulgaria, it was caused by the opening of the financial pyramid of CCB. The bank's bankruptcy has raised a number of questions among citizens about the stability of the country's banking system and control over banks. Therefore, I believe that the reforms set out in Basel III, focusing on increasing risk sensitivity and the stability of the standardized approach to credit risk, further limiting the approach to internal modeling and finalizing the definition of leverage ratio and potential capital floor, will contribute to the stability of banks. Banks need to be well capitalized in order to provide real support to the economy. We must take the necessary measures to prevent systemic risks and reduce the possibility of granting new rescue measures on a large scale. The stability of EU banks is a step towards a stable economy for the Member States.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution, which emphasizes the importance of the work of the Basel Committee in developing internationally agreed minimum standards for prudential requirements for large internationally operating banks.The work of the committee is important to avoid regulatory fragmentation around the world.It should be pointed out that banks must be well-capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risks and prevent a recurrence of the bailouts scenario, as was the case during the crisis.At the same time, care must be taken to ensure that the cumulative impact of regulation does not jeopardize the ability of financial institutions to support the economy in such a way as to maintain stable economic growth.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because the report calls for a stronger regulatory regime for banks, but this could lead to a credit crunch again and ultimately the real economy will suffer as a result.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The aim is to ensure that European financial services companies do not face significantly increased capital requirements.This is necessary to enable banks to compete with other banks in the rest of the world.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I support the resolution that has been tabled.Given the consequences of the crisis for the banking sector, it is important to ensure that they have sufficient capital to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid a recurrence of the huge public rescue measures taken during the crisis.In addition, the shadow banking sector needs to be tightened up to ensure fair competition and financial stability.It should be noted that Basel III will increase the simplicity, comparability and convergence of risk-weighted capital rules and help to create a global level playing field.However, any review must first address the problem of banks that are too large and too broad to allow them to fail, and prevent losses from being borne at the expense of society.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The resolution raises the issue of banks' capital adequacy and the impact on lending capacity. The question is whether the extra funds that banks should hold as a reserve under the proposed revision of the banks' capital adequacy rules (Basel III finalization) will reduce their ability to lend to the real economy and reduce competitiveness. internationally. That is why, as emphasized in the resolution I voted in favor of, any changes to these rules should take into account the specificities of the European banking sector and the key role that banks play in financing the European economy. Banks need to have sufficient capital to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid a repeat of the huge bailouts made during the crisis.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that a well-established and well-capitalized system is the fundamental prerequisite for safeguarding financial safeguards, for ensuring proper lending to the real economy and for supporting economic growth.The G20 also agreed on the development of a reform program aimed at protecting regulatory standards, together with the BCBS developed international standards aimed at establishing prudential requirements to apply to international banks.However, as these prudential requirements may vary in their application depending on the banking activity, the BCBS is considering further changes to the prudential system for banks.However, the BCBS will have to carefully evaluate the impact of the reforms on countries and banking models.I therefore voted in favor

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written.- I support the motion for a resolution on the finalization of Basel III which seeks to create a well-capitalized and resilient banking system.Such a banking system is a prerequisite for preserving financial stability and securing lending to the real economy.The recent economic crisis has shown the importance of the role of credit rating agencies in the overall market confidence in a country or company.For these reasons, it is crucial to establish global standards and principles that will regulate the prudential status of banks and harmonize practices.Great efforts have been made to increase the simplicity and convergence of business, and I express the hope that in the future the associated risks will be reduced and that overall business and economic trends will be more predictable.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- The project presented makes it possible to defend European banks against their competitors, particularly American ones.I therefore support him and vote for him.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - Banks must be an efficient part of our economy, not an element of risk. They play a key role in financing the European economy and are likely to remain the main source of funding for households and businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. A resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability and supporting economic growth. The audit currently being conducted by BCBS must encourage and promote balanced chances of success, a level playing field for all globally. It must reduce, not further emphasize, differences in jurisdictions and banking models and avoid unnecessarily penalizing the EU's banking model. The key is in an approach based on proper risk assessment, with the same rules that apply to the same risk. A sound framework for financial stability and growth needs to be comprehensive and balanced to encompass dynamic supervisory practices, not just focus on static regulation that mainly relates to quantitative aspects. I want to emphasize the need for greater transparency and accountability in order to increase the legitimacy of BCBS councils and take them over. Banks need to be well-capitalized to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and not repeat the rescue of banks with huge financial resources, which we witnessed during the crisis.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - After the neoconservative wave of the eighties and the neoliberal fury that deregulated the financial sector, it soon became apparent that private banking needed some rules under penalty of jeopardizing the entire system. The rules created from Basel I to III are intended to impose minimum levels of equity. However, the rules for their accounting become increasingly complex and opaque, as befits interest groups that always profit from the lack of transparency. Today, the citizen is instilled in the idea that asset risk assessment models are the responsibility of so-called systemic banks, unlike others that are subject to a standardized model. That is, we have, as proved by a study by Standard & amp; Poor's, assets with different weightings from bank to bank, therefore, a system in which solvency ratios and stress tests are completely manipulated by large banks, thus removing any credibility from the entire supervisory system. For our part, the solution is simple. Credit is too important to be left to the private sector's free enterprise. Public control of banking and the financial system is now an imperative necessity.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the finalization of the Basel III accord, the main objective of which is to increase the resilience capacity of the major international banks, that is to say their capacity toadapt to economic conditions.In response to the financial crisis, it is essential to improve the robustness of banks while preserving their ability to finance the economy.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing.- A resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a conditio sine qua non of financial stability, ensuring adequate credit provision to the real economy and economic growth.In the wake of the recent global financial crisis, G20 leaders approved a comprehensive reform program that benefits international banking systems, including the strengthening of prudential requirements.In this sense, it is extremely important that banks are capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce the risk of systemic crises and avoid a repetition of the huge bailouts that were witnessed during the crisis.I argue for the need for adequate regulation for the banking sector in order to ensure fair competition and financial stability.I therefore vote in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to act, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- It is essential that banks are an efficient element of our economy and not an element of risk.Banks need to be well capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid the repetition of huge bailouts during the crisis.The Basel Commission's ongoing work should promote a level playing field at the global level, mitigating differences between jurisdictions and banking models and not unduly penalizing the EU banking model.Parliament's position with this resolution is to underline the need for greater transparency and accountability.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- I have supported this resolution of the Parliament's Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee on the international banking regulation process known as Basel III.With this resolution, we request that the financial position of the entities be improved but without significantly increasing capital requirements, and that the European banking model not be affected within the framework of international competition.In addition, the report supports the risk-based approach to calculating capital levels, but reducing variability.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- The Basel III package for financial sector regulation is a step backwards.It essentially stipulates that some financial institutions are too large to be forced to comply with the principles of fair competition or even responsible financial management, and that states actually commit themselves to rescuing them in the event of a threat of bankruptcy.Sadly, in many cases, the Commission has been the one to lobby for the weakening of the Basel III agreements.Together with my group colleagues, I am voting against and calling for more attention to be paid to the supervision of financial institutions.At least as a preventive measure against a possible new financial crisis.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The banking system wants to be resilient and with adequate levels of capitalization, these conditions being indispensable for the preservation of financial stability, the guarantee of the adequate concession of credits to the real economy throughout the cycle, the reinforcement of economic growth and the creation of job. The EU needs appropriate regulation for the banking sector in order to ensure fair competition and financial stability, as banks play a key role in financing the economy, being the main source of financing for households, businesses and citizens generally. EU legislation tried, early on, to reflect this aspect of banking activity. The work to finalize the Basel III framework aims at strengthening simplification, greater comparability and the convergence of the risk-weighted capital framework, underlining the need for greater transparency and accountability. This revision should promote a level playing field worldwide, mitigating the differences between the various jurisdictions and banking models, without prejudice to the European banking model. As I consider it important that this work can be carried out efficiently and reliably, in favor of the smooth functioning and applicability of banking legislation, I voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted against this resolution, in which Parliament blocks the revision of the Basel directive on the capital requirements of banks.Increasing capital requirements forces banks to save a larger sum of capital when making loans.This is a condition for reducing the instability and vulnerability of the financial system.However, the position of the banking lobbies and the Commission is that this would decrease the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis the US ones.I think that the high volatility of European banks and their disproportionate size is a very serious threat to European society and requires drastic intervention for financial institutions to fulfill their social function.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- This resolution aims to dilute the work of Basel III and limit the capital requirements for European banks, one of the most speculative in the world.The financial system has amply demonstrated its inability to regulate itself and the serious risk it poses to the stability of the economic system as a whole: that is why our proposal is based on public banking and the prohibition of speculative activity.Meanwhile, it is necessary to ensure that private banks comply with such elementary precautions as providing themselves with sufficient capital so that their shareholders assume the financial risks they incur, instead of transferring their speculative losses to the States.That is why I cannot accept the content of this report and I have voted against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (CVBV) has proposed stricter requirements on banking capital, as envisaged by the revision of the rules contained in the Basel III agreement.It is important that these measures allow banks to continue to play their key role as lenders to the European economy, without compromising, for example, their ability to lend.With the hope that the relevant bodies, such as the Commission and the European Central Bank, will provide Parliament with accurate and transparent updates and assessments on the ongoing work of the BCBS, I have decided to cast my vote in favor of the resolution.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it calls on the EU Commission to get involved in agreements that should be managed on a bilateral basis.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of the finalisation of Basel III. It is paramount that banks are an efficient component of our economy and not an element of risk. Banks need to be well capitalised in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid the repeat of the enormous bailouts witnessed during the crisis. This resolution has been made to state Parliament’s position on some key issues under discussion by the Basel Committee (BCBS) that will influence the legislation for the banking sector in the coming years.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution calling for the completion of the Basel III framework, because I believe that it is important for banks to be a functional part of the economy. They cannot be a risk to economies, and in order to prevent the gigantic bank failures that we observed during the crisis, the banks must be adequately capitalized to support the real economy. The work of the Basel Committee represents an effort to prepare the ground for reducing the differences between legal environments and banking models. Although the recommendations issued by the committee are not binding, they represent the standards of the banking sector for the central banks of the member countries. I also agree with the rapporteur's view that it is not possible to penalize the EU's banking model and that it is necessary to maintain the same rules for the same level of risk when regulating it. The resolution we have adopted today is a contribution to the Basel Committee's debate on future legislation in the banking sector. Our intention is to emphasize the need for greater transparency and accountability, which would increase the legitimacy of the Basel Committee. Its conclusions should be more closely linked to the work of the European institutions so that they can be better integrated into the reforms currently under way in the EU. The banking sector does not have a good reputation among the people, and it would therefore be good if more responsible rules of conduct could be introduced into its operation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - A sustainable and well-capitalized banking system and sound global standards and principles are key to maintaining financial stability and providing loans to the real economy. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision brings together central banks and supervisors of major banking institutions around the world, which set internationally agreed minimum standards for prudent banking and address the negative effects of the global economic and financial crisis still facing countries in the European Union and elsewhere. Worldwide. Parliament's report, however, sets out some good starting points for the future, such as preventing the negative consequences of an unreliable financial system for the real economy and depriving the right to use normal banking practices in cases where they have already failed, conferring powers on supervisors to require a precise calculation of the risk of traditional banking instruments, and Parliament's commitment to continue its efforts to prevent a new wave of bad bank resolution. However, as the recommendations of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision are not ambitious and too lenient, the promises of world leaders that taxpayers will no longer pay for irresponsible conduct of banks have not been fulfilled to date and there is a strong possibility that we will witness negative deregulation in the future. in this area, I did not support the report in the vote.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - The motion for a resolution by the grand coalition in the European Parliament is clearly positioned against an increase in capital requirements for European banks as a result of the upcoming Basel III reforms. I expressly believe that such an increase is indispensable for the stability of our financial system and as a lesson from the financial crisis, and I have therefore voted against the text. The current banking regulation is based on risk weighting of the capital requirements and thus stipulates that risks can be quantified in advance. It also completely ignores the enormous risks of the persistently low interest rate environment. As an argument against the Basel reforms, Parliament cites a disadvantage for European banks. In fact, American banks currently have to hold far more equity capital than their European competitors. I also do not share the argument that lending in the euro area will be jeopardized by an increase in equity. The greatest threat is a financial crisis and this can only be prevented if the necessary conclusions are finally drawn from the developments in the banking system of 2008 that were devastating for taxpayers.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The Basel III framework aims to increase the simplicity, comparability and convergence of the risk-weighted capital framework in order to address the excessive variability of risk-weighted assets and to apply the same rules to the same risks.The Commission should assess the feasibility of a future regulatory framework consisting of less complex, more appropriate and proportionate prudential rules that are specifically tailored to different types of banking models.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on completing Basel III. I consider all efforts to stabilize the banks to be fruitless. This is symptom treatment that does not touch the real roots of the problems that are also rooted in the monetary system. It is good to have higher capital requirements. However, this can hardly be achieved by means of improved supervision and it cannot be dependent on concerted cooperation within the framework of the G20 or the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision. All of these regulatory efforts miss the mark, lack clear liability regulations and replace them with politically driven, pseudo-objective supervision and regulation. A good regulatory framework does not need this international cooperation and its creation is at least delayed and probably prevented. If, moreover, the supervision - as in the context of the banking union the supervision by the SSM at the ECB - is “hijacked” by national interests, then it is all about objectivity. Just as the SSM is at the mercy of national interests, the Basel Committee also serves as a cover for the implementation of national industrial policy. It is not right if the very same loans that remain on the balance sheet of European banks are discriminated against in regulatory terms, while the same risks in the USA are taken from the banks by semi-governmental organizations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- I support the resolution on the finalization of Basel III.A resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for preserving financial stability and ensuring adequate lending to the economy.The existence of global standards and principles for the prudential regulation of banks is important especially in times of crisis.The efforts made by the BCBS to finalize the Basel III framework, which aims to increase the simplicity, comparability and convergence of the capital risk framework to address its excessive variability, need to be acknowledged.I welcome the initiative proposed by this report on a stronger role for the European Parliament in the overall process, and the call for dialogue and the exchange of best practices at European and international level.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the oral question on the completion of the Basel III framework.Banks, which have irresponsibly lent to companies, also contributed to the latest financial and economic crisis, the consequences of which many countries are still feeling today.I support good banking supervision and prudential requirements.The resolution rightly emphasizes that banks must be well-capitalized in order to support the real economy and reduce systemic risk, and so that the large-scale public funding that we witnessed during the crisis does not happen again.Fair competition and financial stability will be achieved through appropriate regulation of the non-bank lending sector.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- Obviously the main concern of the large groups of Parliament and the dominant economic circles of the Union was to "maintain the competitiveness of European banks" vis-.-Vis American counterparts.This is why banks are not forced to increase their capital adequacy and their speculation techniques are not addressed.We voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - A well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability, while it must support economic growth. In the context of tackling credit risk and business risk, huge sums have been spent on rescuing banks, sums that citizens of the Member States of the European Union are required to pay. Especially in the case of Greece, the rescue of banks, the return of huge dividends to shareholders and the recapitalization of financial institutions translated into the signing of memoranda.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the finalization of the Basel III agreement, as do I welcome the work of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) on consolidating global standards and principles for prudential banking regulation. I agree with the rapporteur that the rescue packages provided to banks during the crisis must not be repeated, so there is a need for sufficiently recapitalised banks that can support the real economy. I also support the call in the motion for greater transparency and accountability and an interinstitutional dialogue in order to increase the legitimacy and recognition of BCBS decisions. I also agree that one of the important points in the motion for a resolution points out that, unlike other jurisdictions, in the European economy, banks play a key role in financing households and businesses, especially SMEs. This must continue to be taken into account while seeking to diversify the forms of European economic financing.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ It is paramount that banks are an efficient component of our economy and not an element of risk. Banks need to be well capitalised in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid the repeat of the enormous bailouts witnessed during the crisis. The ongoing work of the Basel Committee should promote a level playing field at the global level by mitigating – rather than exacerbating – the differences between jurisdictions and banking models and not unduly penalising the EU banking model. A risk-based approach to regulation is key, with the same rules being applied to the same risk. I therefore support Parliament’s resolution that underlines key issues that could help to achieve greater transparency and accountability in enhancing the legitimacy and ownership of the Basel Committee (BCBS).

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.Parliament thereby reaffirms that banks must be properly capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid any repeat of the massive bailouts seen during the crisis.It stresses the need to develop appropriate regulation of the shadow banking sector in order to ensure fair competition as well as financial stability.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Basel III is a global, voluntary regulatory framework on bank capital adequacy, stress testing, and market liquidity risk. The motion for a resolution on the Basel III accord calls for a revision of the regulatory framework, to include, inter alia, a better promotion of a level playing field at the global level by mitigating the differences between jurisdictions, national banking competencies and models, which in turn would mitigate the likelihood of unduly penalising the EU banking model. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe in better coordination and harmonisation of banking standards; as in most other sectors, there can be more opportunities for growth and prosperity.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the motion for a Resolution submitted following oral question B8-001810 / 2016 pursuant to Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure on the finalization of Basel III (2016/2959 (RSP)).role in financing the European economy and is likely to remain the main source of funding for households and businesses, especially SMEs.The motion for a resolution also emphasizes that EU legislation has always sought to reflect this fact and should remain so.Recognizes the importance of diversifying the sources of financing of the European economy and welcomes in this regard the current work within the Capital Markets Union.The motion for a resolution also emphasizes the importancefor different banking models.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- This oral question of the ECON Committee is related to the end of Basel III.The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) is proposing to improve the prudential framework for banks dealing with credit risks, which would mark the beginning of Basel IV.For example, the proposal goes in the direction of revising standardized methods that calculate risk for the bank's weighted assets, without prejudice to international agreements agreed in Basel that oppose an increase in capital levies, while respecting the specificity of the Union banking sector.So I voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the completion of the Basel III framework, as a resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability and providing adequate loans to the real economy throughout its life cycle and contributing to economic growth.The Basel Committee is also developing standards for the sound and prudent operation of large international banks.It is discussing further changes to the credit rating framework for banks related to credit and operational risk, which is positive.These reforms focus on increasing risk sensitivity and the soundness of standardized credit risk approaches.Strict global standards are needed to regulate the prudent and safe operation of banks, which the Basel Committee is committed to.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against this resolution, in which Parliament blocks the revision of the Basel directive on the capital requirements of banks.Increasing capital requirements forces banks to save a larger sum of capital when making loans.This is a condition for reducing the instability and vulnerability of the financial system.However, the position of the banking lobbies and the Commission is that this would decrease the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis the US ones.I think that the high volatility of European banks and their disproportionate size is a very serious threat to European society and requires drastic intervention for financial institutions to fulfill their social function.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - The motion for a resolution by the grand coalition in the European Parliament clearly positions itself against an increase in capital requirements for European banks as a result of the upcoming Basel III reforms. I expressly believe that such an increase is indispensable for the stability of our financial system and as a lesson from the financial crisis, and I have therefore voted against the text. The current banking regulation is based on risk weighting of the capital requirements and thus stipulates that risks can be quantified in advance. It also completely ignores the enormous risks of the persistently low interest rate environment. As an argument against the Basel reforms, Parliament cites discrimination against European banks. In fact, American banks currently have to hold far more equity capital than their European competitors. I also do not share the argument that lending in the euro area will be jeopardized by an increase in equity. The greatest threat is a financial crisis and this can only be prevented if the necessary conclusions are finally drawn from the developments in the banking system of 2008 that were devastating for taxpayers.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - The Basel Committee is an international body which draws up prudential rules applicable to banking establishments in order to improve their solvency. These are recommendations, which must then be transposed by the competent institutions. The trend since the 2008 crisis has been one of tightening requirements, which has forced banks to increase their equity or reduce their commitments (lend less, more expensive, or to less risky projects or companies). Two concepts clash. The first favors the competitiveness of European banks against their competitors, particularly American ones. She therefore takes a dim view of the introduction of the new requirements. This is the position the report takes. The election of Donald Trump, who has announced that he wants to loosen the constraint on American banks, reinforces the timeliness of the threat. The second view is placed more on the side of the saver and systemic stability, considering that the soundness of banks must be further accentuated to protect depositors against the risks of resolution and to guarantee the soundness of the system. According to this approach, banks are only waiting for a loosening of regulations to resume their bad risky practices (securitization, derivatives, etc.). The political position that I take is to support the first option. So I voted in favor.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has proposed to improve the prudential framework for banks in terms of credit and operational risk ("Basel IV").The proposed measures include, inter alia, a revision of the standard method for calculating risk-weighted assets in a bank.The proposed changes significantly contribute to limiting the role of national audit institutions.This directly leads to a greater centralization of European power.That is why I voted against the resolution

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The proposal states that, inter alia, a sound framework for financial stability and growth should be comprehensive and balanced, so that it can include dynamic supervisory practices and not just focus on static regulation, mainly on quantitative aspects.With my vote in favor of the final vote, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against this resolution, in which Parliament blocks the revision of the Basel directive on the capital requirements of banks.Increasing capital requirements forces banks to save a larger sum of capital when making loans.This is a condition for reducing the instability and vulnerability of the financial system.However, the position of the banking lobbies and the Commission is that this would decrease the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis the US ones.I think that the high volatility of European banks and their disproportionate size is a very serious threat to European society and requires drastic intervention for financial institutions to fulfill their social role.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I call for dialogue and the exchange of best practices between regulators on the application of the principle of proportionality at EU and international level.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for a resolution further to Question for Oral Answer B8 001810/2016 pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure on the finalisation of Basel III. A resilient and well capitalised banking system is a prerequisite for preserving financial stability, providing appropriate lending to the real economy throughout the cycle and supporting economic growth. The G20 leaders agreed in the aftermath of the financial crisis to a comprehensive reform agenda strengthening the regulatory standards of international banks, including the strengthening of prudential requirements. The European Union implemented the internationally agreed standards in the framework of the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and Capital Requirements Directive (CRD IV). I voted against because I believe the approach, which assumes that every standard has to be applied in the same way, would not be efficient or proportionate.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- This text expresses the position of the European Parliament regarding the discussion of a reform of the prudential framework for banks that is currently being carried out by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS).This reform aims to make the standardized approach more risk-sensitive and, at the same time, restrict the use of internal models for certain portfolios, in addition to setting some tiers for the products of the rest based on the standardized approach.By means of my affirmative vote, I show support for the Basel negotiations, considering it essential that their adaptation to the European framework of financial regulation does not lead to substantial increases in the capital requirements of the entities, as well as that it does not affect the different entities asymmetrically.banking business models and help to design and maintain a stable regulatory framework and equal treatment for all entities.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - During the last plenary a motion was voted on the finalization of Basel III and on the future Basel 4 on capital requirements for banks. In the motion there are points that can be shared but also some important critical issues. For example, we believe that the appeal to use the internal method that allows banks to calculate capital requirements through internal models instead of the standardized method is unsustainable, given that the use of this method has generated distortions and paved the way for real and own abuses by the big banks. Furthermore, we do not support the introduction of a risk-based approach to government bonds, which would have the effect of discouraging investments in the bonds of countries deemed most at risk by the markets, thus damaging countries such as Italy. However, we share some principles highlighted very clearly in the motion, including the need for regulation not to further restrict banks' lending capacity to the real economy and the importance of ensuring equal conditions in the market between operators. For these reasons we preferred to abstain during the vote in the Chamber.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- This resolution aims to dilute the work of Basel III and limit the capital requirements for European banks, one of the most speculative in the world.The financial system has amply demonstrated its inability to regulate itself and the serious risk it poses to the stability of the economic system as a whole: that is why our proposal is based on public banking and the prohibition of speculative activity.Meanwhile, it is necessary to ensure that private banks comply with such elementary precautions as providing themselves with sufficient capital so that their shareholders assume the financial risks they incur, instead of transferring their speculative losses to the States.That is why I cannot accept the content of this report and I have voted against it.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because a resilient and adequately capitalized banking system is a prerequisite for maintaining financial stability, providing appropriate lending to the real economy throughout the cycle and promoting economic growth.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - Bank risk calculation models were the major cause of the financial crisis as they were regularly used to hide significant risks in banks' balance sheets. Based on this observation, the Basel framework adopted in 2007 guarantees a minimum level of equity capital in order to ensure the financial soundness of banks. The European financial sector points to so-called negative repercussions on its ability to finance the real economy if they were to strictly implement the new proposals of the Basel Committee. That speaks for itself. But the majority of political groups were above all concerned about the competitiveness of European banks vis-à-vis their American counterparts, and above all criticized the efforts of the Basel Committee for greater transparency. At best we can welcome the demand for the creation of a level playing field between small and large banks. This resolution is not going in the right direction. I voted against.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - After the neoconservative wave of the eighties and the neoliberal fury that deregulated the financial sector, it soon became apparent that private banking needed some rules under penalty of jeopardizing the entire system. The rules created from Basel I to III are intended to impose minimum levels of equity. However, the rules for their accounting become increasingly complex and opaque, as befits interest groups that always profit from the lack of transparency. Today, citizens learn that asset risk assessment models are the responsibility of so-called systemic banks, unlike others that are subject to a standardized model. That is, we have, as proved by a study by Standard & amp; Poor's, assets with different weightings from bank to bank. In other words, we have a system in which the solvency ratios and stress tests are completely handled by the major banks, thus removing any credibility from the entire supervisory system. For our part, the solution is simple. Credit is too important to be left to the private sector's free enterprise. Public control over banking and the financial system is now more than evidence, it is a necessity.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written. - The motion for a resolution urges the Commission to exercise more judgment in the implementation of the Basel III criteria and in the work of the BCBS (Basel Committee on Banking Supervision) and to address the specifics of the European banking system. Since the 2008 crisis, the requirements for banks have increased more and more. The last round of BCBS regulations on stability (TLAC, leverage ratio, capital requirements, RWA, capital adequacy requirements, LCR, NSFR) places demands on banks for which the European system is not designed - but which the USA and Asian banks strongly favor. So that the European banks can compete on an equal footing with the US banks and the European banking structure does not disappear completely in the medium term (and so that European financing only comes from non-European banks), the Commission, but also the EBA, should take better account of the special features of the European system take - and not take a one size fits all approach.
