For these reasons, I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the completion of Basel III.This resolution is to be considered balanced, as it should respect the principle of not significantly increasing global capital requirements, while at the same time strengthening the overall financial position of European banks.Banks represent a fundamental component for the effective functioning of our economy;they must be well capitalized in order to support the real economy, reduce systemic risk and avoid the bailouts that occurred during the crisis.The work that the Basle Committee is doing should be able to mitigate the differences between jurisdictions and European banking models.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ It was the reckless deregulation of the banking sector which led to the financial and economic crisis of 2008, a crisis we still suffer from today. I therefore welcome EU efforts to create more responsible prudential standards for the financial sector, in order to avoid such a crash happening again.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the completion of the Basel III framework.A resilient and well-capitalized banking system is a fundamental condition for maintaining financial stability and contributing to economic growth.As banks play a very important role in financing the European economy and are likely to remain the main source of funding for households and businesses, effective banking supervision is needed to complete the Basel III framework, which aims to increase clarity, comparability and a risk-based capital framework to address excessivefluctuations in risk-adjusted assets and apply the same rules for the same risks.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, EU Common Security and Defence is further evidence of the unrelenting push for the militarisation of Europe at all levels, from coordinated security and defence policy through to an EU army. At its core, the CSDP report militaristically demands more investment in defence and defence research for Member States to reach the NATO capacity target of a minimum of 2% of GDP. It demands more money from the EU general budget to be allocated to defence spending and demands a strong munitions and defence industry in Europe.  This report is symptomatic of the ever—growing militarisation of the European Union that is driven by the unelected Commissioners and larger Member States. The use of the result of the Brexit referendum to push ahead with these militaristic aims is utterly unscrupulous, as is the undermining of the neutrality of Member States such as Ireland. Instead of focusing on the militarisation of the EU, can we not redouble our efforts to tackle poverty, hunger, land rights, climate change, citizen participation and economic inequalities?

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, Europe has been and remains vulnerable to terrorist attacks, to the security issues we have and to other issues (the migration crisis and so on). We are living all this today and we see that the world is changing every day. And we remain vulnerable because Member States do not react in a coordinated way, some have different policies and different opinions, we do not exchange information - and these are law enforcement agencies - and because our databases, European databases, national databases they are not complete, they are not filled in with correct, immediate and complete data by the Member States and also some of them do not communicate with each other, so there is no interoperability between these databases. It is very difficult to fight terrorism or other dangers in these conditions. Secondly, we also have colleagues in the European institutions and in the European Parliament who simply do not believe that there is any measure to prevent terrorist attacks, for example, or to ensure the security of citizens. I mean, some take it as a fad or take it as an intrusion into privacy and that's it. They do not think about the security of the citizens and, I repeat, they do not take it seriously. We must resolve all these issues among ourselves, but, on the other hand, we must submit to public opinion. And, lastly, I apologize for being late, one thing: they are for the European armed forces, but by no means do they have to replace NATO. We must work with NATO and demand guarantees from the new President of the United States that NATO will continue to defend Europe and, in particular, Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, unfortunately nowadays the EU and its Member States live in a more dangerous and less predictable security environment. We are facing a broad and evolving set of challenges, both conventional and hybrid. Despite the fact that these challenges represent common risks and threats to the security of the EU, they affect us differently. Consequently the Member States react to them in an uncoordinated and fragmented way.  Therefore, I strongly believe that a substantial revision of the Common Security and Defence Policy will enable the EU to effectively cooperate and coordinate their efforts and capabilities in order to contribute in a decisive way to the security of the Union. Working from this perspective, a revised CSDP will not only assert the European Union’s strategic autonomy and strengthen its resilience, but will also further enhance political integration within the EU. This strategy should be based on a strong collective defence principle, efficient financing and should be implemented in coordination with international institutions in the field of security and defence, particularly in full complementarity with NATO.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, we kept being told a hundred times, a thousand times, during our campaign that no one is talking about a militarised EU. Yet, as we have just heard my comrade Lynn Boylan from the Communist Group say, the other Member States immediately responded to Brexit with precisely such a proposal for militarisation.  Well, good luck! I mean we are not going to be around, but we are still going to be allies, right? During our referendum campaign, a decision was made to deploy British troops to the defence of Poland and of Estonia, and it was not criticised on any side. Nobody tried to press it into the arguments about the referendum, because we understand that we still have a vested interest, an immediate interest, in the prosperity and security of our European friends. We want to be good neighbours, we want to be dependable partners, but our relationship from now on is going to be based on alliance, not assimilation.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, I am reminded of the famous ‘duck test’. If it looks like a duck, if it swims like a duck and it quacks like a duck, then it’s probably a duck. Commissioner Mogherini has told us that there are no plans for an EU army – soldiers fighting under the EU flag, yes, EU battle groups, yes, EU headquarters, yes – but no EU army. I suspect that this somewhat fails the duck test.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), as the Christian Democrats see a need for increased European cooperation on defense issues, including defense equipment coordination and research.The resolution rightly emphasizes the need for coordination with NATO.The emphasis on "strategic autonomy" is not a problem in this context, as there should be an opportunity for the EU to act when NATO neither can nor should do so.I continued to vote in favor of financing EU operations with funds from national budgets and against writings about the "EU Army".I voted in favor of writing a "permanent EU headquarters for civil and military missions and operations within the CSDP", as the text also emphasized that this would not be a copy of NATO structures, but would instead provide the necessary basis for planning and command capabilities for missions andefforts within the CSDP.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The following report highlights how the security situation in Europe has reached a level considered critical, especially after the latest terrorist attacks by ISIS.In this regard, the rapporteur proposes to invest more resources in defenses, such as allocating 2% of GDP, intensifying relations with NATO, creating a European military headquarters for missions and other measures in this direction.Although some fairly interesting issues are dealt with, there is completely no assessment of the negative impact that the above could have on some Member States, which is why I voted negatively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - This AFET report is based on the Annual Report of the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for an increase in the military component in the CSDP, greater investment in defense research and advocates for allocating 2% of the GDP for defense spending. The report further calls for a Union White Paper on Security and Defense, and calls for a strong defense industry. In addition, it supports further reforms to the security sector and also train and equip the military financed with development aid (including the civil instrument that contributes to stability and peace), promotes the expansion of the Athena mechanism to finance all missions Union military and tactical groups, escaping parliamentary control and pressuring the deployment of Union tactical groups for all types of crisis management. We reject the military funding of the Union budget, and prioritize the civilian approach to conflict resolution and stop contributing to the military escalation, and we advocate a total separation between the Union and NATO, while the report proposes a greater cooperation. For this, I voted against.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this report as it goes against our position on the CSDP, it supports the militarisation of the EU including calling for the reform of EU law to be reformed to allow European defence industries to benefit from state aid as their counterparts in the US do. It wishes to expand the military aspect of the Common Security and Defence Policy including investment in defence research and other capabilities whilst fostering a closer relationship with NATO. In this regard it is regressive and does not suit Ireland’s position of neutrality regarding military alliances.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.I support a common security and defense policy and fully support the steps towards a substantial autonomous defense capacity of the EU aimed at protecting our citizens and promoting our values and interests in full respect of the Treaties,international law and human rights.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy. We must acknowledge that the security situation in Europe has deteriorated significantly. It has become more complex, more dangerous, and more difficult to predict. Traditional and hybrid threats are posed by state and non-state actors, come from the South and the East, and have different effects on Member States. The security of EU Member States is highly interlinked, but they respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated and inconsistent manner. Lack of coordination is one of the weaknesses of the Union's action, which is being successfully exploited by aggressors. Europe also lacks resilience to effectively counter hybrid threats. I agree with the rapporteur that, for these reasons, the CSDP needs to be thoroughly and fundamentally overhauled in order to enable the EU and its Member States to make a decisive contribution to the Union's security, international crisis management and demonstrate the EU's strategic autonomy. It is clear that no country can deal with the current security challenges on its own. It is therefore necessary to ensure that the CSDP is based on a strong principle of collective defense and effective funding and is implemented in coordination with international institutions in the field of security and defense, with full complementarity with NATO. The EU should encourage Member States to adhere to NATO's capability level, which requires at least 2% of defense spending. GDP, as reaffirmed at the summits in Wales and Warsaw.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy (according to the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common security and defense policy) because I believe that the development of its common security and defense policy areaThe EU is an important step in protecting its citizens, as well as its values and interests, always with full respect for international law and human rights.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - With this resolution, Parliament is responding to the Council's annual report on the state of the common security and defense policy (CSDP), in particular on the implementation of the CSDP in the individual Member States. Against the background of the increasingly deteriorating security environment in the EU (annexation of Crimea, war in Syria), Parliament is in favor of a number of measures that are intended to strengthen joint action by the member states in the area of ​​the CSDP. These measures include, among other things, the fundamental revision of the CSDP, the establishment of a permanent EU headquarters for planning civil and military operations, and support for research in the field of CSDP. The report also highlights the importance of cooperation with NATO for the EU. I support the report because I believe that closer cooperation between Member States is necessary in the area of ​​CSDP, as no country can tackle the challenges of the globalized world on its own.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This report aims to ensure the EU's grip on the foreign and defense policies of the Member States.It assumes that the EU is threatened both by violent border changes by Russia and the destabilization of states in the Middle East.The report details the many concessions that are expected from states for the CFSP to become a reliable partner of NATO.It also defines how the Commission should impose its rules in the area of defense procurement.I voted against this unacceptable report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- The security environment in Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent months.This unpredictability and complexity oblige us to make more effective use of the current instruments of the common security and defense policy.It must be subject to a vast and profound revision in order to respond to these new challenges.For these reasons, I voted in favor of this text.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ These past years have sadly marked a shift in Europe’s security environment. We face tensions from Russian aggression, terrorist threats in our own region, and the uncertainty left after the UK referendum and the US elections. All of these issues call upon us to work together in one of the most vital cornerstones of any society – its safety and security. Which is why this time provides us the best window of opportunity to implement the Common Security and Defence Policy that would in no way compete with a similar transnational structure – NATO – but on the contrary, would complement and strengthen its current agenda. This policy is not one of militarising Europe, but rather increasing its readiness and capabilities for its defence. A large part of the report focuses on the sheer capabilities that the EU currently lacks in the defence sector, which is why it also calls for investments in defence research in order to catch up with the quickly advancing technologies all around the world. Only through these strategies will we be able to independently ensure the safety and security of our citizens in these turbulent times.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: written.- The VVD has abstained from the final vote of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy, because the setting up of a European military headquarters is not appropriate at the moment.NATO is and remains the cornerstone of European security policy and NATO efforts should not be duplicated.The VVD supports the proposal for a unified defense market, more defense investments, including in the field of research and development.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy.Europe's security environment has deteriorated significantly and has become less stable, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.Europe currently lacks resilience to effectively counter hybrid threats, which are often cross-border in nature.I therefore agree with the need to review the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) in order to enable the EU and its Member States to make a decisive contribution to the Union's security, to international crisis management and to demonstrate the EU's strategic independence.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are opposed to the development of a centralised EU defence and foreign policy capability. As such we reject the annual review process of CSDP and CFSP and the calls for increased EU capability contained within this report. We remain fully committed to NATO as the primary guarantor of security in Europe. We are supportive of the NATO 2% defence spending minimum. It is UKIP party policy to ensure the UK remains at least above 2% and we would also encourage fellow NATO allies to meet this commitment. We are however uneasy at language contained within this report in which the EU calls on Member States to meet this requirement. There is a fine line between this and the 2% commitment to NATO being replaced with one to the EU. This risks further undermining NATO and risks the position of traditionally neutral countries.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I voted against this report, which assumes that the European Union is threatened both in the south and in the east.The report asks Member States for many concessions and details how the Commission should impose its rules in the area of defense procurement, undermining our sovereignty.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which underlines that the security environment in Europe has deteriorated significantly and that to cope with it, the Union must adopt a revised and more robust common policy based on apermanent structured cooperation.Likewise, this policy should be based on a strong principle of collective defense and effective funding, as well as on the active participation of all Member States.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The great changes that have occurred in recent years in the global scenario make it increasingly necessary to reflect on Europe's ability to face the enormous challenges of our time, adversities that arise not only in conventional forms but increasingly as hybrid threats that they see state and non-state actors involved. The Paşcu report, which I supported with my vote today, strongly underlines the need for a substantial revision of the CSDP in order to allow the EU and its Member States to contribute decisively to international crisis management and affirmation of the strategic autonomy of the Union. We need a White Paper on European defense and security that identifies the way to a strengthening of the continent's defense industry and at the same time foreshadows the lines of action in international scenarios. However, the heart of the new CSDP must lie in the creation of a true autonomous defense capability for the EU that aims to protect its citizens and promote its values ​​and interests, in full compliance with treaties, international law and human rights.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - This Report indicates the deterioration of European security due to the growth of the terrorist threat and the war situation in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, as well as new challenges such as cyberterrorism. It points to a growing restlessness of public opinion in the face of terrorism and political instability, and exposes the need to reinforce the common security and defense policy with greater coordination and a budget growth of at least 2% per member country. It also requests greater facilities to finance international operations and the urgent creation of an economic fund for this purpose. It calls for the strengthening of military research and the European arms sector with sufficient funding, and aid for industrial production similar to that received by North American companies in the sector. I voted against it, because it delves into the political and financial commitment to a strong Army and arms industry in the Union to combat external threats. Although I understand that some of these threats are real, I believe that increasing the climate of war is not going to achieve a real resolution of the problems and to achieve a framework of stability and peace in the Union.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I supported this report by Mr Pascu on the implementation of the common security and defense policy.It is necessary to advance in a European army, but I have abstained in the references to allocate 2% of the GDP of the States for this.I believe that a more thorough analysis is needed before establishing any concrete figures, however much this was reiterated at the Welsh and Warsaw Summits.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- This report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy must in fact ensure the EU's grip on the foreign and defense policies of the Member States.Indeed, the report starts from the principle that the EU is threatened in the east and in the south by both the violent border modifications operated by Russia (point 7) and the destabilization of the States of the Middle East.States must make concessions for the CFSP to become a reliable partner of NATO and it defines its rules in the field of defense procurement (paragraph 44).For these reasons, therefore, I naturally voted against.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I do not agree with what is said in this report, so I did not intend to vote in favor of him.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy, which carries out an assessment of the implementation of policies in this area, as well as of the events that have taken place this year.The report calls for a review of these policies, as well as a Union White Paper, a stronger defense industry and the European Defense Action Plan.On the other hand, it considers it necessary to improve and expand cooperation with NATO.Likewise, greater intra-community coordination is requested within the Union, in order to better adapt to new threats.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it speaks for the implementation of the common security and defense policy in the European Union. Europe's security environment has deteriorated significantly and has become less stable, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable, threats are traditional and hybrid, posed by state and non-state actors, come from the South and the East and have different effects on Member States. Parliament recalled that the security of EU Member States was closely interlinked and noted that, for the time being, they were responding to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated and inconsistent manner, thus complicating and hindering a more common approach. This lack of coordination is one of the weaknesses of the Union's action. Europe lacks resilience to effectively counter hybrid threats, which are often cross-border in nature. Terrorism against Europe by radical Islamist organizations and individuals is on an unprecedented scale and is putting pressure on the European way of life. Parliament emphasized that this had made personal security a priority and that the traditional distinction between external and internal aspects of such security was disappearing. It therefore calls on the EU to adapt to these security challenges, in particular by making more effective use of existing CSDP instruments and combining them with other external and internal instruments, and by calling for greater cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of EU action. To address these problems, a thorough and substantial review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capacity targets, which will require defense spending to increase to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. Finally, CSDP missions, including cross-border assistance, capacity building, military training missions and naval operations, contribute to international peace and stability. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agree that a common security and defense policy should be implemented at EU level.The European security environment is noted to have deteriorated significantly, becoming more uncertain, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.Threats are both conventional and hybrid.They are created by both state and non-state actors from the south and east, and affect each Member State differently.It should therefore be noted that the security of the EU Member States is strongly intertwined.However, Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated and fragmented way, which makes it difficult and often hinders the implementation of a more uniform approach.Therefore, calls for a decisive prevention policy based on comprehensive deradicalisation programs are appropriate.The establishment of permanent structural cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the EU Treaty) will enable the development of self-defense or a permanent defense structure that would improve crisis management operations.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - The current situation of deteriorating security inside and outside the European territory has well demonstrated that the Union must equip itself with the tools to defend the peace and security of its citizens. This report is in line with the commitment of the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, in hoping for a full review of security and defense policies to address the structural changes in the international context. We call for the establishment of effective mechanisms that fully exploit the potential already present in the European treaties, such as permanent structured cooperation. The invitation addressed to the Member States, which retain their defense prerogatives, is that of better cooperation, which involves a solid principle of collective defense and efficient financing to promote the strategic autonomy of the European Union. This means strengthening its capabilities and placing itself on the international scene as a reliable partner, capable of cooperating in full complementarity with the international institutions active in the sector, primarily NATO, to meet the security needs of the European Union and those of the its neighborhood.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on the Implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy because I think the Union should use its foreign policy tools more efficiently by bearing in mind that the European security environment has deteriorated considerably. Indeed, more and better coordination between Member States is needed in order to tackle the current challenges. As a matter of fact, this resolution provided the base for further developments of the EU foreign policy tools towards a revised and more robust CSDP.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - No country can face the security challenges alone: ​​today more than ever a united action is needed to ensure the defense of European borders and internal security. It is necessary to radically review the framework of the common security policy adopted so far, strengthen it and start acting in a perspective of federal integration of intelligence services, the armed forces and border control structures as is being done positively for the new Coast Guard. of European Union. Together with the necessary political and legal decisions to be taken, the development of a stronger defense industry cannot be left behind in order to strengthen the Union's strategic autonomy and technological independence. Strengthening the EU's status as a guarantor of security in Europe's neighborhood requires appropriate and sufficient capabilities, as well as an internationally competitive, efficient and transparent defense industry that ensures a sustainable supply chain. Today the European defense sector is characterized by fragmentation and duplication, which must be phased out through a process that provides incentives and rewards to all national actors and takes into account the long-term prospects of an integrated defense market.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report uses the deteriorating political climate in Europe, especially with Russia, as well as the Islamist threat as a pretext to ensure the European Union's grip on the foreign and defense policies of the member states.The common security and defense policy, of which this report defines the outlines, would be modeled on NATO's action plans, with the consequence of submitting our foreign policy to American interests.In addition to the many concessions expected from Member States, there are new public procurement rules.I was obviously opposed to this report which locks our nations in an Atlanticist straitjacket when, on the contrary, we wish to maintain balanced relations with all the international powers with the aim of bringing about the emergence of a multipolar world.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - Europe is facing an arc of instability. In the south, ISIS and other terrorist organizations are on the rise in the Middle East and North Africa. In the east, Russia's hybrid war against Ukraine, the illegal annexation of Crimea and hybrid tactics, including cyber terrorism and information warfare, used to destabilize the Eastern Partnership countries are the most urgent threats to EU security. I support the EP's resolution on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (based on the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy). CSDP instruments should remain a key tool in the global approach. The intensity of the hybrid threats we face is unprecedented. The future common strategic framework should focus on concrete and achievable proposals to help counter hybrid threats and promote the resilience of the EU and the Member States. The common strategic framework should be developed in full coordination and in regular consultation with NATO, which will develop its own response to the hybrid war. A unique opportunity to harmonize the EU's responses with those of NATO should not be missed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report which provides for a necessary and thorough review of the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP). Citizens need to perceive and feel a greater commitment from the European Union on this issue. Terrorist propaganda must be vigorously combated through more efficient CSDP operations. A more unified foreign policy would contribute significantly to lessening the fighting in Iraq and Syria. The report stresses the need for strong support from Member States with the essential collaboration of national parliaments, in order to ensure the speedy realization of the priorities of the European foreign and security policy (EUGS). Sharing the same strategic interests with NATO represents a great opportunity for the Union, but we need to work for stronger and closer cooperation also with other institutional partners such as the OSCE, as well as with strategic bilateral partners.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are opposed to the development of a centralised EU defence and foreign policy capability. As such we reject the annual review process of CSDP and CFSP and the calls for increased EU capability contained within this report. We remain fully committed to NATO as the primary guarantor of security in Europe. We are supportive of the NATO 2% defence spending minimum. It is UKIP party policy to ensure the UK remains at least above 2% and we would also encourage fellow NATO allies to meet this commitment. We are however uneasy at language contained within this report in which the EU calls on Member States to meet this requirement. There is a fine line between this and the 2% commitment to NATO being replaced with one to the EU. This risks further undermining NATO and risks the position of traditionally neutral countries

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The annual report on the common security and defense policy presents several passages which I believe are problematic.These include the request to member states to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, as foreseen in the NATO meetings in Wales and Warsaw;a strengthened partnership with NATO;the creation of a European civil / military headquarters for CSDP missions and operations;the request to the EU to support the member states participating in the coalition against ISIS by creating an ad hoc CSDP mission;the request to modify the instrument for peace and stability to allow the EU to equip military actors in partner countries;the review of funding mechanisms for European battalions and military operations.Being concerned by some of the above proposals, I voted no.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: in writing. - I voted against the own-initiative report on the implementation of the European Union's Common Security and Defense Policy, because it is in line with those voices in Europe that call for more militarization and repression. I disagree with the report on the increase in Member States' military spending in order to achieve the goals set by the NATO imperialist alliance. I disagree with the European Union military mechanisms, ATHENA and EU Battlegroups, which are European mechanisms for repressing and enforcing policies that have the potential to intervene in an independent country. We are fighting for a Europe of peace and solidarity. For a Europe that will be a factor of stability in the wider region and not a factor of destabilization, economic imperialism and military intervention.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: in writing.- In respect of the Danish defense reservation, we have voted against the initiative report on a European Defense Union.For the Social Democrats, NATO is, and will remain, both Denmark's and the EU's primary and most important security guarantor.That is why it is also crucial for us that the measures towards increased defense cooperation that other EU countries may wish to participate in are fully compatible with NATO cooperation and its structures.We do not support the idea of an EU army, but would of course like to see the possibility of better coordinating the procurement of materiel, as well as other practical measures that can lead to lower costs across countries and that are not subject to the defense reservation.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We vote in favor of the report and point out that the European security environment has deteriorated significantly, becoming more fluid, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - The report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy is an attempt to intensify the European Union's security mechanisms. Although we are going through a period of turmoil and we must step up our efforts to safeguard the security of European citizens, this report focuses on conservative practices and objectives, without ensuring democratic and sound control processes, while promoting closer cooperation with NATO, events that find opposites. That is why I decided to vote against the report.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - There is no day when the media do not force our eyes to observe the slaughters carried out by ISIS, or to communicate to us in an apocalyptic way an unstable and complex international situation, as well as dangerous and unpredictable. Ours is undoubtedly a fortunate generation because, thanks also to the European Union, it has not experienced the atrocities of war closely, so that this condition can remain and be extended to vote in favor of the report. In an EU that is highly interconnected, the reaction to threats, in fact, remains uncoordinated and fragmented, thus preventing efficiency and resolutive readiness. In order to manage critical cases and give the EU strategic autonomy, the involvement of Member States ab initio is essential for multiple reasons ranging from avoiding future impasses to the practical benefits of pooling European defense capabilities. Permanent structured cooperation is hoped for together with the drafting of a White Paper on defense. Furthermore, the hypothesis of a permanent Union headquarters for missions, civilian and military operations should not be overlooked, since the current conditions are fraught with structural weaknesses. Moreover, it is evident that the European defense sector is characterized by fragmentation and duplication, these elements weaken strategic autonomy and technological independence.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy due to Ireland’s position on neutrality.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Union faces a set of threats, both conventional and hybrid, created by states and non-state subjects from the south and east. This complex framework requires an operational and effective Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP). This fact is recognized by two thirds of European citizens, who advocate a greater European commitment to security and defense (Eurobarometer). To this end, I advocate a review of the CSDP that establishes Permanent Structured Cooperation, as provided for in the treaties. I believe that the reinforcement of defense investment (ideally for 2% of GDP) should be complemented with better defense procurement processes, in addition to understanding greater support for research. We need a more capable and competitive defense industry. I follow the desire to establish a permanent EU headquarters for civil and military operations, but I warn of the need to coordinate action with NATO, as a pillar of European collective defense. In this regard, the EU-NATO relationship must be strengthened and include cooperation with other partners, such as the African Union or the OSCE. I share the concern about cybersecurity, as the most urgent vector for greater cooperation in defense. For these reasons, I support this report.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The security of the EU Member States is deeply interconnected, and like the rapporteur I agree that we still reply to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated and fragmented way. In turn this complicates matters and often hampers a more common approach exposing vulnerabilities of the Union’s action. Like everyone I am concerned that terrorism carried out by radical Islamist organisations and individuals is targeting Europe on an unprecedented scale, bringing the European way of life under pressure. Such requires a proper response from our end through coherence with other external and internal instruments. This can only be achieved through better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the field of counter-terrorism. In this sense, I see scope in this report which calls upon the European Council to start developing the common security and defence policy into a common defence as provided for in Article 42(2) TEU to strengthening the EU’s resilience.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: written.- I voted in favor of the own-initiative report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (CSDP).The focus was on how to strengthen the common ability, which is extremely important today.It is about our ability to work effectively together to protect us from warfare as well as to lead military peacekeeping operations.On the other hand, I have voted against the EU having a common military defense or the EU investing in a military defense.Cooperation within the EU is necessary to secure our environment and Sweden, but issues relating to funding and military units are issues that are to be decided by the Member States themselves.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing.- This report is linked to that on the creation of a European Defense Union.Therefore, it too supports a military-type strengthening at European level to respond to ISIS terrorist attacks in the first place.The report talks about investing 2% of each Member State's GDP in defense, then a strengthened partnership with NATO, and advances the possibility of the European Union to equip military actors in partner countries.Also in this case, therefore, my vote is negative and against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - This AFET report is based on the Annual Report of the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for an increase in the military component in the CSDP, greater investment in defense research and advocates for allocating 2% of the GDP for defense spending. The report further calls for a Union White Paper on Security and Defense, and calls for a strong defense industry. In addition, it supports further reforms to the security sector and also train and equip the military financed with development aid (including the civil instrument that contributes to stability and peace), promotes the expansion of the Athena mechanism to finance all missions Union military and tactical groups, escaping parliamentary control and pressuring the deployment of Union tactical groups for all types of crisis management. We reject the military funding of the Union budget, and prioritize the civilian approach to conflict resolution and stop contributing to the military escalation, and we advocate a total separation between the Union and NATO, while the report proposes a greater cooperation. For this, I voted against.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The EU faces a series of regional crises and challenges that are increasingly interconnected and complicated, not least that of Islamist terrorism. European security is in jeopardy due to uncoordinated and fragmented action between Member States. I believe that the EU should be able to intervene at 360 degrees in crisis management, from prevention to resolution of the same, not only through dialogue and cooperation with third countries from the region, but above all with greater cooperation and interoperability between Member States . Therefore, I voted in favor of this resolution which supports the full involvement of the Member States in the process of reviewing the common security and defense policy. The EU should encourage member states to achieve NATO targets, which require a minimum level of defense spending of 2% of GDP, in order to enhance the complementarity of capabilities between the EU and NATO in terms of collective defense and of efficient financing. EU engagement should follow a roadmap defined in the form of a Security and Defense Implementation Plan and White Paper, in line with the priorities identified in the overall strategy.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - The European security environment has deteriorated considerably, becoming more and more changeable, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable. Member States are highly dependent on each other for security, and they react in an uncoordinated and fragmented manner to common threats and dangers, complicating and often preventing a common approach. The European Union is obliged to respond to increasingly complex crises, must step up dialogue and cooperation with third countries in the region and must be prepared to deal with structural changes in the international security landscape. I voted in favor of integrating cybersecurity and defense as basic elements of the common security and defense policy, given that conflicts and crises in and around Europe take place in both physical and cyberspace. Legislative reform is needed to enable defense industries to benefit from the same state aid as US industries.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, more dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. A thorough and substantial review of the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) is needed to address these issues. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation would make it possible to set up self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. It emphasizes that the CSDP must be based on the principle of strong collective defense and effective funding, and that the CSDP must be implemented in full coherence and complementarity with international institutions responsible for security and defense, such as NATO. He believes that the EU should encourage Member States to meet NATO's capacity targets, which requires that defense spending be increased to at least 2% of GDP, as confirmed at the Welsh and Warsaw summits. I am convinced that an effective CSDP requires a serious commitment and an increased and more efficient exchange of intelligence and other information between Member States, better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. As the report points to just that, I voted in favor.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy as the report suggests too far-reaching interference by the EU in the affairs of the Member States.Underlining the great importance of activities aimed at improving security in the European Union, one should strive to build a strategy that will take into account the interests and sovereignty of states in this area.According to the report, the EU should respond to the challenges to the internal security of the Member States.It must be made clear that defense issues should forever remain a matter of national sovereignty.I believe that the report presented must not seek to interfere with the competences of the Member States, and I therefore abstained from voting.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The developments in the field of CSDP were positive. However, in recent years the security situation in and around Europe has created unprecedented  challenges that need to be tackled by all European Member States, as no single country or organisation is able to face them alone. Whilst I agree that we need to move to a substantial autonomous defence capacity aiming at protecting citizens and the cores on which the European Union is based, it is important that such a move should respect the neutrality of countries like Malta.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This European Parliament resolution follows on from the Council's 2015 annual report on the common foreign and security policy (CFSP), in particular the implementation of the common security and defense policy (CSDP).In a context where the European security environment is deteriorating considerably and where one can fear a withdrawal of the United States from NATO, I consider that the European Union and its Member States must take the full measure of their responsibility., by continuing and strengthening ongoing cooperation in the field of defense.For these reasons, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text on the implementation of the common security and defense policy which rightly underlines the importance of increased coordination between the Member States in the field of defense while the climate security is an ongoing concern. When it comes to defense, the European Union must be ambitious, and this requires the development of our defense industry, as well as adequate funding. When our security is at stake, Europe cannot afford to depend on technological knowledge from third countries. In addition, the text calls in particular for the establishment of elaborate de-radicalization programs and solid radicalization prevention policies in the face of threats raised by terrorist organizations. These are two fights that I myself brought to the European Parliament in my report on the prevention of radicalization and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organizations.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of EU action. To address these problems, a thorough and substantial review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capability targets, which will require that defense spending be increased to at least 2% of GDP over time. Finally, CSDP missions, including cross-border assistance, capacity building, military training missions and naval operations, contribute to international peace and stability. In line with the Hungarian position, I voted in favor of the report

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I voted against the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy, as I believe that calling for wider EU competences in the field of security and defense is unacceptable. Today, two lines are clearly emerging in Europe, that of the Federalists and that of the Anti-Federalists. I am one of the latter, because I believe that Europe will be stronger if we return to the idea of ​​a 'Europe of nations'. I believe that security is an exclusive competence of the Member States and must remain so. Security and defense are the last sign of the sovereignty of the Member States, and I will continue to uphold these views.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- The report as a whole is against the interests of EU countries. It serves the policy of the US and NATO.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated manner and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of EU action. To address these problems, a thorough review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capacity targets, which will require an increase in defense spending to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. Finally, CSDP missions, including cross-border assistance, capacity building, military training missions and naval operations, contribute to international peace and stability. In line with the Hungarian position, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on the Implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy as I am opposed to the militarisation of the European Union. I believe the EU could play an invaluable role on the world stage in conflict prevention. I am engaged in the campaign to establish a Peace Institute in Wales which will help promote peace in our society and in our everyday lives. The EU should have its own Peace Institute to help develop a policy that would bring people real security.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: the report details the many concessions that are expected from States for the CFSP to become a reliable partner of NATO.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - (PT) This report essentially pursues the same objectives as the report on the so-called European Defense Union, approved at this same session. Increasing Member States' defense budgets, funding and development of military industry and research, creation of European military forces, specialization of military forces by Member State, greater cooperation with NATO and the EU's ambition to become a military bloc . All in the name of combating terrorism, radicalization, and strengthening the confrontation and encirclement of Russia, obliterating any analysis of the EU's responsibilities in military conflicts in neighboring regions. The report is part of the militaristic escalation underway in the EU, and actively promoted by it, with the European Parliament doing its part. An attitude that fuels the arms race, not forgetting the nuclear one, which increases world tensions, contradicting commitments made with the non-proliferation and disarmament treaty, and which increases the risks of a major military conflict with unforeseen consequences. A policy that opposes and compromises Peace, and that does not disconnect from the policies of exploitation and impoverishment of workers and peoples. The EU reveals its true face as an enemy of peace. Of course, we could only vote against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because Ireland is neutral country and should stay as one.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Europe is constantly facing new challenges in terms of its stability, to which we must learn to respond in an appropriate way. The security of the Member States of the European Union is interconnected. However, they often respond in isolation to emerging threats, which complicates joint action. The importance of the European Union in terms of its foreign policy relevance is not increasing, despite its economic strength and the declared common security and defense policy. The continuing threat of terrorism, but also possible attacks in cyberspace, for example, puts the standard European way of life under pressure. There is a need to show joint initiative and better coordination in the field of defense and protection of our citizens. Otherwise, we will only face a further increase in populism and radicalization. This also applies to investment in research and development in the case of defense technologies. Despite rising tensions in several Member States, they are naively declining. We need to eliminate fragmentation and duplication in the European defense sector.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report as it is too unrealistic and biased.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy.I do not agree with many of the amendments on the European Union 's position on security and defense, and for this reason I cannot support the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the call for an EU White Book on Security and Defence and a stronger defence industry, and I welcome the European Defence Action Plan. I believe it is time to reform the Athena mechanism for financing the missions and operations of the EU. I think it is the right moment for us to push for a bolder approach to EU defence, towards a full military alliance. The European Union and NATO must divide their tasks to avoid duplication of efforts. We must reach a common position and encourage steps towards a substantial autonomous defence capacity for the EU, aiming at protecting its citizens and promoting its values and interests, with full respect for the Treaties, international law and human rights.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour because security is a priority for European citizens. No country can face the current security challenges on its own. First, because the changing European neighbourhood and complex crises have showed that internal and external security are becoming more and more intertwined. Therefore the EU should be empowered to act along the entire spectrum of internal and external instruments.  Secondly, because over the last years, CSDP cooperation, such as border assistance, capacity building and training in the (broader) EU neighbourhood has proven its benefit. We should strengthen existing CSDP tools and use them more efficiently. I encourage further cooperation and coordination between Member States, also in the framework of the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, with the commitment, ownership and support of Member States and national parliaments. I therefore welcome the roadmap on CSDP that VP/HR Mogherini will present, with a concrete timetable and actions.  Finally, I welcome all references to increased dialogue and enhanced cooperation on security and defence with international institutions and third countries. Without duplicating NATO structures, we should strengthen the partnership, in full complementarity. Cooperation, be it between EU Member States or with partner countries and institutions, will entail practical and financial benefits.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report considering that the European security environment has deteriorated considerably and has become more dangerous and less predictable. We must not forget that the security of the Member States of the Union is closely interconnected and that we must react in a coordinated way to common threats and risks. Lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of the Union's action, and it lacks the necessary resilience to effectively tackle threats that often have a cross-border dimension. Similarly, the Union must prepare to face structural changes in the international security landscape and challenges such as conflicts between States, the collapse of States and cyber attacks, as well as terrorism and the consequences of climate change in terms of security. For all this, we must make more effective use of existing CSDP instruments and use them in a coherent way with other external and internal instruments.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution tabled by the European Parliament on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (based on the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy), because I firmly believe that it is a revision of the CSDP is needed to make a substantial contribution to the security policies of the EU Member States. I believe that these actions play an indispensable role in the prevention and management and resolution of international crises and represent a basis on which to build a common action plan for the defense of European citizens. With my choice in the classroom, I encourage all European institutions to launch a policy aimed at collaborating with the Member States in order to manage, in full autonomy, the control and defense of the territories as a whole. I argue that no country can stand up to modern security threats alone and that is why I am extremely convinced of the usefulness of collaboration between all the forces in question. I am sure that, through a substantial change to the CSDP, we can fully participate in maintaining security in Europe in full compliance with recognized treaties and human rights.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on "Implementing the Common Security and Defense Policy" because I consider the issue to be one of the key challenges facing the EU at the moment.It is important here to dare new ways of powerful, efficient cooperation within the framework of NATO.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The European Union should be able to react appropriately to any conceivable threat situation at any time.This requires the establishment of permanent structures.This includes, among other things, a European headquarters for the common security and defense policy and the further promotion of the establishment of EU battlegroups.Furthermore, a future common security and defense policy should be in close cooperation with NATO and other organizations.In addition to expanding strategic cooperation, it is also important to strengthen the defense industry in the European Union.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. I am opposed to the development of a centralised EU defence and foreign policy capability. As such I reject the annual review process of CSDP and CFSP and the calls for increased EU capability contained within this report. I remain fully committed to NATO as the primary guarantor of security in Europe. I am supportive of the NATO 2% defence spending minimum. It is UKIP party policy to ensure the UK remains at least above 2% and we would also encourage fellow NATO allies to meet this commitment. I am however uneasy at language contained within this report in which the EU calls on Member States to meet this requirement. There is a fine line between this and the 2% commitment to NATO being replaced with one to the EU. This risks further undermining NATO and risks the position of traditionally neutral countries.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - The report calls for the strengthening of the European cooperation component of the CSDP, in close collaboration and shared objectives with NATO, to better define in this phase of uncertainty about the future of the Union if, as Europeans, we believe that greater autonomy and capacity is needed action in this area in the coming years. Foreign and defense policy are different but closely related: I voted in favor of this report also because I believe that a step forward in dialogue and interdependence on defense and security can increase mutual trust and continue the steps already taken in building of an effective foreign projection of the European Union. It is the complexity of today's security and defense-related problems that demands this of us. A multidisciplinary approach is needed, as I said now, but it is not enough. On the one hand, the size and type of challenges to be faced will, if not already done, exceed the capacity of each individual nation to manage them independently. On the other hand, the complexity, the cost of the operational capabilities and technologies required far exceed the possibilities of each individual State to intervene effectively in the internal and international scenarios, making cooperation an essential necessity for the future of the common defense and security policy. .

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: in writing.- In the same spirit as the report by Urmas Paet on the European Defense Union, this report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy bears the same criticisms, with the added bonus of stigmatizingRussia.This report also urges states to make concessions in order to strengthen the partnership with NATO, and asks the Commission to define precise rules on procurement in the defense sector.It is a text which completely excludes the idea of sovereignty and, for these reasons, I opposed it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - This Report indicates the deterioration of European security due to the growth of the terrorist threat and the war situation in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, as well as new challenges such as cyberterrorism. It points to a growing unease of public opinion in the face of terrorism and political instability, and exposes the need to reinforce the common security and defense policy with greater coordination and a budget growth of at least 2% per member country. It also requests greater facilities to finance international operations and the urgent creation of an economic fund for this purpose. It calls for the reinforcement of military research and the European arms sector with sufficient funding and aid for industrial production similar to that received by North American companies in the sector. I voted against, because it delves into the political and financial commitment to a strong Army and arms industry in the Union to combat external threats. Although I understand that some of these threats are real, I believe that increasing the warlike climate will not be able to achieve a real resolution of the problems and to achieve a framework of stability and peace in the Union.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. Overall, I support the report. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO. Nevertheless, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written. - We Swedish Social Democrats think that it is important for the EU to adapt to security policy developments by using the existing tools for the EU's common defense and security policy (CSDP) more effectively. We welcome the fact that the report examines various possibilities for streamlining Member States' cooperation within the framework of the CSDP. We are also in principle in favor of the new proposal to strengthen the opportunities for the EU to support partner countries in terms of capacity building in support of security and development (CBSD). However, we would like to emphasize the importance of the OECD's criteria for official development assistance (ODA) being respected in decisions on how military operations are to be financed by the EU aid budget. That is why we chose to abstain in the vote on the two amendments on paragraph 29, which want to reject or reject the proposal altogether. Furthermore, we do not support the report's consistent calls for the CSDP to develop towards a common defense, as we believe that defense policy should remain a national competence. We also believe that it is important that CSDP measures continue to be used only to preserve peace and prevent conflicts outside the Union, in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, and not to develop into an internal defense. As the text explicitly calls for this, we chose not to vote in favor of the report.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and unpredictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid in nature. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the most serious vulnerabilities in EU action. To address these problems, a thorough and substantial review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capacity targets, which will require defense spending to increase to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. Finally, CSDP missions, including cross-border assistance, capacity building, military training missions and naval operations, contribute to international peace and stability.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - The report calls for an increase in the military component of the CSDP, more investment in defense and defense research. We oppose the report because it supports deep cooperation with NATO, calls for a strong defense industry and welcomes the European Action Plan, which benefits the European Union's defense and security industries. We call for radical (including chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear) disarmament at European Union and global level, no military funding from the European Union budget, strict separation of the European Union from NATO and a civilian European Union. A European Union that promotes peace and problem-solving through dialogue and not through the use of weapons.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. I believe there were many positive elements to the report and I do agree with the assertion that the EU faces new threats which are hybrid and often cross borders. As well as that, I do agree that the European security environment has deteriorated considerably over the past few years and has become more fluid and more complex. Nevertheless, I felt that the report went too far in terms of harmonising security and defence policy at EU level. For example, I am not in favour of requiring Member States to allocate 2% of their GDP towards defence spending. Again, I believe this should be a decision taken at Member State level. However, I was in favour of some aspects: for example, I supported the call for strong preventive policies based on comprehensive deradicalisation programmes to be used against all forms of extremism.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- This own-initiative report by the Social Democratic MP Paşcu calls for a strengthening of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), taking into account the current crises and in particular the annexation of Crimea.A new headquarters of the CSDP is to be built for operations, including border controls, military training and maritime operations.According to the FCR, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully exploited within the framework of a European superstate.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Iris HOFFMANN
text: written. - In principle, I support the call for better coordination in the common security and defense policy, especially for reasons of cost and because of the resulting synergy effects. As much as I can understand the deepening of the CSDP as a long-term strategic goal, I would like to accompany this process critically. Overall, the entire project is still too vague. However, I consider the approach for the report to be fundamentally wrong because there is no concrete structural or substantive basis. Before we agree to such an ambitious project, the Member States must first be prepared to make these funds available additionally. In addition, I expect the European Council to submit a content-based security and defense strategy to Parliament at the same time. This then requires a broad parliamentary debate on the goals of such a project and its implementation. I therefore reject the report.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: written.- I voted in favor of the own-initiative report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (CSDP).The focus was on how to strengthen the common ability, which is extremely important today.It is about our ability to work effectively together to protect us from warfare as well as to lead military peacekeeping operations.On the other hand, I have voted against the EU having a common military defense or the EU investing in a military defense.Cooperation within the EU is necessary to secure our environment and Sweden, but issues relating to funding and military units are issues that are to be decided by the Member States themselves.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times. It has become more complex, more dangerous, and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of EU action. To address these problems, a thorough review of the Common Security and Defense Policy is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation would make it possible to set up self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capability targets, which will require that defense spending be increased to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. Finally, CSDP missions, including cross-border assistance, capacity building, military training missions and naval operations, contribute to international peace and stability. In line with the Hungarian position, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the CSDP should have a strong cooperation with NATO. However, the EU must have an autonomous defence capacity. As such, I fully support this project.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy (based on the Council's annual report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy to the European Parliament) (2016/2067 (INI)), given the complex European security environment that has become much more dangerous and less predictable and the need for stronger coherence and coordinated action against threats and dangers faced by Member States. The report points to the significantly deteriorating security situation in Europe and how the Common European Defense and Security Policy is far below the needs and expectations of the public. Consistent implementation of the objectives of the Common Security and Defense Policy as set out in the EU Treaty is needed. It is necessary to strengthen the defense capability and the strategic and technological autonomy of the Union in this regard. I also support the opening of a permanent EU General Staff for CSDP civilian and military missions and operations, from which an integrated operational headquarters would provide support.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The intention of the European Union to secure control over the foreign and defense policies of the Member States strikes me as too tangible.Likewise, I do not intend to support any strengthening of the power of the Commission, for example in the area of defense procurement.I voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing.- The current security environment is characterized by lower predictability and, conversely, higher interconnectedness of other sectoral areas associated with it.The dynamics of security threats is so rapid that it is necessary to respond more flexibly to current events.To do this, the common security and defense policy needs to have the appropriate resources and tools.I supported this report because I agree with its vision of permanent and structured cooperation between Member States and an integrated approach to crises.I would also like to emphasize the importance of deeper cooperation in the field of cyber protection.Cyber attacks can take on devastating proportions, and it is therefore essential to prepare together as best as possible for this form of criminal activity.

name: Marc JOULAUD
