text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Ioan Mircea Pascu on the implementation of the common security and defense policy.The current situation calls for the Union to play a more important role in crisis management and to assert its autonomy.This affirmation involves the establishment of a permanent European headquarters and the definition of a global strategy for the common foreign and security policy led by the High Representative.The lack of coordination between EU Member States is a threat to our common security.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which seeks to revise the common security and defense policy so that the EU is able to intervene across the entire spectrum of crisis management, encompassing all stages of the process.conflict cycle, and that we adapt to new security and defense challenges.All this requires measures that are recommended in this report such as, among others, a solid principle of collective defense, effective funding (2% of GDP), the integration of cybersecurity into the spectrum of the CSDP, etc.I am particularly pleased that the last paragraph of this report recommends reforming European law to allow European defense industries to benefit from the same state aid as that enjoyed by American industries.This is an amendment that I brought.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ Over the last years we have been facing a number of challenges. The crises in multiple areas of the world, terrorism, radicalisation, are only some of the problems that Europe needs to address. Dr Pascu’s approach is moving in the right direction. A thorough and substantial revision of the CSDP is needed in order to enable the EU and its Member States to contribute in a decisive way to the security of the Union, to the management of international crises and to asserting the EU’s strategic autonomy, recalling that no country can face the current security challenges on its own.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting against the present resolution on the revision of the common security and defense policy.The way the future procedure is described in it, it reads out a much tougher and more one-sided policy towards Russia and it also requires a far closer bond with NATO at all levels.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - The common security and defense policy has been a major topic of discussion within the Community since the 1950s. The top six countries gradually expanded to include other advanced industrialized countries, with each of these countries producing "their" weapons, whether small arms or others. The original concept, ie the Western European Union, was to bring about the convergence of standards and possible cooperation between arms manufacturers. Especially after France withdrew from the NATO military component and moved its headquarters to Brussels, the project had a real contour. After de Gaulle's retirement, a significant coughing overseas was enough, or a raised eyebrow at NATO's top chief, and new weapons were purchased from the United States, especially in the renewal of the fleet and other modern systems. Nevertheless, from time to time, there is an effort to refresh the original concept and support the EU military-industrial complex. Perhaps the only area where this has succeeded and where the EU is competing successfully is the Airbus consortium, but this is mainly for civilian use. There are only two successful multilateral implementations left, both in aeronautics, Eurofighter Typhoon and Gripen. For reasons of principle, we therefore demand that the common security and defense policy be implemented in principle in accordance with the UN Charter and international law. It is essential to strictly separate the EU and NATO. Weapons of mass destruction of all kinds must be banned and destroyed worldwide.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- This own-initiative report by the Social Democratic MP Paşcu calls for a strengthening of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), taking into account the current crises and in particular the annexation of Crimea.A new headquarters of the CSDP is to be built for operations, including border controls, military training and maritime operations.According to the FCR, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully exploited within the framework of a European superstate.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I could not support the report because its rapporteur believes that the basis for close and effective cooperation between the EU and NATO is the complementarity and compatibility of their missions and therefore of their inventories. In addition, the report supports the Commission's defense initiatives, such as the Defense Action Plan and the Defense Industry Policy, which should be pursued following the presentation of the EU White Paper on Security and Defense, and supports the Commission's further involvement in defense through well-targeted research, planning and implementation, welcomes the preparatory action for CSDP research and calls for adequate funding for the remainder of the current MFF, and supports the development of an EU defense research agenda in the next MFF (2021-2027). I do not believe that the EU should invest in the arms industry to meet the arms lobby. So it has finally arrived and will reach for European subsidy money. Everyone who wants the peaceful development of our continent and the planet is logically afraid of this development, because the militarization of Europe has always led to a war conflict, and not to averting it, so why should it be different today.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of EU action. To address these problems, a thorough and substantial review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capability targets, which will require that defense spending be increased to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. In line with the Hungarian position, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since we have always advocated not only civilian power Europe but also an independent and sovereign Europe. In contrast to our vision, the present report is full of controversies since, while developing the idea of an autonomous European defence policy, it advocates deepening our ties with NATO even further at the same time.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I supported the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy, because I believe that the security of European citizens is of paramount importance to the EU. Today, more than ever, the EU needs an adequate defense and security policy to protect its borders, to be able to prevent crises and to pursue an active policy against hybrid warfare. I believe that the EU and the Member States need to invest more in their own defense. It is extremely important to build a common defense capacity and more investments in the general purchase of defense equipment, common scientific activity in the defense sector, general training of servicemen and building a common intelligence and counterintelligence activity. I support the idea that the EU should have its own strategic defense that complements NATO's capacity, not duplicates it. NATO is a strategic partner of the EU with which it has close cooperation, but in today's conditions of migration and crises, the EU needs its own defense alliance with which to maintain security and peace in Europe.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) is one of the most important parts of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), as it contains an obligation between all Member States to intervene jointly in case of need. Member States are increasingly experiencing a state of insecurity, and are reacting in an uncoordinated and fragmented manner. Therefore a substantial revision of this policy will allow the EU to coordinate its efforts to contribute to the security of its citizens. Unfortunately, Europe is increasingly vulnerable in the face of the crises and attacks to which it has been subjected in recent months, and continues today to be a possible target, despite the prevention and intelligence efforts made by the Member States, which however do not act in coordinated manner. Therefore, concrete solutions must be found, and I believe that voting in favor of the report can help in this, in order to strongly support the idea of ​​a momentum of a truly political Europe, starting from a common policy of security and defense.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report entitled "Implementation of the common security and defense policy".In parallel with the Paët report adopted yesterday, the aim is to ensure the European Union's grip on the foreign and defense policies of the Member States.This report threatens the sovereignty of the Member States by not allowing them to use their tools and their military industries freely.Defense must remain a prerogative of States.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- This report seeks to ascertain the grip of the European Union on the foreign and defense policies of the Member States.It assumes that the EU is threatened on its eastern flank by violent Russian border changes, and on its southern flank by the destabilization of states in the Middle East.In addition, detailed here are the many concessions that the EU expects from states in order for the CSDP to become a reliable partner of NATO.Finally, the report defines the way in which the Commission should impose its rules in the field of defense procurement.Faced with so many challenges to the sovereignty of States, which is more in a sovereign domain as important as that of security and defense, our group has shown firm opposition.So I voted against it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report because it makes an assessment of the implementation of the CSDP and the developments in this area in the last year. The report calls for a substantive review of the CSDP, the drafting of a Union White Paper on Security and Defense, a stronger defense industry and the European Defense Action Plan. It also promotes the reform of the Athena mechanism to finance the missions and operations of the Union. It also advocates cooperation with NATO. Faced with more severe conflicts, of longer duration and with diverse actors, it is emphasized that although the Union's security is interconnected, the response continues to be fragmented and uncoordinated, making it vulnerable. It is emphasized that the lack of resilience of the Union prevents it from responding better to transnational attacks. In this sense, the Union is asked for more intra-community coordination, as well as with third countries; adapt to new threats applying all the tools of the CSDP and other available instruments; as well as to carry out a more preventive policy. The report seeks to increase the military component in the CSDP, plus investment in defense research.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - This AFET report is based on the Annual Report of the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for an increase in the military component in the CSDP, greater investment in defense research and advocates for allocating 2% of the GDP for defense spending. The report further calls for a Union White Paper on Security and Defense, and calls for a strong defense industry. In addition, it supports further reforms to the security sector and also train and equip the military financed with development aid (including the civil instrument that contributes to stability and peace), promotes the expansion of the Athena mechanism to finance all missions Union military and tactical groups, escaping parliamentary control and pressuring the deployment of Union tactical groups for all types of crisis management. We reject the military financing of the Union budget, and prioritize the civilian approach to conflict resolution and stop contributing to the military escalation, and we advocate a total separation between the Union and NATO, while the report proposes a greater cooperation. For this, I voted against.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - In a context in which the European security environment has deteriorated considerably and in which threats have diversified and increased, it is necessary to adapt to these security challenges and, in the face of the terrorist threat, prevent through de-radicalization programs. The common security and defense policy must be thoroughly reviewed, which must take into account cybersecurity and cyberdefense as key elements. Likewise, it highlights the importance of the establishment of a permanent headquarters of the Union in which the missions and operations of the CSDP are planned and executed, being compatible with the rest of the international institutions. I vote in favor because no country is capable of facing the current security challenges alone and because it is essential to play a more active role in the threat of radicalization and terrorism, which will be possible through the promotion of the European defense policy.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- This own-initiative report by the Social Democratic MP Paşcu calls for a strengthening of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), taking into account the current crises and in particular the annexation of Crimea.A new headquarters of the CSDP is to be built for operations, including border controls, military training and maritime operations.According to the FCR, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully exploited within the framework of a European superstate.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The European security environment is significantly disrupted, and the threats are conventional and hybrid in nature, coming from the south and the east, and affecting Member States differently.The EU needs to adapt to these security challenges, in particular through the more effective use of existing CSDP instruments in line with other external and internal instruments and better cooperation between Member States, especially in the field of counter-terrorism.The report notes the importance of more actively combating radicalization and terrorist propaganda and promoting judicial co-operation among criminal justice systems, including Eurojust.In the fight against radicalization and terrorism, close cooperation between the institutions of the Union and the Member States, but also with all other world organizations, is important, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ European countries have to decide whether European countries need to create common army or not. The Lisbon Treaty creates the possibility to take some steps in this direction. I support steps to eliminate duplication, overcapacity in defence and security and barriers to defence procurement. But I am against imposing an obligation on Member States to spend 2% of GDP for defence.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The threat of military and terrorist attacks is now taking on new dimensions.The use of biological and chemical weapons can endanger generations.That is why EU security requires a strong common security and defense policy, based on the principles of prevention, unity, non-aggression and cooperation between the Member States of the Union, as well as cooperation with other defense systems.However, the development of such a policy must not be in the interests of narrow groups, but must be transparent and credible for the people of the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (according to the annual report from the Council to the European Parliament on the common security and defense policy), for the reasons I have given in detail in my speech to the European Parliament.in Strasbourg on 22 November 2016, as well as because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a vote in favour of the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The report needs great support in order to reduce the incoordination that is fragmenting the EU and preventing it from effectively tackling hybrid threats. It is important to prioritise securing a stable and safe European environment for citizens, especially after the rise of radical Islamic organisations targeting Europe ‘on an unprecedented scale.’ In addition, there is a need to reiterate that maximum cooperation and communication among Member States is crucial in these times of countering terrorism. Finally, yet importantly, the report stands out as it calls for a more unified and effective European Foreign and Security Policy that shows signs of contributing to the reduction of armed clashes.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- This report is based on the Council's Annual Report on Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), which requires an increase in the EU's military component and increased investment in defense research, promotes a strong anddefends NATO's target of 2% of GDP for defense spending.This Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) could not be more wrong with regard to the principles on which it is based.The militarization of the EU, military financing through the Union budget, embracing the measures proposed by NATO, are inconceivable and unacceptable ideas.I voted against.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The CSDP outlined here plans closer ties to NATO at all levels and, at the same time, a much tougher and more one-sided policy towards Russia.I refuse.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament report.Given the difficult geopolitical situation, we must make every effort to ensure our security and to strengthen cooperation and mutual understanding between European Member States in the field of CSDP.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This assessment report on the implementation of European security and defense policy is timely. The European foreign affairs official is expected to announce in December her action plan towards the creation of a European army. It allows you to put a layer behind the report voted on the day before. It includes the need for military operations to complement NATO, the creation of a defense budget, especially research, specific to the EU and other dangerous escalations, disconnected from popular sovereignty. The height of cynicism: this so-called "pooling" is demanded in the name of "budget constraints" that they have set for themselves. Neoliberal logic is therefore creeping in everywhere. Worse, they are asking for a common defense market because "protectionism and the closed nature of European defense markets are an obstacle". And if a sovereign state objects, it is threatened with infringement proceedings with financial penalties. Dismantle the French defense under the leadership of the Eurocrats. Shame. I vote against this attack on the sovereign right to protect our geostrategic interests and our industry.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report assumes that the EU is threatened by Russian-led operations and the destabilization of the Middle East.The report details the many concessions that are expected from states for the CFSP to become a reliable partner of NATO.It also defines how the Commission should impose its rules in the field of defense procurement.I therefore opposed this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- The security of EU Member States is highly interlinked but they react to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated and fragmented way, thus making a common approach more difficult or often impossible to apply.This lack of coordination is one of the weaknesses of the Union's action. Europe does not have the resilience to effectively address hybrid threats, which often have a cross-border dimension.A more unified and therefore more effective European foreign and security policy can make a decisive contribution to reducing the intensity of armed clashes across the world.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of this report because this policy is essential to strengthen Europe’s security and defence mechanisms.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - The European security situation has deteriorated significantly in recent years. Not only is the European Union the target of terrorist acts, but there are also ongoing tensions at the external borders and long-lasting hotbeds of violence in Africa and elsewhere in the world that threaten international peace and stability. According to the results of the June 2016 Eurobarometer, two out of three Europeans demand that the European Union make greater efforts in security and defense. Rightly so, because today individual Member States are reacting in an uncoordinated and fragmented way to risks that threaten us all and no country alone is able to counteract these crisis situations. In addition, we must also be aware that we cannot continue to rely on others for our safety. So it is time for a radical change. Member States must join forces. If we want a credible, decisive European foreign policy, then, as stated in this report, we urgently need to work on joint operations and missions, joint investment in defense, a joint defense capability and a European operational headquarters. In time, all of this should result in a European troop strength that guarantees international peace and security.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - The security environment in Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent times as a result of conflicts in its neighborhood. Although the security of the Member States of the Union is interconnected, they respond to common threats in an uncoordinated way and on their own, which makes it impossible to take a common approach to crisis management, which also weakens the position of the Union itself. A more coherent, and therefore more effective, European foreign and security policy could be beneficial in resolving the conflict in Syria and Iraq. However, this will not be possible without a thorough review of the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), which should consist of several steps. Permanent cooperation structures need to be set up to enable the Union to intervene in various crises and at any stage of the conflict, based on the principle of strong collective defense and effective financing. The CSDP should be conducted in coordination with international security and defense institutions and be fully complementary to NATO. Member States should meet NATO's capacity commitments and targets, which require a minimum level of defense spending of 2% of GDP. I support a stronger Europe in the field of defense.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The report makes an assessment of the implementation of the CSDP and of the developments in this field in the last year. In the current global geopolitical situation with increase of security threats in Europe and in our neighbouring countries such as human trafficking, arms trafficking, terrorism attacks and wars, I support the idea of progressing in the direction of a European Defence Union and EU actions for the creation of good governance structures, the respect for rule of law and human rights, and preventing and combating radicalisation. I agree that the CSDP has a key role to play in conflict prevention as well as in post-conflict capacity and peace building in ensuring a global stable environment. CSDP missions and operations can be an integral part of preventive engagement and crisis response mechanisms, especially if activated in a timely and effective manner. Having said that, however, I also disagree with a number of paragraphs in the report, such as putting binding commitments on Member States on how much they need to spend from their GDP to sustain the increase of the defence industry and on substantially financing a European Defence Research programme from the EU budget. Therefore, I abstained on the final report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The draft resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs notes that the European security environment has deteriorated significantly, outlines the new security challenges facing the Union and calls on the EU to adapt to these security challenges, in particular by addressing other security challenges. make more effective use of CSDP instruments in line with external and internal instruments, and call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. As no single country can face the current security challenges, it calls for a thorough and substantial review of the Common Security and Defense Policy so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the Union's security, manage international crises and assume the EU's strategic autonomy . It urges close cooperation with NATO and the EU to encourage its member states to meet NATO's capability targets, which will require an increase in defense spending to at least 2% of GDP. It calls for the deepening of European defense cooperation and the establishment of a permanent EU headquarters for civilian and military CSDP missions and operations. I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- This report is based on the principle that the EU is threatened in the east and in the south by both violent border changes made by Russia and the destabilization of states in the Middle East.The report details the multiple concessions that are expected from States for the CFSP to become a reliable partner of NATO (points 15, 21, 23, 33 to 37, 40).It also defines how the Commission should impose its rules in the area of defense procurement.Unfavorable vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- Defense policy is a prerogative reserved for States, it is out of the question to accept that it be ceded to an illegitimate supranational body.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I support the report. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizens’ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity. We therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I support initiatives to strengthen Europe's security policy, as we face an increasing number of challenges that require strong and strong action.However, we also need to pay attention to what is going on around us.After the US presidential election, we need to realize that the European Union's role in NATO is far from enough.I think we need to consider every option before we take the next step.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Due to developments in the last years, the security in the European Union has deteriorated thus becoming a more complex and dangerous and less predictable issue. I have voted for this report. I have voted for this report that will enable a revision of the CSDP in order to enable the EU and its Member States to better contribute to the security of the Union.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy because Member States should coordinate their security and defense investments and improve their financial support for EU defense research.Strong commitment, accession and support from Member States and national parliaments, in close cooperation with all relevant EU bodies, is needed to ensure the swift and effective implementation of the Union's Global Foreign and Security Policy Strategy.European.A future EU defense research program should fund research projects in priority areas agreed by Member States.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because it recalls that Member States are highly dependent on each other in terms of security and raises the alarm that they react in an uncoordinated and fragmented manner to common threats and dangers.The report also notes that Europe lacks the necessary strength to respond effectively to hybrid threats, which are often cross-border in nature.Another factor that led me to vote on this report is that the report highlights the negative impact of the military occupation on the security of Europe as a whole and reiterates the idea that any change in Ukraine's borders deviates from the principles of the UN Charter and the Final Act.Helsinki.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: In written form. - Given the highly changed international environment, the EU needs a new approach and a new security strategy. The report emphasizes that Europe no longer has full control over its security environment and calls on the EU to adapt to the new challenges by using existing CSDP instruments more effectively. The report calls for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. The report also fully supports the further strengthening of security and defense cooperation with other institutional partners such as the UN.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- The revised common security and defense policy aims at a much tougher, more one-sided policy towards Russia and very close ties to NATO at all levels, which is why I spoke out against this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- This report seeks to define the future orientations of the military strategy of the European Union.It promotes increased spending on defense, military research and security policy.This increase could, according to the report, be supported by a reorientation of funds relating to development aid, a peaceful instrument aimed at establishing peace and stability.I have chosen to vote, in principle, against this text, because a true European defense policy calls first for a major debate within all the Member States.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Transnational cooperation, greater defense cooperation at EU level and closer cooperation with NATO are essential to improving the security situation in Europe.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I believe that the military component of the common security and defense policy should not be increased and developed. Today's overriding goal for European states is not only to strengthen their own armed forces, but also to pursue a much broader political and diplomatic dialogue. Only a more united and therefore more effective European foreign and security policy can make a decisive contribution to reducing the intensity of the armed clashes in Iraq and Syria and to combating the 'Islamic State'. In addition, preventive policies based on comprehensive deradicalisation programs need to be stepped up, and the distribution of extremist content on the Internet needs to be tackled more effectively, and greater judicial cooperation between criminal justice systems needs to be encouraged. EU funding for the defense sector and defense research must not be allowed. I do not support the proposal to deploy EU battlegroups for any crisis management tasks. I believe that new arms races or new military formations are by no means an escape from ever-increasing tensions. They can only become catalysts of higher voltages. Unable to address social problems properly, because additional funds will be needed for new military needs, we can see an outbreak of those problems in the most disgusting forms.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - Implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy provides greater support to Member States fighting Islamic State. I voted in favor of the report which calls on the Council to set up an emergency funding fund for the initial phase of military operations and calls on the EU to coherently support member states in the coalition against the so-called Islamic State, by creating Joint Security and Defense Policy in Iraq focusing on education. Security has become a major problem for EU citizens. We call for a full and substantive review of the Common Security and Defense Policy, which can no longer be simply a means of crisis management outside the Union, because it must ensure a genuine European common security and defense policy, bridging internal and external security, but also becoming an EU tool for managing international crises at all stages of the conflict cycle. The effective implementation of recent decisions on the development of the CFSP is vital for the protection of citizens and the promotion of EU values ​​and interests, in full respect of the Treaties, international law and human rights.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that the citizens of the European Union must be guaranteed the best level of security and this can only be done with an effective revision of the CSDP.This improvement will have to develop with cooperation between Member States and with NATO.But at the same time, I believe that a civil and peaceful approach to conflict resolution must be adopted, as we must always act in compliance with human rights.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The European security environment is deteriorating considerably, and the EU need to find ways to react to an arc of increasingly complex crises in its neighbourhoods. I strongly believe the EU needs to do that in a coherent and coordinated manner, pursuing a common approach, and in collaboration with NATO and other partners. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this report because I believe that it has well identified the advantages and disadvantages of the European Union's action so far in the field of security and defense. The fact is that the European Union is a spatially large community, with a population of almost 510 million, and that in its neighborhood and external borders there is an unstable environment that threatens the stability of the entire continent. It is important for the European Union to establish coordinated action in the areas of security services, defense capabilities, information exchange and practical action on the ground with the aim of self-protection and protection of allies outside the European Union. This is the task of nation states and national security intelligence forces, but exposed to numerous non-traditional security challenges, we must become aware that coordination and joint action is the only and exclusive way to achieve the goal, which is peace and an environment that allows prosperity and development for all. Building a future European security institutional and resource community must follow a path in which Member States agree on all key points, challenges, strengths, areas of cooperation and common interest. Strengthening institutional ties is a precondition for the consistent implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy and the European Union's Common Defense and Security Policy.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This report seriously undermines the independence of France in matters of defense policy, industrial armament policy and diplomacy, since it is a question of subjecting everything to European requirements which are in reality those of France.'NATO.I am therefore obviously voting against.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The international context is characterized by increasing instability and complexity. Europe is faced with threats that are increasingly difficult to predict, coming from different geographical areas and from both state and non-state actors, which no Member State is able to tackle on its own. A substantial and thorough review of the common security and defense policy is therefore indispensable in order to provide the European Union with an effective capacity to intervene. I therefore share the request to draw up a White Paper on security and defense, which indicates to the Council the most suitable strategy for achieving a genuine common policy, which meets the expectations of Parliament and citizens. I commend the commitment shown by High Representative Federica Mogherini in implementing the European Defense Action Plan and I hope that Parliament and all the other institutions will continue to support her efforts in this regard. A more united and stronger Europe would also strengthen the role of NATO, with which it shares the same strategic interests, and would be able to take complementary action in areas such as peacekeeping and conflict prevention. The criticisms of those who see contradictions between CSDP and NATO are therefore completely out of place.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - No country can face the current security challenges alone. Our security environment has been compromised and has become more fluid and less predictable. The threats are conventional and hybrid in nature, caused by state and non-state actors, coming from the south and from the east. The lack of coherence is one of the weaknesses of the Union's action. The EU should be prepared to face structural changes in the international security environment - challenges such as the collapse of states and cyber attacks, as well as the security implications of climate change. It is essential for the EU to adapt to these security challenges, in particular by using existing CSDP instruments more effectively. The CSDP needs to be revised to allow the EU and its Member States to make a crucial contribution to the security of the Union, to resolving international crises and to reaffirming the EU's strategic autonomy. The CSDP must be even faster and more effective. We Europeans must be ready to respond to crises immediately, while fully respecting the UN Charter, international treaties and human rights. The EU should step up dialogue and cooperation with third countries in the region and with regional and sub-regional organizations. We have become aware of the fact that we must collectively and responsibly take on a greater role in the world. Our partners expect the EU to play an important role, especially in ensuring global security. Better cooperation and coherence between Member States is imperative.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - (PT) This report essentially pursues the same objectives as the European Defense Union report, adopted at this same session. Increase in Member States' defense budgets, financing and development of military industry and research, creation of European military forces, specialization of military forces by Member State, greater cooperation with NATO and the ambition to become a military bloc. All in the name of combating terrorism, radicalization, and reinforcing the confrontation and encirclement of Russia, obliterating any analysis of the EU's responsibilities in military conflicts in neighboring regions. A policy of blood and death, war and destruction, promoted by the majority of the European Parliament. A policy that fuels the arms race, not forgetting nuclear, that increases global tensions, contradicting commitments made with the non-proliferation and disarmament treaty, and that increases the risks of a major military conflict with unforeseen consequences. A policy that opposes and compromises Peace, and that does not disconnect from the policies of exploitation and impoverishment of workers and peoples. Of course, we could only vote against it.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- I have decided to support this report, which calls for a thorough review of the common security and defense policy, stressing the need to strengthen the partnership with NATO and transatlantic relations in general.I consider close cooperation with NATO to be essential for the protection of citizens and the promotion of the EU's values and interests, of course in full respect of the Treaties, international law and human rights.The report calls for an EU White Paper on Security and Defense, which I consider to be very desirable.The report also calls for a stronger defense industry and supports the reform of the ATHENA mechanism for financing EU operations and missions.I believe that a thorough review of the CSDP is necessary, Europe must be prepared and actionable, it must be a relevant player on the international stage.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- The development of a stronger defense industry would certainly strengthen the strategic autonomy and technological independence of the Union.In this sense, I believe it is right to underline the need to further deepen cooperation in the field of cyber-defense and ensure the full cyber-resilience of CSDP missions.The threats present in the European context are both conventional and hybrid in nature, attributable to both state and non-state actors.The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked.That said, the lack of effective coordination is one of the weaknesses of the Union's external action.I voted in favor of approving this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- The report calls for the EU to respond to NATO's "internal security challenges, including upheavals not covered by Article 5".While the report contains many calls for cooperation with NATO, it also calls for strategic autonomy for the EU.I hereby abstained from voting.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot in good conscience vote for the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy. This is not only because I am a pacifist by principle and cannot condone the use of violence under any circumstances. In addition, I truly believe that there are more efficient and constructive methods for implementing peace and security in our European neighbourhood.  In fact, it is my firm conviction that the current militarisation of our policies and the ‘machoisation’ of our politics and public discourse only worsens an already very unstable geopolitical situation. We in Europe would most probably find ourselves, literally speaking, in the line of fire, should a major conflict break out involving Russia. We ought to tread very lightly now that the fundamentals of our security structure is in shatters.  The military escalation between Russia and NATO on the former’s borders is a historically well-known recipe for disaster. Instead of directing our scarce resources towards military defence and cooperation with NATO, Europe should focus on de-escalation, diplomacy and dialogue, and empowering democrats in the European neighbourhood with whom we can forge new alliances for peace and true stability.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- As a follow-up to the report on the European Defense Union, which I supported, I spoke in favor of this report proposing to revise and strengthen the common security and defense policy.This will allow the European Union to intervene in all crisis management, including their prevention and resolution, giving priority to engagements in conflicts having direct consequences for the security of the EU.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated considerably, becoming more fluid, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable. The threats that currently haunt the European Union are both conventional and hybrid, created either by States or by non-state actors, these come from the south and east and affect Member States differently. The multiplicity of humanitarian crises that today are felt on the periphery of the Union, namely in West Africa, passing through the Sahel, the Horn of Africa, the Middle East and the East of Ukraine to the Caucasus, need a European reaction in security and defense. The Union must therefore intensify dialogue and cooperation with third countries in the region, as well as with regional and sub-regional organizations. At the same time, acts of terrorism carried out by radical organizations and individuals target Europe on an unprecedented scale, putting the European way of life under pressure and making the security of European citizens a priority. I believe that the EU must prepare itself to face structural changes in the international security landscape, in order to face the new - but, in truth, not so new - defense and security challenges. I therefore voted in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are opposed to the development of a centralised EU defence and foreign policy capability. As such we reject the annual review process of CSDP and CFSP and the calls for increased EU capability contained within this report.  We remain fully committed to NATO as the primary guarantor of security in Europe. We are supportive of the NATO 2% defence spending minimum. It is UKIP party policy to ensure the UK remains at least above 2% and we would also encourage fellow NATO allies to meet this commitment.  We are however uneasy at language contained within this report in which the EU calls on Member States to meet this requirement. There is a fine line between this and the 2% commitment to NATO being replaced with one to the EU. This risks further undermining NATO and risks the position of traditionally neutral countries.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Report on the Implementation of the common security and defense policy, which carries out an assessment of the implementation of policies in this area, as well as of the events that have taken place this year.That is why a review of these policies is called for, as well as a Union White Paper, a stronger defense industry and the European Defense Action Plan.On the other hand, it is necessary to improve and expand cooperation with NATO.Likewise, greater intra-community coordination is requested within the Union, in order to better adapt to new threats.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- The important topic of the report, the implementation of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy, is, however, rather weak.I believe that it pays too much attention and even over-sensitivity to the threat of terrorism and places too little emphasis on the EU's defense capabilities against conventional military threats.The threat of terrorism has always been and remains more of a police function that should not be confused with the role of the military.At the same time, the text could contain more provisions on strengthening military cooperation between EU Member States, reducing the technological backwardness of the United States, and assessing factors such as the threat to Russia.Some of these provisions are included in the amendments tabled.Rejecting them will make this resolution a weak document that does not meet its original objectives.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - This report deals with the need to strengthen European defense cooperation - an old dream of the European Union (EU) since the Pleven Plan. Insecurity in Europe and in neighboring countries has deteriorated exponentially in recent years, creating a set of new challenges that need to be tackled collectively. I therefore endorse the need to strengthen collaboration and cooperation between the European armed forces, in particular through some of the recommendations presented with a view to combating terrorism and the various daily threats to the security of citizens more effectively. Proposals for the creation of a European headquarters, a European defense semester, a minimum investment of 2% of GDP by Member States for Defense are somewhat controversial and do not generate unanimous opinion within the European Parliament. However, they are all ambitious proposals - they deserve reflection, being the subject of negotiations until we reach a more consensual result, which favors collective security in Europe. I also endorse the idea of ​​carrying out a thorough review of the Common Security and Defense Policy, which will allow the EU and the Member States to contribute more to the security of the Union as a whole, affirming its strategic autonomy in this area.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the common security and defense policy (CSDP) and which suggests ways to strengthen its effectiveness. The CSDP must be strengthened in order to assert the strategic autonomy of the European Union and to strengthen its resistance capacity. This resolution calls on the Union to continue its CSDP missions, such as EUNAVFOR MED, which makes it possible to fight effectively against the trafficking of arms and human beings in the Mediterranean off Libya. This report also calls for the launch of CSDP training operations in Iraq to support member states involved in the coalition fighting against Daesh. In the area of ​​defense, it is crucial that the European Union does not take actions which could duplicate those carried out by NATO. As such, this resolution underlines the new measures adopted to strengthen EU-NATO relations, particularly in the area of ​​cooperation against cyber attacks. Finally, I supported this text because it recalls the need for the Union to react more quickly and more firmly to real threats and for the European armed forces to cooperate more closely.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - This Report indicates the deterioration of European security due to the growth of the terrorist threat and the war situation in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, as well as new challenges such as cyberterrorism. It points to a growing unease of public opinion in the face of terrorism and political instability, and exposes the need to reinforce the common security and defense policy with greater coordination and a budget growth of at least 2% per member country. It also requests greater facilities to finance international operations and the urgent creation of an economic fund for this purpose. It calls for the reinforcement of military research and the European arms sector with sufficient funding and aid for industrial production similar to that received by North American companies in the sector. I voted against, because it delves into the political and financial commitment to a strong Army and arms industry in the Union to combat external threats. Although I understand that some of these threats are real, I believe that increasing the warlike climate will not be able to achieve a real resolution of the problems and to achieve a framework of stability and peace in the Union.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on roll call votes on the European Defence Union report, and voted against the overall report for this reason: Malta is a neutral country. Its constitution prohibits participation in military alliances and in international cooperative efforts promoting warfare capabilities and exercises, unless backed by the UN. The report is based on premises for EU action that contradict this commitment.  Moreover, I disagree that at this time especially, the EU should reinforce a military dimension to its character. This move might appear suitable to counter the supposedly disintegrating effects of Brexit; it could have the opposite effect.  There is no popular constituency for a European Union that morphs into a military coalition, funded from EU budgetary resources.  Again, we see the old ‘business as usual’ methods by which ‘small’ steps ‘forward’ are cumulated and then presented as requiring further integration, failing which disaster would ensue. This is not an acceptable way by which to forge unity in Europe. I abstained on all subsidiary roll call votes because it would not have been coherent to vote one way or the other on different aspects of the issues at hand, while voting against the overall concept.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy.The report calls for the EU to adapt to security challenges and to make effective use of the existing possibilities of security and defense policy.Furthermore, closer cooperation with NATO is called for.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - This AFET report is based on the Annual Report of the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for an increase in the military component in the CSDP, greater investment in defense research and advocates for allocating 2% of the GDP for defense spending. The report further calls for a Union White Paper on Security and Defense, and calls for a strong defense industry. In addition, it supports further reforms to the security sector and also train and equip the military financed with development aid (including the civil instrument that contributes to stability and peace), promotes the expansion of the Athena mechanism to finance all missions Union military and tactical groups, escaping parliamentary control and pressuring the deployment of Union tactical groups for all types of crisis management. We reject the military funding of the Union budget, and prioritize the civilian approach to conflict resolution and stop contributing to the military escalation, and we advocate a total separation between the Union and NATO, while the report proposes a greater cooperation. For this, I voted against.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it is a blatant attempt to form an EU Army.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I abstained on the report on the Implementation of Common Security and Defence Policy. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizens’ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence.  However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity. We therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing - I am fundamentally in favor of strengthening Europe's defenses.Above all, however, I am in favor of continuing cooperation within NATO, where the defense of EU Member States, which are also NATO members, is guaranteed by Article 5. Thus, in defense policy, I am in favor of continuing cooperation within NATO.At the same time, I think that the EU Member States should retain a certain national sovereignty with regard to defense policy.That is why I voted against.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I voted in favor of the report on the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP). The situation in which Europe finds itself today is extremely unstable. Sharp conflicts are taking place right on our borders. In the report, we try to assess the extent to which the CSDP has been implemented so far. However, the potential of this framework, which is enshrined in the Treaties of the Union, does not seem to be sufficiently exploited. We therefore call on the Commission to draw up a White Paper on Security and Defense, while welcoming the European Defense Action Plan. We emphasize the need to reform the ATHENA mechanism, which funds EU missions and operations. At present, it is the Union's foreign missions that are a clear example of how defense cooperation can work at European level. There is no need for European defense to be deepened or replaced by a NATO counterpart. On the contrary, a separate European defense should work with NATO. On the other hand, if we want to consider strengthening the European defense industry and development, we need to ask ourselves where we will transfer resources to. It is not possible to use research or regional policy funding for defense. However, I believe that European defense should become independent so that we can better protect our citizens and the values ​​on which the Union is founded.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Parliament's report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy notes that the European security environment has recently become much more uncertain, dangerous and less predictable, with Member States responding inconsistently to common threats, making a single EU approach very difficult. Despite supporting the rapporteur's introductory remarks, I do not agree that the EU's common security and defense policy should be heavily revised, but that its better and more effective implementation should be ensured. Furthermore, I do not agree with the statement that Europe is no longer able to control security within its borders, but I believe that stabilization efforts and a more competitive and efficient security sector need to be stepped up. As Parliament's report does not include the essential principles we stand for in the Greens / EFF, such as disagreement with the use of European defense research funding at EU level and the strengthening of third country armed forces, it also sets out a number of requirements that contrary to our belief, I did not support it in the vote.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - A Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) is high on the European agenda, but it is difficult to reach agreement on this between the different Member States and political families. Every report on this gets bogged down in a long list of everything that has anything to do with military or defense matters. It looks like a letter to Sinterklaas. Sometimes we see the contours of a European army emerge, then the desire to increase defense budgets so that there is money to invest in drones or military research. However, there is always no clear vision of defense and security for the outside world or the foreign embassies. So it is difficult to agree with such a report. Green wants a common security and defense policy to focus on humanitarian missions, peacekeeping and crisis management, rather than warfare and the defense of our homeland. Instead of increasing the defense budget, we could look more closely at how we can use the annual 200 billion euros more efficiently. By jointly tendering, conducting joint military research and, above all, increasing transparency in the "military market" by simply respecting European public procurement rules. But this has in many cases fell on deaf ears.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- This own-initiative report by the Social Democratic MP Paşcu calls for a strengthening of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), taking into account the current crises and in particular the annexation of Crimea.A new headquarters of the CSDP is to be built for operations, including border controls, military training and maritime operations.According to the FCR, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully exploited within the framework of a European superstate.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The security environment in the EU has deteriorated significantly and is becoming increasingly unstable, dangerous and less predictable.As a result, the Common Security and Defense Policy needs to be thoroughly and significantly revised in order to enable the EU and its Member States to make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union.One of the tools is, for example, the creation of a permanent EU headquarters for civilian and military missions and common security and defense policy operations.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I support the report. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizens’ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence.  However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity. My colleagues and I therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I voted against this resolution. The EU wants to copy the pillar of European defense, NATO, in order to better undermine and bypass it. For future strong and modern military capabilities, the EP is demanding additional budgetary resources from the member states so that the EU can advance the rule of law, peace and security worldwide through armed force. To this end, the 27 armies are to unify their national defense forces. The Council and the Commission will deepen military concepts and contacts with the arms industry in discussion groups and working groups. The calculation: Brussels should take over the financing of the national defense forces, and therefore also the high command. Who pays determines. By transferring the management of deficiencies in the military to the EU level, the national governments get rid of this problem at home. Because the armies of the 27 member states are either saved to the brim or chronically underfunded. The Bundeswehr even has to recruit minors. However, many emaciated national armies do not result in a powerful EU army. In Germany we have fought for a viable, constitutionally anchored parliamentary reservation over many years. In Germany, the Bundestag decides on the Bundeswehr deployment. That is being wiped out by the EU. National parliaments will be helpless in the face of a future EU task force.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - In a time of lasting instability surrounding the European Union, special focus has been placed on the implementation and consistent conduct of European security and defense policy. I support this report because it successfully identifies key shortcomings among Member States, and that is the low level of readiness, cooperation and compatibility of military resources. It is crucial that Member States work to coordinate action in the field of security and defense in order to ensure greater stability and predictability of the system. However, in the implementation of security and defense policy, it is important to ensure cooperation with other countries in the European Neighborhood, cooperation that will create a stable partnership based on trust and mutual assistance. In light of the recent US presidential election, the issue of European defense and security is becoming increasingly important due to announcements that the United States will refrain from an active role in NATO. The European Union must be able to defend itself against security challenges.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (based on the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy).The security environment has changed significantly in recent years due to various circumstances, and the EU needs to respond to all these changed circumstances and adapt accordingly.I support the report, which emphasizes that the EU should step up dialogue and cooperation with third countries in the region, as well as with regional organizations, and be prepared to deal with structural changes in the international security environment and challenges involving inter-state conflicts.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy, which calls in particular for more coordinated action by Member States in view of the deteriorating security situation in the EU's immediate neighborhood and the current global interconnectedness, especially in cyber security.It is clear that no Member State can face the current threats alone, and no Member State can solve the situation in Syria, for example, alone.It is therefore a matter of better coordination not only in the response phase, but also in the action phase, because only a coordinated EU policy has the potential to prevent sources of tension.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The implementation of the CSDP will not be able to deal effectively with existing and future threats.In addition, the majority of Member States are unable to meet its obligations and obligations.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. This lack of coordination is one of the vulnerabilities of EU action. To address these problems, a thorough and substantial review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capability targets, which will require that defense spending be increased to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. Finally, CSDP missions contribute to international peace and stability. In line with the Hungarian position, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report because it provides an accurate, realistic yet critical picture of the problems of the EU's common security and defense policy, while indicating the possible direction forward, in particular by creating a greater degree of defense autonomy for Europe. He points out that the mass of overlaps and parallels would clearly require the coordination of Member States' defense capabilities and assets, as well as the meaningful use of existing capabilities and assets at European level (such as "battlegroups"). The political and military rationale for closer and more independent European defense is reflected in the report’s deteriorating security environment in the EU over the years, new types of security challenges, terrorist, cyber, hybrid threats and, above all, military threats in our immediate southern and eastern neighborhood. - by presenting a political threat - convincingly to me. Reflecting my own experience, the report also points out that governments cannot rely solely on defense in the field of defense, because the EU's one-sided, selfish conception and neglect of its own defense capabilities do not prevent some countries 'leaders from providing their allies' defense guarantees. considered. I believe that it is precisely this report and Parliament's decision that can help to recognize at EU level the need to incorporate political and legal guarantees into the system in the future in order to prevent such unilateral behavior by Member States in the formulation of the CSDP and the Defense Union.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing.- The European security situation has deteriorated significantly, becoming less clear, more complex and unpredictable.It should be remembered that the security of the Member States of the European Union is very much interdependent and the current situation of fragmentation and lack of coordination is particularly dangerous.The EU needs to adapt as quickly as possible to the current security challenges, in particular by making more effective use of existing tools under the Common Security and Defense Policy in combination with other external and internal instruments.In particular, consideration should be given to establishing permanent structured cooperation, developing a sectoral strategy for foreign and security policy, creating a permanent EU headquarters for civilian and military CSDP missions and operations, and continuing to work closely with NATO.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The deterioration of the European security environment in recent years, manifested by the proliferation of conventional, non-conventional and hybrid threats, calls for the need to strengthen the Union's common security and defense policy (CSDP). The rise of the terrorist phenomenon generated by radical Islamic organizations, as well as the emergence of complex crises near the Union's external borders, require a stronger response from the Member States in the common framework created by the CSDP. From this point of view, there is a need for better coordination of Member States' defense capabilities, while intensifying cooperation with existing structures within NATO. It would also be useful to support the European defense industry and reform the ATHENA system to fund EU military missions and operations. The adoption of an EU White Paper on Security and Defense would be an important aid in setting out the main priorities in this area. The adoption of the European Defense Action Plan (EDAP) and the European Defense Research Program (EDRP), together with strengthening the role of the European Defense Agency (EDA), are likely to strengthen the CSDP and strengthen the security of European citizens. For these reasons, I support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for the text of colleague Pașcu.I see that the security environment in Europe has deteriorated significantly and is now more fluid, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.I also note that the threats are both conventional and hybrid, that they come from both state and non-state actors, that they originate from the South and the East and that their repercussions vary from state to state.member to another.I am for a European army!In addition, it will save a lot of money in many countries.It will also increase the effectiveness of our defense.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy assesses the implementation of the CSDP and the developments that took place in the last year. The report supports an EU White Book on Security and Defence, a stronger defence industry and promotes the European Defence Action Plan. Further, the report endorses cooperation between the EU and NATO. I voted in favour of the overall report, as I believe the CSDP is a vital element in protecting EU citizens, as well as the promotion of EU values and interests, with full respect for the Treaties, international law and human rights.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - The European security environment has deteriorated significantly in recent times, becoming more flexible, complex, dangerous and less predictable. These threats are taking increasingly diverse forms, both traditional and hybrid. The security of EU Member States is closely interlinked, yet Member States respond to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated way and with fragmented resources. To address these problems, a thorough and substantial review of the CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) is needed so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union. The report emphasizes that the establishment of permanent structured cooperation (Article 42 (6) of the Treaty on European Union) would make it possible to set up a self-defense or a permanent self-defense structure. Through CSDP missions, the EU could intervene in the full spectrum of crisis management, including crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the EU should encourage member states to meet NATO's capacity targets, which will require defense spending to increase to at least 2% of GDP over time. The CSDP instruments also call for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, especially in the fight against terrorism. Finally, CSDP missions, including cross-border assistance, capacity building, military training missions and naval operations, contribute to international peace and stability. In line with the Hungarian position, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (based on the Council's annual report on the common foreign and security policy to the European Parliament). I believe that it is necessary to ensure the implementation of the common security and defense policy as soon as possible. It is also necessary to adopt a strategy, establish joint political and administrative bodies and permanent structural cooperation. It is very important to develop the capabilities of the military industry, developing as much Dual-use technology as possible. It should be borne in mind that the equipment of the security and defense forces of the European Union is very diverse. Consequently, abilities are also diverse. In some equipment cases, equipment incompatibility can still be determined. That is why it is especially important to work on smarter investment in the defense industry, especially as I have already pointed out Dual-use technology where, for example, fleets that protect the borders of the European Union, including Croatia on the Adriatic, can focus on equipping for search and rescue operations. medical transport, prevention of marine pollution, and modular upgrades in a very short time can become combat fleets.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I voted against because I firmly believe that competence over defense policy must always be and remain within the competence of nation states as the foundation of national sovereignty. In this regard, I support NATO as the basis for defense and security cooperation between the European Union and the transatlantic allies. Therefore, I strongly oppose the proposals, which are becoming louder at the level of the European Union, and which call for the establishment of the European Union army and, in this connection, expensive military structures. In my opinion, the above proposal, apart from the financial loss, could only result in an irreparable loss of trust of the former NATO allies and thus significantly weaken ties with our international defense partners. The report suggests that the European Union must face challenges to internal security in member states, including overthrow, which is not covered by NATO action. Although the compromises contain many calls for cooperation with NATO, they also contain many calls for the creation of an autonomous security and defense policy and a collective defense principle - which grossly infringes on the principle of national sovereignty.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the implementation of the common security and defense policy (based on the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy). aEuropean security environment has deteriorated sharply and become more uncertain, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable. Security in the EU is highly intertwined and countries respond to threats and risks inconsistently and inconsistently, which needs to change. Inconsistency and disunity contribute to Europe's vulnerability and helplessness in joint action against threats. The CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) has been one of the steps towards unity and coherence, but due to the structural shortcomings of the CSDP, they are still ineffective. The strategic plans of the EU and NATO are similar, so they must work together and complementary. The relationship between organizations must be cooperative and not competitive. A step towards cooperation was the signing of a joint declaration in Warsaw on improving cooperation on hybrid and cyber threats. There is also a need to develop a strong defense industry to strengthen the EU's strategic autonomy and technological independence. Member States are not yet implementing systematic and long-term defense cooperation with sufficient commitment, and this needs to change.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - This Report indicates the deterioration of European security due to the growth of the terrorist threat and the war situation in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, as well as new challenges such as cyberterrorism.
