It points to a growing restlessness of public opinion in the face of terrorism and political instability, and exposes the need to reinforce the common security and defense policy with greater coordination and a budget growth of at least 2% per member country. It also requests greater facilities to finance international operations and the urgent creation of an economic fund for this purpose. It calls for the strengthening of military research and the European arms sector with sufficient funding, and aid for industrial production similar to that received by North American companies in the sector. I voted against it, because it delves into the political and financial commitment to a strong Army and arms industry in the Union to combat external threats. Although I understand that some of these threats are real, I believe that increasing the climate of war is not going to achieve a real resolution of the problems and to achieve a framework of stability and peace in the Union.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- This own-initiative report by the Social Democratic MP Paşcu calls for a strengthening of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), taking into account the current crises and in particular the annexation of Crimea.A new headquarters of the CSDP is to be built for operations, including border controls, military training and maritime operations.According to the FCR, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully exploited within the framework of a European superstate.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. A revision of the CSDP is needed in order to enable the EU to contribute in a decisive way to the security of the Union, to the management of international crises and to asserting the EU’s strategic autonomy; recalls that no country can face the current security challenges on its own. It is most cost-efficient to create a single permanent EU headquarters for civilian and military CSDP missions and operations, from where an integrated operational staff would support the entire planning cycle.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This is to ensure the EU's grip on the foreign and defense policies of the Member States.This report is based on the principle that the EU is threatened in the east and in the south by both violent border changes made by Russia (point 7) and the destabilization of states in the Middle East.The report details the multiple concessions that are expected from States for the CFSP to become a reliable partner of NATO (points 15, 21, 23, 33 to 37, 40).It also defines how the Commission is to impose its rules in the field of defense procurement (point 44).I therefore voted against.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The idea of a common security and defense policy should arouse positive emotions.Unfortunately, this resolution went too far and undermines the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of defense policy.NATO efforts should be supported, not cumbersome regulations.I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The European security environment has deteriorated significantly, becoming more flexible, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.Threats are both traditional and hybrid in nature, triggered by state and non-state actors, coming from the south and the east, and affecting different Member States differently.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - This Report indicates the deterioration of European security due to the growth of the terrorist threat and the war situation in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, as well as new challenges such as cyberterrorism. It points to a growing unease of public opinion in the face of terrorism and political instability, and exposes the need to reinforce the common security and defense policy with greater coordination and a budget growth of at least 2% per member country. It also requests greater facilities to finance international operations and the urgent creation of an economic fund for this purpose. It calls for the reinforcement of military research and the European arms sector with sufficient funding and aid for industrial production similar to that received by North American companies in the sector. I voted against, because it delves into the political and financial commitment to a strong Army and arms industry in the Union to combat external threats. Although I understand that some of these threats are real, I believe that increasing the warlike climate will not be able to achieve a real resolution of the problems and to achieve a framework of stability and peace in the Union.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I note with concern that terrorism against Europe by radical Islamist organizations and individuals is on an unprecedented scale and is putting pressure on the European way of life;I emphasize that, as a result, personal security has become a priority and the traditional distinction between external and internal aspects of such security is disappearing.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (based on the Annual Report from the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy). The European security environment has deteriorated considerably, becoming more fluid, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable. The security of the EU Member States is deeply interconnected and they react to common threats and risks in an uncoordinated and fragmented way. The report calls for a strong preventive policy based on comprehensive deradicalisation programmes. I voted in favour because I believe that a thorough and substantial revision of the CSDP is needed in order to enable the EU and its Member States to contribute in a decisive way to the security of the Union, to the management of international crises and to asserting the EU’s strategic autonomy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- This proposal is based on the evolution of the current strategic context of the Union, characterized by deteriorated security, the mix of conventional and hybrid threats, the intervention of state and non-state actors and the emergence of new (less predictable) risks to the Eastand to the South.This context requires prioritizing the prevention of crises that take place beyond the Community borders, but without ceasing to intervene in the resolution and stabilization phases in those conflicts that directly affect the security of the Union.Aware that Europe has to deal with a growing number of crises in its immediate neighborhood (the most visible consequence of which is terrorist acts perpetrated on our own territory) in the most effective way possible - which requires joint action and more cooperation.narrow - I thought it appropriate to vote in favor of this text.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - This AFET report is based on the Annual Report of the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for an increase in the military component in the CSDP, greater investment in defense research and advocates for allocating 2% of the GDP for defense spending. The report further calls for a Union White Paper on Security and Defense, and calls for a strong defense industry. In addition, it supports further reforms to the security sector and also train and equip the military financed with development aid (including the civil instrument that contributes to stability and peace), promotes the expansion of the Athena mechanism to finance all missions Union military and tactical groups, escaping parliamentary control and pressuring the deployment of Union tactical groups for all types of crisis management. We reject the military funding of the Union budget, and prioritize the civilian approach to conflict resolution and stop contributing to the military escalation, and we advocate a total separation between the Union and NATO, while the report proposes a greater cooperation. For this, I voted against.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because I firmly believe that a thorough and substantial overhaul of the CSDP is necessary so that the EU and its Member States can make a decisive contribution to EU security, international crisis management and enforcementof the EU's strategic autonomy.No country can cope with today's security threats alone.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written.- I voted against the report on the common security and defense policy.I am in favor of European cooperation, for example, in the procurement of defense equipment and the creation of a common defense equipment market.Likewise, counter-terrorism action is more effective when it is carried out together.Instead, I do not accept the development of a common security and defense policy into a defense union.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The report calls for the establishment of a "white paper on European defense". The Union's military intervention capabilities should be increased and diversified, beyond any parliamentary control. In addition, the desire to develop operational capabilities that are more independent of the member states is accompanied by ever closer rapprochement with NATO. Worse, it is to encourage massive subsidies to the arms industry by asking member states to increase their defense efforts to at least 2% of GDP. Such a policy can only be done to the detriment of the Union's other development policies. With the GUE / NGL, we remain resolutely hostile to militarist escalation and in favor of a disarmament policy. The EU would do better to devote its energy and its finances to the promotion of peace, multilateralism and peaceful dialogue between peoples. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The European Union as a military bloc promotes its belligerent, militaristic and external interference. In a position of total subordination in relation to NATO, it is requested the reinforcement of defense budgets, the increase of investment in research and the military industry, in addition to the creation of a European army, possibly for future criminal war actions such as that this Parliament approved on Libya and how this Parliament is preparing to approve on Syria. A policy of blood and death, of war and destruction, to which all those who promote and approve it are associated. A policy that fuels the arms race, not forgetting nuclear, increasing world tensions, contradicting commitments made with the non-proliferation and disarmament treaty. A policy that opposes and compromises Peace, and that does not disconnect from the policies of exploitation and impoverishment of workers and peoples.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of implementing a common security and defense policy.I believe that the European security environment has worsened significantly, becoming more unstable, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.A more unified and more effective European foreign and security policy is therefore needed, which can contribute significantly to maintaining a situation of stability and peace.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: written.- A common European security and defense policy is to be rejected under the aspect of national sovereignty.Defense policy must be the domain of sovereign peoples, which does not exclude that defense and military measures in the event of a crisis or war are coordinated at the European level (and possibly under the direction of a joint European command).However, the orientation of a European defense and security policy towards NATO, as expressed in the present report, must be completely rejected.On the contrary, the aim is to achieve the greatest possible independence from US and NATO guidelines.The “complementarity” of European and NATO structures invoked in the report contradicts all efforts to establish an independent European defense and security policy and should therefore be rejected.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the current unpredictable security situation in our closest neighbourhood, the EU needs a fully efficient Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) even more than ever before. This is actually a view which is also shared by around two thirds of EU citizens according to the recent Eurobarometer survey. Personally, I am firmly convinced that, in line with the report’s recommendations, the EU should firstly make good use of its tools available at hand. This means ensuring that our currently deployed 17 military and civilian missions are able to address the whole spectrum of crisis management, and thereby that they are fulfilling their mandate properly. Furthermore, the deployment of EU battlegroups should become one of the possible crisis response options for the EU as they have been operational since 2007 but have never been used. This is why the report stresses as well the importance of creating a permanent EU headquarters coupled with the extension of scope of the ATHENA mechanism to finance all EU military missions. Consequently, I am sure that this report will ensure a higher level of coherence in EU external action, thus I voted in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I support the report. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizens’ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence.  However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be a Member State or industry driven activity. Labour MEPs therefore abstained on the final vote. The EU must remain above all a project of peace. In our common security and defence policy we must emphasise the need to refrain from selling arms to regimes which violate human rights and commit war crimes. The EU must always stand for human rights, democracy, and the rule of law, and nothing in our CSDP should ever compromise those commitments.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since as a liberal I believe in the fight against radicalisation. I believe that the Common Security and Defence Policy will also help to reduce conflicts in the Middle East. We need to create synergies between EU capabilities and we also need to increase investments in security and defence. This topic is relevant especially right now, in light of the recent terrorist attacks and the unstable political landscape outside the Union. In this situation we need a permanent structured cooperation. Moreover I support the Defence Action Plan and the EU Defence Research Programme. Cooperation between Member States on this sensible topic will only be beneficial for the safety of the EU citizens.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up.- I voted for the own-initiative report of my colleague Ioan Mircea Pașcu on the implementation of the EU's common security and defense policy.Starting from the finding that the European security environment has deteriorated considerably, becoming more and more changeable, complex, dangerous and less predictable, the report proposes a detailed and in-depth review of the CSDP.I agree that a successful review of the CSDP will need to fully include EU Member States from the outset, in order to avoid the risk of future bottlenecks.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I support the report presented because I believe that the EU's common security and defense policy should be clearly strengthened. On a theoretical level, I am convinced that the creation of a common European army would be clearly beneficial and that these troops could effectively support the forces of the North Atlantic Alliance, which is currently the only security alternative for us. On the other hand, I am a realist, and I think that the creation of a European army would in fact be plagued by the same problems that NATO now has. By this I mean, in particular, the lack of willingness of states to contribute to their own defense and the general reluctance of states to engage in defense at the collective level. Therefore, as a first step towards common defense, EU countries should now focus primarily on maintaining a level of defense spending of 2% of GDP, but also on improving cooperation between national armed forces. The European Union should be able to respond quickly and effectively to current security threats. Whether this will be due to the cooperation of states or thanks to joint troops is not so relevant at the moment.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I did not support the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy. In the light of the current escalating security crises, the report calls for more effective use of existing Common Security and Defense Policy instruments, as well as a strong prevention policy. The report also contains a number of articles calling for stronger cooperation with NATO. Despite these acceptable requirements, the report examines the revision of the common security and defense policy, which should aim at permanent structured cooperation enabling the development of self-defense. Although I am aware that the challenges facing the European Union are unprecedented and need to be addressed, I am more in favor of strengthening cooperation with NATO. I think that it is precisely this cooperation that we should build on defense and not seek to create a parallel structure that could ultimately weaken this defense based on cooperation with NATO.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Pascu report, as I agree with the proposals on the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy.I highlight my support for the development of an autonomous defense capacity by the EU, with the aim of protecting its citizens and promoting their interests always in full compliance with the Treaties, international law and human rights.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I support the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy based on the annual report of the Council and the common foreign and security policy.Defense and security have become very important on the agenda not only of European and national institutions, but also of a whole range of other important actors such as civil society, the media, groups of experts and ultimately citizens.An unstable European environment requires a clear and consistent response to all threats, and the European Union must ensure the consistent implementation of the common security and defense policy.The problem with the European Union's security architecture is that it has relied too heavily on NATO and done little to harmonize military procedures, equipment compatibility and the development of the military industry.In the new geopolitical circumstances, enhanced cooperation and coordination in the field of security and protection is becoming a priority.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the implementation of the common security and defense policy.The European security environment has become more uncertain, more complex, more dangerous and less predictable.Europe now needs to respond to a number of increasingly complex crises in the area, which stretches from West Africa through the Sahel, the Horn of Africa and the Middle East, and eastern Ukraine to the Caucasus.In order for the EU to be prepared to cope with structural changes in the international security environment and to be a strong factor in peace-building, it is necessary for Member States to cooperate even more closely and develop a coordinated approach within the common security and defense policy.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, George Orwell said, 'If thoughts corrupt language, then language corrupts thoughts.' Propaganda gives birth to other people and a different mentality. We have seen this in the past at home, in Romania, in other post-communist Central and Eastern European states, and, unfortunately, we see it today. The Russian Federation waited, had patience for years, built and now attacks. It attacks everywhere in Central and Eastern Europe. He attacks through propaganda and has already begun to take direct action. Russian is used, licenses are bought in these post-communist states - television and radio licenses are bought in which it will be broadcast, or is already broadcast, directly in Russian. So people's minds will be converted, drop by drop, by Russian propaganda. We all need to see and not be naive that, yes, history can repeat itself if we are not careful. Yes, we can re-enter the sphere of Russian influence, perhaps more than influence, if we are not careful and do not believe that it is indeed possible. Let us not imagine that we have won freedom and democracy once and for all. On the contrary, now is the time for Russia to attack us again and we must be together and united and awaken people, because people do not understand and do not believe.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: - Mr Chairman! On this, I voted against. I will refer, as did Mrs Macovei, to Orwell. Well, it is George Orwell who perfectly described this mechanism when there is a police of thoughts in the country, when there is a Ministry of Truth which, as an institution, allows or disallows the content to public communication. I know this world because we were ruled by Moscow - there was censorship there and we know what effects it had. And this nightmarish world of George Orwell in Russia has lost. However, it turns out that this nightmare is now triumphing in Western Europe, which until recently was an oasis of freedom and free speech. It was also possible to speak of those things on which you were wrong. It was allowed to speak in public space, there was free speech, there was free communication. Unfortunately, this is the hallmark of the collapse of the civilization of the West, which was once an oasis of freedom. And I would like that this oasis of freedom would remain and that my homeland would be a free country - that our thoughts and words would not be administered by any offices. Even if I'm mistaken, I should have the right to announce it publicly.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, as a Member of this House and a representative of one of the Member States of the European Union, I would like to express my great disappointment and bewilderment at the hate speech that some of my colleagues are instilling through such texts. I voted against this report because, in addition to the harsh language against a global and strategic player on the international stage, Russia, the report also calls into question the competence of the Member States of the European Union, which are 'not sufficiently aware of their audience and propaganda arena'. and misinformation. " This is an outright insult to democratically elected governments and heads of state, as well as to the citizens of the European Union themselves. The voted text is also a blow to the development of relations with Russia on the basis of bilateral cooperation and joint projects with individual member states of the European Union. This report is supposedly against propaganda and hate speech, and it itself provokes this.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - I am glad that the report on hostile propaganda reminds us that communism was destroying the tradition and identity of the nations conquered by the Soviet Union, that the tool of this destruction was a historical lie and, unfortunately, that this tool is still used in post-communist Russia.I am glad that our appeal calls for the crimes committed by communism to be remembered through cultural policy and education, and thus to fulfill the obligations of remembrance towards its victims.My only regret is that we still have not yet condemned the cult of Bolshevism leaders practiced in Russia, but I think that the report we have adopted today is a good step in that direction, and also in condemning the apology of the Soviet Union as such.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I want to echo what my friend and colleague Mr Jurek just said. Marxism and Leninism must, in crude mathematical terms, be reckoned the most murderous ideology ever devised by human intelligence, and yet this is a point that has to be made anew in every generation. I saw an opinion poll the other day that showed that a third of American millennials believe that George W. Bush killed more people than Stalin did. Well, here’s a nice easy way to remember the difference. The limerick comes courtesy of the great poet and historian Robert Conquest: ‘There was an old bastard named Lenin Who did two or three million men in. That’s a lot to have done in But where he did one in, That old bastard Stalin did ten in.’

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, this report is all about an EU communication to counteract anti-EU propaganda. I do not think that taxpayers’ money should be spent on this because it is very dangerous when the state starts getting involved in telling us what is, and what is not, acceptable to be said. Perhaps, being fair and reasonable people, the EU would be amenable to a compromise – to spending half of the money countering pro—EU propaganda, the same politicians who told us that leaving the EU would lead to World War III or the end of western political civilisation as we know it. Perhaps we could have a bit of help countering some of that propaganda. The UK Government spent EUR 10 million sending a booklet to every household with pro-EU propaganda telling people to vote for the EU, but actually what you often find is that propaganda backfires. I am sure it would be only too fair to counteract pro—EU propaganda and nonsense as well, but what are the chances of the EU voting for that? Zero.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal, sharing the rapporteur’s belief that combating anti-EU propaganda and disinformation by third countries is essential – in the first place to uphold democratic values and a united Europe. EU citizens cannot effectively legitimise us, and the work we do on their behalf, if they do not have access to accurate information. Speaking from an Irish point of view, investing in education in order to equip the public better for critical thinking has long been a priority. As Franklin D. Roosevelt stated, democracy cannot succeed unless those who express their choice are prepared to choose wisely. Given the prevalence of disinformation, stemming in particular nowadays from electronic means of dissemination such as social media, it is imperative that we collaborate on deconstructing such propaganda. I therefore welcome the recommendations offered in this report.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, this report takes an extremely selective, aggressive, hostile and confrontational position towards Russia, ignoring other countries guilty of many of the same things. My position and voting decisions should not – I would emphasise – be interpreted as defending Russia, or even supporting Russia, but rather as registering my support for stopping the EU from needlessly aggravating what is acknowledged to be a poor and increasingly negative relationship with Russia. Contributing to a return of the Cold War mentality is unhelpful, and binding the United Kingdom to such inflammatory and confrontational statements is not in my country’s interests.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, in the novel Nineteen eighty-four, George Orwell created a world of three continents in conflict with each another. The governments of the day, in that novel, managed to control their own people by the creation of propaganda. Their own propaganda was called ‘news speak’ and they controlled people for having thought crimes. Just as, in that book, Oceania was against Eurasia, we now have proposals in this particular document to pit the EU against Russia. This creates propaganda within its own text. For example, in paragraph one of the report, it says that Russia employs a wide range of tools such as Russia Today and Sputnik yet, in paragraph 36 of this same report, it says that the EU must create its own communication policies and television companies to fight Russia. One propaganda against another does not make things fair.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report presents some measures to be taken to counter information campaigns with the European Union.However, there are some very problematic elements, for example they are identified as actors who implement propaganda to discredit the European Union, Russia and ISIS.I find it inconceivable to equate a partner country of the European Union with a terrorist organization that has attacked Europe several times with extremely violent actions.Furthermore, one of the possible solutions is to finance the media of neighboring third countries.Since I find the measures proposed in the report unclear and in some inadequate, I have decided to vote negatively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - We are here before one more example of Russophobia in this Parliament, which constantly exaggerates the differences between Russia and the Union. The report is a frontal attack on the media, calling for the use of NATO instruments, such as the Center of Excellence for Strategic Communications (COE STRATCOM), to combat the Russian media. In addition, it calls for direct support to "independent" media, which is a paradox, since by sponsoring them from European organizations, these media would obviously cease to be independent. Not content with this, in the report, and following this paranoid anti-Russian rhetoric, it is argued that "the security and intelligence services conclude that Russia has the capacity and intention to carry out operations aimed at destabilizing other countries", continuing with the militaristic rhetoric and engaging in an unacceptable escalation of tension. The report identifies two threats related to propaganda: a state actor, Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh, and focuses on giving the Union the means to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns, mainly against Russia, a UN country to who puts the same level of threat as Daesh. My vote was clearly against.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: in writing. - The adoption of this report in the plenary session of the EP is a real scandal and a provocation vis-à-vis such an essential partner as Russia (both politically and economically). Indeed, by assimilating Daesh propaganda on the internet to Russian news sites such as RTnews or Sputniknews, the European legislator is setting himself up as the supreme censor of the freedom to think differently from the “Eurobeaters”. Russian news sites are openly Eurosceptic, especially since the sanctions decided by the EU in connection with Vladimir Putin's positions on the Syrian conflict. So, not supporting the contradiction, what better way for Europhiles than to ban these websites? This censorship is in line with the French government bill aimed at penalizing “so-called” disinformation sites on abortion. Thus, in the coming months in France, it will no longer be possible to offer alternatives to abortion online. From now on, the sites offering a vision other than that of the well-meaning Brussels and the French “ProLife” will be purely and simply filtered by the servers. This method is already applied in China for all non-governmental social networks.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- The propaganda targeting the EU and its citizens is a fact that requires a strong reaction from us.The fight against propaganda and radicalization requires cooperation between Member States and European institutions.However, I regret that this text is not up to the stakes.That’s why I decided to abstain.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on EU strategic communication to counter third country propaganda against the EU and its Member States. I share the concern expressed in the resolution about the Kremlin's rapidly growing disinformation and propaganda, including disinformation and propaganda, in order to maintain or increase Russia's influence and with the aim of weakening and fragmenting the EU. One of the aims of the Kremlin's propaganda is to portray some European states as "traditionally under Russia's sphere of influence," undermining their sovereignty and European identity. Therefore, in order to counter the Kremlin's discourse, there is a need to raise awareness of the crimes committed by the communist regime, to carry out public information campaigns and to use education systems, and to support research and document research in EU Member States. In addition, it is essential for the EU to act in a united and coordinated manner in the means and instruments to combat propaganda. This is especially important for the Baltic countries, which are becoming Russia's information war front. In Lithuania, the Kremlin applies a complex strategy of propaganda and disinformation, seeks to assert that traditional Lithuanian values ​​and the rest of Western European values ​​are different, and to show that Lithuania is defenseless and therefore not worth defending. In order to overcome the propaganda carried out by the Kremlin, the national security services need to be mobilized, but I want to emphasize that their autonomy must be maintained in order to gather information effectively and preserve state secrets.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- The resolution addresses the threats posed by targeted propaganda against the EU by state and non-state actors.The report explicitly names the activities of Russia and IS that are directed against the EU and its member states.Russia is trying to disrupt relations between the member states and with the US and to question the EU's value system.With its propaganda, IS tries to radicalize people and induce them to fight against European values.I support the report because it calls for the competent authorities, both at European and at Member State level, to work better and in a more coordinated manner in order to prevent hate propaganda against the EU.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The aim of this report is to fight against the famous “hybrid threats” which would threaten the European Union.These threats have two sources: Russia and the Islamic State.This report is a testimony to the drift of the European Union, which, failing to have any consistency, tries to exist by manipulating fears, and crudely amalgamates a sovereign state respectful of the international treaties it has.signed and a terrorist organization.I voted against the report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I welcome the idea of producing a communication on behalf of the Union on this subject.However, I have reservations about leveling the different threats.The war at the gates of Europe and the methods of radicalization used by ISIS / Daesh are a threat today unlike the current politics of a country like Russia.For this reason, I decided to abstain.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on EU strategic communication to counter anti-third party propaganda.European society is facing active disinformation, propaganda and growing radicalization.At present, strategic communication and information warfare are not only an external but also an internal issue for the EU.I therefore agree with the need to adopt an EU strategic communication action plan to counter propaganda, misinformation and growing radicalization.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The recent breakdown in relations between the west and Russia, of which both parties are guilty, has produced far more insecurity in Europe. Diplomacy and deterrence are delicate mechanisms. We are uneasy with the constant peddling of aggression and justifications for more EU action.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This scandalous report plays on fears by putting on the same level, in a crass and absurd way, a sovereign state like Russia and a terrorist organization such as the Islamic State which would both be at the origin of supposed and vague "hybrid threats ”.I voted against.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this report which asks the Union to develop actions to counter propaganda against it by third countries.MEPs call on the Union and its Member States in particular to include the counter-propaganda strategy against ISIL / Daesh in a larger and more comprehensive regional strategy combining diplomatic, socio-economic and development tools.and conflict prevention.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I have abstained from voting on the report, because despite agreeing with the content, I do not share the approach. It is focused on the particular criticism of a country, Russia, and a terrorist group, Daesh. Equating and putting a country and a terrorist group on the same level does not seem right to me and distorts the text. I share the criticism of the propaganda policy of Russian communication focused on breaking the integration process of the Union. And in this regard, as the text indicates, I regret the support given by Russia to the anti-European forces in the Union, as regards far-right parties, populist forces and movements that deny the basic values ​​of the liberal democracies. I also agree that the Union must make its strategic communication a priority, allocating the relevant resources to it. And I unreservedly condemn the terrorist group Daesh, and, of course, their systematic use and promotion of hate speech for political purposes. The Union must develop strong and effective common policies to protect society from radicalization processes that lead to terrorism and violent extremism.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The European Union has recently been facing systematic pressure generated by disinformation and propaganda campaigns which aim to undermine the basic concept of objective information within the Union. I decided to abstain on the Fotyga report because, while considering it essential to strengthen EU strategic communication, I do not consider it appropriate to equate the measures to be taken against state actors, such as Russia, with those to be taken against terrorist organizations such as Daesh. This is an approach that I do not consider adequate, even though I share the need to invest in coordinated training and awareness-raising actions involving the online and local media. We need a different perspective, which fosters collaboration between EU institutions and Member States and also relies on collaboration between NATO and the EU, but which does not put different situations on the same level.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against this report on strategic communication of the Union against third party propaganda, because it makes an analysis that leaves out many aspects of the geopolitical reality in which the Union currently finds itself.Encouraging hate and fear speech seems to us to be an ineffective way of ending the discursive threats that the Union receives.The analysis and the tone of the entire report is partial and not very truthful, and is also situated in a political line opposite to ours in matters of Foreign Policy.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: in writing. - Rarely has such a Manichean text been proposed to our assembly. How even to dare to mention on the same level Daesh, a terrorist organization, and the Russian Federation, sovereign state of law, obligatory and desired partner of a Europe fully aware of its identity and its raison d'être? It is a Russophobic, cartoonish report that shows a clear degradation of democracy and press freedom in Europe. Despite millions of euros injected into the communication - propaganda should we say - of the European institutions, the Europeans refuse to submit to your diktats and seek alternative sources of information, especially in Russia. Why ban RT if you don't ban the BBC, British state television, at the forefront of disinformation in Syria or Libya? Why not ban the eight financial groups which share 100% of television and 97% of written media in France? This report is insulting to Russia, but it also testifies to the soft dictatorship that the European authorities intend to put in place in a Europe where only supporters of the system can express themselves. You bring down a new Iron Curtain over Europe, and we are no longer on the safe side ...

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I voted against this report because I do not agree with it at all.The only section I could share is number 6. It is not acceptable to vote on a resolution where Russia and ISIS and the propaganda that both use are equated.I strongly disagree with the content of this report, which in my opinion should not have been written.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - It is always ideology and not the general interest that prevails in this cenacle that is the European Parliament. We had further proof of this with the vote by MEPs on a text aimed at "countering the propaganda carried out against the European Union by third countries". In other words, European taxpayers' money will be used as a priority to crush any criticism, dispute or dissonant voice within the Union. I had already opposed the opinion of the Culture Committee on this text by tabling amendments recalling in particular that pluralism and freedom of expression are enshrined in the European treaties. During this vote, I also recalled that if the Union suffers from an unprecedented crisis of legitimacy, it will not be resolved by marketing measures or even propaganda operations. One can wonder about the sincerity of European parliamentarians who decry Russia on the subject of human rights and freedom of expression but also have no difficulty in pampering Turkey which nevertheless multiplies the purges of elected officials , journalists and any dissenting voice. I obviously voted against this report, another example of the endemic schizophrenia of European institutions.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The report being voted on is not balanced and acceptable, so I did not intend to support it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- This Parliament's own-initiative report refers to two external threats in terms of propaganda directed against the Union: one coming from a non-state actor, the terrorist group Daesh and a state actor, the Russian Federation, and seeks to counter theradicalization through cooperation between Member States and European institutions.However, one state, Russia, is placed on the same plane as a terrorist group.Although the need to react through strategic communication against propaganda directed at the Union and its citizens is clear, mixing state and non-state actors on the same plane is not an appropriate approach for a resolution by this Parliament.For this reason, I have decided to abstain from voting.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it spoke out on the EU's strategic communication to counter third-party propaganda against it. The EU, its Member States and its citizens are under increasing systematic pressure to take action on information, disinformation and misleading information campaigns and propaganda from countries and non-state actors, such as cross-border terrorist or criminal organizations in the EU's neighborhood. Hostile anti-EU propaganda takes many forms and means, often tailored to the specificities of EU Member States, in order to distort the truth, raise doubts, oppose Member States, promote strategic separation of EU and NATO partners and paralyze the decision-making process, discredit EU institutions . Parliament therefore called on the EU institutions to recognize that strategic communication and the information war were not only an external but also an internal issue for the EU, and also expressed concern at the limited perception of some Member States as propaganda and disinformation audiences and arenas.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of high-quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agree that strategic communication against this propaganda is needed.The EU and its Member States are under increasing, systematic pressure, as they have to deal with information and disinformation campaigns and the propaganda of some countries and non-governmental actors.Information warfare is a historical phenomenon that is as old as warfare itself.It is an essential part of hybrid warfare, a combination of covert and overt military and non-military measures aimed at destabilizing the political, economic and social situation in an attacking country without an official declaration of war.These attacks are not only faced by the EU's partners, but also by the European Union, its institutions, all Member States and citizens, regardless of nationality or religion.It is therefore important that we are aware of the threats and respond to them appropriately.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this EU Strategic Communication Report to combat third-party propaganda against it.Propaganda targets the EU and its citizens, and that is a fact, so the need for a strategic communication reaction is obvious.I also think that mixing state (Russia) and non-state (ISIS) actors is not an adequate approach for such a text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from the vote on the resolution on EU strategic communication to counteract ant-EU propaganda by third parties because I do not believe that this approach to communication can work efficiently in Europe. In fact, I think that EU communication campaigns are more important than campaigns contesting anti-European propaganda. We should focus on the former instead of defending ourselves from the latter.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European Union is a great reality capable of promoting democracy and well-being not only among its citizens but also in neighboring regions. It is an area of ​​freedom that is often seen as an example for peoples who are embarking on the path of integration and respect for the rule of law, but it is also seen as a threat by those who see respect for freedom of thought, speech and religion only a limitation of one's power. Authoritarian and violent realities still surround Europe: Russia and Islamic theocracies still constitute a danger today for those who want to build a free, democratic and open world. These realities carry out intense propaganda to mystify the work of the EU and to strengthen those who work to break it up. We must be aware that a weaker Europe means a strengthening of the authoritarian regimes on our borders, a weaker internal democracy and an impoverishment of the population. We must work to change Europe, to improve it, not to destroy it.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This report aims to counter the propaganda directed against the European Union, which is mainly carried out by ISIS and Russia. Propaganda by the Islamic State to justify their terrorist acts which have recently hit France and Belgium; Russian propaganda to discredit and weaken the European Union and its institutions. By associating a criminal and terrorist organization with a major international power, the European Union is helping to stir up tensions with Russia. This report uses our basic rights such as freedom of expression, freedom of the press and political pluralism as pretexts to carry out an anti-Russian information campaign and to marginalize Russia in our trade and diplomatic relations. We consider, on the contrary, that we must pacify and intensify our relations with all the great international powers, in particular to bring about the emergence of a multipolar world. This is the reason why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - EU Member States and their citizens are facing increasing pressure from misinformation and propaganda from countries and non-state actors. Neighboring transnational terrorist and criminal organizations, whose interest is to undermine the notion of objective information or ethical journalism by disseminating information in a biased form or as an instrument of political power, seek to attack democratic values ​​and interests. This information war was first used especially by the Soviet Union during the Cold War and has been an intrinsic component of modern hybrid warfare ever since, combining open and masked military and non-military measures. I voted in favor of the EU Strategic Communication Report to counter third-party propaganda against it because I believe that communication is needed as honestly and realistically as possible in order to avoid the misinformation that currently exists in the media. for the well-being and safety of EU Member States and their citizens.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The European Union is often the victim of very negative propaganda coming from certain third countries or groups.It is important to put in place a strategy to set the record straight about the European Union.However, I voted against this report.I do not consider this text to be a good basis for developing this strategy.I do not believe the proposed approach is timely.Moreover, the report puts Daesh and Russia on the same footing.We cannot treat Russia and Daesh the same.It is an insult to the Russian people.Russia is and must remain one of our strategic partners.Daesh is an enemy of the European Union.I remind you that our fellow citizens have been the victims of numerous attacks perpetrated by this Islamist group.For all of these reasons I voted against this report.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: written.- I voted against this resolution as it is a plea rather than a report, far removed from the geopolitical interests of the Union.It is in my opinion unacceptable that he resembles a potential ally such as Russia with Daesh.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on strategic communication of the European Union to counteract the propaganda against it by third parties because this Europe appears under attack from the outside but also from the inside with hostile propaganda towards it that presents itself invarious forms and uses various tools with the aim of distorting the truth, sowing doubt, discrediting the EU institutions themselves in the eyes of citizens.I voted in favor because today, when Europe is in trouble, it is necessary to work to improve, not to eliminate, reducing the economic gaps, working on contents, strengthening the affinities between peoples.Because, as Spinelli, Rossi, Colorni imagined, the Union of Nations must continue to be a solid barrier against wars, prejudices, violations of human rights, isolation, racism, ignorance, provincialism.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Taxpayers’ money should not be used this way.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - This report aims to analyze and counter what is called a "systematic pressure" of information campaigns, disinformation, misinformation and propaganda by third parties whose purpose is to discredit the European Union. The actors in the report are specifically two: Russia and ISIS. I find it unacceptable to equate, or even just deal with in the same relationship, two very different situations whose actors are respectively an important sovereign partner state of the EU and the Member States and a terrorist organization that has committed some of the most serious attacks and acts of violence never carried out. In doing so, the necessary dialogue with an undisputed protagonist of the international scene overlaps with Islamic terrorism that sows terror in Syria, northern Iraq and Europe. The delegation of the 5 Star Movement and I voted against this report because, instead of favoring dialogue and stability, it raises walls and mistrust.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on this highly important issue we have been heavily exposed to in recent years. Threats of disinformation campaigns, spreading misleading and incorrect information through the EU public, are undermining our democracy and trust. As seen in some earlier cases, some of the key decisions of EU citizens have been influenced by such propaganda. As this is a real and serious security threat, we need to be able to come up with efficient tools how to counter it.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: in writing. - Propaganda, misinformation and deliberately manipulated stories disguised as news articles are increasingly flourishing freely. Especially on social media, propaganda is spread systematically. In some places, the spread of propaganda and deliberate manipulation is so great that it can pose a democratic problem. If a population does not have access to a free, critical and professionally competent press, democracy can be undermined and authoritarian forces gain ground. It is important to emphasize that, of course, a clear distinction must be made between criticism and propaganda. Criticism is a fundamental element of a free, democratic society. Thus also criticism of the EU, governments, parties or politicians. Criticism can be both justified or unjustified, constructive or sensationalist. All this a free, democratic society must be able to bear. Propaganda differs by being deliberately and systematically manipulative. Propaganda is also often spread to achieve other goals - e.g. to destabilize a country or territory, to incite hatred against minorities or to encourage acts of violence and war. We neither can nor should accept that this kind of propaganda runs free. That is why we support a number of individual proposals, but do not vote in favor of or against the overall report as we believe that there is a need for a more thorough proposal, preferably on the part of the Commission.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and call on the relevant institutions and authorities of the European Union to closely monitor the sources of funding for anti-European propaganda.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on the European Union's communication strategy to counter propaganda against third parties.Although safeguarding Europe's interests and rights is a normal and legitimate priority, I believe that this report focuses solely on creating impressions against third countries, without promoting sound ideas in favor of Europe.That is why I voted against it.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Negative vote.The report refers to propaganda by ISIS / Daesh and Al-Qaeda to the detriment of Europe, but it is mainly a relationship against Russia and focuses on the means for the EU to support its strategic propaganda campaigns againstof Russia.The Daesh / Russia parallelism also seems absurd.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - The European Union symbolizes and pursues ideals of democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms among which it strenuously includes that of expression. These principles can legitimately give rise to misunderstandings in those who have not understood them or have not struggled to obtain them, however, often, their content is deliberately misrepresented, giving rise to anti-EU (dis) information and propaganda. However, today, actors of a predominantly non-state nature wage campaigns of discredit and hatred against us. Indeed, today's wars more than with arms, equip themselves with tools such as financial speculation and discredit, as has unfortunately also emerged to the detriment of Italy. The role played by the fourth estate enjoys abnormal responsibilities and I therefore vote in favor of the report since I believe that defensive means must be adopted against the hate campaigns undertaken against the Union. I consider it a priority to offer decisive cooperation with social media service providers in the IT sector to stem hate speech and disinformation. At the same time, it is necessary to investigate the socio-demographic reasons that lead to radicalization and to prepare multidimensional institutional tools that link academic research, prison administration, police, justice, social services and education.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against it by third parties.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing.- It is undeniable that there are a number of organizations and even states committed to promoting propaganda and counter-information against the European Union.From terrorist organizations like Daesh to states like Russia, disinformation efforts have multiplied.Equally worrying has been the use of the Internet and social networks to incite hatred and violence.The Union cannot and must not renounce its principles of respect for the freedom of expression and the independence of the media, but it has an obligation to react.I particularly welcome the "Action Plan for Strategic Communication" and the need to support media freedom within the framework of the European Neighborhood Policy, and thus support the report by Mrs Fotyga.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted for the report because we must take massive and united action against the online propaganda carried out by terrorist organizations and countries such as Russia, which fuels fear and insecurity and threatens to divide Europe.We need a comprehensive approach here, because only then will we be able to defend ourselves against state and non-state actors who pose a threat to us and our partners.I therefore welcome the call for greater coordination at national and European level, because this is the only way we can effectively combat disinformation and propaganda.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the EU should consider its strategic communication efforts as a priority to demonstrate how it is a successful model of integration which continues, amid crisis, to attract countries wanting to replicate this model and become part of it. No soft power strategy can succeed without cultural diplomacy and promotion of intercultural dialogue between and within countries, something which, as the report states, should encourage long-term public and cultural diplomacy actions and initiatives, such as scholarships and exchange programmes for students and young professionals, including initiatives to support intercultural dialogue. We should counteract efforts to discredit EU institutions and transatlantic partnerships, which play a recognised role in the European security and economic architecture, in the eyes and minds of EU citizens and of citizens of neighbouring countries. This would indirectly undermine our efforts as Europeans to be effective in actions based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law; one of the most important tools used is incitement of fear and uncertainty in EU citizens. Finally, I support the rapporteur in his call to tackle radicalisation and terrorist propaganda though enhanced Member States’ and EU cooperation by granting the EU the means to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - We are here before one more example of Russophobia in this Parliament, which constantly exaggerates the differences between Russia and the Union. The report is a frontal attack on the media, calling for the use of NATO instruments, such as the Center of Excellence for Strategic Communications (COE STRATCOM), to combat the Russian media. In addition, it calls for direct support to "independent" media, which is a paradox, since by sponsoring them from European organizations, these media would obviously cease to be independent. Not content with this, in the report, and following this paranoid anti-Russian rhetoric, it is argued that "the security and intelligence services conclude that Russia has the capacity and intention to carry out operations aimed at destabilizing other countries", continuing with the militaristic rhetoric and engaging in an unacceptable escalation of tension. The report identifies two threats related to propaganda: a state actor, Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh, and focuses on giving the Union the means to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns, mainly against Russia, a UN country to who puts the same level of threat as Daesh. My vote was clearly against.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - European citizens are exposed to disinformation and propaganda campaigns by third countries and non-state actors that endanger the concept of objective information or ethical journalism, making factious information or a pure instrument of political power. Two clear examples are both the propaganda war and the intrusion of the Russian media in the countries of the eastern neighborhood, and the direct propaganda and communication strategies implemented by ISIS / Daesh, Al-Qaeda through social media. I voted in favor of this resolution, because it brings to European attention, and not only, a sensitive but underestimated issue, which has a major impact on EU citizens, especially the youngest. Furthermore, the resolution suggests some measures to counter the propaganda. I believe that the strategic communication plan in the "Joint Framework to Counter Hybrid Threats" is effective and support further efforts towards greater coordination between Member States, NATO, the European Endowment for Democracy, the OSCE and the EU institutions. Another useful tool, the two weekly newsletters of the EU Strategic Communication Task Force that each Member State could make available to its citizens to raise public awareness of the propaganda methods used by third parties.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on EU strategic communication to counter hostile third party propaganda.Although it may seem that the issue of propaganda is a legacy of the past, in some countries it still remains an important tool in the hands of the authorities to manipulate public opinion in order to implement their own policies.Creating false awareness among citizens through disinformation activities is commonplace in the Russian Federation.Propaganda also serves the effective recruitment of ISIS fighters.Recognizing the need to act in this matter, it is necessary to create strategies to counteract the propaganda applied towards the EU and its Member States at various levels.One of the proposed solutions is to support organizations and special groups that deal with eliminating this phenomenon.Given the seriousness of the problem, I voted in favor.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe that the key to countering messages which encourage anti-Europe sentiments is by empowering our citizens with correct, concise information. I believe that to strengthen European relations with the rest of the globe, it is essential to use the tool of diplomacy to ensure mutual agreement on matters which effect the EU and beyond.  As technology continues to grow, it is also important that we focus on countering negative messages with positive ones within the framework of growing technology through strategic diplomatic communication and cooperation between the Member States and beyond.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report covers propaganda activities carried out by third parties against the European Union and its Member States. The report assesses what strategy the European Union can adopt to counter communication, particularly from third countries. While the Islamic State carries out very aggressive propaganda to recruit young people, promote radical Islam, undermine European values ​​and interests and incite hatred against them, it is only mentioned once in this report. report. Conversely, Russia is cited 25 times, this difference in treatment between, on the one hand, the propaganda of the Islamic State, our enemy, and Russia, which remains, despite our fundamental disagreements, an essential partner, is not free from ulterior motives and confusions. Although I share the idea that such counter-propaganda work is necessary, I also consider that these ambiguities undermine the objective defended by the report. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- The report on the Union's strategic communication aimed at countering propaganda directed against it by third parties underlines that the European Union is facing increasing pressure from propaganda and disinformation campaigns from state and non-state actors.We must fight against all forms of propaganda, whether it emanates from TV stations, agencies or the Internet.I support several of the provisions of this text, and in particular those encouraging better cooperation with social networks to fight hate speech, incitement to violence and discrimination online.However, the numerous blunders and the lack of coherence of this report justify my abstention on this text.In particular, it does not seem wise to me to combine the communication strategies of the terrorist organization of the Islamic State, which perverts our youth, with those of Russia.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- The report on the Union’s strategic communication to counter propaganda directed against it by third parties urges the Commission to promote better communication at Union level.It is important to put in place a comprehensive strategy to combat all forms of disinformation and propaganda, of which Europe is increasingly the victim.In terms of security, I believe that measures must be put in place to allow Member States to cooperate closely and easily.However, I abstained on this report because several inaccuracies and clumsiness make it inconsistent.In particular, the reconciliation that is made between the communication strategies of the Islamic State and those of Russia does not seem relevant to me.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - On the occasion of this report, I would like to reiterate the importance of combating propaganda on the internet regardless of the issuer. I am concerned about the slippage that I see taking place in the qualification of what really is information. I have in mind the American election where the responsibility of social media is evident in Trump's victory. As with Brexit, they relayed massively false information that is the bedrock of extreme postures. These platforms have become media that people consult to form an opinion. However, it is not about media in the traditional sense. Operating in a closed circuit, depending on the "friends" you follow, you have no access to a contradictory point of view. The positions pass there, without putting into perspective, without hierarchy. Worse, some topics give rise to pitched battles where hate speech feeds into shocking videos whose source is unverifiable. It is a central question of the future of our democracies to supervise these practices and to put in place the necessary safeguards: the fight against the concentration of the media and their freedom everywhere in the world, education too.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing.- I voted against this report and I abstained on the separate votes which took place on the different paragraphs.I did it on purpose.Of course, I agree on the need for the EU to put in place an effective and democratic strategy to combat hostile propaganda.But I cannot bring myself to put almost on the same footing the countermeasures to be opposed to Putin's Russia and those which aim to respond to the criminal fanatics of Daesh who slit the throats of innocent people and plan deadly attacks on European soil.I condemn Putin's authoritarian behavior and Russia's belligerent posture, but that does not justify putting them in the same bag as ISIS's bloodthirsty barbarians.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.This report deals with hybrid threats against the European Union, allegedly emanating from ISIS and Russia.We cannot support a text which operates a crude amalgamation between a sovereign State and a terrorist organization.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- negative.The report equates Russian propaganda with that of ISIS, thus constituting a text that is untrue.It does not serve the needs of the EU to deal with any anti-propaganda.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of high-quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on strategic communication to counteract anti-EU propaganda by third parties. Cyber warfare is increasingly used in several countries together with restrictions on the freedoms of independent media and civil society. This is unacceptable to the people in Wales that I represent who value the freedom of the press. We have been all too aware in the past year what a huge impact disinformation and misinformation campaigns can have on our society.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- In a world where information flows play an increasingly important role in people's perception of what is happening in the outside world, it is important that we mark against those who want us badly.Although the report goes beyond the scope in several respects, it is important that the EU takes these challenges seriously and finds concrete policy measures to address misinformation.I voted in favor of this report, despite its somewhat erroneous scope - it is particularly unfortunate to confuse IS and Russia.The latter is a sovereign state and the other a terrorist organization.In its entirety, however, the report fills a vacuum, especially as the challenges become increasingly apparent and stressful for the Union and its functioning - it is for this reason that I choose to show my support for the report as such.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: this report is a testimony both of the obsidional drift of the European Union, which fails to have any consistency, tries to manifest its existence by manipulating fears, and of the enslavement that theThe EU constitutes for international life as it is outside the limits of diplomacy to amalgamate in such a crude way a sovereign state and a terrorist organization.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report is nothing more than an element of deepening the reactionary and anti-democratic character of the European Union. Starting from the values ​​it claims to defend, it includes in its scope the freedoms of communication, information and expression. Values ​​that EU policies contradict and compromise, of which the most crude example is the humanitarian crisis of migrants and refugees. It integrates a victimization strategy, building a supposed context of offensive against the EU, in an alleged unprecedented information war, a powerful media offensive, it is said, compromising its territorial integrity and the sovereignty of States, seeking the internal destabilization of the EU and NATO members. External intervention and interference is openly promoted in a speech that is not lacking in a drab and backward anti-communist rhetoric, seeking to confuse today's capitalist Russia with the USSR. Arguments used to move towards the limitation and more control of the media, the internet, school programs and even political parties. The EU's information is made absolutely true, distinguishing between propaganda and criticism, marking what is acceptable criticism. Thus, the doors of censorship that so many black pages wrote on European soil are opened. Practices worthy of authoritarian and dictatorial regimes. We voted against.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - A constructive criticism of the European Union is very important for its proper functioning. Nobody questions that. Thanks to it, the European Union is a successful project that has helped ensure more than 70 years of peaceful coexistence in Europe. There is still room for improvement, but the prevailing interest of other countries to get involved is also an important measure. However, objective criticism cannot be confused with the open lies and propaganda to which the EU, its liberal-democratic establishment and the Member States themselves are exposed. Russia is a key global player. Our common interest should be to combat radicalization and atrocities, which are currently mainly represented by Daesh. Instead of cooperating, however, we are witnessing various efforts to weaken European cohesion. This is done, for example, through the financial support of populist and extreme right-wing parties and movements in individual states. Part of this agenda is to present various aspects of the undemocratic establishment and states as stronger than they really are. Incitement to hatred, restrictions on the rights of certain sections of the population or violence cannot be considered as freedom of expression. Defense against such conduct, whether on social networks but also in real life, must be our primary goal.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report which places a state like Russia on the same level of threat as Daesh and recognizes European propaganda as the only possible one.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing.- I am pleased that the report has been adopted.Thanks to everyone who contributed to this.I devote my personal work on it to the latePresident of the Republic of Poland Lech Kaczyński and all other victims of the Smolensk catastrophe.The circumstances of their deaths were the subject of a huge wave of lies and propaganda manipulation on the part of the Kremlin.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the EU communication strategy for counter-propaganda.I believe that the report moves against the peoples and nations, purely in favor of the United States, while the interests of the banks prevail.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that Russians’ activities in Europe represent a hybrid threat that seeks to influence public opinion and decision-making processes, clearly aiming to weaken EU coherence and undermine EU policies. Nowadays we have to face a wide range of dangers, including the hacking of emails and websites, media manipulation, backing for anti-government demonstrations and political support for Russia-friendly populist parties. I support the report as I believe we need to start taking the actions of third parties as a very serious threat for our peace and stability and to tackle information, disinformation and misinformation campaigns and propaganda from countries and non-state actors. Moreover, it is time to develop a counter-narrative to ISIL/Daesh involving the education system, including through the empowerment and increased visibility of mainstream Muslim scholars who have the credibility to delegitimise ISIL/Daesh propaganda.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
