text: written.- I voted in favor of the report considering that the Union, its Member States and its citizens are under increasing systematic pressure to deal with information campaigns, disinformation and intoxication and propaganda by countries and non-state actors, as transnational terrorist and criminal organizations in neighboring countries.Freedom of the media, access to information and freedom of expression are cornerstones of the Union's democratic system.We must bear in mind that strategic communication and the information war is not only an external issue to the Union, but also an internal one, so the Union must consider its strategic communication as a priority, allocating the relevant resources to it.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I abstained on the vote on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against it by third parties because, although I firmly believe it is essential to protect European citizens from media disinformation attacks from by third countries and by non-state actors such as criminal organizations, in this specific case the resolution ventures a comparison between the information activity of the Kremlin and that of terrorist groups such as ISIS / Daesh. I believe it is essential to support the commitment that the EU has made to achieve the principles of democracy which are also manifested through media freedom, free access to information and a guaranteed plurality of information. I firmly believe that there is a need to counter all actions of political media propaganda aimed at distorting the truth and creating a division between the Member States, publicly weakening the credibility of EU actions, but it is necessary, at the same time , a discernment between the different modus operandi as in this case.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted for the very good report by my group colleague Anna Fotyga on “Strategic communication by the EU in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties”.He speaks plain language and names things by name that each and every one of us comes across when using twitter and facebook on a daily basis: deliberately disseminated disinformation and propaganda against the EU - often starting from Russian servers.We are talking about a new, digital form of the Cold War.It is important to prepare for this - in the interests of our citizens.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- At the moment the European Union sees itself more and more clearly threatened by state and non-state actors.In the area of communication, the increased threat level is mainly expressed through propaganda directed against them.In order to be able to counter such threat situations in a more cohesive manner in the future, greater coordination among the member states must be promoted.Furthermore, cooperation between the European Union and the NATO Center of Excellence for Strategic Communication should be expanded.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The recent breakdown in relations between the west and Russia, of which both parties are guilty, has produced far more insecurity in Europe. Diplomacy and deterrence are delicate mechanisms. I feel uneasy with the constant peddling of aggression and justifications for more EU action.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. ‒ While I fully understand the essential need to counteract propaganda and disinformation by third parties that directly threaten the values and the stability of the Union, I simultaneously believe that in order to achieve this goal, our strategic communication must meet some basic requirements: 1) It should observe fundamental European values, such as freedom of expression and  freedom of the press; 2) it should be sensible to the different political natures of the parties involved; and 3) it must be effective – and at least not counter-productive. After a long and careful evaluation, I understand that the final report does not sufficiently meet these three basic requirements: 1) The idea of a free and independent media is hard to reconcile with the proactive training and support of these same Media by the EU itself; 2) The report puts Russia, a nation-state with a long history, at a same level as Daesh, an accidental pseudo-state and a terrorist group; failing to recognize the long-term need of a peaceful cooperation between Russia and the Union, specially where our interests overlap; 3) I thus believe that the implementation of this strategy may unnecessarily escalate on going conflicts and don’t serve its own strategic priority.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: in writing.- By a dubious amalgamation - Russia is compared to the Islamic State - this report enacts the strategy to be pursued against "propaganda directed against it by third parties".This report is itself totalitarian in this case, denouncing the fact that criticism is leveled against it within the EU itself, but also outside.And of course, this liberticidal report in no way defines an effective strategy against Daesh.For these reasons, I opposed this report.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - Paragraph 1 of this report says, overall, that "hostile propaganda against the European Union" aims "to distort the truth, to instill doubt, to divide the Member States [...], to paralyze the decision-making process, to discredit the institutions of the Union and the transatlantic partnerships ”, by inciting fear and uncertainty. The targeted propagandists are Russia and Daesh, in a hallucinatory amalgamation of bad faith. No mercy for Russia and its supporters, a search for excuses for those whom Daesh radicalizes. It seems to me that the European Union and the technocrats who run it with the complicity of European governments are doing very well to succeed in provoking the rejection of what they are: by the policies they lead or impose, by the absence of transparency, by the contempt they have for the opinion of the people, by their societal and immigrationist choices ... They themselves constantly practice disinformation, massive and partial propaganda, favorable to the TTIP , hostile to Russia or to Eurosceptics, promoting the European Union as the only legitimate form of European cooperation. In fact, you would like to institute information control for your own benefit and that of your dogmas. I refuse this censorship.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted against this report on the Union's strategic communication against third-party propaganda, because it makes an analysis that leaves out many aspects of the geopolitical reality in which the Union currently finds itself.Encouraging hate and fear speech seems to us to be an ineffective way of ending the discursive threats the Union receives.The analysis and tone of the entire report is partial and untrue, and it is also situated in a political line opposite to ours in matters of Foreign Policy.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: in writing.- Disinformation and all forms of propaganda are a danger, especially on the internet.We must fight against them wherever they emanate.However, this report is ill-conceived.It lacks the rigor that quality information requires by amalgamating.This is the reason why I abstained, less on the substance than on the method.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the final vote on this resolution. Labour MEPs agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity; and putting ISIS on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that supporting quality and independent journalism more actively is the way forward.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written.- For us Swedish Social Democrats, the EU is a collaboration where we rely on free debate and free media.We would like to see initiatives for more open debate and critical source scrutiny to raise awareness of incorrect information disseminated within the EU, but believe that the report does not take a particularly constructive stance in this regard.The fact that the text only deals with a few actors when the use of propaganda occurs in several countries around the world is problematic from our perspective.We are particularly opposed to a non-state actor, in particular the terrorist organization IS / Daish, being placed in the text in the same context, and treated in a similar way, as a state actor (Russia).We believe that this gives IS / Daish a form of legitimacy that the EU has been trying to avoid for many years and that we cannot support.All in all, this meant that we chose not to take a position on the report on strategic communication.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I supported the report to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of training journalists for a high standard of qualitative analysis and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives against targeted misinformation.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - The report identifies two threats to propaganda: a state agency, namely Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh. This indirect attempt to connect the two is by no means accidental, as it attempts to present Russia's role in Eastern Europe similar to that of Daesh in the Middle East. This is inadmissible for us. The report also lists a number of synergies that the European Union and the Member States should work with in cooperation with NATO to address these situations. For these reasons, we consider this attitude of voting against to be appropriate.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. While I think that the safety of European citizens is of paramount importance, and equally, that they should not be subject to propaganda and misinformation at the hands of foreign entities, I do not believe it is appropriate to class ISIS/Daesh on a par with the Russian Federation. In doing so, we risk legitimising and recognising the terrorist group as the government of the area in which they exert de facto control.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written. - The report on “The EU's strategic communication in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties” is problematic. The primary concern is to combat propaganda by extraterritorial actors, namely Russia and IS, and to set up counter-propaganda. The fact that there is Russian propaganda is undisputed and is also proven, for example, by NATO documents. In Eastern Europe in particular, where the media in smaller countries are often relatively financially weak, there is a risk of a Russian-dominated one-sidedness of the information offered. Some states also supported political parties within the EU with substantial amounts. The question, however, is how to identify this propaganda and how to restrict it without damaging the public's interest in information. When weighing both concerns, a weighing must be made. Is the danger from third party propaganda to be rated higher than the danger of important information being censored by the EU? After considering the matter, I decided to vote in favor of the report, despite serious reservations.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of high-quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted against the European Union's Strategic Communication Report on Combating Third-Party Propaganda (2016/2030 (INI)), given that the report deals simultaneously with Russia and ISIL / Daesh, and I believe that the EU's attitude towards one countrythat is, a terrorist organization cannot be treated in the same way and does not represent the same level of problems that the EU should face in the same way in the same document.In addition, the reduction of different issues and problems as discussed in this report could lead to different interpretations of the relationship with these third parties and could diminish the reputation of the EU Parliament as a significant and internationally recognized institution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The aim of this report is to fight against hybrid threats directed, it seems, against the European Union and carried out by Russia and the "Islamic State" group.This is the emanation of a desire for existence which, failing to be a verified reality within community borders, manifests itself in the confusion and manipulation of minds, so much the amalgamation between an important Stateand sovereign and a terrorist organization appears as a crude provocation.I voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing.- I believe that freedom of expression must remain one of the fundamental pillars of the European Union.However, a distinction needs to be made between freedom of speech and propaganda.Campaigns that deliberately and systematically disinform not only EU citizens need to be combated and not underestimated.I supported this initiative, which aimed to combat the dissemination of false information from third countries.Intolerant rhetoric in general must not be overlooked, and in particular that which comes from within terrorist groups, it must not be tolerated in any form.I am glad that the European Parliament has decided to go against the reaction and that Europe will not remain passive in this area.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: written.- The SP recognizes the dangers of disinformation from third parties, such as Russia and IS, but has abstained because the report makes too many calls for things that we do not support, such as the strengthening of the European External Action Service (EEAS) and closer cooperation with NATO.Moreover, the report is not critical enough with regard to the EU information supply.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted against the report by my colleague Anna Fotyga on the Union's communication aimed at countering propaganda directed against it by third parties.Committed to the desire to promote the European Union's external action in its fight against terrorism and against foreign propaganda, I could not nevertheless support this report which tends to put Russia and the “Islamic State” group on the sameplan.Even though Russia can carry out propaganda operations within the European Union, it seemed to me inappropriate to compare this situation to the terrorist propaganda of the group "Islamic State", which has already caused too many victims onour territory.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because I do not believe that putting the Islamic State group and Russia on the same level serves European interests.The propaganda carried out by Russia is in no way comparable to the deadly propaganda of the "Islamic State" group.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The report as a whole is to be rejected.He criticizes the media plurality created by social media and even equates it with an “information war or hybrid warfare”, which must be better controlled, but at the same time wants the EU to promote media plurality in other countries by increasing its presence in social networks.Mentioning a Russian “propaganda war” that is said to be expanding rapidly in Eastern Europe is not expedient.It is particularly noteworthy that the report goes into detail on the propaganda war and the lack of media plurality in Russia, but only finally cites IS and al-Qaeda, and not a single sentence was written about the lack of media plurality and censorship in Turkey.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: in writing.- Russia's anti-Western propaganda has been observed for some time.This is best seen in Russia's border countries, which used to be part of the Soviet Union, including Latvia.This propaganda is nothing but public misinformation aimed at dividing society.I believe that the European Parliament's resolution is a step in the right direction to combat this propaganda, which is why I supported this resolution in plenary.The first step in a successful fight against propaganda is to realize that such an information war is unfolding and to inform the public about it.The European Union must take appropriate steps to counter the heavy artillery of the Kremlin's disinformation, but the people themselves must assess the information, its content and its objectivity.

name: Jan KELLER
text: in writing.- I consider Mrs Fotyga's report on the desirability of counter-propaganda against Russia and the Islamic State to be very bad.The whole report is written in a language we know intimately from a period when there was no right to be divided.The report is filled with suspicion of those who dare to think critically, and is outlined against all those who are allegedly "hiding behind freedom of speech."The author of the report tends to divide people into those who are incapable of their own judgment and those who are called to tell them the only valid truth.I well remember that the same argument was made in the times of Husák's normalization, which is why I voted against this report.I could understand the tone of the message if it were part of Putin's propaganda.However, I find the opinion of the European Parliament undignified.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. ‒ EPLP abstained on the final vote on the resolution. We agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as a propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity; and putting ISIS on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that supporting quality and independent journalism more actively is the way forward.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing. - Propaganda, misinformation and deliberately manipulated stories disguised as news articles are increasingly flourishing freely. Especially on social media, propaganda is spread systematically. In some places, the spread of propaganda and deliberate manipulation is so great that it can pose a democratic problem. If a population does not have access to a free, critical and professionally competent press, democracy can be undermined and authoritarian forces gain ground. It is important to emphasize that, of course, a clear distinction must be made between criticism and propaganda. Criticism is a fundamental element of a free, democratic society. Thus also criticism of the EU, governments, parties or politicians. Criticism can be both justified or unjustified, constructive or sensationalist. All this a free, democratic society must be able to bear. Propaganda differs by being deliberately and systematically manipulative. Propaganda is also often spread to achieve other goals - e.g. to destabilize a country or territory, to incite hatred against minorities or to encourage acts of violence and war. We neither can nor should accept that this kind of propaganda runs free. That is why we support a number of individual proposals, but do not vote in favor of or against the overall report as we believe that there is a need for a more thorough proposal, preferably on the part of the Commission.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - Mrs Fotyg's report appears to be erroneously mentioned in the EU's strategic communication to combat third-party propaganda against it. A cursory glance at the 58-point text shows that, in fact, the report focuses on how to propaganda in third countries against their current regimes. It is emphasized on several occasions that the work of the Big Brother, the United States, is a good example to individual EU countries. Russophobia, which is characteristic of a significant part of the Polish political scene, finds its expression in the division of the report. After the introductory points, we first find a beautifully called chapter entitled Understanding and Revealing the Russian Disinformation and Propaganda War. After 9 points imbued with crackling Russophobia, the bigoted Catholic deals with the methods of the Islamic State. And in all 8 points. Thus, in her eyes, Islamic radicals and their methods of radicalizing a relatively large Muslim community within the EU seem to be significantly less dangerous than Russia, which refuses to become a raw material pendant for EU states. In the following paragraphs, we will read, for example, that "and calls on the Member States to adapt and update their legislation" or "to fully implement and enforce existing legislation on hate speech". If I take this wording seriously, the author of the report will certainly soon be investigated, probably in Poland, for the spread of morphobia.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - The report on “The EU's strategic communication in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties” is problematic. The primary concern is to combat propaganda by extraterritorial actors, namely Russia and IS, and to set up counter-propaganda. The fact that there is Russian propaganda is undisputed and is also proven, for example, by NATO documents. In Eastern Europe in particular, where the media in smaller countries are often relatively financially weak, there is a risk of a Russian-dominated one-sidedness of the information offered. Some states also supported political parties within the EU with substantial amounts. The question, however, is how to identify this propaganda and how to restrict it without damaging the public's interest in information. When weighing both concerns, a weighing must be made. Is the danger from third party propaganda to be rated higher than the danger of important information being censored by the EU? After considering the matter, I decided to vote in favor of the report, despite serious reservations.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of high-quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since the report is highly biased and misleading as far as it concerns to the sources of anti-EU propaganda. Instead of truly working to address the real threats coming from Daesh, this report was drafted to finance anti-Russian propaganda from the EU budget. Here I believe we have a contradiction in terms since ‘independent media’ which will be in charge of counter-propaganda is going to be financed by the EU, therefore not leaving much options for the latter to be truly independent.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing. - It is common practice for the authors of reports to create a tying by voting for a piece of material that is unacceptable, with reference to health, human or minority rights, the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises, and so on. As a result, I’ve come across a lot in the EP already, but not with such roughly slippery material yet. In a report, linking the activities of the national press in a state governed by the rule of law to the propaganda machine of the world’s current largest terrorist organization, putting an equal sign between the two, is hair-raising. But this has been further enhanced by the rapporteur asking for the means of a propaganda campaign against the EU to fight the state actor. He does not want to harass terrorists because he thinks they are harmless. Anyone with open eyes and ears in the world will notice the unheard-of media predominance of NGOs and the press, which are abundantly funded by overseas capital, but may even be aware of the writings of Udo Ulfkotte and other fact-finding agents. Doesn’t this kind of harsh propaganda intervention sting the eyes of those involved? Deeply irresponsible, the report is blatantly extreme and it is very sad that the existing democracy is so deep.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - It should not be unclear to anyone that disinformation, false news and propaganda are harmful to both citizens and states. The post-fact era serves riding populism with lies and provocation and eats up a European value base that includes freedom and democracy. There are good and worthwhile ideas in the resolution. However, I do not believe that equating Russia with ISIS will facilitate the necessary dialogue. The resolution also uses the term “war” (information war, propaganda war, etc.) for Russian actions. At a time when Russia is also waging a real war, it does not make sense to talk about war in situations where there are rather attempts at influence or propaganda. The EU is currently trying to put pressure on Russia to behave better. Attempts to put pressure from economic sanctions to declarations have not led Russia to change its behavior. The pressure can still be exerted, but at the same time I would like to see strong EU support for Russia's own NGOs and part of its opposition. Change also requires pressure from within. I abstained because, although there are many good points in the report, its shortcomings are too great for me to accept.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The European Union, despite the various challenges and threats it faces, has been able to defend the founding principles of integration, unity, determination and cooperation, and therefore represents a model to follow. Nevertheless, among the various threats, the EU is increasingly subject to hostile propaganda, aimed at sowing terror, insecurity, aimed at discrediting institutions and questioning democratic values, the rule of law and human rights. The report, therefore, points out the main actors of this propaganda, including some terrorist groups, and emphasizes the need for the Union to focus on communication strategies aimed at countering the threat of disinformation promoted by such propaganda. The proposal calls for greater cooperation between Member States; the provision of relevant resources to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns and capable of exposing and dealing with the ISIS / Daesh war of disinformation and radicalization; as well as a strategy at the European level capable of countering this hostile propaganda. Consequently, I express my favorable opinion on the report on strategic communication by the European Union to counteract the propaganda against it by third parties.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing.- The European Union is often targeted by propaganda campaigns from state and non-state actors, which threaten the Union itself and the Member States.This concerns more particularly the group "Islamic State", whose propaganda aims to recruit young people, promote radical Islamism, harm European values and interests or incite hatred against our peoples.Our commitment must be total in the face of this scourge.Some actions taken by Russia are also ambiguous.However, contrary to what the report proposes, I believe that it is desirable to maintain diplomatic and political relations with this country.For this reason, I preferred to abstain on the final vote.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The central theme here is the fight against hybrid threats potentially directed against the European Union.Within the radius of the identified sources of these threats, they are two, placed on an equal footing: Russia and the "Islamic State" group.We can observe here all the obsessional drifts of the EU which, failing to have any existence in the field of defense and security policy, tries to manifest its existence by manipulating fears and distorting reality to amalgamatebetween Russia - a sovereign state - and the group "Islamic State" - a terrorist organization.I can only oppose a shamefully distorting and disturbing view, and have voted AGAINST this web of dishonesty.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - We are here before one more example of Russophobia in this Parliament, which constantly exaggerates the differences between Russia and the Union. The report is a frontal attack on the media, calling for the use of NATO instruments, such as the Center of Excellence for Strategic Communications (COE STRATCOM), to combat the Russian media. In addition, it calls for direct support to "independent" media, which is a paradox, since by sponsoring them from European organizations, these media would obviously cease to be independent. Not content with this, in the report, and following this paranoid anti-Russian rhetoric, it is argued that "the security and intelligence services conclude that Russia has the capacity and intention to carry out operations aimed at destabilizing other countries", continuing with the militaristic rhetoric and engaging in an unacceptable escalation of tension. The report identifies two threats related to propaganda: a state actor, Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh, and focuses on giving the Union the means to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns, mainly against Russia, a UN country to who puts the same level of threat as Daesh. My vote was clearly against.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - This report addresses the issue of cybersecurity, especially the attacks suffered by the Union by the media and propaganda that seek to discredit it and its institutions. It also focuses on the fight against Daesh propaganda on the internet. The report proposes, among others, to study the sources of funding for anti-European propaganda, to increase the visibility of moderate Muslim academics who have credibility to delegitimize the propaganda of Daesh and to create a site, in social networks widely used to discredit the Union and incite hatred, aimed at the general public that groups together the different media aimed at detecting misinformation and explains how it works. I give my vote in favor of the report, because it is important to put an end to the misinformation that ultimately threatens something as important as being able to access objective and quality information from citizens, which is essential to be able to train in a society democratic and legal.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - The report on “The EU's strategic communication in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties” is problematic. The primary concern is to combat propaganda by extraterritorial actors, namely Russia and IS, and to set up counter-propaganda. The fact that there is Russian propaganda is undisputed and is also proven, for example, by NATO documents. In Eastern Europe in particular, where the media in smaller countries are often relatively financially weak, there is a risk of a Russian-dominated one-sidedness of the information offered. Some states also supported political parties within the EU with substantial amounts. The question, however, is how to identify this propaganda and how to restrict it without damaging the public's interest in information. When weighing both concerns, a weighing must be made. Is the danger from third party propaganda to be rated higher than the danger of important information being censored by the EU? After considering the matter, I decided to vote in favor of the report, despite serious reservations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ Disinformation, propaganda and fake news are having an impact on the proper function of European democracy. Europe needs to enhance cooperation with third parties to combat this threat effectively.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The EU is committed to conducting its activities on the international stage according to principles such as democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and freedom of the media, access to information, freedom of expression and media pluralism and the like. The report emphasizes that hostile propaganda against the EU takes various forms and uses various means, tailored to the profiles of member states, to distort the truth, arouse suspicion, divide Member States and cause disagreement between the European Union and its North American partners. The means used for propaganda purposes are to provoke fear and insecurity in EU citizens and to present hostile state and non-state actors stronger and more successful than they really are. The report emphasizes that strategic communication and information warfare are an external and internal problem of the EU and expresses concern that hostile propaganda is used by a number of disseminators within the EU. Russia invests significant financial resources in its disinformation and propaganda instruments applied either directly through state channels or through Kremlin-controlled companies and organizations. They also often provide financial support to political extremists and large-scale disinformation campaigns in the mass media. The report encourages the governments of the Member States to be cautious about Russian information operations in Europe and to share capacity and counter such operations, so I supported this report.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: In written form. - On 23 November, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on EU Strategic Communication to oppose propaganda against the European Union by third countries. The development of technology and communication offers more and more opportunities to exercise the freedoms of citizens and journalists. At the same time, the Internet, as a dual-use tool, poses a number of dangers. The EU must make every effort to preserve the values ​​of democratic and media pluralism, freedom of speech, but also to ensure that its citizens are well informed. The naming of direct threats in the face of Russian propaganda and the disinformation campaign of constructs such as Daesh is a key element in building a more effective EU communication policy. The only possible response of the European Union is to promote media freedom, strengthen the role of the Strategic Communication Task Force and ensure greater visibility of the Union's achievements. I believe that the truth is the strongest weapon in the fight against disinformation in the post-truth era, and I would welcome further EU action in this direction.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing.- Parliament voted in favor of a low-quality propaganda product that discredits the European Union.In one report, merging a terrorist organization with a particular country is a vivid propaganda technique.The main goal is clear: to show that Russia and Daesh are almost the same.So far, I think that the European Union has a firm moral position that propaganda can be fought with facts and objectivity.When Parliament voted in favor of this report, I realized that I was wrong.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - How the EU can deal with information warfare and propaganda depends on the responsibility of every politician, every public figure.Transparency in action and expression in all policy areas, together with the emphasis on citizens' right to information, quality education, personal responsibility and fair punishment in the event of breaches of the law, can prevent the spread of lies, wrongdoing and targeted manipulation.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- This report focuses on the Union’s strategic communication aimed at countering propaganda directed against it by third parties.This report makes a number of proposals in order to effectively tackle the spread of disinformation hostile to the EU.Beyond the lack of substance on the means of implementing these proposals, the text focuses on two threats: one from Russia, the other from the "Islamic State" group.These two entities are treated identically despite being a state on the one hand and a terrorist organization on the other.Despite the usefulness of seeking to fight against propaganda directed against the EU, the too many vagueness and confusion within this text prompt me to abstain.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the EU Communication Strategy for Countering Propaganda against Third Parties, as this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- I completely oppose this report because the European Union seems to perceive the flexibility and uncontrollability of messages on social media as a threat and wants to counteract the inability to act in a manner similar to censorship.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.In recent years, European countries have been facing particularly intense propaganda and disinformation campaigns aimed at questioning fundamental, European-cherished, democratic values, destroying the unity of the EU Member States, and causing destruction.Through various channels and methods, these campaigns are carried out by both Russia and terrorist groups.The most realistic European response to these campaigns is to raise public awareness of the specificities of these campaigns, the customers, the sources of funding and the real intentions.Education is the most important factor in enabling citizens to critically analyze media content and respond to misinformation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - The acute paranoia of this parliament is limitless. Convinced of a forthcoming Russian attack on the EU, he brings out the vocabulary of the Cold War and is the first actor in the escalation of tensions with Russia. This counter-propaganda report begins by comparing a UN Security Council member state with a terrorist organization. For the rest, you can look under the microscope for measures against the group "Islamic State". The object is to denounce a "propaganda war" orchestrated by Moscow against the European Union. Those who oppose a "positive narrative" about the EU are repainted as "extremists and populists", who would dare to break the cohesion of the "West". The report calls for promoting "independent" media in the EU and Russia ... by funding them with EU money. Funny vision of independence. "There is a need to critically assess how to deal with media sources that are proven to have been repeatedly involved in a strategy of willful deception and disinformation" and track down elected officials who venture to meet their Russian counterparts. I vote against this dangerous block against block logic!

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The aim is to fight against the so-called “hybrid” threats directed against the European Union itself by Russia and the “Islamic State” group.This report testifies to the drift of the Union, in that, on the one hand, it manipulates fears to arrogate to itself a certain legitimacy and, on the other hand, because it makes an amalgam between a sovereign State anda terrorist organization.I therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Strategic communication and the information war are not only an external issue for the EU but also an internal issue.We have to worry about the growing number of hostile propaganda relays in the Union. The propaganda and disinformation strategy of third countries against the EU can take different forms and involve, in particular, traditional media, social networks, school programs andpolitical parties, both within and outside the European Union.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because while the EU is committed to respecting fundamental freedoms, including media freedom, the third-party actors currently trying to discredit the Union, such as Daesh, do not share the same values. They are using the media to spread misinformation and disinformation, thus violating the principle of imparting objective information through journalism.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written.- The original outline of the report emphasized the need to adopt a clear strategy against hostile propaganda and disinformation spread by third parties, aimed at disrupting Europe and its society and inciting young people to violence against societies in whichthey grew up.That is why I also support all initiatives and instruments that counter messages of hatred and propaganda and make young people and people resilient and immune to the perfidious effects of propaganda.The problem with this report, however, is that in the assessment of the propaganda phenomenon, Russia and the terrorist Daesh are placed on the same level and treated in the same way.Therefore, I did not approve the report, which in no way diminishes the fact that, in my view, propaganda should always be rebuttable and there is no doubt that Daesh's atrocities should be strongly condemned.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - The European Union, its partners, Member States and citizens are currently facing an information war from several sides. The EU is under pressure from 2 mainstream media: Russia, which seeks to disrupt the EU's integration process, and by supporting forces against the Union, in particular extreme right-wing parties, populist movements that deny the fundamental values ​​of liberal democracy. On the other hand, there is propaganda by the terrorist organization Daesh / ISIS, which promotes political, religious and social hate rhetoric at European and global level. As part of the EU's action to combat propaganda, the Union must strengthen cyber security and ensure the resilience of EU information systems. Member States need to work more closely together to protect companies. At home and in their neighborhood, raising awareness, education and literacy about online media is of great importance so that citizens are able to critically evaluate the information they receive. Awareness of radicalization needs to be raised to prevent recruitment, especially of young people. Through its external action, the EU should continue to actively promote respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, in particular freedom of expression, assembly, the right of access to the media and the independence of the media in neighboring countries.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I support the main objectives of the report on the EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against it by third parties, which identifies threats, such as the terrorist group known as Daesh/ ISIS, and suggests countering the propaganda and radicalisation through cooperation between the Member States and the European Institutions.  Having said that, however, the fact that the report is mixing a state such as Russia with non-state actors such as terrorist organisations is not exactly the adequate approach for such a text and therefore I decided to abstain at the final vote.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs aims to tackle radicalism and terrorist propaganda through enhanced cooperation between Member States and the EU. He specifically mentioned two threats: Russia's use of its relations and meetings with EU partners for propaganda purposes rather than a genuine dialogue, and its public weakening of the Union's common position, and the methods of misinformation and radicalization of ISIL / Daesh's information warfare. . It outlines an EU strategy to combat propaganda, focusing on the active promotion of respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, as support for freedom of expression, assembly, the right to information and the independence of the media in neighboring countries strengthens the EU's action against propaganda. . It calls for the strengthening of media pluralism and the objectivity, impartiality and independence of the media, including non-state actors, in the European Union and its neighborhood, and is appalled by the problems with media independence and freedom in some EU Member States. I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- The report proposes to fight against the famous “hybrid threats” which would be threats against the European Union.The threats identified have two sources: Russia and the Islamic State group, placed on an equal footing.This report is a testimony to the drift of the European Union, which tries to manifest its existence by manipulating fears.It is also clearly outside the bounds of diplomacy to so crudely amalgamate a sovereign state and a terrorist organization.Unfavorable vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This report seeks to amalgamate a sovereign state (Russia) and the threat posed by the group “Islamic State”.I vote against.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs abstained on the final vote on the resolution. We agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as a propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity; and putting ISIS on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that supporting quality and independent journalism more actively is the way forward.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this text, which directly accuses Russia of propaganda, of using its networks in Europe to harm our Union and of carrying out mass disinformation campaigns.Such a text, in addition to being totally defamatory towards Russia, also shows the anti-Russian paranoia which unfortunately reigns inside the European Parliament and which has for only consequence a sterile escalation of the sanctions which harm our economies., to our producers and our farmers.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - Propaganda against the European Union is a fact that cannot be denied and that immediately requires a reaction in terms of counter-media communication. The disinformation work perpetrated by Russia and ISIS against the EU and therefore against European values ​​is no longer acceptable. The European Union, which is founded on the values ​​of freedom, equality, democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, access to plural information, cannot accept these behaviors. The violations that Russia has made itself responsible for, annexing Crimea and waging a hybrid war in the Donbass, as well as the continuing interference by the Kremlin in the context of the European media, have strained relations with the Union. On the other hand, the warfare information and communications technologies, which ISIS makes continuous use to justify its actions and recruit young Europeans, represent a real threat to the sovereignty of the Member States and European integrity. For these reasons, I voted in favor of this important resolution, which defines the risks of this information war that brings with it threats to both the external and internal stability of the Union.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- It is important for the European Union to be able to react quickly to any threats that arise.In addition to direct security threats, we also need to address attacks on European values.Anti-EU propaganda is driven by goals such as doubt, the sharing of Member States and the weakening of strategic agreements.The most effective means for groups behind propaganda is to instill fear and restrict their sense of freedom.This message is also conveyed by the terrorist attacks on Europe.I support the activities of the Strategic Communication Task Force and trust that the action plans against propaganda will bring the expected results.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on this report on EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against it by third parties.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I abstained from voting on this report, which, although it points to certain real issues in terms of misinformation and manipulation that we are all subjected to in a highly media-dependent society, I do not think it is necessary. I do not consider that it is our role, a public institution, to intervene and regulate mass communication. I come from a former communist country and I have an increased reluctance to censor, to the restrictions imposed by the authorities on communicators, because the media is censored according to its own rules, according to its own regulations and according to the public. The area of ​​mass communication, with all its shortcomings, deserves our trust, as partners in a society in which each power has established its area of ​​influence. Last but not least, I chose to abstain from voting on an agreement that puts Russia and ISIS in the same category, which I consider to be a lack of diplomatic tact and an incitement that was not necessary.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. - I supported the report, which rightly emphasizes that the information war is not only an external but also an internal problem for the EU. This area is one of the key topics today. The strategy of propaganda and disinformation towards the EU by third countries can take various forms and can use traditional media, social networks, school curricula or political parties, such as the extreme right-wing French National Front of Marine Le Pen. In my opinion, the report should have focused more on Russia as the main source of this hostile propaganda against the EU, thus showing that it considers Russian propaganda to be the greatest threat to stability in the EU. Instead, however, the report reserves the same space for propaganda to the so-called Islamic State, which is significantly less sophisticated and therefore dangerous than that of Russia. Sufficient material and human resources should therefore be allocated to the EU's anti-propaganda strategy to make this risk less threatening to our future.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because it criticizes the media plurality created by social media.It is equated, among other things, with information warfare or hybrid warfare.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Attention must be paid to the dissemination of false information.European society must realize that there is an enormous amount of misinformation on the move and action must be taken against it.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - We must take comprehensive action to combat radicalization and terrorist propaganda. In particular, greater attention must be paid to measures for closer cooperation between the Member States and the EU. Action against the terrorist threat needs to be strengthened in accordance with human rights and the rule of law. However, constructive relations with third countries should be pursued in order to combat anti-EU propaganda and disinformation from third countries. It should be noted that wider political and diplomatic dialogue and peaceful cooperation agreements must be promoted in order to defuse tensions with neighboring third countries. It is necessary to prevent Da’esh from obtaining funding and funding from the oil or arms trade. Therefore, some Member States should review their relations with certain third countries accordingly, as this is particularly important in order to prevent radicalization and protect EU values.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - We point out that the fight against propaganda can not be done with more propaganda but with more positive messages and awareness and information campaigns. The draft resolution underlines that the European Union is under increasing systematic pressure to tackle misinformation and propaganda campaigns by various countries and non-state actors, using a wide range of tools, such as fake news agencies and cyber-trolls democratic values ​​and the division of Europe. By no means do I want to convey that I recommend for the mother to be inactive. There must be a clear separation and we must not liken Russia to the Islamic State. It is irresponsible to put a state like Russia on the same level of threat as the Islamic State. Russia must be recognized as a key partner of the European Union and a key global player, both in terms of external security and the common struggle against the Islamic State.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I abstain from voting on my colleagues' proposal because I believe that in the current state of affairs we are witnessing a significant increase in the number of dangers that can affect and harm the citizens of the European Union, so it would be appropriate to constantly update the population with a continuous exchangeof information between Member States.However, at the same time, I believe that it is wrong to see a conspiracy against the European Union in everything around us, indeed the Member States should collaborate among themselves by transmitting security to their citizens and not alarming them, dragging them, into a media war withNon-European states.Therefore I abstain.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I believe that it is important to raise awareness at the institutional level of the importance of fighting propaganda wars against the European Union and to move beyond the evolutionary stage of what we all know and are aware of according to the clear position of the European Union. negative phenomena. In particular, I would call on the European Parliament and the Commission to follow more closely the developments in the Union's immediate neighborhood, especially to focus on developments in Serbia, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina. In these countries, strong pro-Russian propaganda is at work, which has escalated in several cases - in the parliamentary elections in Montenegro, the illegal referendum held in Republika Srpska and the recent military exercises of the Russian, Serbian and Belarusian armies near the Croatian border. There are signs of Islamist radicalization in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and it is necessary to work on combating this worrying trend. Croatia's neighborhood must not become the soft belly of Europe and it is essential that the European Union continues to give strong support to the European perspective of these countries and to ensure the independence of the media, the verification of information and the preservation of true European values.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This report is an object of amazement as we fortunately see few.It puts Russia and the Islamic State terrorist organization on the same level, which is as outrageous as it is absurd.He therefore shows an ideological blindness far removed from any intelligent diplomacy.Moreover, he forgets one reality: the most effective propaganda against the European Union is the policy pursued by the Union and its disastrous results for the peoples who are subjected to it.The citizens analyzed the Europeanist catastrophe for themselves, they did not need a third state to tell them what to think.I am obviously voting against this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The EU, its member states and citizens are under systematic and growing pressure to respond to disinformation and propaganda campaigns. It seeks to question and undermine the European political narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law - both in the eyes of EU citizens and neighboring countries. Hostile propaganda against the EU takes many forms, often adapted to the profiles of the Member States. The aim is to arouse suspicion and divide Member States and paralyze decision-making processes. Invoking fear and insecurity in EU citizens is one of the most important means used, as is representing hostile state and non-state actors stronger and more successful than they really are. The anti-European propaganda strategy includes traditional media, social networks, school curricula and influence on political parties inside and outside the European Union. I call on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech that intolerant, radical preachers systematically promote in their speeches. The competent institutions must closely monitor the sources of funding for anti-European propaganda.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - This report is nothing more than an element of deepening the reactionary and anti-democratic character of the European Union. Starting from the values ​​it claims to defend, it extends its scope to the freedoms of communication, information and expression. Values ​​that European Union policies contradict and compromise, of which the humanitarian refugee crisis is the most crass example. It integrates a victimization strategy, building a supposed context of offensive against the EU, in an alleged unprecedented information war, a powerful media offensive, it is said, compromising its territorial integrity and the sovereignty of States, seeking the internal destabilization of the EU and NATO members. External intervention and interference is openly promoted in a speech that is not lacking in retrograde and breathtaking anti-communist rhetoric, seeking to confuse today's capitalist Russia with the USSR. Arguments used to move towards the limitation and more control of the media, the internet, school programs and even political parties. The EU's information is made absolutely true, distinguishing between propaganda and criticism, marking what is acceptable criticism. This opens the doors of censorship that so many black pages wrote on European soil. Practices worthy of authoritarian and dictatorial regimes. We voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ The main point of the report is to counter propaganda and radicalisation through cooperation between the Member States and the European institutions. Unfortunately, the report identifies two threats regarding propaganda: a non-state actor, the terrorist group known as Daesh or ISIS, and a state actor, Russia. I believe the propaganda targeting EU and its citizens is an undeniable fact, the need to react by strategic communication is apparent, but mixing the state and non-state actors is not the correct approach.   However, the fact that the EU states are subject to a very strong propaganda, while the Russian one is more present in the Central and Eastern Europe, made me express my support to the report. I am persuaded, however, that further attention should be given to both Russian and Daesh actions, but in a separate way. The separation is necessary not only because of the political gap but also because of the different strategic communication targets. Countering the propaganda and the radicalisation requires cooperation between the Member States and the European institutions. We should not underestimate the role of efficient propaganda and visible impacts on our society.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The report identifies two main threats with regard to propaganda from third countries: a state actor, notably Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh. The text calls for tackling radicalization and terrorist propaganda through enhanced cooperation at Member State and EU level. This is a sensible proposal that I find perfectly in agreement. The problem is that the text also focuses on the fact that the EU is the victim of a pro-Russian propaganda activity carried out by the Moscow government. Notwithstanding the fact that I personally believe that Russia does not currently represent an enemy and a threat to the security of the EU, I consider it profoundly wrong to point the finger at initiatives that cannot in any way be compared to the propaganda carried out by terrorist groups. Once again some members of the European Parliament have been influenced by their anti-Russian prejudices. Therefore I abstained.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- The report deals with countering propaganda used against the EU and the Member States at various levels, talks about the necessary arrangements and changes between institutions that would allow for a faster and better response to actions taken by both the Russian Federation and the recruitment of ISIS fighters.One of the proposed solutions is to strengthen a special task force within the EEAS and to support organizations such as the EED (European Endowment for Democracy).The report also focuses on the Kremlin's propaganda and information campaigns towards Eastern Partnership countries and describes them as part of a broader hybrid war effort, recommending closer cooperation between member states, the EU and international organizations such as NATO and the OSCE.I hereby support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- This report highlights new measures aimed at countering the disinformation campaigns carried out against the European Union and its Member States by Russia, as well as against the propaganda of terrorists from the “Islamic State” group,Al-Qaida and other violent jihadist terrorist groups.I have decided to abstain from voting on this report, which places propaganda from Russia on the same scale as propaganda produced by dangerous organizations such as the Islamic State group or Al-Qaida.This makes no sense because our real enemies remain the Islamic State group and all the other organizations which threaten our security and which we must fight tirelessly.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The Union, its Member States and their citizens are subject to increasing and systematic pressure to curb advertising and information campaigns, misinformation and misrepresentation of information by other entities in the multiform complex that make up the international community today , including terrorist organizations and criminal organizations. Often, these actors intend to call into question the very concept of objective information or journalistic ethics and treat all information as biased or as an instrument of political power through the distortion of facts and the creation of divisions between Member States . It is necessary to reinforce the pluralism, objectivity, impartiality and independence of the media, both within the Union and in its neighborhood. This is possible by supporting journalists and developing capacity building programs for media agents, promoting partnerships and networks for the exchange of information, research related to the media and mobility and training opportunities for journalists. Because freedom of the press, access to information and freedom of expression are fundamental pillars of a democratic system, in which the transparency of ownership of the media and their financing is of the utmost importance, I approve this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The recent breakdown in relations between the west and Russia, of which both parties are guilty, has produced far more insecurity in Europe. Diplomacy and deterrence are delicate mechanisms. We are uneasy with the constant peddling of aggression and justifications for more EU action.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - I voted against the Fotyga report with both hands, unlike 208 colleagues who thought the same thing but chose the diplomatic route of abstention! It is because of them that 304 deputies out of the 691 present were enough to pass a text suffering from an unamendable original sin: to place the Islamic State and Russia on an equal footing. These are the days of information warfare and Europe must adopt a robust strategy to counter the propaganda directed against it. It’s not just an external relations issue. IS campaigns to brainwash young Europeans are a shining example of this when they encourage terrorism in our territory. IS is more than 33,000 dead, 41,000 injured, and 11,000 hostages in the world between 2002 and 2015. I agree with the substance of this text, like the vast majority of those who 'have like me rejected. The problem has been to deal with Russia and ISIS in a single relationship. It is this essential technical defect that I denounce. Whether we like Putin's way of doing things or not, no solution will be found to global terrorism without Russia.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- The report identifies two threats with regard to advertising: Daesh and Russia.The objective will be to combat propaganda and radicalization through cooperation between Member States and European institutions.One of the controversial and unacceptable points of the report is the fact that it places Russia, a sovereign state, on the same level as a terrorist organization.For this reason, the group of Socialists and Democrats chose to abstain in plenary.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- This Parliament's own-initiative report refers to two external threats in terms of propaganda directed against the Union: one coming from a non-state actor, the terrorist group Daesh and a state actor, the Russian Federation, and seeks to counter theradicalization through cooperation between Member States and European institutions.However, one state, Russia, is placed on the same plane as a terrorist group.Although the need to react through strategic communication against propaganda directed at the Union and its citizens is clear, mixing state and non-state actors on the same plane is not an appropriate approach for a resolution by this Parliament.For this reason, I have decided to abstain from voting.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Union's strategic communication aimed at countering the propaganda directed against it by third parties, because the disinformation distilled by Islamist terrorist groups, on the one hand, and by Russia, on the otherpart, puts democracy at great risk.As Alfred Sauvy wrote: “Well informed, people are citizens;ill-informed, they become subjects ”.We must invest more in awareness and education to allow everyone to form their opinion, critically and in full knowledge of the facts.Propaganda has never brought anything good and if it is necessary to cooperate and to put in the means to fight against manipulation, we owe it to ourselves to do so.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- We live in an information society where publicly communicated knowledge is crucial.Not only does this help to spread knowledge, skills and experience more quickly, but it also makes our society very sensitive to attacks, lies and propaganda by unfriendly forces.The document under consideration to help combat lies and propaganda is very timely and necessary.I unequivocally support it.At the same time, I would like to point out that we will not solve this problem once and for all, even with the best legislation.The only long-term and sustainable solution is an active, well-informed civil society that can itself choose and resist lies and propaganda.It is support for the strengthening of such a society that must be an essential part of the EU's information policy and a priority for strategic communication.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Hate speech and the use of violence have had a progressive media impact in recent years, as a result of the use of new information and communication technologies, which transmit content in a much more direct, fast and effective way. Of particular concern is the propaganda directed against the European Union (EU) by third parties. The EU and its citizens have therefore been subject to increasing pressure, so there is an urgent need to combat bias and negative (and I would say 'black') propaganda and information by third countries and non-state actors such as organizations terrorists and / or criminal organizations, preserving those that are their fundamental values, such as democracy or freedom of expression. In that sense, it outlined a communication strategy to stop attacks of this nature - the Action Plan for Strategic Communication. The measures involve supplementary financing that supports the training and freedom of the media (avoiding biased information), as well as a focus on education and the approach of local communities. As I agree with the rapporteur's position on the need for greater cooperation and coordination of all actors at EU level to ensure the success of this strategy, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted against this report on strategic communication of the Union against third party propaganda, because it makes an analysis that leaves out many aspects of the geopolitical reality in which the Union currently finds itself.Encouraging hate and fear speech seems to us to be an ineffective way of ending the discursive threats that the Union receives.The analysis and the tone of the entire report is partial and not very truthful, and is also situated in a political line opposite to ours in matters of Foreign Policy.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on strategic communication by the EU in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties.The report is seen as an intensified parliamentary response to the use of hybrid strategies and operations by state and non-state actors.Particular attention is paid to the activities of Russia and ISIS, which are directed against the EU and its member states.The report calls for greater coordination at EU level with a view to combating disinformation and propaganda.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - We are here before one more example of Russophobia in this Parliament, which constantly exaggerates the differences between Russia and the Union. The report is a frontal attack on the media, calling for the use of NATO instruments, such as the Center of Excellence for Strategic Communications (COE STRATCOM), to combat the Russian media. In addition, it calls for direct support to "independent" media, which is a paradox, since by sponsoring them from European organizations, these media would obviously cease to be independent. Not content with this, in the report, and following this paranoid anti-Russian rhetoric, it is argued that "the security and intelligence services conclude that Russia has the capacity and intention to carry out operations aimed at destabilizing other countries", continuing with the militaristic rhetoric and engaging in an unacceptable escalation of tension. The report identifies two threats related to propaganda: a state actor, Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh, and focuses on giving the Union the means to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns, mainly against Russia, a UN country to who puts the same level of threat as Daesh. My vote was clearly against.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it calls to spend our tax money to counter anti EU propaganda.  Anti EU Propaganda normally means facts.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – EPLP abstained on the final vote on the resolution. We agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as a propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity; and putting ISIS on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that supporting quality and independent journalism more actively is the way forward.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing - I abstained on this resolution.My delay expresses that there are good things in the document that I stand for, but also those that I cannot agree with.I am definitely against propaganda, whether Russian or otherwise.However, in the mentioned document, the so-calledIslamic State and Russia.And I am therefore cautious in such assessments, as I know the situation in the Middle East intimately from my personal experience in that territory.At the same time, on the other hand, I consider it equally important that historical facts are not distorted and that history manipulated in this way is presented to the public and especially to young people, as we have seen in my country, Slovakia.And I consider this to be gross propaganda.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Although the problem of third-party propaganda to the Union has intensified in recent years, I abstained from voting on this report. I agree that European countries are under enormous pressure from conspiracy and propaganda websites, but it is not possible for us to put a state actor, Russia, and a non-state actor, such as the Islamic State, on the same level in one report. The propaganda to which European citizens are exposed is a fact against which the Union will have to define itself through some strategic communication. But using the same means to combat radical Islamism and to define certain parts of Europe as the traditional spheres of influence of Russia is not an adequate approach. Propaganda must be opposed by the European institutions with the authorities of the Member States, as the situation varies considerably from one country to another. It will be crucial to raise citizens' awareness and education of critical thinking. The digital age is marked by an overprint of information that is constantly flooding citizens. The aim of internet propaganda is to unsettle, confuse and divide people. I therefore support the work of the European External Action Service, which is already doing a meritorious job of uncovering and deciphering the misinformation that is spreading on the Internet on a daily basis.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the own-initiative report on the EU's strategic communication to combat third-party propaganda against it. I consider it important for the EU to respond to the activities that Russia, but also ISIS and other states or entities, are creating towards the EU. From the period before 1989, I remember the ever-present propaganda on television, radio and newspapers, which systematically eliminated all signs of opposition to the socialist establishment and the policies of the Communist Party. Today is different, we all have the right to express ourselves and have access to information, and it is all the more difficult to orient ourselves in them and to find out which ones to trust and which ones not, which ones were created to deliberately deceive us. Russia and ISIS play the same note by fostering fear, mistrust and hatred. In the Czech Republic, we currently register forty websites with disinformation content, some of which are directly linked to Russia or have the EU name. This is very worrying. Our common goal is certainly not to create EU propaganda, but to confront the spread of delusions and misinformation. We must defend the truth and teach it to be recognized, even by pupils and students in schools. We also need to communicate better and more clearly with citizens, explain our work, our common efforts, our common European values.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - The report on “The EU's strategic communication in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties” is problematic. The primary concern is to combat propaganda by extraterritorial actors, namely Russia and IS, and to set up counter-propaganda. The fact that there is Russian propaganda is undisputed and is also proven, for example, by NATO documents. In Eastern Europe in particular, where the media in smaller countries are often relatively financially weak, there is a risk of a Russian-dominated one-sidedness of the information offered. Some states also supported political parties within the EU with substantial amounts. The question, however, is how to identify this propaganda and how to restrict it without damaging the public's interest in information. When weighing both concerns, a weighing must be made. Is the danger from third party propaganda to be rated higher than the danger of important information being censored by the EU? After considering the matter, I decided to vote in favor of the report, despite serious reservations.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Russian and Islamist propaganda threatens stability and peace in the European Union.We cannot fight it with some kind of counter-propaganda, but only with honest politics and open communication with people.Success depends only on the will of the governments of the Member States to act in unison.In the case of the Slovak one, I have serious doubts as to whether such a will exists.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - The disinformation and propaganda agenda of today's Russia shows clear parallels with the era of Soviet mass communication. In the European Parliament, I constantly draw attention to the danger of our inaction and our utterly inadequate defense. The solution to the problem begins with its naming, which is why I appreciate and supported the resolution on strategic communication to combat propaganda. Its author is Anna Fotyga, Chair of the Subcommittee on Defense and Security. Today, it is quite clear that information warfare and misinformation are not only an external but also an internal problem of the EU. The report shows that misinformation and propaganda are part of a hybrid war. The hybrid war that the Kremlin is waging against us. It is high time to realize that the word can be stronger than rocket systems.
