Another dangerous activity of the Russian Federation mentioned in the report is the Kremlin's financial support against EU forces in the EU. Subjects denying the fundamental values ​​of liberal democracies, especially far-right parties, populist forces and movements, are on the rise thanks in large part to these efforts. Repairing the damage will not be easy. What to do? There are a large number of necessary steps, I will give one example. I have long pointed out that the efforts made so far are scandalously underfunded. Paragraph 27 refers to the working group on strategic communication. It operates in the order of several experts within the EEAS. It needs to be significantly strengthened and financed by an additional specific budget line.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ EPLP abstained on the final vote on the resolution. We agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as a propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity; and putting ISIS on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that supporting quality and independent journalism more actively is the way forward.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - Criticism of the EU is prohibited. This emerges from the resolution on “Strategic communication by the EU to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties”. In this, the EU Parliament puts Russia and the terrorists of the “Islamic State” on a par. Both are accused of "organized EU counter-propaganda". Criticism of the EU from inside and outside should be prohibited by all means. Even if you equate terrorists with Russia. That is why I voted against this resolution. The EU Parliament deals with “propaganda” very variably anyway. We experience this in everyday parliamentary work when the administration deals with Euro-critical groups. Outwardly, the EU Parliament itself does a lot of propaganda: the Parlamentarium, Europarl-TV, Euranet, “House of the History of the EU” and the European Youth Event are also propaganda instruments, and there is always taxpayer money for them. There is even a parliamentary propaganda cinema: the LUX Prize. It is awarded to the best EU propaganda film produced with the help of EU film funding. This year the prizewinner declared without shame: "Films (like mine) are only available thanks to national and European subsidies." Thanks to tax-financed EU film subsidies, films are made that are not even put on paper in the normal cinema art competition because nobody cares about them. The in-house EU propaganda parliamentary cinema waste of tax money started 10 years ago. We owe it to the CDU EU MP Doris Pack from Saarland.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The European Union has recently been a constant target of a series of negative campaigns directed by destabilizing factors in the immediate and wider European neighborhood.Taking into account the already distorted image of the European Union and European values due to frequent escalations on European territory, it is necessary for the Union to be able to take an active approach to the fight against propaganda conducted against it by third parties.Establishing mechanisms to verify and inform European citizens about objective and factual truths that are different from messages sent by third parties is the only way to preserve the Union's communication integrity.Encouraging free journalism, media freedom and insisting on respecting the highest rules and standards of the profession must be built into such a strategy.I therefore support this report because it is the first step in acting against those who are fighting the European Union through propaganda and information warfare.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the EU's strategic communication against third-party propaganda.In recent years, we have witnessed a changed security environment in Europe.The European Union thus faces, among other things, a number of threats, propaganda and various forms of populism aimed at economically, politically and socially destabilizing the EU.Notwithstanding the fact that the prevention of EU threats by third parties is primarily the responsibility of the Member States, we need a uniform framework at European Union level.By strengthening stronger links between Member States, on the one hand, and between the European Union and NATO, on the other, we will strengthen Europe in security and defense matters.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- Today, I supported the European Parliament's report on EU strategic communication to combat third-party propaganda against it.The report clearly names the need to combat propaganda, which is currently an integral part of the so-called hybrid way of waging war.Russia's propaganda in EU member states is not so much about gaining new supporters of Putin's policy, but about disseminating false and manipulated information in order to prevent any fact-based discussion.The aim of Russian propaganda is to disrupt the cooperation of individual EU member states and the possibilities of democratic debate in these individual states.In the future, however, it is not enough to name these phenomena, but above all to actively defend against them.Adequate financial and human resources need to be set aside for this.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- The report attacks journalism and calls on journalists to use NATO media, such as the Center for Strategic Communications, to "fight" the Russian media.It also seeks to equate Russia with terrorist organizations.Finally, the report lists a number of synergies that the European Union and the Member States should work with in cooperation with NATO to address "dangerous situations".For these reasons we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The European Union 's communication strategy to counter propaganda against third parties is moving in the wrong direction.The logic of "inventing enemies" and scapegoats must not prevail to justify the absence of good political governance.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of high-quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I abstained from adopting this report because, although it points to a significant and novel challenge to European integration and peace on the continent, while making proposals to address it, it also makes statements that I cannot identify with. Nevertheless, I paid particular attention to the Russian propaganda efforts presented in the report, among other things, because they are also strongly present in my country, especially with regard to financial and political support for far-right forces, influencing public opinion and undermining EU membership. Action against this is particularly difficult in this case, as Moscow can count on a partner in the Orbán regime, not an opponent, who follows and openly praises Putin's political methods and essentially implements Putin's scenario in its efforts to address migration and the EU. I would also consider the joint EU-level response outlined in the report important in this case, because it is an internal phenomenon, the government of an EU Member State, which can easily find followers within the Union if the Union is unable to prevent this dangerous situation at the highest level. political game. I believe that this is not only part of, but a precondition for, the effective implementation of a communication strategy against external propaganda against the EU.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - In recent years, there have been more and more acts of propaganda directed against the European Union, especially by Russia, as well as by the Islamic State, Al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups. Strategic propaganda against the Union and its countries aims to distort the facts, raise doubts, divide the Union and its North American partners, paralyze the decision-making process and, above all, instill fear and uncertainty among EU citizens. With the annexation of Crimea and the start of the hybrid war in the Donbass, the Kremlin intensified propaganda against the EU using a wide range of tools, such as television, think tanks, pseudo-agencies and social media trolls. The aim is to challenge democratic values, divide Europe or gain internal support. Moreover, it is common knowledge that the Kremlin finances the activities of European far-right parties or populist movements in Europe that negate the fundamental values ​​of liberal democracy. Similar methods are used by the so-called Islamic State and other terrorist organizations to help them recruit their members in the EU. It is extremely important that the Union institutions and the Member States cooperate more closely to protect young people in particular from radicalization and recruitment into terrorist organizations. This goal cannot be achieved without investing in education and awareness-raising to facilitate the critical analysis and identification of propaganda.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: written.- I voted against the report because I found the text unbalanced.The text had mixed two completely different things, and the approach was by no means correct in relation to the problem.A document that failed in all respects and could not have been rectified even by the proposed amendments.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. - I voted against the "Strategic Communication of the European Union to counter propaganda against it by third parties" as I regard it as a clear and unjustified unilaterally anti-Russian motion. The text calls for the strengthening of the EU task force against "Russia's disinformation campaigns". The task force in question now consists of a "network of 400 experts" which European citizens pay mostly without their knowledge. Its online products are a website and a twitter account dedicated to "media lies in favor of Russian policies". The motion describes the growing disaffection of citizens towards the EU as a "decline of critical thinking in the public" which thus becomes "more predisposed to disinformation and manipulation", but does not, for example, link this disaffection to austerity and the consequent social butchery . Instead, he compares it to the fact that the Kremlin would finance "parties and other organizations within the EU" and that its "propaganda" would target "journalists, politicians and specific individuals within the EU" with the aim of "distorting the truth, instill fear, provoke doubts and divide the EU ". One way to unconsciously avoid taking note of the sad reality, that is, the social disasters resulting from EU policies.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - In the context of the information society, the development of content, models, structure and theories of communication generates opportunities and pressures for systemic and integrated approaches to communication at EU level, so that not only the successful model that is the EU with all values, principles , its successes, but to attract countries to be part of that model. In this regard, the EU must give priority to its strategic communication efforts, involving relevant resources and actors, which correspond to a proactive approach both within and outside the European Community. Strategic communication, assuming the existence of a cause-and-effect relationship between communication activities and the achievement of EU objectives, brings to the fore the role of communication associated with strategic management within it. Moreover, the EU must develop effective communication strategies to promote respect for fundamental rights and freedoms through its actions (internal and external), involving not only local communities but also all stakeholders, using new technologies generated by the digital economy, with a view to synergistically developing positive information flows towards the EU as a whole.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European Union has recently become the target of systematic campaigns of discredit, misinformation and intoxication by propaganda launched by certain countries and non-state actors. These practices stem from the threat posed by European values ​​of democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms to certain international actors who do not share these values. This is a real information war waged mainly by terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and Al Qaeda. To counter these subtle external attacks, the European Union needs strategic communication measures that expose those attempts to European citizens and avoid discrediting the European project in the Member States. In this regard, close cooperation is needed between the European institutions and the Member States, in order to monitor the sources of funding for anti-European propaganda, support the media in the countries included in the European Neighborhood Policy (ENP), support journalistic education within and in the EU's neighborhood and effective communication with citizens. However, I believe that this document needs a number of improvements and differentiated treatment between states and non-state actors.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I abstained in this vote.Indeed, to be completely honest, many passages lend themselves to interpretation and seem to me to pose problems.The imperfect drafting, even sometimes incorrect, does not allow me to give my approval.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the EU strategic communication to counteract anti-EU-propaganda by third parties seeks to create an EU response to misinformation and propaganda against the EU, notably by sources of opposition such as Russia and ISIS. The diffusion of propaganda has become a persistent challenge to EU legitimacy and is used by outside forces to destabilise and weaken Europe’s integrity. I voted in favour of the report because I believe the EU has to do everything in its power to mitigate the spread of misinformation by those who oppose Europe and wish to destabilise the Union.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - Today, in line with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favor of this report, together with my Fidesz colleagues, which aims to strengthen strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda by third parties. The document emphasizes that anti-EU propaganda aims to divide Member States, paralyze decision-making processes, undermine the credibility of the EU institutions and undermine the European narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law. The report calls on the EU and its Member States to take consistent action across the EU against the hate speech voiced by intolerant, radical proponents, which is creating fertile ground for the growth of terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State and al-Qaeda. The report therefore emphasizes the important role of high-quality journalism, education and training in ensuring a high standard of qualitative analysis, and calls on the Commission to put forward legislative initiatives to combat targeted misinformation more effectively.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a European Parliament resolution on the European Union's strategic communication to combat propaganda against it by third parties".It emphasizes that various means, often tailored to the profiles of member states, are used for propaganda purposes against the EU, to distort the truth, to arouse suspicion, to divide Member States, and to cause strategic divisions between the European Union and its North American partners.Such propaganda can potentially paralyze decision-making processes, discredit EU institutions and transatlantic partnerships in the eyes of EU citizens and neighboring countries, and call into question and undermine the European political narrative based on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Enemy propaganda against the EU takes various forms and uses various means to distort the truth, arouse suspicion, divide Member States, discredit the EU institutions and transatlantic partnerships. Russia is aggressively using a wide range of means and instruments to question the values ​​of the West, divide Europe, gain the support of the domestic public and create the image of countries in the EU's eastern neighborhood as decaying countries. On the other hand, Islamist terrorist organizations, especially ISIL / Daesh and al-Qaeda, are conducting active information campaigns to jeopardize European values ​​and increase the level of hatred towards them. I am particularly concerned about the fact that ISIL / Daesh is making extensive use of social media tools to advocate for its propaganda and recruitment goals, especially among young people, who need special protection from this dangerous radicalization. NATO, the EU, member states and NGOs and civil society organizations should establish the best possible coordination and exchange of information and work closely together for the benefit of all EU citizens. The proposed action requires the cooperation and coordination of all relevant actors at EU and national level, and only a comprehensive approach can lead to success in the effort, so I supported this report and voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the EU's strategic communication against third-party propaganda.The EU is committed to taking into account principles such as democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, freedom of the media, access to information, freedom of expression and media pluralism in its action on the international stage.The new Member States are under increasing information and disinformation pressure because some actors want to undermine the objective truth.This, in turn, shakes democratic principles and values.Information wars aimed at destabilizing the political, economic and social situation in the country must be opposed.Measures that threaten the sovereignty and political independence of EU Member States, the security of their citizens and their territorial integrity must also be legitimized.Above all, there is the problem of Russian communication.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The approach to this problem comes from a wrong angle. While we should have been focusing on the professionalism and ethical behaviour of journalists, the approach seems to be to fight propaganda with counter-propaganda. Counter-propaganda which is written by anonymous sources, as in the case of EastStratCom. In addition, we are taking a dangerous step in the wrong direction when we condemn the behaviour of a government of a state and a terrorist organisation in the same document. This sends a signal that either the Russian Government is regarded as a terrorist organisation or ISIS is a sovereign state. Either way, this is unacceptable.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report on strategic communication of the Union against third party propaganda, because it makes an analysis that leaves out many aspects of the geopolitical reality in which the Union currently finds itself.Encouraging hate and fear speech seems to us to be an ineffective way of ending the discursive threats that the Union receives.The analysis and the tone of the entire report is partial and not very truthful, and is also situated in a political line opposite to ours in matters of Foreign Policy.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - The report on “The EU's strategic communication in order to counteract propaganda directed against it by third parties” is problematic. The primary concern is to combat propaganda by extraterritorial actors, namely Russia and IS, and to set up counter-propaganda. The fact that there is Russian propaganda is undisputed and is also proven, for example, by NATO documents. In Eastern Europe in particular, where the media in smaller countries are often relatively financially weak, there is a risk of a Russian-dominated one-sidedness of the information offered. Some states also supported political parties within the EU with substantial amounts. The question, however, is how to identify this propaganda and how to restrict it without damaging the public's interest in information. When weighing both concerns, a weighing must be made. Is the risk of third-party propaganda to be rated higher than the risk of important information being censored by the EU? After considering the matter, I decided to vote in favor of the report, despite serious reservations.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- It is a question of fighting against the famous "hybrid threats" which would be threats against the European Union.These threats have two sources: Russia and the Islamic State group.This report is a testimony to the obsessional drift of the European Union, which, for want of having any consistency, tries to manifest its existence by manipulating fears.This report also bears witness to the danger that the EU now represents for international life, as it is beyond the limits of diplomacy to amalgamate in such a crude manner a sovereign state and a terrorist organization.I therefore voted against.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The European Union is under increasing pressure from Russia, which is using propaganda and information warfare as part of its strategy towards the EU, using substantial resources intended solely for this purpose.The resolution deals with counteracting the propaganda used against the EU and its member states at various levels, it talks about the necessary arrangements and changes between institutions that would allow for a faster and better response to actions taken by both the Russian Federation and the recruitment of ISIS fighters.The report also focuses on the Kremlin's propaganda and information campaigns towards Eastern Partnership countries and describes them as part of a broader hybrid war effort, recommending closer cooperation between member states, the EU and international organizations such as NATO and the OSCE.I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The Union is committed to acting in accordance with the principles of democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, freedom of the media, access to information, freedom of expression and media pluralism.The Union and European values are being attacked by a wide range of attacks, including Russian state propaganda.This must be done against.However, the current proposal took a bad approach to the issue, which is why I abstained.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against this report on strategic communication of the Union against third party propaganda, because it makes an analysis that leaves out many aspects of the geopolitical reality in which the Union currently finds itself.Encouraging hate and fear speech seems to us to be an ineffective way of ending the discursive threats that the Union receives.The analysis and the tone of the entire report is partial and not very truthful, and is also situated in a political line opposite to ours in matters of Foreign Policy.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- EU strategic communication to counter anti-third party propaganda.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against it by third parties. The EU, its Member States and citizens are under growing, systematic pressure to tackle information, disinformation and misinformation campaigns and propaganda from countries and non-state actors, such as transnational terrorist and criminal organisations in its neighbourhood. The report underlines that the EU must consider its strategic communication efforts as a priority, which should involve relevant resources. I voted against because I believe that the report is one-sided and that it wrongfully equates the situation in Russia with propaganda carried out by the terrorists linked to ISIL.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - This Motion for a Resolution highlights the growing pressure to which the Union is subjected by third parties - state and non-state actors who, through propaganda, seek to weaken it. In order to serve as a basis for evaluating the objectives pursued by the Community strategic communication plans, it points out the methods used by Russia to discredit the Union institutions, engineer a strategic separation of the United States and the Union, promote the division between its Member States and challenge European values ​​in terms of respect for human rights and the rule of law. He also looks at Daesh's strategies for recruiting young people, promoting radical Islam, and increasing hatred for community principles and interests. The text calls for greater coordination between the relevant parties both at the Union level and at the national level, so that it works based on an approach that is effective in combating disinformation and propaganda. From the conviction that strategic communication is one of the essential vectors in the framework of our foreign policy, I have voted yes to this proposal.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - We are here before one more example of Russophobia in this Parliament, which constantly exaggerates the differences between Russia and the Union. The report is a frontal attack on the media, calling for the use of NATO instruments, such as the Center of Excellence for Strategic Communications (COE STRATCOM), to combat the Russian media. In addition, it calls for direct support to "independent" media, which is a paradox, since by sponsoring them from European organizations, these media would obviously cease to be independent. Not content with this, in the report, and following this paranoid anti-Russian rhetoric, it is argued that "the security and intelligence services conclude that Russia has the capacity and intention to carry out operations aimed at destabilizing other countries", continuing with the militaristic rhetoric and engaging in an unacceptable escalation of tension. The report identifies two threats related to propaganda: a state actor, Russia, and terrorist groups such as Daesh, and focuses on giving the Union the means to support its own strategic propaganda campaigns, mainly against Russia, a UN country to who puts the same level of threat as Daesh. My vote was clearly against.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With EPLP, I abstained on the final vote on the resolution. We agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as a propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity; and putting ISIS on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that supporting quality and independent journalism more actively is the way forward.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written.- I opposed the report on EU strategic communication to combat anti-EU propaganda from third parties.The report as a whole was weak and completely unjustifiably equated the propaganda carried out by Russia and ISIS.The report was unbalanced and poorly prepared.For these reasons, I could not support the report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - This resolution theoretically builds on the June 2015 EU Action Plan on Strategic Communication to Respond to "External Disinformation Activities". This resolution proposes to strengthen the Union's resources in the informational fight against terrorism, but it establishes a parallel, to say the least, astonishing and even questionable between the "propaganda" of Russia and that of Daesh. There is no other country that one would dare to assimilate to a terrorist organization. This anti-Russian obsession contributes to the exacerbation of political tensions and can only aggravate them. At the very least, it would be appropriate to wonder about the meaning of the term propaganda, which seems to me to be used without taking care to define it, when it would deserve a minimum of contextualization and some comparisons. This text, far from reinforcing the Union's defense policy, helps to fuel a logic of blocs as in the "good old days" of the Cold War. I voted against this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This report, based on the values ​​it claims to defend, broadens its scope to the freedoms of communication, information and expression, values ​​that European Union policies contradict and compromise, of which the humanitarian refugee crisis is the most crass example. There would be many examples and otherwise it would not even be necessary to leave this house to give them. The strategy of victimization that does not lack a retrograde and breathtaking anti-communist rhetoric is all too evident. The EU is the victim of a powerful media offensive, it is said, compromising its integrity. With these arguments, progress is being made towards limiting and controlling the media, the internet, school programs and even political parties. The EU's information is made absolute by distinguishing between propaganda and criticism, marking what is acceptable criticism. Thus, the doors of censorship and other practices worthy of authoritarian and dictatorial regimes are opened, whose memory should still prevail in Europe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written. - The report criticizes the media plurality created by social media and even equates it with an “information war or hybrid warfare”. It seems as if the flexibility of digital communication of the European Union is a thorn in the side due to the lack of the possibility of censorship-like handling. The proposed solution is, like the previous statement of the problem, poorly thought out and one-sided: In order to combat Russian propaganda, there must be more efforts and resources for the expansion of “strategic communication”. Existing positions in the field of strategic communication are to be incorporated into the EEAS and given more staff and budget. It is particularly perfidious that the reporter goes into detail about the propaganda war and the lack of media pluralism in Russia, only lists the IS and al-Qaida afterwards and does not say a single word about Turkey. In summary, one thing can be said: the rapporteur accuses “the Russians” of precisely the kind of behavior that the European Union itself is currently maintaining. Manipulating interpretation of historical events, spreading an alternative narrative, falsifying history. Of course, I did not endorse this report.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: written.- The report in question is a document of ideological-propagandistic armament and the further escalation in relations with Russia.In numerous chapters and individual sections, the alleged "information war" of Russia against Western countries and the alleged interference of Russia in the internal affairs of the EU are underlined.Much of it is in fact NATO propaganda.The main thrust of this report is aimed at Russia and is diametrically opposed to the long overdue easing of tension in relations with Russia.A clear “no” was required here.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – The Kremlin and Daesh have stepped up their propaganda war seeking to undermine the democratic foundations of the EU together with some of our neighbours’ policies. Therefore, I am very glad that the EU treats that sort of disinformation campaign as a potential serious threat for its security environment. That is the reason why the EU has decided now to reinforce its Strategic Communication Task Force with adequate budgetary resources and staffing. However, the task of that unit is challenging as it has to reassure streamlining of the correct information successfully, keeping in mind that countering propaganda with propaganda is counterproductive.  Due to that fact, the only way of dealing with disinformation campaigns is to tackle them with professionalism in journalism. In order to do so, it is crucial to strengthen civil society within the EU and the resilience of media in our neighbourhood countries, such as Ukraine. The report ensures it will be done, along with other tools, through publishing weekly newsletters creating awareness among the general public of propaganda methods. Consequently, I am sure that implementation of this report will make us and our neighbours more resilient in dealing with propaganda, thus I voted in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ EPLP abstained on the final vote on the resolution. We agree that countering propaganda and radicalisation requires cooperation between Member States. However, there are elements in the report itself which could be perceived as propaganda. Russia is not the only state involved in this activity. Also, putting Daesh (ISIS) on the same footing as a state is not appropriate. Therefore, we believe that actively supporting quality and independent journalism is the way forward. As shadow rapporteur on the CULT Committee opinion, it is clear to me that support for independent media and promotion of the freedom of the press, recognising the role of education for media literacy, and the need for putting in place a strategic cultural diplomacy platform at EU level must be the pillars of EU actions aimed at countering propaganda. We must also work to encourage and promote high editorial standards in journalism so as to counter misinformation and propaganda.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that the image of the EU must be preserved all around the world. Hostile propaganda against the EU comes in different forms and so various tools will have to be used to counteract it. This is not only an external EU problem but also an internal one. Disinformation and propaganda are part of hybrid warfare aimed to weaken the image of the European Union. Often this propaganda is based on false or distorted information, in order to create confusion in the mind of the citizens.  Russia is contacting EU counterparts in order to establish propaganda that puts Europe in a bad light. Russia is using a wide range of instruments such as think tanks, special foundations and multilingual TV stations. I stand totally against this way of acting by the Russian Government, and I think that everything has to be done in order to defend Europe and its values. However, I think the topics of Russia and IS should have been addressed in separate resolutions since they are two very different issues.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: written.- It was unfortunate that Fotyga's report on the EU's strategic communication to fight propaganda placed the problem description of Russia - a nation state - next to that of Daish / Isil - a terrorist sect.I called on ALDE's shadow rapporteur to negotiate with the rapporteur that the report be sent back to the committee for processing.It did not work, so I chose to support the report anyway, because despite the unfortunate format, it addresses important issues that I do not feel I can vote against.Organized disinformation campaigns against Europe take place daily, but we should not equate Russia with Daish / Isil in any letter.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - The own-initiative report on the EU's strategic communication to counter third-party propaganda against it focuses on hostile propaganda against the EU in different forms, using tools tailored to Member States' profiles, in order to distort the truth, to give birth doubt, to divide the Member States, to promote the strategic decoupling between the European Union and its North American partners. I voted in favor of this report, which recognizes that the EU must give priority to its strategic communication efforts, which should involve relevant resources and calls on the EU and the Member States to take consistent action at Union level against systematic hate speeches channel. The report argues that an effective communication strategy must involve local communities in discussions about EU action, support people-to-people contact and pay due attention to cultural and social exchanges as key platforms for combating the prejudices of local people.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - This resolution aims to confront propaganda and attack the integrity and values ​​of the EU by state and non-state actors. Their aim is to weaken the Union from within by inciting fear and creating uncertainty among EU citizens. A special chapter of this resolution is the Russian disinformation and propaganda war. In this part, the resolution strongly condemns all the means it uses by the Russian Federation to divide Europe and create the impression of failing states in the Eastern Neighborhood. Nevertheless, in my opinion, it is still too early to talk about the war with Russia. It is true that the EU today faces both direct and indirect Russian disinformation pressure. However, the resolution of existing disputes must be based on diplomacy. It therefore does not seem good to me that the text of the resolution puts Russia and the terrorist group Daesh (ISIS) on one level, although it also skillfully uses propaganda and misinformation to radicalize potential supporters.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I support the present report on combating propaganda, as I think this is an area in which the European Union should have a much more active stance. At the same time, I would like to point out that we must focus carefully so that we do not cross the thin line between the fight against propaganda and the restriction of freedom of speech for those who only want to think critically. The aim of Internet propaganda is to raise doubts, spread false claims and thus evoke fear and negative emotions. Personally, I believe that propaganda campaigns should not be confronted with restrictions, bans or even greater propaganda, but rather with an effort to be better informed and to raise awareness of the true view of the matter. Russia, the Islamic State, as well as other actors are investing huge resources both in their own agencies, which spread misinformation, but also in influencing opinions on social networks or in the mainstream media. The European Union must realize this and devote more effort and resources to fighting this information war.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - The war of the digital age is largely an information war. Thanks to the internet and new media, the opportunities for propaganda activities are much greater than ever before. Even though Europe is not a party to an open armed conflict, we are subjected to constant disinformation pressure from many state and non-state actors. Two of them are particularly dangerous today. The Russian Federation is not a newcomer to the propaganda battlefield, but the digital revolution has created many new channels and tools for manipulating Western public opinion. In the context of the continuing conflict in Ukraine, the intensity of these actions has increased significantly and is effectively diverting attention from Moscow's involvement in this new-era war. This is done by fabricating false information, funding NGOs and political parties in Europe and cybercrime. The second entity that tries to influence Europe through disinformation and propaganda is ISIS - a malicious political tumor that has declared a cultural war on the values ​​of the civilized world. The policy of inspiring fanatical Muslims to launch suicide attacks on European cities has already taken a bloody toll. The report we voted on today could be the start of an effective fight against disinformation and propaganda at European level, as long as the EU elite has enough determination to take swift and concrete action, especially in the case of the Russian Federation.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I abstained on the point concerning the EU's strategic communication to tackle the propaganda directed against it by third parties, because it is necessary to send a strong signal against anti-European propaganda, but I believe that all advertising cannot be placed in the same analysis matrix.Advertising aimed at the EU and its citizens is a fact and the need to use strategic communication to combat it is obvious, but I believe that mixing the state and non-state actors is not the best approach for a European Parliament resolution onthis matter.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I support the report on strategic communication of the European Union to combat propaganda against it by third parties because it calls for active action of the Union in order to preserve the reputation, credibility and truth about the various events in which the European Union is involved.The use of propaganda has become popular in recent years, especially on the battlefields in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq.The beneficiaries of this approach base their actions on attempts to create a distorted image of European values and the activities carried out by the Union in the field of foreign policy.The fight against propaganda must be based on a consistent insistence on ensuring media freedoms, but also on responsible journalistic reporting and work based on the standards of the profession.Establishing a body to work on this issue is a necessary step in the fight against negative campaigns conducted by third parties.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the EU Strategic Communication Report against propaganda directed against it by third parties.The EU is exposed to information and disinformation campaigns and propaganda by countries and non-governmental actors, such as terrorist and criminal organizations in the neighborhood, which undermine the EU's democratic values and interests and provide biased information or use it as an instrument of political power.I therefore agree that the EU must give priority to its strategic communication at various levels, including the EU institutions, the Member States, the various NATO and UN bodies, non-governmental organizations and civil society organizations.However, an effective and responsible approach to communication must also include raising awareness, educating EU citizens and developing online, media and information literacy in the EU and its neighborhood.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, sign languages represent Europe’s multicultural and multilingual heritage, and I am pleased to offer my support for improving the quality of the sign language interpreting profession. Hard-of-hearing, deaf and deaf—blind citizens should not be disabled by their working environment from equal access to the same information and communication as their peers. In Ireland the Recognition of Irish Sign Language for the Deaf Community Bill 2016 is currently being reviewed. This would mean, if passed, that Irish sign language would be designated as a native and independent language – one which is used as a permanent means of communication by over 5 000 members of the deaf community. Additionally, GPs can now easily access professional sign language interpreters for deaf medical care patients, thanks to a new agreement between the health authority, HSE, and the sign language interpreting service. I think we are heading in the right direction. In particular, I look forward to discussion on how to utilise language technologies in providing equal access for all to the digital space.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, earlier in this Chamber we may have had a bit of an interpretation issue. In the English interpretation of what was said, President Schulz was portrayed as saying that he would allow someone to speak so that she could not say he was acting like a terrorist.  I am sure the President of Parliament would not speak in such a way intentionally, as this would come across as inappropriate for the office, so could I just please ask that the interpretation of whatever was said is checked, because that is certainly how it came across in English. I am sure that is not how it was intended in German.  I won’t be leaping to any conclusions against Mr Schulz over this, but I would just ask that we all please remember in future to be very careful over the interpretation being accurate before leaping to conclusions over words that have been used in this Chamber.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The resolution aims to ensure and widen as much as possible the accessibility to works, contents, etc.to deaf people.In today's society it is of fundamental importance to allow deaf people to have access to a greater number of services, including public and government services, online content.Equal access in the digital space is an issue that I believe to be particularly important given the intense development of technologies and rapid digitization.In this sense, we should try to speed up as much as possible the possibility of providing interpretation for sign language to all areas where it is needed.Since I am particularly sensitive to issues of this kind, I voted in favor.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution since it is committed to the effective defense of the rights of deaf, deaf-blind or hard of hearing people and calls for a series of measures such as the official recognition of sign languages, both national and regional , in the different Member States, as well as in the institutions of the Union. In addition, it advocates for the professional recognition of sign language interpreters and advocates the incorporation of sign language into educational programs in a similar way to foreign languages. Likewise, it considers that the inclusion of deaf, deaf-blind or hearing-impaired people must be guaranteed in European programs such as Erasmus +, and their labor integration must be effectively promoted in the European institutions. Aware of the importance of promoting sign language at an educational level to sensitize society as a whole and facilitate respect for the right to equality of the more than 52 million citizens and residents who are estimated to speak in different languages ​​of signs in the Union, I have decided to support this text.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – The motion for a resolution, from Helga Stevens, was a straight forward apolitical and rights-based motion for a resolution on sign languages and sign language interpreters. It was an encompassing motion for a resolution and received unanimous support across Parliament.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text.The European Union has almost a million deaf people who use sign language.In the 21st century, it is fundamental that citizens who are deaf, deaf and blind or hard of hearing have access to the same information and the same means of communication as their fellow citizens.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on sign language and professional sign language interpreters. All persons with disabilities, especially women and children, as well as people with disabilities and hearing impairments, enjoy the same rights and are entitled to personal dignity, independent living, independence and full participation in society. I therefore agree with the need for qualified professional sign language interpreters, whose status must be guaranteed by the official recognition of national and regional sign languages ​​in the Member States and the EU institutions, through formal training (university or similar) equivalent to 3 years of continuous study and registration requirements (formal accreditation and quality control system, eg through continuous professional development) and formal recognition of the profession. I agree that sign language translation is a professional service that should be duly remunerated.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on sign language and professional sign language interpreters, because I believe that access to high quality services for people with disabilities needs to be improved.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution is fairly consensual since it is part of a desire for greater accessibility and integration for people with disabilities, without ever indicating a desire to interfere in the policies of the Member States.Despite a few failing paragraphs, overall it is a consensus resolution in favor of accessibility for people with disabilities.Being in favor of the proposed measures, in the absence of calling into question the competence of the Member States, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted for this text because I believe that it is essential to have qualified and professional sign language interpreters.Obviously, deaf citizens should have access to the same information and communications as their fellow citizens by means of sign language interpretation.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on sign languages ​​and professional sign language interpreters. There are about one million sign language users and 51 million hearing-impaired citizens in the EU, many of whom also use sign language. Citizens with hearing impairments have the right to independence and full participation in society, and sign language interpreters are essential to this. However, the situation of sign language interpreters varies greatly from one Member State to another: in some cases, informal family helpers, and in others, fully qualified university translators. There is also a shortage of qualified professional sign language interpreters in all Member States. I therefore agree with the need to ensure the number of qualified sign language professionals and to ensure that they receive adequate remuneration. All sign language users must also have access to the same information and means of communication as all others, providing sign language translation, subtitling, voice-to-text services and / or alternative means of communication.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, motion for a resolution. There are many aspects of the resolution which UKIP in principle could support and of course we want to further help those people who are deaf, blind, partially sighted and hard of hearing. However we cannot support the EU telling Member States what they should be doing or in any way give an excuse for action at EU level. The only people who should decide these things is our elected national government, not unaccountable EU institutions. As the resolution itself didn’t contain anything which called on the EU or the Commission to act, UKIP abstained.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because, although it can be improved, it clearly represents an opportunity for improving the integration of people who are deaf or hard of hearing.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this report, which underlines the great importance of having qualified sign language interpreters and, to this end, in particular the recognition of national and regional sign languages in the Member States and in thewithin the institutions of the Union, to develop official training and to allow official recognition of the profession.The report also stresses the accessibility for deaf, deaf, and blind or hard of hearing citizens to the same information and communications as their fellow citizens through sign language interpretation, captioning, recognition.voice or other forms of communication, including through oral interpreters.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, because I consider it essential that all people with some type of disability have equal rights, inalienable dignity, equal treatment, an independent life, autonomy and full participation in society.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Around 1 million deaf sign language users live within the European Union, to which must be added the 51 million hard of hearing citizens who also use sign language to a large extent to communicate. These are citizens who have equal rights and can rightly demand equal treatment that can ensure them an independent and autonomous life and full participation in social life. The resolution approved today by Parliament, which I have decided to support with conviction, reiterates the need to guarantee accessibility that is not limited only to the physical environment, but that is extended to information and communication, which must offer content in the language signs. To this end, professional and qualified interpreters are required, enrolled in special registers and appropriately trained and paid. New technologies must be used to bring benefits to users, with interventions that from subtitling reach online content that can be used live and remotely through intermediaries. The European institutions must be at the forefront of this battle, presenting the best examples of good practice and striving to provide reasonable accommodation and accessibility.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, because I fully share the spirit of non-discrimination against social groups such as deaf people, and we defend the principle of equality in institutions.The Resolution has been firmly defended and worked on by our parliamentary group, and defends the full integration of this group by facilitating the accessibility of all information, and requesting European recognition of professional sign language interpreters.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I supported the resolution on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters, as well as the four amendments you tabled to it.This Resolution highlights the need for qualified and professional sign language interpreters, which can be met through the official recognition of national and regional sign languages in the Member States and the institutions of the Union, as well as by university or similar regulated training.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I have decided to support this resolution concerning sign language and professional sign language interpreters. This is based in particular on the UN convention on the rights of people with disabilities, which has been ratified by France and, secondarily, by the European Union. For once, the text does not fall under interference and recalls that people with disabilities should be able to enjoy the same rights as every citizen, in particular through accessibility and reasonable accommodation measures. It is a struggle that is dear to me, which is why I often table amendments in the Culture Committee, on texts relating to sport or education, to promote greater social inclusion of people with disabilities. Furthermore, I am in favor of official recognition of interpreters in sign languages, with in particular the attribution of a similar status, within the European institutions, as for interpreters of spoken languages.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- In Europe live one million deaf citizens and 51 million hard of hearing who struggle every day to make their voices heard in society.In recent years in the European Parliament, I have actively supported the battle for the rights of these citizens.I therefore intended to support with my vote this resolution which promotes the official recognition of national sign languages and also the formal recognition of the profession of sign language interpreter and of specific national or regional registers for operators in the sector.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - On September 28, the historic conference on "Multilingualism and equal rights in the EU: the role of sign languages" took place in the European Parliament. Speakers highlighted the importance of sign language recognition and the availability of interpretation for the full inclusion of deaf people in society. They also stressed that recognition alone is not enough: only the full application of legislation can ensure that deaf people have access to interpreters, with a serious lack of fully qualified university interpreters. This common Resolution of the S & amp; D, PPE, ECR, ALDE, Verts / ALE and EFDD Groups contains the basic principles on the qualification of sign language professionals and on access for deaf, deaf and hard of hearing people. to this type of services, so as to guarantee equal opportunities and non-discrimination in areas such as education, the labor market and European institutions. In Spain alone, more than one million people suffer from hearing impairment, of which about one hundred thousand suffer from profound deafness. For these reasons, I have voted in favor of this Resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it advocated strengthening the profession of sign language and sign language interpreters in the European Union.The resolution calls for the recognition of sign languages as official in the European Union and for the strengthening of the profession of sign language interpreter.Almost 52 million people in the European Union use sign language, but the profession of sign language interpreter is not recognized in all Member States and many do not yet have a university teaching.In my opinion, deaf and blind people and people with hearing impairments must have access to the same information, communication and learning methods as everyone else.We must provide sign language translation, subtitling, voice to text translation services, and interpreters.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one element of the education-employment-access triangle is left out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier-free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. In Hungary, this is guaranteed by law, it is time for this to become a daily practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agree with the motions for resolutions because all persons with disabilities, including the deaf and hard of hearing, some of whom use sign language, have full rights as full citizens and an inalienable right to respect for their dignity, equal treatment and independent participation, independence and full participation insociety.Given that there are around one million deaf sign language users and 51 million deaf citizens in the EU, many of whom also use sign language, it is important to make their lives as easy as possible and to enable them to be equally involved in society.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report, which considers that access to high-quality services and reasonable adaptation of sign language needs to be strengthened to ensure equal treatment and participation of people with disabilities in society.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution because the Union constantly fights against discrimination based on disability and for the equal participation of such persons in society. In this regard, I recognised the need to provide the European institutions with qualified and professional sign language interpreters.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- Recognizing the importance of sign language is an act of civilization that can no longer be postponed.All European citizens have the right to be informed, to access public documents, to be able to know and to intervene in the political debate.It is necessary to remedy the shortage of sign language interpreters and equip ourselves with new professionals capable of making what has been developed by the institutions of the European Union truly usable for all citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This consensual motion for a resolution aims to improve accessibility and integration of people with disabilities, relying in particular on the United Nations Convention on the rights of people with disabilities, ratified in 2016 by France and the European Union.Among the recommendations, we will retain the desire to make all public services accessible to people with disabilities and to officially recognize national sign languages.I obviously voted in favor of this text.We consider that it is essential in our societies to protect and promote the integration of the most vulnerable.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Taking into account the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and the United Nations Convention, it is necessary for the EU to combat discrimination on the grounds of disability and to develop the necessary measures to ensure autonomy, social and professional integration and participation in community life for people with disabilities. At the same time, it should be noted that there are currently around one million sign language users and 51 million hearing-impaired citizens, many of them using sign language. I consider that persons with disabilities, in their capacity as full citizens, women and children, or deaf and hard of hearing persons, those who especially use sign language and do not use it, have equal rights and are entitled to have part of inalienable dignity, equal treatment and an independent life. In this context, I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on sign language and professional sign language interpreters because I believe that there should be no discrimination against people who use sign language.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, which places greater emphasis on professional and qualified sign language interpreters. The proposal indicates the need to remedy the shortage of such interpreters, through formal recognition of the profession, the achievement of a formal qualification and registration in a register. It undoubtedly manifests itself as a very valid proposal because it benefits certain groups of subjects (deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens) who must have the same right as others to access information. And it is for this reason that sign language interpretation is a highly relevant professional service. Furthermore, the proposal stresses the importance of introducing deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing students as well as parents to national sign language through school and preschool courses. Implementation of the EU INSIGN pilot project, which aims to improve communication between the deaf and hard of hearing with EU institutions, is requested.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, motion for a resolution. There are many aspects of the resolution which UKIP in principle could support and of course we want to further help those people who are deaf, blind, partially sighted and hard of hearing. However we cannot support the EU telling Member States what they should be doing or in any way give an excuse for action at EU level. The only people who should decide these things is our elected national government, not unaccountable EU institutions. As the resolution itself didn’t contain anything which called on the EU or the Commission to act, UKIP abstained.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - As enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the European institutions have a duty to fight against all forms of discrimination based on disability. The deaf and hard of hearing experience every day the obstacles to equal participation in all areas of life, whether it be education, employment, health, justice or social and political life. The Union has a moral obligation to remove these obstacles and combat any existing discrimination. We must ensure that all citizens have access to the same information and communications in the form of sign language interpretation and subtitling with a high level of quality, a quality that too often varies considerably from one Member State to another. In this sense, I hope that the competent institutions can benefit from the new language technologies in allowing equal access for all to the digital space. I also believe that the insufficient implementation of the legislative recognition of sign language at national level and the lack of formal recognition of the profession of sign language interpreter need to be remedied. For these reasons, I voted in favor of the draft resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and emphasize the need for specialized professional sign language interpreters.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution on sign language and its professional interpreters is a positive initiative for the benefit of people with disabilities but also for a profession that offers important services to European society, strengthening their position and providing additional opportunities.That is why I voted in favor.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Positive vote for this report aimed at removing the obstacles that still prevent the full integration of deaf and hard of hearing citizens.The creation of a society accessible to the hearing impaired is fully acceptable.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - The shortage of professional and qualified sign language interpreters pushes me to vote firmly in favor of this resolution. Beyond any kind of doubt, it is a priority to guarantee total accessibility to the deaf and hard of hearing not only in the political processes that characterize the Union, but in any type of activity. It is therefore recommended that national and regional sign languages ​​be recognized in all Member States and within the European institutions themselves. The promotion of the linguistic identity of deaf communities and the learning of sign language is also required. This appears to be achievable only through an efficient training system, which must be followed by the establishment of a register of interpreters and the formal recognition of the profession. Furthermore, accessibility requires to be pursued regardless of the burden and it is mandatory also due to the scarce offer of interpretation that can be found. Ensuring equal access to employment, education and training is a categorical imperative and is the tangible result of early intervention programs aimed at developing life skills. In line with this, I look forward to the full implementation of the EU INSIGN pilot project, a real-time sign language interpretation service.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on sign language and professional sign language interpreters.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing.- In Europe, there are only about one million sign language users and more than 50 million people with hearing impairment.These figures are sufficient to understand the impact of any measure in this area.However, there is no holistic approach at European level in this matter, which must take into account the increasing mobility of citizens, with the consequent language barriers, as well as the specificities of the online world, namely in access to public services.This resolution makes a detailed identification of these challenges and presents a set of solutions and best practices, intending to be a first impetus for their implementation.In this sense, Parliament - as this resolution rightly proposes - must implement a set of measures to combat unjustified discrimination within doors.I therefore support this resolution.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the rapporteur in his emphasis for qualified and professional sign language interpreters. True inclusiveness permits deaf, deafblind and hard-of-hearing citizens to have access to the same information and communication as their peers in the form of sign language interpretation, subtitling, speech-to-text and/or alternative forms of communication, including oral interpreters. Early intervention programmes are crucial for children in the development of life skills, including language skills.  This motion is positive in the sense that it notes, furthermore, that those programmes should ideally include deaf role models rather than categorise them as stereotypes.  In this sense, I support the call for Member States to encourage the learning of sign language in the same way as foreign languages. I believe that all persons with disabilities are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society.  The EU’s multilingualism policy should be enabled further to promote this principle.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution since it is committed to the effective defense of the rights of deaf, deaf-blind or hard of hearing people and calls for a series of measures such as the official recognition of sign languages, both national and regional , in the different Member States, as well as in the institutions of the Union. In addition, it advocates for the professional recognition of sign language interpreters and advocates the incorporation of sign language into educational programs in a similar way to foreign languages. Likewise, it considers that the inclusion of deaf, deaf-blind or hearing-impaired people must be guaranteed in European programs such as Erasmus +, and their labor integration must be effectively promoted in the European institutions. Aware of the importance of promoting sign language at an educational level to sensitize society as a whole and facilitate respect for the right to equality of the more than 52 million citizens and residents who are estimated to speak in different languages ​​of signs in the Union, I have decided to support this text.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The resolution adopted by Parliament on sign languages ​​and qualified sign language interpreters will help to ensure that the fundamental right of deaf and hard of hearing citizens, sign language interpretation, is guaranteed. Sign language interpretation ensures the full participation of the persons concerned in social, cultural and political life, as sign language is the mother tongue itself for those who use sign language. Forms of discrimination affecting the deaf and hard of hearing must also be eliminated. I would like to highlight in particular the rights of children and those who belong to a minority language-speaking community, and further positive, supportive impulses are needed at European and Member State level with regard to their situation. It is very important that there are services for families and children that ensure the rights of children and parents who speak and sign in the minority language, including access to appropriate education for children.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the regulation of sign language and professional sign language interpreters.I believe that action in this matter is very important in order to ensure the highest possible comfort of work for people with disabilities.The EU institutions are bound by the obligations of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) to implement its provisions in order to ensure equal treatment of disabled citizens.The adopted resolution proposes solutions of a comprehensive nature, contributing to the facilitation of the free functioning of disabled people in public space and EU institutions.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ All citizens, including persons with disabilities, are entitled to dignity, equal treatment, independent living and autonomy. This is why I am in favour of this resolution as it is important to recognise the need for qualified and professional sign language interpreters for deaf and hard-of-hearing people. This service is important and we need to ensure that appropriate remuneration is given to those offering the service. Persons with disabilities must have access to the same information and communication as their peers in the form of sign language and this is why we need to make sure that these communication tools are made available at both national and European Level, and that those offering the service have the qualifications needed.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - European citizens all have full rights, regardless of whether we are talking about people with disabilities, especially women and children, and especially deaf and hard of hearing people. These persons use sign language as a means of communication with other persons, which is why they have equal rights and are entitled to enjoy inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. Unfortunately, this is hampered by the fact that they use sign language. I therefore support the need to ensure the training of qualified and professional sign language interpreters, and the necessary measures are the official recognition of national and regional sign languages ​​in the Member States and the EU institutions, formal training (university or similar, equivalent to three years). up-to-date study, which corresponds to the required training of spoken language interpreters), as well as registration (official accreditation and quality control system, such as continuing professional development).

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- By adopting this resolution, Parliament is making its recommendations for the better integration of deaf and hard of hearing European citizens.I supported this text, which places particular emphasis on the training and status of professional sign language interpreters.With regard to equal treatment, it is essential to grant the same status to sign language interpreters as to spoken language interpreters.The European institutions will have to set an example by officially granting these statutes to its sign language interpreters.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor because I believe that all deaf and hard of hearing people have the right to dignity, equal treatment, autonomy and social inclusion.I urge the Member States and the European institutions to increase the number of sign language interpreters to allow deaf and hard of hearing people to participate fully in the social life.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this report.This is a consensual motion for a resolution, which builds on the UN convention and aims to promote the inclusion of people with disabilities, but without encouraging interference in the policies of the member states.So there is no reason to oppose it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - Following the ratification by the European Union of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2010, the EU institutions are already in the process of having a legal obligation to implement the provisions contained in the Convention, which includes accessibility and equality for all. citizens with disabilities. To this end, my group of European Conservatives and Reformists requested a statement from the Commission, accompanied by a resolution that I supported. The aim is to put pressure on the EU institutions to fully implement the Convention, which includes the provision of sign language for public events and meetings held in the EU institutions. The resolution includes qualifications, reasonable accommodation and accessibility, employment, education, training and the role of the EU institutions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.Deaf, hard of hearing and hard of hearing citizens should have access to the same information and communication with their fellow citizens through sign language interpretation, subtitling, speech recognition and / or alternative forms of communication, including interpreter.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation.
