There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written. - Accessibility is a prerequisite for people with disabilities to be able to live independently and participate fully in society on equal terms. Said accessibility is not limited only to the physical accessibility of the environment, but includes accessibility to information and communication, also in the form of content presented in sign language. On the other hand, both the professional situation of qualified and professional sign language interpreters and the quality of subtitles on public and private television varies considerably between Member States. Bearing in mind that the 1961 European Social Charter establishes in article 15 that every disabled person has the right to social integration and participation in the life of the community, from the European Parliament we support this resolution on sign languages ​​and professional sign language interpreters.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution on sign language. I support more rights for sign language users as well as the measures called for in the resolution regarding professional qualifications for interpreters. It is an issue of accessibility and equality. Representing a bilingual nation where the rights of Welsh speakers have been hard won, I know the importance of equality in relation to language.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The issues of sign language and the existence of interpreters are extremely relevant. This resolution comes a few days after the National Day of the Portuguese Sign Language, an event that should be valued in the respect for the inclusion of its users. The PCP has materialized some measures in this direction, through its intervention in the Assembly of the Republic. Here are some measures that should be considered: - The need to provide technical support to deaf students, including interpretation (so that it is not paid by families); - Considering that few companies have the resources to include deaf people, it is important to promote services that promote an inclusive policy (availability of interpreters); - Strive for the recognition of sign languages ​​as official languages; - Involve deaf associations in the definition of policies; - Improve the professional situation of sign language interpreters and teachers, by equating them with equivalent professionals (other language interpreters and teachers); - Allow bilingual people / children to enter schools that use sign language; - Develop technologies that allow access to emergency or other services (such as 112 - a measure, moreover, recently announced). This resolution, which is eminently technical, highlights the needs of deaf people. Many of the issues that are part of our proposals for this area are included. We voted in favor.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters.I firmly believe in the importance and defense of the rights of deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens, from a symbolic but also a practical point of view.The latter must have access to the same information and communications as their counterparts in the form of sign language interpretation, subtitling and alternative forms of communication, including interpreters.Equal access to services for citizens must be a constantly present variable, which we MEPs must never forget.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it has obvious tangible benefits for the deaf community.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The European Parliament's resolution seeks to strengthen and improve the position and situation of sign language, its accessibility, but also to strengthen the role of professional sign language interpreters and thus become more involved in the fight against discrimination on the grounds of disability.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the resolution to ask Member States and institutions to remove some obstacles that still prevent the full integration of deaf citizens.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the motion for a resolution as a whole, as deaf, blind and hard of hearing citizens should have access to the same information and communication with their fellow citizens through sign language interpretation, subtitling, speech recognition and / or alternativeforms of communication, including interpreters.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – The European Parliament resolution seeks to improve the situation of the sign languages, their access and availability, and strengthen the role of professional sign language interpreters, in order to step up the fight against discrimination based on disability. Access to high-quality sign language services and measures of reasonable accommodation need to be strengthened in order to ensure equal treatment and participation of persons with disabilities in society.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution bearing in mind that as full citizens, all people with disabilities, in particular women and children, including deaf and hard of hearing people, both those who use sign language and those who do not, enjoy equal rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, an independent life, autonomy and full participation in society.Therefore, it is necessary to have the official recognition of national and regional sign languages in the Member States and the institutions of the Union, as well as formal training.All citizens of the Union should have access to the same information and communication as the rest through sign language interpretation, subtitles, voice recognition or alternative forms of communication, including oral language interpretation.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report on ensuring the rights of individuals who use sign language and that their need for interpreters is respected. The report outlines the necessary qualifications that should apply for an interpreter and applies the same standards for sign language interpreters – this is an important step to ensure that no discrimination exists and that these interpreters have professional recognition.   The European institutions must have a commitment to making the political process as accessible as possible for everyone – including through sign language interpreters – and this requires recognised minimum standards. Access to employment, education and training are a key issue for the inclusion of people with hearing disabilities and we must ensure that every action is taken to ensure the equal opportunity to learn and work.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted for the very good resolution of my EKR colleague Helga Stevens on “Sign language and professional sign language interpreters”.I would like to see a strengthening of sign languages in Europe and even better accessibility for the deaf - also in the European Parliament.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- There are around 1 million deaf people in the European Union.Any grievances with regard to their equality must be remedied immediately.This also includes recognizing the various regional and national sign languages.It is through this recognition that we guarantee the deaf full-fledged interpretation in all EU institutions.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution because I oppose EU interference and action in EU Member States regarding sign language, but I don’t oppose the use of sign language. It should be up to national governments to decide.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, given that access to high-quality sign language services and measures of reasonable accommodation need to be strengthened in order to ensure equal treatment and participation of persons with disabilities in society.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because the European Union must not only defend in words but also concretely apply the rights of all citizens. And in fact, as full citizens, all people with disabilities, and in this particular we are talking about those who need the support of sign language, have the inalienable right to full participation in the life of the society to which they belong. The guarantee of this right must be demonstrated starting with the European institutions. In particular, I am convinced that it is right to urge the institutions to give the same recognition to sign language interpreters that is granted to spoken language interpreters in relation to the interpretation services they provide on a daily basis. To achieve this, there are concrete steps that can also be taken in the Member States, starting with training and formal recognition of the profession. Finally, we must recognize that the interpretation of sign language constitutes a professional service that requires adequate remuneration, by virtue of the service they offer and the possibility they give to the institutions to guarantee respect for the right to equality among all European citizens.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, because I fully share the spirit of non-discrimination against social groups such as deaf people, and we defend the principle of equality in institutions.The Resolution has been firmly defended and worked on by our parliamentary group, and defends the full integration of this group by facilitating the accessibility of all information, and requesting European recognition of professional sign language interpreters.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I fundamentally believe that high-quality sign language services and measures of reasonable accommodation need to be strengthened across the EU. This is the only way in which persons with disabilities can receive equal treatment and fully participate in society.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make political public life accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is already guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of the report because it is moving in the right direction, calling on the European Union to recognize the needs of deaf and hard of hearing people and to take all necessary measures to provide them with all the necessary professional interpretation services.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that clearly states that all citizens, all persons with disabilities including those who use sign language and those who don’t, all have equal rights  and are entitled to equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. There are currently 51 million deaf sign language users in the EU and 51 million hard of hearing citizens. The EU needs to combat discrimination based on defining and implementing its policies and activities. One opportunity we can use in Ireland, is the ratification of the UN Convention on the rights of persons with disabilities which clearly articulates that all persons including those in the deaf, deaf blind and hard of hearing community are entitled to full participation in society. This convention also elaborates on the need for reasonable accommodation, but there can be no reasonable accommodation without the provision of qualified and professional sign language interpreters. For this to happen one crucial requirement is the have official recognition of national and regional sign languages in the Member States and within EU institutions.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ With the EU ratifying the UNCRPD (UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities) in 2010, the EU institutions are now under a legal obligation to implement the provisions contained in the Convention, which includes accessibility and equality for all disabled citizens.  To this effect, the ECR Group requested to have a Commission statement with a resolution voted in plenary in order to put pressure on the EU institutions to fully implement the CRPD, which includes the provision of sign language interpreters for public events and meetings held in the EU institutions. The ECR Group has drafted a resolution which addresses the following issues: qualifications, reasonable accommodation and accessibility, employment, education, training and the role of the EU institutions. I voted in favour of the ECR joint motion for a resolution.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: In written form. - Mr President, unfortunately, many European citizens face various barriers that prevent them from exercising their full range of rights. One of the groups most affected in this respect is people with disabilities, who are often placed in a situation of lack of adequate social integration and inability to reach their full potential. The insufficient number of sign language translators clearly points to this problem. It makes it difficult to obtain information from sources other than written sources, presupposes difficulties in education, the provision of social services and active participation in political life for people with hearing and speech impairments. I believe that a truly inclusive 21st century Europe must strive by all means to overcome the difficulties faced by people with disabilities, as this will help to unleash their potential and, ultimately, to enrich the European economy.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ There is a great need for developing new language technologies and high quality sign language interpreting services. Moreover, there needs to be more involvement of representatives from the deaf community.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Motion for a Resolution on Sign Language and Professional Sign Language Translators because all Member States lack qualified and professional sign language translators, and as full citizens, all persons with disabilities, especially women and children, including deaf and hard of hearing people,use sign language and those who do not use it, have equal rights and have the right to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society.What is primarily needed to be done is to officially recognize national and regional sign languages in the Member States and within the EU institutions, to recognize the profession and to provide formal training (college or similar level).

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- On the whole, the motion for a resolution is rather consensual, once is not customary, as it does not attack the policy of the Member States and is limited to recommendations on accessibility and inclusion.In addition, I generally support the measures proposed and welcome respect for the sovereignty and competences of States.I voted for.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Adam Kosa on sign language and professional interpreters.The report calls for the recognition of a status of qualified sign language professionals.A statute modeled on that of spoken language interpreters to put an end to the breach of equality between professional interpreters.It is also a question of developing standards on sign language while recognizing the regional and national specificities present in the EU.The report highlights considerations which today affect millions of Europeans (one million are deaf, 51 million are hard of hearing) and which the European institutions must address.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which mainly emphasizes the need for qualified sign language interpreters.More generally, it recalls the evidence of equality to which deaf or hard of hearing people are entitled, particularly in access to information and communication, a fortiori in the public service and in particular for political programs.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting in favor of this resolution.It takes an important step towards equality and equality for people with disabilities, especially by providing sign language interpreting.In addition, she advocates greater accessibility for people with disabilities in terms of interpreting.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is that high-quality sign language services and measures of reasonable accommodation need to be strengthened across the EU. This is the only way in which persons with disabilities can receive equal treatment and fully participate in society.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: written. - I welcome our resolution on sign languages ​​and professional sign language interpreters. We should promote sign language learning in the same way as foreign language learning! After all, there are around 1 million deaf and 51 million hearing-impaired sign language users in the EU. In view of the multitude of national and regional sign languages, which, like the spoken languages, are full natural languages ​​with their own grammar and syntax, official recognition of the profession of sign language interpreter is long overdue. This is particularly true of the Member States. We in the EU institutions could lead by example. Many deaf people still face major obstacles when trying to participate in areas such as education, employment, justice, culture or even politics. One of the main reasons for this is the existing shortage of qualified, professional sign language interpreters. As a rule, these require academic training. However, their registration, quality control and ongoing professional development are just as important. Another concern that is particularly important to me is that the Europe-wide emergency number 112 should be available to all people, i. H. also accessible to deaf citizens in Europe. The emergency services must be appropriately equipped and able to respond to accidents and emergencies in which deaf and hearing-impaired citizens are involved.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing.- In Wednesday's plenary vote in the European Parliament, I voted in favor of sign languages and sign language interpreters.It is estimated that there are around 1 million deaf people in sign languages and 51 million hard of hearing people in the European Union, most of whom also use sign languages.However, every citizen has the right to equal treatment and full integration into society.That is why, in plenary, I supported further efforts to ensure the independence and autonomy of deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing people.Member States should commit to the training of new sign language interpreters in order to guarantee access for all citizens to education, employment, technology and a full life.And the institutions of the European Union should lead by example.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I support the resolution on sign languages ​​and professional sign language interpreters. Every citizen, regardless of their state of health, has the right to a full, independent and equal life. Accessibility should not be limited to the physical accessibility of the environment, but should also be limited to the accessibility of information and communication, including in the form of providing content in sign language. I am convinced that the development of new language technologies could benefit people who use sign language. The Convention emphasizes the need to provide professional sign language interpreters in order to ensure equal access to employment, education and training.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - In the EU there are around 1 million deaf sign language users and 51 million hard of hearing, who often use sign language All these people, whether they use sign language or not, have the right to an independent life, equal treatment, autonomy and participation in social life. Accessibility, understood both on a physical level and on information and communication, is the key element in guaranteeing these rights. There is unfortunately a shortage of qualified sign language interpreters in our Member States, and therefore very often limited access to information for those with disabilities. For these reasons, the report approved today presents proposals aimed at increasing the number of professional and qualified sign language interpreters, increasing accessibility to information, ensuring equal access to employment, education and training. and, finally, to make the institutions of the European Union more accessible. Citizens of the Union are entitled to the same opportunities regardless of race, gender, age and disability, and for these reasons I am voting in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because, although it can be improved, it clearly represents an opportunity for improving the integration of people who are deaf or hard of hearing.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written.- I have voted in favor of the motion because it succinctly contains some basic principles in relation to the qualification of professionals in the interpretation of sign language and the access of deaf, deaf-mute and people with serious hearing problems to ittype of services, so as to guarantee equal opportunities and non-discrimination in areas of special interest, such as access to education or the labor market, and especially in European Institutions.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution since it is committed to the effective defense of the rights of deaf, deaf-blind or hard of hearing people and calls for a series of measures such as the official recognition of sign languages, both national and regional , in the different Member States, as well as in the institutions of the Union. In addition, it advocates for the professional recognition of sign language interpreters and advocates the incorporation of sign language into educational programs in a similar way to foreign languages. Likewise, it considers that the inclusion of deaf, deaf-blind or hearing-impaired people must be guaranteed in European programs such as Erasmus +, and their labor integration must be effectively promoted in the European institutions. Aware of the importance of promoting sign language at an educational level to sensitize society as a whole and facilitate respect for the right to equality of the more than 52 million citizens and residents who are estimated to speak in different languages ​​of signs in the Union, I have decided to support this text.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of increasing accessibility of communication with sign language.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Persons who use sign language and those who do not use it, have equal rights and have the right to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. The EU's multilingualism policy promotes the learning of foreign languages, and one of its objectives is for every European, apart from their mother tongue, to speak two languages. For this reason, learning and promoting national and regional sign languages ​​could contribute to this goal. Deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens must have access to the same information and communication as other persons in the form of sign language translation, text-to-speech or alternative forms of communication, including interpreters. I believe that the EU institutions must be an example of best practice when it comes to ensuring adaptation and accessibility for their employees, elected officials and interns, and that includes translation into sign language. The motion for a resolution encourages institutions to officially grant sign language translators the same status as interpreters in relation to the translation services they offer institutions, including access to technological support, preparatory materials and documents, so I supported it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Removing barriers for the hearing impaired must be a matter of course.By not respecting this basic need, they are expelled from society, preventing and denying them the exercise of their fundamental rights.Therefore, I fully support the proposal that all institutions of public and social life provide accessible and adequate interpretation into sign language so as to create all the conditions for a full-fledged life for hearing-impaired citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the motion for a resolution on sign language and professional sign language interpreters because it is complete and substantiated.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- I advocate equal rights for people with disabilities.An important step in this direction is the provision of sign language interpretation, more accessibility for people with disabilities in the sense of interpretation.I fully agree with this version.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution.Sign language users must have better access to information and the conditions to ensure their full participation in society.In order to achieve these goals, it is especially important to train qualified professional sign language interpreters and ensure their working conditions.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- Member States face a shortage of qualified and professional sign language interpreters.To remedy this, the resolution calls for “the official recognition of national and regional sign languages in the Member States and within the institutions of the Union”, as well as the establishment of official training (university or equivalent, i.e. three yearsfull-time studies, which corresponds to the training required for spoken language interpreters) and official recognition of the profession.All of this is going in the right direction.I simply regret that the joint resolution does not take into account the proposals made by my GUE / NGL group.In particular, he called for the establishment of a code of ethics for interpreters, or the establishment of emergency services capable of communicating with hearing-impaired individuals.Nevertheless, I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- Despite a few problematic paragraphs on multilingualism in the EU or on freedom of movement, it is generally a consensual resolution in favor of accessibility for people with disabilities, without calling into question the competenceMember States.Therefore, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- As full citizens, all persons with disabilities, including deaf and hearing impaired persons, including those who use and who do not use sign language, enjoy the same rights and have an inalienable right to dignity,equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society.The EU institutions must be an example of good practice towards EU citizens, with regard to the adoption of reasonable accommodation and accessibility measures, which include the provision of sign language interpretation.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion because thanks to professional sign language interpreters there will be greater equality of access to information and discussion for deaf and hard-of-hearing people.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote in favor of the motion for a resolution concerning sign language and professional sign language interpreters. Every citizen has the right to choose his life, to fulfill himself in his singularity and to freely exercise his potential. It is essential to fight against any discrimination based on disability. Equality between individuals must be real in accordance with the 2006 United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Everyone has the right to dignity, to equal treatment, to independent life, to full participation in social life. Accessibility is not limited to physical accessibility, but goes beyond, in particular the accessibility of information and communication as well as equal access to justice, to employment , education and training. By voting for this resolution, we are helping to ensure the full and equal enjoyment of all human rights for people with disabilities while respecting their dignity.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the text of the EP Resolution, which seeks to improve the situation of sign languages, their access and availability, and strengthen the role of professional sign language interpreters, in order to step up the fight against discrimination based on disability.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The GUE / NGL Group had tabled a separate draft resolution on sign languages and qualified sign language interpreters and the PPE, S&D, ECR, ALDE, Verts / ALE and EFDD groups.I supported the latter with my vote.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution is fairly consensual, as it is part of a desire for greater accessibility and integration for people with disabilities, without ever indicating a desire to interfere in the policies of the Member States.It is based in particular on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which was ratified in 2016 by France and the European Union.Despite a few failing paragraphs, it is therefore overall a consensual resolution in favor of accessibility for people with disabilities.We are also quite favorable to the proposed measures.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- Despite some flawed paragraphs, this resolution in favor of accessibility for people with disabilities is a step in the right direction.I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this text on sign language and professional sign language interpreters.In particular, it calls on the European Union to put sign language interpreters and spoken language interpreters on an equal footing, both in terms of their remuneration but also in terms of their access to preparatory documents to prepare thesittings of Parliament.People with deafness should not be excluded from European construction and European action because of their disability.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- One of the fundamental principles of the European Union is equal treatment for all, including women, children, minorities and people with disabilities.Today, we adopted a motion for a resolution that makes this possible for people with disabilities.Through the European Union institutions, the petitioners want to set a good example of the use of sign language, supported by recommendations and measures.I welcome the initiative, we have once again taken a step in the right direction.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ All persons with disabilities, including deaf and hard-of-hearing persons have equal rights and are entitled to equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that stresses the need for qualified professional sign language interpreters.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I have spoken out in favor of this report and I am committed to equal rights for people with disabilities.In my opinion, the provision of sign language interpretation and more accessibility for people with disabilities in the sense of interpreting is a further step in the right direction.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.There is a significant proportion of people in the EU who use sign language and for whom access to not only the physical environment but also information and communication is essential for independent living and participation in society.It is therefore important that both the Member States and the EU institutions do their utmost to ensure that they have access to the same information and communication as other citizens through sign language or other forms of communication.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I support the resolution that has been tabled. It should be noted that accessibility is a precondition for deaf, deaf and blind people and people with hearing impairments to live independently and with equal rights to participate fully in society. They must have access to the same information and means of communication as everyone else. Against this background, it is necessary to provide more assistance and more concrete measures. In particular, sign language should be included in educational programs in order to raise awareness and promote the use of sign language. Necessary adaptation measures, including the services of professional sign language interpreters, must be put in place to ensure equal access to employment, education and training. In addition, the national and regional sign language or languages ​​should be officially recognized in the Member States and in the EU institutions, and the working conditions of sign language interpreters should be improved.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - There are around one million deaf sign language users in the EU and 51 million hearing-impaired citizens, many of whom are also sign language users. The resolution, which I voted in favor of, emphasizes the need for formal recognition of national and regional sign languages ​​in the Member States and the EU institutions, strengthening the role of professional sign language interpreters, and providing high-quality sign language interpretation services in order to strengthen the fight against discrimination on the grounds of disability. Also, as pointed out in the resolution, accessibility must be ensured, ie deaf, hard of hearing and hard of hearing citizens must have access to the same information and communication with their fellow citizens through sign language interpretation, subtitling, speech recognition and / or alternative forms of communication. As full-fledged citizens, all people with disabilities have equal rights and are unquestionably entitled to respect for their dignity, equal treatment, as well as independent living, autonomy and full participation in society.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that all people with disabilities whether or not they use sign language have equal rights. The European Union, both with the TFEU establishes, in accordance with Article 10, the need to fight against discrimination based on disability and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union prohibits such discrimination and, at the same time, promotes the equal participation of disabled people in the life of the community. Furthermore, in the European area we can count 1 million deaf sign language users and 51 million hard of hearing citizens, consequently the European Union, in addition to promoting the knowledge of a greater number of languages ​​spoken, must also promote knowledge of the language. of signs, recognizing the same importance to those who know this language as spoken language interpreters. These rights recognized to disabled people must also extend to accessibility to information sources, therefore the presence of sign language connoisseurs should also be promoted on the European media. I therefore voted in favor.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this report because I believe that we must continuously work on erasing all forms of discrimination against people with disabilities. Here we often forget people who at first glance we think do not have a disability, so there is often a wrong assumption that they should not be given equal access to information, work or simply participation in social activities. The Declaration of Human Rights obliges us, as citizens of Europe and as members of the European Parliament, to work continuously for the betterment of our citizens and the improvement of the situation in the world. By hiring a professional sign language interpreter, we enable deaf people and people with hearing impairments to have the same level of participation as everyone else. This is particularly important for the European institutions, which represent all the citizens of Europe. It is important to really represent all citizens and provide fellow citizens with disabilities equal access to our institutions and the same experience as others. Due to the way society works today, deaf and hard of hearing people are placed in an inferior position both in terms of their own representation and in terms of functioning in life, so they should enable interpreters in all public institutions, especially those of the legal type. to live what we say, to live equality and to implement it every day.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution is fairly consensual since it is part of a desire for greater accessibility and integration for people with disabilities, without ever indicating a desire to interfere in the policies of the Member States.It is based in particular on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which was ratified in 2016 by France and the European Union.Under these conditions, attached to improving the lives of people with disabilities, I vote in favor of this resolution.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - There are approximately one million people in the EU who use sign language for the deaf, and a further 51 million deaf people. Accessibility is a prerequisite for people with disabilities to lead independent lives and participate equally in society, and it is not limited to physical accessibility to the environment, but also to the accessibility of information and communication, including in the form of sign language content. The EU institutions must be an example of best practice when it comes to ensuring reasonable accommodation and accessibility for its employees, elected officials and trainees, and this includes translation into sign language. However, there is a lack of qualified and professional sign language translators in all Member States. The need for them can only be met with the official recognition of national and regional sign or sign languages ​​in the Member States and within the EU institutions, and with formal training and official recognition of the profession. Likewise, balanced and comprehensive information on sign language and deafness must be offered so that parents can make informed decisions that are in the best interests of their children. Early intervention programs are key to developing life skills in children. Deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing students and their parents must be enabled to learn the national or regional sign language of their environment through pre-school care and in schools.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The issues of sign language and the existence of interpreters are extremely relevant, given the continued disregard for the rights of deaf people and their families. The resolution incorporates many of the issues on which we have been commenting, presenting concrete proposals, which include, among others, - the need to ensure technical support for deaf students, including interpretation; - boost services that promote an inclusive policy, seeking to counter the factors of exclusion, namely in access to employment, to which the deaf are subject; - guide the recognition of sign languages ​​as official languages; - involve deaf associations in the definition of policies; - improve the professional situation of sign language interpreters and teachers, by equating them with equivalent professionals; - allow bilingual people and children to enter schools that use sign language; - develop technologies that allow access to emergency or other services. The resolution, of an eminently technical nature, correctly emphasizes the needs of deaf people, reasons that motivated the favorable vote.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - For me as a Social Democrat, it is absolutely a priority to prevent any form of discrimination against people, including deaf citizens. That is why I am glad that we have succeeded in enforcing the resolution on sign languages ​​and professional sign language interpreters. Deaf people use national sign languages, which should be equal to other languages. There are around 1 million deaf people in the EU who use sign language and 51 million hard of hearing people, many of whom also prefer sign language. Until sign languages ​​are equal, it will be impossible for their users to achieve independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. Therefore, it is necessary to be able to use sign languages ​​in communication with national authorities and EU institutions, which in practice cannot be done without the involvement of interpreters in sign languages. We must strive for their equal conditions with interpreters in natural languages.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- In 2010, the EU ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD).The EU institutions are now legally bound to implement the rules in this convention that cover the equality of citizens with disabilities and the accessibility of services.My group asked for a statement from the Commission to put pressure on the EU institutions to fully implement the convention containing provisions on sign language interpreters at public events and meetings held in the EU institutions.I have hereby supported the resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I wanted to vote in favor of this resolution, which aims to improve the autonomy of people with disabilities, hard of hearing, deaf or blind.It is our duty to ensure that these people have the same rights as other citizens, by encouraging the development, training and recognition of the skills and status of sign language interpreters.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - All European citizens deserve equal treatment and equal opportunities, regardless of their differences. Accordingly, in view of the provisions of the TFEU rules, the European Union must combat potential inequalities when defining and implementing its policies and activities. In this context, citizens with special needs, such as the deaf and other people with hearing problems, including those who communicate via sign language, should benefit from a status identical to that of the whole of society. Thus, the human dignity intrinsic to their existence, which is inalienable to them, as well as the right to equal treatment, autonomy and active and complete participation in society, must be guaranteed to these citizens. Currently, in the European Union, there are about one million deaf people, as well as 51 million citizens with severe hearing difficulties, who communicate using sign language. The recognition of sign language as an official language in the Member States and their organizations is therefore crucial. Consequently, my vote is in favor.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up.- Deaf and hard of hearing people are full citizens, who should not be discriminated against and who should have access to services and information just like anyone else.The most important role in this regard is played by qualified and professional sign language interpreters, unfortunately too few in relation to sign language users.Their profession must be officially recognized in each country and importance must be attached to appropriate vocational training, in the same way as to the necessary training of spoken language interpreters.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative, non-binding, motion for a resolution. There are many aspects of the resolution which UKIP in principle could support and of course we want to further help those people who are deaf, blind, partially sighted and hard of hearing. However we cannot support the EU telling Member States what they should be doing or in any way give an excuse for action at EU level. The only people who should decide these things is our elected national government, not unaccountable EU institutions. As the resolution itself didn’t contain anything which called on the EU or the Commission to act, UKIP abstained

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- As full citizens, all persons with disabilities - in particular women and children, in particular deaf and hearing impaired people, including those who use and who do not use sign language - enjoy the same rights andthey have an inalienable right to dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society.There are about one million sign language users in the European Union and 51 million hearing impaired citizens, many of whom are also sign language users.Hence, priority issues are: the need for qualified interpreters and sign language professionals;improving accessibility to these services;ensuring equality of employment, education and training.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - On September 28, the historic conference on "Multilingualism and equal rights in the EU: the role of sign languages" was held in the European Parliament. Speakers highlighted the importance of sign language recognition and the availability of interpretation for the full inclusion of deaf people in society. They also stressed that recognition alone is not enough: only the full application of legislation can ensure that the deaf have access to interpreters, with a serious lack of fully qualified university interpreters. This joint motion of the Groups S & amp; D, EPP, ECR, ALDE, Greens and EFDD, contains the basic principles on the qualification of professionals in sign language and on the access of deaf, deaf-mute and people with serious hearing problems type of services, in such a way as to guarantee equal opportunities and non-discrimination in areas such as education, the labor market and European Institutions. In Spain alone there are more than one million people suffering from hearing impairment, of which about one hundred thousand suffer from profound deafness. For these reasons, I have voted in favor of this motion.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on sign languages ​​and professional sign language interpreters because it enshrines several important aspects in this area. First of all, this resolution stresses the importance of having sign language interpreters who are qualified and professional. Second, it further clarifies the distinction between accessibility and reasonable accommodation in sign language. Third, it addresses the issue of accessibility, including the need to ensure that people who are deaf, deaf and blind or hard of hearing have access to the same information and communications as their fellow citizens. Fourth, it highlights the commitment of Member States to guarantee the right to work for deaf, deaf, blind or hard of hearing citizens through education and training. Finally, she reiterates the role of example that the European institutions must play in terms of reasonable accommodation and accessibility for staff and visitors to the institutions.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I support the proposal to provide for the use of sign language interpreters in the work of the EU institutions.This creates the potential to reach an even wider audience.On the other hand, I lack specific review statistics and analyzes based on the interests of the deaf themselves as to what the real need for such translation is and how justified the costs would be.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - All citizens, and particularly citizens with disabilities, have the right to equal rights, undoubtedly having the right to dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. Currently, there are approximately one million sign language users in the European Union (EU) and 51 million hearing impaired citizens, many of whom are sign language users. The TFEU establishes that the EU, in defining and implementing its policies and actions, aims to combat discrimination on the grounds of disability, thereby assigning mechanisms for adopting legislation and combating this type of discrimination. This proposal lists measures that intend the EU to reinforce the promotion of the qualification of sign language interpreters and professionals, the inclusion of this language in the various public services, in the political and democratic process and in digital services. I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution as I consider it essential to provide the sign language interpretation service as a measure that contributes to combating discrimination and facilitates the inclusion of millions of people with hearing impairment.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- The European Union has nearly one million deaf people using sign language and 51 million hearing-impaired citizens, many of whom also use it.I voted in favor of this resolution which stresses the need for qualified and professional sign language interpreters.It is important to support the recognition and training of sign language interpreters.People with this disability must be able to enjoy the same rights as any citizen and must not be penalized for accessing their rights and freedoms.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, because I fully share the spirit of non-discrimination against social groups such as deaf people, and we defend the principle of equality in institutions.The Resolution has been firmly defended and worked on by our parliamentary group, and defends the full integration of this group by facilitating the accessibility of all information, and requesting European recognition of professional sign language interpreters.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this resolution. There are many challenges on the issue of sign language, but as we consider those challenges we should not forget about the situation in this House. I have already addressed my concerns directly to the President about the availability of sign language interpretation in the European Parliament. I have organised two events on Parliament premises about  disability issues and I am sorry to say that many improvements still need to be made to ensure people with disabilities have proper access to this institution.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution since it is committed to the effective defense of the rights of deaf, deaf-blind or hard of hearing people and calls for a series of measures such as the official recognition of sign languages, both national and regional , in the different Member States, as well as in the institutions of the Union. In addition, it advocates for the professional recognition of sign language interpreters and advocates the incorporation of sign language into educational programs in a similar way to foreign languages. Likewise, it considers that the inclusion of deaf, deaf-blind or hearing-impaired people must be guaranteed in European programs such as Erasmus +, and their labor integration must be effectively promoted in the European institutions. Aware of the importance of promoting sign language at an educational level to sensitize society as a whole and facilitate respect for the right to equality of the more than 52 million citizens and residents who are estimated to speak in different languages ​​of signs in the Union, I have decided to support this text.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - Following the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2010, the European Union has undertaken the obligation to implement the provisions contained therein. More specifically, this convention highlights the importance of the professional services of sign language interpreters in order to facilitate the equal and equal participation of deaf people in society. Indeed, accessibility, employment, education and training are some of the problems addressed in this resolution, as well as a more specific provision concerning the provision of sign language interpreters for public events and meetings held in the EU institutions. Considering that there are around 1 million deaf and 51 million hard of hearing people using sign languages ​​in Europe and that there is a shortage of professional and qualified interpreters in all Member States, it is important that the European institutions fully implement the Convention UN. I have therefore decided to vote in favor of the resolution.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I support the right for people to use sign language and I think it is a great way for people to communicate I do not wish to see the EU involved in such things. Therefore I abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of this resolution which seeks to improve the situation of the sign languages, their access and availability, and strengthen the role of professional sign language interpreters, in order to step up the fight against discrimination based on disability. Access to high-quality sign language services and measures of reasonable accommodation need to be strengthened in order to ensure equal treatment and participation of persons with disabilities in society.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ I support this measure to recognise sign language interpreters, and the important role they play for those without hearing.  It has been educational to see sign language used each day with colleagues, enabling full integration into the workplace, and making it possible to draw on the talents of those who would otherwise be excluded.  These languages are hard to learn, and must be treasured as part of our European culture, giving a strong message on equality for all.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I unequivocally supported the motion for a resolution tabled on the basis of the Commission's statement on sign language and professional sign language interpreters. Deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens must have the same access to information and communication as others, through sign language interpretation, subtitling, audio-to-text and alternative means of communication, including spoken language interpreters. The EU institutions are setting examples of good practice for staff, elected public officials and trainees, and for EU citizens in ensuring adequate adaptation to needs and accessibility, including the provision of sign language interpretation. Nevertheless, all institutions should be urged to formally give sign language interpreters the same status as spoken language interpreters in terms of interpreting services provided to the institutions or their staff and elected public officials, including access to technical support.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's own-initiative report on sign language and professional sign language interpreters. The report seeks the full involvement of the hearing impaired in society, in particular containing concrete proposals to address the shortage of qualified sign language translators, emphasizes the need to provide public and state services to the hearing impaired, accurate translations in court proceedings, or points to the use of language skills. technologies in the digital field. The report was adopted as amended, mentioning in particular the amendment calling for the Member States' commitment to call on media service providers to ensure that their services are gradually made available to people with a visual or hearing disability in the Audiovisual Media Services Directive. I voted in favor of this amendment because it is in line with what we in the Committee on Culture and Education are trying to push into the revised directive. I consider it essential that audiovisual media services be accessible to people with hearing impairments. It is essential to promote the full participation of people with hearing impairments in society and to give them access to information, including digital content. I consider making audiovisual media services accessible to people with hearing impairments a measure that will make a significant contribution to ensuring equal opportunities for these people, with a wider impact on their access to education and employment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - I believe that all people with disabilities must be given equal rights and the inalienable right to respect for their dignity, equal treatment and independent living, independence and full participation in society. At this point, it is important to note that there are around one million deaf sign language users and 51 million deaf citizens in the EU, many of whom use sign language. It should also be borne in mind that national and regional sign languages ​​are fully developed natural languages ​​with their own grammatical and syntactic rules, just like spoken languages. It is a matter of concern that there is a shortage of qualified and professional sign language interpreters in all Member States. Qualified and professional sign language interpreters are urgently needed in all Member States. However, an increase in the number of interpreters can be achieved by officially recognizing national and regional sign languages ​​in the Member States and EU institutions, providing formal training and officially recognizing the profession of sign language interpreter. I also support the resolution's call for deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens to have access to the same information and communication as hearing people. In view of all the above, I voted in favor of the resolution and supported it in the vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Deaf, hard of hearing citizens must have the same access to information and communication as others.Parliament therefore emphasizes the need to increase their support and strengthen specific provisions, e.g.sign language interpretation and textual information, but their quality must be ensured.The EU institutions need to create examples of good practice.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters.Help for people who depend on sign language and interpreters for them is a valuable concern.However, the present regulation seems to me to be a clear case of overregulation.Demanding that the interpreters have an academic training will result in a shortage of supply on the market.It is also not necessary to bureaucratise the profession through registrations.In the AfD I am campaigning for the abolition of compulsory chambers.I am against taking steps that encourage further professions to be unified.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- I express my support for this report because it offers a systematic approach to tackling the discrimination faced by people with disabilities.There are various forms of disability, as well as various degrees, and it is necessary to provide equal access to information, employment and participation in social events and activities.It is necessary to make sustained efforts to create a society that will provide equal opportunities for all and that will be aimed at the well-being of all, especially those struggling with certain shortcomings.Hiring professional sign language interpreters allows servants with disabilities and deaf people to integrate more easily and fully into the community.This is especially evident when observing the work of various institutions.A society of equality must be established and all people must have an equal chance of success in life, regardless of their own physical shortcomings or difficulties.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution at the end of the debate on the Commission statement on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters.I support the resolution, which emphasizes that deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens must have access to the same information and communication as hearing people.According to data, there are around one million deaf sign language users and 51 million deaf citizens in the European Union.In the light of greater access for deaf and hard of hearing citizens to equal information and communication, public and government services should be accessible through sign language interpreters on site or remotely via the Internet.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- The report is moving in the right direction, calling on the European Union to recognize the needs of deaf and hard of hearing people and to take all necessary measures to provide them with all the necessary professional interpretation services.It also calls for the implementation of holistic policies in this direction.Our group tried to strengthen the report by introducing amendments to specific policies in education systems, but without finding support from other political groups.We voted in favor of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.Deaf, hard of hearing and hard of hearing citizens should have access to the same information and communication with their fellow citizens through sign language interpretation, subtitling, speech recognition and / or alternative forms of communication, including interpreters.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one of the elements of the education - employment - access triangle falls out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier - free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - It is well known that the EU (Charter of Fundamental Rights) explicitly prohibits discrimination on the grounds of disability, supporting the equal participation of people with disabilities in society. I voted so that all people with hearing impairments, who face the lack of professionalism of interpreters in sign language, can be successfully involved in all areas of socio-economic life, benefiting from inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living. , autonomy and full participation in society. At the same time, given that the EU promotes multilingualism and, implicitly, language learning, sign language must be included in curricula in order not only to promote and learn sign language (like any other foreign language), but also to create the necessary conditions for the development of the degree of accessibility (of information and communications) of people with disabilities. In this respect, the official recognition of the profession of sign language interpreters and the granting, by the various institutions (starting with those of the EU), of the same status as that of spoken language interpreters, as regards the interpretation services they offer. institutions and / or their staff or appointed officials, including access to technical assistance and materials is a desire and a pressing need for people with disabilities.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up.- There is currently a shortage of qualified sign language interpreters.I would like to emphasize that people with disabilities are full citizens and must be treated equally, providing them with all the necessary conditions for active participation in society.In this context, I believe that the Member States of the European Union should encourage the learning of sign language in the same way as foreign languages are studied.An important element is the development of textbooks in formats and languages accessible to all.At the same time, there is a need for official recognition of regional and national sign languages in the Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.It is essential to have qualified and professional sign language interpreters and, to this end, measures should be taken for the official recognition of national and regional sign languages in the Member States and within the institutions of the Union, official training (university or equivalent, ie three years of full-time study, which corresponds to the training required for interpreters in spoken languages), registration and, finally, official recognition of the profession.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ INSIGN is the EU’s pilot project, which initiates the implementation of a real-time sign language application and service, aimed at improving communication between deaf and hard-of-hearing people and the EU institutions. This initiative will help cater to the needs of deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing visitors in the EU institutions by directly providing access to national or regional sign language and speech-to-text services. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on improving access to sign language and professional sign language interpreters because I believe, in the objective of true equality, that hearing-impaired persons should have access to the same quality interpretation and communication as any other person would have.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - Deaf people have the right to political participation. There is a need for qualified sign language interpreters to make the political process accessible during elections, public consultations and other events. Sign language interpretation is not an aid, but a fundamental human right: it is the mother tongue of the person who uses sign language. Interpretation enables deaf and deafblind people to live independent lives and to participate fully and equally in society. The decision calls on the Commission to examine the implementation of equal access to education for deaf and deaf children in the Member States and to fully implement the INSIGN European pilot project to improve communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. . If one element of the education-employment-access triangle is left out, the deaf will continue to be at a disadvantage: interpretation and barrier-free access will play a key role. Deaf, deaf-blind and hard-of-hearing students and their parents should therefore be given the opportunity to learn the national or regional sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. I am proud that this is guaranteed by law in Hungary, it is time for this to become an everyday practice and for all members of society to pay attention to people with disabilities. I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the Motion for a Resolution on Sign Language and Professional Sign Language Translators.I believe that all persons with disabilities have equal rights and have the right to participate fully in society.I fully support all EU institutions in the fight against discrimination on the grounds of disability and believe that deaf, blind and hard of hearing citizens of the Union must be given access to direct communication with Members of the European Parliament as well as with administrators in the EU institutions.The EU institutions must be an example of best practice when it comes to ensuring reasonable accommodation and accessibility for its employees, elected officials and trainees, and this includes sign language translation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Since 2010, when it ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the European Union has a legal obligation to implement the provisions contained in the Convention. But six years after ratification, only slight progress has been seen. In order to give citizens with disabilities full access and equality, the European Union institutions should be the best examples for the Member States and ensure equal access to information and communication for people with disabilities. That is why I co-signed the resolution of my fellow Members from the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists, which offers approaches to improving the position of people with disabilities, namely deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing citizens. First of all, within the EU institutions and the Member States, official recognition of national and regional sign language, official education and recognition of sign language as a professional and professional service requiring appropriate compensation, ie giving equal status to sign language translators as professional translators. In addition, I believe that it is necessary to ensure equal access to employment, education and training of young deaf people in order to reduce their unemployment.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters.People with hearing impairments must also have the same rights and be treated equally.They must have autonomy, the possibility of independent living and participation in society.Any discrimination must be condemned, as condemned by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.It is necessary to strive for sign language to be mastered by as many people as possible, or.so that as many people as possible have the opportunity to learn it and act as an interpreter.Any development of new language technologies would be of great help to sign language users.Deaf people would have easier access to health care, the judiciary and education through official interpreters.The European institutions have already taken a big step in this direction, but the next step could be to make sign language one of the official languages in the European Parliament.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, because I fully share the spirit of non-discrimination against social groups such as deaf people, and we defend the principle of equality in institutions.The Resolution has been firmly defended and worked on by our parliamentary group, and defends the full integration of this group by facilitating the accessibility of all information, and requesting European recognition of professional sign language interpreters.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- Despite a few flawed paragraphs, overall this is a consensus resolution in favor of accessibility for people with disabilities.I therefore voted for this report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- As full citizens, people with disabilities, and in particular women and children, including the deaf and hard of hearing, sign language users and non-sign language users, have equal rights and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment and independent living., for independence and full social participation.I voted in favor of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
