I am therefore of the opinion that the Commission's Draft Implementing Regulation exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1/2003. 1107/2009 and I consider that the assessment of representative uses of bentazone is not sufficient to conclude that the plant protection product containing the said substance will not have any harmful effects on human or animal health or groundwater, or any unacceptable effect on the environment. I call on the Commission to respect the precautionary principle set out in Article 191 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and to give priority to requesting and evaluating all relevant missing information before taking an approval decision.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - According to the term established in Reg.1141 / 2010, there was a request for renewal of the active substance already authorized bentazone, since its authorization initially expired on 6/30/2016. This resolution opposes the European Commission's draft implementing measure which approves the renewal of the substance for another fifteen years. There are well-founded concerns about the effects of this active substance on the environment, which justify deepening and improving the knowledge available, with a view to adopting the measures that prove necessary in terms of safeguarding the environment and public health. It is important to keep in mind the high dependence of this substance in certain cultures, such as rice, as well as the fact that currently there are no restrictions on the use of bentazone, whereas in the past the substance was authorized only for use as a herbicide. Immediately, and in view of the problem of the lack of alternatives invoked by several producers, it would be important to consider the mandatory reduction of the application doses and the concentration of this active substance, considering, at the same time, the role of adjuvants, the necessary inhibition of harmful side actions. and, thus, the facilitation of decomposition.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - Bentazone is a widely used herbicide and is an important part of plant protection and agricultural production. However, in line with the petitioner, I believe that human and animal health and effective environmental protection must come first, because that is what sustainability of agricultural production depends on. Criteria for endocrine disruptors have not yet been clearly established, and despite pressure from the agricultural sector, I think that this is a reason to wait for the relevant data on which to base these criteria. The objection does not seek to call into question existing scientific research, but calls for validated data to be available before a substance that is potentially toxic and toxic to reproduction is authorized for another 15 years. It is also a matter of complying with existing legislation. Members of the European Parliament have the right to object to implementing acts, and previous cases have shown that, despite the fact that there is no official influence on the European Commission's action, political pressure can play a key role in the outcome.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - The approval of the active substance bentazone expires on 30 June 2017. The Commission's draft measure approved the renewal of the authorization of the substance and, in line with Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 and current scientific and technical knowledge, certain conditions and restrictions were included . Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 provides for the exercise of implementing powers by the Commission. The recitals in the resolution regarding the data gaps in the consumer risk assessment and groundwater exposure were duplicated from the peer review of the risk assessment without adequately explaining why these gaps would constitute grounds for refusing active substance renewal. The mere existence of a data gap is not a sufficient reason to object. The only supportive data requested was related to the endocrine disrupting potential testing in a developmental toxicity study in rats. This data gap has been identified due to the application of the transitional criteria for endocrine disrupters and the Commission is currently in the process of defining new criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors. It is therefore expected that in any case new data will be required when these criteria become applicable. I hereby voted against the resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I spoke against the objection to the renewal of the authorization of the active substance bentazon.I understand the concerns about the possible harmful effects that this herbicidal substance could have on humans or the environment.However, I rely on the opinions of European agencies which have concluded that the active substance bentazon is safe when used appropriately.I do not want farmers who already bear the brunt of many restrictive standards to find themselves in additional difficulties in growing their vegetables.It is therefore our duty to ensure that this substance is used correctly without harming farmers.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the non-legislative resolution on renewing the approval of the active substance bentazone. We believe it is important to assess missing safety information on the use of this substance. However, we would like this issue to be decided by national Parliaments.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - The European authorization of bentazon should not be renewed until its safety has been demonstrated. In short, that is the message sent by the plenary of the European Parliament on Wednesday in a non-binding resolution targeting this herbicide which acts against broadleaf weeds and is widely used in the agricultural sector. The objectors, first and foremost MP Pavel Poc, in this resolution focused exclusively on the procedural aspects of this authorization. Not easy, but necessary work! On the one hand, certain data were still recently requested from the applicant company as part of the “data confirmation procedure”, a practice which had been strongly criticized by the European Ombudsman in a decision of February 2016. In addition, the The Commission granted a maximum authorization of 15 years, i.e. until 31 January 2032, despite the absence of data on human and animal toxicity as well as on ecotoxicity, as indicated in the EFSA study. So it is all this complementary work that MEPs want to see done by the European Food Safety Authority before the Commission and national experts decide whether or not to authorize bentazon.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No. 2016/549 of April 8, 2016, which modifies Implementing Regulation (EU) No. 540/201, extended the approval period for the active substance bentazone until June 30, 2017. In turn, the European Commission has proposed the extension of the bentazone until January 31, 2032, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009 on the marketing of phytosanitary products. For my part, I voted in favor of a 7.5-year extension and against the abolition of the use of the active substance. I understand that bentazone acts as a selective post-emergent herbicide against broadleaf weeds in a wide range of crops, which allows weed control and is a fundamental tool for the management of various crops in Spain, such as rice. . The abolition of the use of bentazone reduces the phytosanitary tools of farmers, worsening their competitive capacity.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation aiming to extend the approval for the active substance bentazon until January 31, 2032. The reason for meurged to make this choice is simple: today, there is not sufficient evidence to confirm that this substance may not have a harmful effect on human or animal health or on groundwater or have aunacceptable impact on the environment.Therefore, for obvious public health reasons, it seemed important to me to oppose any extension of bentazon.I am also pleased that this resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to fund research and innovation in viable and cost-effective solutions to replace these pesticides for health reasons.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing.- I voted against this motion for a resolution that aims to renew the approval of the active substance bentazone, which in Portugal is registered in maize, rice and peas, being the first two basic crops of national agriculture.This type of herbicide has proved to be an important tool for farmers, as it contributes to the maintenance of a sustainable control of weeds in the crops for which it is authorized.For that reason and the fact that both the report and EFSA emphasize that this substance does not represent an increased risk to human health or the environment, I considered that there would be insufficient reasons to object to its renewal, taking into account, above all, theimpact that such a measure would have on European farmers, in general, and Portuguese, in particular.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I vote in favor of the objection in line with the precautionary principle to avoid the renewal of the bentazone.In the absence of data demonstrating the safety of a chemical substance, I understand that its use should not be authorized.The European Commission exceeds its enforcement powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009.The planned reauthorization of bentazone for 15 years is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009, which is to ensure a high level of protection for both human and animal health and the environment.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution because of doubts about the process for approving active substances and the possible implications for health and the environment. There is great concern that the Commission is using the confirmatory data procedure too readily, which can mean the approval of substances which have not been fully analysed. The European Ombudsman has raised concerns about the fact that substances can be approved without understanding the extent of their potentially harmful effects. In this case, the risks relate to mammalian toxicology, ecotoxicology, and the environment. These are important data gaps which should be addressed before authorisation, not years afterwards.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this objection, because I am against the renewal of the active substance bentazone, one of the pesticides most frequently found in underground and deep waters, as there is no scientific data to show that it is aSafe substance, neither for human and animal health nor for the environment.Therefore, the Commission proposal violates the precautionary principle and ignores the Ombudsman's proposals to improve the Commission's pesticide approval system (restricting the practice of approving a substance while simultaneously requesting data that is expected toconfirm your security), so I voted in favor of the objection.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not wish to see the EU involved in the regulation of chemicals.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of this objection. The Commission should take into account all necessary data confirming safety of a given substance before issuing the authorisations. The approval period should be proportionate to the possible risks inherent in the use of such substances. The precautionary principle should be the guiding principle in the authorisation process of plant protection products.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported the objection to the re-introduction of bentazone. I do not agree with the procedure chosen by the Commission in the authorization process. The authorization of the active substance bentazone will expire on 30 June 2017. However, in its proposal, the Commission plans to extend the authorization for another 15 years, taking into account current scientific and technical knowledge. The active substance bentazone is known as a selective herbicide against broadleaf weeds and is commonly used in agriculture. One of the characteristics of this substance is also a very high potential to penetrate into groundwater. Bentazone has been discovered in the groundwater of several countries, although more detailed information of this nature is missing in the Commission's proposal. In addition, the consumer risk assessment has not yet been completed. This is because the residue definition for plant risk assessment and enforcement in livestock was considered preliminary due to lack of data. The Commission is thus seeking to approve the placing on the market of bentazone before it has a decision confirming its safety. Although such a procedure may be used in certain cases, the European Ombudsman has already called on the Commission to stop applying it to active substances. I therefore trust that the Commission will accept this objection and withdraw its proposal.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The active substance bentazone acts as a selective herbicide for the control of leaf weeds in a wide range of post-emergence crops and is widely used in agriculture. Due to its properties, it easily seeps into groundwater. Therefore, bentazone is present in both groundwater and surface water in most Member States. The use of this substance in the EU is allowed until the end of June 2017. However, the European Commission now proposes, based on an assessment by the European Food Safety Authority, to extend the use of bentazone until 31 January 2032, the longest possible period. I believe that the European Food Safety Authority should consult experts on the toxicological effects of bentazone on mammals and its impact on the environment. In addition, it is essential to provide data confirming that the substance is not an endocrine disruptor, as various studies have found toxicity for prenatal development in rats, which is a matter of concern. I believe that the Commission decision approving bentazone would allow this active substance to be placed on the market before the Commission has obtained all the necessary information to support this decision. As bentazone is missing data on its actual negative impact on the environment and human health, I voted in favor of accepting the objection to the renewal of the approval of this substance.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In writing - The initial risk assessment carried out by the competent authority of the rapporteur Member State - the Netherlands - and the EFSA concluded that the active substance bentazone is safe if used appropriately.Herbicides are important for EU agriculture, food safety in the EU and a set of tools for European farmers and gardeners.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. – I abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution. Although there are concerns regarding its effect on the environment as well as human and animal health this should be subject to regulation by the Member States. Therefore, I could neither bring myself to vote for or against this measure.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The widespread use of bentazone in agriculture must be conditioned by the positive results of relevant tests which must determine all the side effects of the use of this substance in the production of agricultural products.Health and cleanliness of the environment, especially that in which food is produced, must be the absolute priorities of the European Union.Setting stricter criteria and procedures for approving the use of pesticides in agriculture is a prerequisite for safe and healthy production of agricultural products and protection of groundwater.I do not support the resolution because both key amendments were rejected.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing regulation renewing the authorization of the active substance bentazone in accordance with the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market and amending the Annex to the Commission Implementing Regulation.I believe that the draft Commission implementing regulation does not go beyond the implementing powers set out in the regulation.I also consider that the evaluation regarding the use of the active substance bentazone is sufficient and that no further evaluation is needed in this regard.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- WHO has classified bentazone as slightly dangerous.There are also studies that show that it is toxic to living organisms and that, if found in a high content of drinking water, it is also very toxic.That is why we voted against the motion for a resolution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The information submitted to this committee must be confirmatory in terms of its effects on human, animal, groundwater or any other unacceptable effects on the environment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for an objection to the renewal of the authorization of bentazone as a plant protection product. The current permit expires on 30 June 2017 and the European Commission has proposed an extension (until 2032). However, it has been suspected that, as a result of intensive use, it is detectable in groundwater and is likely to have a detrimental effect on human reproduction. I agree with the motion that these agents should only be used responsibly and in moderation, and I think it is important that, with proper scientific evidence, it is only possible to decide on the extension of such agents, with food safety in mind. If these agents are suspected, we should not use them. The motion will not immediately terminate the authorization of bentazone, but bearing in mind the precautionary principle, I am convinced that it should not be extended immediately. This needs to be preceded by a very rapid, serious and comprehensive research. I do not consider the available evaluations to be satisfactory. There are alternative ways, their efficient use and the replacement or reduction of the use of classic forms of farming can be developed. Last but not least, I consider it important to strengthen the role of phytosanitary doctors and to tighten up the authorization procedure and use in the event of suspicion.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: written.- I voted against the objection as there is not enough scientific evidence on this matter to oppose the renewal of the authorization.Unreasonable and non-scientific decision-making is unreasonable from an industry perspective.Politicians do not have a sufficient knowledge base to address such an issue without scientific evidence.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The health of European citizens is one of the priorities of the Union and its institutions. The presence of harmful chemicals in agricultural products used in consumer food as a result of the use of herbicides against weeds is unacceptable. One of these compounds is the active substance bentazone and is commonly used in Member States' agriculture against broadleaf weeds in a wide range of crops. At European level, it is the Commission that authorizes the use of these products, usually for a period of 15 years. In this case, however, the Commission extended the approval period to 30 June 2017, as tests on guinea pigs revealed a number of adverse effects on pregnancy and fetal development and on the completion of surface water tests. . If these indications are confirmed, the compound should be included among endocrine disruptors and banned. In these circumstances, the draft implementing regulation drawn up by the Commission cannot be approved, as it poses a risk to the health of European citizens. I support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution.The assessment of the representative uses of the active substance bentazone is not sufficient to conclude that, for at least one of the representative uses, a plant protection product containing the active substance bentazon may not have a harmful effect on human healthanimal or groundwater or have an unacceptable impact on the environment.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ While I consider it important to apply the precautionary principle when there is a potential danger for human or environmental health, in this case, several circumstances justify a more cautious approach, in particular against the background of the still unresolved questions over a proper definition for criteria for endocrine disruptors. For this reason but also because of the potential interest-related matter of the ANO leader I decided to abstain.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I do not support the European Parliament resolution on the draft Commission implementing regulation extending the authorization of the active substance bentazone in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006.Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the placing of plant protection products on the market and amending the Annex to Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) no.540/2011.The active substance bentazone acts as a selective herbicide used against weeds in various crops, and from it there is a possibility of groundwater pollution.I consider that the European Commission erred in allowing this substance to be placed on the market before complete information on its safety was obtained.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The approval of the active substance bentazone, which is often used in agriculture, expires on 30 June 2017.Although the Commission has proposed to extend the authorization of this active substance, I believe that the protection of human health, as well as the environment, should be a priority for the European Union institutions.Before deciding to grant an extension, the Commission should obtain all necessary information on the effects of that substance on humans, animals, plants and the environment.Namely, the consumer risk assessment has not been completed, nor has the assessment of groundwater exposure.I consider that the information received by the Commission on bentazone does not contain sufficient corroborating information that this substance will not have any adverse effects on human, animal or groundwater health, so I supported the report objecting to its prolongation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- Objections to the draft Commission Implementing Regulation renewing the approval of the active substance bentazone in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market and amending the Annex to Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) no.I did not support 540/2011.Bentazone is an active substance that acts as a selective herbicide to control leaf weeds in a wide range of post-emergence crops and is widely used in agriculture.The substance penetrates groundwater extremely easily.Also, the risk assessment for consumers is not yet known.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I vote in favor of the objection in line with the precautionary principle to avoid the renewal of the bentazone.In the absence of data demonstrating the safety of a chemical substance, I understand that its use should not be authorized.The European Commission exceeds its enforcement powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009.The planned reauthorization of bentazone for 15 years is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009, which is to ensure a high level of protection for both human and animal health and the environment.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - Bentazon is a commonly used pesticide, especially for peas, beans and potatoes. Doubts remain as to its harmfulness to humans and the environment: - Bentazon can infiltrate surface and groundwater. This contamination depends, in part, on the type of soil and its porosity and is hampered by the rapid photodegradation of this substance. - Doubts also remain as to the dangerousness of bentazon for human health, although, according to the conclusions of several scientific studies, notably from the WHO, this would be conditional on the absorption of very high doses of bentazon. The objection rightly points out that many assessments are still necessary for the granting of the authorization: these include, in particular, assessments on the risk to the consumer and the possibility of infiltration of ground and surface water. In view of the importance of this information, the so-called “confirmation data” procedure goes against the precautionary principle, and cannot be the basis for granting an authorization for a period of fifteen years (the maximum period ). I therefore voted for this objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- I have decided to reject this objection, which has no factual basis.Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 provides for the exercise of implementing powers by the Commission, so from a procedural point of view this objection does not make much sense.I voted against the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The active substance bentazone is a selective post-emergence pesticide used in a wide range of crops against broadleaf weeds, the use of which is widespread in agriculture.I voted in favor of the relevant document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I vote in favor of the objection in line with the precautionary principle to avoid the renewal of the bentazone.In the absence of data demonstrating the safety of a chemical substance, I understand that its use should not be authorized.The European Commission exceeds its enforcement powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009.The planned reauthorization of bentazone for 15 years is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No. 1107/2009, which is to ensure a high level of protection for both human and animal health and the environment.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I call on the Commission to request and assess the missing information before taking a decision.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106 : Renewing the approval of the active substance bentazone. The active substance bentazone acts as a selective post-emergent herbicide against broadleaved weeds in a broad range of crops and is commonly used in agriculture. However, the active substance bentazone has a high potential for direct leaching to groundwater due to its inherent properties. The objection considers that the draft Commission implementing regulation exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009. It underlines that the assessment on the representative uses of the active substance bentazone to be insufficient to conclude that, for at least one of the representative uses, a plant protection product containing the active substance bentazone may be expected not to have any harmful effect on human or animal health or on groundwater or any unacceptable influence on the environment. I voted in favour because I believe that, by applying the confirmatory data procedure for the approval of the active substance bentazone, the Commission breached the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 and infringed the precautionary principle.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this objection, because I am against the renewal of the active substance bentazone, one of the pesticides most frequently found in underground and deep waters, since there is no scientific data to show that it is aSafe substance, neither for human and animal health nor for the environment.Therefore, the Commission proposal goes against the precautionary principle and ignores the Ombudsman's proposals to improve the Commission's pesticide approval system (restricting the practice of approving a substance while simultaneously requesting data that is expected toconfirm your security), so I voted in favor of the objection.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because, due to the inherent properties of bentazone, there is a high chance that the active substance bentazone will end up in the groundwater.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This resolution supports the precautionary principle, denouncing EU procedures through delegated acts for the authorization of these substances.Our solution would be to allow more time for more studies to clarify this issue, preserving an intermediate transition period capable of answering production questions.In this sense, we abstain.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- I supported the motion for a resolution with which the Commission's plan to approve bentazone for the maximum period of time despite the lack of a safety test.In line with the precautionary principle, the Commission must be urged to test this herbicide comprehensively, especially for possible groundwater hazards.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I do not support this objection seeking to revise the extension of the authorization for the use of the active substance bentazone.Bentazone is a selective contact herbicide that acts on weeds by inhibiting electron transport in the process of photosynthesis.After the initial application, this herbicide successfully dries the weeds in just a few days.Because there is still no defined view on the harmful effects of the use of this substance in agricultural production (due to the impact on groundwater, soil quality and final food products).As there is no opinion on all the harmful effects and duration of the negative effects of the substance itself, it is necessary to conduct relevant research to determine the extent and impact of side effects.The European Union must insist on the consistent implementation of existing regulations in consumer protection and product quality standards and safety of the entire production process.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The first item is an oral question to the Council and Commission: EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Elimination of Violence against Women and Domestic Violence - (2016/2966 (RSP)).

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: author. – Madam President, violence against women is not a private issue. It is a serious crime and it is widespread. Behind every victim, there is a heart-breaking story of a broken life. Too many women and girls today live in fear and despair, bleeding in their minds and bodies, hurt and crushed by guilt and shame. I have visited shelters from Sweden to Greece, witnessing amazing examples of civil society taking women and girls by the hand to help them recover their dignity and rebuild their life. However, women at home continue to be beaten, and often children witness terrible scenes. In public there are cases where even going to a swimming pool or to a music festival poses a danger of harassment or rape, and persecution in the social media has become a global phenomenon affecting an entire generation. Let us be clear: this is often about men attacking women out of jealousy or frustration, under the influence of alcohol or for revenge. Often they just cannot accept a woman being strong, independent and modern, making her own choices and then daring to live them. Let us talk about Lucia, an Italian woman disfigured by acid. She had the courage to denounce her former partner. She said: ‘It is not your fault to have chosen the wrong man. It is his fault to have hit you.’ The time has come to say no to sexism and to build a culture of respect for women and girls – and religion and culture can never be excuses for the abuse of women. On the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, with our joint resolution, let us give a voice to women who are victims of violence. Let us help them to break the vicious circle of silence and loneliness. Together we call on the Member States to implement the Anti-Trafficking Directive, the European Protection Order and the Directive on Protection of Victims, and to ratify the Istanbul Convention. We also ask them to speed up the accession of the EU to the Convention, to strengthen our tools, to combat and prevent violence against women and to protect victims. Madam President, the EPP Group will continue to be committed to a policy of zero tolerance on violence against women.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: author. - Madam President, violence against women and girls is a scourge of terrible topicality which strikes everywhere in Europe and in the world. This violence is indicative of the inequalities and discrimination suffered by women compared to men. Moreover, women in Europe are not protected in the same way from violence depending on the country in which they live. The fight against violence against women is a daily struggle, which calls for a profound change in mentalities, nourished by prejudices and sexist stereotypes. This is not a problem that only affects women. It involves all of our societies and requires a strong political response. The accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention will bring a first stone to the building to better fight against violence against women in Europe and provide legal tools to protect them. Through our oral questions, we ask the Commission and the Council for precise answers on the state of play of the negotiations. We therefore urge the 14 States of the Union which have not yet done so to ratify the Istanbul Convention. Beyond that, the Socialists and Democrats group defends the adoption of a directive on the fight against violence against women. I am also convinced that the rule of law mechanism will help to strengthen the implementation of the Istanbul Convention in member states. I am delighted that tomorrow we are proposing a joint resolution to make our voice heard in this fight and say no to violence against all women and girls. My great regret is that this text ignores the denial of access to safe and legal abortion and the resulting forced pregnancies. However, we are talking here about a form of characterized violence against women. While the Istanbul Convention ignores the right to abortion, United Nations recognize it as a human right.I will not stop working so that abortion can be recognized and protected as a fundamental right within the European Union.Inaction and indifference are not options when it comes to defending women's rights.As Martin Luther King once said, our lives begin to end the day we become silent about the things that matter.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: author. – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my appreciation for the great support among almost all the political forces in this House to promote the Istanbul Convention. We are almost unanimously asking the European Union and individual Member States to ratify it, and for the first time we are sending a clear and strong political message. We are – and we will always be – on the side of victims of gender—based violence and violence against women. I will never get tired of repeating that violence against women is a violation of women’s human rights and an extreme form of discrimination embedded in gender inequalities and contributing to reinforcing them. For those who still wonder why we are once again debating this, my answer is very simple. We are not gender ideologists, we are human rights defenders. It is true that the accession process was initiated by the Commission, all EU Member States have already signed it and 14 Member States have ratified it. But my experience has never proved me wrong: never take rights for granted. We should be vocal until we have a generation of Europeans completely aware that gender—based violence is not tolerable and there is never a justification for it. On behalf of my Group, I would like to express our full support for the Commission and for making sure that the Council reacts. Until the Istanbul Convention is ratified by the European Union, we will not have an instrument in Europe to set legally binding standards to specifically prevent violence against women and girls, protect victims and punish perpetrators. I look forward to cooperating with the Commission and the coming Council Presidencies to make the Istanbul Convention an EU instrument against violence against women.  My last words go to the Orange Campaign on Friday. We should orange the world and join the UN women’s initiative, keeping in mind that we have to fight inequalities and violence every single day.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: author. – Madam President, let me start with some good news from the last days. The horrible law proposed by the Turkish Government to clear a rapist of all his charges if he marries the victim has been withdrawn by the AKP. The Turkish Government has not withdrawn this proposal because they think it is wrong, but because of thousands of women fighting against this proposal in the streets of Istanbul. It is so sad, but also so obvious, that we will have to fight for our freedom over and over again.  Now one could argue, well, this is far away, and this is not happening in the European Union. But it is. It is happening in the European Union as well. Every third woman in the European Union experiences violence in her life. This might seem like an abstract number, but out of 280 women in this Chamber, approximately 90 would have been those who experienced violence in their lives. This is not ‘the others’. This is us. It is women who are sitting with us in this Chamber, voting, representing their constituents – maybe women that you have a coffee with from time to time. They have the same fate as millions of women in the European Union, and it is not enough to talk about it once a year.  We need to do something, especially in times when the other side is gearing up, where there are more and more people who are trying to go back to the good old times, to the 1950s, when a husband beating up his wife was actually not really a reason to bother about and, yes, we will have to fight for our freedom over and over again: against a Polish Government that wants to restrict women’s rights, against the Turkish government that wants to do that, and against a backlash that we are facing in the European Union. We will have to fight against this, but this fight will be a thousand times stronger if we have a good legal foundation, and the Istanbul Convention is one of the tools to do that. So please, Madam Commissioner, and all Member States, ratify this Convention.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Author. - Madam President! In no country has enough been done to combat violence against women and girls. The threat of violence reduces our living spaces - it is not about anything less important than that. The Istanbul Convention, or the Council of Europe Convention on Violence against Women, is an important tool for all of us who fight violence against women, not least because it places violence against women in a context of power and structures. The Convention also requires all countries to take a holistic approach to stopping gender-based violence through public funding of women's shelters, through preventive measures, through requirements for consent legislation. However, we can also state that we live in a culture that accepts men's violence against women. Otherwise it would have been stopped. Public figures who have abused the bodies of women and girls continue to be held on their backs. Just look at the newly elected president Donald Trump, the former head of the IMF and the French presidential candidate Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the film director Roman Polanski. In addition, several countries still allow a prostitution industry where women and girls can be bought by men. In such a culture, it becomes difficult to create justice and deliver convictions for rape cases, for example. It is not only in Sweden that convictions in rape cases shine with their absence. That is the truth throughout Europe. Here in Europe, there is a lack of political will. Earlier today, we voted on a report calling for refurbishment. Is it more important to rattle with weapons than to defend women's bodies and rights? It does not hold! The struggle for equality, for women's bodies, against macho culture, must be allowed to take the central place it should have in this House. We demand that the Istanbul Convention be ratified by the EU, by the Member States. At the same time, we also want an EU strategy and funding to combat violence against women. We have a lot of work ahead of us. We hope that the Commission and the Council will stand with us in that work.The European Parliament will demand action.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Author. - On the eve of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, it is absolutely unacceptable that there is limited progress in the fight against violence against women and gender-based violence. According to a recent FRA study, one in five women in the EU has experienced physical violence by someone other than their partner since the age of 15. Women with disabilities in particular are estimated to be one and a half to 10 times more likely to be abused than women without disabilities. Violence against women, but certainly also against men and children, is a violation of fundamental rights and an extreme form of discrimination that is both a cause and a consequence of gender inequality. On 4 March 2016, the Commission proposed that the EU accede to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding instrument at international level to prevent and combat violence against women. Only 14 EU countries, including Belgium, have ratified the convention. I naturally support the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention. Of course, it is in principle up to the Member States to do their job and protect women from violence, but the EU can take additional action, for example in relation to victims' rights and protection orders and in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for having this debate today, just two days before International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. There is no doubt that combating all forms of violence against women and girls is a core element of the observance of fundamental rights. It is therefore of the utmost importance to send out a strong message on our commitment to uphold equality and respect for human rights. We believe that our joint effort and a strong message of unity are needed to ensure the protection of all women and girls in Europe. I know this House shares the Council’s long-standing commitment to see an end to the suffering of victims through a binding and effective instrument such as the Istanbul Convention. I would like to recall that the Council has repeatedly expressed its commitment to the prevention and elimination of all forms of violence against women. These are crimes that have no place in the EU Member States, and the Council has encouraged them to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention. As you know, all the Member States have already signed and, so far, 14 of them have ratified the convention. We are aware of Parliament’s efforts, such as last year’s initiative by the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality in launching a working group on violence against women, and all the many hearings and inter-parliamentary committee meetings you have organised to raise awareness. We very much welcome these initiatives and I would like to inform you that the Presidency – specifically the working party Chair – will be addressing the hearing on the EU accession to the Istanbul Convention co-organised next week – 29 November 2016 – by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Women’s Rights Committee. This will be an excellent opportunity for exchanges with the co-rapporteurs and representatives of the Council of Europe, the United Nations and the Commission. Allow me to turn now to the state of play as regards our work in the Council, and on the EU’s proposed accession to the Istanbul Convention. This matter has been one of our priorities since the very start of our Presidency last July. It has been dealt with by the Council’s working party responsible for fundamental rights, which last convened on 10 November 2016. In a first phase, Member States have agreed to concentrate on the Council decision authorising the signature, on behalf of the EU, of the Istanbul Convention. There is very broad support among Member States for this accession. However, there are still diverging views regarding the scope of the EU’s accession. These involve complex legal matters on which Member States are seeking more clarity. Nevertheless, we are confident that we will be able to make substantial progress with the proposal for a Council decision on the signing of the Convention. Another meeting is scheduled next week to continue the negotiations. As regards the external dimension of the Istanbul Convention, the Presidency is organising a meeting in December with the Council’s working party responsible for human rights. Throughout these last months of our Presidency, we have been in regular contact with the co-rapporteurs on this subject, Ms Bildt and Ms Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy, and this close collaboration with Parliament will be encouraged in the future. For our part, and I think this is most important, we still aim to submit the proposal for the Council decision on the signing of the Convention to the Council in December. Lastly Madam President, I need to apologise for not being able to be here with you until the end of your debate. I will have to leave after the presentation by Commissioner Jourová but, be sure, our colleagues here, and we as a Presidency, will pay attention to it during our last days and weeks in office, and we are still working towards getting an agreement in December.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me thank you all, first and foremost, for keeping violence against women high on the European Parliament’s agenda. It is a privilege to be here just a few days before – this has already been mentioned several times – the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women on 25 November, and to give you an overview from the perspective of the Commission, together with the Council Presidency, on how we see the progress towards an EU accession to the Istanbul Convention.  Together with you and Member States’ Ministers at this year’s United Nations Conference on the Status of Women, where we as ‘Team Europe’ successfully represented the EU in delivering on our messages, we agree that the importance of the Istanbul Convention and the need to address the difficult issue of gender—based violence in a coordinated and focused way is desirable. This Conference took place in March shortly after the Commission adopted proposals for the signing and conclusion of the accession to the Convention. Since then, we have put all our efforts behind constructive discussions with the Council to reach political agreement. The Council Presidencies involved have been very successful and useful in facilitating this. We have held in-depth discussions on all legal aspects of the accession, in particular the extent of accession. We discussed the division of roles between the Member States and the Union in the implementation of the Convention. As you know, the Commission is of the view that EU accession should generate the added value we are seeking to make a difference on the ground. We want to strengthen and complement the existing framework in a wide range of policy areas. The competences and roles of the EU and Member States are closely intertwined. That is why the EU aims to accede to this Convention in parallel to national ratifications. I seriously hope that we can reach an agreement on the terms of the signing decision within the coming month. We heard from the Presidency that it should be in December. This would be the best news. Signing this decision would demonstrate the common political will of the Union to be bound by the Convention. We have emphasised since the beginning that only the joint participation of both the EU and the Member States makes sense, legally and politically. I am constantly encouraging the Member States to ratify alongside the EU, and the Member States can rely on available European Programmes and funds to help in this process. I would like to thank the Parliament again for its support and I look forward to its interim report, which will be adopted next year. We will continue to monitor and support the implementation of the existing legal instruments to combat violence against women. That includes the Victims’ Rights Directive and EU legislation on cross-border recognition of protection orders.  I have promised to you several times that we want to devote the year 2017 to strengthening combating violence against women, so I am particularly glad to announce to you that, on 25 November, as part of our year of focused actions to combat violence against women, I will launch the promised EU—wide campaign. My objective is to provide a framework for a coordinated approach and join forces together with you, Member States, the European Institute for Gender Equality, UN Women and other International Organisations, civil society organisations, academia, businesses, trade unions, media and, within the Member States, also with law enforcement authorities, because I said we want to make a change on the ground. This means that the women will be protected not only by preventive measures, but also – let us face it – by a necessary reaction from the side of criminal justice.  During the year of focused actions to combat violence against women, many activities are planned. It is a cross-cutting effort and work within the Commission, involving many of my colleague Commissioners and their services. Apart from communication, best practices and experience sharing, it also includes funding. As for the Commission’s work on this campaign, you very often call for more efforts in mainstreaming gender topics and gender policy, so I can confirm today that several of my colleague Commissioners will take very concrete actions next year from their perspective, be it eliminating violence in transport, the campaign against alcoholism – which is very often one of the enabling situations in domestic violence – or the effort to get this topic more to documentary film creation. This is a very wide range of different plans and actions and I can only say that I have received a very good reaction from my colleague Commissioners. With regard to the funding I indicated, the Commission dedicated EUR 4 million from the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme in 2016 to support Member States in developing and implementing national practical and targeted information, awareness-raising and educational activities aimed at preventing and combating violence against women. Why do we rely on Member States for this? Simply because violence against women has many different forms in Member States. That is why we speak about targeting actions and the Commission provides the funding for this, as well as the unifying logo, slogans, design and many other things. That is just for you to understand how the campaign will work. Activities will cover all forms of violence against women or focus on specific forms or issues, as relevant. In addition to the EUR 4 million, EUR 6 million will be provided in 2017 for transnational grassroots projects to prevent the problem and protect and support victims, under the Daphne strand of the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. This money will go to the organisations – the NGOs – which work on the ground and which can also contribute in a very significant way to the success of this campaign. Just to add regarding the money, in 2016 alone the EU spent EUR 24.5 million to support 62 gender-based violence combating humanitarian projects. I would like to thank the Parliament once again for its support of our endeavours in fighting violence against women. I remain committed to continue informing you in a timely manner on all developments in this area, and of course to invite you to join and participate in our coming campaign.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner, for your thought.It is all the more important for us not only to have a definite vision, but also to have resources behind it.The political group speakers now follow.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, violence against women is, unfortunately, (The President interrupted the speaker for a problem of interpretation) a scourge which spares none of our European countries - I mean none - and it is a shame. It is an absolute shame. We are two days away from November 25 and the international day dedicated to the fight against violence against women and we meet again here, in this hemicycle in Strasbourg, as every year, around the same time and almost in the same type of configuration, all of them, to deplore this state of affairs and call for mobilization. It's enough. How many more years will we meet to deplore the worsening situation for women? Of course, this year, we have a new perspective which is the accession of the European Union to the so-called Istanbul Convention aimed at preventing and combating all forms of violence against women. It is a major act, a significant and extremely important step forward that would thus be taken for a mobilization, a reinforced concrete commitment of the European Union and its institutions in favor of the elimination of violence against women. It would also put additional pressure on the Member States which, although having signed this famous convention, have not yet ratified it or have not yet concretely implemented it in their country. I therefore strongly urge the European Commission to do everything to continue to put pressure - if I may say so - on the Member States, so that they face up to their responsibilities and that they mobilize so that, together, we we really managed to implement real concrete plans to fight and eliminate all forms of violence against women.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, every hour forty-eight women and girls are victims of sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In the Mexican city of Puebla, fifty femicides have been registered in the last fifteen months. On December 31, a sixteen-year-old girl died in Calcutta, raped by seven men. She could go on telling these stories and our souls would shrink. And, unfortunately, this reality has nothing to do with geographical issues. In Europe you also suffer in the same way. Figures in Spain reveal that there is an annual average of 113,000 complaints from victims of gender violence. This year, so far this year, thirty-nine women have been murdered at the hands of their abusers. Unfortunately, in Europe there are no homogeneous data, but we know, according to studies, that 33% of European women have been victims of some type of violence. This forces us to act forcefully. It is urgent to ratify the Istanbul Convention, but the need for a European directive against gender violence is no less urgent. I know that legislating is not the only solution, but it is the way to commit and oblige public institutions in the fight against violence against women. We speak of truncated lives, of broken families, of future condemned to pain. What else has to happen for us to decide to act? This is not the time for complacency or excuses. Let's break the complicit silences, because we too are them.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, violence against women is a very real and all too frequent reality for many women worldwide. In the EU alone, research has shown that one third of women have experienced physical and/or sexual violence since the age of 15. This equates to 62 million women. That is my Member State, the population of my country, represented in that number. While cases are reported and action is taken, there are still far too many instances where women are trapped, suffering in silence and with no conceivable way out. Violence against women does not just apply to physical abuse. It also covers the emotional manipulation and psychological trauma thousands of women are subjected to just because they are women. Violence against women is a form of gender-based violence. It is gross, inexcusable and a violation of human rights.  Given the varying forms violence against women can take, as well as the numerous avenues through which such violence can be executed, no single intervention will result in its elimination. A combination of infrastructural, legal, cultural, educational and social actions, in addition to the sharing of best practices between Member States, is essential to raise awareness and stimulate the action needed, so I welcome the Commissioner’s reassurances on all of those areas. The Istanbul Convention opens the path to make change possible. I therefore urge Member States, including my own, the UK, to ratify and implement the Convention if they have not already done so.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, thank you, Commissioner Jourová, because we are sure that she will finally get the European Union to ratify the Istanbul Convention. And it will be great news, because it is an extraordinary instrument, finally legally binding and comprehensive, to end gender violence and intra-family violence. But the women who every day, by our side, in all the countries of the Union, are mistreated, raped, attacked, murdered, do not want any more words from us, they want us to eradicate violence against women once and for all. And we can do it. The Slovak Presidency speaks highly of the Istanbul Convention, but Slovakia has not ratified the Convention. Theresa May and Angela Merkel are two of the most powerful women in the world, but neither the UK nor Germany have ratified the Istanbul Convention. Ladies and gentlemen, you are done with wet papers. There is no single reason not to ratify and implement the Istanbul Convention in every state in the Union, and those that do not deserve to be singled out. Enough of the hypocrisy, gentlemen. Enough of excuses.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, what is the most widespread crime in the world? Violence against women. One in three women is a victim of violence. I am one of them because I revealed the unpaid work, because I was a woman, an immigrant, a trade unionist. Can incidents of violence like this against me be prevented? Of course. That is why we support the Istanbul Convention, because it is the first binding international legal instrument against violence. But there are those Member States that claim high costs and either do not ratify it or do not implement it. Is the ratification of the contract enough, as we rightly ask? Of course not. It is necessary to change the culture and it is necessary to educate from an early age on mutual respect between the sexes, so that men learn that the above power given to them by nature is not to use violence against women.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, we are tired of seeing every day, the figures, the deaths, the statistics ... This statistic that haunts the European Union: that a third of women in Europe have been victims of any physical or sexual violence. time. And I believe that, for that, we need to strengthen our legal instruments and apply them better. Both are important: more legal instruments and better enforcement. Today we are at the gates - and it is very important - to ratify the Istanbul Convention by the European Union, an instrument that will mean having the first binding mechanism at the level of Europe to create a common legal framework, and it is very important . Ratifying this Convention will guarantee to translate the commitments acquired into real and concrete actions and will mean that in Europe sexist violence will no longer be seen as a particular isolated case, but as an endemic, systemic problem that we must face. So, go ahead with ratification, Commissioner, let's go as quickly as we can. And I believe that this Parliament must also urgently call on all Member States to complete the ratification process individually.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to try to make a slightly different reflection with you. It has now been more than five years since the approval of the Istanbul Convention and I think we have to ask ourselves a question: why not all EU states have ratified it yet and others have not even signed? The states that have not ratified it certainly have not, because they are not against violence against women. So, let us pause to understand the real reasons for these non-ratifications. The reason why some States oppose ratification is to be found in some contents of the convention itself, which go beyond the subject of the fight against gender-based violence, such as the introduction, for the first time in an international treaty, of the social definition of "gender", which becomes binding for the States that ratified the convention. And it is therefore understandable that states in which the gender debate is more complicated are reluctant to such ratification. If at the time this forcing had not been made, which has nothing to do with the urgency of the issue of violence against women, today, probably, we would not find ourselves facing such a paradoxical situation. Let us ask ourselves, rather, if in the States where it has been ratified and for which it has been legislated on the matter, there have been clear positive statistical results in terms of decreasing gender violence. Shouldn't we focus attention on the fact that Member States actually legislate and take measures to prevent and combat the phenomenon of violence against women? In fact, many states have focused on repression measures and still too little on prevention ones. From the experience we have experienced with our hands around Europe, unfortunately, the concept of prevention is still focused on locking up the potential victim in a protected structure, thus limiting their freedom and movements, and leaving the dangerous subject free of movement.Well, it seems absurd to me that an instrument like the convention, which should unite us in this battle, ends up dividing us and, five years later, we have not yet reached a result, a solution.In short, let's overcome these formalistic issues and focus more on monitoring what is really happening in individual states.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, you are not addressing the silent agenda, and I do not call on anyone in here to do anything, because you cover up the fact that young migrants, often of Muslim backgrounds, are over-represented in the violence against women statistics – which, by the way, is not the same as claiming that all Muslim migrants are prone to this type of behaviour.  Their crimes against women, each year, in my country: female genital mutilation, 5 700 reported cases; honour killings, around a dozen; polygamy, around 20 000 illegal marriages; false marriage, 1 200 reported each year; child marriages, 5 000 to 8 000; and all this is done in the shadow of Sharia law.  It took years before the Rotherham child abuse case was brought to light in the UK, out of fear of being labelled racist. In the UK we still have a parallel society of Sharia courts operating right under our noses. In fact all over Europe we see the same pattern. Those claiming to champion women’s rights are in denial and attempt to sweep this problem under the carpet. No amount of EU law or funds will make a difference until this is addressed. The truth is that by letting millions of young migrant men with Muslim backgrounds into our countries, we have submitted our women to these attacks. It is a form of terrorism. No more cover-ups, no more mitigating circumstances, no more political correctness. Like President-elect Trump, I would like more scrutiny of those you are letting in, but in the EU that won’t happen, so in order to protect our women, we need to drain the EU swamp and then make Europe great again. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Fellow Members!What is this blowing?Anyone who wants to express an opinion should do so in a manner and refrain from doing so.By the way, there was a blue card for Mrs Atkinson.Do you accept this blue card?Mrs Görling would like to ask you a question.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: blue-card question. – Reluctant as I am to offer Ms Atkinson the opportunity to spout more of her vile views, I do feel compelled to ask her: does she believe that in the UK, of which she appears to be so fond, violence against women is a very recent thing that has only occurred with immigration from Muslim countries, or will she knowledge that violence against women has been a scourge in our society for centuries?

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: blue-card answer. – Of course, Mrs Girling, I accept that. I have been fighting against this type of violence all my life as a woman who has actually been affected by violence in the home and on the street. My statistics are government statistics, but it is a fact, whether you like it or not, and that is why our government is having an investigation at the moment into Sharia law. Until we actually address the problems and we address that it is the Muslim migrants coming into our countries because of open borders ... And that is why you will be going, Madam. You will be leaving this Chamber because we voted for Brexit and because you all wonder why the populace are on the rise in America and in Holland and in other countries: because of people like you and them across there.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, in Northern Ireland in 2014-2015, there were over 13 000 reported incidents of domestic violence. The Police Service of Northern Ireland responded to one domestic incident every 19 minutes. In this period, there were 2.5 times as many domestic abuse crimes as drug offences. These are unacceptable figures, and we must do everything in our power to tackle these awful abuses. In Northern Ireland, the 24-hour domestic and sexual violence helpline is managed by the Women’s Aid Federation. In 2014-15, it managed 27 000 calls and reported a rise in the percentage of male callers, and in this Chamber we should not forget that men are often the victims of these crimes as well. So, it is right that, both in this Parliament and in our national parliaments, we send a message. The Government is not just willing, but ambitious to tackle these abuses at the earliest stages. International agreements can be pursued, but local solutions are necessary.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Madam President, I would like to emphasize that the Istanbul Convention establishes a comprehensive legal framework for preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. It is also a call for more gender equality, which cannot be achieved, while statistics continue to show that one in three women in Europe has been the victim of physical or sexual violence at least once in their lives. In this regard, I support the accession of the European Union to the Convention and call for its ratification by the Member States. A few aspects to consider, however. In the first place, in order to achieve the desired results, it is important that the provisions of the Convention are consistent with the various national legal systems. This implies both the adaptation of the relevant regulations at national level and the provision of sufficient financial and human resources. Next, I would like to emphasize the key role that close cooperation with civil society organizations has in achieving a coordinated approach to combating violence against women and raising awareness. The national campaign we conducted with them in Bulgaria on violence against women "Let's open our eyes and break the silence" showed that our cooperation can be a powerful catalyst for change. Finally, it is important to continue at European level our efforts to create a common system for collecting data on violence against women, because violence against women is not just a problem for women. It affects each of us. The institutions must therefore be active, and the accession of the European Union to the Convention is a decisive step in this direction.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - We are in 2016, we live in times of extraordinary development. Our human rights seem to be well protected. But with growing xenophobia and nationalism, we can see the rise of another phenomenon - sexism. Suddenly, we need to talk again about women’s rights, which we enacted decades ago, such as women’s free choice of their own bodies. This has also happened in Slovenia, although this right is protected by the constitution. This is a trend that is extremely worrying. It needs to be recognized and stopped. The Union can only be successful if we defend the rights of all people - and, after all, we make up half of women. Violence against women and domestic violence is the number one threat to women's well-being. It threatens us both physically and mentally, contributes to gender inequality and leaves behind long-term consequences. Statistics prove that we are not taking enough action. As has been heard, every third woman after the age of fifteen has already been a victim of violence. It could be me, it could be you. We must stop these serious violations of women's rights. We urgently need to take a step towards addressing violence against women more effectively. 28 Member States have already signed the Istanbul Convention. Only half of them ratified the agreement, including my country Slovenia. And now we need to bring this process to an end and provide the same level of protection for women. I therefore support the resolution and call on the Commission to introduce appropriate measures through the directive.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Jourová! International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women: I would like to focus on a field of violence against women in which I would like to see more engagement at all political levels. It's about violence against women in obstetrics, human rights behind the delivery room door, it's about the right to a safe birth - for mother and child. All over the world, mothers are reminders of the grievances that existed during the Roses Revolution. In Germany, and indeed throughout Europe, obstetrics is increasingly falling under the wheels of profitability. Up to 400 maternity wards are on the red list across Germany. The lack of midwives is glaring. For large clinics, births have to be efficient, fast and timely. The rights of the woman giving birth are disregarded and pressed into an inhumane womb machinery - fatal for mother and child. Hence my appeal: let's take the Roses Revolution seriously. Let's take up their concerns. Let's create a right to a safe birth - across Europe.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this morning I went over the twenty-three seen and the sixteen recitals that are the basis for our request for the Union to join the Istanbul Convention. There are thirty-nine compelling reasons to support this request. What else can be added? So it occurred to me to apply to victims of gender violence the same idea that the Association for Historical Memory raises with the disappeared during the Franco regime. It has not been easy. I first needed to know how many women have been killed for this cause in the Union in the last ten years. It is significant: it has been impossible to find the data, because not all States face the same vision, even deaths related to machismo. Without getting discouraged, I have obtained one, extrapolating to the Union level the sexist murders committed in that period in Spain: more than 700. The result is recital 40, the one that I was missing: dedicating a minute of silence to each of these 7,000 women would keep us silent, in thunderous silence, four days, fourteen hours and thirty-five minutes.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Madam President, the Istanbul Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights, and is, without a doubt, a huge step to take political and judicial measures against sexist violence, because the abuser is not born, the abuser it does. In my country, this year alone, there are already at least forty women murdered. And I'm sorry that Mrs. Atkinson left because she should be told that there are 40 women killed precisely by Christians, not by any Sharia or anything. It is not a question of religions, it is not a question of races and it is not a question of economic or cultural situations. Every second counts and, therefore, we need the Commission and the governments to reach an agreement right now, and to get serious and with real political will. Finally, we would ask you to have a little coherence in foreign policy in this European Union. And, without a doubt, we must applaud the feminist struggles of these last days in Turkey: we neither must nor do we want to allow setbacks in our rights.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: - Madam president."Pretty, do I study or work for you?": It is one of the typical macho compliments that women have to suffer in their daily lives and that many men use naturally.Men have the responsibility to banish the machismo in which society has educated us and to turn ourselves into the fight against all kinds of violence against women.Today, more than half of the women in the European Union have suffered sexual harassment;and in Spain, so far this year, thirty-nine women have been murdered at the hands of their partners.Faced with this inadmissible scourge, it is urgent that all Member States ratify the Istanbul Convention and that, as the Commissioner has promised, the European Union do so before the end of 2016. This is a fundamental step to build a global framework for the protection ofall women victims of sexist violence, because women's safety is also everyone's safety.Not one more!

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Yes, there could be many more men present here.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Madam President!The EU Commission wants the EU to join the Istanbul Convention as a state.We reject violence against women - all of them.There is no need for a convention or discussion for this.but that is not the point.The Istanbul Convention wants to stipulate that a person's gender is a social construct.The sex thus arises through man himself, through imagination and training, through the tides, through the sun, moon and stars.Man makes himself god.Ladies and gentlemen, this is nonsense.And if you agree to this nonsense, you are probably on drugs.The Istanbul Convention wants all national legislation to be based on this gender gaga crap.No one in their right mind can agree to this.Gender mainstreaming - that is the plague of this century.This is wealth garbage, it belongs on the rubbish heap of history.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Fellow Members!From forming different opinions, we still accept these and listen to each other.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: - Madam President, dear colleague, your lyrical flights in favor of the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention in no way relieve you of the responsibility which is yours in the current regression of women's rights, because you have allowed Islamic fundamentalism to flourish in Europe, this deadly ideology which advocates the application of Sharia law, including polygamy and forced marriage. You have organized the migratory subversion of the European Union through the migrant relocation plan, resulting in the explosion of sexual assaults, such as in Cologne last year. Finally, you support Turkey's accession to the European Union. I just remind you that the Turkish government was just considering, a few days ago, to overturn the conviction of a rapist who consents to marry his victim. So, before ratifying yet another convention, start by assuring women of their first right, namely the right to security. To conclude, I would remind you that this accession seriously undermines the sovereignty of the Member States and that the European Union has no legitimacy to impose this convention on them.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Madam President, first of all, I would like to point out the complex of inferiority and historical ignorance that distinguishes all those in this Chamber who have referred to Istanbul as Istanbul. The Istanbul Convention therefore recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights, which is unquestionable. In addition to information and awareness-raising at national and EU levels, measures are needed to prevent violence, protect victims and prosecute perpetrators. Many Member States have ratified the Convention, including Greece, but have typically lagged behind in transposing it into national law. I do not want to believe that the main reason given by the Member States for not ratifying the Convention is the high cost of implementing it, because, on the one hand, if the violence is reduced, there will be a corresponding reduction of the required funds by EUR 7 billion, and on the other, because human pain is not measured by money. As the Apostle Paul once said, "avarice is the root of all evil."

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Madam President, every year one hundred and eleven women die in Europe from sexist violence and, therefore, every day a common action from the European Union is more necessary in the face of the violation of the most important of human rights: the right to life. The data that the Fundamental Rights Agency gives us are chilling. A third of European women have suffered physical or sexual violence at least once in their life, and in most cases it is not reported out of fear or shame. The victims, in many cases, are helpless, and their attackers enjoy impunity. Faced with a European panorama where women are not equally protected in all States, it is urgent to adopt a common legislative framework that, although it is not the immediate solution, it will be a great advance to protect the victims. To end the violence we must take not only legal measures but also educational, cultural and social ones. That is why we have submitted this oral question to the Commission.
