In it, we urge, Commissioner, that the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention becomes a reality as soon as possible, since this is the most powerful binding legislative instrument to combat violence, in which the different forms are criminalized. violence against women in a framework where victims are protected and criminals are prosecuted. There is still a long way to go, as women continue to be murdered, raped and abused. That is why I ask the Commission to speed up the pace, because the violence does not stop, and I believe that we need a Europe that has a clear and unique voice. Not one more, not one more murdered woman!

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Madam President, Simone de Beauvoir said: "It will only take a political crisis, an economic crisis or a religious crisis for the rights of women to be called into question. These rights are never acquired." Today we are living through the three crises: a political crisis with an upsurge of populism and conservatism, an economic crisis, of course, and a religious crisis - just look at what is happening today in Syria and the victims. , particularly, what are women in these migratory movements. These three crises should make us even more vigilant with regard to violence against women, because we can of course expect that there will be an even resurgence of this violence against women. It is not just a question of denouncing, which is what we do today, of course. What we are asking through the ratification of the convention is to act. Act so that there are indeed concrete action plans to fight against this violence, act so that there are legislative tools that allow us to play our role as parliamentarians in order to be able to impose a certain number of things. Therefore, to all those who say that we do not have the tools to act - as the Council said earlier when it indicated that there were things to be settled legally - , I say we can act, and I would even say that we must act.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President! We are all against violence against women and we must not be indifferent to the suffering of women. However, we must not have one more thing - to pretend that this nightmare will end with the ideological Istanbul Convention. The accession to it by the Union will lead to the fact that in all Member States the definitions of crimes covered by the Convention will be contaminated by gender ideology. An ideology that assumes that gender has a socio-cultural background and that violence against women is a result of an allegedly patriarchal society that needs to be changed to the only right left-wing fashion. How nonsense this assumption is can be seen in many Western European countries that have been following this path for years, and where the statistics on violence are alarming. The ratification will eliminate all reservations to the convention submitted by the member states, and the EU institutions will guard the sick vision of society.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - No is no.Leave me alone is no.I don't feel like a no.Not doing is no.I don't want is no.This, friends, we can say in all languages here in the hemisphere.And yet, one in three women is a victim of violence.I am pleased that we are taking the step here today to accede to the Convention, but let's be honest: we need to do more.We have to come up with a real action plan.We have to get to a situation where the men keep their hands off the women.We need to achieve a situation where we really protect victims, where reports of sexual violence are taken seriously, where victims are helped.Colleagues, I call you here today, let's all get up together today in this hemisphere, please get up with me and cry out loud: No to violence against women.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like us all to ask ourselves that Europe is one in which one third of women, one third of European citizens, one third of women who cross Europe, suffer physical or material or symbolic violence in virtue of its belonging to a gender. There is no justification for the non-ratification by 14 countries of the Istanbul Convention and it is surprising that some colleagues evoke the spectrum of gender to justify the non-ratification; just as there is no justification, in those countries that have ratified the convention, for its failure and full implementation. We must fight against all forms of male violence against women, precisely, material, physical, symbolic, psychological. And we will be in the streets of Rome on November 26, as part of a demonstration called to say "no less", to denounce and fight against all forms of male violence. Finally, I want to dedicate my speech to Figen Yuksekdag, a parliamentarian from the HDP, currently held in prison by the Erdogan regime. I believe that Kurdish women and Turkish women who are fighting against the regime ..... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here to discuss the Istanbul convention against violence against women. Allow me first of all to point out the incredible irony of this convention which bears the name of the Turkish capital. Indeed, only a few days ago, the government of this country wanted to pass a law which would have annulled the convictions for sexual assault on a minor if the perpetrator wanted to marry his victim. These attacks on the dignity of women are appalling. The degradation of the condition of women in our various countries is unbearable, because the rights of women are declining. Islamist fundamentalism takes root, attacks women head-on and seeks to lock them into fabric cages. The attacks on their physical integrity remain at a dramatically high level. In France alone, a woman is raped every 40 minutes. The free trade treaties that the European Commission negotiates or the laws that it imposes on the Member States, such as the El Khomri law in France, make employees more precarious and make women their first victims. You have all subscribed to these texts of social regression. The National Front, the first feminist party in France, for its part rejects these monstrous attacks on women's rights, and we will fight throughout this term and during the presidential campaign that is coming, alongside Marine Le Pen so that the condition of women is finally improving. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: question "blue card".- Madam President, I note with regret that our colleagues from the French populist extreme right are using women victims of violence to campaign for an election.It is a scandal.I want to ask Ms. Montel the following question: What do you say to the millions of women, white or not white, who have been victims of sexual violence, who have been beaten, who have been killed by white European men in the western world?

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: answer "blue card".- Your question makes absolutely no sense, dear madam.Marine Le Pen is going to lead a very dynamic campaign, and you will see that a significant number and a growing number of women will vote and support Marine Le Pen, who is the only candidate who defends women in this presidential election in France.(Ms. Corazza Bildt's off-mic reaction: "Well, that proves this is an election campaign!")

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - I appreciate the work of the petitioners, but I do not think that this is a matter for the European Union. Unlike my colleagues, I believe that in the fight against violence against women, we are not tackling the problem of discrimination against women against men by the state. Criminal law in all Member States does not differentiate between victims of violence according to their gender. We address the application of these laws in practice, the functioning of the police and the courts, but also how to effectively prevent violence and how to protect its victims, including potential ones. In addition, the Istanbul Convention would introduce into the EU legal system a definition of the term gender, which is unknown to the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This would open a wide gateway to the promotion of identity-based policies. I am seriously concerned that it is this way of thinking that polarizes society, because it allows the division of us versus they to penetrate every area of ​​politics. Today, more than ever, we need the exact opposite, to focus on what unites us as Europeans and citizens and not what divides us.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! It cannot be repeated often enough: The Fundamental Rights Agency in Vienna has ascertained that in the EU every woman over the age of 15 has been the victim of physical or sexual violence once in their life. That's shocking. It happens everywhere: in all walks of life, in all age groups and in all Member States. Yes, and it has become socially acceptable again to make fun of women in a sexist way. It is well known that everything begins with words. The EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention would be a clear sign that history cannot be reversed. Accession would enable better implementation of existing laws, appropriate rights of intervention against perpetrators, it would improve prevention and victim work, raise awareness for the creation of emergency shelters and so on. This guideline, which has been discussed many times today, is therefore very necessary. The Commission is to be thanked for taking the initiative and it has Parliament's support. A few days before November 25th, this is an important sign. The Council should recognize that there is no point in putting such an essential subject on the back burner. It is not a minor matter, it should be causa prima. Combating violence against women is the foundation of a civilized society and the Presidency should also put pressure on the defaulting Member States.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - I do not approve of domestic violence. Violence against women is, of course, a bad thing, it must be unequivocally condemned, it must be combated. But I do not consider the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention to be an appropriate tool in the fight against domestic violence. Commissioner, I ask: why is the Commission promoting an instrument that takes the Member States' sovereign competences in this matter? The right of each Member State to consider at national level whether or not to waive this competence should be respected. The Convention forces 14 Member States that have not yet ratified it to agree, for example, on the binding introduction of the concept of 'gender' as a social construct and the promotion of gender ideology; second point: and interfering in education, including restricting parents' rights. Accession to the Convention would undermine the judicial system of the Member States without sufficiently addressing the issue of violence itself. This once again weakens citizens' trust in the Union. That is why I urge you to support other methods of stopping violence in our society, but not by pushing through this controversial convention. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, you acknowledge, through what you have said, that there is this violence and you have said that ratification of the convention does not solve the problem.What would be your solution to the problem then?Because, if it's the one you said, that at the national level everything would be solved, why hasn't it been solved so far?

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: answer to the blue card question - What's more problematic than creating another document that respects what the 14 states reject?It's all over.The whole problem that 14 states have here is that gender concepts, ideologically motivated ideas are being introduced here - we reject them, that's all.And when another document is drafted, we all - all from every camp - say here that we want to suppress violence against women and domestic violence.Well, let's suppress him without the things that bother him.

name: Stefan ECK
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I didn't take any dope, as Frau von Storch suggested. So, combating violence against women cannot be that important to a number of Member States, because they have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention. What values ​​do these member states actually speak of when they raise their moral finger against other countries, even though they are not even able to adapt their national legislation to the Convention? This convention is rightly considered to be the most important instrument for combating violence against women at present. It creates comprehensive protective measures for all women and for girls and women on the move. This is very, very important today. We must declare war on sexism by all possible means, we must act now! All Member States should ratify the Convention as soon as possible so that we can take a step forward on this important issue.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, more than 20 years have passed since the proclamation of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, but worrying figures still persist: one in 20 European women has been raped, one in every 5 has been pursued. These data make clear evidence. This is a fight between men and women and a cause for each and every one. That is why we call today on those Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the Istanbul Convention. That is why we call on the Council to proceed with negotiations on the accession of the European Union. But, let it be clear, this is a change that does not happen only with this debate or with the ratification of a treaty. It is a change that requires constant and laborious work. We are the continent of the world that fights most for the defense of human rights. Here, too, we must be a beacon of hope for millions of women who here, or across borders, still suffer simply because they are women.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Madam President, Commissioner and ladies and gentlemen, every day hundreds of women feel in their skin and body the violence of those who understand that being a woman is unlucky for nature, for a social and cultural destiny that destroys their soul. In fact, we all know that this is just one way of maintaining a meaningless justification for violence. Violence that occurs in different ways: in the marked body, in the refusal of another power to decide on my own body, in the rejection of my reproductive health rights, in the denial of my education, in the early death, simply because I am a woman . We are talking about those who understand that being genetically mutilated is just another bad luck. No longer from nature, but from culture, education and our history. And this is what we have to fight. We have an asset in hand, Commissioner. And we have to give a signal, a signal of solidarity with all women, a signal that we believe, as a whole, in equality, that unique European value.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! We have been discussing the Istanbul Convention for a long time, the more so because in many countries - for example Germany - this convention has not yet been ratified. Of course, this is an ideological document, marked by Marxist prejudices against the family as a space of violence. It is, of course, also a hypocritical document that ignores violence in environments such as momentary relationships or accompanying phenomena such as pornography. But today we are not talking about the content of this convention - this discussion has been or is still going on in our countries. Today we are discussing whether to provide the European Union with one more instrument of interference in the policies of our countries, and no one who truly values ​​democracy, sovereignty, political responsibility and public debate should agree on this. I urge those colleagues who have not yet ratified the Convention - hold this discussion at home and leave this Parliament alone!

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I agree with the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention as a symbolic gesture, because violence against women is still a widespread evil and needs to be combated.In the same way, it is necessary to fight violence against every person, children, the elderly.I am against violence against unborn children.I also think that this is also why we should not make violence against women a specific crime at EU level.Specific measures against violence against women and domestic violence must be taken by the Member States.If the EU is committed to combating violence, I see this as supporting the efforts of the Member States, and I can agree to such an EU commitment.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: - Madam President, criminalize physical, sexual and psychological violence, provide safe shelters for women victims of violence, educate on gender equality, inform professionals who work with victims and provide the necessary financial resources, Here are some of the measures proposed by the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international tool intended to combat violence against women. We learn that this will not happen in the end, but it is particular to hear Istanbul quoted when we have in mind the plans to degrade the rights of young girls that were envisaged by this abject proposal from the Turkish authorities to allow rapists to repair their crimes by marrying their victims. When it comes to violence against women, those responsible are first and foremost individuals. But to eradicate these unspeakable acts, governments and the European Union also have their share of responsibility. This is why our legislation must be aligned with the Istanbul Convention. The situation of women in the face of violence is not going to change with the snap of a finger or a pen, but our responsibility is to legislate to change the law and in-depth mentalities. This is the meaning of the Istanbul Convention. Of the 28 Member States that have signed it, only half have ratified it. We must get out of duplicity and take action. The European Commission proposed the Union's accession to this convention last March and I welcome that. It must step up the pace - you have made proposals to us - because a common approach is essential to protect women in the same way, regardless of where they live in the Union.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - Thank you, Mr President. Violence against women is one of the greatest human rights violations, with no geographical, economic, cultural or social boundaries. Almost one in four women in the European Union has experienced physical abuse. And all violent crimes - physical, psychological, sexual, economic - cause irreparable damage to women's physical and mental health. And while we pay a lot of attention to the issue of violence against women, it is painful to see that we are still failing to protect women from such crimes. Last year, in Parliament, we adopted a written statement calling on the Commission to declare 2016 the Year for Combating Violence against Women. The Commission did not comply with this request. But I congratulate her on taking concrete steps to get the European Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention, which is a big and important step that will really make a difference in this never-ending struggle, and we must remember that all programs and measures to stop violence against women will only work. when women are assured that they will be cared for, psychological and social assistance, health care, and the perpetrators will be punished if they talk about violence.

name: Soraya POST
text: - Madam President! November 25 is a day to mourn that we have not come any further. It is a day to mourn that we do not want to look at violence in close relationships for what it actually is: a security policy problem. I ensure that the EU is at the forefront of human rights research, but I choose to ignore both by excluding violence in close relationships in the new security agenda. We have thus taken a major step back in the issue. The ratification of the Istanbul Convention by all Member States, including the EU, is an important step that must be taken. If we seriously believe that we want to abolish violence in close relationships, we must understand that it is not a women's issue that belongs to the private sphere. If we are to get away from the violence at the societal levels, we must get away from the violence in the international arenas. We can therefore not talk about defense policy and gender-based violence separately, but we must acknowledge the connection. It is when we create a security policy for people and not for ancient national borders that we can stop mourning. It is then that we can seriously eradicate the problem that constantly threatens the existence of women.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I would of course like to join the urgent request made by the previous speaker. It is very clear that the Istanbul Convention must finally take effect, must be introduced and implemented across Europe. But I would also like to address another point: It's about climate policy for women - and I don't mean the weather by that. Climate policy for women - it's about the social climate in which women move. The social climate in the USA is poisoned, for example, by the sexist Trump. In Europe it is the right, the very right and the very, very right that poison the climate against women. They create a social climate, a social climate that makes violence against women possible. Society is always part of the perpetrators. Society makes it possible for violence against women to happen and to go undetected for so long. I believe we have to sign, ratify and implement the Istanbul Convention - across Europe. And I am of the opinion that we need a climate pact for women in order to finally improve the social climate in Europe.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Ms. President! If there is one case where there should be full agreement in the world, but for some innocent-incomprehensible reason it still doesn’t exist: it’s a case of violence against women. That is why it is simply unacceptable that the Istanbul Convention has still not been ratified by all EU Member States, including Hungary. While we know that one in three European women is affected or affected by some form of violence against women. The situation of multiple disadvantaged women on the periphery of society is particularly difficult, as they have little means of enforcing their rights. They need special attention and help. Violence against women is not just a matter for women, but a public affair that poisons and violates democracy. It is a social problem that requires complex legal, social, educational and cultural measures and their consistent implementation. The first step in this direction must be the ratification of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, faced with such a widespread tragedy in our civilized Europe, only a few dull and racist voices can think that the phenomenon can only be traced back to immigration. Faced with this tragedy, Commissioner, we see that civil society, associations, NGOs are doing an enormous job. Not so the European institutions. The Council is still debating - they said - amid sophisticated legal problems. Here, I mean that we have solved the most sophisticated legal problems when we were interested in arriving at a result. And the Commission has not yet done what we ask every year and now we are asking with point 10 of the resolution, that is a directive that is a legal basis, because in some Member States there is no law, there is no law , a basis of law that protects victims and persons subjected to violence. So, Commissioner, we ask you once again this: build on our strength, on the strength of women in this Parliament and ask the Commission to propose a directive, a legislative act. We want laws and we want resources and services, because in many countries women's homes and reception services are closing.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this resolution, Parliament repays an unbridgeable debt to the many, too many women victims of violence in Europe and restores hope towards a path that should be quick and unhindered, but which instead proceeds at a slow pace.in the Council.Violence against women represents an extreme form of discrimination and a violation of the victims' fundamental rights and freedoms.For this reason, we ask that every act of violence against women and girls, and therefore also domestic violence, be included among particularly serious criminal acts, as also enshrined in our treaty.The Union must commit and intervene with a global plan to fight against all forms of gender inequality, because no state can feel less involved than another in this struggle for civilization.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has already been said that one in three women suffers at least one episode of physical or sexual violence in her life. Not only that: according to data from the European Commission, only 30% of victims manage to report the abuses suffered to the competent authorities, thus condemning to silence a problem that risks turning into a social scourge. Now, my opinion is that the Presidency of the Council today, just today, has lost an opportunity: to be present here with something new. Instead he did a homework, mostly hypocritical, without making any commitment in this direction. November 25 will be the International Day against Violence against Women. I believe that today this initiative of the European Parliament must not only represent a symbolic fact, but must be a concrete action for the Member States, not only for ratification, but above all so that they are called to greater legislative responsibility in legally prosecuting the violence of gender, while promoting gender equality as an essential value of our plural and democratic society.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Unfortunately, accession to the Istanbul Convention would not mean an end to violence against women in the Member States at the same time. Today, we can see countless examples of governments having a lot to do in this area. Abuse statistics are, in turn, biased downward, as in many cases no consequences or reports follow an abuse, especially if it is within the family. Yet the FRA’s analysis is telling: one in three women has experienced physical or sexual violence since the age of 15. Violence against women is a crime, and this must be understood by European citizens and those who come to Europe. Accession to the Convention would bring about a change in the ability of public authorities to take concerted action against violence against women and domestic violence, and to establish specific policies for crime prevention or victim protection that would be monitored by international experts. It is a pity for the delay, because in this way the implementation of the provisions will be postponed, so the improvement of the situation cannot start either.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, women and young girls are often exposed to serious forms of violence, such as domestic violence, sexual harassment, rape and genital mutilation, which are serious human rights abuses and equality between men and women. The incidents described are unacceptable. One in three women in the European Union has experienced physical or sexual violence, or both, and only about 30% of victims report incidents to the police. At the same time, one in four women chooses not to report sexual violence suffered out of shame and one in five do not want anyone to know. The accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention will therefore contribute to the wider goals of the Union for gender equality, the protection of women against all forms of violence and will contribute to the efforts to prosecute the perpetrators, to eliminate violence against women and to elimination of domestic violence.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, I think so many tragic stories have been told here, in the most brilliant way, that there is no need for repetition. However, I would like to refer to the thousands of women, mainly from Syria, who have drowned in the Mediterranean Sea in their quest for freedom. There are not many ways beyond the Conventions, but we need education and punishment, that is, prevention and repression. Education should include specific courses on gender equality. I want to close with the following: in this room, ladies and gentlemen, there is a woman who has suffered the most brutal violence in her face and is sitting behind me. It is Mrs. Kouneva, who was attacked with caustic poison. I want to greet her with a round of applause, not because she suffered this violence of course but because she was already fighting before the event and much more because she continues to fight after this tragic story, vigorously, for the rights of women and men . I especially thank her. (Members applaud Mrs Kouneva)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Also from the Presidency a warm greeting and closeness.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mister President! On New Year's Eve, several women in Cologne who were just happy about New Year's Eve were really assaulted. Sexual violence was used, some were even raped, and in principle nothing could be done. First of all, the perpetrators have not really been found, and if they had been found, German law would not have had the opportunity to actually convict them because Germany has not yet signed the Istanbul Convention. That's exactly why this is so important. We really need a tool, a law against violence against women that makes women safe, that really says: No means no, so that you can feel safe - not only in Germany, all over the world. Basically: I find it really inhuman when Beatrix von Storch says here: Everyone who defends this, who demands it, is on drugs. That's a slap in the face from any woman who has ever been subjected to violence. Just as it is to say here now that this is none of the EU's business. If the EU also ratifies, then that will of course be a very strong signal to all Member States that have not yet done so. It is imperative that we do something to fundamentally combat violence against women.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, violence against women continues, still continues. Women victims of physical, psychological and sexual violence, violence within the family, violence in the presence of children, children. It is not tolerable, it is no longer tolerable. The European Union needs to send a clear message on the need to protect women across Europe from violence. Specific and harmonized legal rules are needed. In this sense, the provisions of the Istanbul Convention contain useful legal instruments not only to prosecute perpetrators but also to prevent violence. I am thinking, for example, of the possibility of removing the perpetrator of domestic violence from the home. But protecting women from violence also means protecting children. Children, victims of witnessed violence, witnesses of family violence, which cause psychological trauma and often leave indelible traces. I am aware of the legal challenges for the Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention, but I hope that today's debate and the resolution we will vote on tomorrow will be an effective stimulus towards a swift and successful conclusion of the accession process.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the signing of this convention will not translate into results if it is not accompanied by concrete policies to combat poverty and social exclusion. In fact, it is symptomatic that the resolution to be voted on has no reference, much less a relationship, between the right-wing policies to attack social and labor rights, or the austerity policies that the European Union has imposed and the increase in inequalities, poverty and social exclusion, high levels of unemployment, precarious work and how these phenomena affect women in particular and contribute to the increase in sexual and domestic violence, which in Portugal killed 428 women between 2004 and 2015, or in the increase prostitution networks and human trafficking. This reality requires a change in social and labor policies aimed at eliminating any type of violence against women, but also at eliminating inequalities, strengthening social and labor protection, ending precariousness and increasing wages.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 4 March 2016 the Commission proposed the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international instrument for preventing and combating violence against women. November 25 marks the International Day against Violence against Women, an opportunity for awareness and reflection to relaunch the commitment to overcome, prevent and defeat all forms of violence and harassment against women in every area of ​​personal and family life. and social, including the workplace. Italy, like other member countries, has transposed the Istanbul Convention into its legislation. However, all other Member States must do so soon. An effort by everyone is needed on the cultural level, to allow the overcoming of sexist and offensive behaviors towards women and to educate citizens to respect. The accession of the European Union to the convention is a further step forward to ensure greater efficiency and coherence in policies for the prevention and fight against violence against women and domestic violence: but concrete policies are needed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this discussion. I am really unhappy to have to repeat that the situation is not getting better; the situation is becoming worse in Europe and that is why we decided to earmark quite a lot of money to the campaign. That is why we keep exerting pressure on the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention. That is why we are in such intensive discussions with the Council to have the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention adopted.  These are the concrete measures and concrete steps. I just want to tell you and confirm that what was quoted here by Ms Arena – from Simone de Beauvoir – was right: we are now in a period of where the atmosphere in society as such is worsening. I am working also in the field of anti-extremism and anti-radicalisation of society. I am in contact with the main IT providers. We are trying to combat hate speech online with all possible efficient tools, and this is the sphere where a lot of violence against women starts.  And it is not only against women. It is against all the other vulnerable groups in our societies. We should bear in mind that this is a complex issue and the worsening of the atmosphere in our society is not any excuse for saying, ‘okay, so this is also the case with violence against women’. We must combat and mobilise forces against this on all fronts. I know that you expect answers from me and I am going to raise several questions here. I will not be long as I know that we are limited by time.  You asked: is the political will missing? I think we have to monitor what will be done at Member State level, whether they will ratify the Convention, but I can only share with you my frustration that I was in discussions with some colleagues from Member States, some of the Ministers and people responsible for equality and gender policy, and they told me it is more and more difficult to sell. It is more and more unpopular in some of our Member States. Why is that so? We have to support this policy from a European level and to support these colleagues who work in the Member States. Another question which was flying through the air here: is violence against women a taboo in society? Is it really culturally rooted in some parts of our society where we hear that violence is something normal, it is normality? Is there really such a strong silent acceptance of this phenomenon in our society?  If so, then I am afraid that we cannot change it just by legislation. We need to do much more on the preventive side. We need to do much more campaigning, awareness-raising. We have to work with the young generation. So it is a very complex issue, and I am afraid that if something is culturally-rooted, it will take more time to change it and we have to keep on trying. We will open the data on this which we now have from the Eurobarometer. For 94% of our citizens, violence against women is intolerable. It is a very surprisingly high number, but at the same time, one quarter of people say ‘but the victims are very often also guilty’. We will see these surprising findings from this new survey, which will show us that we have to work more vis-à-vis society itself, and legislation will not do this by magic.  And believe me, I speak to politicians, I speak to organisations, NGOs, to people who are somehow engaged, and all of them say that this is very serious, this is getting worse, we have to combat this. And then when I speak to – and forgive me for this expression – ‘normal people’, they say to me: ‘What do you want? Nothing is happening, it cannot be that bad’. And this applies to everything we do on gender. Once that label of ‘gender’ is put on it, it does not take off. People say: ‘What do you want? Sometimes when I promote gender policy and the policy of equality I work with economic figures. I have never done this for this problem of violence. I will do it now. The estimation of the costs for Europe is more than EUR 200 million a year. This is the cost of violence against women. And why am I quite reticent to use this argument? Because here, we have to speak about the lives of women and children. This is not about money, but it is good to understand that it also has this economic aspect. The last difficult question is: can we change the behaviour of the victims themselves? Everybody – and the Eurobarometer survey showed it – knows somebody who is a victim. So why do we have so few of them – 15-20% of victims – who report it and use the helping hand of society, use the social services, use the power of law enforcement authorities? Why is this so? We need to change this and we need to encourage them.  We have legislation for this. The Victims Directive clearly asks and demands that the law enforcement authorities take a special approach to victims of violence, of domestic violence, to children and women who are the victims of this. So we need to join forces and we need to use all possible instruments, not only legislation, to change the situation.  I am sure the Istanbul Convention should be ratified by all Member States because there are practical measures. There are also measures which can help children who are victims, as well as women. European Union accession is equally important. It is not true that we are decreasing the competences of Member States by this accession. We are enlarging the coherence of this policy within Europe. We can get better data collection and monitoring of the situation. It is also equally important and it will achieve slightly different goals from those which must be achieved through ratification by the Member States.  One last comment. It must be absolutely clear to European society, to European people, and to the newcomers, the people who come in the refugee influx – and this is more a message for this side of the Chamber – that violence against women is intolerable in Europe, for all, and we must not relativise it. This must be absolutely clear, and this must not only be the subject for awareness-raising in European citizens, but also in all integration plans and activities vis-à-vis the people who are coming to Europe.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.I have received two motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written.- The Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence is the first instrument in Europe that establishes legally binding and specific standards for the prevention of gender-based violence and the protection of victims.and the punishment of the aggressor.The Convention covers a wide range of measures, including obligations ranging from awareness raising and data collection to legal measures on criminalizing different forms of violence.Although all the Member States of the European Union have signed the Convention, only fourteen of them have ratified it.From the European Parliament we consider it essential to support the Union's adherence to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - Women living in the EU are unfortunately still frequently victims of violence. According to an analysis carried out by the Fundamental Rights Agency in 2014, it is estimated that one third of all women in Europe have experienced physical or sexual violence at least once in their adult life, 20% have experienced online harassment, and one in 20 women has been raped and more than one in 10 women has been victims of sexual violence by force. It is worrying that we are making little progress in combating this phenomenon, which is a clear violation of human rights and a form of discrimination. In March this year, the Commission proposed that the EU accedes to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international instrument to prevent and combat violence against women. All EU Member States have signed the Convention, but only 14 have ratified it. The accession of the EU to the Convention will improve the effectiveness and coherence of the EU's internal and external policies on combating and preventing violence against women and gender-based violence in Europe. Moreover, it will ensure a more effective implementation of the Union's laws, programs and funds adopted for this purpose. It will also contribute to the EU's efforts to achieve equality between women and men, anti-discrimination, public health and economic growth.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. – This Friday we are marking the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. It is a reminder that this violation of human rights continues globally. 1 in 3 women worldwide have experienced physical or sexual violence. 4.5 million people are victims of forced sexual exploitation – 98% of them are women and girls. 32 countries exempt rape perpetrators from prosecution when they are married to or subsequently marry the victim. Just now Turkey tried to reintroduce the inhumane law. We can only stop this by working together. More men must stand up against violence, denounce it, and stop it. Male leaders, including traditional and religious leaders, must lead the way. Violence against women is a serious impediment to women’s progress in any area of life. Combating all forms of violence against women must therefore be a priority for the EU and I call on the EU to ratify the Istanbul Convention. We need to address the root causes of gender inequality and support better services for women in violent situations, more accurate reporting of risk and prevalence, and provide greater help for women’s organisations. All of us must work tirelessly to stop violence, whatever form it takes.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- Violence against women is a widespread human rights violation that the European Union must not overlook.EU Member States all have more or less legislative action to combat violence against women, but in many of these countries more can be done to protect women and bring criminals to justice.I am therefore pleased that the EU is acceding to the Istanbul Convention, which will make it possible to harmonize legislation at EU level and improve the collection of statistics.It is extremely unfortunate that so far only 14 EU Member States have ratified the Istanbul Convention.I also call on Estonia to move forward with the ratification process of the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: signed up. - On 25 November, we celebrate the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, but unfortunately the progress made in combating violence against women and gender-based violence is not noticeable. Statistics have not improved and women are still being beaten to death in EU countries. On 4 March 2016, the Commission proposed the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding instrument on preventing and combating violence against women at international level. All Member States have signed it, but only 14 have ratified it. The European Commission has a duty to encourage Member States to ratify the Convention or at least to revise their legislation to ensure that it complies with the Convention. The extent of physical and sexual violence against women throughout the Union requires renewed policy attention and immediate action. We can no longer remain indifferent.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. Unfortunately, violence against women and gender-based violence continue to be widespread in the European Union. Recent studies show that 1/3 of all women in Europe have been physically or sexually abused at least once in their adult lives, while around 20% of young women have been sexually harassed online. The fight against and elimination of all forms of violence against women, the right to equal treatment and non-discrimination are fundamental rights enshrined in the European Treaties. What remains is for these rights to take root deep in the foundations of our societies and to be applied in practice and in everyday life, changing anachronistic mentalities and perceptions. The Istanbul Convention is an important legal text that covers the issue of violence against women at various levels, setting out specific commitments and objectives, such as prevention, anti-discrimination, criminal sanctions to address impunity and protection and support for victims. EU accession will ensure a coherent European legal framework for preventing and combating violence but above all set an example for the ratification of the Convention by all European Member States.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Emmanuel Maurel, under the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the granting of further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (COM (2016)0431 - C8-0242 / 2016 - 2016/0197 (COD)) (A8-0296 / 2016)

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: protractor. - Mr President, Commissioner, as you all know, Jordan is one of the first collateral victims of the Syrian chaos and, as such, it faces considerable challenges which, if not were not overcome, would create a situation of even greater instability. I will not go into what is happening in Jordan again, but the economic and social consequences of what is happening around this country are obviously considerable. Tourism has dropped sharply, exports are slowing down because Jordan's natural trade opportunities, Syria and Iraq, are totally devastated, growth is sluggish, unemployment has exploded. So we have a country that is both politically stable, but in great difficulty economically and socially. Despite this, Jordan faces another challenge, a colossal and considerable challenge, that of welcoming hundreds of thousands of refugees from these countries at war, fleeing persecution and misery. I recall that in Jordan, the refugees are less in camps than in the cities, where the Jordanian authorities try to integrate them, to allow them to work, and all this with a lot of dignity. This should appeal to those of us who know a little about the situation in this country, as Europeans also facing this refugee crisis, but with answers that are sometimes slow to come and in any case a generosity that we do not give. not really proof. Thus, faced with this exceptional situation, the European institutions have obviously decided to provide aid, relief to Jordan via what is called "macro-financial assistance" (AMF). Of course, there are other ways to help this country, it is not the only one. Moreover, the Commission is working on making rules of origin more flexible for Jordanian products and we may mention the negotiation a trade agreement that is both asymmetric and progressive. But in any case, within the INTA committee, we discussed this macro-financial assistance and we reached an initial agreement. There were technical elements since it was necessary to accept the modifications introduced by the Council on the Commission text - that did not take us much time - but obviously, we mainly talked about the amount. There was unanimity within the INTA committee, right and left alike, to try to propose an amount much higher than that suggested by the Commission, which was only 200 million euros. There was an interesting debate. We felt that the Jordanians' financial needs were great and that Europe had ample means to help them. There was a debate, a discussion. I would also like to thank Bernd Lange, chairman of the INTA committee, who worked hard to find a compromise. We finally reached a compromise which I consider acceptable, since there would be a first tranche of 200 million euros which would be disbursed immediately but with the promise, or in any case the commitment of the Commission, to make even over the next year. This is what this report proposes. Personally, however, I would like to reiterate two requests that I have included in the explanatory memorandum. First, I think that the Commission must show intelligence and flexibility in the terms of what is called "the memorandum of understanding", that is to say that it negotiates with the authorities. Jordanian and not obsessed with structural reforms whose pace would be too hasty. But we must not forget that the AMF is only a loan; these are not gifts. At some point, like what we did when we had the debate on Tunisia with Ms. de Sarnez who was the rapporteur, we will obviously have to wonder about the renegotiation of Jordanian debt, which may be very important in the future.There you have it, dear colleagues, Commissioner, Mr President, I would obviously like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who, on this subject, have been very active and determined to ensure that the European Parliament speaks with one voice on a subject which isimportant, since it is about the future of the countries of our immediate neighborhood.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank the rapporteur, Mr Emmanuel Maurel, and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for their valuable work on this report. I also thank the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) and the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) for their support.  As you know, Jordan is among those partner countries facing enormous political and economic challenges due to the regional conflict and the influx of more than one million Syrian refugees. The intensification of the conflicts in Syria and Iraq led to a deterioration of the macroeconomic situation in Jordan in 2015, with trade, the tourism sector and the gas supply being particularly affected. It is in this broader context of regional conflict and with every intention of supporting Jordan and its people during this difficult time that the Commission submitted its proposal for the macro—financial assistance operation. The international community has continued to fully support Jordan in this difficult situation and pledged about EUR 10 billion at the so-called London Conference in February 2016 for countries most affected by the Syrian refugee crisis. At this conference the EU pledged EUR 2.4 billion including a EUR 200 million macro—financial assistance loan. The EU—Jordan partnership priorities approved recently by the Council also include the prospect of this macro-financial assistance. In view of these international commitments, it is crucial that Parliament and the Council agree on the proposed macro—financial assistance of EUR 200 million to Jordan so that this support can be effectively and swiftly delivered.  The new macro—financial assistance operation will of course be subject to the fulfilment of a number of economic reforms. Jordan must satisfactorily implement the programme of the International Monetary Fund as well as the policy measures to be agreed between the EU and Jordan in a memorandum of understanding.  Once agreement on the proposed loan is reached, we will work to agree quickly the policy measures with our Jordanian partners. It is likely that these would cover measures in the areas of public finance management, fiscal reform, the societal safety net and access for Syrian refugees to the labour market, measures that would help Jordan withstand the economic pressure it is currently facing while securing a stable future for its people.  I am pleased that Parliament and the Council were able to agree on the final text in trilogue on 27 October 2016, with two amendments that the Commission can support. In accordance with the joint statement agreed by the three institutions the Commission will, in 2017, if appropriate, submit a new proposal for macro-financial assistance, provided that the usual preconditions for this type of assistance are fulfilled and on the basis of an updated assessment by the Commission of Jordan’s external financing needs. I am pleased to underline that two weeks ago the Council confirmed already its approval of the Commission proposal subject to the approval of this Parliament.  I hope, therefore, that you will choose to vote positively on the proposal and the accompanying compromise. We need to move ahead quickly to achieve a positive impact in support of Jordan and the Jordanian people. I hope we will have your full support going forward.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that, on this occasion, it is necessary to recall the intervention of the king of Jordan last March 2015 in Strasbourg: a call for unity and the development of a collaboration of a strategic partnership between European Jordan . The priority of this strategy is to create an alternative to radicalization to overcome economic uncertainty and exclusion but, above all, to move towards a consolidated peace. Jordan applied for a loan from the European Union because development and growth are an absolute priority for Jordan. I want to remind you that Jordan - as has already been done, however - beyond the serious economic and financial difficulties, has opened its arms to a huge number of Syrian refugees: 1 400 000, representing 20% ​​of the Jordanian population. . It is as if the entire population of Belgium moved to France. It is also facing major difficulties also in terms of energy supply, a significant drop in revenue from the tourism sector, as well as a drop in foreign investment. Hence, a massive presence of refugees, with a cost for the Kingdom of Jordan estimated at 7 billion euros, and a still very high current account deficit, which is around 11.7% of Jordan's GDP. The negotiating team at the trilogue, as the speaker recalled, fought to obtain an increase in macro-financial assistance: the agreement at the institutional level was not found but the disbursement of 200 million remains a choice of great responsibility and friendship towards Jordan, with a commitment for 2017 to disburse an additional 200 million. Therefore we will strongly and strongly support this measure.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as we have heard from the previous three speakers, Jordan is facing a very serious financial and economic crisis brought on by the instability in the region and the refugee flows coming from that. According to the UNHCR, there are 650 000 refugees, and as we have heard from the Commissioner, possibly a million, and as we have heard from Mr Cicu, possibly 1.4 million. That is a significant number no matter how you measure it. Yet despite its economic difficulties, Jordan has not followed the example of other countries in Europe and around the world. It is not calling for walls to be built around its nation. On the contrary, it has shown a remarkable generosity to its neighbours and has kept its borders open. Because of that generosity, we should be as generous as possible to the country.  Jordan, also in difficult circumstances, continues to have an effective democratic system. It includes a multi-party parliamentary system. It respects the rule of law and human rights in Jordan are guaranteed, and of course, these are all preconditions for receiving MFA. Like the rapporteur, I am disappointed that we could not have been more generous, but also like the rapporteur, I am pleased that during the trilogue we managed to find a compromise that at least looks like we can promise more money to Jordan in 2017, if the need arises. I strongly support this agreement and congratulate both the rapporteur and the Commission on their work.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Commissioner!Mr. Prime Minister!I was in Jordan recently with a delegation from the Committee on Budgetary Control.It is clear that aid flows to this country both from the European Union and from European Union Member States, as well as from international institutions.It must also be made clear that we had reservations about the purposefulness of some expenses.You have to help, but you need to do it wisely, wisely, knowing what we are giving for and controlling this money, so that a black hole does not form, as this may discourage the European taxpayer from giving these amounts.So trust and check - trust but check.This help is needed.There is, for example, education for refugee children.These are humanitarian goals, but it is also important for us, for Europe, that as many people as possible stay there and not come to us.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Emmanuel Maurel, for the very good work he has done and for the investment he has made. We obviously have to help Jordan, which is in a critical situation. It has a war on its borders, especially with Syria and Iraq, countries that are completely destabilized. It hosts around - because we don't know exactly - a million Syrian refugees and a few tens of thousands of Iraqi refugees. It should be remembered that in addition to these people are more than two million Palestinian refugees who have been in Jordan for decades. The situation is therefore very difficult and the economy is very destabilized. Tourism is obviously on the decline, the debt is growing and the country is experiencing difficulties in terms of infrastructure and financing for the reception of refugees. Therefore, it is obvious that we have to help Jordan - that goes without saying - but it is even better if we can be there. We therefore all support this idea of ​​macro-financial assistance to Jordan. We all said we wish it was more important than it is. Remember that Jordan is a stable country in a totally destabilized environment. Hence the importance of being at this meeting. 200 million is good, but it would have been better to go further. We take into account the Commission's commitment to do more next year and we, as Parliament, will be extremely vigilant to ensure that this meeting is maintained and that this commitment is kept. Finally, let us add that it is not money that we give, it is money that we lend. It must be clear and I think that the European Union would be inspired to think of a reconversion of debts on extremely specific projects, as France and Germany have done for Tunisia, for example. I urge the Commission to work on this point and to deepen this question of debt reconversion on field projects that we can then clearly finance and evaluate.Perhaps this is also what we should do for Jordan.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I also believe that it is essential to show our solidarity with Jordan which, for 70 years, has suffered from the repercussions of movements around the world. The non-resolution of the question of the Palestinian State, then the consequences of the wars in Iraq, the civil war in Syria and the hold of the Islamic State in the region have only increased the number steadily. of refugees in the territory of Jordan. I therefore support Emmanuel Maurel's proposal to increase macroeconomic financial assistance beyond the 200 million euros that are planned. This aid must be granted unconditionally and through other means than conditional loans from the International Monetary Fund. On the other hand, Jordan's economic autonomy must all the more be taken into account given that the arrival of Syrian refugees still considerably increases the financial needs in terms of public services, water supply, education or of energy. It is better to use the funding provided in the framework of the neighborhood policy, accompanied by the renegotiation of debts and a commercial partnership aimed at helping the Jordanian economy.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are about to vote on the granting of aid to Jordan in the form of macro-financial assistance.In other circumstances the 5 Star Movement has not expressed itself favorably with respect to the transfer of economic contributions to other countries but Jordan represents a notable exception: due to its geographical position, it has received all the effects of the Syrian crisis, its tourism has dropped., its unemployment has risen, growth has declined.Nor can we ignore the fact that it has taken in over 650 000 Syrian refugees on its territory, doing what almost all of Europe refuses to do: looking after them.Furthermore, Jordan is on the front line against terrorism, against Isis, and helping Jordan also means protecting Europe.Therefore, we believe we must support these efforts.We will be voting in favor of this and I thank Mr Maurel for his work.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, it is obvious that, in a tumultuous Middle East, we defend the idea of ​​supporting a State which presents a certain stability. Nevertheless, I am always wary of the politics of human rights since human rights are not a policy. It is first of all necessary to politically support the actors of this region and to ensure that, where the Western empires have destabilized the Middle East, we can rebuild a real realpolitik. I think that, in this foreign policy of the European Union, it is necessary to clearly see the stakes, namely the support for all the forces which resist the Islamic State and which fight against it. We believe that the first to benefit from this aid are obviously the Christians, who were the first destabilized by the policy of radical Islamism. I am thinking in particular of Lebanon, which has just acquired a new president. Lebanon was not helped like a number of other countries and, in my opinion, like Jordan, we should make the same efforts to support Lebanon, which has shown that it can just have a stability policy even stronger than that of Jordan. Lebanon has just acquired a president. Lebanon, in my opinion, receives many more refugees than Jordan and no one is talking about Lebanon today. I believe that we French people, especially here in the European Parliament in Strasbourg, should be more attentive to the need to develop a homogeneous policy and not to favor only a unilateral policy in favor of a certain number of refugees. In my opinion, we need to review our entire foreign policy and, although the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has unfortunately suspended all aid to Lebanon, we should resume our political will to ensure that all options are put in place. Jordan, Lebanon and the Middle East for a real return to stability.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: - Dear Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! A good 8 million people live in Jordan and, according to current figures that can be found in German media, up to one and a half million refugees are currently living in the country. That puts the country at the limits of resilience. Nevertheless, the Jordanian government is doing everything possible to keep the situation under control and to accommodate the refugees properly and in a humane manner. Many colleagues responded to this. As the EPP, we would have liked the Commission to have promised now to increase macro-financial assistance from EUR 200 million to EUR 350 million. That the compromise says we'll look into this in 2017 is good. But we should keep in mind: if we do not support the country, if we endanger the stability in the country, if we want to maintain the forces, the stability and security in the country, not also with financial means, but only support in warm words, there is a risk that another country in the region will be hit. We already have too many countries in the region where people are unsafe, where people are fleeing for understandable reasons. I would like us to make at least a small contribution through this macro-financial aid to give people a future in their home country. Therefore, please not only ensure that the money is spent, but also that structural reforms are tackled in the country in order to create sustainable prospects for the people. But please all help us to try to go beyond this financial aid to bring peace and quiet in Syria and the region in order to improve the reality of life in the region as a whole.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Indeed, we are talking about a compromise here. We as the European Parliament, we as Trade Committee Chairs wanted to give EUR 350 million macro-financial aid to Jordan. That is obviously also the need that is there. And just because the Council refused to go down this route, we are now talking over 200 million with the possibility of adding something more in 2017. Given the situation, I ask myself why a country that organizes the integration of refugees in an exemplary manner, which, unlike other countries we talk to, does not receive any reasonable equipment, when it is clear that this money - As Mrs de Sarnez said - it is not given away, it is only given away. That is why I cannot understand the Council at all, that it was so unwieldy in the negotiations that it was not possible to even talk about an additional euro. In this respect, it is a compromise that I also support, but a compromise that I would actually have liked to see designed differently so that the refugee situation in Jordan could be better addressed. I would like to expressly thank our rapporteur, Mr Maurel, who tried hard to push this through, but unfortunately failed because of the resistance of the Council - which otherwise spends a lot of money on very dubious things. Nevertheless, many thanks for that.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr. President, when I recently visited Jordan, I saw the great impact that the refugee crisis has on the Jordanian people. They have received more than 1.4 million Syrian refugees and a large group of Iraqis and others. I therefore welcome the financial help from the EU to Jordan to relieve some of their burden. However, in addition to the macro-financial assistance to help Jordan, we should also not forget to help the refugees themselves, including those who are refugees but not registered as such. As I have seen for myself, the EU is helping many refugees, but the problem is that the larger groups of the refugees are either not registered or are not allowed to register. These groups are helped by the Jordanian people, churches and NGOs. I therefore call on the Commission not only to assist Jordan at the macro level, but also at the micro level by giving financial assistance to NGOs and civil society.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: - Mr President, despite the regional instability of the conflicts suffered by neighboring countries, Jordan has carried out an important reform agenda, contained in the roadmap for political and economic reform, which includes, among other issues, both the reform of the electoral law, such as the decentralization law, aimed at building a more participatory political system. Jordan is an important ally of the European Union in the Middle East and a key partner in the fight against terrorism, and is actively involved in the international coalition against Daesh. It is also a fundamental stability factor in a region marked by conflict, so its internal stability is a matter of paramount importance. Jordan has generously contributed, it has already been said, to host hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees fleeing the horror of war. Right now more than a million Syrians live in Jordan, and half of them are children. Based on all that has been said, it is necessary to highlight the need to strengthen our political commitment to the country, as well as our macro-financial assistance, which complements the existing programs of the International Monetary Fund. In this way, we will be able to help maintain their political and economic stability and assist in the development and implementation of the aforementioned reform program.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all too often lately the public debate on trade policy has focused on highly divisive issues, which are creating opposing factions and not a common consciousness that can fully exploit its potential. In fact, international trade is also a fundamental tool of foreign policy and not just a means of improving access to markets. The case of macro-financial assistance to Jordan in this sense is emblematic. The European Union has undertaken a great show of solidarity with a country of six and a half million inhabitants that hosts more than two million refugees. Jordanian history must be an example: a people struggling with a regional crisis and with strong geopolitical instability, which did not hold back in the face of great difficulties. It must be acknowledged, thanks also to the excellent work of the rapporteur Emmanuel Maurel, that the European Parliament had set even more ambitious objectives, which at least had the consequence of further raising the bar for the final decision. The measure that we will bring into force with our vote really aims to support the commitment of our partners, trying to mitigate the causes of migratory flows. This is a good example of commercial policy, which knows how to look beyond just economic interests, capable of influencing the future.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, we are aware that since the beginning of the conflict in Syria and Iraq in 2011, the Jordanian economy has significantly deteriorated. The conflict strains public finances, impacts tourism, blocks trade routes and influences the flow of natural gas from Egypt. In addition, Jordan hosts approximately 1.4 million Syrians, of whom 635 000 are registered with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. In total. Syrians now make up 21% of Jordan’s 6.7 million inhabitants. This is a very heavy burden to carry for such a small country.  The Commission proposes making available to Jordan macro-financial assistance (MFA) for a maximum amount of EUR 200 million, provided in two instalments in the form of loans, but I do not believe this is enough. I fully support the idea to increase the amount of MFA up to EUR 350 million. Obviously the allocations would be conditional on successful programme reviews under the IMF’s new financial arrangement and Jordan would need to commit to specific reforms.  Jordan is home to tens of thousands of refugees from Syria. It has been carrying this burden for many years and we need to do everything to help them in this situation. Let us not waste any more time because the situation is getting worse by the minute.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, the people of Jordan undoubtedly deserve the solidarity of the European Union, and this parliament must clearly support the granting of macro-financial assistance, as resulted from the agreement with the Council, also thanks to the excellent work of our colleague Emmanuel Maurel.Everyone is aware of the situation on the ground: Jordan is being affected by instability in the region, facing serious humanitarian and security problems and, despite this, has set a remarkable example of generosity in welcoming refugees.These reasons are more than sufficient to justify European financial support to Jordan.This is how we have fulfilled our duty, therefore, to express this solidarity in a concrete way and to actively support a stable partner in a turbulent region.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Jordan is one of those key states in our neighborhood with which we have the opportunity to work concretely for the stabilization of the Mediterranean region and the Middle East. The crises and hotbeds of instability in the region, as we know, have repercussions in Europe. With Jordan, we are fortunate to be able to work beyond the context of an acute crisis. I therefore welcome the compromise reached on October 27 on macro-financial assistance of 200 million euros initially and which leaves the door open to an extension and an increase in this amount in 2017. Given the needs specific to the country as well as to our ambition to preserve Jordan as an island of stability, our actions must be up to the challenge. Second remark: I am delighted that, in parallel with the granting of macro-financial assistance, we are able to support the implementation of important structural reforms in Jordan. This country, through its political and economic choices, is an example of moderation and modernity in the region. Jordan has done very valuable human work in welcoming Syrian refugees and has launched important reforms in recent years, especially on the political and democratic front. The new electoral law of last March and the good conduct of the elections, which we observed last September, are another example. Finally - and I will end with a question - I am convinced that we must make our partnership even closer with Jordan, on all levels and using various tools. The European external investment plan is undoubtedly one of these tools, but what are the other initiatives planned and the areas considered as priority?

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the conflict in Syria has no borders because it affects everyone: first of all Europe, where terrible terrorist attacks have forced thousands of refugees onto our shores. Then there are the countries that suffer from this conflict above all due to their territorial proximity to that dramatic theater of war: Lebanon and Jordan, on which the instability of the entire Middle East region weighs more. Countries that are also those that, however, react with greater responsibility and solidarity, welcoming thousands of refugees and setting an example for all. The European Union must continue to guarantee financial assistance to Jordan, which is a key partner in the region, also because it plays a very important role in combating terrorism and ISIS. But with public debt reaching 93% of GDP, Jordan alone is certainly unable to withstand this pressure. However, it is essential to link our support to specific conditions, first of all imposing respect for democratic and human rights. The political dialogue with Jordan will have to consolidate in practice a positive model that sets an example for the whole Middle East.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, Jordan is the country directly affected by the crisis in Syria and Iraq due to its geographical location. Conflicts in the region have hampered the sale of Jordanian products in its historic markets. In addition, the reduction of tourist traffic and foreign investment, the closure of trade routes and the repeated interruptions of the supply of natural gas from Egypt act as a deterrent to the development of the country and burden its economy. In addition, there are an estimated 1.4 million Syrian refugees in Jordan, representing 20% ​​of the country's population. The annual cost of caring for them is $ 3 billion, with only 1/3 being covered by sponsorships from the international community. In Turkey, with far fewer problems than refugees, literally billions of euros are donated. So the 350 million that the report proposes as the Union's macro-financial assistance to Jordan is just a joke. I propose to triple the amount by deducting corresponding amounts from the funds earmarked for Turkey.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in September I participated in a CONT mission to Lebanon and Jordan, countries which have received the largest number of Syrian refugees in proportion to their population. We noted the difficult conditions in which Syrian and also Palestinian refugees live, but also the considerable effort of the Amman government to welcome populations fleeing the conflicts in neighboring countries. However, the very high number of refugees present on Jordanian territory is at risk of leading to the collapse of some public services in the country, such as the health and education system. In particular, the lack of places available in schools means that the right to education is also denied to very many Syrian minors. The migratory pressure and the consequences that the Syrian conflict has had on the Jordanian economy, particularly in terms of exports and tourism, are contributing to a surge in public debt. It is therefore right and necessary for the Union to provide macro-financial assistance to Jordan, a country which stands as an example of solidarity for the efforts made to give a dignified welcome to refugees, including many minors.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that good cooperation between the European Union and Jordan is in the common interest. The European Union and Jordan are currently cooperating in the framework of the European Neighborhood Policy, which covers various areas, including economic development, trade, security, the role of young people and women, improving administrative capacity and human rights. Unfortunately, due to its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the ongoing crisis in the Middle East. Due to the volatile situation in Syria and Iraq, Jordan's economy suffers from low levels of tourism, foreign trade and foreign direct investment. In addition, the country's economic and social model has come under unprecedented pressure from large numbers of refugees and displaced persons arriving in the country over the past five years. In this regard, I support the granting of EUR 350 million in financial assistance to Jordan in order to help the country's economic stabilization. Macro-financial assistance is the European Union's exclusive crisis response tool, which in the case of Jordan will make a significant contribution to the country's socio-economic development.
