name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Jordan and Lebanon have the largest number of refugees in the world. In 2014, Jordan's population was 6.8 million and now it has reached 9.5 million, because we now have 2.7 million refugees who make up 40% of the population. This means that these people have settled in the cities and that there is a lot of pressure on public services and education. At the same time, Jordan's debt is skyrocketing. We therefore have an obligation, as the European Union, to support both Jordan and Lebanon, as I have repeatedly said in this Chamber. So instead of giving our money to Turkey, which is not living up to its obligations, we need to support Jordan. At the same time, the European Union must support the Aegean islands, which have been flooded with thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants. In Samos, in Chios, on the other islands, the inhabitants, with mass gatherings, send a message that is a cry of agony. You must also listen to the inhabitants of the Aegean.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the experience of the Syrian refugee crisis shows unequivocally that we cannot proceed as in the past, leaving the greatest weight on the shoulders of some countries. We are facing the greatest migration crisis of our time and a clear strengthening of global solidarity is needed. The burden of countries hosting large numbers of refugees needs to be alleviated. Jordan is one of the countries that makes a significant contribution to its population: 670,000 refugees are housed only in refugee camps. Thousands of women and men, especially children, need immediate help. All live in critical conditions, often without having known anything in their life other than war and the desperation of the camps. Macro-financial assistance to Jordan is an excellent initiative to foster the stabilization of the Middle East and is the right way to concretely demonstrate solidarity with a country, like Jordan, which is experiencing such a critical situation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So Jordan has found itself practically close to the hotbeds of war in a very unstable area, and yet it has opened its doors wide to the many refugees who make up a quarter of its total population.This is, of course, a great burden for everyone, even for a country of about five million inhabitants.This, of course, also severely undermines financial stability, as well as economic potential, tourism and all that once enriched Jordan as a country, of course, with thousands of wonders.And that is why it is right to dedicate this macro-financial framework to this country as well.Of course, I would like to strive that this is not a one-time aid of 200 million, but that this is a project that will continue in the future, because remember that Jordan has taken on its shoulders a big piece of the refugee takeover, also a European country.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Undoubtedly, macro-financial assistance to Jordan is not only justified, but also urgently needed. The country is one of the most affected by the migration crisis. It is estimated that the number of non-Jordanian residents has doubled since 2011, thus placing Jordan as the world record holder for refugee-to-population ratios. In addition, the unstable situation in the region significantly affected its economic condition. Meanwhile, Jordan is a country of special importance for the region, as it offers a chance to restore political and economic stability in this area and is therefore strategic for its security. There is no doubt that everything possible should be done to help Jordan play this important role to the best of its ability, as well as to ensure sustainability and stability, so macroeconomic support is undoubtedly very much needed here.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Honourable Members very much for their very wide and unified support for the proposal. A few remarks were raised by many Members. For instance, many supported the sum but said it should be bigger.  Why did the Commission propose what it proposed and what was accepted in the trialogues? The proposed MFA amount takes into account several factors: firstly Jordan’s external financing needs at the time of the Commission’s decision, which was at the end of June; secondly, a marked reduction in IMF financing; thirdly, the burden—sharing efforts of other donors; and, fourthly, the Commission’s budget constraints. It also takes into consideration Jordan’s reserves in foreign currencies, which are at relatively healthy levels. We should not forget that this MFA operation is part of the larger and very substantial package of assistance to Jordan. That includes support in forms other than direct financial assistance. The Jordan Compact also includes about EUR 550 million in grants for the next three years, as well as a significant relaxation of the rules of origin for an extended duration. It should also be seen in combination with the first MFA programme, which brings the EU’s total amounts for balance of payments support alone to EUR 380 million.  Since the outbreak of the Syrian crisis in 2011, the EU has allocated almost EUR 1.13 billion euros to Jordan under various instruments. In any case, as is now underlined in the joint declaration to be adopted with the proposed decision, the Commission stands ready to continue providing support to Jordan should the situation call for it and acute needs remain. I hope that you will follow the advice of the rapporteur, Mr Maurel, and approve the Commission proposal, which was accepted or agreed in trialogue.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: protractor. - Mr President, I am happy to note that almost all the parliamentarians who have spoken are well aware of the urgency of the situation in Jordan and of the need to provide it with substantial financial assistance, with a few exceptions, we 'saw during the debate. I would like to reassure certain colleagues, both Mr Le Hyaric and Ms Gabriel: macro-financial aid is only one tool among others. There is of course also: 1) what Mrs de Sarnez raised, that is to say the idea of ​​a work on the restructuring of the debt, which seems to me to be totally important and urgent, 2) the projects of investment to which Ms. Gabriel was referring, 3) the outline of a reflection on a commercial partnership that could be fruitful between the European Union and Jordan - I said this, but perhaps not clearly enough -, and 4) the sum of 200 million - I will repeat - for this time and a commitment from the Commission for the same sum, or even more, the following year. President Bernd Lange reiterated that what was difficult in our negotiations was obviously the relatively inflexible position of the Council, even though, moreover, we are increasing the number of declarations which measure the seriousness of the refugee crisis and seek solutions to get out of it. Finally, to answer the representative of the National Front - he is not here, he left the hemicycle - who has embarked on a long dissertation on the Union's foreign policy, I would first like to say that no do not ignore here the fate of Eastern Christians in this Parliament, but no one ignores the fate of the Lebanese either. We can also recall that, within the framework of the neighborhood policy, the European Union has helped Lebanon on numerous occasions: there is an association agreement, financial technical assistance and more than 700 million euros. euros allocated exceptionally in the context of the Syrian crisis. What I mean by that, it is that, obviously, Europe is fully aware of the situation in these countries and is doing its best to help resolve this crisis, which is indeed a very important crisis.In any case, I thank you for this debate and I hope that tomorrow's vote will be as much as possible - and I think that this is what the Jordanians also expect from us.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 November 2016.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Werner Langen on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs entitled 'Towards a definitive VAT system and combating VAT fraud' (2016/2033 (INI)) (A8-0307 /2016).

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I would like to present the ECON committee's draft report. We intensively discussed the European Commission's action program, which was presented on April 7, 2016. There were a total of 239 amendments. Two committees were invited to give advice. In the end we passed 81 points, which found a large majority with 47 votes in favor, 5 against and 5 abstentions. First of all, I would like to thank everyone who took part for the constructive cooperation and the good ideas. In the end, I believe, we found compromises that should be included in the Commission's deliberations on the specific legislative measures, but also in the Council's decision-making. The problem with tax issues is that the Council has to be unanimous, but we have to be heard beforehand. That is why we took the matter more seriously, even if we are ultimately not in the codecision procedure. It is undisputed that the member states can decide independently about their tax policy. However, the Sixth VAT Directive of 1993 provides a framework for excise and VAT. This Sixth VAT Directive has been revised and reformed several times. One big problem remains, that is the VAT gap and cross-border VAT fraud. The revenue is around EUR 1 trillion. The VAT gap confirmed by the Court of Auditors last year was EUR 160 billion including fraud, which was estimated at EUR 60 billion. This means that around 16% of the revenue is not collected or, as a result, cannot be collected due to fraudulent measures. We all agree that something needs to be done about it. But in the past all steps have been very hesitant. The Commission has therefore proposed that cooperation between the Member States, the exchange of data, improve the information and use necessary and possible technical units for cross-border billing. We have welcomed all of this and there was broad agreement in committee that the ideas that the Commission has proposed are generally positive. But we also discussed proposals going beyond this, namely - in particular - the project, supported by the Czech Republic and by a significant number of member states in the last Ecofin Council, to set up a pilot project on the reverse charge procedure in the Czech Republic. That was not without controversy and we reached a compromise on such a pilot project, but we also said: The duration of such a pilot project must not mean that the other measures are ultimately not taken. Because it is a question of fairness: the lost VAT revenues are significantly higher than the EU budget. You have to know that, and the VAT directive of 1993 says: A definitive system is sought. The final system is now proposed: that the destination principle should be introduced, that we should improve coordination, cooperation, that we should fight fraud. But there are also other measures: In addition to the pilot project I have mentioned, the Commission's proposal to provide a list of reduced goods and services not for the normal tax rate but for reduced tax rates is particularly important. Here we find that the list is very long today, that it is far too long, because it stems from the history of the creation of the VAT Directive and at that time the states insisted that their own interests should also be made the standard for future common legislation. The most glaring case is the Council's decision in the summer to put a zero tax rate on hygiene products for men and women in the UK to allow.That means we have an abundance of tasks.I would like to express my thanks.The report was adopted by a large majority, and I would ask colleagues to vote in favor of the report as a whole, despite all the split votes and all changes to the compromises.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Langen!I have a question for you: The carousel deals that are created by these frauds arise from the fact that someone in the supply chain can credit himself with the VAT and then he exports the goods, right?Have you thought about replacing the whole VAT system with a sales tax, where only the last person, the seller, charges this sales tax to the unregistered taxpayer, but the registered customers and suppliers do not charge each other this tax?Because that would remove the whole basis for the carousel fraud.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.-  Colleague!That is the main content of the reverse charge procedure that the Czech Republic wants to do in a pilot project.We held a hearing and the Czech representative from the Ministry of Finance said very clearly: In the sectors that we have examined so far, this has proven its worth, and fraud has decreased.But there are also technical possibilities that the reporting procedures are reported at the same time in a one-stop-shop procedure, so that you cannot apply for a refund first, then liquidate the company and pay no taxes, thus promoting fraud.There are several things, but that requires a high technical standard on the part of the member states and extremely good cooperation, which has not been possible until now, because national egoism is still taking off when it comes to tax issues.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, the creation of a single VAT area in the EU could support a deeper and fairer single market, boosting jobs, growth, investment and competitiveness. While VAT is one of the major sources of revenue in the EU, we should recognise that the current VAT system is fragmented, complex for the growing number of businesses operating cross-border, and prone to fraud. The VAT system needs to be reformed, and the recommendations in this regard include simplification, in order to become business-friendly; combating the growing risk of fraud; increasing efficiency, in particular exploiting the opportunities of digital technology; integrating the cost of revenue collection; enhancing trust, both between business and tax administrations and among EU Member States’ tax administrations; and improving the quality of Member States’ replies to information request and the reliability of the VAT information exchange system. The Commission and the Member States should strengthen cooperation with non-EU countries and enforce VAT collection. We need to implement necessary reforms in order to combat fraud efficiently, remove administrative barriers and reduce regulatory costs so as to simplify life for European businesses.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Langen, and everybody who has contributed to this very significant report. We are very glad of your valuable guidance for the Commission and I am also glad that we share the same views on many of these issues.  VAT is a big source of revenue for the Member States and that is why, every once in a while, we have to check if everything in this field is fit for purpose because the world around us is changing. There are obviously some shortcomings which we have to address. First, Member States are faced with a massive revenue loss. The VAT gap has been estimated at around EUR 160 billion each year. Cross-border fraud alone accounts for EUR 50 billion each year. Second, complying with VAT rules for cross—border and digital activities is still very cumbersome. Compliance costs need to be reduced. Third, we must adapt the system to technological progress, tax goods and services where they are consumed, and give Member States more flexibility in setting VAT rates.  The Commission, via the Action Plan, sets out immediate and urgent actions to tackle the VAT gap and adapt the VAT system to the digital economy, e—commerce and the needs of small and medium—sized enterprises. It provides a clear orientation towards a robust, definitive VAT system for cross—border supplies and proposes options for modern and flexible rules on VAT rates. Overall this Action Plan sets out progressive steps towards a modernised and rebooted VAT system tailored to the single market. The proposed initiatives are numerous and ambitious, but I believe that they are realistic with their step—by—step approach. I am pleased that the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) welcomes many of these.  The option we put forward for the definitive VAT system based on the – already agreed – destination principle consists in taxing intra—EU supplies in the Member States of destination via an extended one—stop shop. I warmly welcome Parliament’s support in the report adopted by ECON and its strong reference to the principle of the fractionated payments of VAT, which should remain a core element of the definitive VAT system. This would ensure a consistent treatment with domestic supplies and drastically reduce cross—border fraud. It has been estimated that this option would reduce cross—border VAT fraud by 80%. In real terms EUR 40 billion more could be collected per year. Other options, like the generalised reverse charge, which ECON’s report recommends, do not offer the same potential. In fact replacing VAT by a sort of sales tax could significantly increase fraud and administrative burdens for businesses. In our view, this is not the right approach. The time has also come to adapt the VAT rates legislation to the definitive VAT system based on the destination principle, which should allow for creative rates flexibility for Member States. I welcome Parliament’s willingness to provide us with a clear guidance on the options we have set out in the VAT Action Plan. We will give full consideration to this guidance when preparing our legislative proposals next year. By the end of this year the Commission will already address some of your recommendations in a series of ambitious legislative proposals.  As regards SMEs and e-commerce, the Commission’s upcoming proposal will include a threshold and other simplification initiatives targeted at small and micro-businesses, including an extended and enhanced one—stop shop mechanism. This proposal will also address current distortions putting EU businesses at a significance disadvantage compared to non-EU businesses, which can legally supply small consignments VAT-free into the EU annually and frequently omit paying the VAT they should.  As regards rates for e-publication, our upcoming proposal will give Member States the option of aligning the VAT treatment of e—publication, such as books, newspapers and periodicals, with that of printed publication. Taking into account last May’s ECOFIN Council conclusions on the Action Plan, the Commission will pursue its efforts to achieve consensus. We count on Parliament’s active support in this respect.  The Commission is equally determined to take strong actions to speed up the fight against VAT fraud in the EU, an idea dear to this House. As recommended and supported by you, the Commission is working to improve the administrative cooperation between the Member States, in particular by reinforcing Eurofisc, by more efficient and real time sharing of information, and by adding a common risk analysis, as well as by deepening cooperation with other European and national law enforcement authorities. I look looking forward to a good debate and good cooperation when trying to find good and concrete proposals next year.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me say that this is a very important and well prepared initiative. Better, more efficient and fairer taxation is one of our key economic priorities and we are acting accordingly. Collecting taxes better applies not only in relation to large corporations or multinationals but also in any areas where we are losing money. As was said by the Commissioner and the rapporteur, we are losing tens of billions of euros every year in VAT fraud or VAT avoidance, and there is no excuse for us not to act. Unlike in the case of corporate taxation, where Europe cannot resolve all of the issues, these are our own domestic issues. So there is no excuse for not taking decisive steps – and improving the exchange of information among Member States is not a sufficient solution. That is why I believe the Commission proposal is a very good and efficient way to tackle the issue. I consider VAT to be an effective means of collecting tax, and I believe that any move towards a turnover or sales tax, rather than solving problems, would create more problems. That is why I really support the initiative to tackle the challenges of the digital economy and, especially, to improve and amend the cross-border aspect. Once again, I would call on the Commission and the Council to build consensus as soon as possible and to start to act.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - President! As in the case of tax fraud and tax evasion, the creation of a European VAT system free of corruption requires, above all, political will. Only together can the Member States take effective action against VAT fraud and only with the full agreement of the rules needed to break down unnecessary administrative barriers, thus making life easier for European businesses. Because the more complex a system is, the easier it is to circumvent it. It is therefore particularly to be welcomed that the Commission has committed itself to creating an effectively functioning single EU VAT area, all the more so as the current VAT system is not capable of preventing fraud. I would add that in the case of the single EU VAT area, pilot projects - which introduce different logics into the VAT system - are not necessarily sympathetic to us. The Commission estimates that the loss of VAT revenue is around EUR 170 billion a year, of which cross-border fraud alone is at least EUR 50 billion, although I fear that the real figures here are much higher, in some places they say EUR 1 trillion a year, which we lose. , or because of a malfunctioning VAT system. Yes, the Member States must therefore do their utmost to ensure that the exchange of information between them is effective, because without it and without coordination of tax policies between Member States, the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion will never be effective. I also agree that the Commission should closely monitor the functioning of national tax authorities, avoiding unfortunate cases such as the one in Hungary, where the National Tax and Customs Administration was reported by its own staff member, for which larger domestic and multinational companies protected by government circles assisted, but at least looked aside, in fraudulent tax amounts of more than € 3 billion a year. By the way, this is what the Hungarian government is doing This case ended with the lawsuit of a public interest notifier, and we see the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!There are many provisions in the report that deserve support, such as paragraph 32, which calls for products purchased in digital or physical form to be subject to this taxation.Paragraph 65 rightly draws attention to carousel and missing trader fraud.However, I do not think that the so-calledreverse charge - paragraph 37 - will lead to less fraud or an improvement in the situation of SMEs.After all, this is an artificial transfer of responsibility between entities.I cannot vote in favor of a report with provisions aimed at harmonizing tax policy.A healthy competitive environment cannot simply be called barriers.Personally, I am not in favor of including financial services under VAT and the creation of another body, the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as mentioned in paragraph 79.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: for the ALDE Group. - The current VAT system is imperfect and it is therefore appropriate for the Commission to present a proposal for a VAT action plan. Modernization and simplification of the whole system are needed. The current system does not sufficiently prevent fraud and its scale is enormous. As part of the measures against tax fraud, I consider it important and almost necessary to apply the mechanism of transferring the tax liability to the final taxpayer. The wider introduction of the reverse charge mechanism is the third pillar of tax administration reform in my country, the Czech Republic, and completely eliminates so-called carousel VAT fraud. Of course, the EP's draft report also addresses this mechanism and welcomes the pilot project in this area. I would like to call on the Commission to objectively assess its impact on the fight against VAT fraud, and I hope that the Commission's assessment will be based on the creation of a new VAT system in the EU. Not only because the mechanism of transfer of tax liability is tested in practice, unlike other, so far only theoretical concepts. Cooperation within the EU, but also with third countries, is also a prerequisite for a successful fight against fraud. In particular, the rapid and regular exchange of information in the field of the internal market is an effective tool. It is therefore necessary to equip our national authorities so that they can improve tax collection, the scope of controls and mutual communication. Even in view of the numerous revelations linking VAT evasion to organized crime and serious crime, including terrorist financing, modernization of the current system is necessary. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: blue-card question. – In the Czech plan for a pilot for reverse charging, the Czech Government would like to use the reverse charge plan for roughly five years. When you call upon the Commission to consider the results of the pilot project, and only after that to decide on the shape of European reform, does that mean that you are in favour of postponing the proposed reform for many years?

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: blue-card answer. – I would say that the pilot project has two purposes. The first is to tackle the level of crime in this area, which is high in the Czech Republic, and the second is to demonstrate whether this approach can deliver results. I think the Commission does not need five years to evaluate what is going on. There has already been success in some areas in the Czech Republic in this regard, and the enlarged pilot project could be assessed in less than five years, I would say.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, as with corporation tax avoidance, the biggest culprits in VAT fraud are multinationals. Overseas sellers use big names like Amazon to sell VAT-free products in the EU, and multinationals turn a blind eye. This is the cause of the biggest share of the EU’s VAT gap. These companies must take some responsibility for combating such fraud, which drives local businesses to the wall and deprives the public purse of millions in revenue. We need to ensure that decisions about VAT rates and exemptions are in the hands of local, accountable governments. The Irish Government, for example, claims that the EU rules do not allow a lower rate on life-saving defibrillators. VAT, like all indirect taxes, has a regressive effect on distribution, and the poor lose the largest portion of their income. We should ensure that our VAT systems include both luxury rates and reduced rates on essential items.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, for several years now the VAT rules in the EU have been out of touch with small businesses and the way in which citizens make a living. The Commission’s VAT action plan makes important proposals to bridge this divide by introducing a single definitive VAT regime for the EU, and I welcome this. For two years now I have been raising the issue of the difficulties of the VAT mini one-stop-shop, or ‘VAT MOSS’ as it is known, ever since small businesses in South West England began contacting me to say that the changes would put them out of business. I have submitted questions to the Commission, written to UK ministers and Commissioner Ansip, and most recently submitted an amendment to this report, constantly calling for a VAT threshold of EUR 100 000 for start-ups and small businesses. So I am pleased that other MEPs have joined the call, and we can all welcome the Commission’s proposals for this VAT threshold in the final Parliamentary report. We must ensure that the VAT regime works for people, not against them, in our overall goal of tackling tax fraud. Lastly, I am delighted that we also have a reference to the social, environmental and gender dimension of VAT on certain products. We can and should use lower rates and zero rates to encourage renewable energy and the insulation of buildings, and to prevent discrimination against menstruating women. No intervention would be complete without a shout-out to the tireless tampon tax campaigners in the UK and across the continent! The End Tampon Tax campaign in the UK was phenomenal and I encourage all of you here to sign our Written Declaration no 89 to bring the success achieved in the UK to the rest of Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: blue-card question. – Excuse my ignorance, Ms Scott Cato, but I do not quite understand the ‘gender dimension of VAT’. Could you could explain this?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card answer. – I certainly can and thank you for giving me the opportunity. I went on to talk about the tampon tax and the fact that women across Europe are facing additional tax on necessary sanitary products, which obviously men do not have to use. Some countries have reduced the rates, but other countries still charge what are actually luxury rates of VAT on tampons and sanitary towels, and on moon cups as well. So what we are suggesting – and this is where you can sign our written declaration and share it with your friends – is that all countries zero-rate those products which women use.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, by exiting the EU Britain will soon restore full sovereignty over taxation matters. We will be able to abolish VAT and design our own sales tax suited to our own country. That tax could be flexible: if we like, we could charge a higher rate on sectors dominated by imports; we could choose to levy higher rates for luxury goods and lower rates for staple goods, thereby countering objections to the regressive nature of VAT. The great thing is that it will be up to us. Our democracy will be restored, and where issues arise we will be able to address them without needing the European Commission’s say-so. The government of the fifth largest economy in the world will even acquire the power to make its own decisions on the taxation of sanitary products. You lot can work towards a standard VAT regime controlled by Brussels. We will set our own taxes, thank you very much.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Thank you. Milk and honey is the promise ...

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Katainen! Value-added tax is of great importance - and this is why this report too - because it is the most important source of income for the budgets of the Member States and also an important source of income for the European Union. In 2014, EUR 1 000 billion in VAT revenues were earned across the EU, 17.6 billion of which went into the European Union's budget. This makes up a total of 12.2% of the European budget. The tax shortfalls with such a large tax are also gigantic, and the rapporteur has already mentioned the following: the tax shortfall on VAT is higher than the budget of the European Union. The tax shortfall is reflected in the VAT gap, which has accumulated to EUR 170 billion annually, of which EUR 50 billion is due to cross-border fraud. Again, this is primarily carousel fraud, and behind carousel fraud is organized crime. European investigators recently struck a big blow against organized crime. They were able to uncover a carousel fraud system that caused damage of EUR 320 million. The fight against VAT fraud and VAT avoidance, i.e. also closing the VAT gap, must therefore have priority. For this reason, the VAT system needs to be made simpler, less fraudulent and more business friendly. For SMEs in particular, easier handling is necessary without additional administrative effort, and digital technologies will be important, digital processing platforms, so that this VAT can be collected better and more profitably in the future. I thank the rapporteur, who has presented a very balanced and good report. And I hope that this report will help us generate additional revenue for the Member States and for the European Union.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, 1973 will forever stand in the history of Britain as a year of infamy. On 1 January that year, as a consequence of the Prime Minister Ted Heath’s signature, we joined the EU. Later that year, his Chancellor Lord Barber introduced VAT into the UK. The VAT is really an example of everything that is wrong about the European Union. It started at 10% but has grown to 20%. It is swollen in size and complexity. In the UK, it has 3 200 pages of tax legislation, and as the Commissioner said: it cannot cope with innovation or start-ups.130 countries, have adopted it, yes, but one significant country – the United States – has not. It is more innovative and is more flexible, and has an economy greater and better than that of those in the European Union. Just as the British people recognised and reversed a decision of Ted Heath and his huge deceit on sovereignty, on Brexit the UK Government has a huge opportunity to reverse VAT and have a more flexible regime in taxation.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, first of all let me congratulate our rapporteur Mr Langen on an excellent report. In the report, we can read that the current VAT system across the EU is excessively complicated, with a multitude of VAT rates and exemptions that put unnecessary burden on companies involved in cross-border trading. Moreover, this complexity opens up ample possibilities for VAT fraud and VAT avoidance within the single market. According to the Commission’s assessment, in 2014 alone the VAT gap between expected revenue and revenue actually collected was estimated at about EUR 160 billion.  These enormous losses suffered by all Member States call for swift and ambitious action to address VAT fraud. The focus should be on three areas: firstly, we should minimise the amount of goods that benefit from reduced VAT rates across the EU. Secondly, in the longer run, we should aim at gradually harmonising national VAT rates within the single market. Thirdly, the EU should take steps to address tax fraud coming from the so-called carousel schemes.  One way of solving this last problem is to ask banks to separate the VAT obligations from the gross price paid for a given transaction. A payment by a payer for any given invoice should then be immediately split by the bank into VAT tax due that would be transferred to the national tax authority, and the remaining amount would be transferred to the seller’s account.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur. I believe that, in the global strategy which is being put in place in terms of taxation, this action plan of the European Commission to combat fraud in the field of VAT is a welcome element. When we know the figures for this fraud, we see that there is indeed something wrong. This is a subject which obviously concerns the European Union directly since we are discussing a tax which also constitutes one of the rare own resources of its budget. However, out of 1 trillion, the 170 billion in annual fraud, including 50 billion in cross-border transactions, are not acceptable by our fellow citizens or by our States, any more than by the European Union. I think that the avenues proposed by the Commission go in the right direction as regards the delivery of a good between Member States which would become taxable in the State of arrival or the possibility for the purchaser to finalize his VAT with the establishment of mini-counters which, I think, will help improve the system. A debate is open on the advantage granted to the Czech Republic to test in a pilot project the mechanism of self-regulation. Let's be frank, we don't believe it, we don't think it will reduce fraud. We do not think that this is going in the right direction because VAT is a useful tax, an effective tax, and we just have to correct the things that do not allow us to collect this tax in good conditions. But putting in place self-regulation means giving up the VAT mechanism. We therefore prefer proposals which go in the direction of strengthening the action proposed by the European Commission.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - The current VAT system has been in force since 1993 and is designed as a transitional regime.It has been enough time for us to find out that this system allows carousel and other fraud in the tens of billions of euros.You can take a lot of precautions, but the bottom line is that this system allows for carousel fraud.I therefore call on the Commission, as well as the Council, to change the VAT system to a turnover tax system.This means that the individual links in the supply chain will not charge this tax to each other and therefore claim it at the same time, which allows fraud, but only the last link that will already be sold to the final consumer who is not a registered taxpayer,only he would invoice the tax.This is what will really solve these huge problems that we have had with VAT here for 20 years.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: - I would also like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Werner Langen, for his excellent work and that of the fellow shadow rapporteurs, of course. I am very happy with the VAT action plan because in my country, the Netherlands, the problem of VAT carousel fraud keeps popping up. For example, it became known this year that a network of Danish and Spanish jihadists may have earned hundreds of thousands of euros for the international jihad through VAT fraud in the purchase and sale of Gouda cheese and Dutch chicken fillet. And this example shows once again how important it is to tackle VAT fraud at European and international level. But there is another reason why I am very happy with the VAT action plan and this report, because at the top of my wish list has been for a long time that entrepreneurs with, for example, a web shop no longer have to keep 28 different VAT administrations. Let us quickly put an end to the current complicated declaration system that creates high administrative burdens for entrepreneurs. One joint form would help a lot.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, one of the reasons why we have fraud in VAT is because people are required, due to crippling austerity, to go outside the law for basic goods. Essential goods are made more expensive. The Greens representative mentioned tampons and women’s sanitary products. The Economic and Social Research Institute in Ireland found that groups hardest hit by VAT were households in the poorest income decile – households in rural areas, six-person households and those containing a single adult with children.  I hear people say that VAT gives people choice. Where is the choice for low income families? The only people who really have choice with VAT are the rich. It is inequitable, and those who can afford to pay the most should pay the most.  In Ireland, our VAT take is around EUR 10 billion per year. This year alone we are going to burn two billion we already have on promissory note bonds. We get nothing back for it.  We are also going to give away billions to Apple in tax. Fill that hole by taxing what should be taxed and get rid of this inequitable tax – and also stay out of our tax affairs. We are sovereign on that.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, welcome the Commission's efforts to reform VAT. Now we have a certain imperfect and insufficient harmonization, and we have a level of fraud that is more than unbearable: € 160 billion more than justifies the proposed reforms, although their implementation will, of course, have to be closely monitored. Let us be aware of the very high cost of "non-Europe", of not having a complete and armored European system in this matter. When I remember last week's negotiations, the budget conciliation sessions and the endless battle with the Council to achieve an increase in the allocation of items by 50 million, such as Horizon 2020, the truth is that I am filled with a certain sadness that this debate did not does more than confirm. We therefore support the action plan, not so much the reverse charge pilot project proposal, the effects of which should be studied very carefully. On the other hand, the orientation towards reducing costs and bureaucratic burden of small and medium-sized enterprises seems entirely correct to us and we defend the appropriate use of differentiated tax rates to favor and influence sustainable consumption in matters (inaudible) such as those explained by the Mrs. Scott Cato rightly so.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the text and proposal of this VAT reform at European level does not satisfy us and does not satisfy us because it does not propose efficient, sufficient and definitive solutions to this serious problem, as the figures at stake have shown. Four points to improve: abandoning the principle of the country of origin for the country of destination will only facilitate fraud, especially "carousel" fraud, which is the most important one and which takes away more resources from states. As a second point: there is no real information sharing system: transparency is fundamental. For example, there is no single European business register which would help communication to combat these frauds. Three: there is no upper limit on VAT imposed by Member States. We know that too high a level of VAT compresses consumption and God knows how much we need it today in Europe. And the last point is on the reverse charge, which is a mechanism that has proved ineffective in combating fraud and risks favoring new ones, also placing an onerous administrative burden on small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, value added tax (VAT) is an important source of revenue for each Member State and at the same time contributes significantly to the European Union's revenue. This is why the European Union highlights the need to create a common VAT system, under the pretext that goods and services will be taxed in the country where they were provided. This sounds like a good idea. However, the tax system of each country is different and the development of the country's economy is based on it. The leveling integration of all into a common VAT tax system will therefore create economic upheaval and loss of revenue. The real purpose of this proposal is to deprive states of the ability to manage their economies and meet their needs and aspirations and to delegate this right to the European Union. The consequences of this policy have been seen in Greece, where the troika has destroyed the country's economy and has imposed a value added tax of 24% which is borne by the final consumer ... (The President cut off the rapporteur)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! In 1993 the first transitional arrangement was created. It has been 23 years since then, and the world has changed a lot: Online trading has become indispensable, cross-border services are part of everyday life. The problem, however, is that it has increased VAT fraud and distorted competition between Member States. We therefore have to discuss many and broad solutions. The Commission has proposed the reverse charge, a system that will now tax goods and services in the country of destination. Since VAT is a consumer tax, it would make sense for it to be collected in the consumer's country and not in the entrepreneur's country. We have therefore also developed an alternative model in Austria. An alternative to the reverse charge system would be a Europe-wide IT platform, on which the seller must register in the customer's country. The monthly sales tax is automatically determined there, and the data is immediately forwarded to the authorities and shared across Europe. I would ask you to consider this approach as well - it has positive sides. Because we need a competition of ideas, because only the variety of possible solutions can fight tax fraud and demonstrate and strengthen Europe's ability to act.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Mr President, I would like first to commend the rapporteur, Mr Langen, for his work on this file, as well as the Commission for its continuing endeavours to clamp down on VAT fraud. Any new VAT system must of course promote economic growth in a sustainable way, while protecting public policy objectives. In that regard, I would like to underline the need for the European Commission to speedily make clear when and how it will honour its pledge to introduce a VAT threshold for small businesses engaged in cross-border trade of e-services.  Many British firms have had a very difficult time adjusting to the new VAT system, with little help from the current British Government. I hope that the Commission at least can help them by stating exactly when, and at what level, the threshold will be reintroduced. I would also like to underline the need for the Commission and Member States to work to exempt essential products from VAT, not least sanitary products. VAT is a regressive tax, when applied to sanitary products like tampons and towels, it becomes a sexist tax too.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Taking the floor in this discussion, I would like to emphasize that in my country, Poland, the size of the so-called the VAT tax gap in recent years reached 30% of revenues, so it was clearly higher than the EU average. Therefore, the new Polish government has been taking steps since the beginning of this year, changing the law, reforming the tax services, which has already brought good results, and VAT revenues are nearly 10% higher than in the same period last year. Changes in the law not related to VAT include restrictions in the quarterly tax settlement system, extensions of the reverse VAT system, restrictions in the registration of the so-called "Poles" used to defraud VAT, increasing the size of financial and criminal sanctions for VAT fraud, and finally introducing a central register of receipts and a central register of invoices. Therefore, it seems to me that the proposals prepared by the Commission, aimed at limiting VAT fraud, should only concern intra-Community trade, while in the remaining scope this decision should be left to individual Member States.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: - Mr Chairman! Thank you very much to my colleague Werner Langen for this initiative and for this document that we are talking about now. Indeed, these 28 different VAT orders are one of the main barriers in our single European market. It is also one of the reasons for geo-blocking - it is mentioned very often. 28 different legal orders - too many of these regulations, often very complicated. Therefore, entrepreneurs who are afraid of complications with VAT in different countries, complicated procedures and procedures that they do not know, often limit their activities to those countries where VAT understands where they are dealing with VAT without hiring additional people, without the extra hassle. This is especially true for small entrepreneurs. They limit their development and their earnings, and therefore the consumer has less access to products and services from all over our wonderful common market. As a result, we also have less competition on our European market. We have been talking about this for a long time, I expect from the European Commission, Commissioner, a bold, bold proposal on VAT matters and I am calling you to harmonize at least VAT procedures on our common European market.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, this is a particularly important report which the Commission should make its honey on one of the essential fiscal resources of States. For my part, I would like to speak on two subjects. The first concerns public services, which should benefit from reduced rate VAT when they deal with social, health, environmental, nutritional and cultural aspects in order to preserve the essential values ​​of the Union. Social services of general interest, for example, should benefit from an exemption. The second subject concerns territories, and in particular isolated rural territories in which certain economic activities play an important social role. This is the case, for example, of the equine sector, which is characterized by a multiple vocation implantation encompassing sport, nature and horse riding, as well as tourism, horse therapy, etc. Farms are generally quite fragile and their economic balance undoubtedly depends on the VAT rates. This is the reason why excessive VAT would jeopardize these operations and set up a gray economy which would run counter to fair and transparent taxation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, like other colleagues of mine, I obviously welcome the Commission's decision to put in place an action plan on VAT. I think it is really necessary to have a reform which will establish a single community space in the field of VAT. We know that VAT in Europe is something important. In 2014, it represented EUR 1 trillion in revenue, or around 7% of the Union's GDP and, above all, it is part of the Union's own resources which allow us to finance a whole series of projects. interesting for our fellow citizens, whether it is the youth guarantee, cultural programs, aid to the most disadvantaged or even aid to the licensees of multinationals. But, as we all know, there is still too much fraud. So I think this text will really help us improve the VAT collection system, eliminate VAT fraud and cut red tape. I think this last point is important, because it will simplify the business operations of SMEs and, more importantly, it will underline the need for harmonization at EU level in tax policy. We have also appealed to the Member States since - as we all know - it is a national policy, but it is good to converge towards an equivalent rate of VAT in the various Member States if we want to find a solution to this problem. We also ask for a regular review of the annex to the "VAT" directive containing the list of goods and services reduced in VAT, because I would like to remind you that VAT is still an unfair tax which affects everyone in the same way. categories of the population. It therefore seems essential to me to support the reintroduction of a higher VAT rate, in particular for all luxury products, but also - as my colleague has just said. Denanot - to exempt social services of general interest from the law of the market and, as regards the application of VAT, to maintain the exceptions enjoyed by public services.Finally, Commissioner - and for me this is the most essential request made to the Commission - the impact of the lack of harmonization of tax rates at European Union level must be assessed.I think this is what will really convince the Member States, given cross-border fraud.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Monsieur le Président, dernièrement, tout le monde semble avoir parlé en français mais, malheureusement, je vais faire mon intervention en anglais. VAT is a major and growing source of tax revenue in the European Union. However, the current VAT system is too vulnerable to fraud and too bothersome and complex for businesses that wish to expand beyond a Member State in which they are established. Therefore, I would like to welcome the outcome of the report, which puts forward proposals to improve the VAT collection system, eradicate VAT fraud and reduce red tape, highlighting the need to reform the system with the aim of achieving a single EU VAT area and thus helping to promote employment, growth, investment and competitiveness. However, there is one aspect that I would like to underline: we need to assess carefully the consequences of the reverse charge mechanism and to examine whether this procedure would simplify the situation for small and medium-sized enterprises and reduce VAT fraud, because it might, in practice, create more loopholes and increase the VAT collection loss that it is intended to address.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!On this occasion, I would like to stand up for culture, for such regulations and practices in the field of VAT that cover broadly understood culture, creative industries, and the creators themselves.It is when it comes to VAT that very often conservation services were treated very differently.It is in the area of culture that audiobooks had reduced VAT, while e-books - not.In practice, many such elements unfortunately touched the area of culture and the artists themselves.At the same time, I would like to thank the rapporteur very much.This is the right step in the right direction, but what I miss in the final, in this long term, is the culture itself.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that I have spoken on the issues of tax avoidance and evasion, the tax ruling and the vulnerability to fraud of the VAT system. I reiterate the harmful effects of these systems which are reflected on the competition regime, causing distortions; on the budgetary revenues of the Member States, subtracting large revenues to the detriment of public finances; on small and medium-sized enterprises, creating a distorted tax environment. In fact, the lack of VAT tax harmonization represents the financial lifeblood of criminal activities, which exploit the legislative and information differences between the various Member States with the implementation of "carousel" frauds, which generate up to 53 billion euros lost VAT revenue every year. This phenomenon undermines citizens' trust and takes away the functioning of the digital single market and its harmonization with the capital market. He responds to these requests in the report to which I join, aware of the need for improvement of the current VAT system as announced by the Commission on 7 April.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr Katainen, firstly, according to the Greek budget for 2017, Greek citizens will be required to pay EUR 20.3 billion in direct taxes and EUR 26.2 billion in indirect taxes. Most of this money will go to VAT. Secondly, there was an increase in VAT from 23 to 24% in the Aegean islands. This means that all the Aegean islands have been dismantled. There can be no efficient economic operation, especially at a time when the Aegean islands are full of refugees. Thirdly, increased VAT means that companies leave Greece and go to Bulgaria and Cyprus. But mainly it means that the impoverished Greek people now pay dearly for food, pay dearly for electric heating, pay dearly for heating oil. It is not possible for this situation to continue. Therefore, zero VAT is required on the basic foodstuffs of the Greek people who have become impoverished and who are suffering from huge unemployment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Cross-border VAT fraud costs Member States millions of euros a year.The types of VAT fraud are, of course, very diverse and change and adapt very quickly, including to legislation.Therefore, the Commission must take care in its measures to be, of course, as effective as possible to anticipate all possible future forms of tax fraud, as far as possible, and thus limit the most well-known forms of carousels, which are widespread in the electrical industry., mobile telephony, textiles, goods, which therefore travels within the European Union and generates millions and millions of tax fraud.Therefore, of course, a certain unification of VAT in the area of the European Union is to be welcomed, and of course we also call for greater transparency as well as appropriate sanctions.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank Mr Langen for his efforts on the report. Obviously, we have a system that is not working the way we wanted it to work right now. And frankly, it can't be otherwise, since we introduced this methodology forty years ago. It cannot be adequate today. In this line of thought, I welcome the Commission's efforts and its ambitious plan to tackle VAT fraud, as there are unscrupulous traders who generate billions in damage. In my opinion, there are several steps we need to follow for a lasting solution to this problem. The first is a comprehensive, complete, unified European Union VAT system - payment and refund. This would make it much easier for companies that are bona fide and prevent fraud. Second, we certainly need to ease the administrative burden and procedures for startups. We cannot expect companies with three staff to cope like large international companies. Finally, national services must communicate openly and fully.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, reforming the European VAT system is now indispensable. The current system, obsolete, has in fact proved vulnerable to fraud and a source of distortion of competition to the detriment of small and medium-sized enterprises. For example, VAT fraud, carried out by criminal groups alone, according to the latest estimates, cost at EU level between 40 and 60 million euros every year. Several investigations conducted by Europol have in fact shown that criminal groups also finance themselves through large-scale cross-border VAT fraud, the so-called "carousel" fraud, also taking advantage of the legislative gaps between Member States. To eradicate this phenomenon, it is essential to strengthen administrative cooperation between states in order to remove legal obstacles that prevent the exchange of information between administrative and judicial authorities. I therefore thank the rapporteur for his work on the text proposing a reform of VAT, which I agree with.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, congratulations to my colleague Langen on an excellent report.As we have all pointed out, the existing VAT system is complicated, there is a large administration on entrepreneurs and tax administrations and it leaves a lot of room for tax fraud.That is why, of course, I support this report and the proposals made to simplify the VAT system, but what I would like to point out is that neither VAT reform nor any other can be successful without the unity of all Member States and, of course,an important role that the Commission must play in harmonizing the whole system.Let's take the first step, and that is to start working together, exchanging information and thus prevent fraud and protect honest entrepreneurs and citizens while, of course, we work in parallel on changes and the adoption of a new system.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I support the report and consider it important, especially from two perspectives: the issue of fraud and the issue of SMEs. I'm not going to talk about fraud anymore, because a lot has been said. However, I would like to highlight the problems that SMEs have from several points of view. Of course, fraud puts a lot of pressure even on SMEs, but the existing system, set up in 1993, is complex. SMEs, when they want to work cross-border, face different statements and have a major burden. The Commission needs to think of a single form of declaration. We need a new, simplified system for SMEs that they can easily apply. Commissioner, I am glad that you have a program and you want a VAT exemption threshold for SMEs. But have you thought about the pressure and cost of an SME when it comes to technology and equipment? Have you thought about changing anything here? Because an SME can recover its VAT on the facilities it imports or buys in years, perhaps due to the low turnover. So maybe here you think of something to differentiate the import by technology.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would also like to thank Mr Langen, because if a report is presented in the area of taxation that is so praised across the political spectrum, then I think it really deserves recognition and thanks.The complexity of the system, the leaks that arise within the system due to fraud - I agree with everything that my colleagues have said.I come from the Czech Republic and it has been mentioned many times here.Our movement is in opposition at national level, at European level I feel part of a coalition.For this reason, I would also like to give the Ministry of Finance of the Czech Republic a chance to show what it can do to actually submit a pilot project and process it in such a way that it does not further complicate the problem and unnecessarily delay the European level.I firmly believe that the Ministry of Finance will succeed, if it does not happen, it is his disgrace.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I want to congratulate my colleague Mr Langen on his report. I think it is an important marker to the Commission to bring forward new proposals and I also think it is important that we have a VAT collection system that is fit for purpose. This is supposed to be a single market: why these distortions can be allowed to occur is a fundamental issue. Also, in the digital world, we know it is difficult to make sure we can track down these payments. So we need a system that is fit for purpose. We also need a collection system that actually brings in the money. There is very little point in having VAT rates unless we have a technologically sound collection system that can bring the money in, to close the deficits in all our Member States. Lastly, it is important that the reverse charging mechanism is included in the report. This does point to new ways of doing business. If we can learn from that as a pilot project, we should do so, because ultimately this is about closing the gap – making sure that the EUR 50 billion that is out there, cross-border, is brought home to Member States so that we can close deficits.

name: Brian HAYES
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for their mostly positive ideas about how to further improve the VAT system. Mr Langen has obviously done a valuable job and all the thanks to him are well deserved. Tax fraud is a cancer in our society. It is bad for entrepreneurs, it is bad for consumers and it is bad for our societies. That is why there are good reasons to reform the VAT system in order for it to be more watertight than it is at the moment.  I will make a couple of personal and rather political observations. These are not necessarily the political views of the Commission. As a former finance minister, I like VAT a lot. It is a money machine but it must be a fair money machine. If it functions well, you do not need to worry about revenues. They just come. It is basically a very simple tax and, if we manage to address the fraud opportunities, it is one of the best taxes we can have. But I also want to say that I do not see the VAT system as a perfect tool for taking care of social policy goals because it is much better to collect returns by VAT but then use direct subsidies to help those who need our joint help and common effort. So VAT is a good money machine but not ideal for addressing social issues. That is why direct subsidies are more efficient in this respect.  Also, the fewer reduced rates there are, the more efficient the VAT system is. I know that there are always good reasons to use reduced rates for good purposes but, at the same time, it is not good for the efficiency of the system as such. So that is why I, personally, am not a big fan of a large amount of reduced rates because it would be better to keep a general rate at as low a level as possible and at the same time not to use too many reduced rates.  But, as I said, these couple of observations were more my own opinions and contributions to this good discussion which we have witnessed today.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I would like to follow up on what Vice-President Katainen said. Of course, in our application we also have the socio-political, environmental and other functions that are possible. But you are right: in its report, the Court of Auditors found that only a limited number of socio-political, low taxes can actually be justified - especially for food and basic needs. So that's where we'll have to argue. But I would like to thank everyone for their positive contributions, for the undeserved praise - because everyone contributed. I believe that if we levy VAT based on the country of destination principle, then it will be up to the Member States to be better able to close the tax gap. Because then it is up to you whether that is the case. At a meeting in Athens this spring, the Greek finance minister said: Since the introduction of automatic cash registers in retail stores in Greece, revenues have increased by 18%. That means there are also technical devices that the Member States can use themselves. The country of destination principle is such. All arguments have been exchanged, especially the question that small and medium-sized enterprises are most likely to suffer from the high level of bureaucracy that the input tax procedure - the deduction procedure - entails. We agree to fight the fraud. I would like to make another point that the two British colleagues, who are no longer present, said: the VAT should be a sign of what is going wrong in Europe; he said the rate would be increased from 10 to 20%. The tax rate is still the independent responsibility of the member states. So this is the wrong track. The other statement that Brexit offers the British the opportunity to finally introduce their tampon tax is the highest Nonsense.Because so far there are over 500 exceptions that the member states have defended.If the British government has not been able to do this in the past, then it should be responsible and it should not be blamed on Europe.Thank you very much again.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 November 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Julia PITERA
text: in writing. - In 2014, revenues from VAT amounted to nearly EUR 1 trillion. Unfortunately, the current VAT system, especially in cross-border transactions, is prone to fraud and error. Moreover, the effectiveness of counteracting fraudulent activity varies greatly between Member States. Europol has estimated that the activities of organized crime lead to revenue losses of approximately EUR 50 billion per year in the Member States. The scale of this phenomenon is extremely difficult to estimate, as only two Member States collect statistics in this area. In the process of combating VAT fraud, it is extremely important to simplify the system, also through the use of modern technology. One should also strive to minimize both financial and administrative burdens for entrepreneurs. Increasing the effectiveness of counteracting VAT fraud will be facilitated by the cooperation of Member States towards an agreement on the final VAT system. Effectiveness will also be achieved through the coordination of tax policy and the exchange of information in this regard between the Member States, as well as the tax authorities of the Member States. It is also worth striving to ensure that the exchange of information also covers the judiciary and law enforcement agencies. The Commission's announcement that by 2017 it will propose a VAT system to be simpler and more efficient is to be welcomed.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - VAT is a tremendously regressive tax that requires a greater effort by people with fewer resources. Increasing the tax burden based on VAT is a profound social injustice. The tax collection should come mainly from direct and progressive taxes that weigh more on people with higher incomes. In this regard, the European Union must not put pressure on States to increase VAT rates, within the necessary commitments to meet the deficit objective. We also believe that the simplification of the current complex system cannot be used to restrict the number of goods and services to which reduced or super-reduced VAT rates can be applied. Once again, it has a serious impact on people with lower incomes, who would bear on basic goods and services, in the case of the Spanish State, a 21% VAT compared to the 4% or 10% today. It also affects products of a reduced type by their social component. On the other hand, we express our rejection that VAT rates are the same across the European Union, as purchasing power is not the same in all states.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: signed up.- The current European VAT system was introduced 23 years ago as "temporary".This system has encouraged tax fraud in the case of trade between Member States in the single market.Finally, the European Commission has acknowledged that the transition to a VAT-based VAT system in the country of origin is not possible.That is why the European Commission is proposing to keep the VAT-based VAT system in the countries of destination of the exported products and services.This is the right solution.However, we need to find the best solutions to stop tax fraud in the case of VAT, respectively for importers to declare, on their own initiative, the obligations to pay VAT for imported products and services.Unfortunately, the European Commission's proposals in this direction are still unconvincing.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Brian Hayes, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision (recast) (COM(2014) 0167 - C7-0112 / 2014 - 2014/0091 (COD)) (A8-0011 / 2016).

name: Brian HAYES
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am glad we are having this debate on this important piece of legislation here in plenary this evening. It is the outcome of an important and positive negotiation, for which I want to thank everyone in this Chamber. In June of this year, we reached agreement with the Dutch Council Presidency: I believe this is a good outcome for European pensioners, and we have brought more protection, more transparency and more security to the way that occupational funds are managed across Europe. I believe we have achieved the right balance between respecting differences between Member States’ individual pension schemes and encouraging pension mobility within the European Union. Although this is a minimum harmonisation directive, it is also an extremely sensitive piece of legislation in that we are dealing with other people’s money here. We are dealing with people who have saved money, who have put that money aside, and we must always respect that. This has been a guiding principle that I had in the course of the negotiations. I want to highlight the excellent working partnership in Parliament’s negotiating team, and that applies to all my colleagues and all the political Groups. I was proud of the fact that we received a very broad majority in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. I want to thank my colleagues, here this evening, who worked with me as their rapporteur and I also want to thank the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality for their work in terms of the opinions they gave on the proposal. I especially want to thank the secretariat of the Economic and Affairs Committee for the excellent work they did and the expertise they brought to this issue. Ultimately, I believe Parliament’s position was upheld very strongly in the negotiations, and I want to highlight some of our achievements. On funding provisions, we managed to ensure that under-funding can occur when doing cross-border business. Currently under-funding is not permitted for cross-border activity, and this has caused a great deal of uncertainty for cross-border pension business. We brought clarity to this area, and we have ensured that appropriate action should be taken by regulators to correct the situation. On cross-border transfers we have ensured that when a pension scheme is being transferred to another Member State there is just one single authorisation from the regulator of the host Member State along with prior consent from the home Member State regulator. Both regulators must assess a limited list of criteria when approving transfers. The transfer must also be approved by members and beneficiaries of the scheme – a crucial issue. These procedures have never been set out before in EU legislation, so we have made advances here. On the pension benefit statement, this annual statement to members and beneficiaries on their pension rights has been turned from a very prescriptive and fully harmonised statement into a principles-based approach, and therefore we have more flexibility in terms of using Parliament’s proposed structure. We have also ensured that members and beneficiaries receive, at the very least, the key information on their contributions, the costs, the guarantees and the projections within their scheme. We have ensured that the depository function remains as a Member State option, so as to take into account the variety of pension systems and the way in which depository activities can be conducted. On environmental, social and government (ESG) risks for occupational pension funds: under this directive, we now have to assess these risks when making investment decisions. This idea follows the work of the United Nations. This is the first financial services directive in which such a requirement has been incorporated. It was a crucial issue for many members of Parliament’s negotiating team, and we have achieved that. On intergenerational balance, it has been recognised in the text that there should be intergenerational solidarity between younger and older members of a pension scheme, so that younger generations should not be disproportionately burdened if there are losses in the scheme. I am optimistic that this directive can pave the way for a stronger internal market for pensions across the European Union, but I also feel that it can kick-start a real debate on pensions in the EU – a debate that is much needed here. Lastly, can I make this remark: I hope that we will recast the debate on pensions, which is necessary in a situation where so many people who are currently working across the 28 EU Member States lack pension cover for the future. That is an issue that we need to address in a creative and constructive way.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Sometimes there has to be a trade-off between keeping strictly to the time and communicating practically. This time I chose communication.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I shall try not to take more than the three minutes that have been allocated to me.  I welcome the importance that this Parliament attaches to the revision of the Institutions for Occupational Retirement Provision Directive (IORPs). Your agreement will be an important step towards modernising the EU framework for occupational pension funds.  The Directive accommodates diversity in the EU pensions landscape with principles-based rules under a minimum harmonisation approach, which gives Member States maximum flexibility in implementation in national systems. The IORP2 directive brings improvements to governance provisions on cross-border activities and transfers, provisions on transparency to members, an increased freedom of investment of IORPs over the long term contributing to these EMU objectives.  Let me briefly present these improvements. The financial crisis has reinforced the need for sound governance of financial institutions and clear information to members and beneficiaries. Failure of governance of certain funds in the EU meant in some cases a cut in members’ and beneficiaries’ rights. In the new IORP2 directive, occupational pension funds and their members and beneficiaries will benefit from pension funds governed by experienced persons who carry out their duties in an objective, fair and independent way. The directive will make it easier for pension funds to conduct cross-border business, creating new opportunities for companies and their workforce. By making use of these possibilities, innovative companies ranging from SMEs to multinationals will be able to reduce costs through economies of scale, risk diversifications and innovations. The directive will improve the information provided to individuals about their pension savings. As a result, individuals will know more about their pensions. They will receive updates about their pensions regularly and will be able to make more informed choices about where they put their money. The directive will ensure that clear information is provided to pension scheme members and beneficiaries. The directive will stimulate the capacity of IORPs to invest in financial assets with a long-term economic profile and thereby support the financing of growth in the real economy.  The new rules will also make it easier for pension funds to invest in long-term assets, strengthening the role they can play in the capital markets union. Finally, the new directive will also encourage responsible investments. As a result of the agreement, pension funds will have to consider the risk of environmental, social and governance risks in their investment decisions and documents. This entails a three-yearly statement of investment policy principles. I would like to thank this House once again and look forward to a productive debate.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - First of all, thanks to Brian Hayes for the pleasant cooperation between our committees on this file and congratulations for the result achieved. Three points were leading in our committee's deliberation on this subject. First of all, pension funds serve a social purpose and should be treated as such. Number two, European uniformity in pensions is not going to work. The differences between the member states are too great for that and the pension landscape in Europe is too different. Three, we from Europe must ensure that we encourage those countries where IORPs do not yet exist to develop such systems and not the opposite. All these three points have been included in this directive thanks to the good work of the Council and Parliament. We have struck a good balance between the need to have good European standards in governance, supervision and transparency, while at the same time ensuring that Member States have the flexibility to adapt these standards to their own specific context.
