And that is a result that should not be underestimated, especially given the original proposal.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, for active and healthy ageing, it is necessary to have sustainable levels of pensions. This is not always the case in Europe, and we have new threats like the economic landscape, carbon bubbles, resource efficiency and other factors. This is a crucial issue where I see that we have taken the first step to ensuring and guaranteeing adequate pensions for all Europeans. In the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) we duly hope that the Commission will soon be ready to take the next steps which are needed. This means taking into account the different earning patterns of women and men. If a woman’s salary is roughly 70% to 80% of a man’s, the woman’s pension euro is worth only about 60 cents because salaries are lower and working periods are shorter. If we do not compensate this in our pension calculation structures, this is going to be an unsustainable risk in the future.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! We all know that pension systems in Europe are being tested. The greatest challenges arise from the demographic development in Europe. Of course, major challenges also arise from the limited public funds available to the member states. In addition, there are challenges from the ongoing phase of low interest rates, which make savings for the future even more difficult. We have to face these challenges. Because one thing is clear: The state pension system needs an effective supplement, both by strengthening company and private pension schemes. Here the European Union can deliver, and it has delivered. Our group welcomes the revision of the Directive on Occupational Pensions, which has been negotiated under the auspices of our EPP rapporteur, Brian Hayes. The directive affirms that the opportunities for occupational pension provision in the Member States must be more strongly promoted and better secured. To achieve this, the specifics of the different types of occupational pension schemes must be recognized. We succeeded. The institutions for company pension schemes have special, effective security mechanisms. They are closely linked to employers. This is a fact that must also affect the assessment of risks in the facilities. The legislators have opted for comprehensive risk protection, but deliberately against the introduction of a solvency balance sheet. It was important to us that the company pension scheme be strengthened across the board. Small and medium-sized institutions should have the chance to continue to offer their services despite the demanding Europe-wide rules. Company pension schemes will benefit from the new directive. From the new directive will benefit retirees who will in future receive better, uniform and regular information on their entitlements.In the end, it is a very good result for European financial market and social policy.

name: Paul TANG
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - A warm welcome to the readers and viewers of Geen Stijl. Europe and pensions. Yes, you are shocked, I know, but count to ten, keep breathing, not foam mouth. That is always possible. The Netherlands, Belgium, Sweden, France, Germany: different countries with different pension systems and it will remain so. The European directive sets minimum conditions that the Netherlands amply satisfies in most cases and in some cases not. In this way, participants receive a better explanation of the consequences of the investment policy by their pension fund for the environment and society. For example, participants receive better protection if their pension fund wants to move to another country, a triple lock. More information and better protection. That is the result and that result also convinces the CDA group in the European Parliament, but not their party colleague Pieter Omzigt, who was unable to count to 10. So better information, better protection, while you thought we only think about our own pension.

name: Ashley FOX
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my Group welcomes the text agreed with the Council in trialogue. The UK has already introduced automatic enrolment schemes, so all employees enjoy workplace pensions with contributions from their employers. I therefore hope that this legislation will encourage the provision of work- based pensions across the whole of the EU.  This report makes substantial improvements to the Commission’s original proposal. It is a less prescriptive text that recognises pensions as a Member State competence, focuses more on the provisions for cross-border IORPs, and deletes the delegated acts originally proposed by the Commission. Employees will now receive a tailored annual pension benefit statement and will be consulted if there are decisions which affect their pension payouts. I am happy that there are no harmonised EU solvency requirements. I support the more lenient funding regime, which was included, rather than the fully funded model. Allowing for periods of under-funding is important to reflect instances such as mergers, which would prevent funds from being fully funded at all times.  I am pleased the legislation is now more proportionate and that IORPs with less than 100 members will have reduced compliance commitments. Finally, my group is happy to see that if a Member State has equivalent protection in place then the requirement to appoint a depository for defined contribution schemes would not be necessary. We are pleased with this report and we thank Mr Hayes for his excellent work.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - (NL) Mr President, it is a kind of Dutch party here tonight. And you can see that in the large number of Dutch speakers. In the Netherlands, when the P-word is retired, everyone is actually immediately upright and then people look with suspicion at “What does Brussels have to do with this? What are they going to do in Europe with our pensions? ”. I am pleased with this final result, for which I would also like to compliment the rapporteur Brian Hayes and all the other negotiators who have also been active in the trilogues. Because I think we can be very satisfied with this. It is a proposal aimed at minimum harmonization, especially in the areas of governance and transparency. And this means that there is sufficient freedom for all member states to pursue their own policy, for example in the field of protection of members and pensioners. Because it is of course - as the rapporteur has already said - a sensitive subject, as it is about other people's money, for which other people have themselves saved up. So we have to handle it very carefully. No new powers have been delegated to the Commission or to the European pension regulator EIOPA and the national pension funds will continue to be subject to national supervision, in the Netherlands from the Dutch Central Bank. And also, the information and governance requirements are no longer as detailed as in the first proposal. Because of course it is important that participants and pensioners are properly informed about their rights and obligations, but they can of course decide very well for themselves which color paper, ink and font should be used. A focus on the principles instead of the finicky rules. So no over-the-top patronizing, fortunately that has been removed. And finally, Mr President, I also think it is important that sufficient attention is paid to the sharing of benefits and risks between generations and this is of course very important to keep the pension system affordable in the future.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we have raised from the beginning, faced with a highly internationalized labor market, with great mobility of workers within Europe and also outside it, we share the objective of guaranteeing social rights, ensuring their mobility for workers. workers on the move. It also seems good to us to improve transparency and provide clear information to workers so that they know their rights and can defend them. However, we are concerned that the second pillar of pensions is promoted as the desirable model of the pension system, because we are committed precisely to a 100% public system, where the life pension is the norm and where the casino is not played with the savings from the people. Therefore, we are concerned that this will be used as an opportunity to fuel speculative and dangerous investments. We fear that the logic of the recast is to favor the mobilization of capital for large infrastructures, in the same spirit as the Juncker plan. We also regret that the rapporteur has refused to require solvency guarantees for this type of fund. We do not understand that they want to reduce the demands precisely on something as vital as pensions. We also regret that pension funds can serve to commercialize public services and common goods. In this sense, we are concerned about the emphasis placed on investment in large infrastructures, which often contribute to the privatization of public matters, such as ports or other energy structures. Ladies and gentlemen, pensions are a right, not something to speculate on. We cannot play the casino with the rights of the people.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr. President, indeed I am another Dutchman speaking on pensions. This is unavoidable on this topic because indeed in the Netherlands as soon as you talk about pensions and Europe, it is great fun, and that is even an understatement. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Brian Hayes – by the way, in Ireland it is also good fun on pensions and Europe – for his very good work. Maybe from the starting position we had slightly different views on this file. For Brian, it was also very important to stimulate the cross-border activity of pension funds, whereas for me, the protection of the people back home to ensure that their pension funds could not just go under and leave them unprotected was very important, as was ensuring that national banks keep their supervision and their control.  We secured that very well, and the compromise that we struck is a very good way of dealing with cross-border pension funds. This is indeed crucial. Why is Europe addressing this issue? It is because we are talking about huge investments with huge consequences that people are relying on, and you want to make sure that people can rely on them in the longer term too. We are especially happy that, under the Green initiative, pension funds are now obliged to report on their investments and future carbon stocks so that in the longer term the carbon bubble is being taken care of for the pension funds’ longer-term investments. That is a very important Green success which we have happily achieved under the leadership of Brian Hayes. Thank you for that once again, and also thanks to all the Dutch shadows who joined in the negotiations.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The better you work now, the better you will feel when you are my age. Please remember that!

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Mr President, developments in pensions, together with the Union Green Paper and government legislation, show that the occupational funds, which you are strengthening in every way, tax breaks for employers and so on, are a method of demolishing social security. the member states. The precondition is the substantial abolition of the auxiliary insurance, the restriction of the main one to the level of a poor house, as is the case in Greece with the third left memorandum of the SYRIZA-ANEL government. It is a form of compensatory private insurance that, if you have the financial means, you participate - of course, millions of unemployed, unpaid, low paid, flexible employees are excluded - without ever knowing if and how much you will get. The reserves are being played by the crows of the private insurance in the stock markets, strengthening the companies, while many billions have been lost everywhere or pensions are being cut like in Greece. The insurance policy does not close, as the Greek government and others claim, of course, as long as the employer and the state seek new exemptions for the sake of capitalist competitiveness. There is a way for employees: organizing and fighting for exclusively public, universal insurance based on their modern needs.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur and to those who worked directly on this report. I believe that, first of all, we must recognize that pension systems based on the 'pay as you go' principle, ie intergenerational transfer, are obsolete given that we are witnessing an aging trend across Europe and, obviously, as labor force increases. That is why we need to encourage pension systems in which each individual contributes to his or her pension fund throughout his or her active life. And occupational pension schemes fall into this category. That is why I congratulate the European Commission and support the Commission's proposals, as well as the proposals in this report. However, I would like to point out that in some Member States, when occupational pension schemes are in sectors financed from the public budget, we must avoid excessive contributions from public budgets to these schemes, as they mean nothing more than inter-generational tax transfers. paid.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, Europe’s population is aging. Today we have four people of working age for everyone over 65, but by 2060 this ratio will be halved. This means that the pension system we have today will become untenable. This is a critical piece of legislation and my congratulations to the rapporteur Brian Hayes and to the shadow rapporteurs for ensuring that the pension system is simplified while retaining essential information, for boosting cross-border schemes, and for introducing new rules on greater transparency on remuneration policy for the managers of pension funds.  High standards on governance of pension funds are essential if we are to tackle scandals like the BHS one in the UK. Pension schemes have to be well run by managers who are fit and proper, to ensure that ordinary members get vital information about how their money is being spent and what they can hope to receive once they retire.  Let us not forget that pension funds are key players in making the capital markets union a reality. Therefore, it is really important that they take more environmental, social and corporate governance criteria into account when investing, but at the same time, if we want these funds to ensure they have a good return for future pensioners, it is important they improve the diversity of their portfolios, not just concentrating on investing in OECD countries with low economic growth.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Mr President, in the European Union, by 2060, the degree of social dependence on the working age population will exceed 140%, which requires, as I have been reinforcing in my reports on the European Semester, that we carry out socially responsible reforms in pension schemes to ensure that my generation will be entitled to decent pensions. It is economically unfeasible for us to continue to burden public pension systems - dependent exclusively on solidarity between generations, threatened by the worrying levels of youth unemployment that we have been witnessing - just as it is economically unfeasible to continue to ignore the results of the changes demographic factors, namely the increase in the average life expectancy of Europeans and the reduction in birth rates, as well as the late start of work. Public pension systems must continue to ensure dignity in old age, remaining the pillars of a European social model. But it makes more and more sense today to promote and reinforce complementary pension plans, associated with employment contracts, which allow workers, voluntarily, to guarantee a stable financial situation for their future. Member States must be able to ensure mechanisms for the supervision of these occupational pension plans, ensuring that they are a credible and safe complement for our citizens, as well as striving for their transparency, allowing our fellow citizens to know the respective conditions and that so they can make decisions about their future in conscience.

name: Thomas MANN
text: -  Mister President! After many Dutch, now another German. I would like to thank Brian Hayes for his excellent work and the tough negotiations in the trialogue. May it be possible that tomorrow's vote sends a clear signal for the continuation of the company pension scheme. We say yes to a minimum of European harmonization. We insist, however, that the Member States, due to their very different agreements and implementations, can independently take further action. This includes increased protection for the beneficiaries. Demographic development should also be taken into account and a balance between the generations should be ensured. Company pensions are pension schemes that serve social purposes. They are not a financial service. The application of Solvency II would have endangered its continued existence, high additional costs and great bureaucratic effort would have been the consequences. In Germany we have 20 million employees who are entitled to company pensions. The funds to cover this amount to more than EUR 550 billion. I am very pleased that the content of my work as rapporteur on the topic in 2012 and 2013 has now been consistently continued - thanks to your work - another important step on the way to a more social Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the situation in Greece in terms of pensions is really disappointing and has been created due to the troika policy. Earlier, Mr Katainen, I referred to VAT. Now I will tell you the facts about pensions, a policy that started from 2010 until now. Today, therefore, six out of ten retirees receive less than 650 euros, while 80% of retirees in Greece receive less than 750 euros. The insurance system was dismantled, because with the famous PSI the loss of the insurance funds reaches 12.5 billion euros. Is there an answer to this question? Indeed, the insurance system can be recapitalized, because there are 19.5 billion euros from the third loan package that Greece received and they have not been used and 12.5 or even 14 billion euros could be allocated for the recapitalization of the insurance funds in which were damaged. The banks were recapitalized. It can also be done for the insurance system.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I will be very short. I just want, on my behalf and on the Commission’s behalf, to thank rapporteur Hayes for an excellent job and it is also very good to hear that the principles are so widely shared here and that there is a political will to look at this proposal, and hopefully everything will go well in the future.

name: Brian HAYES
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I promise on this occasion I will stick under my two minutes. I want to express my thanks for all of the contributions that have been made. As people have said: the great news is we are living longer, and we have got to respond to the demographic needs across the European Union, but we have also got to respect the fact that we have, within the European Union, many different pension schemes, different pillars, and that has to be respected.  So our principle of having minimum harmonisation, respecting Member States, and doing that in a framework, is at the heart of this proposal. I think it is really important that we send out a strong message to encourage employers and employees, which is a great European tradition in terms of the social market economy, to start saving and putting money aside. We are not going to do that if we impose new solvency requirements on pensions, if we impose new taxation on pensions. Now is the time for people to save, to ensure they have an adequate income into the future, and the way to do that is to make sure that we get this proposal right. Others have spoken about the challenges. Yes, this is a low interest rate environment. It is an enormous challenge for pension schemes to yield the return that they need. We have seen a move from defined benefit to defined contribution schemes within the second pillar. There is a clear funding gap for many of these schemes. That is why we need a period of certainty and not to start having enormous regulatory burdens placed on the industry right now.  I am particularly proud of the fact that we have managed to put in place a better regime for cross-border pension provision and for cross-border schemes in terms of the fully funded arrangement, and also in terms of the clear rules for home and host. This is a major advance to ensure that we can get more take-up of cross-border pension schemes.  Finally, this has to be seen within the context of CMU, within the context of aligning our pension policy towards jobs, investment and growth across the European Union. If we do that we will make a success of that into the future by protecting people’s real incomes into the future.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 24 November 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - In the European Union, the pension gap between women and men is on average 39%. That is why the Commission should propose actions and possible structural changes that are needed to ensure equal levels of pensions for women and men in all Member States. One solution would be to encourage Member States to develop complementary schemes that contribute to second-pillar pensions, so as to eliminate the pension gap between women and men and ensure women's access to decent pensions. These occupational pension institutions are a vital part of the European economy, holding assets worth € 2.5 trillion on behalf of around 75 million citizens of the Union. Given that we have hundreds of thousands of cross-border workers at European level who have a job in another Member State, I think it is important to find a pragmatic solution for those institutions that decide to manage a scheme in another Member State. This could lead to significant savings for these institutions, improve the competitiveness of the sector at Union level and facilitate labor mobility.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - The development of pension systems in the second pillar (company pension) must not be at the expense of the statutory pension (first pillar), which still offers the best guarantee against poverty in old age. After all, people are pushed into pension systems where they share the risks, but cannot reap the benefits from shares. A stress test showed that there is a gap of € 430 billion between the promised returns and the actual resources available to deliver on the promises. This could amount to 770 billion euros with a constant economic climate. When the piggy bank is taken out of the statutory pension, the figures may be patched up, but it does not offer a sustainable solution. Incidentally, we do not want to stimulate the cross-border pension market. However, I fully support the report, as the investment and risk management procedures also include environmental, social impact and governance criteria. This not only makes pension funds more transparent, they also receive the legal guarantee that an environmentally sound investment strategy cannot be brought to justice if that investment yields less than a socially or environmentally unfriendly investment. And that is unique in European legislation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Next on the agenda is the debate on the report by Catherine Bearder, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking (2016 /2076 (INI)) (A8-0303 / 2016).

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, our thanks must go to Commissioner Vella for delivering this ambitious action plan against wildlife trafficking. In preparing my report I must thank my shadow rapporteurs, the Committee on International Trade, the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Committee on Development and the Committee on Fisheries for their opinions, the Secretariat of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the policy team of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE), and my own staff, who have all worked very hard on this report. Also, thanks to all the members of MEPs4wildlife who have consistently backed the drive to bring this plan forward. Whilst we have been meeting here today in Strasbourg an estimated 44 more elephants have died: one every 15 minutes. They are poached, killed most brutally to make useless trinkets out of their tusks. But the problem of wildlife trafficking is not just elephant or rhino poaching. Brutal as this is, it is not the whole story. Wildlife trafficking is the trade in plants, animals, fish, birds and insects collected illegally – taken from the wild and sold in the global market place. That market place is huge. Europe is a market and a transit route for these goods. It is frogs’ legs, caviar or sharks for the catering industry. It is skins, furs and timber for the fashion and furniture industry. It is bones and scales for medicines, and reptiles and birds for pets. The lists go on and on. The risk of detection is low and the financial rewards attract criminals who launder money, destabilise communities and fund their illegal activities. In short, it is terrorism against nature and it has to be stopped.  My report builds on the Commission’s good action plan by calling for some more ways to reduce wildlife trafficking. First, wildlife trafficking must be given the same priority as drugs, human trafficking and money laundering in Europol’s Serious and Organised Crime Threat Assessments. Secondly, while it is illegal in source countries to seize certain species, they have no protection here in the EU, and this is a gap in the law. We should introduce a US-style ‘Lacey Act’ at EU level. Thirdly, better reporting needs coordination and watching. An EU wildlife trafficking coordinator would ensure this and watch Member States. This works very well with our human trafficking work, and we should repeat it here. Fourthly, until we can prove otherwise, we must introduce a full and immediate ban on the trade, export and re-export of ivory across the whole of the EU, including ‘pre-Convention’ ivory, and rhino horns. Finally, the punishment must fit the crime. The UN Convention on Serious and Organised Crime sets a minimum of four years’ internment. All Member States should sign up now and implement common standards of justice so these gangs know they will be caught and punished anywhere in the EU. At the end of the day, the fight against wildlife trafficking stands and falls with the EU’s Member States. They must make this plan an urgent priority. The public is with us on this, the politicians now need to act. This is about fighting crime, but also about protecting the planet and its wondrous gifts for future generations.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr. President, there has been a dramatic surge in wildlife trafficking. It raises between EUR 8 and 20 billion each year for organised criminal groups, ranking alongside trafficking of drugs, people and arms. It not only threatens the survival of some species, it also creates corruption, claims human victims and deprives poorer communities of much-needed income. It also threatens security in Central Africa, funding militia and terrorist group activities.  The Commission responded by adopting in February an EU Action Plan to tackle wildlife trafficking within the EU, and to strengthen the EU’s role in a global fight against these illegal activities. Member States endorsed the plan at the June Environment Council. Parliament already had an important role in developing the EU approach. Your resolution of 2014 was an important contribution to the development of the action plan.  This new resolution is comprehensive and ambitious. It is particularly encouraging to see that several committees – Development, International Trade and Fisheries – have provided substantial input to the resolution, in addition to the Environment Committee. This reflects the multi-dimensional nature of wildlife trafficking as well as the need for a large spectrum of stakeholders and communities to take action and work together to address this trafficking.  In the Commission also, not only myself and Carmen Vella but also several other colleagues – Federica Mogherini, Nina Mimica and Dimitris Avramopoulos – were all closely associated in the development and adoption of the Action Plan, with the support of our services. We have now turned to implementation of the Action Plan, as requested in your resolution. It is too early to give a detailed report on this, but good progress has already been made since its adoption.  The Action Plan helped the EU to get successful outcomes at the recent Conference of the Parties of the CITES Convention. The CITES COP was a success and the EU was a major driver for that. My colleague Commissioner Vella was on the spot with the Commission team to guide EU positions, and I know also that the rapporteur herself and several other Members of this House were in Johannesburg following the negotiations. The EU tabled a record number of proposals at this meeting. This included the inclusion of new species in CITES, in particular rare and valuable reptiles and birds which are traded into the EU for the exotic pet market. The resolution was adopted, which for the first time in CITES clearly recognises that corruption is a key enabler for wildlife trafficking and calls on CITES parties and bodies to investigate and penalise it. The EU also pushed for targeted recommendations and sanctions to improve the fight against ivory, rhino horn and tiger trafficking.  At international level, we have also succeeded in including the issue of wildlife trafficking on the agenda of the G20 and of the Financial Action Task Force, the main international body in charge of money laundering, so that the financial dimension of wildlife trafficking will be addressed. Within the EU, the Commission has been working with enforcement agencies from the Member States, Europol and European networks of judges and prosecutors, to raise the awareness of wildlife crime, especially through training sessions and the facilitation of joint enforcement operations.  The Commission and the Member States are also developing guidelines on trade ivory to make sure that trade within the EU, or exports from the EU, do not contribute to international ivory trafficking. We will continue to work on many strands of the EU Action Plan to make sure that the EU delivers on its commitments and makes a real difference in the fight against wildlife trafficking.

name: Brian HAYES
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, on behalf of the Committee on Development, and the opinion, we managed to bring near unanimity in terms of our Committee. We welcome this report and congratulate Mrs Bearder for the work that she has done; equally we congratulate the Commission on their ambitious action plan. It is worth saying that we are talking here about an illegal activity, which has been recognised to be close to USD 19 billion in terms of its scale globally. We are talking about the fourth largest illegal activity on the planet and Europe is not just a taker of this illegal activity; it is also a significant transit point. So we have responsibilities. We have signed up to a UN Convention and, as the Commissioner has said, it is now about implementation. It is about getting it done, Member State by Member State, and calling out those Member States where there is an insufficiency of response in terms of that UN mandate.  So we very much support what Mrs Bearder has put forward in this particular resolution. The Committee on Development fully supports the work that she has brought to Parliament in terms of this plenary session. We expect substantial support for this in the House tomorrow.  It is worth saying, as she rightly said, that the public is ahead of politicians here. The public is demanding action on this illegal activity. They are demanding an international coordinated response and if it does not start here within the European Union, across the 28 Member States, it cannot start anywhere, and I think that is the message that needs to come from this debate this evening.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. blue-card question. – Mr President, illegal wildlife trade is a global problem with implications that go beyond wildlife: the threat to our ecosystems as well as our global security. Sharp increases in wildlife crime and the increasing involvement of organised criminals only go to emphasise that the moment to act is now. We need a full-ranging, comprehensive approach, one that tackles not only economic development in source countries but also supply chains and demand in domestic markets and other destination countries. Trade policy, customs, law enforcement and development policies must be coherent and complementary, and sufficient resources must be available. The EU and its Member States must lead these efforts, ensuring that appropriate wildlife sustainability provisions are prioritised in its trade policy and included in all future trade agreements, with the aim of elimination of illegal wildlife trade. My own-initiative report, which will be voted in the Committee on International Trade (INTA) next January, reflects these concerns and the ambitions of my colleague Catherine Bearder’s report. I therefore welcome this report and I am fully supportive of it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- (The speaker speaks without a microphone.) ... I support this report and, of course, I speak out against illegal trade and hunting.However, I would like to ask - and I could actually ask all the rapporteurs that - whether you agree to paragraph 56 of the report, where it is claimed that legal trophy hunting has contributed to the massive decline in endangered species.I would be interested to know where you got this information from, whether you can prove it and whether you could kindly send me some information.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, if I can beg your time on this, he has actually referred his question directly to the rapporteur. So I do not know how I can answer a question that is referred directly to the rapporteur. Is the rapporteur able to answer this question, one might ask? Personally, I do not believe that trophy hunting is a suitable way to tackle this problem. But Mr President, I leave it to your discretion as to who answers this specific question.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Once the debate is over - in fact, it is the rapporteur who closes it - there will be time to respond.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. - Mr President, Commissioner, Madam rapporteur, the Committee on Fisheries stresses the fact that this action plan is largely silent on the aquatic domain. Unfortunately, there are serious problems in the aquatic world, including in the marine environment, related to the trafficking of wild species, including charismatic species such as corals and turtles, among many others. It must be recognized that there is still illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing in European seas and rivers, and part of it is based on trafficking in wild species. When we pressed, and rightly, to change behavior in third countries, giving them yellow and red cards, we were still not efficient in controlling the fishing of glass eels, for example, sturgeons, turbot, among many others, within our own borders. There is a call for greater coordination between the different directorates-general of the Commission and for new methodologies and technologies to be applied in the fight against trafficking. Finally, it is suggested to create a prize that recognizes the commitment of those who, whether on land or at sea, defend wild species, sometimes at the risk of their own lives.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. - Mr President, the illicit trade in so-called wild animals, that is, in fact, in disobedient animal species, is a heinous crime against biodiversity. Organized wildlife smuggling, valued at € 20 billion a year, is contributing to the ongoing desertification of our planet and must therefore be dealt with in the strictest possible terms. Cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination needs to be strengthened. We are called upon to support a worldwide fauna effort by ensuring the survival of important species through the imposition of more effective wildlife protection measures. The European Union Action Plan on Combating Illicit Trafficking in Wildlife is just one step in the right direction. In general, however, humanity must realize that it is part of nature and not its owners and behave accordingly.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Mr. President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank Ms. Bearder for the excellent cooperation we had in drafting this report and congratulate her on her work. Illegal trafficking in wild flora and fauna is one of the most lucrative types of organized crime in the world with an annual turnover of between € 8 billion and € 20 billion. It has more than doubled since 2007, and has tripled since 1998, making it the fourth largest illegal activity in the world after drug trafficking, counterfeiting and human trafficking. This form of crime is becoming a serious threat to security, political stability, the economy, the source of income at the local level, natural resources and the cultural heritage of many countries. In the fight against illegal trade in wild species, I consider it important to take preventive measures in order to make the offer of illegally caught wild species as inaccessible as possible to our citizens. Control measures need to be tightened and effective policies developed to combat potential illegal activities on the Internet. The European Union and its Member States must consistently implement existing legislation and international agreements. To combat this form of organized crime, it is necessary to provide the competent authorities with sufficient resources and adequate administrative capacity. All stakeholders involved should be adequately trained depending on the important function they perform in this fight against crime. Equally important, the success of the implementation of the EU Action Plan requires cooperation between Member States, and I see this report as an incentive to better exchange information and increase joint efforts to put an end to illegal wildlife trade.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We have a report before us that has done a really good job on the part of Parliament - the Commissioner has already pointed this out. There was also a good presentation from the Commission, namely the action plan as a whole. But I want to express my thanks to the rapporteur, Catherine Bearder from the ALDE Group. She did a really good job. We were able to communicate well with one another in shadow meetings. From 188 amendments and four opinions from other committees, 19 compromises have been forged. Unfortunately, the report has now become a bit long at 65 digits, which in my opinion has made it a bit less precise. But on the other hand it also became clear that almost all members of parliament and committees are pulling in the right direction here and want to put an end to the illegal wildlife trade. The Commissioner has already pointed out that it is not just about elephants and rhinos - I will come to that in a moment. Pangolins and reptiles in particular are traded illegally in the EU. This includes pangolins, small crocodiles, certain turtles, but also orchids, tropical woods and exotic parrots. The Member States would have to make far more efforts here - and we should support them in doing so - to put an end to this illegal trade. I would like to draw particular attention to one point: Paragraph 58 in the report. It deals with the illegal trade in ivory and rhinoceros horn within the EU. This should clearly be banned. Just to confirm: The large elephant census in Africa, which was completed just a few months ago, clearly shows how endangered these animals are. Between 2007 and 2014 the elephant population decreased by 30%. In the 18 countries examined, only 350,000 elephants counted.That is far less than was previously expected.So from there once again the proof that we have to strongly oppose illegal trade here.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - An alarming number of elephants, tigers, rhinoceroses and other animal species are being killed for gadgets and souvenirs, so-called medicines or useless fashion accessories. Unscrupulous poachers and traders put nature on sale for big money and we must all put an end to that. Illicit wildlife trafficking is one of the most important forms of organized crime in the world. The trade puts billions of euros in the hands of criminal organizations every year, has links to the drug and arms trade and finances militias and terrorist groups. Moreover, illegal activities are increasing spectacularly. Illegal trade is not only deadly to many protected species, it is also extremely dangerous. Trade leads to insecurity and instability, for example in Central Africa and this was also explicitly recognized by the UN Security Council. The EU is involved. After all, Europe is not only a sales market for illegal products, but also functions as a hub. Reasons enough to combat this illegal trade. In the interest of nature and our safety. A European action plan does not come a moment too soon. We have a good action plan, but that is not the end of it. The great challenge is to effectively put words into action. The implementation, enforcement and monitoring of the action plan and existing legislation are crucial. It remains for me to thank colleague Bearder and the other colleagues for the pleasant and constructive cooperation.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, I would like to thank Catherine Bearder for her great work. With this report all the European paperwork has been done, and now it is time for action – urgent action. I must compliment the Commission; the Commission is doing more than its bit, but I am more doubtful about the role of the Member States. If you look at the Council conclusions from June 2016, they were rather weak. The Council conclusions only ‘invited’ the relevant actors to implement the action plan, and that is far too weak. This action plan has 32 actions; 24 of these 32 actions had to be implemented before the end of 2016, that is today. So my question to the Commission is: can you inform Parliament of this a little bit sooner than July 2018? And Mr President, can you send the minutes of this meeting to the Council, asking the Council to put the Action Plan again on the Council agenda.  Is it urgent? Yes, it is extremely urgent. In the two years since the communication was published, we have lost more than 10% of the wild rhinos, and more than 75 000 elephants.

name: Stefan ECK
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! The report is certainly a major step in saving many threatened species and curbing the illegal trade in wildlife, wildlife products and rare plants. But unfortunately I have to say that EU policy has once again failed miserably, because this report comes much too late for countless animal and plant species that are already extinct or are on the verge of extinction. We are witnesses of the sixth mass extinction on this planet, and the illegal wildlife and plant trade is largely responsible for this. This report comes far too late because the focus of Commission policy is primarily on the mostly self-inflicted crises and because the political will is simply lacking when it comes to animals and nature, when economic interests are affected. My colleague Catherine Bearder and the members of the MEPs for Wildlife are absolutely not to blame for this report being late and acting like a sedative for the Commission to me. Why is the Commission opposed to an absolute ban on the ivory trade? Why don't we have a trade ban on exotic species yet? Why have we not yet got a ban on the importation of game trophies for rare species? Why don't we have a trade ban on the endangered bluefin tuna and many other fish species? Commissioner, if we do not enact stricter laws after this report, your children and grandchildren will only know many animal and plant species from books and film documents. It is now in the hands of the Commission to prevent this. That is what the citizens of Europe expect from you.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as a member of the MEPs for Wildlife group, I would like to warmly welcome the Commission’s proposal, the Action Plan, and also I would like to say thank you to Catherine Bearder for the great report from the Parliament.  In my one minute I would like to underline just three points. The first is, and it was already mentioned, the implementation, not only of the Action Plan, but also of the existing EU regulation in the Member States.  Secondly, for proper implementation of the regulation and the Action Plan we need strong and competent authorities in the Member States. There are serious shortcomings regarding the authorities in the Member States. Here the Commission has to give support for the Member States for proper authorities, but also the Commission has to control the proper implementation of the Action Plan and the existing regulation by the authorities in the Member States, and this is lacking from time to time.  Thirdly, we sometimes need further legislative measures regarding the authorities, regarding environmental inspections, and we need strong sanctions against those who are violating the existing rules and who are violating the Action Plan.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must not assume that illegal wildlife trafficking concerns only environmentalists. Economically, with a turnover of $ 213 billion, it is the fourth largest criminal market after drugs, the trade in human beings and the arms market. The report is excellent and strengthens the contents of the European Commission's action plan, as, for example, it calls for greater coordination between Member States and EU agencies, but also for the Member States to draw up national action plans. in order to ensure effective, coherent and harmonized approaches. It stresses the importance of new forms of financing for the fight against illegal trafficking by the European Union, as well as the introduction of regular checks that periodically verify the progress and effectiveness of the action plan. The report also expresses concern about the lack of proper implementation of CITES in some Member States and focuses on hunting trophies, calling for an immediate ban on all imports and exports of rhino horn and ivory. Finally, it highlights the importance of the awareness campaign for both local populations and consumers. I thank the rapporteur and all my colleagues because a really good job has been done.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, we must recognize that this text has the merit of putting an end to the trade in ivory and rhinoceros horns in Europe. Likewise, he rightly advocates better adaptation of fishing gear to avoid bycatch of endangered marine species. We can rejoice that he denounces at the same time corruption and the major role of the online animal trade. However, to the creation of a special European office, we would have preferred international coordination on trafficking. Our amendments also proposed strengthening the Interpol organization and unfortunately the European Police Office (Europol) was preferred. Likewise, the accession of the European Union to the CITES convention on endangered species is presented as progress. We can clearly see where the Union is coming from. It is purely and simply a matter of gradually replacing States in international decisions on these subjects. Unfortunately, the Bearder report calls on the Union to monitor the Member States and even impose an increase in their budgets in this area. Worse, the criminal law recommendations clearly threaten our sovereignty. This is regrettable for a text which had nevertheless integrated our proposals on the particularly lucrative nature of this trade or on the need for an approach involving the countries concerned.

name: Norbert LINS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Wildlife trafficking is one of the most lucrative crimes in the world. It is about EUR 8 to 20 billion in dirty money. The flourishing trade in illegally acquired plants and animals poses a serious threat to nature and humans. I think it is positive that we are holding a plenary debate here for the second time within a few weeks. Europe is destination, transit and origin at the same time and is therefore heavily involved in illegal trade flows. That is why we need a specific and coordinated strategy. That is why I find the Commission's action plan very positive, which focuses on cooperation between the police and customs, joint operations and, above all, better and uniform enforcement in the Member States and, in particular, the EU's international commitment, especially in CITES. For example, at the successful COP 17 in Johannesburg, the rules for trophy hunting were significantly tightened internationally. Only well and sustainably organized trophy hunting has profitable effects for nature and people. The Commission, the External Action Service and the Member States must now invest even more resolutely in implementation so that we can dry up these EUR 8 to 20 billion as quickly as possible.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Ippermettili nibda billi nirringrazzja, l-ewwel u qabel kollox, lil Catherine Bearder, u anke lill-kollega tagħna, Susanne Melior, li kienet ix-Shadow Rapporteur f'isem is-Soċjalisti u d-Demokratiċi. Huwa fatt li l-komunity internazzjonali bħalissa qed tiffaċċja żieda extraordinaryarja fil-kummerċ illegal ta 'annimali selvaġġi, b'tali mod li qegħdin ikunu f'riskju li jintilfu l-isforzi ta' konservazzjoni u preservazzjoni li saru fl-aħħar. Teżisti żieda fid-global demand għal dawn l-inspċi selvaġġi u l-products tagħhom, bl-Unjoni Ewropea sservi kemm ta 'hub ċentrali kif ukoll bħala punt ta' tranżitu għal traffikar f'kontinenti oħra. U f'dan il-kuntest, jeħtieġ li, b'mod frattjat, ikun hemm sett ta 'miżuri biex l-Unjoni Ewropea tkun f'pożizzjoni tiġġieled it-illegal traffikar ta' speċi selvaġġi u magħmula minnhom products. U fil-preżent, several speċi selvaġġi traffikati b'mod illegal qegħdin f'riskju ta 'estinzjoni. Dan ifisser li l-implimentazzjoni ta 'dan il-pjan hija kruċjali u r-respons entijat huwa neċessarju. Fl-opinjoni tiegħi, hemm tliet aspects ewlenin li wieħed irid jindirizza. L-ewwelnett, il-criminal. Nistgħu nibagħtu Messaġġ b'saħħtu biss jekk ikollna leġiżlazzjoni narrow them but tippermettix l-importazzjoni ta 'speċi selvaġġi protected. It-hold, nappella lill-mexxejja Ewropej biex jindirizzaw the-problem ta 'siti onlajn li jbigħu dawn il-products, u jiżguraw li dawn jiġu penalized. U fl-aħħarnett, important kuxjenza akbar dwar dan is-suġġett. Huwa biss permezz ta 'aktar edukazzjoni u għarfien li nistgħu nnaqqsu drastikament id-question għal dawn il-products, fl-Unjoni Ewropea u lil hinn. Il-pjan ta 'azzjoni mill-Unjoni Ewropea qiegħed hemm. Issa jeħtieġ li l-Istati Members jikkommettu ruħhom politikament u jkunu parti minn dan il-pjan ta 'azzjoni. Biex dan iseħħ, iżda, hemm bżonn sostenn adegwat, kemm f'termini financialjarji, kif ukoll f'termini ta 'riżorsi human. U nittama li dan ir-rapport ikun biss l-ewwel pass biex din l-activity ta ' organized crime tkun addressed bis-seriousness.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mrs Bearder, who brings her usual rigour and enthusiasm to this subject and it is very welcome. We need to start taking wildlife trafficking more seriously. It is a transnational organised crime, which requires a suitably serious and coordinated response. It has far-reaching implications; not only does it contribute to biodiversity loss and species extinction, it also helps to fund organised criminal groups which undermine regional stability and the rule of law.  I believe in smart regulation, and that means clear and enforceable rules with an absolute minimum of derogations and exceptions. No excuses and no confusion. On that basis, I would like to echo Mr Eck’s call for consideration of a trade ban on exotic species, because all the way through these discussions I ask myself why do we need to trade legally in these species at all. I fully support the calls for a more coordinated joined-up approach to combating wildlife trafficking across different policy areas such as trade, development, foreign affairs, justice and home affairs, and I wish her every success with this report.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: - Wild life crime poses a serious threat to biodiversity, but it mainly poses a threat to animals. Just think of the four elephants who will die for their ivory tusks during this brief debate. And illegal trade in animals is not just about ivory, horn and tiger skins. It is mainly about animals. And millions of animals are traded alive in Europe, with the Netherlands as the beating heart of this ruthless business. Illicit trade is closely intertwined with legal trade and uses the same routes. And Madam President, we are not talking about toasters here. We are talking about animals with awareness and feeling and that is why we should certainly not encourage the legal trade in wild animals. And it is great that this plan focuses on the prevention, enforcement and shelter of wild animals. Because as long as there are insufficient suitable shelters for wildlife, many enforcers will prefer to look the other way when confiscating an alligator, Barbary macaque or lion cub. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague, Mrs Bearder, for her report. As has been said, wildlife trafficking is the fourth most lucrative illicit activity after drug trafficking, human trafficking and the arms trade. The profits made each year are estimated to be between 8 and 20 billion euros, but the real cost is inestimable. This is why I endorse the Commission and encourage Member States to seriously tackle this crime against biodiversity. European countries which do not penalize this traffic become privileged entry points, but also important hubs for this international trade. Let us not forget that this trafficking feeds above all on poverty, crime and armed conflicts and that, in some regions of the world, conservationists are also in danger of death. But let's not forget that humans don't need a gun to be the most dangerous predator. Let us question our ways of life, fight against the disappearance of plant and animal species, protect ecosystems, stop concreteization and deforestation like land grabbing. In a recent WWF report, it was shown that the pressure of human activities has caused the disappearance of half of vertebrates in just forty years, and climate change is likely to exacerbate this pressure even more. Europe must be at the forefront and preserve our climate, otherwise we will all be responsible for the sixth species extinction.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: -  Mister President! It is to be welcomed and it is high time that the Commission tries to prevent illegal wildlife trafficking and thus poaching as well. After all, poaching and illegal trade go a long way toward exterminating animal and plant species. However, under paragraph 56 of this report, legal and thus sustainable trophy hunting was also cited as a major reason for endangering endangered animals, and this follows more an ideological position against sustainable hunting and less reason. Sustainable hunting has certainly not led to the extinction of animal species in the last few decades, on the contrary. And the example of Kenya, where hunting has been banned since 1977 and the wild animal population has declined by 68% to this day, is hopefully well known to the Commission. The reasons for this are a lack of wildlife management, civilization pressures, but also a lack of protection against illegal hunting. The animals there have no real value for large parts of the population, they become unrestrained and were unrestrainedly killed as illegal trophy suppliers and pests. In South Africa, however, where hunting is allowed, the rhino population increased by around 900% in spite of the poaching of 2,000 animals, because it is important and worthwhile for the state and the locals to protect animals and to preserve their populations also increase. Because wherever people live from and with trophy hunting, the wild animal automatically receives value, is protected and, accordingly, is less the target of illegal hunting. The wild animal thus also provides a livelihood for many people and a decent reward for the regional population. Well-trained and equipped game rangers or bush rangers are a guarantee for the preservation of the wild animal population. The number 56 discriminates against hunting and is therefore to be rejected because it is simply wrong. I will agree with the report itself because very much there is much positive in it.And we have to say: in the end, sustainable hunting really only protects the environment.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - I thank my colleague Bearder for this report. Indeed, the illegal wildlife trade poses a serious threat to wildlife and the rule of law. Let's take a look at the rhinoceros. Poaching in South Africa alone breaks a record this year. More than a thousand rhinos have already been poached, which is a low point. Rhino poaching has increased by 9,000 percent in seven years. More than three rhinos a day are currently being killed. The horn of this animal is more expensive than gold. It yields 50,000 euros per kilo. Such proceeds make this crime too attractive to the poor population of the region and we must therefore tackle this crime very hard with the action plan before us. I would also like to point out the importance of legal hunting, point 56. In some reserves, sustainable legal game management is an important source of income. This source of income offers the poor population a good alternative to poaching. Certified legal sustainable hunting trophies can therefore make an important contribution, despite all emotions and prejudices. And as a hunter you can be proud of that. And we must be able to admit these. Furthermore, I think it is important that the European development funds provide financial support for emerging countries to stop, arrest and punish poachers and smugglers. And I am therefore pleased that the Environment Committee has supported my amendment on this point. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Stefan ECK
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I have only one question for the previous speaker: is it true that your husband is a hunter?

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" answer.- I am very glad that you are asking me that question.My husband is a hunter and my whole family, all farmers, are not hunters.But you need them both.I found out after my husband's marriage how the hunters also clearly contribute to the right balance in this case we are now talking about.I am totally against illegal hunting.But you just need a legal hunt.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! On the one hand - we heard today - there is a well-organized criminal company that generates around EUR 20 billion a year. On the other hand, we have a - let me call it that - hodgepodge of measures that are intended to counteract this organized criminal market of the illegal wildlife trade. I don't think that can work. In other words, I am happy with the measures that are to be taken now. I would also like to thank the rapporteur and her colleagues most sincerely for this wonderful report, which finally shows an opportunity to counter this organized crime. First of all - and this has already been mentioned today - we have to dry up the sales market. Wherever there is demand, supply will also be delivered. Wherever the penalties are not really deterrent - both for those who buy illegal goods and for those who deal with them - it will simply continue to live. And because it is about species protection today: Commissioner Katainen, I can't help myself: We also need functioning species protection in the European Union, and I think we have pushed that very, very well with the Habitats Directive. The task now is to continue implementing this Habitats Directive. It works wherever it is implemented. Please do not destroy it by opening it as part of REFIT, but support us in further implementation.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We all know the pictures and I agree with the rapporteur, who said: this is terror against nature. The structures of mafia trading are almost the same. We just have to make sure that we attack these structures somewhere. It is not enough now to send appeals that we have to work together more, but actually intervene in the structures. We have to siphon off the profits that come from this trade. We actually have to make sure that we cut the trade routes and we also have to see that we ultimately impose harsher penalties. The penalties that are imposed if someone is caught are sometimes ridiculous - even with illegal trade. Europe has a pioneering role and Europe must also take on this pioneering role, not only because Europe is a destination, but also because it is a trading center for illegal trade. We must therefore not only work together in Europe, but also with the target countries - I am mainly mentioning China and Vietnam here. There, too, there has to be cooperation in order to curb global trade. I appeal again: This is a human problem and it has to be put on the agenda of the world community, otherwise we will and will have a catastrophe in years' time ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: - Mr President, being the co-editor of a recent motion for a resolution on the fight against ivory trafficking through trophy hunting, the question naturally touches me particularly. While I share a large part of the findings of this report, I nevertheless wish to make certain essential caveats. First of all, stop lumping wildlife trafficking in the same bag as drugs or, worse, people. Since Aristotle, the scale of beings has been a founding principle of natural philosophy. It is perhaps time to recall that, philosophically, man is superior to the animal as the animal is to the plant and the plant to the mineral. It therefore seems irresponsible and scandalous to me to compare trafficking in wildlife to trafficking in human beings, otherwise known as slavery - an analogy expressed in black and white in this report. Another theme also biased: trophy hunting. If it is respectful of biodiversity and well supervised, it is nevertheless necessary. It makes it possible to co-finance wildlife conservation plans and to provide monitoring and traceability to work in symbiosis with sovereign States. These States precisely, respect them! Respect Namibia which, moreover, has enshrined in its sovereign Constitution the positive role of hunting in respect of biodiversity. Speak with the States, of course, but let them decide on their criminal policy in this area after exporting ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Europe must be forceful in the fight against wildlife trafficking in the face of its three worst faces. First, the loss of biodiversity. It is estimated, according to what is exposed in the report, that we face a clear extinction of species that can unbalance the trophic chain of animal species and cause, therefore, irreparable damage to some ecosystems that are unique on our planet. Second, the financing of criminal organizations. Approximately, the wildlife smuggling business moves around 20 billion euros annually; 20 billion hidden euros, which are neither taxed to the States, nor is it known where they come from, nor help to improve the economy of the countries of origin of these species; on the contrary, they destabilize it. Third, impunity for environmental crimes. The commission of environmental crimes has usually been considered minor, with small penalties that rarely go beyond the administrative penalty. We must be aware that the damage we do to nature will be returned to us 10, 100 or 1 000 times, and, accordingly, we must establish coherent, effective and dissuasive criminal penalties, as mentioned in the report. For all this, because we must act with prevention, cooperating with other countries, and because we must be strict in complying with the rules that we have all agreed upon, the States and the Commission and the European Union cannot delay the implementation of the action plan. against wildlife trafficking.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the action plan to combat wildlife trafficking within the EU is ambitious and strengthens our role in the fight against this illegal activity in the world. Trafficking is becoming one of the most profitable criminal realities and annually brings up to 20 billion euros into the pockets of organized crime groups, a figure equivalent to that of drug trafficking, people, weapons. The European Union is one of the main destination countries for the wildlife trade and coordinated action is needed to address its causes, to apply existing rules effectively and to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination . Above all, there are negative impacts on existing biodiversity and ecosystems, as well as on our children. Yes, because, as Commissioner Vella rightly said, to make our citizens and consumers understand the importance of this decision: at the current rate, children born today will see the last wild elephants and rhinos die before they are 25 years old. . And not only, among other things, the so-known species such as elephants and rhinos, but many other no less important species.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: - Mr President!Today we are discussing an extremely important issue, namely the EU action plan against the illicit trade in wildlife.Global demand for this illegal trade is growing.The penalties are far too low in many countries, and the risk of a criminal going there is far too small.The profits made in this trade are huge.The EU is not only a country of origin and recipient but also a country of transit.We need common legislation to close loopholes in the regulations.The meshes in the net that make us have not been good enough at preventing this illegal trade.This is a cross-border environmental issue to prevent the extinction of animals and plants.We need tougher rules.Approve the report.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, we are seeing an unprecedented loss of endangered species, and species in general, all over the world. At the same time, we see wildlife trafficking expanding at a faster pace than ever. So, yes, we do need to act with much more urgency and in a stricter way than we have envisioned to date. This includes compulsory trained units on duty in customs services, including trained dogs. It means specialised training units, including in police forces. It means liability for transportation companies, including air freight companies and other middlemen in the processes. Yes, it means banning imports of trophies – and, yes indeed, that actually fuels the illegal transportation of wildlife and endangered species because it makes it harder to make the difference between legal and illegal. If we do not act on these points right now, if we do not take responsibility here in Europe, as I urge the Commission to do, then in a couple of years’ time it could be too late.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: - Mr President, wildlife trafficking has become one of the most lucrative illegal businesses in the world, after drugs, human trafficking and the arms trade. In southern countries, especially, this practice depletes biodiversity, fuels corruption, fuels armed conflict and impoverishes many populations. Well, we know that Europe is a destination, a market and a central hub for this traffic. Although we would have liked more forcefulness in the report, the action plan seems to us, however, that it is on the right track. But yes: it is essential that all European policies take into account the protection of species in a transversal way, in line with the objectives of poverty reduction and sustainable development objectives. It is a question of the coherence of European policies. Finally, it seems essential to us that the European Union recognize the trafficking of species as an ecocide: they are ecological crimes against the human rights of nature and of all living beings. And crimes have to be tried.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! As long as buyers are willing to pay enormous amounts of money for valuable specimens, the illegal wildlife trade will continue. And always - especially if the punishment for crimes is small in relation to the profit achieved - there will be people and groups organizing this practice. Let us note that despite many actions, trainings and increasing social awareness, we are constantly seeing an increase in this crime, not only locally, but above all in the form of cross-border organized crime. Therefore, there is a need to strengthen European law and strengthen global cooperation in this area, as well as greater respect by Member States of EU law. However, by fighting this practice, we cannot eliminate the beautiful hunting tradition, because in many cases, thanks to hunters, many disappearing species of animals have been restored or saved.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, illegal wildlife trafficking poses a serious and growing threat to biodiversity and the environment, but it also represents a source of income for criminal organizations, with a total annual business value of several billion euros. , proceeds that are often used to finance further very serious crimes. It is therefore indispensable that the commitment of the European institutions, in addition to harmonizing and making the regulatory framework more stringent, is aimed at strengthening cooperation between the police forces of the countries of origin, transit and destination of wild species and at encouraging the sharing of information with the relevant and competent agencies of the Union. The illegal wildlife trade is a challenge we cannot afford to lose. It is necessary to preserve the biological wealth of our planet and keep it intact for future generations and it is necessary to take away this source of income from organized crime. So I thank my colleague Bearder for her work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the European Commission has adopted, since February 2016, an action plan to combat wildlife trafficking. Trafficking that has become one of the most lucrative criminal activities in the world. The illicit trade in wildlife has increased dramatically in recent years, adversely affecting biodiversity and natural resources, with revenues estimated at between € 8 billion and € 20 billion a year. At the same time, the illegal wildlife trade poses a threat to the development of local communities where wildlife resources are now depleted, while demand for wildlife products remains high. The Union action plan on wildlife trafficking should therefore help to prevent and crack down on illegal trade and reduce the supply and demand of illegal species, as well as to strengthen the implementation of existing rules for the fight against crime.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, both the EU and the United Nations have finally woken up to the fact that this is not just an environmental problem.It is now understood that poaching and trade in wildlife parts also threaten good governance, security and sustainable development in states.Studies show that armed groups in Africa fund their activities and thus also conflicts with the proceeds of poaching.Immediate action is needed to eradicate this greedy and futile phenomenon that threatens biodiversity in all areas, and the EU in particular must act directly on this, whether it is environmental or trade policy or tourism.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I agree with my predecessors when they talked about the importance of the harmfulness of this phenomenon.Indeed, wildlife trafficking is a phenomenon that threatens populations themselves, and it has already fallen into such categories that these species are becoming extinct.I also agree with the importance of prevention, education and upbringing, much has been said here, but I think the main thing lies in each of us.What is the access of each of us to resources, whether economic or to the landscape, or also to animal resources?I think that if we follow the motto "flood after us", then our offspring will feel it very soon.I would very much like us to subscribe to a truly responsible and sensible environmental approach.I would also like to support him.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, trafficking in protected species represents the fourth illegal market after drugs, weapons and human beings, with a turnover of tens of billions of euros a year. Often managed by organized crime to the detriment of the environment, it often serves to finance terrorist movements. The low probability of detection and high profits are an irresistible attraction for organized crime. In this context, I consider effective the European action plan promoted by the Commission, which will strengthen the role of the Union in the global fight against illegal wildlife trafficking through the prevention, cooperation and recognition of Europe as a target market and as a point of origin and transit of wild species products. However, particular attention needs to be paid to the timely implementation by Member States of all instruments of the action plan. The constant monitoring of the Commission and the annual report to be presented to the European Parliament will be useful checks to test the validity of the measures adopted.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I do appreciate the broad support for the Action Plan which comes from across all the political groups. This is very positive news.  In many contributions, many Members highlighted the importance of implementation; that is of course of the essence. We have to make sure that our Member States will implement everything that we have agreed. Many colleagues here said that the Commission must make sure that the Action Plan is implemented. We do our share, but implementation is mostly in the hands of Member States, and you as representatives of Member States can hopefully put pressure on your governments so that these things are taken seriously. So let us take this implementation as a core issue.  The third point I want to make is that the EU has the strictest rules on the trade in hunting trophies. Trade is possible but strictly framed, which is very good. The EU made a proposal to CITES and this proposal was accepted, which means that there are guidelines to ensure that hunting trophies are from legal and sustainable origins. We now have an international standard that establishes an export permit for species like lions, hippos and polar bears.  On the fourth element, illegal killing has nothing to do with hunting, because hunting always has legal rules and it is better to have sustainable rules for hunting. Illegal killing is a crime which destroys sustainability and that is why we have to concentrate our efforts, especially with this.  Some Members asked about the continuation of the process. The Action Plan covers five years from this year to 2020, and the Commission and the EEAS will establish a scoreboard to monitor implementation. The Commission will report to the European Parliament and to the Council by July 2018 on progress made. Evaluation of the plan’s curbing of wildlife trafficking will be carried out in 2020. Thank you very much for a very good discussion and let us focus on implementation, both at national but also at European level.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the speakers tonight for their support and their kind words about this report. It is also very good to hear that the Commission is starting implementation. But, as with any of this, the important thing is enforcement and making sure that we do what we say we are signed up to do. So we will be looking to you, Commissioner, to make sure that that is done. On the issue of trophy hunting: trophy hunting pretends to be about conservation. If it was about conservation we would not have a problem, but there are tens of thousands of animals taken from the wild and it is creating a market for illegal trophies and putting money into big businesses. It is not helping local communities. It is not helping the animals. It is very complicated to stop wildlife trafficking. The source countries need help. We need to stop the money laundering and the gun running. I am very pleased to hear about the online marketplace, which is also a really growing market. Biodiversity is under huge pressure; climate change and human pressure on wildlife areas are adding to that, but wildlife trafficking is a concerted attack for profit. It is heart-breaking to see what is happening. Out there are brave game rangers risking their lives, and others are facing determined criminals. We face telling our children: once there were elephants, or rhinos, or redwood trees. This action plan is good, but so far it is just a paper document. We have to work altogether to turn that into action, and quickly. The biosphere is under attack. It is the life-sustaining system of our planet and it is the beautiful result of millions of years of evolution. Without action now we will lose most of it forever. We in the EU can and must protect it, and we can set an example for the rest of the world about how we can do it. This report and action plan is the start of a journey. Please support my report, and then we can really get to work on tackling this horrible crime.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
