text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – I welcome the Commission’s Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking, as the EU needs a coordinated response to wildlife trafficking, which is a serious and growing problem in Europe and globally. It is an organised international crime worth billions, and linked to other forms of serious crime such as money laundering and the financing of militias. In addition to being a security issue, wildlife trafficking also endangers biodiversity and ecosystems. It is essential to protect vulnerable and endangered species of flora and fauna to meet the UN’s sustainable development goals. Therefore, it is important to follow the key priorities set out by this Action Plan, namely to address root causes, effectively implement and enforce rules, increase global cooperation, and address internal trade. Member States need to increase protection of target species and habitats, especially for those that are vulnerable. Furthermore, as wildlife trafficking is a global issue, there needs to be dialogue and cooperation with source, transition, and destination countries.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - As undeniable as climate change is the sixth species extinction. Overfishing, extensive cattle ranching in the Amazon or palm oil plantations in Borneo and Sumatra eliminate the habitat for animals and plants. But the great cruelty that contributes to the disappearance of species is the trade in exotic animals. Bloody business that moves billions. According to a UN report, more than 80 elephants are killed every day, annually more than 1 000 rhinos and 120 tigers, species dramatically on the verge of disappearance. Spain is the gateway to Europe for many live species from the illegal trade that are confiscated and relocated in private wildlife centers or are unfortunately euthanized even though they are threatened or endangered species. Around 15,000 animals have been seized in Spain since 2005, which, like many other Member States, lacks its own rescue centers, leaving confiscated animals in private and donor hands without an official protocol for readaptation to the environment. Spain, due to its enclave, should have more support at the European level not only for customs control but also for the direct victims of this illegal trade.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - It is unanimously acknowledged that wildlife trafficking is another, among the most profitable, form of growing international organized crime worldwide. Such a regulatory initiative is welcome, as wildlife trafficking is a negative, organic phenomenon linked to other forms of serious, organized crime, with a negative impact on biodiversity, ecosystems, Member States' heritage, natural resources and species conservation. Moreover, wildlife trafficking undermines global security, political stability and the socio-economic development of the EU. As such, the EU Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking requires a strategic approach at EU level, based on the cooperation of all stakeholders, not just the actors involved in this negative phenomenon. In order to develop an appropriate EU plan against wildlife trafficking, the initiative to consider the model and mechanisms used to combat trafficking in human beings is welcome. The development and implementation of mechanisms for monitoring measures and progress by Member States in this area must also be linked to the process of disseminating results and awareness-raising campaigns to change their behavior at individual and collective level.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Drug trafficking, human trafficking, arms trade: these are the three most lucrative activities in the criminal world. At the foot of this podium, with up to 20 billion euros in annual profits, is the trafficking of wild species, plants and objects taken from these illicit businesses. The situation worsens from year to year, leading to the disappearance of certain species. The height of the horror: the rarer a species becomes, the more the price of products linked to these murders increases, causing the massacre to intensify. The European Parliament is proposing an action plan and calling for exemplary sanctions to combat this scourge. Without biodiversity, there will be no more humanity. We ask, among other things, that heavy sanctions be taken on European soil against traffickers, as well as the establishment of a European coordinator for the fight against this type of crime. Europol must regard this activity as a form of organized crime. Finally, we are asking for legislation inspired by the American model and in which it is clearly mentioned that if a product has been made or obtained illegally in a country, it is also illegal in the country of destination.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Next on the agenda is the debate on the report by Dominique Riquet, on behalf of the Transport and Tourism Committee, on new opportunities for small transport companies, including collaborative business models (2015/2349 (INI)) (A8-0304 / 2016).

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: protractor. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to express my thanks to my co-rapporteurs for the quality of their contribution, the cordiality of our reports and the ability we have had to obtain a very broad assent together. It is necessary to recall that transport, essential for the movement of people and goods, is a fundamental element of the internal market. Alongside public transport, which is often in difficulty, SMEs in the transport sector - or, should I say, "mobility" - represent an essential activity and often the bulk of the sector's activity, a capital element of mobility, especially in urban nodes, and a dynamic source of growth and, therefore, of job creation to meet the ever-increasing demand for mobility. The challenges facing European transport SMEs as a whole are of various kinds. They are firstly confronted with a regulatory challenge due to the complexity, the inherent costs generated and the great disparity in the rules governing access to regulated professions; secondly, to an economic challenge linked to heavy charges and to the perennial problem of financing with difficult access to credit for limited investment capacities; third, to an environmental challenge resulting from congestion, emissions and dependence on fossil fuels; fourth, to a technological challenge with the emergence of the new economy, intermediation platforms, empowerment, automation and vehicle connectivity. Moreover, this last point leads me to underline the appearance of a new phenomenon in this context. It was in the transport sector that the collaborative economy first made its most spectacular breakthrough. Uberization is a term that bears witness to this. However, this new economy brings ruptures positive technological and commercial innovations, but also poses certain problems for traditional players and regulators. The progress generated by the collaborative economy is numerous: improvement of the quality and fluidity of existing services; securing actors for the benefit of the consumer - I mean the gains in confidence generated by the reciprocal identification and notification of the consumer and the service provider; strengthening of transaction security; creation of a new type of self-employed worker, often in need of income and participating both in increasing growth and reducing unemployment. However, let us not forget the challenges posed by this platform economy, starting with the definition and supervision of the relationships between these platforms and service providers, both for the purposes of taxation and social protection or the security of legal stability. Then, should the nature of the service offered by the service provider to the individual be qualified as "commercial" or "cost-sharing" in the context of co-consumption? In addition and as a consequence of the above, the question is raised of the fiscal and social status of the actors of the collaborative economy as well as the differentiation between the non-profit sharing economy for the service provider and the platform economy. for profit. Data protection is obviously an important subject, without forgetting the relationship with the so-called "classic" transport economy and corporations. Access to regulated professions is often complex, restricted and different in the Member States. The response to all of these problems involves, on the one hand, improving the environment for SMEs in the sector by reducing their administrative burden, simplifying their access to credit, and even to research, by modernizing the status of professions and by easier access to new technologies for traditional players. This response implies, on the other hand, the convergence between the classic economy and the new collaborative economy at European level by the harmonization of statutes and rules of access to professions, by the determination of what falls under sharing and which is profit in a commercial activity, by the harmonization of tax and social systems in order to ensure identical rules between the traditional economy and the new economy and by the progression towards European frameworks which define the status of the professions and their economic framework. My dear colleagues, these are the challenges ahead. I am delighted that this report has received very broad support from my colleagues in the Transport Committee. I hope that it will be useful in moving towards more efficiency, growth, employment and sustainability in the service of citizens and I am about to listen to your interventions very carefully.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the report by Mr Riquet which provides a really balanced view of current developments in the transport sector, while pointing out some of the major challenges. Let me respond to the elements of his report. First, on the importance of SMEs in the transport sector. Road transport is a sector which is characterised by hundreds of thousands of SMEs. As an example, 95% of road freight companies are micro-companies with less than 10 employees. As opposed to other modes of transport, companies in road transport are subject to stiff competition in an already open market. This is largely due to the creation of a single market.  However, looking at the local level and at passenger transport in particular, the development has been quite different. Local and regional markets are often closed and strictly regulated, or even operated directly by public authorities. This way of functioning has not been challenged until recently. In some cases it has not promoted the industry to develop innovative solutions for transport.  On the role of the Commission, our role is to propose, where appropriate, EU legislation that addresses issues identified in a proportionate manner, having regard to the different public interests possibly involved, such as road safety or social working conditions, and of course our role is also to ensure that Member States comply with EU law, and the responsibility of Member States highlighted by your report is therefore very welcome.  On the 2017 road initiatives, as you know, the Commission has announced legislative proposals in the field of road transport to be presented in the first semester of 2017. When reviewing existing EU legislation in road transport, we will be looking for a balance between social standards and enhancing the functioning of the internal market. In particular, we are looking at ways to improve rules on access to the profession of road transport operator that are supposed to ensure fair conditions for hauliers of different Member States. We need to adjust and clarify rules in a way that does not increase administrative burdens.  On digitalisation of the economy, digitalisation is an opportunity to increase mobility and reduce congestion in cities, but it may also be a challenge for transport. We must ensure access to relevant transport data by all potential service providers, which is essential to ensure fair competition and effective functioning of the single market, and for municipalities and regulators to improve mobility services.  On the collaborative economy and regulation of shared passenger transport, the Commission has made it clear, notably in the communication on the collaborative economy, that it supports initiatives that help make better use of resources and that make the lives of citizens easier. We have also made it clear that all undertakings must observe Union law, as well as applicable national law, which itself must be in line with Union law. Within this framework, however, it is up to the undertakings concerned to choose their business model. At the same time, we have encouraged Member States to take the emergence of new technological solutions and business models as an opportunity to modernise decades-old regulations, and only apply restrictions if fully justified, proportionate and non-discriminatory.  When looking at the legislation and applying it to new business models, the Commission encourages Member States to take into account the particularities of the collaborative economy. In this context, thresholds may be a good means to distinguish between professional providers and peer providers. Banning services should only be a last resort and should be objectively justified by reason of an overriding public interest. In the specific case of passenger transport by taxi, hire car and ride-sharing, the Commission launched a fact-finding study which has identified a huge diversity of national and local rules, resulting in a very different development on the market in each Member State.  While one can see some restrictions which are difficult to justify, we also see some good examples. More and more Member States realise the potential of technological development, as well as new ways of organising transport services. Some Member States have decided to modify and simplify their laws by removing unnecessary barriers while ensuring minimum standards. These signs are encouraging and the Commission will continue to support this process.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the transport market, traditional business models are now being joined by new business models which appear to be of interest in terms of employment and because they make the services offered more competitive, to the benefit of end consumers. But we cannot fail to say that we are concerned about the possible repercussions on working conditions, its precariousness, its safety, with the risk that the boundary between self-employed and subordinate work becomes blurred. Furthermore, digitized business models do not appear so transparent with respect to competition rules, with the risk of favoring unfair market practices, avoidance and tax evasion. We therefore need a legal framework that establishes a grid within which the need to protect the traditional market prevails, to secure workers, to guarantee consumers, to prevent the collaborative economy from taking place within the spaces of the economy and undeclared work. .

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, irrespective of my personal wish to intervene in this report, I represent here Mrs Monteiro - who excuses her absence - who is the shadow rapporteur on behalf of the PPE. I will transfer her criteria in her name, since she is absent. The report, in the opinion of Mrs. Monteiro, analyzes the new opportunities for the transport sector, especially in the area of ​​the collaborative economy. Mrs Monteiro believes that it is an important issue that current legislation takes innovation into account. In her opinion, digital applications facilitate the connection between client and company and are part of the unstoppable innovation. Ms Monteiro considers that there is too much regulation for access to the taxi profession and that Member States should not protect either one or the other, but rather find a fair solution in order to create optimal conditions for the two business models . The shadow rapporteur also calls on the Member States to update their national laws, so that they encompass an idea of ​​a collaborative economy. And I am now going to make a series of personal judgments, not without saying beforehand that my agreement with Mrs. Monteiro is absolute: the collaborative economy can and should be an element of innovation and competition, as long as it respects the basic elements of transport, such as safety and consumer protection, and do not incur unfair competition. However, the element that worries the Spanish delegation is that of light commercial vehicles. Small companies cannot use means of transport that optimize economies of scale. Mr Riquet wonders in his report, in paragraph 37, whether there are reasons to exempt light commercial vehicles from the application of European regulations. Well, as his title indicates — New opportunities for small businesses in transport—, this is a report that aims to facilitate the integration of small and medium-sized companies in the transport market.It is therefore incoherent, in our view, to question the exemption for light commercial vehicles, since it would be contrary to what is intended in the title of the report.Therefore, we understand and see as a hindrance the tightening of the administrative conditions for smaller vehicles.Light cargo vehicles represent a very small part of the freight transport sector in Europe.Consequently, the Spanish delegation of the PPE will vote against paragraph 37 of this report, without prejudice to our final positive vote on this good work, as will be the vote of the entire PPE Group on this report, which we find positive and very realistic.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like, from the outset, as co-rapporteur for the S&D Group, to thank the rapporteur, Mr Riquet, who has created a good atmosphere and good collaboration in the team he has coordinated. . The report was very important for me and my group, because we had the opportunity to propose the improvement of the situation of SMEs by creating new opportunities for these SMEs in the field of transport. There are challenges for small transport companies and we, the Parliament, the Commission, the Council, but also the national authorities need to support them. That is why I consider this report important and I hope that it will be supported and voted on by all political groups. I emphasized in the report the need for the Member States and the Commission to take appropriate measures to combat anti-competitive practices on the part of the large integrated groups. The Commission needs to increase transparency and ask it to publish a roadmap on the release of data on publicly funded transport. We must not run away from the truth: small businesses cannot enter public or even publicly funded urban urban transport precisely because of the large integrated groups. I have proposed several amendments to this report and I thank the rapporteur, but also the shadow rapporteurs for the way in which we negotiated the compromises. The report also refers to social dumping and social protection and consumer protection. The report calls for the establishment of cooperation structures between small transport enterprises, research institutes and local and regional authorities, in order to better organize urban and interurban mobility, in order to respond effectively to the emergence of services and products, including to those offered by SMEs. I am also co-chair of the SME intergroup and I have had many debates on SMEs, including in the field of SMEs. transport. Mr Riquet mentioned many of them: access to finance, the issue of documentation, bureaucracy, costs. The report calls on the Commission, in collaboration with the national, regional and local authorities of the Member States, to develop a communication platform to advise and train SMEs, as it has often been found that SMEs, small businesses, chosen, avoids expanding into the transport sector due to the increased risks involved in cross-border activity. We need to better understand, Commissioner, that small transport companies are inherent in European mobility, SMEs are creative, innovative, but they need to have a favorable environment in order to grow. We need to support small businesses to turn challenges into opportunities, especially when it comes to ICT. The model of the collaborative economy has also made its presence felt in the field of transport, with more flexible forms of work and this is beneficial. We must not forget that small transport companies are particularly important in hard-to-reach regions, in remote areas, in rural areas, but also in the peripheral areas of urban areas. That is why this own-initiative report of the European Parliament is important and I support its vote. I conclude by thanking my colleagues who tabled amendments and the rapporteur, Mr Riquet, who took an objective position in negotiating the compromises. I hope, Commissioner, that you will take into account the recommendations in the report.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the transport sector have to face many constraints: tax, environmental or social barriers that effectively hinder their functioning. Overcoming these barriers is not possible without friendly legislation. The digital revolution has created many new opportunities for small and medium-sized transport companies. New transport-sharing business models are the most popular of these opportunities, so we badly need a sensible and comprehensive assessment of their impact on the entire transport services market. Both the self-regulation of this segment and the imposition of too many restrictions on it will not be conducive to innovation, safety and protection of the rights of consumers and employees. It is certainly not about giving too much importance to the social aspects, which this report unfortunately tends to do, but about a balanced and coordinated response to the challenges of the digital revolution at European level. Undoubtedly, all forms of state protectionism, which we have witnessed for many months, especially in the area of ​​road freight transport, are detrimental to the development of small transport companies. When designing the future of the European road haulage market, the European Commission should remember that it is this sector of small and medium-sized enterprises, and that most of them are companies from Poland and other Central European countries.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate Mr Riquet on this report that suggests a powerful work program for small European transport companies to adapt to two major challenges: the evolution that will induce this sector to intensive use of new technologies and their adaptation to new business models that come from the hand of the collaborative economy. Thus, these companies will play a decisive role in the fight against climate change, at the same time that they will be in the best position to solve the great challenge facing the integration of the different modes of transport into an intelligent mobility system , the solution to the challenge of the «last kilometer», both in non-urban spaces and in cities. Encouraging current and future entrepreneurs to take advantage of this opportunity requires properly promoting the transport market unit. Furthermore, as this report points out, it requires a change in the philosophy of regulation to adapt it to the new reality, to favor innovation and fair competition, and to guarantee consumer rights. In addition, it must recognize and take advantage of the momentum that many local authorities are already dedicating to promote this transformation with small and local operators. If we are correct, the change will be a source of quality jobs. Commissioner, it only remains for me to urge the Member States once again to fulfill the investment priorities set out in the TEN-T because they are necessary to allow this evolution. For this reason, they add value at European level and that is why they must be concluded.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, thank you, Commissioner, thank you to your colleagues for your good cooperation and, of course, especially to our rapporteur, Mr Riquet. New digital transport services for the transport sector are emerging like mushrooms in the rain and good so. I am particularly pleased that there is exceptional activity on the front of small and medium-sized enterprises and startups. New services and new operators will bring the much-needed ease of use and user-orientation to transport and help to combine different modes of transport into functioning travel chains. Legislators and, at national level, that here in Brussels are a little confused as to how to proceed and whether new regulation is needed to guide development, or rather the deregulation of existing regulation. Complicating matters is the fact that the new services are not exclusively transport services, but are increasingly also digital services or combinations of several different transport services, in which case the old rules of the game are no longer exclusively valid. Our legislators must now be like curling parents who, as if paving the way and creating the conditions for action, but allow the industry and the companies themselves to do the work. I would venture to say that I am personally familiar with this issue quite a lot and come to the conclusion that the most prominent feature is now create an EU-level responsibilities in the security and guarantee of consumer protection rules of the game.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, every day, European citizens ask themselves the question of their transport, of everyday life. They live, like us, with this digital wave which is a positive development and which leads to the multiplication of platforms which heckle our existing models. Among these platforms, we find new ethical business models that pursue values ​​of sharing, climate protection and social bonding. This is a little bit on this that the collaborative economy should be based and, from there, we should say that a collaborative economy can benefit everyone, whether it is the manufacturer, the driver, the passengers or the environment. Our role, as legislator, is to anticipate technological upheavals without slowing down innovation. This is why I want to say that it is urgent to have a strict regulatory framework and I am making this appeal to the European Commission because there are still too many legal uncertainties, which are obstacles to the development of the collaborative economy. In this regulatory framework, we must, on the one hand, define what a collaborative economy platform that is based on cost-sharing as opposed to platforms that provide professional services and, on the other hand, harmonize the rules at European level. There are two other reasons for regulating the collaborative economy as well. First of all, to protect it from itself because it is a sector which is still not very mature and which has a tendency towards monopoly. Then, rules should be established so that competition is not unfair and does not encourage fiscal dumping or social dumping. This risk of dumping exists. It's when a small category of people use collaborative platforms to make a business out of it. It is therefore on this condition that the collaborative economy will be able to flourish in a regulatory framework ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my support for the report and highlight some points which are a priority for us. The first concerns the environment and the need to put small businesses in the conditions, including economic ones, to comply with the new environmental policies deriving from the Paris agreements and to be able to amortize any new higher costs and charges. We are also in favor of new opportunities for collaborative business models, paying particular attention to social problems, possible distortions, social dumping and problems related to security. We favor collaborative models but we are keeping pace to stem these problems. We then welcome the revision of the current regulation for the rules on international transport and cabotage. Since it came into force, there have been enormous problems, especially related to some forms of transport and in particular to heavy road transport. Finally, we are promoting universal internet access for a greater collaborative economy by guaranteeing free internet access for all.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: - First of all, I would like to thank Mr Riquet for the rapporteurship. You see, even at our age you can still be very innovative and that is important in this report. We are dealing here with a crown jewel of the European economy. The combination of small and medium-sized businesses, start-ups, the sharing economy and the Internet, together with transport, is truly a source of innovation and new employment. And I also want to call on the Commissioner to be flexible with new pilot projects. There are thousands of people in Europe who want to start small businesses in the sharing economy, in the transport world and as a start-up. We must use that. And sometimes the European rules for subsidies are very strict. Then, Madam President, a minute about small commercial vehicles. My colleague de Grandes has already mentioned it. We have to take a good look at that, because there are many of those small vans that ignore the rules for transport in Europe, for example at the point of the tachograph. We have to take a good look at that. Don't panic, but an investigation.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, I would also like to congratulate colleague Riquet on his report, which combines the lightness of the idea that one day we will be able to get on a mobile phone - or that he will bring us breakfast directly and take us home - with the solidity of his reflections on the need for funding and the need for a legislative framework. And, therefore, I also encourage the Commission and the Commissioner present here to further implement investments on the part of synergies in the CEF between transport, telecommunications and energy or also investments in urban nodes, precisely to facilitate the small transportation companies. Also Apple and Google at the time were small and, therefore, I also warn that it cannot be, on the other hand, that the gaps in the European Union regulations in social or tax matters serve for some companies, even if they are small For now, they escape national regulations in matters as important as consumer safety, in terms of quality and safety, responsibility - we have asked travel agencies: they must also have responsibility -, taxation, of course - He has talked about tax dumping - or labor standards, not to mention public services and their obligations.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, small and medium-sized enterprises are the main driver of the European economy, creating jobs for two thirds of employed Europeans. In addition, they add value because they know the local market very well and are characterized by quick reactions and closeness to customers. The transport sector in particular is one of those areas in which small transport companies play a crucial role in the functioning of mobility in Europe. Transport companies face significant challenges to meet growing demand, mobility and are often pushed out of the market by monopolies, and are under extreme pressure. An example of such pressure is the requirements introduced by France and Germany to impose a minimum wage in this sector, disproportionately restricting the freedom to provide services and the free movement of goods. And that, in my opinion, is discrimination. Any change in legislation must take account of fundamental freedoms in the European Union and must in no way restrict fair competition and entrepreneurship.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I too would like to congratulate Dominique Riquet on a very good report, and I would like to draw attention to the fact that digitalisation should focus on passengers, on the consumers, rather than what I may call the complex approach. Creativity of SMEs, all that provides for enormous opportunities, but based on the condition (and that is something that you have stressed, Madam Commissioner) of an internal market without barriers – of course, fully respecting the Community legislation, and national laws for sure, but at the same time, in this framework, by addressing eventual anti-competitive approaches and measures, giving an opportunity to new business models. That will create the opportunities, that will provide for  better services, focus on the consumers but also on creating jobs. I think we should maintain that approach.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Mr President, this report calls on Member States to stop over-regulating small transport businesses, which I find most hypocritical. Across the UK, self-employed hauliers and SME hauliers have been drowned in EU legislation. The driver’s certificate of professional competence has crippled the UK’s small transport businesses, costing them an absolute fortune. This has led to a massive drop in the number of qualified drivers and also to a significant shortage of drivers. The EU should stop criticising Member States and start looking a little bit closer to home.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Two thirds of all workers in the EU work in small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why we should pay particular attention to their activities, facilitate their creation, enable them to grow and, in particular, not overload them with bureaucracy. Particularly in the transport sector, small transport companies play the decisive role in securing the mobility of tomorrow. In terms of the first and last leg of a trip, they are simply essential. This report makes it clear that SMEs are finding it difficult to meet the growing challenges successfully due to increasing environmental regulations and the sometimes unfair competitive pressure from monopoly-like market structures. Thanks to technological innovations, the transport sector is also dominated by digitization. The development of the collaborative economy is really significant. It is precisely this that promotes sustainable forms of mobility, which above all require legal certainty. In connection with multimodal travel in particular, I consider it absolutely essential that the information on mobility services offered by SMEs is included in the publicly accessible travel information and planning services. This is the only way to make the services of even the smallest transport companies accessible to a large group of people. Of course, easier access to loans and public financial aid is necessary for these companies. Even start-ups should benefit from EFSI support. We reject complicated administrative procedures for this. Cross-border business activities deserve to be promoted.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the dramatic growth of the digital economy is about to radically change the transport market. I welcome Mr Riquet's report, which gives us an opportunity to reflect on new business models. These, it is true, come with new services and a degree of flexibility that is difficult to match by traditional players, but also with a number of new challenges, especially if we refer to the balance between competitiveness and the maintenance of social rights. In this context, we should start with the question: what is our role, as legislators, in the face of the challenges posed by the phenomenon of the collaborative economy? In other words, can we apply the old rules, adapt them, or come up with new ones? It is essential that the European Parliament sends a clear message that it supports innovation and that it can turn the current debate into a set of concrete rules for market players. I also believe that the success of a single and integrated transport market depends on the existence of common rules for all Member States. As a MEP with left-wing views, I believe that technological advancement can also bring significant improvements to transport employees, especially in terms of related abuses ... (The President withdrew the floor.)

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Small and medium-sized enterprises are a key factor supporting economic growth and creating new jobs, therefore it is important to eliminate all barriers to their development. Light commercial vehicles play an important role in the European transport sector. In recent years, we have observed a significant increase in small and medium-sized transport companies, which translated into an over 30% increase in demand for these vehicles and services they provide. Therefore, I would like to pay tribute to the report presented and express my support for those provisions that support the development of SMEs, talk about the need to reduce burdens, overregulate and support access to finance and credit. However - like the Spanish or Portuguese delegation - I cannot agree with paragraph 37 and the Polish delegation will vote against its adoption. The proposal that light vehicles should be subject to the same requirements as large transport vehicles carrying tens of tons of goods at a time will have a negative impact on small European transport companies mainly engaged in transporting goods over short distances. We are concerned that this would not only result in an additional administrative burden, increasing costs, but would also limit their development and competitiveness.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Union's transport policy cannot ignore the key role that small and medium-sized enterprises play in this sector, generating economic activity, creating jobs and helping to make management more efficient.mobility in Europe.The added value of these companies is found in particular in the most remote areas, where knowledge of the local market and proximity to the customer are crucial.In this context, it is important to emphasize collaborative models, which are increasingly widespread, which represent an additional resource for the sustainable development of connectivity, especially in peripheral, mountain and rural regions, with indirect benefits also for the tourism sector.Last, but of fundamental importance, is the issue of access to the market, with respect to which I believe it is essential to ensure fair conditions regardless of the size of individual companies.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - Mr President, I would also like to thank Mr Riqueta, under whose leadership, for this excellent report. I think it's very progressive and I am glad that both the Committee on Transport as the Commission was very positive traffic digitalization and jakamistalouden brought about new opportunities. We have invested billions in the Internet and high-speed connections, which now enable completely new types of services in the transport sector, where we can often operate more efficiently in terms of the environment and time and, above all, deliver services that consumers are very happy with. At the same time, however, I am very concerned about what the report draws attention to: still many member states rather tend to prevent these new innovations to market entry, rather than that they should encourage companies to develop new services and innovations. That would be important to change. The report rightly emphasizes the need to reform regulation to support these new services and innovations, and on the other hand, regulation must also be proportionate to the size of the business economy. In particular, it must be borne in mind that regulation must not become too burdensome for small businesses. The challenge for us is, of course, that technology is evolving much faster than legislation is keeping pace, consumer expectations are evolving much faster and, as a result, legislation must be very enabling and flexible. But it is excellent that such a report has been made and is very positive and encouraging about this new digital economy.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. This is a very important subject and special thanks are due to the rapporteur, Mr Riquet, as SMEs play a significant role in transport on European roads and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. With a small share capital, young entrepreneurs can also get involved, so launching transport services is a good opportunity for young entrepreneurs. Unfortunately, however, I feel contrary to this positive line in paragraph 37 of the report, which questions the derogation for passenger cars, claiming that their presence in international traffic is unjustifiably high. It should be noted that there are no reliable data on this, and that if these carriers also had to comply with all the requirements for vehicles over 3.5 tonnes, this could impose a disproportionately high additional financial and administrative burden on them. Therefore, the Hungarian delegation cannot support this point of the report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, transport is a vital part of economic and social life. Unfortunately, Greece also lags far behind the other Member States in this area, as carriers in Greece waste valuable time due to road congestion, which leads to non-compliance with mandatory rules for working hours and driving time. and rest of the drivers. In addition, carriers are affected by the measures taken under the Memorandum, Commissioner Mrs Bulc, and are in a bad financial position. Also, the European Union-Russia Cold War conflict has had an adverse effect on carriers in the European South. Greek transporters have lost 10 million euros from the Russian embargo, as at least 40% of Greek agricultural products were transported to Russia by truck. A minimum European average wage should therefore be introduced, the unfair practices used by France and Germany as well as social dumping should be stopped and the rights of small transport companies should be protected.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Small transport enterprises are an important part of the European economy, not least because they contribute to jobs and growth. In many areas, they significantly improve the accessibility and quality of passenger transport. Small transport companies have developed their activities and function well where there is no rail infrastructure and road transport is insufficient, facilitating the mobility of inhabitants. This is an important task from the point of view of territorial and social cohesion. Therefore, I believe that these companies should be supported and appropriate conditions for development should be created. I agree with the author of the report that we need better coordination between local and regional authorities and these actors, not only in urban areas but also in remote, less populated areas with weaker infrastructure. Their cooperation is essential to meet challenges such as digitization, reducing emissions or making good use of resources from the Structural Funds.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this was a really good and constructive discussion and I thank the honourable Members for all their contributions and comments and for the debate. It shows me that Parliament is taking a position in many respects very similar to that of the Commission, especially when it comes to modernisation of the regulatory frameworks. Among other things, emerging business models may indeed raise problems of legal uncertainty with regard to the application of the existing legal framework. We also agree that we need to distinguish between profit-making and cost-sharing activities. This is, again, in line with the Commission’s communication on the collaborative economy. In that communication, besides a clear definition of terms, the Commission also made very clear that operators in the collaborative economy should comply with rules that are well designed to ensure consumer protection, safety and security, adequate working conditions and training and fiscal compliance. With this report, Parliament calls on the Commission and Member States to combat anti-competitive practices. The reaction of Member States to the emergence of new players has indeed been diverse and the Commission is following the developments. Whether or not the Commission needs to intervene will depend on case-by-case assessment. When appropriate, the Commission may use its competition-policy tools to guarantee the proper functioning of the market with access for SMEs. We take note of Parliament’s call on the Commission to continue monitoring the developments and impact of the collaborative economy and the Digital Agenda. Monitoring exchanges of best practices and enforcement are among the key actions that the Commission intends to pursue, as explained in the communication of 2 June 2016. Here, I can also assure you, once again, that we keep SMEs constantly in mind. Not long ago, I was one of them. Therefore we will be paying special attention to ensure open systems and access to customers, especially in the digital age, while at the same time ensuring that safety is not compromised.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: protractor. - Mr President, dear Commissioner, dear Violeta, dear colleagues, first of all I thank you for your contribution to the clarity and quality of the contributions which have been made, as well as for the excellent spirit which presided over the establishment of this report. Beyond the large public transport companies, the major part of transport in Europe is therefore provided by these millions of craftsmen, self-employed persons and SMEs who have to face environmental challenges and technological progress which upset their operating conditions. and life. Europe should support their adaptation to these rapid changes by improving their environment and focusing its action on the following priorities: more efficient, simpler and less costly regulation, more transparent, stable and attractive taxation, access to credit which must be simplified, accelerated and more effective, as well as social protection and fiscal equality. The explosive development in transport of these new platform economy technologies also requires a rapid and powerful effort on our part, namely a harmonization of access and exercise regulations which are sometimes corporatist and differ greatly from one another. territory to another, as well as a convergence effort to move towards a European definition and regulation of digital platform activities in transport. A word on amendment 37 which has been mentioned several times. It is by no means a question of regulating, and even less of over-regulating, it is a question of asking the Commission to kindly study a new problem, which is that of light commercial vehicles in international transport. This completely unpredictable phenomenon, moreover, but new, worried a certain number of Member States enough for nine of them to refer the matter to the Commission in a letter which was co-signed by nine ministers. I thinks that it is not a question of regulating, it is a question of seeing clearly and, if new elements are added, of thinking about them all together.Finally, this own-initiative report - this modest report, Commissioner - aims to encourage the European Commission to propose as quickly and effectively as possible the measures necessary to support harmonization and convergence of all types.companies in the transport sector.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.The voting will take place on Thursday, November 24, 2016.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - The impact of the digital economy and the rapid development of transport platforms is a reality that the European legislator can no longer ignore. The challenges are numerous, from the protection of workers' rights to access to the profession of driver through the legal responsibility of platforms. The report presented to us contains positive elements in the fight against social dumping, driver training and even the fight against monopolies. I also welcome the distinction between platforms that generate real profits and the collaborative economy, which is fundamentally based on cost sharing. However, I regret that this report does not take into account the risk of precariousness for drivers using platforms like Uber. I also do not agree with paragraphs that seek to limit the ability of states to regulate these platforms; this is at odds with the message sent in favor of a modernized regulatory framework. Finally, I consider that carriers using these platforms should be regulated as “transport companies”. The digital medium is only a tool at the service of the provider who offers a well-defined service: the transport of individuals!

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on international air transport agreements by Michael Cramer, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (O-000128/2016 - B8-1807 / 2016) (2016/2961 (RSP)).

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! In December 2015 the Commission adopted an Aviation Strategy for Europe. As part of this strategy, it was proposed to start negotiations at EU level on aviation safety agreements with Japan and China and on aviation agreements with China, Turkey, Mexico, the six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Armenia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations ASEAN. On March 8, 2016, the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with China and Japan on aviation safety agreements. On June 7, 2016, the start of negotiations on aviation agreements at EU level with ASEAN, Turkey, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates was approved. The Council is currently still discussing draft negotiating directives for the start of negotiations at EU level on aviation agreements with China, Mexico, Armenia and the remaining four member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council. The Committee on Transport and Tourism - not Transport and Tourism - put the following questions to the Commission in this context: What objectives, priorities and timeframes have been set for the negotiation of aviation agreements for which the Commission has received the negotiating directives? What is the state of the negotiating directives on which the Council still has to decide? How does the Commission intend to ensure that Parliament is immediately and fully informed of all stages of the negotiations, pursuant to Article 218 (10) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union? How does the Commission intend to ensure adequate transparency and access to files during the negotiations? Can the Commission guarantee that Parliament and the Council will be informed at the same time, before and after each negotiation round - on an equal footing, I would say? Can the Commission confirm that it does will not seek the provisional application of concluded aviation agreements until Parliament has given its approval to the agreements?Commissioner, I look forward to your answer.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Cramer.We will enter into a semantic discussion about the difference between tourism and tourism.In the landscape where I come from, we try very hard not to treat tourists as strangers.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Mr Cramer, thank you very much for all your questions. I hope I will be able to respond to them adequately. Since the publication of the Commission communication on developing the external aviation agenda, the EU and the Commission have been successfully pursuing aviation agreements in the neighbourhood and with key external partners. In the aviation strategy last December, we announced an ambitious external aviation agenda to ensure that our industry can be where growth is, and can deliver benefits to the European consumer and the EU economy. To that end, the Commission proposed to negotiate EU air transport agreements with a number of partner countries – China, the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), Turkey, Mexico, all six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council and Armenia – as well as EU air safety agreements with China and Japan. The objective is to tap into those markets and improve commercial opportunities within a modern regulatory framework. EU transport agreements with these partners aim to provide for market access based on the acceptance of certain common rules. In the case of neighbourhood countries, the EU expects the partner country to agree to implement the entire EU aviation acquis. The Commission aims to replicate in new air transport agreements the positive impact of the existing agreements. These already cover almost half of today’s passengers flying in and out of the EU, and deliver consumer benefits through a modern, transparent and enabling regulatory framework, better connections and lower fares. With all the countries with which we sign such agreements we also see dramatic increases in traffic. EU bilateral aviation safety agreements promote cooperation to ensure high levels of civil aviation safety and environmental compatibility. They also serve the purpose of facilitating and promoting trade and investment relations for aeronautic products and services. Through the negotiation of such air safety agreements with China and Japan, the Commission is seeking to replicate the benefits that have been achieved from similar agreements with the United States of America, Canada and Brazil. So what is the state of play of negotiations? On 7 March 2016, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations for bilateral air safety agreements with China and Japan. A first round of negotiations with China will take place in December in Beijing and a first round of negotiations with Japan is expected in early 2017. On 7 June 2016, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Qatar, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), ASEAN and Turkey. The first round of negotiations has taken place with Qatar, ASEAN and Turkey. The next rounds are planned for early 2017. Concerning the UAE, there is no confirmation yet on the starting date for negotiations. The dialogue so far has been very constructive and the interest of all parties in making progress is already clear. We intend to sustain a quick pace throughout the negotiations. Further requests for authorisation to launch negotiations with Armenia, Mexico, China and the four remaining countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council, namely Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, and Saudi Arabia, are still on the table at the Council. We expect that the Commission will be authorised by the Council in December to open negotiations with Armenia. Regarding cooperation with the European Parliament, as you know, honourable Members, the Commission considers it very important that Parliament is kept fully informed of progress in the aviation negotiations. The modalities for the Commission’s contribution to keeping Parliament informed were agreed between our two institutions and set out in the framework agreement. Good cooperation on these matters must continue, as outlined in my letter of March this year to the Chair of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, Mr Cramer. My staff are working in this spirit to keep interested members of the Transport Committee informed about the state of play in the negotiations, as provided for in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, concluded earlier this year between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, on improved practical arrangements for cooperation and information sharing in the context of international agreements. These negotiations provide a good opportunity to discuss further the modalities of our cooperation on these matters.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Indeed, the big question tonight is: how will the European Parliament be involved in the negotiation of international aviation agreements? Since the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Commission has the right and duty to negotiate such agreements on behalf of the 28 Member States. And the European Parliament, as you heard from our President, would like to be involved in those negotiations. But Mr President, I have learned that parliaments should not negotiate themselves. That is dangerous. We have all kinds of views, we have all kinds of wings in this house, we do not have to negotiate ourselves. However, Madam President, and I very much agree with the Transport Committee and the Tourism Committee, there is indeed a big difference between Fremdenverkehr and tourism. Because tourism sounds much more sympathetic. And I ask Ms Bulc to keep that information flow going. Indeed, interim reports on the negotiations would be very welcome. Mr President, we should not underestimate the cultural differences between the European Union and a number of our treaty partners. The level playing field that we would like, for example with the Gulf States, but also the issue of illegal state aid, as well as the social aspects, are of great importance to the European Parliament. And I trust, Mr President, that the European Commission will properly fulfill this new task from the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the air transport agreements between the Union and third countries, with a particular focus on new and expanding markets, represent an important opportunity for Europe's international connectivity. The negotiation of such agreements is a crucial stage in this context, as it will have a decisive influence on their eventual content. For these reasons, I would like to emphasize how essential the full and constant involvement of the European Parliament is, as expressly provided for in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It is not just a question of transparency: being able to assess the issues at stake, knowing the timing and the state of the art, before and after each negotiation round, means being able to consciously choose whether to support or not, in the future, a potential agreement reached. In this sense, I believe that the opportunities created by these agreements cannot and must not prevail over the need to ensure fair and transparent market conditions for EU airlines. At the same time, I firmly believe that in the negotiation phase it is essential to ensure that the respective policies of the parties concerned support high levels of social protection. Lastly, I would like to underline that the role of the European Parliament should not be limited to being only cognitive but also proposing content.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as we know, aviation agreements date back to 1913 when France and Germany exchanged notes over the movement of their airships. Following phenomenal technological advances during World War II, the transition that moved us from airships to biplanes to the invention of the jet engine meant we were now developing the ability to move more and more people and freight around the world. As a result, in 1944, 54 countries signed the Chicago Convention, which is an important reminder that these agreements predate the foundation of the United Nations. In 1946 the first bilateral between the UK and the US became the model. This consisted of a schedule which outlined prices and capacity in order to regulate air traffic between two countries. These were registered under the auspices of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), where additional criteria were lodged. The EU court judgment of 2002 sent a clear message: that, in order to have the EU nature of our carriers recognised, Member States had to allow access for the relevant third country.  To conclude, while it is vitally important that we are updated with the progress of negotiations, we should be aware that unrealistic demands on third-country airlines who wish to access the EU will ultimately damage the opportunities for our airlines to expand their networks worldwide. Ultimately, these agreements are about trade, jobs and wealth and it is vital that we take a pragmatic approach.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to underline that many of us have negotiated numerous international agreements and we know that there has to be a certain balance. Obviously, while we would love to be consulted on every single proposal that is made, sometimes negotiating techniques mean that this is not always possible. But that is one side of the story. The second part of the story – and you have heard it – is that many of us have different concerns. Some have social concerns, some have concerns about security, safety or trade, some want to see a liberal approach etc. I must say that the Parliament is very lively today on these issues. While I might not share some of the concerns, I do appreciate the fact that the Parliament has to be engaged. We need to find the right balance. This is perhaps the way to avoid unpleasant surprises later on. This means that we can have solid interaction with the Commission from time to time in plenary as we are doing today, but the Committee and the Commission services should be in intensive contact on the relevant issues to be negotiated. That is a message to the Commission. The message for us is that the agreements are an opportunity. It is something that can address a number of the issues that we are legitimately concerned about. Some of you mentioned social issues and some mentioned anti-competitive measures. I am the rapporteur for aviation strategy, and I would like to see a fair competition clause in the bilateral agreements. This is just one example, but I think that we need to understand that, while there has to be a balance, we also need to address these agreements as an opportunity to settle some of the problems and some of the concerns, but also maximise the effect for our consumers, our industries and our airliners and to avoid counterproductive results.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the development of air transport, both within Europe and with third countries, is very important. It is good that the mode of transport is being developed strategically, ambitiously and in a coordinated way. There is much to be expected from the ongoing agreement negotiations with the partner countries, and I therefore fully agree with President Cramer's request to keep Parliament informed of the progress of the negotiations. I am a little worried if the Commission now has too many balls in the air at the same time. I hope that there will be clear progress in the ongoing negotiations before negotiations are opened with new partners. In addition, I hope for a very honest and straightforward approach to possible situations where negotiations at EU level threaten to thwart. In this case, Member States must be able to continue and develop cooperation with third countries, including on the basis of bilateral agreements.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, information and transparency vis-à-vis the European Parliament and citizens are essential, especially in a sector such as aviation, which involves millions of passengers every year. I would like to know from the Commission how it intends to address certain specific issues in these agreements, such as environmental, social, security and competitiveness. As regards the environment and safety, we are well aware that not all third countries show the same attention and concern and it is therefore necessary that European standards be maintained. As a Union we must pursue the Paris objectives and we must take all necessary measures to that end, including, for example, the need to choose the shortest routes and not the least expensive ones for airlines. It is also necessary to underline the importance of the correlation between social aspects and those related to safety. No less important, then, is the security linked to the fight against terrorism. Finally, I would like to ask the Commissioner how she intends to protect European industry and fair competition, given the state aid rules in our internal market and the growing presence of foreign capital which often falls outside the scope of these rules. .

name: Andor DELI
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, I am really pleased that this topic has made it to the plenary agenda. It is evident and maybe normal to have a certain level of rivalry between European institutions, but I am convinced that the European Parliament can help the Commission’s efforts to achieve strong and sustainable deals and agreements. This is true for all policy areas, but it is very evident in the aviation sector, given the fact that it is a very complex global industry and service area.  As one of the two co-legislators the European Parliament could work more effectively and swiftly if it were involved in the whole negotiation process from the very beginning. I am afraid that this fact is not getting the proper level of attention. For example, at the beginning of October, the EP delegation got the opportunity to participate at the 39th plenary session of the ICAO in Montreal, of which I was also part. We arrived for the final days of the difficult negotiations on global market-based measures (GMBM) and other dossiers. If we had been allowed to participate from an earlier stage, it would help us to understand the whole process and the reasons behind certain decisions much better. This kind of insight could help us when it comes to European legislation and the approval of these agreements in Parliament. I do hope that during the ICAO visit this became evident for the Commission as well, so we should build on this experience also when it comes to the new aviation agreements and negotiations. I kindly ask you, Commissioner, to take these arguments into consideration when planning future negotiations in the aviation sector.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, I also join in the interest in agreements, both in terms of security and air services, with all the States, with all the countries that have been appointed - in some, as you know, we still have other debates in quality of reserves—. And, therefore, it seems fundamental to me to insist on the need for these agreements to be established on the basis of reciprocity and, of course, in the most absolute respect of the international standards established by ICAO, in terms of environmental requirements. and services, such as the ILO in the case of social rules. And, of course, I am also with my colleagues and with my colleagues regarding the need for greater transparency and communication as daily as possible with this Parliament. You know that we are precisely open to enlargement and that we are against protectionism in that sense, which is reductionist. But in these types of agreements, the more transparency and the more support that we will provide, the better results you will have.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Dear Commissioner,Two conclusions can be clearly drawn from this debate today.The first is that these contracts are needed and that we all believe they are needed.And the second conclusion - that we do not know anything about them, that we are uninformed, that the European Commission ignores Art.218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.Ladies and gentlemen!Learn from reality!Now there are huge protests against TTIP and against CETA.Most of these protests, ladies and gentlemen, are precisely due to the fact that the European Parliament and stakeholders were not informed about the progress of the negotiations, where it was going, etc. And today too: today the Commissioner answered a few questions, butit seems clear that we want more of these answers.Ladies and gentlemen!Learn from reality!

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Commissioner Bulc for joining us tonight because I know she came all the way from Warsaw from the high-level conference on drones. The point I want to make is that the Commission recently forwarded to the secretariat of the Committee on Transport and Tourism EU restricted information regarding the air agreements with ASEAN. An email from the Transport Committee secretariat was sent to some MEPs – not all, only a few – with the following information, and I quote, ‘Documents are accessible on a need-to-know basis to the following authorised persons: chairs, vice—chairs, coordinators, rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs and staff involved in the specific file.’ I have one question: why not extend the right to know to all interested MEPs, given that restricted documents are to be consulted individually in a secure reading room? My second question, Commissioner, is how will you debrief Parliament after each negotiating round?

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, thank you Commissioner for coming to respond to the question, and I would also like to thank those who have brought us to this point. I am sure, Commissioner, that you hear from the floor here tonight the many concerns that various Members have. They want to be involved, and the point has been made very clearly by a number of colleagues that if you could engage early with Parliament and get its views on board, it will save trouble or conflict down the road. I hope that that will not come, but the views of parliamentarians are important and I hope that you will take them on board.  I very much welcome the agreements that you are hoping to make with other countries, and I think they are very important. You said it yourself: it is so that EU airlines can tap in to other markets. I think that that is important. We tend to see it so much from the other side: it is about other airlines coming here and availing themselves of the lucrative market that is the European Union. However, we should look at it from the other said too, and the value that is there for European airlines to tap into markets and to bring customers, those who would be carrying out business and passengers to those markets. Indeed on the return leg too it would bring tourists, business and consumers to Europe. The facts speak for themselves. Previous air agreements have been very successful and have led to a growing aviation market, so I really would appeal to you following tonight’s debate to set up structures so that the European Parliament can be informed and be kept up to date on the progress and the content of the negotiations.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the negotiation of the multiple agreements that the European Union has undertaken in the field of commercial aviation obliges us to make an effort of transparency, because their exercise is the basis of trust. I believe that it is an obligation to make known calendars, interests at stake, dates and objectives foreseen in these processes, as well as that the Treaties are complied with with regard to the information that this Parliament must receive and the moment in which it must do so like the European Council and before and after each negotiating round. Finally, it must be ensured that the agreements are only implemented after the approval of this House. I think the protocol of clarity and transparency that this question raises solves any doubt about the progress of a negotiating process. Obviously, it does not guarantee that everyone agrees with the contents of an agreement reached under these conditions, but we will avoid criticism for opacity in the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, aviation plays an important role in the European economy, supporting 5.5 million jobs, contributing € 110 billion to the European Union's GDP and boosting tourism and overall economic growth. As for the EU-Turkey aviation agreement sought, however, there is strong suspicion over the European Union's recent exchanges with the Erdogan government to secure co-operation on crisis management. Commissioner Bulc, the Commission must ensure that the sovereign rights and vital interests of each Member State, and in particular Cyprus and Greece, are safeguarded in the framework of the intended aviation agreement, and that Turkey fully complies with its obligations. arising from the agreement, but also from European and international law. In addition, full transparency must be ensured during the negotiations, so that we have an idea of ​​what exactly is being discussed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for your interest in this topic and, of course, for sharing your views. I strongly believe that the changing landscape of global aviation offers many opportunities for the EU. Our successful internal EU aviation market shows that open markets are the best basis for developing our international aviation relationships. But let me stress this point: market opening must come with a clear, fair and stable regulatory environment. EU aviation agreements are our tools to achieve this and make the external aviation policy a success. We should therefore aim to capitalise on the benefits of international aviation agreements without delay and with as many partners as possible. I know that some of you might dispute that, but if we do not have enough partners with whom we can negotiate at the same time, we will lose the competitive situation and that works against us. Under the Treaty, provisional application may begin from the date of signature of an international agreement, if so decided by the Council. You know very well that there is, unfortunately, a very long delay between the signing and the conclusion of EU air transport agreements. This is due to the fact that they are mixed agreements that have to be ratified by all 28 Member States before proceeding to conclusion at EU level. We are, however, only at the beginning of the process. The first negotiating rounds were promising. I am looking forward to continuing to work with Parliament and I will keep you fully informed of the progress of the talks. The Commission is committed to transparency. For the agreements pursued as part of the aviation strategy, in particular, we have made available the documents that come under the Commission’s responsibility, as provided for in the framework agreement. We have also arranged to debrief the rapporteurs on the progress made today. Dialogue is ongoing as to how to make this information process even smoother. When addressing this we have to consider too the sensitive nature of this information and our commitment, both that of the Commission and that of Parliament, to handle it accordingly.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place in December.The motions for resolutions to be tabled under Rule 128 (5) will be announced at a later date.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: in writing. - Referring to the European Aviation Strategy adopted by the Commission in 2015 and to the newly launched aviation safety negotiations with Japan and China, as well as to EU-level air transport agreements with ASEAN, I would like to express my concern about the danger of unfair competition which could arise in the case of flights over Russian territory. Due to the sanctions imposed on Russia and its response to them, European airlines pay significantly higher rates for transit flights over Russian territory. The amounts we are talking about here are very large. Some European airlines have extensive connection networks and even operate several hundred flights over the territory of Russia. Tickets are already very expensive. Signing an agreement with, for example, China, whose airlines have significantly lower rates for transit flights over Russia, may cause many European carriers to simply collapse. In addition, I would like to point out that the Commission should strive to standardize the fees charged for flights over the territory of a given country, in this case the European Union countries. Currently, fees are uneven and there are large differences that should be harmonized.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - The aviation sector is a strong driver of economic development, job creation, mobility and trade in the European Union. The European aviation sector has developed significantly over the last 20 years thanks to market liberalization and increased demand for this type of service. Particular progress has been made in international traffic outside Europe, with extremely high growth in certain regions of the world, and is associated with a shift in the world's economic focus towards the east, especially Asia. As part of the Commission's December 2015 strategy, it is proposed to open negotiations on the signing of an EU-level air safety agreement with Japan and China and an air services agreement with China, Turkey, ASEAN, the UAE, Oman, Qatar, etc. EU aviation policy must certainly take advantage of new growing markets, as they will open up great economic opportunities in the coming decades, as it has already become clear from previous agreements that comprehensive air transport agreements with third countries are at EU level. -a effective tool. This is why some of the key questions arise: What are the objectives, issues and timeframes envisaged for the negotiation of air transport agreements? What is the current state of the remaining negotiating directives? How does the Commission plan to ensure transparency and access to documents during the negotiations?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on European security of energy supply (2016/2994 (RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ensuring a safe, reliable and uninterrupted energy supply in the EU is a top objective of European energy policy. As stated in the Energy Union Strategy, we need to adopt a broad approach on energy security, encompassing solid emergency plans, external supply diversification, enforcement of internal market rules, infrastructure development, indigenous renewable generation and energy savings.  First, the Commission has proposed a revision of the 2010 Security of Gas Supply Regulation in order to improve further the level of preparedness and resilience of our gas system.
