This proposal aims at a more robust and consistent security of support framework, in particular by strengthening regional cooperation to lay the foundation for true solidarity among Member States.  Second, the EU needs to ensure that intergovernmental agreements signed by its Member States with third countries in the area of energy are more transparent and fully compliant with EU law. To that end, the Commission proposed to significantly improve the information exchange mechanism with regard to intergovernmental agreements and non-binding instruments.  Third, the Commission adopted the LNG and gas storage strategy, which analyses the related strategic infrastructure to complete the internal energy market and the necessary projects to end the single source dependency of some Member States.  Lastly, the security of supply package included the heating and cooling strategy. The Commission strategy focuses on removing barriers to decarbonisation in buildings and industry, highlighting the role of modern technologies, increased energy efficiency and the use of renewables. In July 2015 the Commission proposed a revision of the Energy Labelling Directive and it will soon present a comprehensive review of the Renewable Energy Efficiency and Energy Performance of Buildings Directives.  But energy security also refers to the electricity sector itself, where security of supply requires us to develop a more integrated approach, based on common methods and rules, as well as regional cooperation. To ensure this, the Commission is currently considering a proposal for a new regulation on how to prevent and manage crisis situations in the European electricity sector, which would include the obligation to draw up risk preparedness plans for Member States, as well as sharing information and cooperation in times of crisis. In 2014 more than 80% of our total gas imports came from just three countries. The diversification of both suppliers and supply routes is therefore a key area to ensure security of supply, but we also need more competition that keeps prices in check. As argued in the Energy Union Strategy, the Commission has identified four main areas that can play a crucial role in enhancing gas supply diversification in Europe. First, the realisation of the Southern Gas Corridor is a landmark project as it will link the EU market to the immense gas resources around the Caspian Basin. The implementation of the project is on track and, as of 2020, it will start supplying the European market with 10 billion cubic meters of Azeri gas each year. The Caspian region has an incredible potential in terms of expanding these gas volumes. Following the signature of the Ashgabat Declaration, the Commission is working with Azerbaijan, Georgia, Turkey and Turkmenistan to extend the Southern Gas Corridor to Central Asia. Second, we have to cooperate with the countries bordering the Eastern Mediterranean in order to develop their rich resources. With regard to Eastern Mediterranean gas, a solution to the transport mode is required. Both the LNG and pipeline options are on the table.  Third, although North Africa already supplies 15% of our gas imports, the region still has untapped oil and gas reserves, both conventional and unconventional. The main challenge to realising this potential and linking it to the EU market is to overcome the current security issues and political instability. In order to realise the opportunities in our southern neighbourhood a Euro-Mediterranean Platform on Gas has been set up and is operational.  Fourth, with the emergence of new suppliers, LNG will become an important flexibility element in the coming years. In this respect, we need to ensure an optimal use of our existing and future regasification capacities. When it comes to gas supply, it is important to stress that Ukraine is – and should remain – an important transit country for Russian gas to Europe. The Commission has led trilateral negotiations between Russia, Ukraine and the EU to ensure a continuous flow of Russian gas into Ukraine and to the rest of Europe. We are also working with our Ukrainian partners to revise and upgrade the existing Memorandum of Understanding on Energy Cooperation to be fit for the common challenges ahead. We hope to sign this at the EU—Ukraine summit later this week. Let me conclude this intervention with a few words on Nord Stream II. Irrespective of the organisational set—up of Nord Stream II, the Commission’s overall negative assessment of the project’s contribution to the EU’s energy policy goals remains valid. If built, Nord Stream II would have to fully comply with applicable EU law, as the project cannot happen in a legal void or only according to Russian law. Nord Stream II, if built, has to be operated under a legal framework which also takes due account of the key principles of our energy market rules. Transport capacity from Russia is currently only used at a rate of about 50%. If constructed, Nord Stream II would, according to our estimates, increase access transmission capacity from Russia even further.  In this context, let me also mention the decision on OPAL that the Commission took a few weeks ago. This is the result of an exemption procedure under the EU’s Third Energy Package legislation for the use of an internal pipeline in the EU, and was requested by a national regulator. This decision will allow a more efficient use of the existing infrastructure and, in particular, allow competitors better access to it, thereby enhancing competition. In our view, this makes the economic case for Nord Stream II even less compelling. I am now ready to listen to your comments and then respond to them.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President. Colleagues! Imagine that we have a goal not only to run a marathon, but to run a marathon in less than three hours. If we want to achieve this, there are certain things we simply will not do - we will not drink beer every day, we will quit smoking. We know that we cannot make a living from sweet bulk alone. If a goal is to be achieved, there must be consistent action and stick to it, otherwise the goal will not be achieved. In the European Union, we have set ourselves the goal of creating a so-called Energy Union, the way a marathon is run. The Energy Union has several objectives at the same time: to reduce import dependence, to reduce CO2 emissions and to increase competition between energy suppliers so that consumers have the lowest possible prices. It is therefore completely incomprehensible that three things are happening or not happening on the part of the Commission that are actually hindering this Energy Union. The first is - what happens to a settlement? Will there be a settlement with Gazprom or not? Gazprom has long abused its dominant position, forcing Eastern Europe to pay much more for gas. We read in the press that a friendly solution is possible, where he will not have to pay anything at all. What is it? How does this fit in with our goals? The second is this Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline. European Commission, you say all the time: 'Well, it has to be connected, he has to meet ...' Clear and light, black on white it must be said! And the third is the expansion of the Opel gas pipeline specifically for Gazprom. All three of these things work against our goals of achieving the Energy Union. It's like a marathoner smoking every day, not training.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there was not, I think, all this urgency to debate, now, on European energy security. We are just weeks away from the approval of the Buzek report and we are in the absence of new and relevant facts. Of course, mind you, the security of supply is confirmed as an essential element of the European energy strategy, as well as being a responsibility of the nation states. Energy security also increasingly means fighting energy poverty on a large and small scale. But the timing, for me, is not the best, especially in view of the winter legislative package which is scheduled for November 30th and which will contain many indications on the subject, as well as focusing in particular on renewables, market design and energy efficiency. It is perhaps in that context, looking at the overall picture, that we can better understand the prospects for European energy security in the medium and long term, without however neglecting the contingent debate, such as the one on North Stream 2 or other infrastructure projects that seem go against the reasons for the Energy Union. It is therefore very important that the Commission comes out with the new proposals on 30 November in order to allow this Parliament a debate, a development of its work, adequately attentive, present and constructive.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Commissioner!The decision made by the European Commission, in favor of the position of the German regulator regarding the OPAL gas pipeline, definitely eliminates all the positive effects of the position of the European Commission with regard to the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline.it is Gazprom that is gaining a de facto hegemonic position.This decision is being protested by Polish companies such as PGNiG.Ukrainians and the Ukrainian side also raise objections.The decision undermines European law, as well as the principle of solidarity in relation to Ukraine and other states, as enshrined in the treaty on the energy community, the association agreement with Ukraine and other legal acts.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, two years ago President Juncker launched his Energy Union as one of his priorities, but since then, despite the energy security package, we have seen many actions that are at odds with this priority. It is difficult to understand how Nord Stream 2 and the OPAL pipeline, which provide Gazprom with increased access to Europe, will achieve our goals of energy security. It seems that, despite common goals to build an energy union, some Member States would still rather focus on their own energy security and their own national production. One good example is in central Europe, where Poland and the Czech Republic had to put in place barriers against inflows from the German grid. Is this uncoordinated approach really acceptable if we have a single market? When I was asked to comment on the Gazprom antitrust case, I stressed the need for much better interconnection between competition policy, single market legislation and energy policy, as the overall approach lacks coherence. This lack of coherence is to the benefit of market players and others who favour divide-and-rule policies. For every piece of bad news, there is good news, and I am happy that the Baltic Connector gas pipeline project is moving forward, but there are still many concerns. One of the concerns in our part of Europe is definitely the fact that the Baltic countries are still synchronised with the Russian and Belarus systems. I would very much like to see the Commission addressing this, too, in order to improve energy security.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, there is much talk in this House about security of energy supply, but quite little about security of access to energy. In the Spanish State, more than five million people suffer from energy poverty. As the news tragically reminded us recently, each year more people die from lack of energy supply than from traffic accidents. A right as basic as access to energy is becoming more and more a luxury. For this reason, we must recognize the right to energy as a common good and necessary for life and prohibit power outages for people in vulnerable situations - as the directives mandate. And, of course, to fulfill this right, supply must be ensured. But it is not a problem that the gas comes from Russia or beyond, as the Commission is proposing, it is a problem of not wanting to assume that the European Union must implement a true energy transition that, on the one hand, improves efficiency energy and, on the other, allow the development of renewable energies. In fact, the European Commission's own stress tests for eventual gas supply cuts say so: current infrastructures are sufficient and meeting the 2030 renewable and efficiency targets would improve the situation and reduce dependence on fossil fuels imported. For this reason, we ask the Commission and the Member States not to listen to the lobbies so much for the Winter Package and to listen more to the people. And finally, those rich resources of the Caspian Sea make us accomplices of authoritarian regimes like that of Azerbaijan. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. -  Mister President! Where does our energy come from? From Russia, Saudi Arabia, the Gulf States and many other countries that you yourself, Commissioner, have said are not reliable partners, or are very far away, or both. That is precisely why we are dependent today on having large energy stores. And you, Commissioner, pointed out that we must use underground gas storage facilities. At the same time, however, we can solve a completely different problem: We sometimes have far too much electricity in our grids, so much that we very often have to switch off wind turbines. This means that we could generate a lot more energy ourselves and then would not have to import this energy. That is an essential factor. The amount is very important. But there are already plants that turn electricity into natural gas. They are only unprofitable because the Member States impose disproportionately high taxes on them, and we have to change that. As far as the Commission is concerned, we have to do one thing: we have to increase the minimum proportion of this natural gas, which is only 0.5% today. If we do that, then we can generate significantly more energy ourselves. We don't need to import them, and that means we're making a significant contribution to our energy security.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, energy security based on federalism puts our peoples in energy insecurity.You deny States the fundamental freedom to contract, to ensure energy security at home in full sovereignty, which is contrary to subsidiarity, but above all to efficiency.Only long-term contracts led by States, through the economic visibility they give, allow long-term investment of private or State capacities.The liberalization of energy leads us into the short-termism of the cheapest and thereby weakens long-term security and profitability.By subjecting states' energy diplomacy to the goodwill of Brussels through short-termism, the liberalization of a natural monopoly and your political diplomacy, you are engaging in total energy insecurity.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Honestly, I'm fed up with hearing that you have to fight Gazprom, then Nord Stream 2 is set up, and then OPAL is reborn.If we want to achieve something in the field of energy, we have to remember that tea becomes sweet not so much from mixing as from adding sugar, i.e. we have to take care of energy supply - do not exterminate people with windmills or solar panels, but take care of real cheap energy, gas and oil.For example, Libya is such a reservoir, and if someone in the European Commission had a bit of thought, he would enter into an agreement with the Libyans from Cyrenaica, who are fighting for independence, want to break away from Libya: he entered into an agreement with them, provided them with weapons and money.We would have the oil supplies from Cyrenaica arranged that way.Unfortunately, nobody does it, only words, words, words and words are uttered.I'm really sick of this.Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: - Mr Chairman! Dear Commissioner, 2016, the year of implementation of the Energy Union, is ending. The Commission has prepared some very good proposals, including - as part of the gas package - a regulation on the security of gas supply or the decision on intergovernmental agreements. At the same time, however, the European Commission recently approved a new decision by the German regulator regarding the OPAL gas pipeline. I appreciate the Commission's efforts to make this decision based on market mechanisms, but there is still no fully competitive energy market in Central Europe, and there are even energy islands, as is well known. This makes the decision on OPAL as controversial as the plans to expand the Nord Stream. It is also contrary to the spirit of the energy union: firstly, it weakens the region's energy security by favoring one supplier, secondly, it creates tensions between EU countries and, thirdly, it harms the Union's neighbors, including Ukraine. And one more thing - I say this as the European Parliament's rapporteur for the regulation on security of gas supply: today the Council is blocking the otherwise good proposals of the Commission regarding this regulation on security of gas supply in the trialogue. Paradoxically, the Commission's decision on OPAL may reassure some countries that the interest is not important, the letter and spirit of the Energy Union are not important, and this would be the worst solution and the worst assumption for energy security.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the geostrategic dimension of energy security is certainly crucial, but energy poverty cannot wait. Commissioner Bulc, tell the Commissioner for Energy, who is absent today. We are talking about fifty million Europeans, five million Spaniards. What else needs to happen for them to take urgent action? It is urgent to grant a winter truce, to give priority to a European framework to combat energy poverty, with reduced rates and a review of taxes and charges on the electricity bill. The Commission must focus European funds for efficiency and self-generation on citizens who are victims of energy poverty, benefit them with efficiency obligations, improvements in the retail market and promotion of self-consumption. We are talking about security. We are talking about a vital right such as access to energy, which affects many people, many real people who cannot wait, Commissioner.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Security, or security, is today the greatest need of the inhabitants of Europe, probably the most important criterion for assessing or measuring the usefulness of the European Union for the inhabitants of our continent and the most important field of confrontation with populism, which lives by arousing fears and fears on our continent. Out of the many dimensions of security that Europeans need, what is actually materializing is what we call the energy union or energy security. This happens after a few lessons from the main supplier from the east, who not only abuses a dominant position but also can sometimes use gas as a political weapon. It can be seen in the regulations of the European Union, it can be seen in the possibilities of financing the development of infrastructure, which is the technical premise of European solidarity. Indeed, we note as an important step the new regulation on the security of gas supply of February 16, 2016, which, in Parliament, rests in the safe hands of Jerzy Buzek as rapporteur. But apart from those projects that build safety, we have projects that call into question this type of regulation, but both of these projects have been mentioned: it is about Nord Stream 2 and the decision to use up to 100% of the OPAL gas pipeline. All the arguments have been raised in this case, therefore I will save you time.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, how we deal with Nord Stream 2 will be a test of whether we are serious in what we talk about. The Third Energy Package was designed in order to tear down monopolies, not to allow them. The whole idea with the Energy Union is to increase security, to bring us together and to secure our supplies and ensure that we cannot be exposed to political projections from someone who would like to use energy for those means. However, Nord Stream 2 is contrary to all that. It has a political aim: to divide and undermine European cooperation. It will establish a new architecture for European energy markets. It will give Gazprom a dominant role, and it will undermine the security of a number of European countries – not only their energy security, but also their security in a wider sense. That is why it is important to hear from the Commission about what they are going to do with Nord Stream 2. We can’t at the same time say that we want to increase unity, cooperation, solidarity, energy union and secure the implementation of our legislation while allowing this to happen to undermine the security of a number of Member States in the European Union, as well as security in Europe. So I think the question is for the Commission to deal with, and to prove that we are serious about what we talk about in front of our neighbours and members.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). - Mr President, Commissioner, security of supply cannot ignore tackling energy poverty immediately. The new legislative package, to be launched by the Commission on 30 November, must tackle energy poverty on the ground. First we need a common definition. "Those who pay more than 10% of their income for energy": this is no longer an approach that works. Those who do not have the financial means, Commissioner, just do not warm up, just do not cool off in the summer, just do not pay. They do not have to pay. In Greece, indicators show that 36% of citizens are experiencing energy poverty. We need a strategy that will reduce electricity prices, increase the energy efficiency of buildings, set targets in each Member State and enable the combined use of all European funding tools, the so-called NSRF, the Juncker package ", But also the contribution of the private sector.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the European Union must take serious measures to ensure its energy security. The solution to the problem is the energy independence of the states of the Union. A common framework for action by the Union must be established with common principles, within which the Member States will retain their sovereign rights and use their wealth-producing resources. As far as Greece is concerned, it must utilize the TAP pipeline, the "Greek Stream" pipeline, but also the liquefied gas, as well as the natural gas and oil that are in the Greek EEZ. In addition, Greece must, with the help of the European Union, invest not only in alternative energy sources, but also in lignite-based power plants, while taking measures to protect the environment. In particular, Greece should be granted the exemption from the obligation to purchase gas emission allowances, as is the case for Bulgaria and Poland. Finally, measures must be taken to tackle energy poverty, as the Greek people are in danger of freezing this winter as well, as the price of heating oil has soared.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman!We have already raised the issues of European energy security dozens of times in this Chamber, but I have the impression that we are constantly confronted with the same painful reality.Although the European Union is a global economic power, when it comes to energy security, others dictate our conditions.Our high dependence on energy from third countries may also, in my opinion, pose a threat to the sovereignty of the Union.Therefore, I appeal to be able to overcome national egoisms and not let ourselves be played out and divided by third parties, for example in the implementation of projects such as Nord Stream 2. I am convinced that only by acting together and giving a strong signal about our unity and solidarity, we are able to increase the EU's energy security and act for the benefit of European consumers.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, the EU’s energy security is a top priority for the Commission. That is a fact. It is not only considered in a time of supply crisis; it has become an integral part of the EU’s energy policy and is firmly enshrined in the Energy Union strategy.  Let me now try to reply to some of the topics that many of you raised. First, Nord Stream: if built, Nord Stream 2 would have to fully comply with applicable EU law, as the project cannot happen in a legal void or only according to Russian law. It has to at least comply with the main principles of the Third Energy Package and fully respect the applicable rules of EU environmental and public procurement legislation. On topic number 2, OPAL: in general, enabling efficient use of existing pipelines contributes better to market integration and security of supply for all EU Member States than building new costly pipelines. The decision does not provide access to new supply sources or alternative supply routes in a crisis situation, but promotes closer integration of the Czech and German gas market. On the topic of the overall situation in the gas sector and climate change, the EU gas markets have been experiencing important changes in the last two to three years and are exposed to a lot of uncertainty regarding future consumption levels. Following the COP 21 Summit in Paris, opportunities are arising for the gas market as a traditional fuel. Yet, thanks to the increasing energy efficiency and continued development of renewables, the sluggish recovery of the EU economy gas consumption is likely to pick up by 2020. On the fourth topic, the Winter Package of 30 November: in July 2015, the Commission proposed a revision of the Energy Labelling Directive, and it will soon present a comprehensive review of the Renewable Energy Efficiency and Energy Performance of Buildings Directives. But energy security also refers to the electricity sector itself, where security of supply requires us to develop a more integrated approach based on common methods and rules, as well as regional cooperation.  Last, but not least, energy poverty: EU legislation clearly assigns responsibility for protecting vulnerable consumers and addressing energy poverty to Member States. However, the Commission has been taking action to assist Member States to meet their obligations under EU law by identifying best practices and supporting the exchange of information on how to alleviate energy poverty in the most cost effective way. As announced in the Consumer Communication, the Commission will further consider how to improve the EU-wide data collection and monitoring of energy poverty.  Finally, let me stress one more time that the Commission is putting a lot of effort into strengthening the frameworks and concrete projects to enhance the EU’s energy security, in full consistency with the priorities identified by the Energy Union strategy. We welcome the support of the European Parliament for our work in this area; this is crucial in order to ensure a swift implementation of the Energy Union strategy. Thank you very much.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. - The Commission continues to include in its objectives the increase of renewable energies, the abatement of emissions, security of supply. Yet in fact, it continues to support fossil sources, such as gas, with a nod to that obtained in the US with fracking, or even oil, when not nuclear. Meanwhile, over 50 million European citizens live in conditions of energy poverty at a level that requires interventions to safeguard their health. Furthermore, many Member States are far from the targets set for renewable energies, which would instead guarantee a secure and autonomous supply. I therefore repeat what I have already argued in the past, namely the fact that it is essential to achieve a rapid abandonment of dependence on fossil sources, to facilitate widespread self-production and energy self-sufficiency based precisely on renewables. The transition phase must be rapid and supported by research, innovation and an effective and effective use of all European funds available to increase energy efficiency and the production of energy from renewable sources.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - The geostrategic dimension of security of energy supply cannot make us lose sight of the drama of more than 50,000,000 Europeans affected by energy poverty. 60% of deaths in home fires are attributed to energy poverty. Rosa died early Monday in Reus (Tarragona) when her mattress caught fire. The 81-year-old woman had been without light for two months, she lit up with the candles that caused the fire. How many deaths must there be for the Commission to adopt urgent measures in the face of this drama? A European framework for the fight against energy poverty is a priority, with the promotion of reduced tariffs and the revision of taxes and billing rates. The Commission should focus the efficiency and self-generation funds on citizens who are victims of energy poverty, while benefiting them with efficiency obligations, improvements in the retail market and promotion of self-consumption. A common definition is required, addressing data normalization, and gathering best practices. Ultimately, no one should have to choose between heating or cooling and food or medicine, much less pay with their own life. For all this, we urge the Commission to urgently adopt the appropriate measures.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I am very pleased that the European Commission is once again highlighting the issue of security of supply in the field of energy. I don’t think the importance of the topic can be overemphasized. We MEPs know exactly what it is like when energy supply is disrupted or systems that were previously considered reliable suddenly fail due to a shortage of supply. A reliable energy supply is a precondition for all other economic activities. A predictable, stable and affordable electricity and gas supply is needed for the safety of economic and residential consumers. EU integration is a unique and irreplaceable opportunity for European Member States. By interconnecting and coordinating their existing self-sufficient energy networks, Member States may be able to operate a much more efficient and cost-effective system. Naturally, as Energy Union integration progresses, energy planning will become increasingly detached from the level of the Member States and rise to higher, regional and EU levels. I fundamentally welcome this integration, but at the same time it is very important that, in the process, we do not forget one of the European Union's greatest competitive advantages, the strength of the diversity of different nations. I believe that defining national energy mixes at Member State level is a feature that, while encouraging coordination, is at the same time strengthening everyone. It is important for each Member State to be able to determine what it will build its energy system for.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to thank all colleagues who have stayed here so far - especially the services.I wish you a good night's sleep.Sleep well.(The sitting was closed at 10.45 p. M.)
